514	""
514	CHAPTER ONE
514	""
514	PLAYING PILGRIMS
514	""
514	"""Christmas won't be Christmas without any presents,"" grumbled Jo, lying"
514	on the rug.
514	""
514	"""It's so dreadful to be poor!"" sighed Meg, looking down at her old"
514	dress.
514	""
514	"""I don't think it's fair for some girls to have plenty of pretty"
514	"things, and other girls nothing at all,"" added little Amy, with an"
514	injured sniff.
514	""
514	"""We've got Father and Mother, and each other,"" said Beth contentedly"
514	from her corner.
514	""
514	The four young faces on which the firelight shone brightened at the
514	"cheerful words, but darkened again as Jo said sadly, ""We haven't got"
514	"Father, and shall not have him for a long time."" She didn't say"
514	"""perhaps never,"" but each silently added it, thinking of Father far"
514	away, where the fighting was.
514	""
514	"Nobody spoke for a minute; then Meg said in an altered tone, ""You know"
514	the reason Mother proposed not having any presents this Christmas was
514	because it is going to be a hard winter for everyone; and she thinks we
514	ought not to spend money for pleasure, when our men are suffering so in
514	the army.  We can't do much, but we can make our little sacrifices, and
514	"ought to do it gladly.  But I am afraid I don't,"" and Meg shook her"
514	head, as she thought regretfully of all the pretty things she wanted.
514	""
514	"""But I don't think the little we should spend would do any good.  We've"
514	each got a dollar, and the army wouldn't be much helped by our giving
514	that.  I agree not to expect anything from Mother or you, but I do want
514	"to buy _Undine and Sintran_ for myself.  I've wanted it so long,"" said"
514	Jo, who was a bookworm.
514	""
514	"""I planned to spend mine in new music,"" said Beth, with a little sigh,"
514	which no one heard but the hearth brush and kettle-holder.
514	""
514	"""I shall get a nice box of Faber's drawing pencils; I really need"
514	"them,"" said Amy decidedly."
514	""
514	"""Mother didn't say anything about our money, and she won't wish us to"
514	give up everything.  Let's each buy what we want, and have a little
514	"fun; I'm sure we work hard enough to earn it,"" cried Jo, examining the"
514	heels of her shoes in a gentlemanly manner.
514	""
514	"""I know I do--teaching those tiresome children nearly all day, when I'm"
514	"longing to enjoy myself at home,"" began Meg, in the complaining tone"
514	again.
514	""
514	"""You don't have half such a hard time as I do,"" said Jo. ""How would you"
514	like to be shut up for hours with a nervous, fussy old lady, who keeps
514	you trotting, is never satisfied, and worries you till you're ready to
514	"fly out the window or cry?"""
514	""
514	"""It's naughty to fret, but I do think washing dishes and keeping things"
514	tidy is the worst work in the world.  It makes me cross, and my hands
514	"get so stiff, I can't practice well at all."" And Beth looked at her"
514	rough hands with a sigh that any one could hear that time.
514	""
514	"""I don't believe any of you suffer as I do,"" cried Amy, ""for you don't"
514	have to go to school with impertinent girls, who plague you if you
514	don't know your lessons, and laugh at your dresses, and label your
514	"father if he isn't rich, and insult you when your nose isn't nice."""
514	""
514	"""If you mean libel, I'd say so, and not talk about labels, as if Papa"
514	"was a pickle bottle,"" advised Jo, laughing."
514	""
514	"""I know what I mean, and you needn't be statirical about it. It's"
514	"proper to use good words, and improve your vocabilary,"" returned Amy,"
514	with dignity.
514	""
514	"""Don't peck at one another, children.  Don't you wish we had the money"
514	Papa lost when we were little, Jo?  Dear me! How happy and good we'd
514	"be, if we had no worries!"" said Meg, who could remember better times."
514	""
514	"""You said the other day you thought we were a deal happier than the"
514	King children, for they were fighting and fretting all the time, in
514	"spite of their money."""
514	""
514	"""So I did, Beth.  Well, I think we are.  For though we do have to work,"
514	"we make fun of ourselves, and are a pretty jolly set, as Jo would say."""
514	""
514	"""Jo does use such slang words!"" observed Amy, with a reproving look at"
514	the long figure stretched on the rug.
514	""
514	Jo immediately sat up, put her hands in her pockets, and began to
514	whistle.
514	""
514	"""Don't, Jo.  It's so boyish!"""
514	""
514	"""That's why I do it."""
514	""
514	"""I detest rude, unladylike girls!"""
514	""
514	"""I hate affected, niminy-piminy chits!"""
514	""
514	"""Birds in their little nests agree,"" sang Beth, the peacemaker, with"
514	such a funny face that both sharp voices softened to a laugh, and the
514	"""pecking"" ended for that time."
514	""
514	"""Really, girls, you are both to be blamed,"" said Meg, beginning to"
514	"lecture in her elder-sisterly fashion. ""You are old enough to leave off"
514	boyish tricks, and to behave better, Josephine.  It didn't matter so
514	much when you were a little girl, but now you are so tall, and turn up
514	"your hair, you should remember that you are a young lady."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not!   And if turning up my hair makes me one, I'll wear it in two"
514	"tails till I'm twenty,"" cried Jo, pulling off her net, and shaking down"
514	"a chestnut mane.  ""I hate to think I've got to grow up, and be Miss"
514	March, and wear long gowns, and look as prim as a China Aster!  It's
514	bad enough to be a girl, anyway, when I like boy's games and work and
514	manners!  I can't get over my disappointment in not being a boy.  And
514	it's worse than ever now, for I'm dying to go and fight with Papa. And
514	"I can only stay home and knit, like a poky old woman!"""
514	""
514	And Jo shook the blue army sock till the needles rattled like
514	castanets, and her ball bounded across the room.
514	""
514	"""Poor Jo!  It's too bad, but it can't be helped.  So you must try to be"
514	contented with making your name boyish, and playing brother to us
514	"girls,"" said Beth, stroking the rough head with a hand that all the"
514	dish washing and dusting in the world could not make ungentle in its
514	touch.
514	""
514	"""As for you, Amy,"" continued Meg, ""you are altogether too particular"
514	and prim.  Your airs are funny now, but you'll grow up an affected
514	little goose, if you don't take care. I like your nice manners and
514	refined ways of speaking, when you don't try to be elegant.  But your
514	"absurd words are as bad as Jo's slang."""
514	""
514	"""If Jo is a tomboy and Amy a goose, what am I, please?"" asked Beth,"
514	ready to share the lecture.
514	""
514	"""You're a dear, and nothing else,"" answered Meg warmly, and no one"
514	contradicted her, for the 'Mouse' was the pet of the family.
514	""
514	As young readers like to know 'how people look', we will take this
514	moment to give them a little sketch of the four sisters, who sat
514	knitting away in the twilight, while the December snow fell quietly
514	without, and the fire crackled cheerfully within.  It was a comfortable
514	room, though the carpet was faded and the furniture very plain, for a
514	good picture or two hung on the walls, books filled the recesses,
514	chrysanthemums and Christmas roses bloomed in the windows, and a
514	pleasant atmosphere of home peace pervaded it.
514	""
514	Margaret, the eldest of the four, was sixteen, and very pretty, being
514	plump and fair, with large eyes, plenty of soft brown hair, a sweet
514	mouth, and white hands, of which she was rather vain. Fifteen-year-old
514	Jo was very tall, thin, and brown, and reminded one of a colt, for she
514	never seemed to know what to do with her long limbs, which were very
514	much in her way.  She had a decided mouth, a comical nose, and sharp,
514	gray eyes, which appeared to see everything, and were by turns fierce,
514	funny, or thoughtful.  Her long, thick hair was her one beauty, but it
514	was usually bundled into a net, to be out of her way.  Round shoulders
514	had Jo, big hands and feet, a flyaway look to her clothes, and the
514	uncomfortable appearance of a girl who was rapidly shooting up into a
514	woman and didn't like it. Elizabeth, or Beth, as everyone called her,
514	was a rosy, smooth-haired, bright-eyed girl of thirteen, with a shy
514	manner, a timid voice, and a peaceful expression which was seldom
514	disturbed.  Her father called her 'Little Miss Tranquility', and the
514	name suited her excellently, for she seemed to live in a happy world of
514	her own, only venturing out to meet the few whom she trusted and loved.
514	Amy, though the youngest, was a most important person, in her own
514	opinion at least.  A regular snow maiden, with blue eyes, and yellow
514	hair curling on her shoulders, pale and slender, and always carrying
514	herself like a young lady mindful of her manners.  What the characters
514	of the four sisters were we will leave to be found out.
514	""
514	The clock struck six and, having swept up the hearth, Beth put a pair
514	of slippers down to warm.  Somehow the sight of the old shoes had a
514	good effect upon the girls, for Mother was coming, and everyone
514	brightened to welcome her.  Meg stopped lecturing, and lighted the
514	lamp, Amy got out of the easy chair without being asked, and Jo forgot
514	how tired she was as she sat up to hold the slippers nearer to the
514	blaze.
514	""
514	"""They are quite worn out.  Marmee must have a new pair."""
514	""
514	"""I thought I'd get her some with my dollar,"" said Beth."
514	""
514	"""No, I shall!"" cried Amy."
514	""
514	"""I'm the oldest,"" began Meg, but Jo cut in with a decided, ""I'm the man"
514	of the family now Papa is away, and I shall provide the slippers, for
514	"he told me to take special care of Mother while he was gone."""
514	""
514	"""I'll tell you what we'll do,"" said Beth, ""let's each get her something"
514	"for Christmas, and not get anything for ourselves."""
514	""
514	"""That's like you, dear!  What will we get?"" exclaimed Jo."
514	""
514	Everyone thought soberly for a minute, then Meg announced, as if the
514	"idea was suggested by the sight of her own pretty hands, ""I shall give"
514	"her a nice pair of gloves."""
514	""
514	"""Army shoes, best to be had,"" cried Jo."
514	""
514	"""Some handkerchiefs, all hemmed,"" said Beth."
514	""
514	"""I'll get a little bottle of cologne.  She likes it, and it won't cost"
514	"much, so I'll have some left to buy my pencils,"" added Amy."
514	""
514	"""How will we give the things?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""Put them on the table, and bring her in and see her open the bundles."
514	"Don't you remember how we used to do on our birthdays?"" answered Jo."
514	""
514	"""I used to be so frightened when it was my turn to sit in the chair"
514	with the crown on, and see you all come marching round to give the
514	presents, with a kiss.  I liked the things and the kisses, but it was
514	"dreadful to have you sit looking at me while I opened the bundles,"""
514	said Beth, who was toasting her face and the bread for tea at the same
514	time.
514	""
514	"""Let Marmee think we are getting things for ourselves, and then"
514	surprise her.  We must go shopping tomorrow afternoon, Meg. There is so
514	"much to do about the play for Christmas night,"" said Jo, marching up"
514	and down, with her hands behind her back, and her nose in the air.
514	""
514	"""I don't mean to act any more after this time.  I'm getting too old for"
514	"such things,"" observed Meg, who was as much a child as ever about"
514	'dressing-up' frolics.
514	""
514	"""You won't stop, I know, as long as you can trail round in a white gown"
514	with your hair down, and wear gold-paper jewelry. You are the best
514	actress we've got, and there'll be an end of everything if you quit the
514	"boards,"" said Jo.  ""We ought to rehearse tonight.  Come here, Amy, and"
514	"do the fainting scene, for you are as stiff as a poker in that."""
514	""
514	"""I can't help it.  I never saw anyone faint, and I don't choose to make"
514	myself all black and blue, tumbling flat as you do.  If I can go down
514	easily, I'll drop.  If I can't, I shall fall into a chair and be
514	"graceful.  I don't care if Hugo does come at me with a pistol,"""
514	returned Amy, who was not gifted with dramatic power, but was chosen
514	because she was small enough to be borne out shrieking by the villain
514	of the piece.
514	""
514	"""Do it this way.  Clasp your hands so, and stagger across the room,"
514	"crying frantically, 'Roderigo! Save me! Save me!'"" and away went Jo,"
514	with a melodramatic scream which was truly thrilling.
514	""
514	Amy followed, but she poked her hands out stiffly before her, and
514	"jerked herself along as if she went by machinery, and her ""Ow!"" was"
514	more suggestive of pins being run into her than of fear and anguish.
514	Jo gave a despairing groan, and Meg laughed outright, while Beth let
514	"her bread burn as she watched the fun with interest. ""It's no use!  Do"
514	the best you can when the time comes, and if the audience laughs, don't
514	"blame me.  Come on, Meg."""
514	""
514	Then things went smoothly, for Don Pedro defied the world in a speech
514	of two pages without a single break.  Hagar, the witch, chanted an
514	awful incantation over her kettleful of simmering toads, with weird
514	effect.  Roderigo rent his chains asunder manfully, and Hugo died in
514	"agonies of remorse and arsenic, with a wild, ""Ha! Ha!"""
514	""
514	"""It's the best we've had yet,"" said Meg, as the dead villain sat up and"
514	rubbed his elbows.
514	""
514	"""I don't see how you can write and act such splendid things, Jo."
514	"You're a regular Shakespeare!"" exclaimed Beth, who firmly believed that"
514	her sisters were gifted with wonderful genius in all things.
514	""
514	"""Not quite,"" replied Jo modestly.  ""I do think _The Witches Curse, an"
514	Operatic Tragedy_ is rather a nice thing, but I'd like to try
514	_Macbeth_, if we only had a trapdoor for Banquo.  I always wanted to do
514	"the killing part.  'Is that a dagger that I see before me?"" muttered"
514	Jo, rolling her eyes and clutching at the air, as she had seen a famous
514	tragedian do.
514	""
514	"""No, it's the toasting fork, with Mother's shoe on it instead of the"
514	"bread.  Beth's stage-struck!"" cried Meg, and the rehearsal ended in a"
514	general burst of laughter.
514	""
514	"""Glad to find you so merry, my girls,"" said a cheery voice at the door,"
514	and actors and audience turned to welcome a tall, motherly lady with a
514	'can I help you' look about her which was truly delightful. She was not
514	elegantly dressed, but a noble-looking woman, and the girls thought the
514	gray cloak and unfashionable bonnet covered the most splendid mother in
514	the world.
514	""
514	"""Well, dearies, how have you got on today?  There was so much to do,"
514	getting the boxes ready to go tomorrow, that I didn't come home to
514	dinner.  Has anyone called, Beth?  How is your cold, Meg?  Jo, you look
514	"tired to death.  Come and kiss me, baby."""
514	""
514	While making these maternal inquiries Mrs. March got her wet things
514	off, her warm slippers on, and sitting down in the easy chair, drew Amy
514	to her lap, preparing to enjoy the happiest hour of her busy day.  The
514	girls flew about, trying to make things comfortable, each in her own
514	way.  Meg arranged the tea table, Jo brought wood and set chairs,
514	dropping, over-turning, and clattering everything she touched.  Beth
514	trotted to and fro between parlor kitchen, quiet and busy, while Amy
514	gave directions to everyone, as she sat with her hands folded.
514	""
514	As they gathered about the table, Mrs. March said, with a particularly
514	"happy face, ""I've got a treat for you after supper."""
514	""
514	A quick, bright smile went round like a streak of sunshine. Beth
514	clapped her hands, regardless of the biscuit she held, and Jo tossed up
514	"her napkin, crying, ""A letter!  A letter!  Three cheers for Father!"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, a nice long letter.  He is well, and thinks he shall get through"
514	the cold season better than we feared.  He sends all sorts of loving
514	"wishes for Christmas, and an especial message to you girls,"" said Mrs."
514	March, patting her pocket as if she had got a treasure there.
514	""
514	"""Hurry and get done!  Don't stop to quirk your little finger and simper"
514	"over your plate, Amy,"" cried Jo, choking on her tea and dropping her"
514	bread, butter side down, on the carpet in her haste to get at the treat.
514	""
514	Beth ate no more, but crept away to sit in her shadowy corner and brood
514	over the delight to come, till the others were ready.
514	""
514	"""I think it was so splendid in Father to go as chaplain when he was too"
514	"old to be drafted, and not strong enough for a soldier,"" said Meg"
514	warmly.
514	""
514	"""Don't I wish I could go as a drummer, a vivan--what's its name?  Or a"
514	"nurse, so I could be near him and help him,"" exclaimed Jo, with a groan."
514	""
514	"""It must be very disagreeable to sleep in a tent, and eat all sorts of"
514	"bad-tasting things, and drink out of a tin mug,"" sighed Amy."
514	""
514	"""When will he come home, Marmee?"" asked Beth, with a little quiver in"
514	her voice.
514	""
514	"""Not for many months, dear, unless he is sick.  He will stay and do his"
514	work faithfully as long as he can, and we won't ask for him back a
514	"minute sooner than he can be spared.  Now come and hear the letter."""
514	""
514	They all drew to the fire, Mother in the big chair with Beth at her
514	feet, Meg and Amy perched on either arm of the chair, and Jo leaning on
514	the back, where no one would see any sign of emotion if the letter
514	should happen to be touching.  Very few letters were written in those
514	hard times that were not touching, especially those which fathers sent
514	home.  In this one little was said of the hardships endured, the
514	dangers faced, or the homesickness conquered. It was a cheerful,
514	hopeful letter, full of lively descriptions of camp life, marches, and
514	military news, and only at the end did the writer's heart over-flow
514	with fatherly love and longing for the little girls at home.
514	""
514	"""Give them all of my dear love and a kiss.  Tell them I think of them"
514	by day, pray for them by night, and find my best comfort in their
514	affection at all times.  A year seems very long to wait before I see
514	them, but remind them that while we wait we may all work, so that these
514	hard days need not be wasted.  I know they will remember all I said to
514	them, that they will be loving children to you, will do their duty
514	faithfully, fight their bosom enemies bravely, and conquer themselves
514	so beautifully that when I come back to them I may be fonder and
514	"prouder than ever of my little women."" Everybody sniffed when they came"
514	to that part.  Jo wasn't ashamed of the great tear that dropped off the
514	end of her nose, and Amy never minded the rumpling of her curls as she
514	"hid her face on her mother's shoulder and sobbed out, ""I am a selfish"
514	girl!  But I'll truly try to be better, so he mayn't be disappointed in
514	"me by-and-by."""
514	""
514	"""We all will,"" cried Meg.  ""I think too much of my looks and hate to"
514	"work, but won't any more, if I can help it."""
514	""
514	"""I'll try and be what he loves to call me, 'a little woman' and not be"
514	rough and wild, but do my duty here instead of wanting to be somewhere
514	"else,"" said Jo, thinking that keeping her temper at home was a much"
514	harder task than facing a rebel or two down South.
514	""
514	Beth said nothing, but wiped away her tears with the blue army sock and
514	began to knit with all her might, losing no time in doing the duty that
514	lay nearest her, while she resolved in her quiet little soul to be all
514	that Father hoped to find her when the year brought round the happy
514	coming home.
514	""
514	Mrs. March broke the silence that followed Jo's words, by saying in her
514	"cheery voice, ""Do you remember how you used to play Pilgrims Progress"
514	when you were little things?  Nothing delighted you more than to have
514	me tie my piece bags on your backs for burdens, give you hats and
514	sticks and rolls of paper, and let you travel through the house from
514	the cellar, which was the City of Destruction, up, up, to the housetop,
514	where you had all the lovely things you could collect to make a
514	"Celestial City."""
514	""
514	"""What fun it was, especially going by the lions, fighting Apollyon, and"
514	"passing through the valley where the hob-goblins were,"" said Jo."
514	""
514	"""I liked the place where the bundles fell off and tumbled downstairs,"""
514	said Meg.
514	""
514	"""I don't remember much about it, except that I was afraid of the cellar"
514	and the dark entry, and always liked the cake and milk we had up at the
514	top.  If I wasn't too old for such things, I'd rather like to play it
514	"over again,"" said Amy, who began to talk of renouncing childish things"
514	at the mature age of twelve.
514	""
514	"""We never are too old for this, my dear, because it is a play we are"
514	playing all the time in one way or another.  Our burdens are here, our
514	road is before us, and the longing for goodness and happiness is the
514	guide that leads us through many troubles and mistakes to the peace
514	which is a true Celestial City.  Now, my little pilgrims, suppose you
514	begin again, not in play, but in earnest, and see how far on you can
514	"get before Father comes home."""
514	""
514	"""Really, Mother?  Where are our bundles?"" asked Amy, who was a very"
514	literal young lady.
514	""
514	"""Each of you told what your burden was just now, except Beth. I rather"
514	"think she hasn't got any,"" said her mother."
514	""
514	"""Yes, I have.  Mine is dishes and dusters, and envying girls with nice"
514	"pianos, and being afraid of people."""
514	""
514	Beth's bundle was such a funny one that everybody wanted to laugh, but
514	nobody did, for it would have hurt her feelings very much.
514	""
514	"""Let us do it,"" said Meg thoughtfully.  ""It is only another name for"
514	trying to be good, and the story may help us, for though we do want to
514	"be good, it's hard work and we forget, and don't do our best."""
514	""
514	"""We were in the Slough of Despond tonight, and Mother came and pulled"
514	us out as Help did in the book.  We ought to have our roll of
514	"directions, like Christian.  What shall we do about that?"" asked Jo,"
514	delighted with the fancy which lent a little romance to the very dull
514	task of doing her duty.
514	""
514	"""Look under your pillows Christmas morning, and you will find your"
514	"guidebook,"" replied Mrs. March."
514	""
514	They talked over the new plan while old Hannah cleared the table, then
514	out came the four little work baskets, and the needles flew as the
514	girls made sheets for Aunt March.  It was uninteresting sewing, but
514	tonight no one grumbled.  They adopted Jo's plan of dividing the long
514	seams into four parts, and calling the quarters Europe, Asia, Africa,
514	and America, and in that way got on capitally, especially when they
514	talked about the different countries as they stitched their way through
514	them.
514	""
514	At nine they stopped work, and sang, as usual, before they went to bed.
514	No one but Beth could get much music out of the old piano, but she had
514	a way of softly touching the yellow keys and making a pleasant
514	accompaniment to the simple songs they sang.  Meg had a voice like a
514	flute, and she and her mother led the little choir.  Amy chirped like a
514	cricket, and Jo wandered through the airs at her own sweet will, always
514	coming out at the wrong place with a croak or a quaver that spoiled the
514	most pensive tune.  They had always done this from the time they could
514	lisp...
514	""
514	    Crinkle, crinkle, 'ittle 'tar,
514	""
514	and it had become a household custom, for the mother was a born singer.
514	The first sound in the morning was her voice as she went about the
514	house singing like a lark, and the last sound at night was the same
514	cheery sound, for the girls never grew too old for that familiar
514	lullaby.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWO
514	""
514	A MERRY CHRISTMAS
514	""
514	Jo was the first to wake in the gray dawn of Christmas morning. No
514	stockings hung at the fireplace, and for a moment she felt as much
514	disappointed as she did long ago, when her little sock fell down
514	because it was crammed so full of goodies.  Then she remembered her
514	mother's promise and, slipping her hand under her pillow, drew out a
514	little crimson-covered book.  She knew it very well, for it was that
514	beautiful old story of the best life ever lived, and Jo felt that it
514	was a true guidebook for any pilgrim going on a long journey.  She woke
514	"Meg with a ""Merry Christmas,"" and bade her see what was under her"
514	pillow.  A green-covered book appeared, with the same picture inside,
514	and a few words written by their mother, which made their one present
514	very precious in their eyes.  Presently Beth and Amy woke to rummage
514	and find their little books also, one dove-colored, the other blue, and
514	all sat looking at and talking about them, while the east grew rosy
514	with the coming day.
514	""
514	In spite of her small vanities, Margaret had a sweet and pious nature,
514	which unconsciously influenced her sisters, especially Jo, who loved
514	her very tenderly, and obeyed her because her advice was so gently
514	given.
514	""
514	"""Girls,"" said Meg seriously, looking from the tumbled head beside her"
514	"to the two little night-capped ones in the room beyond, ""Mother wants"
514	us to read and love and mind these books, and we must begin at once.
514	We used to be faithful about it, but since Father went away and all
514	this war trouble unsettled us, we have neglected many things.  You can
514	do as you please, but I shall keep my book on the table here and read a
514	little every morning as soon as I wake, for I know it will do me good
514	"and help me through the day."""
514	""
514	Then she opened her new book and began to read.  Jo put her arm round
514	her and, leaning cheek to cheek, read also, with the quiet expression
514	so seldom seen on her restless face.
514	""
514	"""How good Meg is!  Come, Amy, let's do as they do.  I'll help you with"
514	"the hard words, and they'll explain things if we don't understand,"""
514	whispered Beth, very much impressed by the pretty books and her
514	sisters' example.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad mine is blue,"" said Amy.  and then the rooms were very still"
514	while the pages were softly turned, and the winter sunshine crept in to
514	touch the bright heads and serious faces with a Christmas greeting.
514	""
514	"""Where is Mother?"" asked Meg, as she and Jo ran down to thank her for"
514	their gifts, half an hour later.
514	""
514	"""Goodness only knows.  Some poor creeter came a-beggin', and your ma"
514	went straight off to see what was needed.  There never was such a woman
514	"for givin' away vittles and drink, clothes and firin',"" replied Hannah,"
514	who had lived with the family since Meg was born, and was considered by
514	them all more as a friend than a servant.
514	""
514	"""She will be back soon, I think, so fry your cakes, and have everything"
514	"ready,"" said Meg, looking over the presents which were collected in a"
514	basket and kept under the sofa, ready to be produced at the proper
514	"time.  ""Why, where is Amy's bottle of cologne?"" she added, as the"
514	little flask did not appear.
514	""
514	"""She took it out a minute ago, and went off with it to put a ribbon on"
514	"it, or some such notion,"" replied Jo, dancing about the room to take"
514	the first stiffness off the new army slippers.
514	""
514	"""How nice my handkerchiefs look, don't they?  Hannah washed and ironed"
514	"them for me, and I marked them all myself,"" said Beth, looking proudly"
514	at the somewhat uneven letters which had cost her such labor.
514	""
514	"""Bless the child!  She's gone and put 'Mother' on them instead of 'M."
514	"March'.  How funny!"" cried Jo, taking one up."
514	""
514	"""Isn't that right?  I thought it was better to do it so, because Meg's"
514	"initials are M.M., and I don't want anyone to use these but Marmee,"""
514	said Beth, looking troubled.
514	""
514	"""It's all right, dear, and a very pretty idea, quite sensible too, for"
514	"no one can ever mistake now.  It will please her very much, I know,"""
514	said Meg, with a frown for Jo and a smile for Beth.
514	""
514	"""There's Mother.  Hide the basket, quick!"" cried Jo, as a door slammed"
514	and steps sounded in the hall.
514	""
514	Amy came in hastily, and looked rather abashed when she saw her sisters
514	all waiting for her.
514	""
514	"""Where have you been, and what are you hiding behind you?"" asked Meg,"
514	surprised to see, by her hood and cloak, that lazy Amy had been out so
514	early.
514	""
514	"""Don't laugh at me, Jo!  I didn't mean anyone should know till the time"
514	came.  I only meant to change the little bottle for a big one, and I
514	gave all my money to get it, and I'm truly trying not to be selfish any
514	"more."""
514	""
514	As she spoke, Amy showed the handsome flask which replaced the cheap
514	one, and looked so earnest and humble in her little effort to forget
514	herself that Meg hugged her on the spot, and Jo pronounced her 'a
514	trump', while Beth ran to the window, and picked her finest rose to
514	ornament the stately bottle.
514	""
514	"""You see I felt ashamed of my present, after reading and talking about"
514	being good this morning, so I ran round the corner and changed it the
514	"minute I was up, and I'm so glad, for mine is the handsomest now."""
514	""
514	Another bang of the street door sent the basket under the sofa, and the
514	girls to the table, eager for breakfast.
514	""
514	"""Merry Christmas, Marmee!  Many of them!  Thank you for our books.  We"
514	"read some, and mean to every day,"" they all cried in chorus."
514	""
514	"""Merry Christmas, little daughters!  I'm glad you began at once, and"
514	hope you will keep on.  But I want to say one word before we sit down.
514	Not far away from here lies a poor woman with a little newborn baby.
514	Six children are huddled into one bed to keep from freezing, for they
514	have no fire.  There is nothing to eat over there, and the oldest boy
514	came to tell me they were suffering hunger and cold.  My girls, will
514	"you give them your breakfast as a Christmas present?"""
514	""
514	They were all unusually hungry, having waited nearly an hour, and for a
514	"minute no one spoke, only a minute, for Jo exclaimed impetuously, ""I'm"
514	"so glad you came before we began!"""
514	""
514	"""May I go and help carry the things to the poor little children?"" asked"
514	Beth eagerly.
514	""
514	"""I shall take the cream and the muffings,"" added Amy, heroically giving"
514	up the article she most liked.
514	""
514	Meg was already covering the buckwheats, and piling the bread into one
514	big plate.
514	""
514	"""I thought you'd do it,"" said Mrs. March, smiling as if satisfied. ""You"
514	shall all go and help me, and when we come back we will have bread and
514	"milk for breakfast, and make it up at dinnertime."""
514	""
514	They were soon ready, and the procession set out.  Fortunately it was
514	early, and they went through back streets, so few people saw them, and
514	no one laughed at the queer party.
514	""
514	A poor, bare, miserable room it was, with broken windows, no fire,
514	ragged bedclothes, a sick mother, wailing baby, and a group of pale,
514	hungry children cuddled under one old quilt, trying to keep warm.
514	""
514	How the big eyes stared and the blue lips smiled as the girls went in.
514	""
514	"""Ach, mein Gott!  It is good angels come to us!"" said the poor woman,"
514	crying for joy.
514	""
514	"""Funny angels in hoods and mittens,"" said Jo, and set them to laughing."
514	""
514	In a few minutes it really did seem as if kind spirits had been at work
514	there.  Hannah, who had carried wood, made a fire, and stopped up the
514	broken panes with old hats and her own cloak.  Mrs. March gave the
514	mother tea and gruel, and comforted her with promises of help, while
514	she dressed the little baby as tenderly as if it had been her own.  The
514	girls meantime spread the table, set the children round the fire, and
514	fed them like so many hungry birds, laughing, talking, and trying to
514	understand the funny broken English.
514	""
514	"""Das ist gut!""  ""Die Engel-kinder!"" cried the poor things as they ate"
514	and warmed their purple hands at the comfortable blaze. The girls had
514	never been called angel children before, and thought it very agreeable,
514	especially Jo, who had been considered a 'Sancho' ever since she was
514	born.  That was a very happy breakfast, though they didn't get any of
514	it.  And when they went away, leaving comfort behind, I think there
514	were not in all the city four merrier people than the hungry little
514	girls who gave away their breakfasts and contented themselves with
514	bread and milk on Christmas morning.
514	""
514	"""That's loving our neighbor better than ourselves, and I like it,"" said"
514	Meg, as they set out their presents while their mother was upstairs
514	collecting clothes for the poor Hummels.
514	""
514	Not a very splendid show, but there was a great deal of love done up in
514	the few little bundles, and the tall vase of red roses, white
514	chrysanthemums, and trailing vines, which stood in the middle, gave
514	quite an elegant air to the table.
514	""
514	"""She's coming!  Strike up, Beth!  Open the door, Amy!  Three cheers for"
514	"Marmee!"" cried Jo, prancing about while Meg went to conduct Mother to"
514	the seat of honor.
514	""
514	Beth played her gayest march, Amy threw open the door, and Meg enacted
514	escort with great dignity.  Mrs. March was both surprised and touched,
514	and smiled with her eyes full as she examined her presents and read the
514	little notes which accompanied them.  The slippers went on at once, a
514	new handkerchief was slipped into her pocket, well scented with Amy's
514	cologne, the rose was fastened in her bosom, and the nice gloves were
514	pronounced a perfect fit.
514	""
514	There was a good deal of laughing and kissing and explaining, in the
514	simple, loving fashion which makes these home festivals so pleasant at
514	the time, so sweet to remember long afterward, and then all fell to
514	work.
514	""
514	The morning charities and ceremonies took so much time that the rest of
514	the day was devoted to preparations for the evening festivities.  Being
514	still too young to go often to the theater, and not rich enough to
514	afford any great outlay for private performances, the girls put their
514	wits to work, and necessity being the mother of invention, made
514	whatever they needed.  Very clever were some of their productions,
514	pasteboard guitars, antique lamps made of old-fashioned butter boats
514	covered with silver paper, gorgeous robes of old cotton, glittering
514	with tin spangles from a pickle factory, and armor covered with the
514	same useful diamond shaped bits left in sheets when the lids of
514	preserve pots were cut out.  The big chamber was the scene of many
514	innocent revels.
514	""
514	No gentleman were admitted, so Jo played male parts to her heart's
514	content and took immense satisfaction in a pair of russet leather boots
514	given her by a friend, who knew a lady who knew an actor.  These boots,
514	an old foil, and a slashed doublet once used by an artist for some
514	picture, were Jo's chief treasures and appeared on all occasions.  The
514	smallness of the company made it necessary for the two principal actors
514	to take several parts apiece, and they certainly deserved some credit
514	for the hard work they did in learning three or four different parts,
514	whisking in and out of various costumes, and managing the stage
514	besides.  It was excellent drill for their memories, a harmless
514	amusement, and employed many hours which otherwise would have been
514	idle, lonely, or spent in less profitable society.
514	""
514	On Christmas night, a dozen girls piled onto the bed which was the
514	dress circle, and sat before the blue and yellow chintz curtains in a
514	most flattering state of expectancy.  There was a good deal of rustling
514	and whispering behind the curtain, a trifle of lamp smoke, and an
514	occasional giggle from Amy, who was apt to get hysterical in the
514	excitement of the moment.  Presently a bell sounded, the curtains flew
514	apart, and the _operatic tragedy_ began.
514	""
514	"""A gloomy wood,"" according to the one playbill, was represented by a"
514	few shrubs in pots, green baize on the floor, and a cave in the
514	distance.  This cave was made with a clothes horse for a roof, bureaus
514	for walls, and in it was a small furnace in full blast, with a black
514	pot on it and an old witch bending over it.  The stage was dark and the
514	glow of the furnace had a fine effect, especially as real steam issued
514	from the kettle when the witch took off the cover.  A moment was
514	allowed for the first thrill to subside, then Hugo, the villain,
514	stalked in with a clanking sword at his side, a slouching hat, black
514	beard, mysterious cloak, and the boots.  After pacing to and fro in
514	much agitation, he struck his forehead, and burst out in a wild strain,
514	singing of his hatred for Roderigo, his love for Zara, and his pleasing
514	resolution to kill the one and win the other. The gruff tones of Hugo's
514	voice, with an occasional shout when his feelings overcame him, were
514	very impressive, and the audience applauded the moment he paused for
514	breath.  Bowing with the air of one accustomed to public praise, he
514	stole to the cavern and ordered Hagar to come forth with a commanding,
514	"""What ho, minion! I need thee!"""
514	""
514	Out came Meg, with gray horsehair hanging about her face, a red and
514	black robe, a staff, and cabalistic signs upon her cloak.  Hugo
514	demanded a potion to make Zara adore him, and one to destroy Roderigo.
514	Hagar, in a fine dramatic melody, promised both, and proceeded to call
514	up the spirit who would bring the love philter.
514	""
514	    Hither, hither, from thy home,
514	    Airy sprite, I bid thee come!
514	    Born of roses, fed on dew,
514	    Charms and potions canst thou brew?
514	    Bring me here, with elfin speed,
514	    The fragrant philter which I need.
514	    Make it sweet and swift and strong,
514	    Spirit, answer now my song!
514	""
514	A soft strain of music sounded, and then at the back of the cave
514	appeared a little figure in cloudy white, with glittering wings, golden
514	hair, and a garland of roses on its head.  Waving a wand, it sang...
514	""
514	    Hither I come,
514	    From my airy home,
514	    Afar in the silver moon.
514	    Take the magic spell,
514	    And use it well,
514	    Or its power will vanish soon!
514	""
514	And dropping a small, gilded bottle at the witch's feet, the spirit
514	vanished.  Another chant from Hagar produced another apparition, not a
514	lovely one, for with a bang an ugly black imp appeared and, having
514	croaked a reply, tossed a dark bottle at Hugo and disappeared with a
514	mocking laugh.  Having warbled his thanks and put the potions in his
514	boots, Hugo departed, and Hagar informed the audience that as he had
514	killed a few of her friends in times past, she had cursed him, and
514	intends to thwart his plans, and be revenged on him.  Then the curtain
514	fell, and the audience reposed and ate candy while discussing the
514	merits of the play.
514	""
514	A good deal of hammering went on before the curtain rose again, but
514	when it became evident what a masterpiece of stage carpentery had been
514	got up, no one murmured at the delay.  It was truly superb. A tower
514	rose to the ceiling, halfway up appeared a window with a lamp burning
514	in it, and behind the white curtain appeared Zara in a lovely blue and
514	silver dress, waiting for Roderigo.  He came in gorgeous array, with
514	plumed cap, red cloak, chestnut lovelocks, a guitar, and the boots, of
514	course.  Kneeling at the foot of the tower, he sang a serenade in
514	melting tones.  Zara replied and, after a musical dialogue, consented
514	to fly.  Then came the grand effect of the play.  Roderigo produced a
514	rope ladder, with five steps to it, threw up one end, and invited Zara
514	to descend.  Timidly she crept from her lattice, put her hand on
514	"Roderigo's shoulder, and was about to leap gracefully down when ""Alas!"
514	"Alas for Zara!"" she forgot her train.  It caught in the window, the"
514	tower tottered, leaned forward, fell with a crash, and buried the
514	unhappy lovers in the ruins.
514	""
514	A universal shriek arose as the russet boots waved wildly from the
514	"wreck and a golden head emerged, exclaiming, ""I told you so!  I told"
514	"you so!""  With wonderful presence of mind, Don Pedro, the cruel sire,"
514	rushed in, dragged out his daughter, with a hasty aside...
514	""
514	"""Don't laugh!  Act as if it was all right!"" and, ordering Roderigo up,"
514	banished him from the kingdom with wrath and scorn. Though decidedly
514	shaken by the fall from the tower upon him, Roderigo defied the old
514	gentleman and refused to stir.  This dauntless example fired Zara.  She
514	also defied her sire, and he ordered them both to the deepest dungeons
514	of the castle.  A stout little retainer came in with chains and led
514	them away, looking very much frightened and evidently forgetting the
514	speech he ought to have made.
514	""
514	Act third was the castle hall, and here Hagar appeared, having come to
514	free the lovers and finish Hugo.  She hears him coming and hides, sees
514	him put the potions into two cups of wine and bid the timid little
514	"servant, ""Bear them to the captives in their cells, and tell them I"
514	"shall come anon.""  The servant takes Hugo aside to tell him something,"
514	and Hagar changes the cups for two others which are harmless.
514	Ferdinando, the 'minion', carries them away, and Hagar puts back the
514	cup which holds the poison meant for Roderigo. Hugo, getting thirsty
514	after a long warble, drinks it, loses his wits, and after a good deal
514	of clutching and stamping, falls flat and dies, while Hagar informs him
514	what she has done in a song of exquisite power and melody.
514	""
514	This was a truly thrilling scene, though some persons might have
514	thought that the sudden tumbling down of a quantity of long red hair
514	rather marred the effect of the villain's death.  He was called before
514	the curtain, and with great propriety appeared, leading Hagar, whose
514	singing was considered more wonderful than all the rest of the
514	performance put together.
514	""
514	Act fourth displayed the despairing Roderigo on the point of stabbing
514	himself because he has been told that Zara has deserted him. Just as
514	the dagger is at his heart, a lovely song is sung under his window,
514	informing him that Zara is true but in danger, and he can save her if
514	he will.  A key is thrown in, which unlocks the door, and in a spasm of
514	rapture he tears off his chains and rushes away to find and rescue his
514	lady love.
514	""
514	Act fifth opened with a stormy scene between Zara and Don Pedro. He
514	wishes her to go into a convent, but she won't hear of it, and after a
514	touching appeal, is about to faint when Roderigo dashes in and demands
514	her hand.  Don Pedro refuses, because he is not rich. They shout and
514	gesticulate tremendously but cannot agree, and Rodrigo is about to bear
514	away the exhausted Zara, when the timid servant enters with a letter
514	and a bag from Hagar, who has mysteriously disappeared.  The latter
514	informs the party that she bequeaths untold wealth to the young pair
514	and an awful doom to Don Pedro, if he doesn't make them happy.  The bag
514	is opened, and several quarts of tin money shower down upon the stage
514	till it is quite glorified with the glitter.  This entirely softens the
514	stern sire.  He consents without a murmur, all join in a joyful chorus,
514	and the curtain falls upon the lovers kneeling to receive Don Pedro's
514	blessing in attitudes of the most romantic grace.
514	""
514	Tumultuous applause followed but received an unexpected check, for the
514	cot bed, on which the dress circle was built, suddenly shut up and
514	extinguished the enthusiastic audience.  Roderigo and Don Pedro flew to
514	the rescue, and all were taken out unhurt, though many were speechless
514	with laughter.  The excitement had hardly subsided when Hannah
514	"appeared, with ""Mrs. March's compliments, and would the ladies walk"
514	"down to supper."""
514	""
514	This was a surprise even to the actors, and when they saw the table,
514	they looked at one another in rapturous amazement.  It was like Marmee
514	to get up a little treat for them, but anything so fine as this was
514	unheard of since the departed days of plenty.  There was ice cream,
514	actually two dishes of it, pink and white, and cake and fruit and
514	distracting French bonbons and, in the middle of the table, four great
514	bouquets of hot house flowers.
514	""
514	It quite took their breath away, and they stared first at the table and
514	then at their mother, who looked as if she enjoyed it immensely.
514	""
514	"""Is it fairies?"" asked Amy."
514	""
514	"""Santa Claus,"" said Beth."
514	""
514	"""Mother did it."" And Meg smiled her sweetest, in spite of her gray"
514	beard and white eyebrows.
514	""
514	"""Aunt March had a good fit and sent the supper,"" cried Jo, with a"
514	sudden inspiration.
514	""
514	"""All wrong.  Old Mr. Laurence sent it,"" replied Mrs. March."
514	""
514	"""The Laurence boy's grandfather! What in the world put such a thing"
514	"into his head?  We don't know him!"" exclaimed Meg."
514	""
514	"""Hannah told one of his servants about your breakfast party. He is an"
514	odd old gentleman, but that pleased him.  He knew my father years ago,
514	and he sent me a polite note this afternoon, saying he hoped I would
514	allow him to express his friendly feeling toward my children by sending
514	them a few trifles in honor of the day.  I could not refuse, and so you
514	have a little feast at night to make up for the bread-and-milk
514	"breakfast."""
514	""
514	"""That boy put it into his head, I know he did!  He's a capital fellow,"
514	and I wish we could get acquainted.  He looks as if he'd like to know
514	us but he's bashful, and Meg is so prim she won't let me speak to him
514	"when we pass,"" said Jo, as the plates went round, and the ice began to"
514	melt out of sight, with ohs and ahs of satisfaction.
514	""
514	"""You mean the people who live in the big house next door, don't you?"""
514	"asked one of the girls.  ""My mother knows old Mr. Laurence, but says"
514	he's very proud and doesn't like to mix with his neighbors. He keeps
514	his grandson shut up, when he isn't riding or walking with his tutor,
514	and makes him study very hard.  We invited him to our party, but he
514	didn't come.  Mother says he's very nice, though he never speaks to us
514	"girls."""
514	""
514	"""Our cat ran away once, and he brought her back, and we talked over the"
514	fence, and were getting on capitally, all about cricket, and so on,
514	when he saw Meg coming, and walked off.  I mean to know him some day,
514	"for he needs fun, I'm sure he does,"" said Jo decidedly."
514	""
514	"""I like his manners, and he looks like a little gentleman, so I've no"
514	objection to your knowing him, if a proper opportunity comes. He
514	brought the flowers himself, and I should have asked him in, if I had
514	been sure what was going on upstairs.  He looked so wistful as he went
514	"away, hearing the frolic and evidently having none of his own."""
514	""
514	"""It's a mercy you didn't, Mother!"" laughed Jo, looking at her boots."
514	"""But we'll have another play sometime that he can see.  Perhaps he'll"
514	"help act.  Wouldn't that be jolly?"""
514	""
514	"""I never had such a fine bouquet before!  How pretty it is!"" And Meg"
514	examined her flowers with great interest.
514	""
514	"""They are lovely.  But Beth's roses are sweeter to me,"" said Mrs."
514	March, smelling the half-dead posy in her belt.
514	""
514	"Beth nestled up to her, and whispered softly, ""I wish I could send my"
514	bunch to Father.  I'm afraid he isn't having such a merry Christmas as
514	"we are."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THREE
514	""
514	THE LAURENCE BOY
514	""
514	"""Jo!  Jo!  Where are you?"" cried Meg at the foot of the garret stairs."
514	""
514	"""Here!"" answered a husky voice from above, and, running up, Meg found"
514	her sister eating apples and crying over the Heir of Redclyffe, wrapped
514	up in a comforter on an old three-legged sofa by the sunny window.
514	This was Jo's favorite refuge, and here she loved to retire with half a
514	dozen russets and a nice book, to enjoy the quiet and the society of a
514	pet rat who lived near by and didn't mind her a particle.  As Meg
514	appeared, Scrabble whisked into his hole.  Jo shook the tears off her
514	cheeks and waited to hear the news.
514	""
514	"""Such fun!  Only see!  A regular note of invitation from Mrs. Gardiner"
514	"for tomorrow night!"" cried Meg, waving the precious paper and then"
514	proceeding to read it with girlish delight.
514	""
514	"""'Mrs. Gardiner would be happy to see Miss March and Miss Josephine at"
514	a little dance on New Year's Eve.' Marmee is willing we should go, now
514	"what shall we wear?"""
514	""
514	"""What's the use of asking that, when you know we shall wear our"
514	"poplins, because we haven't got anything else?"" answered Jo with her"
514	mouth full.
514	""
514	"""If I only had a silk!"" sighed Meg.  ""Mother says I may when I'm"
514	"eighteen perhaps, but two years is an everlasting time to wait."""
514	""
514	"""I'm sure our pops look like silk, and they are nice enough for us."
514	Yours is as good as new, but I forgot the burn and the tear in mine.
514	"Whatever shall I do?  The burn shows badly, and I can't take any out."""
514	""
514	"""You must sit still all you can and keep your back out of sight. The"
514	front is all right.  I shall have a new ribbon for my hair, and Marmee
514	will lend me her little pearl pin, and my new slippers are lovely, and
514	"my gloves will do, though they aren't as nice as I'd like."""
514	""
514	"""Mine are spoiled with lemonade, and I can't get any new ones, so I"
514	"shall have to go without,"" said Jo, who never troubled herself much"
514	about dress.
514	""
514	"""You must have gloves, or I won't go,"" cried Meg decidedly. ""Gloves are"
514	more important than anything else.  You can't dance without them, and
514	"if you don't I should be so mortified."""
514	""
514	"""Then I'll stay still.  I don't care much for company dancing. It's no"
514	"fun to go sailing round.  I like to fly about and cut capers."""
514	""
514	"""You can't ask Mother for new ones, they are so expensive, and you are"
514	so careless.  She said when you spoiled the others that she shouldn't
514	"get you any more this winter.  Can't you make them do?"""
514	""
514	"""I can hold them crumpled up in my hand, so no one will know how"
514	stained they are.  That's all I can do.  No!  I'll tell you how we can
514	"manage, each wear one good one and carry a bad one.  Don't you see?"""
514	""
514	"""Your hands are bigger than mine, and you will stretch my glove"
514	"dreadfully,"" began Meg, whose gloves were a tender point with her."
514	""
514	"""Then I'll go without.  I don't care what people say!"" cried Jo, taking"
514	up her book.
514	""
514	"""You may have it, you may!  Only don't stain it, and do behave nicely."
514	Don't put your hands behind you, or stare, or say 'Christopher
514	"Columbus!' will you?"""
514	""
514	"""Don't worry about me.  I'll be as prim as I can and not get into any"
514	scrapes, if I can help it.  Now go and answer your note, and let me
514	"finish this splendid story."""
514	""
514	So Meg went away to 'accept with thanks', look over her dress, and sing
514	blithely as she did up her one real lace frill, while Jo finished her
514	story, her four apples, and had a game of romps with Scrabble.
514	""
514	On New Year's Eve the parlor was deserted, for the two younger girls
514	played dressing maids and the two elder were absorbed in the
514	all-important business of 'getting ready for the party'.  Simple as the
514	toilets were, there was a great deal of running up and down, laughing
514	and talking, and at one time a strong smell of burned hair pervaded the
514	house.  Meg wanted a few curls about her face, and Jo undertook to
514	pinch the papered locks with a pair of hot tongs.
514	""
514	"""Ought they to smoke like that?"" asked Beth from her perch on the bed."
514	""
514	"""It's the dampness drying,"" replied Jo."
514	""
514	"""What a queer smell!  It's like burned feathers,"" observed Amy,"
514	smoothing her own pretty curls with a superior air.
514	""
514	"""There, now I'll take off the papers and you'll see a cloud of little"
514	"ringlets,"" said Jo, putting down the tongs."
514	""
514	She did take off the papers, but no cloud of ringlets appeared, for the
514	hair came with the papers, and the horrified hairdresser laid a row of
514	little scorched bundles on the bureau before her victim.
514	""
514	"""Oh, oh, oh! What have you done?  I'm spoiled!  I can't go!  My hair,"
514	"oh, my hair!"" wailed Meg, looking with despair at the uneven frizzle on"
514	her forehead.
514	""
514	"""Just my luck!  You shouldn't have asked me to do it.  I always spoil"
514	everything.  I'm so sorry, but the tongs were too hot, and so I've made
514	"a mess,"" groaned poor Jo, regarding the little black pancakes with"
514	tears of regret.
514	""
514	"""It isn't spoiled.  Just frizzle it, and tie your ribbon so the ends"
514	come on your forehead a bit, and it will look like the last fashion.
514	"I've seen many girls do it so,"" said Amy consolingly."
514	""
514	"""Serves me right for trying to be fine.  I wish I'd let my hair alone,"""
514	cried Meg petulantly.
514	""
514	"""So do I, it was so smooth and pretty.  But it will soon grow out"
514	"again,"" said Beth, coming to kiss and comfort the shorn sheep."
514	""
514	After various lesser mishaps, Meg was finished at last, and by the
514	united exertions of the entire family Jo's hair was got up and her
514	dress on.  They looked very well in their simple suits, Meg's in
514	silvery drab, with a blue velvet snood, lace frills, and the pearl pin.
514	Jo in maroon, with a stiff, gentlemanly linen collar, and a white
514	chrysanthemum or two for her only ornament. Each put on one nice light
514	"glove, and carried one soiled one, and all pronounced the effect ""quite"
514	"easy and fine"".  Meg's high-heeled slippers were very tight and hurt"
514	her, though she would not own it, and Jo's nineteen hairpins all seemed
514	stuck straight into her head, which was not exactly comfortable, but,
514	dear me, let us be elegant or die.
514	""
514	"""Have a good time, dearies!"" said Mrs. March, as the sisters went"
514	"daintily down the walk.  ""Don't eat much supper, and come away at"
514	"eleven when I send Hannah for you.""  As the gate clashed behind them, a"
514	voice cried from a window...
514	""
514	"""Girls, girls!  Have you you both got nice pocket handkerchiefs?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, yes, spandy nice, and Meg has cologne on hers,"" cried Jo, adding"
514	"with a laugh as they went on, ""I do believe Marmee would ask that if we"
514	"were all running away from an earthquake."""
514	""
514	"""It is one of her aristocratic tastes, and quite proper, for a real"
514	"lady is always known by neat boots, gloves, and handkerchief,"" replied"
514	Meg, who had a good many little 'aristocratic tastes' of her own.
514	""
514	"""Now don't forget to keep the bad breadth out of sight, Jo. Is my sash"
514	"right?  And does my hair look very bad?"" said Meg, as she turned from"
514	the glass in Mrs. Gardiner's dressing room after a prolonged prink.
514	""
514	"""I know I shall forget.  If you see me doing anything wrong, just"
514	"remind me by a wink, will you?"" returned Jo, giving her collar a twitch"
514	and her head a hasty brush.
514	""
514	"""No, winking isn't ladylike.  I'll lift my eyebrows if any thing is"
514	wrong, and nod if you are all right.  Now hold your shoulder straight,
514	and take short steps, and don't shake hands if you are introduced to
514	"anyone.  It isn't the thing."""
514	""
514	"""How do you learn all the proper ways?  I never can.  Isn't that music"
514	"gay?"""
514	""
514	Down they went, feeling a trifle timid, for they seldom went to
514	parties, and informal as this little gathering was, it was an event to
514	them.  Mrs. Gardiner, a stately old lady, greeted them kindly and
514	handed them over to the eldest of her six daughters. Meg knew Sallie
514	and was at her ease very soon, but Jo, who didn't care much for girls
514	or girlish gossip, stood about, with her back carefully against the
514	wall, and felt as much out of place as a colt in a flower garden.  Half
514	a dozen jovial lads were talking about skates in another part of the
514	room, and she longed to go and join them, for skating was one of the
514	joys of her life.  She telegraphed her wish to Meg, but the eyebrows
514	went up so alarmingly that she dared not stir.  No one came to talk to
514	her, and one by one the group dwindled away till she was left alone.
514	She could not roam about and amuse herself, for the burned breadth
514	would show, so she stared at people rather forlornly till the dancing
514	began.  Meg was asked at once, and the tight slippers tripped about so
514	briskly that none would have guessed the pain their wearer suffered
514	smilingly.  Jo saw a big red headed youth approaching her corner, and
514	fearing he meant to engage her, she slipped into a curtained recess,
514	intending to peep and enjoy herself in peace.  Unfortunately, another
514	bashful person had chosen the same refuge, for, as the curtain fell
514	behind her, she found herself face to face with the 'Laurence boy'.
514	""
514	"""Dear me, I didn't know anyone was here!"" stammered Jo, preparing to"
514	back out as speedily as she had bounced in.
514	""
514	But the boy laughed and said pleasantly, though he looked a little
514	"startled, ""Don't mind me, stay if you like."""
514	""
514	"""Shan't I disturb you?"""
514	""
514	"""Not a bit.  I only came here because I don't know many people and felt"
514	"rather strange at first, you know."""
514	""
514	"""So did I.  Don't go away, please, unless you'd rather."""
514	""
514	The boy sat down again and looked at his pumps, till Jo said, trying to
514	"be polite and easy, ""I think I've had the pleasure of seeing you"
514	"before.  You live near us, don't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Next door.""  And he looked up and laughed outright, for Jo's prim"
514	manner was rather funny when he remembered how they had chatted about
514	cricket when he brought the cat home.
514	""
514	That put Jo at her ease and she laughed too, as she said, in her
514	"heartiest way, ""We did have such a good time over your nice Christmas"
514	"present."""
514	""
514	"""Grandpa sent it."""
514	""
514	"""But you put it into his head, didn't you, now?"""
514	""
514	"""How is your cat, Miss March?"" asked the boy, trying to look sober"
514	while his black eyes shone with fun.
514	""
514	"""Nicely, thank you, Mr. Laurence.  But I am not Miss March, I'm only"
514	"Jo,"" returned the young lady."
514	""
514	"""I'm not Mr. Laurence, I'm only Laurie."""
514	""
514	"""Laurie Laurence, what an odd name."""
514	""
514	"""My first name is Theodore, but I don't like it, for the fellows called"
514	"me Dora, so I made them say Laurie instead."""
514	""
514	"""I hate my name, too, so sentimental!  I wish every one would say Jo"
514	"instead of Josephine.  How did you make the boys stop calling you Dora?"""
514	""
514	"""I thrashed 'em."""
514	""
514	"""I can't thrash Aunt March, so I suppose I shall have to bear it.""  And"
514	Jo resigned herself with a sigh.
514	""
514	"""Don't you like to dance, Miss Jo?"" asked Laurie, looking as if he"
514	thought the name suited her.
514	""
514	"""I like it well enough if there is plenty of room, and everyone is"
514	lively.  In a place like this I'm sure to upset something, tread on
514	people's toes, or do something dreadful, so I keep out of mischief and
514	"let Meg sail about.  Don't you dance?"""
514	""
514	"""Sometimes.  You see I've been abroad a good many years, and haven't"
514	"been into company enough yet to know how you do things here."""
514	""
514	"""Abroad!"" cried Jo.  ""Oh, tell me about it!  I love dearly to hear"
514	"people describe their travels."""
514	""
514	Laurie didn't seem to know where to begin, but Jo's eager questions
514	soon set him going, and he told her how he had been at school in Vevay,
514	where the boys never wore hats and had a fleet of boats on the lake,
514	and for holiday fun went on walking trips about Switzerland with their
514	teachers.
514	""
514	"""Don't I wish I'd been there!"" cried Jo.  ""Did you go to Paris?"""
514	""
514	"""We spent last winter there."""
514	""
514	"""Can you talk French?"""
514	""
514	"""We were not allowed to speak anything else at Vevay."""
514	""
514	"""Do say some!  I can read it, but can't pronounce."""
514	""
514	"""Quel nom a cette jeune demoiselle en les pantoufles jolis?"""
514	""
514	"""How nicely you do it!  Let me see ... you said, 'Who is the young lady"
514	"in the pretty slippers', didn't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Oui, mademoiselle."""
514	""
514	"""It's my sister Margaret, and you knew it was!  Do you think she is"
514	"pretty?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, she makes me think of the German girls, she looks so fresh and"
514	"quiet, and dances like a lady."""
514	""
514	Jo quite glowed with pleasure at this boyish praise of her sister, and
514	stored it up to repeat to Meg.  Both peeped and criticized and chatted
514	till they felt like old acquaintances.  Laurie's bashfulness soon wore
514	off, for Jo's gentlemanly demeanor amused and set him at his ease, and
514	Jo was her merry self again, because her dress was forgotten and nobody
514	lifted their eyebrows at her.  She liked the 'Laurence boy' better than
514	ever and took several good looks at him, so that she might describe him
514	to the girls, for they had no brothers, very few male cousins, and boys
514	were almost unknown creatures to them.
514	""
514	"""Curly black hair, brown skin, big black eyes, handsome nose, fine"
514	teeth, small hands and feet, taller than I am, very polite, for a boy,
514	"and altogether jolly.  Wonder how old he is?"""
514	""
514	It was on the tip of Jo's tongue to ask, but she checked herself in
514	time and, with unusual tact, tried to find out in a round-about way.
514	""
514	"""I suppose you are going to college soon?  I see you pegging away at"
514	"your books, no, I mean studying hard.""  And Jo blushed at the dreadful"
514	'pegging' which had escaped her.
514	""
514	"Laurie smiled but didn't seem shocked, and answered with a shrug.  ""Not"
514	"for a year or two.  I won't go before seventeen, anyway."""
514	""
514	"""Aren't you but fifteen?"" asked Jo, looking at the tall lad, whom she"
514	had imagined seventeen already.
514	""
514	"""Sixteen, next month."""
514	""
514	"""How I wish I was going to college!  You don't look as if you liked it."""
514	""
514	"""I hate it!  Nothing but grinding or skylarking.  And I don't like the"
514	"way fellows do either, in this country."""
514	""
514	"""What do you like?"""
514	""
514	"""To live in Italy, and to enjoy myself in my own way."""
514	""
514	Jo wanted very much to ask what his own way was, but his black brows
514	looked rather threatening as he knit them, so she changed the subject
514	"by saying, as her foot kept time, ""That's a splendid polka!  Why don't"
514	"you go and try it?"""
514	""
514	"""If you will come too,"" he answered, with a gallant little bow."
514	""
514	"""I can't, for I told Meg I wouldn't, because..."" There Jo stopped, and"
514	looked undecided whether to tell or to laugh.
514	""
514	"""Because, what?"""
514	""
514	"""You won't tell?"""
514	""
514	"""Never!"""
514	""
514	"""Well, I have a bad trick of standing before the fire, and so I burn my"
514	frocks, and I scorched this one, and though it's nicely mended, it
514	shows, and Meg told me to keep still so no one would see it.  You may
514	"laugh, if you want to.  It is funny, I know."""
514	""
514	But Laurie didn't laugh.  He only looked down a minute, and the
514	"expression of his face puzzled Jo when he said very gently, ""Never mind"
514	that.  I'll tell you how we can manage.  There's a long hall out there,
514	"and we can dance grandly, and no one will see us. Please come."""
514	""
514	Jo thanked him and gladly went, wishing she had two neat gloves when
514	she saw the nice, pearl-colored ones her partner wore.  The hall was
514	empty, and they had a grand polka, for Laurie danced well, and taught
514	her the German step, which delighted Jo, being full of swing and
514	spring.  When the music stopped, they sat down on the stairs to get
514	their breath, and Laurie was in the midst of an account of a students'
514	festival at Heidelberg when Meg appeared in search of her sister.  She
514	beckoned, and Jo reluctantly followed her into a side room, where she
514	found her on a sofa, holding her foot, and looking pale.
514	""
514	"""I've sprained my ankle.  That stupid high heel turned and gave me a"
514	sad wrench.  It aches so, I can hardly stand, and I don't know how I'm
514	"ever going to get home,"" she said, rocking to and fro in pain."
514	""
514	"""I knew you'd hurt your feet with those silly shoes.  I'm sorry.  But I"
514	don't see what you can do, except get a carriage, or stay here all
514	"night,"" answered Jo, softly rubbing the poor ankle as she spoke."
514	""
514	"""I can't have a carriage without its costing ever so much.  I dare say"
514	I can't get one at all, for most people come in their own, and it's a
514	"long way to the stable, and no one to send."""
514	""
514	"""I'll go."""
514	""
514	"""No, indeed!  It's past nine, and dark as Egypt.  I can't stop here,"
514	for the house is full.  Sallie has some girls staying with her. I'll
514	"rest till Hannah comes, and then do the best I can."""
514	""
514	"""I'll ask Laurie.  He will go,"" said Jo, looking relieved as the idea"
514	occurred to her.
514	""
514	"""Mercy, no!  Don't ask or tell anyone.  Get me my rubbers, and put"
514	these slippers with our things.  I can't dance anymore, but as soon as
514	"supper is over, watch for Hannah and tell me the minute she comes."""
514	""
514	"""They are going out to supper now.  I'll stay with you.  I'd rather."""
514	""
514	"""No, dear, run along, and bring me some coffee.  I'm so tired I can't"
514	"stir."""
514	""
514	So Meg reclined, with rubbers well hidden, and Jo went blundering away
514	to the dining room, which she found after going into a china closet,
514	and opening the door of a room where old Mr. Gardiner was taking a
514	little private refreshment.  Making a dart at the table, she secured
514	the coffee, which she immediately spilled, thereby making the front of
514	her dress as bad as the back.
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear, what a blunderbuss I am!"" exclaimed Jo, finishing Meg's"
514	glove by scrubbing her gown with it.
514	""
514	"""Can I help you?"" said a friendly voice.  And there was Laurie, with a"
514	full cup in one hand and a plate of ice in the other.
514	""
514	"""I was trying to get something for Meg, who is very tired, and someone"
514	"shook me, and here I am in a nice state,"" answered Jo, glancing"
514	dismally from the stained skirt to the coffee-colored glove.
514	""
514	"""Too bad!   I was looking for someone to give this to.  May I take it"
514	"to your sister?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, thank you!  I'll show you where she is.  I don't offer to take it"
514	"myself, for I should only get into another scrape if I did."""
514	""
514	Jo led the way, and as if used to waiting on ladies, Laurie drew up a
514	little table, brought a second installment of coffee and ice for Jo,
514	and was so obliging that even particular Meg pronounced him a 'nice
514	boy'.  They had a merry time over the bonbons and mottoes, and were in
514	the midst of a quiet game of _Buzz_, with two or three other young
514	people who had strayed in, when Hannah appeared.  Meg forgot her foot
514	and rose so quickly that she was forced to catch hold of Jo, with an
514	exclamation of pain.
514	""
514	"""Hush!  Don't say anything,"" she whispered, adding aloud, ""It's"
514	"nothing.  I turned my foot a little, that's all,"" and limped upstairs"
514	to put her things on.
514	""
514	Hannah scolded, Meg cried, and Jo was at her wits' end, till she
514	decided to take things into her own hands.  Slipping out, she ran down
514	and, finding a servant, asked if he could get her a carriage. It
514	happened to be a hired waiter who knew nothing about the neighborhood
514	and Jo was looking round for help when Laurie, who had heard what she
514	said, came up and offered his grandfather's carriage, which had just
514	come for him, he said.
514	""
514	"""It's so early!  You can't mean to go yet?"" began Jo, looking relieved"
514	but hesitating to accept the offer.
514	""
514	"""I always go early, I do, truly!  Please let me take you home. It's all"
514	"on my way, you know, and it rains, they say."""
514	""
514	That settled it, and telling him of Meg's mishap, Jo gratefully
514	accepted and rushed up to bring down the rest of the party.  Hannah
514	hated rain as much as a cat does so she made no trouble, and they
514	rolled away in the luxurious close carriage, feeling very festive and
514	elegant.  Laurie went on the box so Meg could keep her foot up, and the
514	girls talked over their party in freedom.
514	""
514	"""I had a capital time.  Did you?"" asked Jo, rumpling up her hair, and"
514	making herself comfortable.
514	""
514	"""Yes, till I hurt myself.  Sallie's friend, Annie Moffat, took a fancy"
514	to me, and asked me to come and spend a week with her when Sallie does.
514	She is going in the spring when the opera comes, and it will be
514	"perfectly splendid, if Mother only lets me go,"" answered Meg, cheering"
514	up at the thought.
514	""
514	"""I saw you dancing with the red headed man I ran away from.  Was he"
514	"nice?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, very!  His hair is auburn, not red, and he was very polite, and I"
514	"had a delicious redowa with him."""
514	""
514	"""He looked like a grasshopper in a fit when he did the new step. Laurie"
514	"and I couldn't help laughing.  Did you hear us?"""
514	""
514	"""No, but it was very rude.  What were you about all that time, hidden"
514	"away there?"""
514	""
514	Jo told her adventures, and by the time she had finished they were at
514	home.  With many thanks, they said good night and crept in, hoping to
514	disturb no one, but the instant their door creaked, two little
514	nightcaps bobbed up, and two sleepy but eager voices cried out...
514	""
514	"""Tell about the party!  Tell about the party!"""
514	""
514	With what Meg called 'a great want of manners' Jo had saved some
514	bonbons for the little girls, and they soon subsided, after hearing the
514	most thrilling events of the evening.
514	""
514	"""I declare, it really seems like being a fine young lady, to come home"
514	from the party in a carriage and sit in my dressing gown with a maid to
514	"wait on me,"" said Meg, as Jo bound up her foot with arnica and brushed"
514	her hair.
514	""
514	"""I don't believe fine young ladies enjoy themselves a bit more than we"
514	do, in spite of our burned hair, old gowns, one glove apiece and tight
514	"slippers that sprain our ankles when we are silly enough to wear them."""
514	And I think Jo was quite right.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FOUR
514	""
514	BURDENS
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear, how hard it does seem to take up our packs and go on,"""
514	sighed Meg the morning after the party, for now the holidays were over,
514	the week of merrymaking did not fit her for going on easily with the
514	task she never liked.
514	""
514	"""I wish it was Christmas or New Year's all the time. Wouldn't it be"
514	"fun?"" answered Jo, yawning dismally."
514	""
514	"""We shouldn't enjoy ourselves half so much as we do now. But it does"
514	seem so nice to have little suppers and bouquets, and go to parties,
514	and drive home, and read and rest, and not work.  It's like other
514	people, you know, and I always envy girls who do such things, I'm so
514	"fond of luxury,"" said Meg, trying to decide which of two shabby gowns"
514	was the least shabby.
514	""
514	"""Well, we can't have it, so don't let us grumble but shoulder our"
514	bundles and trudge along as cheerfully as Marmee does.  I'm sure Aunt
514	March is a regular Old Man of the Sea to me, but I suppose when I've
514	learned to carry her without complaining, she will tumble off, or get
514	"so light that I shan't mind her."""
514	""
514	This idea tickled Jo's fancy and put her in good spirits, but Meg
514	didn't brighten, for her burden, consisting of four spoiled children,
514	seemed heavier than ever. She had not heart enough even to make herself
514	pretty as usual by putting on a blue neck ribbon and dressing her hair
514	in the most becoming way.
514	""
514	"""Where's the use of looking nice, when no one sees me but those cross"
514	"midgets, and no one cares whether I'm pretty or not?"" she muttered,"
514	"shutting her drawer with a jerk.  ""I shall have to toil and moil all my"
514	days, with only little bits of fun now and then, and get old and ugly
514	and sour, because I'm poor and can't enjoy my life as other girls do.
514	"It's a shame!"""
514	""
514	So Meg went down, wearing an injured look, and wasn't at all agreeable
514	at breakfast time.  Everyone seemed rather out of sorts and inclined to
514	croak.
514	""
514	Beth had a headache and lay on the sofa, trying to comfort herself with
514	the cat and three kittens.  Amy was fretting because her lessons were
514	not learned, and she couldn't find her rubbers.  Jo would whistle and
514	make a great racket getting ready.
514	""
514	Mrs. March was very busy trying to finish a letter, which must go at
514	once, and Hannah had the grumps, for being up late didn't suit her.
514	""
514	"""There never was such a cross family!"" cried Jo, losing her temper when"
514	she had upset an inkstand, broken both boot lacings, and sat down upon
514	her hat.
514	""
514	"""You're the crossest person in it!"" returned Amy, washing out the sum"
514	that was all wrong with the tears that had fallen on her slate.
514	""
514	"""Beth, if you don't keep these horrid cats down cellar I'll have them"
514	"drowned,"" exclaimed Meg angrily as she tried to get rid of the kitten"
514	which had scrambled up her back and stuck like a burr just out of reach.
514	""
514	Jo laughed, Meg scolded, Beth implored, and Amy wailed because she
514	couldn't remember how much nine times twelve was.
514	""
514	"""Girls, girls, do be quiet one minute!  I must get this off by the"
514	"early mail, and you drive me distracted with your worry,"" cried Mrs."
514	March, crossing out the third spoiled sentence in her letter.
514	""
514	There was a momentary lull, broken by Hannah, who stalked in, laid two
514	hot turnovers on the table, and stalked out again. These turnovers were
514	an institution, and the girls called them 'muffs', for they had no
514	others and found the hot pies very comforting to their hands on cold
514	mornings.
514	""
514	Hannah never forgot to make them, no matter how busy or grumpy she
514	might be, for the walk was long and bleak. The poor things got no other
514	lunch and were seldom home before two.
514	""
514	"""Cuddle your cats and get over your headache, Bethy. Goodbye, Marmee."
514	We are a set of rascals this morning, but we'll come home regular
514	"angels.  Now then, Meg!""  And Jo tramped away, feeling that the"
514	pilgrims were not setting out as they ought to do.
514	""
514	They always looked back before turning the corner, for their mother was
514	always at the window to nod and smile, and wave her hand to them.
514	Somehow it seemed as if they couldn't have got through the day without
514	that, for whatever their mood might be, the last glimpse of that
514	motherly face was sure to affect them like sunshine.
514	""
514	"""If Marmee shook her fist instead of kissing her hand to us, it would"
514	serve us right, for more ungrateful wretches than we are were never
514	"seen,"" cried Jo, taking a remorseful satisfaction in the snowy walk and"
514	bitter wind.
514	""
514	"""Don't use such dreadful expressions,"" replied Meg from the depths of"
514	the veil in which she had shrouded herself like a nun sick of the world.
514	""
514	"""I like good strong words that mean something,"" replied Jo, catching"
514	her hat as it took a leap off her head preparatory to flying away
514	altogether.
514	""
514	"""Call yourself any names you like, but I am neither a rascal nor a"
514	"wretch and I don't choose to be called so."""
514	""
514	"""You're a blighted being, and decidedly cross today because you can't"
514	sit in the lap of luxury all the time.  Poor dear, just wait till I
514	make my fortune, and you shall revel in carriages and ice cream and
514	"high-heeled slippers, and posies, and red-headed boys to dance with."""
514	""
514	"""How ridiculous you are, Jo!""  But Meg laughed at the nonsense and felt"
514	better in spite of herself.
514	""
514	"""Lucky for you I am, for if I put on crushed airs and tried to be"
514	dismal, as you do, we should be in a nice state. Thank goodness, I can
514	always find something funny to keep me up.  Don't croak any more, but
514	"come home jolly, there's a dear."""
514	""
514	Jo gave her sister an encouraging pat on the shoulder as they parted
514	for the day, each going a different way, each hugging her little warm
514	turnover, and each trying to be cheerful in spite of wintry weather,
514	hard work, and the unsatisfied desires of pleasure-loving youth.
514	""
514	When Mr. March lost his property in trying to help an unfortunate
514	friend, the two oldest girls begged to be allowed to do something
514	toward their own support, at least.  Believing that they could not
514	begin too early to cultivate energy, industry, and independence, their
514	parents consented, and both fell to work with the hearty good will
514	which in spite of all obstacles is sure to succeed at last.
514	""
514	Margaret found a place as nursery governess and felt rich with her
514	small salary.  As she said, she was 'fond of luxury', and her chief
514	trouble was poverty.  She found it harder to bear than the others
514	because she could remember a time when home was beautiful, life full of
514	ease and pleasure, and want of any kind unknown.  She tried not to be
514	envious or discontented, but it was very natural that the young girl
514	should long for pretty things, gay friends, accomplishments, and a
514	happy life.  At the Kings' she daily saw all she wanted, for the
514	children's older sisters were just out, and Meg caught frequent
