514	glimpses of dainty ball dresses and bouquets, heard lively gossip about
514	theaters, concerts, sleighing parties, and merrymakings of all kinds,
514	and saw money lavished on trifles which would have been so precious to
514	her.  Poor Meg seldom complained, but a sense of injustice made her
514	feel bitter toward everyone sometimes, for she had not yet learned to
514	know how rich she was in the blessings which alone can make life happy.
514	""
514	Jo happened to suit Aunt March, who was lame and needed an active
514	person to wait upon her.  The childless old lady had offered to adopt
514	one of the girls when the troubles came, and was much offended because
514	her offer was declined.  Other friends told the Marches that they had
514	lost all chance of being remembered in the rich old lady's will, but
514	the unworldly Marches only said...
514	""
514	"""We can't give up our girls for a dozen fortunes.  Rich or poor, we"
514	"will keep together and be happy in one another."""
514	""
514	The old lady wouldn't speak to them for a time, but happening to meet
514	Jo at a friend's, something in her comical face and blunt manners
514	struck the old lady's fancy, and she proposed to take her for a
514	companion.  This did not suit Jo at all, but she accepted the place
514	since nothing better appeared and, to every one's surprise, got on
514	remarkably well with her irascible relative.  There was an occasional
514	tempest, and once Jo marched home, declaring she couldn't bear it
514	longer, but Aunt March always cleared up quickly, and sent for her to
514	come back again with such urgency that she could not refuse, for in her
514	heart she rather liked the peppery old lady.
514	""
514	I suspect that the real attraction was a large library of fine books,
514	which was left to dust and spiders since Uncle March died.  Jo
514	remembered the kind old gentleman, who used to let her build railroads
514	and bridges with his big dictionaries, tell her stories about queer
514	pictures in his Latin books, and buy her cards of gingerbread whenever
514	he met her in the street.  The dim, dusty room, with the busts staring
514	down from the tall bookcases, the cozy chairs, the globes, and best of
514	all, the wilderness of books in which she could wander where she liked,
514	made the library a region of bliss to her.
514	""
514	The moment Aunt March took her nap, or was busy with company, Jo
514	hurried to this quiet place, and curling herself up in the easy chair,
514	devoured poetry, romance, history, travels, and pictures like a regular
514	bookworm.  But, like all happiness, it did not last long, for as sure
514	as she had just reached the heart of the story, the sweetest verse of a
514	song, or the most perilous adventure of her traveler, a shrill voice
514	"called, ""Josy-phine! Josy-phine!"" and she had to leave her paradise to"
514	wind yarn, wash the poodle, or read Belsham's Essays by the hour
514	together.
514	""
514	Jo's ambition was to do something very splendid.  What it was, she had
514	no idea as yet, but left it for time to tell her, and meanwhile, found
514	her greatest affliction in the fact that she couldn't read, run, and
514	ride as much as she liked.  A quick temper, sharp tongue, and restless
514	spirit were always getting her into scrapes, and her life was a series
514	of ups and downs, which were both comic and pathetic. But the training
514	she received at Aunt March's was just what she needed, and the thought
514	that she was doing something to support herself made her happy in spite
514	"of the perpetual ""Josy-phine!"""
514	""
514	Beth was too bashful to go to school.  It had been tried, but she
514	suffered so much that it was given up, and she did her lessons at home
514	with her father.  Even when he went away, and her mother was called to
514	devote her skill and energy to Soldiers' Aid Societies, Beth went
514	faithfully on by herself and did the best she could.  She was a
514	housewifely little creature, and helped Hannah keep home neat and
514	comfortable for the workers, never thinking of any reward but to be
514	loved.  Long, quiet days she spent, not lonely nor idle, for her little
514	world was peopled with imaginary friends, and she was by nature a busy
514	bee.  There were six dolls to be taken up and dressed every morning,
514	for Beth was a child still and loved her pets as well as ever.  Not one
514	whole or handsome one among them, all were outcasts till Beth took them
514	in, for when her sisters outgrew these idols, they passed to her
514	because Amy would have nothing old or ugly. Beth cherished them all the
514	more tenderly for that very reason, and set up a hospital for infirm
514	dolls.  No pins were ever stuck into their cotton vitals, no harsh
514	words or blows were ever given them, no neglect ever saddened the heart
514	of the most repulsive, but all were fed and clothed, nursed and
514	caressed with an affection which never failed. One forlorn fragment of
514	dollanity had belonged to Jo and, having led a tempestuous life, was
514	left a wreck in the rag bag, from which dreary poorhouse it was rescued
514	by Beth and taken to her refuge.  Having no top to its head, she tied
514	on a neat little cap, and as both arms and legs were gone, she hid
514	these deficiencies by folding it in a blanket and devoting her best bed
514	to this chronic invalid.  If anyone had known the care lavished on that
514	dolly, I think it would have touched their hearts, even while they
514	laughed. She brought it bits of bouquets, she read to it, took it out
514	to breathe fresh air, hidden under her coat, she sang it lullabies and
514	never went to bed without kissing its dirty face and whispering
514	"tenderly, ""I hope you'll have a good night, my poor dear."""
514	""
514	Beth had her troubles as well as the others, and not being an angel but
514	a very human little girl, she often 'wept a little weep' as Jo said,
514	because she couldn't take music lessons and have a fine piano.  She
514	loved music so dearly, tried so hard to learn, and practiced away so
514	patiently at the jingling old instrument, that it did seem as if
514	someone (not to hint Aunt March) ought to help her.  Nobody did,
514	however, and nobody saw Beth wipe the tears off the yellow keys, that
514	wouldn't keep in tune, when she was all alone. She sang like a little
514	lark about her work, never was too tired for Marmee and the girls, and
514	"day after day said hopefully to herself, ""I know I'll get my music some"
514	"time, if I'm good."""
514	""
514	There are many Beths in the world, shy and quiet, sitting in corners
514	till needed, and living for others so cheerfully that no one sees the
514	sacrifices till the little cricket on the hearth stops chirping, and
514	the sweet, sunshiny presence vanishes, leaving silence and shadow
514	behind.
514	""
514	If anybody had asked Amy what the greatest trial of her life was, she
514	"would have answered at once, ""My nose.""  When she was a baby, Jo had"
514	accidently dropped her into the coal hod, and Amy insisted that the
514	fall had ruined her nose forever.  It was not big nor red, like poor
514	'Petrea's', it was only rather flat, and all the pinching in the world
514	could not give it an aristocratic point.  No one minded it but herself,
514	and it was doing its best to grow, but Amy felt deeply the want of a
514	Grecian nose, and drew whole sheets of handsome ones to console herself.
514	""
514	"""Little Raphael,"" as her sisters called her, had a decided talent for"
514	drawing, and was never so happy as when copying flowers, designing
514	fairies, or illustrating stories with queer specimens of art.  Her
514	teachers complained that instead of doing her sums she covered her
514	slate with animals, the blank pages of her atlas were used to copy maps
514	on, and caricatures of the most ludicrous description came fluttering
514	out of all her books at unlucky moments.  She got through her lessons
514	as well as she could, and managed to escape reprimands by being a model
514	of deportment.  She was a great favorite with her mates, being
514	good-tempered and possessing the happy art of pleasing without effort.
514	Her little airs and graces were much admired, so were her
514	accomplishments, for besides her drawing, she could play twelve tunes,
514	crochet, and read French without mispronouncing more than two-thirds of
514	"the words.  She had a plaintive way of saying, ""When Papa was rich we"
514	"did so-and-so,"" which was very touching, and her long words were"
514	considered 'perfectly elegant' by the girls.
514	""
514	Amy was in a fair way to be spoiled, for everyone petted her, and her
514	small vanities and selfishnesses were growing nicely. One thing,
514	however, rather quenched the vanities.  She had to wear her cousin's
514	clothes.  Now Florence's mama hadn't a particle of taste, and Amy
514	suffered deeply at having to wear a red instead of a blue bonnet,
514	unbecoming gowns, and fussy aprons that did not fit.  Everything was
514	good, well made, and little worn, but Amy's artistic eyes were much
514	afflicted, especially this winter, when her school dress was a dull
514	purple with yellow dots and no trimming.
514	""
514	"""My only comfort,"" she said to Meg, with tears in her eyes, ""is that"
514	Mother doesn't take tucks in my dresses whenever I'm naughty, as Maria
514	Parks's mother does.  My dear, it's really dreadful, for sometimes she
514	is so bad her frock is up to her knees, and she can't come to school.
514	When I think of this _deggerredation_, I feel that I can bear even my
514	"flat nose and purple gown with yellow sky-rockets on it."""
514	""
514	Meg was Amy's confidant and monitor, and by some strange attraction of
514	opposites Jo was gentle Beth's.  To Jo alone did the shy child tell her
514	thoughts, and over her big harum-scarum sister Beth unconsciously
514	exercised more influence than anyone in the family.  The two older
514	girls were a great deal to one another, but each took one of the
514	younger sisters into her keeping and watched over her in her own way,
514	'playing mother' they called it, and put their sisters in the places of
514	discarded dolls with the maternal instinct of little women.
514	""
514	"""Has anybody got anything to tell?  It's been such a dismal day I'm"
514	"really dying for some amusement,"" said Meg, as they sat sewing together"
514	that evening.
514	""
514	"""I had a queer time with Aunt today, and, as I got the best of it, I'll"
514	"tell you about it,"" began Jo, who dearly loved to tell stories.  ""I was"
514	reading that everlasting Belsham, and droning away as I always do, for
514	Aunt soon drops off, and then I take out some nice book, and read like
514	fury till she wakes up.  I actually made myself sleepy, and before she
514	began to nod, I gave such a gape that she asked me what I meant by
514	"opening my mouth wide enough to take the whole book in at once."""
514	""
514	"""I wish I could, and be done with it,"" said I, trying not to be saucy."
514	""
514	"""Then she gave me a long lecture on my sins, and told me to sit and"
514	think them over while she just 'lost' herself for a moment. She never
514	finds herself very soon, so the minute her cap began to bob like a
514	top-heavy dahlia, I whipped the _Vicar of Wakefield_ out of my pocket,
514	and read away, with one eye on him and one on Aunt. I'd just got to
514	where they all tumbled into the water when I forgot and laughed out
514	loud.  Aunt woke up and, being more good-natured after her nap, told me
514	to read a bit and show what frivolous work I preferred to the worthy
514	and instructive Belsham. I did my very best, and she liked it, though
514	she only said...
514	""
514	"""'I don't understand what it's all about.  Go back and begin it,"
514	"child.'"""
514	""
514	"""Back I went, and made the Primroses as interesting as ever I could."
514	Once I was wicked enough to stop in a thrilling place, and say meekly,
514	"'I'm afraid it tires you, ma'am.  Shan't I stop now?'"""
514	""
514	"""She caught up her knitting, which had dropped out of her hands, gave"
514	me a sharp look through her specs, and said, in her short way, 'Finish
514	"the chapter, and don't be impertinent, miss'."""
514	""
514	"""Did she own she liked it?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""Oh, bless you, no!  But she let old Belsham rest, and when I ran back"
514	after my gloves this afternoon, there she was, so hard at the Vicar
514	that she didn't hear me laugh as I danced a jig in the hall because of
514	the good time coming.  What a pleasant life she might have if only she
514	chose!  I don't envy her much, in spite of her money, for after all
514	"rich people have about as many worries as poor ones, I think,"" added Jo."
514	""
514	"""That reminds me,"" said Meg, ""that I've got something to tell. It isn't"
514	funny, like Jo's story, but I thought about it a good deal as I came
514	home.  At the Kings' today I found everybody in a flurry, and one of
514	the children said that her oldest brother had done something dreadful,
514	and Papa had sent him away.  I heard Mrs. King crying and Mr. King
514	talking very loud, and Grace and Ellen turned away their faces when
514	they passed me, so I shouldn't see how red and swollen their eyes were.
514	I didn't ask any questions, of course, but I felt so sorry for them and
514	was rather glad I hadn't any wild brothers to do wicked things and
514	"disgrace the family."""
514	""
514	"""I think being disgraced in school is a great deal try_inger_ than"
514	"anything bad boys can do,"" said Amy, shaking her head, as if her"
514	"experience of life had been a deep one.  ""Susie Perkins came to school"
514	today with a lovely red carnelian ring.  I wanted it dreadfully, and
514	wished I was her with all my might.  Well, she drew a picture of Mr.
514	Davis, with a monstrous nose and a hump, and the words, 'Young ladies,
514	my eye is upon you!' coming out of his mouth in a balloon thing.  We
514	were laughing over it when all of a sudden his eye _was_ on us, and he
514	ordered Susie to bring up her slate.  She was _parry_lized with fright,
514	but she went, and oh, what _do_ you think he did?  He took her by the
514	ear--the ear!  Just fancy how horrid!--and led her to the recitation
514	platform, and made her stand there half an hour, holding the slate so
514	"everyone could see."""
514	""
514	"""Didn't the girls laugh at the picture?"" asked Jo, who relished the"
514	scrape.
514	""
514	"""Laugh? Not one! They sat still as mice, and Susie cried quarts, I know"
514	she did.  I didn't envy her then, for I felt that millions of carnelian
514	rings wouldn't have made me happy after that. I never, never should
514	"have got over such a agonizing mortification."" And Amy went on with her"
514	work, in the proud consciousness of virtue and the successful utterance
514	of two long words in a breath.
514	""
514	"""I saw something I liked this morning, and I meant to tell it at"
514	"dinner, but I forgot,"" said Beth, putting Jo's topsy-turvy basket in"
514	"order as she talked.  ""When I went to get some oysters for Hannah, Mr."
514	Laurence was in the fish shop, but he didn't see me, for I kept behind
514	the fish barrel, and he was busy with Mr. Cutter the fish-man. A poor
514	woman came in with a pail and a mop, and asked Mr. Cutter if he would
514	let her do some scrubbing for a bit of fish, because she hadn't any
514	dinner for her children, and had been disappointed of a day's work.
514	Mr. Cutter was in a hurry and said 'No', rather crossly, so she was
514	going away, looking hungry and sorry, when Mr. Laurence hooked up a big
514	fish with the crooked end of his cane and held it out to her.  She was
514	so glad and surprised she took it right into her arms, and thanked him
514	over and over.  He told her to 'go along and cook it', and she hurried
514	off, so happy!  Wasn't it good of him?  Oh, she did look so funny,
514	hugging the big, slippery fish, and hoping Mr. Laurence's bed in heaven
514	"would be 'aisy'."""
514	""
514	When they had laughed at Beth's story, they asked their mother for one,
514	"and after a moments thought, she said soberly, ""As I sat cutting out"
514	blue flannel jackets today at the rooms, I felt very anxious about
514	Father, and thought how lonely and helpless we should be, if anything
514	happened to him.  It was not a wise thing to do, but I kept on worrying
514	till an old man came in with an order for some clothes.  He sat down
514	near me, and I began to talk to him, for he looked poor and tired and
514	anxious.
514	""
514	"""'Have you sons in the army?' I asked, for the note he brought was not"
514	"to me."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, ma'am.  I had four, but two were killed, one is a prisoner, and"
514	I'm going to the other, who is very sick in a Washington hospital.' he
514	"answered quietly."""
514	""
514	"""'You have done a great deal for your country, sir,' I said, feeling"
514	"respect now, instead of pity."""
514	""
514	"""'Not a mite more than I ought, ma'am.  I'd go myself, if I was any"
514	"use.  As I ain't, I give my boys, and give 'em free.'"""
514	""
514	"""He spoke so cheerfully, looked so sincere, and seemed so glad to give"
514	his all, that I was ashamed of myself.  I'd given one man and thought
514	it too much, while he gave four without grudging them.  I had all my
514	girls to comfort me at home, and his last son was waiting, miles away,
514	to say good-by to him, perhaps!  I felt so rich, so happy thinking of
514	my blessings, that I made him a nice bundle, gave him some money, and
514	"thanked him heartily for the lesson he had taught me."""
514	""
514	"""Tell another story, Mother, one with a moral to it, like this. I like"
514	"to think about them afterward, if they are real and not too preachy,"""
514	said Jo, after a minute's silence.
514	""
514	Mrs. March smiled and began at once, for she had told stories to this
514	little audience for many years, and knew how to please them.
514	""
514	"""Once upon a time, there were four girls, who had enough to eat and"
514	drink and wear, a good many comforts and pleasures, kind friends and
514	"parents who loved them dearly, and yet they were not contented."" (Here"
514	the listeners stole sly looks at one another, and began to sew
514	"diligently.) ""These girls were anxious to be good and made many"
514	excellent resolutions, but they did not keep them very well, and were
514	constantly saying, 'If only we had this,' or 'If we could only do
514	that,' quite forgetting how much they already had, and how many things
514	they actually could do.  So they asked an old woman what spell they
514	could use to make them happy, and she said, 'When you feel
514	"discontented, think over your blessings, and be grateful.'"" (Here Jo"
514	looked up quickly, as if about to speak, but changed her mind, seeing
514	that the story was not done yet.)
514	""
514	"""Being sensible girls, they decided to try her advice, and soon were"
514	surprised to see how well off they were.  One discovered that money
514	couldn't keep shame and sorrow out of rich people's houses, another
514	that, though she was poor, she was a great deal happier, with her
514	youth, health, and good spirits, than a certain fretful, feeble old
514	lady who couldn't enjoy her comforts, a third that, disagreeable as it
514	was to help get dinner, it was harder still to go begging for it and
514	the fourth, that even carnelian rings were not so valuable as good
514	behavior.  So they agreed to stop complaining, to enjoy the blessings
514	already possessed, and try to deserve them, lest they should be taken
514	away entirely, instead of increased, and I believe they were never
514	"disappointed or sorry that they took the old woman's advice."""
514	""
514	"""Now, Marmee, that is very cunning of you to turn our own stories"
514	"against us, and give us a sermon instead of a romance!"" cried Meg."
514	""
514	"""I like that kind of sermon.  It's the sort Father used to tell us,"""
514	said Beth thoughtfully, putting the needles straight on Jo's cushion.
514	""
514	"""I don't complain near as much as the others do, and I shall be more"
514	"careful than ever now, for I've had warning from Susie's downfall,"""
514	said Amy morally.
514	""
514	"""We needed that lesson, and we won't forget it.  If we do so, you just"
514	say to us, as old Chloe did in _Uncle Tom_, 'Tink ob yer marcies,
514	"chillen!' 'Tink ob yer marcies!'"" added Jo, who could not, for the life"
514	of her, help getting a morsel of fun out of the little sermon, though
514	she took it to heart as much as any of them.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FIVE
514	""
514	BEING NEIGHBORLY
514	""
514	"""What in the world are you going to do now, Jo?"" asked Meg one snowy"
514	afternoon, as her sister came tramping through the hall, in rubber
514	boots, old sack, and hood, with a broom in one hand and a shovel in the
514	other.
514	""
514	"""Going out for exercise,"" answered Jo with a mischievous twinkle in her"
514	eyes.
514	""
514	"""I should think two long walks this morning would have been enough!"
514	It's cold and dull out, and I advise you to stay warm and dry by the
514	"fire, as I do,"" said Meg with a shiver."
514	""
514	"""Never take advice!  Can't keep still all day, and not being a"
514	pussycat, I don't like to doze by the fire.  I like adventures, and I'm
514	"going to find some."""
514	""
514	Meg went back to toast her feet and read _Ivanhoe_, and Jo began to dig
514	paths with great energy.  The snow was light, and with her broom she
514	soon swept a path all round the garden, for Beth to walk in when the
514	sun came out and the invalid dolls needed air.  Now, the garden
514	separated the Marches' house from that of Mr. Laurence.  Both stood in
514	a suburb of the city, which was still country-like, with groves and
514	lawns, large gardens, and quiet streets.  A low hedge parted the two
514	estates.  On one side was an old, brown house, looking rather bare and
514	shabby, robbed of the vines that in summer covered its walls and the
514	flowers, which then surrounded it.  On the other side was a stately
514	stone mansion, plainly betokening every sort of comfort and luxury,
514	from the big coach house and well-kept grounds to the conservatory and
514	the glimpses of lovely things one caught between the rich curtains.
514	""
514	Yet it seemed a lonely, lifeless sort of house, for no children
514	frolicked on the lawn, no motherly face ever smiled at the windows, and
514	few people went in and out, except the old gentleman and his grandson.
514	""
514	To Jo's lively fancy, this fine house seemed a kind of enchanted
514	palace, full of splendors and delights which no one enjoyed.  She had
514	long wanted to behold these hidden glories, and to know the Laurence
514	boy, who looked as if he would like to be known, if he only knew how to
514	begin.  Since the party, she had been more eager than ever, and had
514	planned many ways of making friends with him, but he had not been seen
514	lately, and Jo began to think he had gone away, when she one day spied
514	a brown face at an upper window, looking wistfully down into their
514	garden, where Beth and Amy were snow-balling one another.
514	""
514	"""That boy is suffering for society and fun,"" she said to herself. ""His"
514	grandpa does not know what's good for him, and keeps him shut up all
514	alone.  He needs a party of jolly boys to play with, or somebody young
514	and lively.  I've a great mind to go over and tell the old gentleman
514	"so!"""
514	""
514	The idea amused Jo, who liked to do daring things and was always
514	scandalizing Meg by her queer performances.  The plan of 'going over'
514	was not forgotten.  And when the snowy afternoon came, Jo resolved to
514	try what could be done.  She saw Mr. Lawrence drive off, and then
514	sallied out to dig her way down to the hedge, where she paused and took
514	a survey.  All quiet, curtains down at the lower windows, servants out
514	of sight, and nothing human visible but a curly black head leaning on a
514	thin hand at the upper window.
514	""
514	"""There he is,"" thought Jo, ""Poor boy!  All alone and sick this dismal"

514	""
514	Up went a handful of soft snow, and the head turned at once, showing a
514	face which lost its listless look in a minute, as the big eyes
514	brightened and the mouth began to smile.  Jo nodded and laughed, and
514	flourished her broom as she called out...
514	""
514	"""How do you do?  Are you sick?"""
514	""
514	Laurie opened the window, and croaked out as hoarsely as a raven...
514	""
514	"""Better, thank you.  I've had a bad cold, and been shut up a week."""
514	""
514	"""I'm sorry.  What do you amuse yourself with?"""
514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""So I do!  Will you come, please?"" cried Laurie."
514	""

514	""

514	for as Mrs. March said, he was 'a little gentleman', and did honor to
514	the coming guest by brushing his curly pate, putting on a fresh collar,
514	and trying to tidy up the room, which in spite of half a dozen
514	servants, was anything but neat.  Presently there came a loud ring,
514	than a decided voice, asking for 'Mr. Laurie', and a surprised-looking
514	servant came running up to announce a young lady.
514	""
514	"""All right, show her up, it's Miss Jo,"" said Laurie, going to the door"

514	at her ease, with a covered dish in one hand and Beth's three kittens
514	in the other.
514	""
514	"""Here I am, bag and baggage,"" she said briskly.  ""Mother sent her love,"
514	and was glad if I could do anything for you.  Meg wanted me to bring
514	some of her blanc mange, she makes it very nicely, and Beth thought her

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""It isn't anything, only they all felt kindly and wanted to show it."

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	And so he was, for, as she laughed and talked, Jo had whisked things

514	sat down with a sigh of satisfaction, saying gratefully...
514	""

514	""
514	"""No, I came to amuse you.  Shall I read aloud?"" and Jo looked"

514	""
514	"""Thank you!  I've read all those, and if you don't mind, I'd rather"

514	""
514	"""Not a bit.  I'll talk all day if you'll only set me going. Beth says I"

514	""
514	"""Is Beth the rosy one, who stays at home good deal and sometimes goes"

514	""
514	"Laurie colored up, but answered frankly, ""Why, you see I often hear you"

514	The solitary, hungry look in his eyes went straight to Jo's warm heart.

514	""
514	"""We'll never draw that curtain any more, and I give you leave to look"

514	dance.  Meg and I would make you laugh over our funny stage properties,
514	"and we'd have jolly times.  Wouldn't your grandpa let you?"""
514	""
514	"""I think he would, if your mother asked him.  He's very kind, though he"
514	does not look so, and he lets me do what I like, pretty much, only he's
514	"afraid I might be a bother to strangers,"" began Laurie, brightening"
514	more and more.
514	""
514	"""We are not strangers, we are neighbors, and you needn't think you'd be"

514	""
514	"""You see, Grandpa lives among his books, and doesn't mind much what"

514	""
514	"""That's bad.  You ought to make an effort and go visiting everywhere"

514	""
514	Laurie turned red again, but wasn't offended at being accused of

514	""
514	"""Do you like your school?"" asked the boy, changing the subject, after a"

514	""

514	""
514	Laurie opened his mouth to ask another question, but remembering just

514	""
514	Jo liked his good breeding, and didn't mind having a laugh at Aunt

514	her fat poodle, the parrot that talked Spanish, and the library where
514	she reveled.
514	""
514	Laurie enjoyed that immensely, and when she told about the prim old
514	gentleman who came once to woo Aunt March, and in the middle of a fine

514	lay back and laughed till the tears ran down his cheeks, and a maid

514	""

514	""
514	Much elated with her success, Jo did 'tell on', all about their plays
514	and plans, their hopes and fears for Father, and the most interesting

514	to talking about books, and to Jo's delight, she found that Laurie
514	loved them as well as she did, and had read even more than herself.
514	""
514	"""If you like them so much, come down and see ours.  Grandfather is out,"
514	"so you needn't be afraid,"" said Laurie, getting up."
514	""
514	"""I'm not afraid of anything,"" returned Jo, with a toss of the head."
514	""

514	""
514	The atmosphere of the whole house being summerlike, Laurie led the way

514	fireplace with quaint tiles all round it.
514	""
514	"""What richness!"" sighed Jo, sinking into the depth of a velour chair"
514	"and gazing about her with an air of intense satisfaction. ""Theodore"
514	"Laurence, you ought to be the happiest boy in the world,"" she added"

514	""
514	"""A fellow can't live on books,"" said Laurie, shaking his head as he"
514	perched on a table opposite.
514	""

514	"alarm, ""Mercy me!  It's your grandpa!"""
514	""
514	"""Well, what if it is?  You are not afraid of anything, you know,"""
514	returned the boy, looking wicked.
514	""

514	""
514	"""I'm a great deal better for it, and ever so much obliged. I'm only"

514	""
514	"""The doctor to see you, sir,"" and the maid beckoned as she spoke."
514	""
514	"""Would you mind if I left you for a minute?  I suppose I must see him,"""
514	said Laurie.
514	""
514	"""Don't mind me.  I'm happy as a cricket here,"" answered Jo."
514	""

514	"""Not much, sir."""
514	""
514	"""And you don't think me as handsome as your grandfather?"""
514	""
514	"""Not quite, sir."""
514	""
514	"""And I've got a tremendous will, have I?"""
514	""
514	"""I only said I thought so."""
514	""
514	"""But you like me in spite of it?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I do, sir."""
514	""

514	""

514	""

514	question, sharply put.
514	""
514	"""Only trying to be neighborly, sir.""  And Jo told how her visit came"

514	""
514	"""You think he needs cheering up a bit, do you?"""
514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""Just her father's way of doing good.  I shall come and see your mother"

514	"""If you'd like to have me, sir."""
514	""

514	""

514	"""Hey!  Why, what the dickens has come to the fellow?"" said the old"

514	""
514	"""That's evident, by the way you racket downstairs.  Come to your tea,"
514	"sir, and behave like a gentleman.""  And having pulled the boy's hair by"

514	""
514	The old gentleman did not say much as he drank his four cups of tea,

514	""

514	""
514	They found Mr. Laurence standing before the fire in the great drawing

514	""
514	"""Do you play?"" she asked, turning to Laurie with a respectful"
514	expression.
514	""
514	"""Sometimes,"" he answered modestly."
514	""
514	"""Please do now.  I want to hear it, so I can tell Beth."""
514	""
514	"""Won't you first?"""
514	""
514	"""Don't know how.  Too stupid to learn, but I love music dearly."""

514	""
514	"""That will do, that will do, young lady.  Too many sugarplums are not"

514	""
514	He shook hands kindly, but looked as if something did not please him.

514	""
514	"""No, it was me.  He doesn't like to hear me play."""
514	""
514	"""Why not?"""
514	""
514	"""I'll tell you some day.  John is going home with you, as I can't."""
514	""
514	"""No need of that.  I am not a young lady, and it's only a step.  Take"
514	"care of yourself, won't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, but you will come again, I hope?"""
514	""
514	"""If you promise to come and see us after you are well."""
514	""
514	"""I will."""
514	""
514	"""Good night, Laurie!"""
514	""
514	"""Good night, Jo, good night!"""
514	""
514	When all the afternoon's adventures had been told, the family felt
514	inclined to go visiting in a body, for each found something very
514	attractive in the big house on the other side of the hedge. Mrs. March

514	piano, and Amy was eager to see the fine pictures and statues.
514	""
514	"""Mother, why didn't Mr. Laurence like to have Laurie play?"" asked Jo,"
514	who was of an inquiring disposition.
514	""

514	died when Laurie was a little child, and then his grandfather took him
514	home.  I fancy the boy, who was born in Italy, is not very strong, and
514	the old man is afraid of losing him, which makes him so careful.

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""What do you know about his eyes and his manners?  You never spoke to"

514	""
514	"""I saw him at the party, and what you tell shows that he knows how to"
514	behave.  That was a nice little speech about the medicine Mother sent
514	"him."""
514	""
514	"""He meant the blanc mange, I suppose."""
514	""
514	"""How stupid you are, child!  He meant you, of course."""
514	""
514	"""Did he?"" And Jo opened her eyes as if it had never occurred to her"

514	""
514	"""I never saw such a girl!  You don't know a compliment when you get"

514	matter.
514	""
514	"""I think they are great nonsense, and I'll thank you not to be silly"
514	and spoil my fun.  Laurie's a nice boy and I like him, and I won't have

514	good to him because he hasn't got any mother, and he may come over and

514	""
514	"""Yes, Jo, your little friend is very welcome, and I hope Meg will"
514	"remember that children should be children as long as they can."""
514	""
514	"""I don't call myself a child, and I'm not in my teens yet,"" observed"
514	"Amy.  ""What do you say, Beth?"""
514	""
514	"""I was thinking about our '_Pilgrim's Progress_',"" answered Beth, who"
514	"had not heard a word.  ""How we got out of the Slough and through the"
514	Wicket Gate by resolving to be good, and up the steep hill by trying,
514	and that maybe the house over there, full of splendid things, is going
514	"to be our Palace Beautiful."""
514	""
514	"""We have got to get by the lions first,"" said Jo, as if she rather"
514	liked the prospect.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER SIX
514	""
514	BETH FINDS THE PALACE BEAUTIFUL
514	""
514	The big house did prove a Palace Beautiful, though it took some time
514	for all to get in, and Beth found it very hard to pass the lions.  Old
514	Mr. Laurence was the biggest one, but after he had called, said
514	something funny or kind to each one of the girls, and talked over old
514	times with their mother, nobody felt much afraid of him, except timid
514	Beth.  The other lion was the fact that they were poor and Laurie rich,
514	for this made them shy of accepting favors which they could not return.
514	But, after a while, they found that he considered them the benefactors,
514	and could not do enough to show how grateful he was for Mrs. March's
514	motherly welcome, their cheerful society, and the comfort he took in
514	that humble home of theirs.  So they soon forgot their pride and
514	interchanged kindnesses without stopping to think which was the greater.
514	""
514	All sorts of pleasant things happened about that time, for the new
514	friendship flourished like grass in spring.  Every one liked Laurie,
514	"and he privately informed his tutor that ""the Marches were regularly"
514	"splendid girls.""  With the delightful enthusiasm of youth, they took"
514	the solitary boy into their midst and made much of him, and he found
514	something very charming in the innocent companionship of these
514	simple-hearted girls.  Never having known mother or sisters, he was
514	quick to feel the influences they brought about him, and their busy,
514	lively ways made him ashamed of the indolent life he led. He was tired
514	of books, and found people so interesting now that Mr. Brooke was
514	obliged to make very unsatisfactory reports, for Laurie was always
514	playing truant and running over to the Marches'.
514	""
514	"""Never mind, let him take a holiday, and make it up afterward,"" said"
514	"the old gentleman.  ""The good lady next door says he is studying too"
514	hard and needs young society, amusement, and exercise.  I suspect she
514	is right, and that I've been coddling the fellow as if I'd been his
514	grandmother.  Let him do what he likes, as long as he is happy. He
514	can't get into mischief in that little nunnery over there, and Mrs.
514	"March is doing more for him than we can."""
514	""
514	What good times they had, to be sure.  Such plays and tableaux, such
514	sleigh rides and skating frolics, such pleasant evenings in the old
514	parlor, and now and then such gay little parties at the great house.
514	Meg could walk in the conservatory whenever she liked and revel in
514	bouquets, Jo browsed over the new library voraciously, and convulsed
514	the old gentleman with her criticisms, Amy copied pictures and enjoyed
514	beauty to her heart's content, and Laurie played 'lord of the manor' in
514	the most delightful style.
514	""
514	But Beth, though yearning for the grand piano, could not pluck up
514	courage to go to the 'Mansion of Bliss', as Meg called it.  She went
514	once with Jo, but the old gentleman, not being aware of her infirmity,
514	"stared at her so hard from under his heavy eyebrows, and said ""Hey!"" so"
514	loud, that he frightened her so much her 'feet chattered on the floor',
514	she never told her mother, and she ran away, declaring she would never
514	go there any more, not even for the dear piano.  No persuasions or
514	enticements could overcome her fear, till, the fact coming to Mr.
514	Laurence's ear in some mysterious way, he set about mending matters.
514	During one of the brief calls he made, he artfully led the conversation
514	to music, and talked away about great singers whom he had seen, fine
514	organs he had heard, and told such charming anecdotes that Beth found
514	it impossible to stay in her distant corner, but crept nearer and
514	nearer, as if fascinated.  At the back of his chair she stopped and
514	stood listening, with her great eyes wide open and her cheeks red with
514	excitement of this unusual performance.  Taking no more notice of her
514	than if she had been a fly, Mr. Laurence talked on about Laurie's
514	lessons and teachers.  And presently, as if the idea had just occurred
514	to him, he said to Mrs. March...
514	""
514	"""The boy neglects his music now, and I'm glad of it, for he was getting"
514	too fond of it.  But the piano suffers for want of use.  Wouldn't some
514	of your girls like to run over, and practice on it now and then, just
514	"to keep it in tune, you know, ma'am?"""
514	""
514	Beth took a step forward, and pressed her hands tightly together to
514	keep from clapping them, for this was an irresistible temptation, and
514	the thought of practicing on that splendid instrument quite took her
514	breath away.  Before Mrs. March could reply, Mr. Laurence went on with
514	an odd little nod and smile...
514	""
514	"""They needn't see or speak to anyone, but run in at any time. For I'm"
514	shut up in my study at the other end of the house, Laurie is out a
514	great deal, and the servants are never near the drawing room after nine
514	"o'clock."""
514	""
514	Here he rose, as if going, and Beth made up her mind to speak, for that
514	"last arrangement left nothing to be desired.  ""Please, tell the young"
514	"ladies what I say, and if they don't care to come, why, never mind."""
514	Here a little hand slipped into his, and Beth looked up at him with a
514	face full of gratitude, as she said, in her earnest yet timid way...
514	""
514	"""Oh sir, they do care, very very much!"""
514	""
514	"""Are you the musical girl?"" he asked, without any startling ""Hey!"" as"
514	he looked down at her very kindly.
514	""
514	"""I'm Beth.  I love it dearly, and I'll come, if you are quite sure"
514	"nobody will hear me, and be disturbed,"" she added, fearing to be rude,"
514	and trembling at her own boldness as she spoke.
514	""
514	"""Not a soul, my dear.  The house is empty half the day, so come and"
514	"drum away as much as you like, and I shall be obliged to you."""
514	""
514	"""How kind you are, sir!"""
514	""
514	Beth blushed like a rose under the friendly look he wore, but she was
514	not frightened now, and gave the hand a grateful squeeze because she
514	had no words to thank him for the precious gift he had given her. The
514	old gentleman softly stroked the hair off her forehead, and, stooping
514	down, he kissed her, saying, in a tone few people ever heard...
514	""
514	"""I had a little girl once, with eyes like these.  God bless you, my"
514	"dear!  Good day, madam.""  And away he went, in a great hurry."
514	""
514	Beth had a rapture with her mother, and then rushed up to impart the
514	glorious news to her family of invalids, as the girls were not home.
514	How blithely she sang that evening, and how they all laughed at her
514	because she woke Amy in the night by playing the piano on her face in
514	her sleep.  Next day, having seen both the old and young gentleman out
514	of the house, Beth, after two or three retreats, fairly got in at the
514	side door, and made her way as noiselessly as any mouse to the drawing
514	room where her idol stood.  Quite by accident, of course, some pretty,
514	easy music lay on the piano, and with trembling fingers and frequent
514	stops to listen and look about, Beth at last touched the great
514	instrument, and straightway forgot her fear, herself, and everything
514	else but the unspeakable delight which the music gave her, for it was
514	like the voice of a beloved friend.
514	""
514	She stayed till Hannah came to take her home to dinner, but she had no
514	appetite, and could only sit and smile upon everyone in a general state
514	of beatitude.
514	""
514	After that, the little brown hood slipped through the hedge nearly
514	every day, and the great drawing room was haunted by a tuneful spirit
514	that came and went unseen.  She never knew that Mr. Laurence opened his
514	study door to hear the old-fashioned airs he liked.  She never saw
514	Laurie mount guard in the hall to warn the servants away. She never
514	suspected that the exercise books and new songs which she found in the
514	rack were put there for her especial benefit, and when he talked to her
514	about music at home, she only thought how kind he was to tell things
514	that helped her so much.  So she enjoyed herself heartily, and found,
514	what isn't always the case, that her granted wish was all she had
514	hoped.  Perhaps it was because she was so grateful for this blessing
514	that a greater was given her.  At any rate she deserved both.
514	""
514	"""Mother, I'm going to work Mr. Laurence a pair of slippers.  He is so"
514	kind to me, I must thank him, and I don't know any other way. Can I do
514	"it?"" asked Beth, a few weeks after that eventful call of his."
514	""
514	"""Yes, dear.  It will please him very much, and be a nice way of"
514	thanking him.  The girls will help you about them, and I will pay for
514	"the making up,"" replied Mrs. March, who took peculiar pleasure in"
514	granting Beth's requests because she so seldom asked anything for
514	herself.
514	""
514	After many serious discussions with Meg and Jo, the pattern was chosen,
514	the materials bought, and the slippers begun.  A cluster of grave yet
514	cheerful pansies on a deeper purple ground was pronounced very
514	appropriate and pretty, and Beth worked away early and late, with
514	occasional lifts over hard parts.  She was a nimble little needlewoman,
514	and they were finished before anyone got tired of them.  Then she wrote
514	a short, simple note, and with Laurie's help, got them smuggled onto
514	the study table one morning before the old gentleman was up.
514	""
514	When this excitement was over, Beth waited to see what would happen.
514	All day passed and a part of the next before any acknowledgement
514	arrived, and she was beginning to fear she had offended her crochety
514	friend.  On the afternoon of the second day, she went out to do an
514	errand, and give poor Joanna, the invalid doll, her daily exercise.  As
514	she came up the street, on her return, she saw three, yes, four heads
514	popping in and out of the parlor windows, and the moment they saw her,
514	several hands were waved, and several joyful voices screamed...
514	""
514	"""Here's a letter from the old gentleman!  Come quick, and read it!"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Beth, he's sent you..."" began Amy, gesticulating with unseemly"
514	energy, but she got no further, for Jo quenched her by slamming down
514	the window.
514	""
514	Beth hurried on in a flutter of suspense.  At the door her sisters
514	seized and bore her to the parlor in a triumphal procession, all
514	"pointing and all saying at once, ""Look there!  Look there!""  Beth did"
514	look, and turned pale with delight and surprise, for there stood a
514	little cabinet piano, with a letter lying on the glossy lid, directed
514	"like a sign board to ""Miss Elizabeth March."""
514	""
514	"""For me?"" gasped Beth, holding onto Jo and feeling as if she should"
514	tumble down, it was such an overwhelming thing altogether.
514	""
514	"""Yes, all for you, my precious!  Isn't it splendid of him?  Don't you"
514	think he's the dearest old man in the world?  Here's the key in the
514	"letter.  We didn't open it, but we are dying to know what he says,"""
514	cried Jo, hugging her sister and offering the note.
514	""
514	"""You read it!  I can't, I feel so queer!  Oh, it is too lovely!"" and"
514	Beth hid her face in Jo's apron, quite upset by her present.
514	""
514	Jo opened the paper and began to laugh, for the first words she saw
514	were...
514	""
514	"""Miss March: ""Dear Madam--"""
514	""
514	"""How nice it sounds!  I wish someone would write to me so!"" said Amy,"
514	who thought the old-fashioned address very elegant.
514	""
514	"""'I have had many pairs of slippers in my life, but I never had any"
514	"that suited me so well as yours,'"" continues Jo.  ""'Heart's-ease is my"
514	favorite flower, and these will always remind me of the gentle giver.
514	I like to pay my debts, so I know you will allow 'the old gentleman' to
514	send you something which once belonged to the little grand daughter he
514	"lost.  With hearty thanks and best wishes, I remain ""'Your grateful"
514	"friend and humble servant, 'JAMES LAURENCE'."""
514	""
514	"""There, Beth, that's an honor to be proud of, I'm sure! Laurie told me"
514	how fond Mr. Laurence used to be of the child who died, and how he kept
514	all her little things carefully.  Just think, he's given you her piano.
514	"That comes of having big blue eyes and loving music,"" said Jo, trying"
514	to soothe Beth, who trembled and looked more excited than she had ever
514	been before.
514	""
514	"""See the cunning brackets to hold candles, and the nice green silk,"
514	puckered up, with a gold rose in the middle, and the pretty rack and
514	"stool, all complete,"" added Meg, opening the instrument and displaying"
514	its beauties.
514	""
514	"""'Your humble servant, James Laurence'.  Only think of his writing that"
514	"to you.  I'll tell the girls.  They'll think it's splendid,"" said Amy,"
514	much impressed by the note.
514	""
514	"""Try it, honey.  Let's hear the sound of the baby pianny,"" said Hannah,"
514	who always took a share in the family joys and sorrows.
514	""
514	So Beth tried it, and everyone pronounced it the most remarkable piano
514	ever heard.  It had evidently been newly tuned and put in apple-pie
514	order, but, perfect as it was, I think the real charm lay in the
514	happiest of all happy faces which leaned over it, as Beth lovingly
514	touched the beautiful black and white keys and pressed the bright
514	pedals.
514	""
514	"""You'll have to go and thank him,"" said Jo, by way of a joke, for the"
514	idea of the child's really going never entered her head.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I mean to.  I guess I'll go now, before I get frightened thinking"
514	"about it."" And, to the utter amazement of the assembled family, Beth"
514	walked deliberately down the garden, through the hedge, and in at the
514	Laurences' door.
514	""
514	"""Well, I wish I may die if it ain't the queerest thing I ever see!  The"
514	"pianny has turned her head!  She'd never have gone in her right mind,"""
514	cried Hannah, staring after her, while the girls were rendered quite
514	speechless by the miracle.
514	""
514	They would have been still more amazed if they had seen what Beth did
514	afterward.  If you will believe me, she went and knocked at the study
514	door before she gave herself time to think, and when a gruff voice
514	"called out, ""come in!"" she did go in, right up to Mr. Laurence, who"
514	looked quite taken aback, and held out her hand, saying, with only a
514	"small quaver in her voice, ""I came to thank you, sir, for..."" But she"
514	didn't finish, for he looked so friendly that she forgot her speech
514	and, only remembering that he had lost the little girl he loved, she
514	put both arms round his neck and kissed him.
514	""
514	If the roof of the house had suddenly flown off, the old gentleman
514	wouldn't have been more astonished.  But he liked it. Oh, dear, yes, he
514	liked it amazingly!  And was so touched and pleased by that confiding
514	little kiss that all his crustiness vanished, and he just set her on
514	his knee, and laid his wrinkled cheek against her rosy one, feeling as
514	if he had got his own little granddaughter back again.  Beth ceased to
514	fear him from that moment, and sat there talking to him as cozily as if
514	she had known him all her life, for love casts out fear, and gratitude
514	can conquer pride.  When she went home, he walked with her to her own
514	gate, shook hands cordially, and touched his hat as he marched back
514	again, looking very stately and erect, like a handsome, soldierly old
514	gentleman, as he was.
514	""
514	When the girls saw that performance, Jo began to dance a jig, by way of
514	expressing her satisfaction, Amy nearly fell out of the window in her
514	"surprise, and Meg exclaimed, with up-lifted hands, ""Well, I do believe"
514	"the world is coming to an end."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER SEVEN
514	""
514	AMY'S VALLEY OF HUMILIATION
514	""
514	"""That boy is a perfect cyclops, isn't he?"" said Amy one day, as Laurie"
514	clattered by on horseback, with a flourish of his whip as he passed.
514	""
514	"""How dare you say so, when he's got both his eyes?  And very handsome"
514	"ones they are, too,"" cried Jo, who resented any slighting remarks about"
514	her friend.
514	""
514	"""I didn't say anything about his eyes, and I don't see why you need"
514	"fire up when I admire his riding."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, my goodness!  That little goose means a centaur, and she called"
514	"him a Cyclops,"" exclaimed Jo, with a burst of laughter."
514	""
514	"""You needn't be so rude, it's only a 'lapse of lingy', as Mr. Davis"
514	"says,"" retorted Amy, finishing Jo with her Latin.  ""I just wish I had a"
514	"little of the money Laurie spends on that horse,"" she added, as if to"
514	herself, yet hoping her sisters would hear.
514	""
514	"""Why?"" asked Meg kindly, for Jo had gone off in another laugh at Amy's"
514	second blunder.
514	""
514	"""I need it so much.  I'm dreadfully in debt, and it won't be my turn to"
514	"have the rag money for a month."""
514	""
514	"""In debt, Amy?  What do you mean?"" And Meg looked sober."
514	""
514	"""Why, I owe at least a dozen pickled limes, and I can't pay them, you"
514	know, till I have money, for Marmee forbade my having anything charged
514	"at the shop."""
514	""
514	"""Tell me all about it.  Are limes the fashion now?  It used to be"
514	"pricking bits of rubber to make balls.""  And Meg tried to keep her"
514	countenance, Amy looked so grave and important.
514	""
514	"""Why, you see, the girls are always buying them, and unless you want to"
514	be thought mean, you must do it too.  It's nothing but limes now, for
514	everyone is sucking them in their desks in schooltime, and trading them
514	off for pencils, bead rings, paper dolls, or something else, at recess.
514	If one girl likes another, she gives her a lime.  If she's mad with
514	her, she eats one before her face, and doesn't offer even a suck.  They
514	treat by turns, and I've had ever so many but haven't returned them,
514	"and I ought for they are debts of honor, you know."""
514	""
514	"""How much will pay them off and restore your credit?"" asked Meg, taking"
514	out her purse.
514	""
514	"""A quarter would more than do it, and leave a few cents over for a"
514	"treat for you.  Don't you like limes?"""
514	""
514	"""Not much.  You may have my share.  Here's the money.  Make it last as"
514	"long as you can, for it isn't very plenty, you know."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, thank you!  It must be so nice to have pocket money!  I'll have a"
514	grand feast, for I haven't tasted a lime this week.  I felt delicate
514	about taking any, as I couldn't return them, and I'm actually suffering
514	"for one."""
514	""
514	Next day Amy was rather late at school, but could not resist the
514	temptation of displaying, with pardonable pride, a moist brown-paper
514	parcel, before she consigned it to the inmost recesses of her desk.
514	During the next few minutes the rumor that Amy March had got
514	twenty-four delicious limes (she ate one on the way) and was going to
514	treat circulated through her 'set', and the attentions of her friends
514	became quite overwhelming.  Katy Brown invited her to her next party on
514	the spot.  Mary Kingsley insisted on lending her her watch till recess,
514	and Jenny Snow, a satirical young lady, who had basely twitted Amy upon
514	her limeless state, promptly buried the hatchet and offered to furnish
514	answers to certain appalling sums.  But Amy had not forgotten Miss
514	Snow's cutting remarks about 'some persons whose noses were not too
514	flat to smell other people's limes, and stuck-up people who were not
514	too proud to ask for them', and she instantly crushed 'that Snow
514	"girl's' hopes by the withering telegram, ""You needn't be so polite all"
514	"of a sudden, for you won't get any."""
514	""
514	A distinguished personage happened to visit the school that morning,
514	and Amy's beautifully drawn maps received praise, which honor to her
514	foe rankled in the soul of Miss Snow, and caused Miss March to assume
514	the airs of a studious young peacock.  But, alas, alas!  Pride goes
514	before a fall, and the revengeful Snow turned the tables with
514	disastrous success.  No sooner had the guest paid the usual stale
514	compliments and bowed himself out, than Jenny, under pretense of asking
514	an important question, informed Mr. Davis, the teacher, that Amy March
514	had pickled limes in her desk.
514	""
514	Now Mr. Davis had declared limes a contraband article, and solemnly
514	vowed to publicly ferrule the first person who was found breaking the
514	law.  This much-enduring man had succeeded in banishing chewing gum
514	after a long and stormy war, had made a bonfire of the confiscated
514	novels and newspapers, had suppressed a private post office, had
514	forbidden distortions of the face, nicknames, and caricatures, and done
514	all that one man could do to keep half a hundred rebellious girls in
514	order.  Boys are trying enough to human patience, goodness knows, but
514	girls are infinitely more so, especially to nervous gentlemen with
514	tyrannical tempers and no more talent for teaching than Dr. Blimber.
514	Mr. Davis knew any quantity of Greek, Latin, algebra, and ologies of
514	all sorts so he was called a fine teacher, and manners, morals,
514	feelings, and examples were not considered of any particular
514	importance.  It was a most unfortunate moment for denouncing Amy, and
514	Jenny knew it.  Mr. Davis had evidently taken his coffee too strong
514	that morning, there was an east wind, which always affected his
514	neuralgia, and his pupils had not done him the credit which he felt he
514	deserved.  Therefore, to use the expressive, if not elegant, language
514	"of a schoolgirl, ""He was as nervous as a witch and as cross as a bear""."
514	The word 'limes' was like fire to powder, his yellow face flushed, and
514	he rapped on his desk with an energy which made Jenny skip to her seat
514	with unusual rapidity.
514	""
514	"""Young ladies, attention, if you please!"""
514	""
514	At the stern order the buzz ceased, and fifty pairs of blue, black,
514	gray, and brown eyes were obediently fixed upon his awful countenance.
514	""
514	"""Miss March, come to the desk."""
514	""
514	Amy rose to comply with outward composure, but a secret fear oppressed
514	her, for the limes weighed upon her conscience.
514	""
514	"""Bring with you the limes you have in your desk,"" was the unexpected"
514	command which arrested her before she got out of her seat.
514	""
514	"""Don't take all."" whispered her neighbor, a young lady of great"
514	presence of mind.
514	""
514	Amy hastily shook out half a dozen and laid the rest down before Mr.
514	Davis, feeling that any man possessing a human heart would relent when
514	that delicious perfume met his nose.  Unfortunately, Mr. Davis
514	particularly detested the odor of the fashionable pickle, and disgust
514	added to his wrath.
514	""
514	"""Is that all?"""
514	""
514	"""Not quite,"" stammered Amy."
514	""
514	"""Bring the rest immediately."""
514	""
514	With a despairing glance at her set, she obeyed.
514	""
514	"""You are sure there are no more?"""
514	""
514	"""I never lie, sir."""
514	""
514	"""So I see.  Now take these disgusting things two by two, and throw them"
514	"out of the window."""
514	""
514	There was a simultaneous sigh, which created quite a little gust, as
514	the last hope fled, and the treat was ravished from their longing lips.
514	Scarlet with shame and anger, Amy went to and fro six dreadful times,
514	and as each doomed couple, looking oh, so plump and juicy, fell from
514	her reluctant hands, a shout from the street completed the anguish of
514	the girls, for it told them that their feast was being exulted over by
514	the little Irish children, who were their sworn foes.  This--this was
514	too much.  All flashed indignant or appealing glances at the inexorable
514	Davis, and one passionate lime lover burst into tears.
514	""
514	"As Amy returned from her last trip, Mr. Davis gave a portentous ""Hem!"""
514	and said, in his most impressive manner...
514	""
514	"""Young ladies, you remember what I said to you a week ago.  I am sorry"
514	this has happened, but I never allow my rules to be infringed, and I
514	"never break my word.  Miss March, hold out your hand."""
514	""
514	Amy started, and put both hands behind her, turning on him an imploring
514	look which pleaded for her better than the words she could not utter.
514	She was rather a favorite with 'old Davis', as, of course, he was
514	called, and it's my private belief that he would have broken his word
514	if the indignation of one irrepressible young lady had not found vent
514	in a hiss.  That hiss, faint as it was, irritated the irascible
514	gentleman, and sealed the culprit's fate.
514	""
514	"""Your hand, Miss March!"" was the only answer her mute appeal received,"
514	and too proud to cry or beseech, Amy set her teeth, threw back her head
514	defiantly, and bore without flinching several tingling blows on her
514	little palm.  They were neither many nor heavy, but that made no
514	difference to her.  For the first time in her life she had been struck,
514	and the disgrace, in her eyes, was as deep as if he had knocked her
514	down.
514	""
514	"""You will now stand on the platform till recess,"" said Mr. Davis,"
514	resolved to do the thing thoroughly, since he had begun.
514	""
514	That was dreadful.  It would have been bad enough to go to her seat,
514	and see the pitying faces of her friends, or the satisfied ones of her
514	few enemies, but to face the whole school, with that shame fresh upon
514	her, seemed impossible, and for a second she felt as if she could only
514	drop down where she stood, and break her heart with crying.  A bitter
514	sense of wrong and the thought of Jenny Snow helped her to bear it,
514	and, taking the ignominious place, she fixed her eyes on the stove
514	funnel above what now seemed a sea of faces, and stood there, so
514	motionless and white that the girls found it hard to study with that
514	pathetic figure before them.
514	""
514	During the fifteen minutes that followed, the proud and sensitive
514	little girl suffered a shame and pain which she never forgot.  To
514	others it might seem a ludicrous or trivial affair, but to her it was a
514	hard experience, for during the twelve years of her life she had been
514	governed by love alone, and a blow of that sort had never touched her
514	before.  The smart of her hand and the ache of her heart were forgotten
514	"in the sting of the thought, ""I shall have to tell at home, and they"
514	"will be so disappointed in me!"""
514	""
514	The fifteen minutes seemed an hour, but they came to an end at last,
514	and the word 'Recess!' had never seemed so welcome to her before.
514	""
514	"""You can go, Miss March,"" said Mr. Davis, looking, as he felt,"
514	uncomfortable.
514	""
514	He did not soon forget the reproachful glance Amy gave him, as she
514	went, without a word to anyone, straight into the anteroom, snatched
514	"her things, and left the place ""forever,"" as she passionately declared"
514	to herself.  She was in a sad state when she got home, and when the
514	older girls arrived, some time later, an indignation meeting was held
514	at once.  Mrs. March did not say much but looked disturbed, and
514	comforted her afflicted little daughter in her tenderest manner. Meg
514	bathed the insulted hand with glycerine and tears, Beth felt that even
514	her beloved kittens would fail as a balm for griefs like this, Jo
514	wrathfully proposed that Mr. Davis be arrested without delay, and
514	Hannah shook her fist at the 'villain' and pounded potatoes for dinner
514	as if she had him under her pestle.
514	""
514	No notice was taken of Amy's flight, except by her mates, but the
514	sharp-eyed demoiselles discovered that Mr. Davis was quite benignant in
514	the afternoon, also unusually nervous.  Just before school closed, Jo
514	appeared, wearing a grim expression as she stalked up to the desk, and
514	delivered a letter from her mother, then collected Amy's property, and
514	departed, carefully scraping the mud from her boots on the door mat, as
514	if she shook the dust of the place off her feet.
514	""
514	"""Yes, you can have a vacation from school, but I want you to study a"
514	"little every day with Beth,"" said Mrs. March that evening. ""I don't"
514	approve of corporal punishment, especially for girls.  I dislike Mr.
514	Davis's manner of teaching and don't think the girls you associate with
514	are doing you any good, so I shall ask your father's advice before I
514	"send you anywhere else."""
514	""
514	"""That's good!  I wish all the girls would leave, and spoil his old"
514	"school.  It's perfectly maddening to think of those lovely limes,"""
514	sighed Amy, with the air of a martyr.
514	""
514	"""I am not sorry you lost them, for you broke the rules, and deserved"
514	"some punishment for disobedience,"" was the severe reply, which rather"
514	disappointed the young lady, who expected nothing but sympathy.
514	""
514	"""Do you mean you are glad I was disgraced before the whole school?"""
514	cried Amy.
514	""
514	"""I should not have chosen that way of mending a fault,"" replied her"
514	"mother, ""but I'm not sure that it won't do you more good than a bolder"
514	method.  You are getting to be rather conceited, my dear, and it is
514	quite time you set about correcting it.  You have a good many little
514	gifts and virtues, but there is no need of parading them, for conceit
514	spoils the finest genius.  There is not much danger that real talent or
514	goodness will be overlooked long, even if it is, the consciousness of
514	possessing and using it well should satisfy one, and the great charm of
514	"all power is modesty."""
514	""
514	"""So it is!"" cried Laurie, who was playing chess in a corner with Jo."
514	"""I knew a girl once, who had a really remarkable talent for music, and"
514	she didn't know it, never guessed what sweet little things she composed
514	when she was alone, and wouldn't have believed it if anyone had told
514	"her."""
514	""
514	"""I wish I'd known that nice girl.  Maybe she would have helped me, I'm"
514	"so stupid,"" said Beth, who stood beside him, listening eagerly."
514	""
514	"""You do know her, and she helps you better than anyone else could,"""
514	answered Laurie, looking at her with such mischievous meaning in his
514	merry black eyes that Beth suddenly turned very red, and hid her face
514	in the sofa cushion, quite overcome by such an unexpected discovery.
514	""
514	Jo let Laurie win the game to pay for that praise of her Beth, who
514	could not be prevailed upon to play for them after her compliment. So
514	Laurie did his best, and sang delightfully, being in a particularly
514	lively humor, for to the Marches he seldom showed the moody side of his
514	character.  When he was gone, Amy, who had been pensive all evening,
514	"said suddenly, as if busy over some new idea, ""Is Laurie an"
514	"accomplished boy?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, he has had an excellent education, and has much talent. He will"
514	"make a fine man, if not spoiled by petting,"" replied her mother."
514	""
514	"""And he isn't conceited, is he?"" asked Amy."
514	""
514	"""Not in the least.  That is why he is so charming and we all like him"
514	"so much."""
514	""
514	"""I see.  It's nice to have accomplishments and be elegant, but not to"
514	"show off or get perked up,"" said Amy thoughtfully."
514	""
514	"""These things are always seen and felt in a person's manner and"
514	conversations, if modestly used, but it is not necessary to display
514	"them,"" said Mrs. March."
514	""
514	"""Any more than it's proper to wear all your bonnets and gowns and"
514	"ribbons at once, that folks may know you've got them,"" added Jo, and"
514	the lecture ended in a laugh.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER EIGHT
514	""
514	JO MEETS APOLLYON
514	""
514	"""Girls, where are you going?"" asked Amy, coming into their room one"
514	Saturday afternoon, and finding them getting ready to go out with an
514	air of secrecy which excited her curiosity.
514	""
514	"""Never mind.  Little girls shouldn't ask questions,"" returned Jo"
514	sharply.
514	""
514	Now if there is anything mortifying to our feelings when we are young,
514	"it is to be told that, and to be bidden to ""run away, dear"" is still"
514	more trying to us.  Amy bridled up at this insult, and determined to
514	find out the secret, if she teased for an hour. Turning to Meg, who
514	"never refused her anything very long, she said coaxingly, ""Do tell me!"
514	I should think you might let me go, too, for Beth is fussing over her
514	"piano, and I haven't got anything to do, and am so lonely."""
514	""
514	"""I can't, dear, because you aren't invited,"" began Meg, but Jo broke in"
514	"impatiently, ""Now, Meg, be quiet or you will spoil it all.  You can't"
514	"go, Amy, so don't be a baby and whine about it."""
514	""
514	"""You are going somewhere with Laurie, I know you are.  You were"
514	whispering and laughing together on the sofa last night, and you
514	"stopped when I came in.  Aren't you going with him?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, we are.  Now do be still, and stop bothering."""
514	""
514	Amy held her tongue, but used her eyes, and saw Meg slip a fan into her
514	pocket.
514	""
514	"""I know!  I know!  You're going to the theater to see the _Seven"
514	"Castles!_"" she cried, adding resolutely, ""and I shall go, for Mother"
514	said I might see it, and I've got my rag money, and it was mean not to
514	"tell me in time."""
514	""
514	"""Just listen to me a minute, and be a good child,"" said Meg soothingly."
514	"""Mother doesn't wish you to go this week, because your eyes are not"
514	well enough yet to bear the light of this fairy piece.  Next week you
514	"can go with Beth and Hannah, and have a nice time."""
514	""
514	"""I don't like that half as well as going with you and Laurie. Please"
514	let me.  I've been sick with this cold so long, and shut up, I'm dying
514	"for some fun.  Do, Meg!  I'll be ever so good,"" pleaded Amy, looking as"
514	pathetic as she could.
514	""
514	"""Suppose we take her.  I don't believe Mother would mind, if we bundle"
514	"her up well,"" began Meg."
514	""
514	"""If she goes I shan't, and if I don't, Laurie won't like it, and it"
514	will be very rude, after he invited only us, to go and drag in Amy.  I
514	"should think she'd hate to poke herself where she isn't wanted,"" said"
514	Jo crossly, for she disliked the trouble of overseeing a fidgety child
514	when she wanted to enjoy herself.
514	""
514	Her tone and manner angered Amy, who began to put her boots on, saying,
514	"in her most aggravating way, ""I shall go.  Meg says I may, and if I pay"
514	"for myself, Laurie hasn't anything to do with it."""
514	""
514	"""You can't sit with us, for our seats are reserved, and you mustn't sit"
514	alone, so Laurie will give you his place, and that will spoil our
514	pleasure.  Or he'll get another seat for you, and that isn't proper
514	when you weren't asked.  You shan't stir a step, so you may just stay
514	"where you are,"" scolded Jo, crosser than ever, having just pricked her"
514	finger in her hurry.
514	""
514	Sitting on the floor with one boot on, Amy began to cry and Meg to
514	reason with her, when Laurie called from below, and the two girls
514	hurried down, leaving their sister wailing.  For now and then she
514	forgot her grown-up ways and acted like a spoiled child.  Just as the
514	party was setting out, Amy called over the banisters in a threatening
514	"tone, ""You'll be sorry for this, Jo March, see if you ain't."""
514	""
514	"""Fiddlesticks!"" returned Jo, slamming the door."
514	""
514	They had a charming time, for _The Seven Castles Of The Diamond Lake_
514	was as brilliant and wonderful as heart could wish. But in spite of the
514	comical red imps, sparkling elves, and the gorgeous princes and
514	princesses, Jo's pleasure had a drop of bitterness in it.  The fairy
514	queen's yellow curls reminded her of Amy, and between the acts she
514	amused herself with wondering what her sister would do to make her
514	'sorry for it'.  She and Amy had had many lively skirmishes in the
514	course of their lives, for both had quick tempers and were apt to be
514	violent when fairly roused.  Amy teased Jo, and Jo irritated Amy, and
514	semioccasional explosions occurred, of which both were much ashamed
514	afterward. Although the oldest, Jo had the least self-control, and had
514	hard times trying to curb the fiery spirit which was continually
514	getting her into trouble.  Her anger never lasted long, and having
514	humbly confessed her fault, she sincerely repented and tried to do
514	better. Her sisters used to say that they rather liked to get Jo into a
514	fury because she was such an angel afterward.  Poor Jo tried
514	desperately to be good, but her bosom enemy was always ready to flame
514	up and defeat her, and it took years of patient effort to subdue it.
514	""
514	When they got home, they found Amy reading in the parlor. She assumed
514	an injured air as they came in, never lifted her eyes from her book, or
514	asked a single question.  Perhaps curiosity might have conquered
514	resentment, if Beth had not been there to inquire and receive a glowing
514	description of the play.  On going up to put away her best hat, Jo's
514	first look was toward the bureau, for in their last quarrel Amy had
514	soothed her feelings by turning Jo's top drawer upside down on the
514	floor.  Everything was in its place, however, and after a hasty glance
514	into her various closets, bags, and boxes, Jo decided that Amy had
514	forgiven and forgotten her wrongs.
514	""
514	There Jo was mistaken, for next day she made a discovery which produced
514	a tempest.  Meg, Beth, and Amy were sitting together, late in the
514	afternoon, when Jo burst into the room, looking excited and demanding
514	"breathlessly, ""Has anyone taken my book?"""
514	""
514	"Meg and Beth said, ""No."" at once, and looked surprised.  Amy poked the"
514	fire and said nothing.  Jo saw her color rise and was down upon her in
514	a minute.
514	""
514	"""Amy, you've got it!"""
514	""
514	"""No, I haven't."""
514	""
514	"""You know where it is, then!"""
514	""
514	"""No, I don't."""
514	""
514	"""That's a fib!"" cried Jo, taking her by the shoulders, and looking"
514	fierce enough to frighten a much braver child than Amy.
514	""
514	"""It isn't.  I haven't got it, don't know where it is now, and don't"
514	"care."""
514	""
514	"""You know something about it, and you'd better tell at once, or I'll"
514	"make you.""  And Jo gave her a slight shake."
514	""
514	"""Scold as much as you like, you'll never see your silly old book"
514	"again,"" cried Amy, getting excited in her turn."
514	""
514	"""Why not?"""
514	""
514	"""I burned it up."""
514	""
514	"""What!  My little book I was so fond of, and worked over, and meant to"
514	"finish before Father got home?  Have you really burned it?"" said Jo,"
514	turning very pale, while her eyes kindled and her hands clutched Amy
514	nervously.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I did!  I told you I'd make you pay for being so cross yesterday,"
514	"and I have, so..."""
514	""
514	Amy got no farther, for Jo's hot temper mastered her, and she shook Amy
514	till her teeth chattered in her head, crying in a passion of grief and
514	anger...
514	""
514	"""You wicked, wicked girl!  I never can write it again, and I'll never"
514	"forgive you as long as I live."""
514	""
514	Meg flew to rescue Amy, and Beth to pacify Jo, but Jo was quite beside
514	herself, and with a parting box on her sister's ear, she rushed out of
514	the room up to the old sofa in the garret, and finished her fight alone.
514	""
514	The storm cleared up below, for Mrs. March came home, and, having heard
514	the story, soon brought Amy to a sense of the wrong she had done her
514	sister.  Jo's book was the pride of her heart, and was regarded by her
514	family as a literary sprout of great promise.  It was only half a dozen
514	little fairy tales, but Jo had worked over them patiently, putting her
514	whole heart into her work, hoping to make something good enough to
514	print.  She had just copied them with great care, and had destroyed the
514	old manuscript, so that Amy's bonfire had consumed the loving work of
514	several years.  It seemed a small loss to others, but to Jo it was a
514	dreadful calamity, and she felt that it never could be made up to her.
514	Beth mourned as for a departed kitten, and Meg refused to defend her
514	pet.  Mrs. March looked grave and grieved, and Amy felt that no one
514	would love her till she had asked pardon for the act which she now
514	regretted more than any of them.
514	""
514	When the tea bell rang, Jo appeared, looking so grim and unapproachable
514	that it took all Amy's courage to say meekly...
514	""
514	"""Please forgive me, Jo.  I'm very, very sorry."""
514	""
514	"""I never shall forgive you,"" was Jo's stern answer, and from that"
514	moment she ignored Amy entirely.
514	""
514	No one spoke of the great trouble, not even Mrs. March, for all had
514	learned by experience that when Jo was in that mood words were wasted,
514	and the wisest course was to wait till some little accident, or her own
514	generous nature, softened Jo's resentment and healed the breach.  It
514	was not a happy evening, for though they sewed as usual, while their
514	mother read aloud from Bremer, Scott, or Edgeworth, something was
514	wanting, and the sweet home peace was disturbed.  They felt this most
514	when singing time came, for Beth could only play, Jo stood dumb as a
514	stone, and Amy broke down, so Meg and Mother sang alone.  But in spite
514	of their efforts to be as cheery as larks, the flutelike voices did not
514	seem to chord as well as usual, and all felt out of tune.
514	""
514	"As Jo received her good-night kiss, Mrs. March whispered gently, ""My"
514	dear, don't let the sun go down upon your anger.  Forgive each other,
514	"help each other, and begin again tomorrow."""
514	""
514	Jo wanted to lay her head down on that motherly bosom, and cry her
514	grief and anger all away, but tears were an unmanly weakness, and she
514	felt so deeply injured that she really couldn't quite forgive yet.  So
514	she winked hard, shook her head, and said gruffly because Amy was
514	"listening, ""It was an abominable thing, and she doesn't deserve to be"
514	"forgiven."""
514	""
514	With that she marched off to bed, and there was no merry or
514	confidential gossip that night.
514	""
514	Amy was much offended that her overtures of peace had been repulsed,
514	and began to wish she had not humbled herself, to feel more injured
514	than ever, and to plume herself on her superior virtue in a way which
514	was particularly exasperating.  Jo still looked like a thunder cloud,
514	and nothing went well all day.  It was bitter cold in the morning, she
514	dropped her precious turnover in the gutter, Aunt March had an attack
514	of the fidgets, Meg was sensitive, Beth would look grieved and wistful
514	when she got home, and Amy kept making remarks about people who were
514	always talking about being good and yet wouldn't even try when other
514	people set them a virtuous example.
514	""
514	"""Everybody is so hateful, I'll ask Laurie to go skating.  He is always"
514	"kind and jolly, and will put me to rights, I know,"" said Jo to herself,"
514	and off she went.
514	""
514	Amy heard the clash of skates, and looked out with an impatient
514	exclamation.
514	""
514	"""There!  She promised I should go next time, for this is the last ice"
514	"we shall have.  But it's no use to ask such a crosspatch to take me."""
514	""
514	"""Don't say that.  You were very naughty, and it is hard to forgive the"
514	loss of her precious little book, but I think she might do it now, and
514	"I guess she will, if you try her at the right minute,"" said Meg.  ""Go"
514	after them.  Don't say anything till Jo has got good-natured with
514	Laurie, than take a quiet minute and just kiss her, or do some kind
514	"thing, and I'm sure she'll be friends again with all her heart."""
514	""
514	"""I'll try,"" said Amy, for the advice suited her, and after a flurry to"
514	get ready, she ran after the friends, who were just disappearing over
514	the hill.
514	""
514	It was not far to the river, but both were ready before Amy reached
514	them.  Jo saw her coming, and turned her back.  Laurie did not see, for
514	he was carefully skating along the shore, sounding the ice, for a warm
514	spell had preceded the cold snap.
514	""
514	"""I'll go on to the first bend, and see if it's all right before we"
514	"begin to race,"" Amy heard him say, as he shot away, looking like a"
514	young Russian in his fur-trimmed coat and cap.
514	""
514	Jo heard Amy panting after her run, stamping her feet and blowing on
514	her fingers as she tried to put her skates on, but Jo never turned and
514	went slowly zigzagging down the river, taking a bitter, unhappy sort of
514	satisfaction in her sister's troubles. She had cherished her anger till
514	it grew strong and took possession of her, as evil thoughts and
514	feelings always do unless cast out at once.  As Laurie turned the bend,
514	he shouted back...
514	""
514	"""Keep near the shore.  It isn't safe in the middle."" Jo heard, but Amy"
514	was struggling to her feet and did not catch a word.  Jo glanced over
514	her shoulder, and the little demon she was harboring said in her ear...
514	""
514	"""No matter whether she heard or not, let her take care of herself."""
514	""
514	Laurie had vanished round the bend, Jo was just at the turn, and Amy,
514	far behind, striking out toward the smoother ice in the middle of the
