514	river.  For a minute Jo stood still with a strange feeling in her
514	heart, then she resolved to go on, but something held and turned her
514	round, just in time to see Amy throw up her hands and go down, with a
514	sudden crash of rotten ice, the splash of water, and a cry that made
514	Jo's heart stand still with fear.  She tried to call Laurie, but her
514	voice was gone.  She tried to rush forward, but her feet seemed to have
514	no strength in them, and for a second, she could only stand motionless,
514	staring with a terror-stricken face at the little blue hood above the
514	black water. Something rushed swiftly by her, and Laurie's voice cried
514	out...
514	""
514	"""Bring a rail.  Quick, quick!"""
514	""
514	How she did it, she never knew, but for the next few minutes she worked
514	as if possessed, blindly obeying Laurie, who was quite self-possessed,
514	and lying flat, held Amy up by his arm and hockey stick till Jo dragged
514	a rail from the fence, and together they got the child out, more
514	frightened than hurt.
514	""
514	"""Now then, we must walk her home as fast as we can.  Pile our things on"
514	"her, while I get off these confounded skates,"" cried Laurie, wrapping"
514	his coat round Amy, and tugging away at the straps which never seemed
514	so intricate before.
514	""
514	Shivering, dripping, and crying, they got Amy home, and after an
514	exciting time of it, she fell asleep, rolled in blankets before a hot
514	fire.  During the bustle Jo had scarcely spoken but flown about,
514	looking pale and wild, with her things half off, her dress torn, and
514	her hands cut and bruised by ice and rails and refractory buckles. When
514	Amy was comfortably asleep, the house quiet, and Mrs. March sitting by
514	the bed, she called Jo to her and began to bind up the hurt hands.
514	""
514	"""Are you sure she is safe?"" whispered Jo, looking remorsefully at the"
514	golden head, which might have been swept away from her sight forever
514	under the treacherous ice.
514	""
514	"""Quite safe, dear.  She is not hurt, and won't even take cold, I think,"
514	"you were so sensible in covering and getting her home quickly,"" replied"
514	her mother cheerfully.
514	""
514	"""Laurie did it all.  I only let her go.  Mother, if she should die, it"
514	"would be my fault.""  And Jo dropped down beside the bed in a passion of"
514	penitent tears, telling all that had happened, bitterly condemning her
514	hardness of heart, and sobbing out her gratitude for being spared the
514	heavy punishment which might have come upon her.
514	""
514	"""It's my dreadful temper!  I try to cure it, I think I have, and then"
514	it breaks out worse than ever.  Oh, Mother, what shall I do?  What
514	"shall I do?"" cried poor Jo, in despair."
514	""
514	"""Watch and pray, dear, never get tired of trying, and never think it is"
514	"impossible to conquer your fault,"" said Mrs. March, drawing the blowzy"
514	head to her shoulder and kissing the wet cheek so tenderly that Jo
514	cried even harder.
514	""
514	"""You don't know, you can't guess how bad it is!  It seems as if I could"
514	do anything when I'm in a passion.  I get so savage, I could hurt
514	anyone and enjoy it.  I'm afraid I shall do something dreadful some
514	day, and spoil my life, and make everybody hate me. Oh, Mother, help
514	"me, do help me!"""
514	""
514	"""I will, my child, I will.  Don't cry so bitterly, but remember this"
514	day, and resolve with all your soul that you will never know another
514	like it.  Jo, dear, we all have our temptations, some far greater than
514	yours, and it often takes us all our lives to conquer them.  You think
514	your temper is the worst in the world, but mine used to be just like
514	"it."""
514	""
514	"""Yours, Mother?  Why, you are never angry!""  And for the moment Jo"
514	forgot remorse in surprise.
514	""
514	"""I've been trying to cure it for forty years, and have only succeeded"
514	in controlling it.  I am angry nearly every day of my life, Jo, but I
514	have learned not to show it, and I still hope to learn not to feel it,
514	"though it may take me another forty years to do so."""
514	""
514	The patience and the humility of the face she loved so well was a
514	better lesson to Jo than the wisest lecture, the sharpest reproof.  She
514	felt comforted at once by the sympathy and confidence given her.  The
514	knowledge that her mother had a fault like hers, and tried to mend it,
514	made her own easier to bear and strengthened her resolution to cure it,
514	though forty years seemed rather a long time to watch and pray to a
514	girl of fifteen.
514	""
514	"""Mother, are you angry when you fold your lips tight together and go"
514	"out of the room sometimes, when Aunt March scolds or people worry you?"""
514	asked Jo, feeling nearer and dearer to her mother than ever before.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I've learned to check the hasty words that rise to my lips, and"
514	when I feel that they mean to break out against my will, I just go away
514	for a minute, and give myself a little shake for being so weak and
514	"wicked,"" answered Mrs. March with a sigh and a smile, as she smoothed"
514	and fastened up Jo's disheveled hair.
514	""
514	"""How did you learn to keep still?  That is what troubles me, for the"
514	sharp words fly out before I know what I'm about, and the more I say
514	the worse I get, till it's a pleasure to hurt people's feelings and say
514	"dreadful things.  Tell me how you do it, Marmee dear."""
514	""
514	"""My good mother used to help me..."""
514	""
514	"""As you do us..."" interrupted Jo, with a grateful kiss."
514	""
514	"""But I lost her when I was a little older than you are, and for years"
514	had to struggle on alone, for I was too proud to confess my weakness to
514	anyone else.  I had a hard time, Jo, and shed a good many bitter tears
514	over my failures, for in spite of my efforts I never seemed to get on.
514	Then your father came, and I was so happy that I found it easy to be
514	good.  But by-and-by, when I had four little daughters round me and we
514	were poor, then the old trouble began again, for I am not patient by
514	"nature, and it tried me very much to see my children wanting anything."""
514	""
514	"""Poor Mother!  What helped you then?"""
514	""
514	"""Your father, Jo.  He never loses patience, never doubts or complains,"
514	but always hopes, and works and waits so cheerfully that one is ashamed
514	to do otherwise before him.  He helped and comforted me, and showed me
514	that I must try to practice all the virtues I would have my little
514	girls possess, for I was their example.  It was easier to try for your
514	sakes than for my own. A startled or surprised look from one of you
514	when I spoke sharply rebuked me more than any words could have done,
514	and the love, respect, and confidence of my children was the sweetest
514	reward I could receive for my efforts to be the woman I would have them
514	"copy."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Mother, if I'm ever half as good as you, I shall be satisfied,"""
514	cried Jo, much touched.
514	""
514	"""I hope you will be a great deal better, dear, but you must keep watch"
514	over your 'bosom enemy', as father calls it, or it may sadden, if not
514	spoil your life.  You have had a warning. Remember it, and try with
514	heart and soul to master this quick temper, before it brings you
514	"greater sorrow and regret than you have known today."""
514	""
514	"""I will try, Mother, I truly will.  But you must help me, remind me,"
514	and keep me from flying out.  I used to see Father sometimes put his
514	finger on his lips, and look at you with a very kind but sober face,
514	and you always folded your lips tight and went away.  Was he reminding
514	"you then?"" asked Jo softly."
514	""
514	"""Yes.  I asked him to help me so, and he never forgot it, but saved me"
514	"from many a sharp word by that little gesture and kind look."""
514	""
514	Jo saw that her mother's eyes filled and her lips trembled as she
514	spoke, and fearing that she had said too much, she whispered anxiously,
514	"""Was it wrong to watch you and to speak of it?  I didn't mean to be"
514	rude, but it's so comfortable to say all I think to you, and feel so
514	"safe and happy here."""
514	""
514	"""My Jo, you may say anything to your mother, for it is my greatest"
514	happiness and pride to feel that my girls confide in me and know how
514	"much I love them."""
514	""
514	"""I thought I'd grieved you."""
514	""
514	"""No, dear, but speaking of Father reminded me how much I miss him, how"
514	much I owe him, and how faithfully I should watch and work to keep his
514	"little daughters safe and good for him."""
514	""
514	"""Yet you told him to go, Mother, and didn't cry when he went, and never"
514	"complain now, or seem as if you needed any help,"" said Jo, wondering."
514	""
514	"""I gave my best to the country I love, and kept my tears till he was"
514	gone.  Why should I complain, when we both have merely done our duty
514	and will surely be the happier for it in the end?  If I don't seem to
514	need help, it is because I have a better friend, even than Father, to
514	comfort and sustain me.  My child, the troubles and temptations of your
514	life are beginning and may be many, but you can overcome and outlive
514	them all if you learn to feel the strength and tenderness of your
514	Heavenly Father as you do that of your earthly one.  The more you love
514	and trust Him, the nearer you will feel to Him, and the less you will
514	depend on human power and wisdom.  His love and care never tire or
514	change, can never be taken from you, but may become the source of
514	lifelong peace, happiness, and strength.  Believe this heartily, and go
514	to God with all your little cares, and hopes, and sins, and sorrows, as
514	"freely and confidingly as you come to your mother."""
514	""
514	Jo's only answer was to hold her mother close, and in the silence which
514	followed the sincerest prayer she had ever prayed left her heart
514	without words.  For in that sad yet happy hour, she had learned not
514	only the bitterness of remorse and despair, but the sweetness of
514	self-denial and self-control, and led by her mother's hand, she had
514	drawn nearer to the Friend who always welcomes every child with a love
514	stronger than that of any father, tenderer than that of any mother.
514	""
514	Amy stirred and sighed in her sleep, and as if eager to begin at once
514	to mend her fault, Jo looked up with an expression on her face which it
514	had never worn before.
514	""
514	"""I let the sun go down on my anger.  I wouldn't forgive her, and today,"
514	if it hadn't been for Laurie, it might have been too late!  How could I
514	"be so wicked?"" said Jo, half aloud, as she leaned over her sister"
514	softly stroking the wet hair scattered on the pillow.
514	""
514	As if she heard, Amy opened her eyes, and held out her arms, with a
514	smile that went straight to Jo's heart.  Neither said a word, but they
514	hugged one another close, in spite of the blankets, and everything was
514	forgiven and forgotten in one hearty kiss.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER NINE
514	""
514	MEG GOES TO VANITY FAIR
514	""
514	"""I do think it was the most fortunate thing in the world that those"
514	"children should have the measles just now,"" said Meg, one April day, as"
514	she stood packing the 'go abroady' trunk in her room, surrounded by her
514	sisters.
514	""
514	"""And so nice of Annie Moffat not to forget her promise.  A whole"
514	"fortnight of fun will be regularly splendid,"" replied Jo, looking like"
514	a windmill as she folded skirts with her long arms.
514	""
514	"""And such lovely weather, I'm so glad of that,"" added Beth, tidily"
514	sorting neck and hair ribbons in her best box, lent for the great
514	occasion.
514	""
514	"""I wish I was going to have a fine time and wear all these nice"
514	"things,"" said Amy with her mouth full of pins, as she artistically"
514	replenished her sister's cushion.
514	""
514	"""I wish you were all going, but as you can't, I shall keep my"
514	adventures to tell you when I come back.  I'm sure it's the least I can
514	do when you have been so kind, lending me things and helping me get
514	"ready,"" said Meg, glancing round the room at the very simple outfit,"
514	which seemed nearly perfect in their eyes.
514	""
514	"""What did Mother give you out of the treasure box?"" asked Amy, who had"
514	not been present at the opening of a certain cedar chest in which Mrs.
514	March kept a few relics of past splendor, as gifts for her girls when
514	the proper time came.
514	""
514	"""A pair of silk stockings, that pretty carved fan, and a lovely blue"
514	sash.  I wanted the violet silk, but there isn't time to make it over,
514	"so I must be contented with my old tarlaton."""
514	""
514	""
514	"""It will look nice over my new muslin skirt, and the sash will set it"
514	off beautifully.  I wish I hadn't smashed my coral bracelet, for you
514	"might have had it,"" said Jo, who loved to give and lend, but whose"
514	possessions were usually too dilapidated to be of much use.
514	""
514	"""There is a lovely old-fashioned pearl set in the treasure chest, but"
514	Mother said real flowers were the prettiest ornament for a young girl,
514	"and Laurie promised to send me all I want,"" replied Meg.  ""Now, let me"
514	see, there's my new gray walking suit, just curl up the feather in my
514	hat, Beth, then my poplin for Sunday and the small party, it looks
514	heavy for spring, doesn't it?  The violet silk would be so nice.  Oh,
514	"dear!"""
514	""
514	"""Never mind, you've got the tarlaton for the big party, and you always"
514	"look like an angel in white,"" said Amy, brooding over the little store"
514	of finery in which her soul delighted.
514	""
514	"""It isn't low-necked, and it doesn't sweep enough, but it will have to"
514	do.  My blue housedress looks so well, turned and freshly trimmed, that
514	I feel as if I'd got a new one.  My silk sacque isn't a bit the
514	fashion, and my bonnet doesn't look like Sallie's.  I didn't like to
514	say anything, but I was sadly disappointed in my umbrella.  I told
514	Mother black with a white handle, but she forgot and bought a green one
514	with a yellowish handle.  It's strong and neat, so I ought not to
514	complain, but I know I shall feel ashamed of it beside Annie's silk one
514	"with a gold top,"" sighed Meg, surveying the little umbrella with great"
514	disfavor.
514	""
514	"""Change it,"" advised Jo."
514	""
514	"""I won't be so silly, or hurt Marmee's feelings, when she took so much"
514	pains to get my things.  It's a nonsensical notion of mine, and I'm not
514	going to give up to it.  My silk stockings and two pairs of new gloves
514	are my comfort.  You are a dear to lend me yours, Jo.  I feel so rich
514	and sort of elegant, with two new pairs, and the old ones cleaned up
514	"for common.""  And Meg took a refreshing peep at her glove box."
514	""
514	"""Annie Moffat has blue and pink bows on her nightcaps. Would you put"
514	"some on mine?"" she asked, as Beth brought up a pile of snowy muslins,"
514	fresh from Hannah's hands.
514	""
514	"""No, I wouldn't, for the smart caps won't match the plain gowns without"
514	"any trimming on them.  Poor folks shouldn't rig,"" said Jo decidedly."
514	""
514	"""I wonder if I shall ever be happy enough to have real lace on my"
514	"clothes and bows on my caps?"" said Meg impatiently."
514	""
514	"""You said the other day that you'd be perfectly happy if you could only"
514	"go to Annie Moffat's,"" observed Beth in her quiet way."
514	""
514	"""So I did!  Well, I am happy, and I won't fret, but it does seem as if"
514	the more one gets the more one wants, doesn't it?  There now, the trays
514	are ready, and everything in but my ball dress, which I shall leave for
514	"Mother to pack,"" said Meg, cheering up, as she glanced from the"
514	half-filled trunk to the many times pressed and mended white tarlaton,
514	which she called her 'ball dress' with an important air.
514	""
514	The next day was fine, and Meg departed in style for a fortnight of
514	novelty and pleasure.  Mrs. March had consented to the visit rather
514	reluctantly, fearing that Margaret would come back more discontented
514	than she went.  But she begged so hard, and Sallie had promised to take
514	good care of her, and a little pleasure seemed so delightful after a
514	winter of irksome work that the mother yielded, and the daughter went
514	to take her first taste of fashionable life.
514	""
514	The Moffats were very fashionable, and simple Meg was rather daunted,
514	at first, by the splendor of the house and the elegance of its
514	occupants.  But they were kindly people, in spite of the frivolous life
514	they led, and soon put their guest at her ease. Perhaps Meg felt,
514	without understanding why, that they were not particularly cultivated
514	or intelligent people, and that all their gilding could not quite
514	conceal the ordinary material of which they were made.  It certainly
514	was agreeable to fare sumptuously, drive in a fine carriage, wear her
514	best frock every day, and do nothing but enjoy herself.  It suited her
514	exactly, and soon she began to imitate the manners and conversation of
514	those about her, to put on little airs and graces, use French phrases,
514	crimp her hair, take in her dresses, and talk about the fashions as
514	well as she could.  The more she saw of Annie Moffat's pretty things,
514	the more she envied her and sighed to be rich.  Home now looked bare
514	and dismal as she thought of it, work grew harder than ever, and she
514	felt that she was a very destitute and much-injured girl, in spite of
514	the new gloves and silk stockings.
514	""
514	She had not much time for repining, however, for the three young girls
514	were busily employed in 'having a good time'.  They shopped, walked,
514	rode, and called all day, went to theaters and operas or frolicked at
514	home in the evening, for Annie had many friends and knew how to
514	entertain them.  Her older sisters were very fine young ladies, and one
514	was engaged, which was extremely interesting and romantic, Meg thought.
514	Mr. Moffat was a fat, jolly old gentleman, who knew her father, and
514	Mrs. Moffat, a fat, jolly old lady, who took as great a fancy to Meg as
514	her daughter had done.  Everyone petted her, and 'Daisey', as they
514	called her, was in a fair way to have her head turned.
514	""
514	When the evening for the small party came, she found that the poplin
514	wouldn't do at all, for the other girls were putting on thin dresses
514	and making themselves very fine indeed.  So out came the tarlatan,
514	looking older, limper, and shabbier than ever beside Sallie's crisp new
514	one.  Meg saw the girls glance at it and then at one another, and her
514	cheeks began to burn, for with all her gentleness she was very proud.
514	No one said a word about it, but Sallie offered to dress her hair, and
514	Annie to tie her sash, and Belle, the engaged sister, praised her white
514	arms.  But in their kindness Meg saw only pity for her poverty, and her
514	heart felt very heavy as she stood by herself, while the others
514	laughed, chattered, and flew about like gauzy butterflies.  The hard,
514	bitter feeling was getting pretty bad, when the maid brought in a box
514	of flowers.  Before she could speak, Annie had the cover off, and all
514	were exclaiming at the lovely roses, heath, and fern within.
514	""
514	"""It's for Belle, of course, George always sends her some, but these are"
514	"altogether ravishing,"" cried Annie, with a great sniff."
514	""
514	"""They are for Miss March, the man said.  And here's a note,"" put in the"
514	maid, holding it to Meg.
514	""
514	"""What fun!  Who are they from?  Didn't know you had a lover,"" cried the"
514	girls, fluttering about Meg in a high state of curiosity and surprise.
514	""
514	"""The note is from Mother, and the flowers from Laurie,"" said Meg"
514	simply, yet much gratified that he had not forgotten her.
514	""
514	"""Oh, indeed!"" said Annie with a funny look, as Meg slipped the note"
514	into her pocket as a sort of talisman against envy, vanity, and false
514	pride, for the few loving words had done her good, and the flowers
514	cheered her up by their beauty.
514	""
514	Feeling almost happy again, she laid by a few ferns and roses for
514	herself, and quickly made up the rest in dainty bouquets for the
514	breasts, hair, or skirts of her friends, offering them so prettily that
514	Clara, the elder sister, told her she was 'the sweetest little thing
514	she ever saw', and they looked quite charmed with her small attention.
514	Somehow the kind act finished her despondency, and when all the rest
514	went to show themselves to Mrs. Moffat, she saw a happy, bright-eyed
514	face in the mirror, as she laid her ferns against her rippling hair and
514	fastened the roses in the dress that didn't strike her as so very
514	shabby now.
514	""
514	She enjoyed herself very much that evening, for she danced to her
514	heart's content.  Everyone was very kind, and she had three
514	compliments.  Annie made her sing, and some one said she had a
514	remarkably fine voice.  Major Lincoln asked who 'the fresh little girl
514	with the beautiful eyes' was, and Mr. Moffat insisted on dancing with
514	her because she 'didn't dawdle, but had some spring in her', as he
514	gracefully expressed it.  So altogether she had a very nice time, till
514	she overheard a bit of conversation, which disturbed her extremely.
514	She was sitting just inside the conservatory, waiting for her partner
514	to bring her an ice, when she heard a voice ask on the other side of
514	the flowery wall...
514	""
514	"""How old is he?"""
514	""
514	"""Sixteen or seventeen, I should say,"" replied another voice."
514	""
514	"""It would be a grand thing for one of those girls, wouldn't it?  Sallie"
514	"says they are very intimate now, and the old man quite dotes on them."""
514	""
514	"""Mrs. M.  has made her plans, I dare say, and will play her cards well,"
514	"early as it is.  The girl evidently doesn't think of it yet,"" said Mrs."
514	Moffat.
514	""
514	"""She told that fib about her momma, as if she did know, and colored up"
514	when the flowers came quite prettily.  Poor thing! She'd be so nice if
514	she was only got up in style.  Do you think she'd be offended if we
514	"offered to lend her a dress for Thursday?"" asked another voice."
514	""
514	"""She's proud, but I don't believe she'd mind, for that dowdy tarlaton"
514	is all she has got.  She may tear it tonight, and that will be a good
514	"excuse for offering a decent one."""
514	""
514	Here Meg's partner appeared, to find her looking much flushed and
514	rather agitated.  She was proud, and her pride was useful just then,
514	for it helped her hide her mortification, anger, and disgust at what
514	she had just heard.  For, innocent and unsuspicious as she was, she
514	could not help understanding the gossip of her friends.  She tried to
514	"forget it, but could not, and kept repeating to herself, ""Mrs. M.  has"
514	"made her plans,"" ""that fib about her mamma,"" and ""dowdy tarlaton,"" till"
514	she was ready to cry and rush home to tell her troubles and ask for
514	advice.  As that was impossible, she did her best to seem gay, and
514	being rather excited, she succeeded so well that no one dreamed what an
514	effort she was making. She was very glad when it was all over and she
514	was quiet in her bed, where she could think and wonder and fume till
514	her head ached and her hot cheeks were cooled by a few natural tears.
514	Those foolish, yet well meant words, had opened a new world to Meg, and
514	much disturbed the peace of the old one in which till now she had lived
514	as happily as a child.  Her innocent friendship with Laurie was spoiled
514	by the silly speeches she had overheard.  Her faith in her mother was a
514	little shaken by the worldly plans attributed to her by Mrs. Moffat,
514	who judged others by herself, and the sensible resolution to be
514	contented with the simple wardrobe which suited a poor man's daughter
514	was weakened by the unnecessary pity of girls who thought a shabby
514	dress one of the greatest calamities under heaven.
514	""
514	Poor Meg had a restless night, and got up heavy-eyed, unhappy, half
514	resentful toward her friends, and half ashamed of herself for not
514	speaking out frankly and setting everything right.  Everybody dawdled
514	that morning, and it was noon before the girls found energy enough even
514	to take up their worsted work.  Something in the manner of her friends
514	struck Meg at once.  They treated her with more respect, she thought,
514	took quite a tender interest in what she said, and looked at her with
514	eyes that plainly betrayed curiosity.  All this surprised and flattered
514	her, though she did not understand it till Miss Belle looked up from
514	her writing, and said, with a sentimental air...
514	""
514	"""Daisy, dear, I've sent an invitation to your friend, Mr. Laurence, for"
514	Thursday.  We should like to know him, and it's only a proper
514	"compliment to you."""
514	""
514	Meg colored, but a mischievous fancy to tease the girls made her reply
514	"demurely, ""You are very kind, but I'm afraid he won't come."""
514	""
514	"""Why not, Cherie?"" asked Miss Belle."
514	""
514	"""He's too old."""
514	""
514	"""My child, what do you mean?  What is his age, I beg to know!"" cried"
514	Miss Clara.
514	""
514	"""Nearly seventy, I believe,"" answered Meg, counting stitches to hide"
514	the merriment in her eyes.
514	""
514	"""You sly creature!  Of course we meant the young man,"" exclaimed Miss"
514	Belle, laughing.
514	""
514	"""There isn't any, Laurie is only a little boy.""  And Meg laughed also"
514	at the queer look which the sisters exchanged as she thus described her
514	supposed lover.
514	""
514	"""About your age,"" Nan said."
514	""
514	"""Nearer my sister Jo's; I am seventeen in August,"" returned Meg,"
514	tossing her head.
514	""
514	"""It's very nice of him to send you flowers, isn't it?"" said Annie,"
514	looking wise about nothing.
514	""
514	"""Yes, he often does, to all of us, for their house is full, and we are"
514	so fond of them.  My mother and old Mr. Laurence are friends, you know,
514	"so it is quite natural that we children should play together,"" and Meg"
514	hoped they would say no more.
514	""
514	"""It's evident Daisy isn't out yet,"" said Miss Clara to Belle with a nod."
514	""
514	"""Quite a pastoral state of innocence all round,"" returned Miss Belle"
514	with a shrug.
514	""
514	"""I'm going out to get some little matters for my girls.  Can I do"
514	"anything for you, young ladies?"" asked Mrs. Moffat, lumbering in like"
514	an elephant in silk and lace.
514	""
514	"""No, thank you, ma'am,"" replied Sallie.  ""I've got my new pink silk for"
514	"Thursday and don't want a thing."""
514	""
514	"""Nor I..."" began Meg, but stopped because it occurred to her that she"
514	did want several things and could not have them.
514	""
514	"""What shall you wear?"" asked Sallie."
514	""
514	"""My old white one again, if I can mend it fit to be seen, it got sadly"
514	"torn last night,"" said Meg, trying to speak quite easily, but feeling"
514	very uncomfortable.
514	""
514	"""Why don't you send home for another?"" said Sallie, who was not an"
514	observing young lady.
514	""
514	"""I haven't got any other.""  It cost Meg an effort to say that, but"
514	"Sallie did not see it and exclaimed in amiable surprise, ""Only that?"
514	"How funny...""  She did not finish her speech, for Belle shook her head"
514	at her and broke in, saying kindly...
514	""
514	"""Not at all.  Where is the use of having a lot of dresses when she"
514	isn't out yet?  There's no need of sending home, Daisy, even if you had
514	a dozen, for I've got a sweet blue silk laid away, which I've outgrown,
514	"and you shall wear it to please me, won't you, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""You are very kind, but I don't mind my old dress if you don't, it does"
514	"well enough for a little girl like me,"" said Meg."
514	""
514	"""Now do let me please myself by dressing you up in style. I admire to"
514	do it, and you'd be a regular little beauty with a touch here and
514	there.  I shan't let anyone see you till you are done, and then we'll
514	"burst upon them like Cinderella and her godmother going to the ball,"""
514	said Belle in her persuasive tone.
514	""
514	Meg couldn't refuse the offer so kindly made, for a desire to see if
514	she would be 'a little beauty' after touching up caused her to accept
514	and forget all her former uncomfortable feelings toward the Moffats.
514	""
514	On the Thursday evening, Belle shut herself up with her maid, and
514	between them they turned Meg into a fine lady.  They crimped and curled
514	her hair, they polished her neck and arms with some fragrant powder,
514	touched her lips with coralline salve to make them redder, and Hortense
514	would have added 'a soupcon of rouge', if Meg had not rebelled.  They
514	laced her into a sky-blue dress, which was so tight she could hardly
514	breathe and so low in the neck that modest Meg blushed at herself in
514	the mirror.  A set of silver filagree was added, bracelets, necklace,
514	brooch, and even earrings, for Hortense tied them on with a bit of pink
514	silk which did not show.  A cluster of tea-rose buds at the bosom, and
514	a ruche, reconciled Meg to the display of her pretty, white shoulders,
514	and a pair of high-heeled silk boots satisfied the last wish of her
514	heart.  A lace handkerchief, a plumy fan, and a bouquet in a shoulder
514	holder finished her off, and Miss Belle surveyed her with the
514	satisfaction of a little girl with a newly dressed doll.
514	""
514	"""Mademoiselle is charmante, tres jolie, is she not?"" cried Hortense,"
514	clasping her hands in an affected rapture.
514	""
514	"""Come and show yourself,"" said Miss Belle, leading the way to the room"
514	where the others were waiting.
514	""
514	As Meg went rustling after, with her long skirts trailing, her earrings
514	tinkling, her curls waving, and her heart beating, she felt as if her
514	fun had really begun at last, for the mirror had plainly told her that
514	she was 'a little beauty'.  Her friends repeated the pleasing phrase
514	enthusiastically, and for several minutes she stood, like a jackdaw in
514	the fable, enjoying her borrowed plumes, while the rest chattered like
514	a party of magpies.
514	""
514	"""While I dress, do you drill her, Nan, in the management of her skirt"
514	and those French heels, or she will trip herself up.  Take your silver
514	butterfly, and catch up that long curl on the left side of her head,
514	"Clara, and don't any of you disturb the charming work of my hands,"""
514	said Belle, as she hurried away, looking well pleased with her success.
514	""
514	"""You don't look a bit like yourself, but you are very nice. I'm nowhere"
514	beside you, for Belle has heaps of taste, and you're quite French, I
514	assure you.  Let your flowers hang, don't be so careful of them, and be
514	"sure you don't trip,"" returned Sallie, trying not to care that Meg was"
514	prettier than herself.
514	""
514	Keeping that warning carefully in mind, Margaret got safely down stairs
514	and sailed into the drawing rooms where the Moffats and a few early
514	guests were assembled.  She very soon discovered that there is a charm
514	about fine clothes which attracts a certain class of people and secures
514	their respect.  Several young ladies, who had taken no notice of her
514	before, were very affectionate all of a sudden.  Several young
514	gentlemen, who had only stared at her at the other party, now not only
514	stared, but asked to be introduced, and said all manner of foolish but
514	agreeable things to her, and several old ladies, who sat on the sofas,
514	and criticized the rest of the party, inquired who she was with an air
514	of interest.  She heard Mrs. Moffat reply to one of them...
514	""
514	"""Daisy March--father a colonel in the army--one of our first families,"
514	but reverses of fortune, you know; intimate friends of the Laurences;
514	"sweet creature, I assure you; my Ned is quite wild about her."""
514	""
514	"""Dear me!"" said the old lady, putting up her glass for another"
514	observation of Meg, who tried to look as if she had not heard and been
514	rather shocked at Mrs. Moffat's fibs. The 'queer feeling' did not pass
514	away, but she imagined herself acting the new part of fine lady and so
514	got on pretty well, though the tight dress gave her a side-ache, the
514	train kept getting under her feet, and she was in constant fear lest
514	her earrings should fly off and get lost or broken.  She was flirting
514	her fan and laughing at the feeble jokes of a young gentleman who tried
514	to be witty, when she suddenly stopped laughing and looked confused,
514	for just opposite, she saw Laurie.  He was staring at her with
514	undisguised surprise, and disapproval also, she thought, for though he
514	bowed and smiled, yet something in his honest eyes made her blush and
514	wish she had her old dress on. To complete her confusion, she saw Belle
514	nudge Annie, and both glance from her to Laurie, who, she was happy to
514	see, looked unusually boyish and shy.
514	""
514	"""Silly creatures, to put such thoughts into my head.  I won't care for"
514	"it, or let it change me a bit,"" thought Meg, and rustled across the"
514	room to shake hands with her friend.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad you came, I was afraid you wouldn't."" she said, with her most"
514	grown-up air.
514	""
514	"""Jo wanted me to come, and tell her how you looked, so I did,"" answered"
514	Laurie, without turning his eyes upon her, though he half smiled at her
514	maternal tone.
514	""
514	"""What shall you tell her?"" asked Meg, full of curiosity to know his"
514	opinion of her, yet feeling ill at ease with him for the first time.
514	""
514	"""I shall say I didn't know you, for you look so grown-up and unlike"
514	"yourself, I'm quite afraid of you,"" he said, fumbling at his glove"
514	button.
514	""
514	"""How absurd of you!  The girls dressed me up for fun, and I rather like"
514	"it.  Wouldn't Jo stare if she saw me?"" said Meg, bent on making him say"
514	whether he thought her improved or not.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I think she would,"" returned Laurie gravely."
514	""
514	"""Don't you like me so?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""No, I don't,"" was the blunt reply."
514	""
514	"""Why not?"" in an anxious tone."
514	""
514	He glanced at her frizzled head, bare shoulders, and fantastically
514	trimmed dress with an expression that abashed her more than his answer,
514	which had not a particle of his usual politeness in it.
514	""
514	"""I don't like fuss and feathers."""
514	""
514	That was altogether too much from a lad younger than herself, and Meg
514	"walked away, saying petulantly, ""You are the rudest boy I ever saw."""
514	""
514	Feeling very much ruffled, she went and stood at a quiet window to cool
514	her cheeks, for the tight dress gave her an uncomfortably brilliant
514	color.  As she stood there, Major Lincoln passed by, and a minute after
514	she heard him saying to his mother...
514	""
514	"""They are making a fool of that little girl.  I wanted you to see her,"
514	"but they have spoiled her entirely.  She's nothing but a doll tonight."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear!"" sighed Meg.  ""I wish I'd been sensible and worn my own"
514	things, then I should not have disgusted other people, or felt so
514	"uncomfortable and ashamed of myself."""
514	""
514	She leaned her forehead on the cool pane, and stood half hidden by the
514	curtains, never minding that her favorite waltz had begun, till some
514	one touched her, and turning, she saw Laurie, looking penitent, as he
514	said, with his very best bow and his hand out...
514	""
514	"""Please forgive my rudeness, and come and dance with me."""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid it will be too disagreeable to you,"" said Meg, trying to"
514	look offended and failing entirely.
514	""
514	"""Not a bit of it, I'm dying to do it.  Come, I'll be good. I don't like"
514	"your gown, but I do think you are just splendid."" And he waved his"
514	hands, as if words failed to express his admiration.
514	""
514	Meg smiled and relented, and whispered as they stood waiting to catch
514	"the time, ""Take care my skirt doesn't trip you up.  It's the plague of"
514	"my life and I was a goose to wear it."""
514	""
514	"""Pin it round your neck, and then it will be useful,"" said Laurie,"
514	looking down at the little blue boots, which he evidently approved of.
514	""
514	Away they went fleetly and gracefully, for having practiced at home,
514	they were well matched, and the blithe young couple were a pleasant
514	sight to see, as they twirled merrily round and round, feeling more
514	friendly than ever after their small tiff.
514	""
514	"""Laurie, I want you to do me a favor, will you?"" said Meg, as he stood"
514	fanning her when her breath gave out, which it did very soon though she
514	would not own why.
514	""
514	"""Won't I!"" said Laurie, with alacrity."
514	""
514	"""Please don't tell them at home about my dress tonight. They won't"
514	"understand the joke, and it will worry Mother."""
514	""
514	"""Then why did you do it?"" said Laurie's eyes, so plainly that Meg"
514	hastily added...
514	""
514	"""I shall tell them myself all about it, and 'fess' to Mother how silly"
514	"I've been.  But I'd rather do it myself.  So you'll not tell, will you?"""
514	""
514	"""I give you my word I won't, only what shall I say when they ask me?"""
514	""
514	"""Just say I looked pretty well and was having a good time."""
514	""
514	"""I'll say the first with all my heart, but how about the other?  You"
514	"don't look as if you were having a good time.  Are you?"" And Laurie"
514	looked at her with an expression which made her answer in a whisper...
514	""
514	"""No, not just now.  Don't think I'm horrid.  I only wanted a little"
514	"fun, but this sort doesn't pay, I find, and I'm getting tired of it."""
514	""
514	"""Here comes Ned Moffat.  What does he want?"" said Laurie, knitting his"
514	black brows as if he did not regard his young host in the light of a
514	pleasant addition to the party.
514	""
514	"""He put his name down for three dances, and I suppose he's coming for"
514	"them.  What a bore!"" said Meg, assuming a languid air which amused"
514	Laurie immensely.
514	""
514	He did not speak to her again till suppertime, when he saw her drinking
514	champagne with Ned and his friend Fisher, who were behaving 'like a
514	pair of fools', as Laurie said to himself, for he felt a brotherly sort
514	of right to watch over the Marches and fight their battles whenever a
514	defender was needed.
514	""
514	"""You'll have a splitting headache tomorrow, if you drink much of that."
514	"I wouldn't, Meg, your mother doesn't like it, you know,"" he whispered,"
514	leaning over her chair, as Ned turned to refill her glass and Fisher
514	stooped to pick up her fan.
514	""
514	"""I'm not Meg tonight, I'm 'a doll' who does all sorts of crazy things."
514	Tomorrow I shall put away my 'fuss and feathers' and be desperately
514	"good again,"" she answered with an affected little laugh."
514	""
514	"""Wish tomorrow was here, then,"" muttered Laurie, walking off,"
514	ill-pleased at the change he saw in her.
514	""
514	Meg danced and flirted, chattered and giggled, as the other girls did.
514	After supper she undertook the German, and blundered through it, nearly
514	upsetting her partner with her long skirt, and romping in a way that
514	scandalized Laurie, who looked on and meditated a lecture.  But he got
514	no chance to deliver it, for Meg kept away from him till he came to say
514	good night.
514	""
514	"""Remember!"" she said, trying to smile, for the splitting headache had"
514	already begun.
514	""
514	"""Silence a la mort,"" replied Laurie, with a melodramatic flourish, as"
514	he went away.
514	""
514	This little bit of byplay excited Annie's curiosity, but Meg was too
514	tired for gossip and went to bed, feeling as if she had been to a
514	masquerade and hadn't enjoyed herself as much as she expected.  She was
514	sick all the next day, and on Saturday went home, quite used up with
514	her fortnight's fun and feeling that she had 'sat in the lap of luxury'
514	long enough.
514	""
514	"""It does seem pleasant to be quiet, and not have company manners on all"
514	"the time.  Home is a nice place, though it isn't splendid,"" said Meg,"
514	looking about her with a restful expression, as she sat with her mother
514	and Jo on the Sunday evening.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad to hear you say so, dear, for I was afraid home would seem"
514	"dull and poor to you after your fine quarters,"" replied her mother, who"
514	had given her many anxious looks that day.  For motherly eyes are quick
514	to see any change in children's faces.
514	""
514	Meg had told her adventures gayly and said over and over what a
514	charming time she had had, but something still seemed to weigh upon her
514	spirits, and when the younger girls were gone to bed, she sat
514	thoughtfully staring at the fire, saying little and looking worried.
514	As the clock struck nine and Jo proposed bed, Meg suddenly left her
514	chair and, taking Beth's stool, leaned her elbows on her mother's knee,
514	saying bravely...
514	""
514	"""Marmee, I want to 'fess'."""
514	""
514	"""I thought so.  What is it, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""Shall I go away?"" asked Jo discreetly."
514	""
514	"""Of course not.  Don't I always tell you everything?  I was ashamed to"
514	speak of it before the younger children, but I want you to know all the
514	"dreadful things I did at the Moffats'."""
514	""
514	"""We are prepared,"" said Mrs. March, smiling but looking a little"
514	anxious.
514	""
514	"""I told you they dressed me up, but I didn't tell you that they"
514	powdered and squeezed and frizzled, and made me look like a
514	fashion-plate.  Laurie thought I wasn't proper.  I know he did, though
514	he didn't say so, and one man called me 'a doll'.  I knew it was silly,
514	but they flattered me and said I was a beauty, and quantities of
514	"nonsense, so I let them make a fool of me."""
514	""
514	"""Is that all?"" asked Jo, as Mrs. March looked silently at the downcast"
514	face of her pretty daughter, and could not find it in her heart to
514	blame her little follies.
514	""
514	"""No, I drank champagne and romped and tried to flirt, and was"
514	"altogether abominable,"" said Meg self-reproachfully."
514	""
514	"""There is something more, I think.""  And Mrs. March smoothed the soft"
514	cheek, which suddenly grew rosy as Meg answered slowly...
514	""
514	"""Yes.  It's very silly, but I want to tell it, because I hate to have"
514	"people say and think such things about us and Laurie."""
514	""
514	Then she told the various bits of gossip she had heard at the Moffats',
514	and as she spoke, Jo saw her mother fold her lips tightly, as if ill
514	pleased that such ideas should be put into Meg's innocent mind.
514	""
514	"""Well, if that isn't the greatest rubbish I ever heard,"" cried Jo"
514	"indignantly.  ""Why didn't you pop out and tell them so on the spot?"""
514	""
514	"""I couldn't, it was so embarrassing for me.  I couldn't help hearing at"
514	first, and then I was so angry and ashamed, I didn't remember that I
514	"ought to go away."""
514	""
514	"""Just wait till I see Annie Moffat, and I'll show you how to settle"
514	such ridiculous stuff.  The idea of having 'plans' and being kind to
514	Laurie because he's rich and may marry us by-and-by!  Won't he shout
514	"when I tell him what those silly things say about us poor children?"""
514	And Jo laughed, as if on second thoughts the thing struck her as a good
514	joke.
514	""
514	"""If you tell Laurie, I'll never forgive you!  She mustn't, must she,"
514	"Mother?"" said Meg, looking distressed."
514	""
514	"""No, never repeat that foolish gossip, and forget it as soon as you"
514	"can,"" said Mrs. March gravely.  ""I was very unwise to let you go among"
514	people of whom I know so little, kind, I dare say, but worldly,
514	ill-bred, and full of these vulgar ideas about young people.  I am more
514	sorry than I can express for the mischief this visit may have done you,
514	"Meg."""
514	""
514	"""Don't be sorry, I won't let it hurt me.  I'll forget all the bad and"
514	remember only the good, for I did enjoy a great deal, and thank you
514	very much for letting me go.  I'll not be sentimental or dissatisfied,
514	Mother.  I know I'm a silly little girl, and I'll stay with you till
514	I'm fit to take care of myself.  But it is nice to be praised and
514	"admired, and I can't help saying I like it,"" said Meg, looking half"
514	ashamed of the confession.
514	""
514	"""That is perfectly natural, and quite harmless, if the liking does not"
514	become a passion and lead one to do foolish or unmaidenly things.
514	Learn to know and value the praise which is worth having, and to excite
514	the admiration of excellent people by being modest as well as pretty,
514	"Meg."""
514	""
514	Margaret sat thinking a moment, while Jo stood with her hands behind
514	her, looking both interested and a little perplexed, for it was a new
514	thing to see Meg blushing and talking about admiration, lovers, and
514	things of that sort.  And Jo felt as if during that fortnight her
514	sister had grown up amazingly, and was drifting away from her into a
514	world where she could not follow.
514	""
514	"""Mother, do you have 'plans', as Mrs. Moffat said?"" asked Meg bashfully."
514	""
514	"""Yes, my dear, I have a great many, all mothers do, but mine differ"
514	somewhat from Mrs. Moffat's, I suspect.  I will tell you some of them,
514	for the time has come when a word may set this romantic little head and
514	heart of yours right, on a very serious subject.  You are young, Meg,
514	but not too young to understand me, and mothers' lips are the fittest
514	to speak of such things to girls like you.  Jo, your turn will come in
514	time, perhaps, so listen to my 'plans' and help me carry them out, if
514	"they are good."""
514	""
514	Jo went and sat on one arm of the chair, looking as if she thought they
514	were about to join in some very solemn affair. Holding a hand of each,
514	and watching the two young faces wistfully, Mrs. March said, in her
514	serious yet cheery way...
514	""
514	"""I want my daughters to be beautiful, accomplished, and good. To be"
514	admired, loved, and respected.  To have a happy youth, to be well and
514	wisely married, and to lead useful, pleasant lives, with as little care
514	and sorrow to try them as God sees fit to send. To be loved and chosen
514	by a good man is the best and sweetest thing which can happen to a
514	woman, and I sincerely hope my girls may know this beautiful
514	experience.  It is natural to think of it, Meg, right to hope and wait
514	for it, and wise to prepare for it, so that when the happy time comes,
514	you may feel ready for the duties and worthy of the joy.  My dear
514	girls, I am ambitious for you, but not to have you make a dash in the
514	world, marry rich men merely because they are rich, or have splendid
514	houses, which are not homes because love is wanting.  Money is a
514	needful and precious thing, and when well used, a noble thing, but I
514	never want you to think it is the first or only prize to strive for.
514	I'd rather see you poor men's wives, if you were happy, beloved,
514	"contented, than queens on thrones, without self-respect and peace."""
514	""
514	"""Poor girls don't stand any chance, Belle says, unless they put"
514	"themselves forward,"" sighed Meg."
514	""
514	"""Then we'll be old maids,"" said Jo stoutly."
514	""
514	"""Right, Jo.  Better be happy old maids than unhappy wives, or"
514	"unmaidenly girls, running about to find husbands,"" said Mrs. March"
514	"decidedly.  ""Don't be troubled, Meg, poverty seldom daunts a sincere"
514	lover.  Some of the best and most honored women I know were poor girls,
514	but so love-worthy that they were not allowed to be old maids. Leave
514	these things to time.  Make this home happy, so that you may be fit for
514	homes of your own, if they are offered you, and contented here if they
514	are not.  One thing remember, my girls.  Mother is always ready to be
514	your confidant, Father to be your friend, and both of us hope and trust
514	that our daughters, whether married or single, will be the pride and
514	"comfort of our lives."""
514	""
514	"""We will, Marmee, we will!"" cried both, with all their hearts, as she"
514	bade them good night.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TEN
514	""
514	THE P.C. AND P.O.
514	""
514	As spring came on, a new set of amusements became the fashion, and the
514	lengthening days gave long afternoons for work and play of all sorts.
514	The garden had to be put in order, and each sister had a quarter of the
514	"little plot to do what she liked with.  Hannah used to say, ""I'd know"
514	"which each of them gardings belonged to, ef I see 'em in Chiny,"" and so"
514	she might, for the girls' tastes differed as much as their characters.
514	Meg's had roses and heliotrope, myrtle, and a little orange tree in it.
514	Jo's bed was never alike two seasons, for she was always trying
514	experiments.  This year it was to be a plantation of sun flowers, the
514	seeds of which cheerful and aspiring plant were to feed Aunt
514	Cockle-top and her family of chicks.  Beth had old-fashioned fragrant
514	flowers in her garden, sweet peas and mignonette, larkspur, pinks,
514	pansies, and southernwood, with chickweed for the birds and catnip for
514	the pussies.  Amy had a bower in hers, rather small and earwiggy, but
514	very pretty to look at, with honeysuckle and morning-glories hanging
514	their colored horns and bells in graceful wreaths all over it, tall
514	white lilies, delicate ferns, and as many brilliant, picturesque plants
514	as would consent to blossom there.
514	""
514	Gardening, walks, rows on the river, and flower hunts employed the fine
514	days, and for rainy ones, they had house diversions, some old, some
514	new, all more or less original.  One of these was the 'P.C.', for as
514	secret societies were the fashion, it was thought proper to have one,
514	and as all of the girls admired Dickens, they called themselves the
514	Pickwick Club.  With a few interruptions, they had kept this up for a
514	year, and met every Saturday evening in the big garret, on which
514	occasions the ceremonies were as follows:  Three chairs were arranged
514	in a row before a table on which was a lamp, also four white badges,
514	with a big 'P.C.' in different colors on each, and the weekly newspaper
514	called, The Pickwick Portfolio, to which all contributed something,
514	while Jo, who reveled in pens and ink, was the editor. At seven
514	o'clock, the four members ascended to the clubroom, tied their badges
514	round their heads, and took their seats with great solemnity.  Meg, as
514	the eldest, was Samuel Pickwick, Jo, being of a literary turn, Augustus
514	Snodgrass, Beth, because she was round and rosy, Tracy Tupman, and Amy,
514	who was always trying to do what she couldn't, was Nathaniel Winkle.
514	Pickwick, the president, read the paper, which was filled with original
514	tales, poetry, local news, funny advertisements, and hints, in which
514	they good-naturedly reminded each other of their faults and short
514	comings.  On one occasion, Mr. Pickwick put on a pair of spectacles
514	without any glass, rapped upon the table, hemmed, and having stared
514	hard at Mr. Snodgrass, who was tilting back in his chair, till he
514	arranged himself properly, began to read:
514	""
514	    _________________________________________________
514	""
514	"    ""THE PICKWICK PORTFOLIO"""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	    MAY 20, 18--
514	""
514	    POET'S CORNER
514	""
514	    ANNIVERSARY ODE
514	""
514	""
514	    Again we meet to celebrate
514	    With badge and solemn rite,
514	    Our fifty-second anniversary,
514	    In Pickwick Hall, tonight.
514	""
514	    We all are here in perfect health,
514	    None gone from our small band:
514	    Again we see each well-known face,
514	    And press each friendly hand.
514	""
514	    Our Pickwick, always at his post,
514	    With reverence we greet,
514	    As, spectacles on nose, he reads
514	    Our well-filled weekly sheet.
514	""
514	    Although he suffers from a cold,
514	    We joy to hear him speak,
514	    For words of wisdom from him fall,
514	    In spite of croak or squeak.
514	""
514	    Old six-foot Snodgrass looms on high,
514	    With elephantine grace,
514	    And beams upon the company,
514	    With brown and jovial face.
514	""
514	    Poetic fire lights up his eye,
514	    He struggles 'gainst his lot.
514	    Behold ambition on his brow,
514	    And on his nose, a blot.
514	""
514	    Next our peaceful Tupman comes,
514	    So rosy, plump, and sweet,
514	    Who chokes with laughter at the puns,
514	    And tumbles off his seat.
514	""
514	    Prim little Winkle too is here,
514	    With every hair in place,
514	    A model of propriety,
514	    Though he hates to wash his face.
514	""
514	    The year is gone, we still unite
514	    To joke and laugh and read,
514	    And tread the path of literature
514	    That doth to glory lead.
514	""
514	    Long may our paper prosper well,
514	    Our club unbroken be,
514	    And coming years their blessings pour
514	    On the useful, gay 'P.  C.'.
514	    A.  SNODGRASS
514	""
514	    ________
514	""
514	    THE MASKED MARRIAGE
514	    (A Tale Of Venice)
514	""
514	    Gondola after gondola swept up to the marble
514	    steps, and left its lovely load to swell the
514	    brilliant throng that filled the stately halls of Count
514	    Adelon.  Knights and ladies, elves and pages, monks
514	    and flower girls, all mingled gaily in the dance.
514	    Sweet voices and rich melody filled the air, and so
514	    with mirth and music the masquerade went on.
514	"    ""Has your Highness seen the Lady Viola tonight?"""
514	    asked a gallant troubadour of the fairy queen who
514	    floated down the hall upon his arm.
514	""
514	"    ""Yes, is she not lovely, though so sad!  Her"
514	    dress is well chosen, too, for in a week she weds
514	"    Count Antonio, whom she passionately hates."""
514	""
514	"    ""By my faith, I envy him.  Yonder he comes,"
514	    arrayed like a bridegroom, except the black mask.
514	    When that is off we shall see how he regards the
514	    fair maid whose heart he cannot win, though her
514	"    stern father bestows her hand,"" returned the troubadour."
514	""
514	"    ""Tis whispered that she loves the young English"
514	    artist who haunts her steps, and is spurned by the
514	"    old Count,"" said the lady, as they joined the dance."
514	    The revel was at its height when a priest
514	    appeared, and withdrawing the young pair to an alcove,
514	    hung with purple velvet, he motioned them to kneel.
514	    Instant silence fell on the gay throng, and not a
514	    sound, but the dash of fountains or the rustle of
514	    orange groves sleeping in the moonlight, broke the
514	    hush, as Count de Adelon spoke thus:
514	""
514	"    ""My lords and ladies, pardon the ruse by which"
514	    I have gathered you here to witness the marriage of
514	"    my daughter.  Father, we wait your services."""
514	    All eyes turned toward the bridal party, and a
514	    murmur of amazement went through the throng, for
514	    neither bride nor groom removed their masks.  Curiosity
514	    and wonder possessed all hearts, but respect restrained
514	    all tongues till the holy rite was over.  Then the
514	    eager spectators gathered round the count, demanding
514	    an explanation.
514	""
514	"    ""Gladly would I give it if I could, but I only"
514	    know that it was the whim of my timid Viola, and I
514	    yielded to it.  Now, my children, let the play end.
514	"    Unmask and receive my blessing."""
514	""
514	    But neither bent the knee, for the young bridegroom
514	    replied in a tone that startled all listeners
514	    as the mask fell, disclosing the noble face of Ferdinand
514	    Devereux, the artist lover, and leaning on the
514	    breast where now flashed the star of an English earl
514	    was the lovely Viola, radiant with joy and beauty.
514	""
514	"    ""My lord, you scornfully bade me claim your"
514	    daughter when I could boast as high a name and vast a
514	    fortune as the Count Antonio.  I can do more, for even
514	    your ambitious soul cannot refuse the Earl of Devereux
514	    and De Vere, when he gives his ancient name and boundless
514	    wealth in return for the beloved hand of this fair lady,
514	"    now my wife."""
514	""
514	    The count stood like one changed to stone, and
514	    turning to the bewildered crowd, Ferdinand added, with
514	"    a gay smile of triumph, ""To you, my gallant friends, I"
514	    can only wish that your wooing may prosper as mine has
514	    done, and that you may all win as fair a bride as I have
514	"    by this masked marriage."""
514	    S.  PICKWICK
514	""
514	""
514	    Why is the P.  C.  like the Tower of Babel?
514	    It is full of unruly members.
514	""
514	    _________
514	""
514	    THE HISTORY OF A SQUASH
514	""
514	""
514	    Once upon a time a farmer planted a little seed
514	    in his garden, and after a while it sprouted and became
514	    a vine and bore many squashes.  One day in October,
514	    when they were ripe, he picked one and took it
514	    to market.  A grocerman bought and put it in his shop.
514	    That same morning, a little girl in a brown hat
514	    and blue dress, with a round face and snub nose, went
514	    and bought it for her mother.  She lugged it home, cut
514	    it up, and boiled it in the big pot, mashed some of it
514	    with salt and butter, for dinner.  And to the rest she added
514	    a pint of milk, two eggs, four spoons of sugar, nutmeg,
514	    and some crackers, put it in a deep dish, and baked it
514	    till it was brown and nice, and next day it was eaten
514	    by a family named March.
514	    T.  TUPMAN
514	""
514	    _________
514	""
514	    Mr. Pickwick, Sir:--
514	    I address you upon the subject of sin the sinner
514	    I mean is a man named Winkle who makes trouble in his
514	    club by laughing and sometimes won't write his piece in
514	    this fine paper I hope you will pardon his badness and
514	    let him send a French fable because he can't write out
514	    of his head as he has so many lessons to do and no brains
514	    in future I will try to take time by the fetlock and
514	    prepare some work which will be all commy la fo that
514	    means all right I am in haste as it is nearly school
514	    time.
514	    Yours respectably,
514	    N.  WINKLE
514	""
514	    [The above is a manly and handsome acknowledgment of past
514	    misdemeanors.  If our young friend studied punctuation, it
514	    would be well.]
514	""
514	    _________
514	""
514	    A SAD ACCIDENT
514	""
514	    On Friday last, we were startled by a violent shock
514	    in our basement, followed by cries of distress.
514	    On rushing in a body to the cellar, we discovered our beloved
514	    President prostrate upon the floor, having tripped and
514	    fallen while getting wood for domestic purposes.  A perfect
514	    scene of ruin met our eyes, for in his fall Mr. Pickwick
514	    had plunged his head and shoulders into a tub of water,
514	    upset a keg of soft soap upon his manly form,  and torn
514	    his garments badly.  On being removed from this perilous
514	    situation, it was discovered that he had suffered
514	    no injury but several bruises, and we are happy to add,
514	    is now doing well.
514	    ED.
514	""
514	    _________
514	""
514	    THE PUBLIC BEREAVEMENT
514	""
514	    It is our painful duty to record the sudden and
514	    mysterious disappearance of our cherished friend, Mrs.
514	    Snowball Pat Paw.  This lovely and beloved cat was the
514	    pet of a large circle of warm and admiring friends; for
514	    her beauty attracted all eyes, her graces and virtues
514	    endeared her to all hearts, and her loss is deeply felt
514	    by the whole community.
514	""
514	    When last seen, she was sitting at the gate, watching
514	    the butcher's cart, and it is feared that some villain,
514	    tempted by her charms, basely stole her.  Weeks have passed,
514	    but no trace of her has been discovered, and we relinquish
514	    all hope, tie a black ribbon to her basket, set aside her
514	    dish, and weep for her as one lost to us forever.
514	""
514	    _________
514	""
514	    A sympathizing friend sends the following gem:
514	""
514	""
514	    A LAMENT
514	    (FOR S.  B.  PAT PAW)
514	""
514	    We mourn the loss of our little pet,
514	    And sigh o'er her hapless fate,
514	    For never more by the fire she'll sit,
514	    Nor play by the old green gate.
514	""
514	    The little grave where her infant sleeps
514	    Is 'neath the chestnut tree.
514	    But o'er her grave we may not weep,
514	    We know not where it may be.
514	""
514	    Her empty bed, her idle ball,
514	    Will never see her more;
514	    No gentle tap, no loving purr
514	    Is heard at the parlor door.
514	""
514	    Another cat comes after her mice,
514	    A cat with a dirty face,
514	    But she does not hunt as our darling did,
514	    Nor play with her airy grace.
514	""
514	    Her stealthy paws tread the very hall
514	    Where Snowball used to play,
514	    But she only spits at the dogs our pet
514	    So gallantly drove away.
514	""
514	    She is useful and mild, and does her best,
514	    But she is not fair to see,
514	    And we cannot give her your place dear,
514	    Nor worship her as we worship thee.
514	    A.S.
514	""
514	    _________
