514	    WEEKLY REPORT
514	""
514	    Meg--Good.
514	    Jo--Bad.
514	    Beth--Very Good.
514	    Amy--Middling.
514	""
514	    _________________________________________________
514	""
514	""
514	As the President finished reading the paper (which I beg leave to
514	assure my readers is a bona fide copy of one written by bona fide girls
514	once upon a time), a round of applause followed, and then Mr. Snodgrass
514	rose to make a proposition.
514	""
514	"""Mr. President and gentlemen,"" he began, assuming a parliamentary"
514	"attitude and tone, ""I wish to propose the admission of a new"
514	member--one who highly deserves the honor, would be deeply grateful for
514	it, and would add immensely to the spirit of the club, the literary
514	value of the paper, and be no end jolly and nice.  I propose Mr.
514	Theodore Laurence as an honorary member of the P.  C.  Come now, do
514	"have him."""
514	""
514	Jo's sudden change of tone made the girls laugh, but all looked rather
514	anxious, and no one said a word as Snodgrass took his seat.
514	""
514	"""We'll put it to a vote,"" said the President.  ""All in favor of this"
514	"motion please to manifest it by saying, 'Aye'."""
514	""
514	A loud response from Snodgrass, followed, to everybody's surprise, by a
514	timid one from Beth.
514	""
514	"""Contrary-minded say, 'No'."""
514	""
514	Meg and Amy were contrary-minded, and Mr. Winkle rose to say with great
514	"elegance, ""We don't wish any boys, they only joke and bounce about."
514	"This is a ladies' club, and we wish to be private and proper."""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid he'll laugh at our paper, and make fun of us afterward,"""
514	observed Pickwick, pulling the little curl on her forehead, as she
514	always did when doubtful.
514	""
514	"Up rose Snodgrass, very much in earnest.  ""Sir, I give you my word as a"
514	gentleman, Laurie won't do anything of the sort.  He likes to write,
514	and he'll give a tone to our contributions and keep us from being
514	sentimental, don't you see?  We can do so little for him, and he does
514	so much for us, I think the least we can do is to offer him a place
514	"here, and make him welcome if he comes."""
514	""
514	This artful allusion to benefits conferred brought Tupman to his feet,
514	looking as if he had quite made up his mind.
514	""
514	"""Yes; we ought to do it, even if we are afraid.  I say he may come, and"
514	"his grandpa, too, if he likes."""
514	""
514	This spirited burst from Beth electrified the club, and Jo left her
514	"seat to shake hands approvingly.  ""Now then, vote again. Everybody"
514	"remember it's our Laurie, and say, 'Aye!'"" cried Snodgrass excitedly."
514	""
514	"""Aye!  Aye!  Aye!"" replied three voices at once."
514	""
514	"""Good!  Bless you!  Now, as there's nothing like 'taking time by the"
514	fetlock', as Winkle characteristically observes, allow me to present
514	"the new member.""  And, to the dismay of the rest of the club, Jo threw"
514	open the door of the closet, and displayed Laurie sitting on a rag bag,
514	flushed and twinkling with suppressed laughter.
514	""
514	"""You rogue!  You traitor!  Jo, how could you?"" cried the three girls,"
514	as Snodgrass led her friend triumphantly forth, and producing both a
514	chair and a badge, installed him in a jiffy.
514	""
514	"""The coolness of you two rascals is amazing,"" began Mr. Pickwick,"
514	trying to get up an awful frown and only succeeding in producing an
514	amiable smile.  But the new member was equal to the occasion, and
514	rising, with a grateful salutation to the Chair, said in the most
514	"engaging manner, ""Mr. President and ladies--I beg pardon,"
514	gentlemen--allow me to introduce myself as Sam Weller, the very humble
514	"servant of the club."""
514	""
514	"""Good!  Good!"" cried Jo, pounding with the handle of the old warming"
514	pan on which she leaned.
514	""
514	"""My faithful friend and noble patron,"" continued Laurie with a wave of"
514	"the hand, ""who has so flatteringly presented me, is not to be blamed"
514	for the base stratagem of tonight.  I planned it, and she only gave in
514	"after lots of teasing."""
514	""
514	"""Come now, don't lay it all on yourself.  You know I proposed the"
514	"cupboard,"" broke in Snodgrass, who was enjoying the joke amazingly."
514	""
514	"""Never mind what she says.  I'm the wretch that did it, sir,"" said the"
514	"new member, with a Welleresque nod to Mr. Pickwick.  ""But on my honor,"
514	I never will do so again, and henceforth devote myself to the interest
514	"of this immortal club."""
514	""
514	"""Hear!  Hear!"" cried Jo, clashing the lid of the warming pan like a"
514	cymbal.
514	""
514	"""Go on, go on!"" added Winkle and Tupman, while the President bowed"
514	benignly.
514	""
514	"""I merely wish to say, that as a slight token of my gratitude for the"
514	honor done me, and as a means of promoting friendly relations between
514	adjoining nations, I have set up a post office in the hedge in the
514	lower corner of the garden, a fine, spacious building with padlocks on
514	the doors and every convenience for the mails, also the females, if I
514	may be allowed the expression.  It's the old martin house, but I've
514	stopped up the door and made the roof open, so it will hold all sorts
514	of things, and save our valuable time.  Letters, manuscripts, books,
514	and bundles can be passed in there, and as each nation has a key, it
514	will be uncommonly nice, I fancy.  Allow me to present the club key,
514	"and with many thanks for your favor, take my seat."""
514	""
514	Great applause as Mr. Weller deposited a little key on the table and
514	subsided, the warming pan clashed and waved wildly, and it was some
514	time before order could be restored.  A long discussion followed, and
514	everyone came out surprising, for everyone did her best.  So it was an
514	unusually lively meeting, and did not adjourn till a late hour, when it
514	broke up with three shrill cheers for the new member.
514	""
514	No one ever regretted the admittance of Sam Weller, for a more devoted,
514	well-behaved, and jovial member no club could have. He certainly did
514	add 'spirit' to the meetings, and 'a tone' to the paper, for his
514	orations convulsed his hearers and his contributions were excellent,
514	being patriotic, classical, comical, or dramatic, but never
514	sentimental.  Jo regarded them as worthy of Bacon, Milton, or
514	Shakespeare, and remodeled her own works with good effect, she thought.
514	""
514	The P.  O.  was a capital little institution, and flourished
514	wonderfully, for nearly as many queer things passed through it as
514	through the real post office.  Tragedies and cravats, poetry and
514	pickles, garden seeds and long letters, music and gingerbread, rubbers,
514	invitations, scoldings, and puppies.  The old gentleman liked the fun,
514	and amused himself by sending odd bundles, mysterious messages, and
514	funny telegrams, and his gardener, who was smitten with Hannah's
514	charms, actually sent a love letter to Jo's care.  How they laughed
514	when the secret came out, never dreaming how many love letters that
514	little post office would hold in the years to come.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER ELEVEN
514	""
514	EXPERIMENTS
514	""
514	"""The first of June!  The Kings are off to the seashore tomorrow, and"
514	"I'm free.  Three months' vacation--how I shall enjoy it!"" exclaimed"
514	Meg, coming home one warm day to find Jo laid upon the sofa in an
514	unusual state of exhaustion, while Beth took off her dusty boots, and
514	Amy made lemonade for the refreshment of the whole party.
514	""
514	"""Aunt March went today, for which, oh, be joyful!"" said Jo. ""I was"
514	mortally afraid she'd ask me to go with her.  If she had, I should have
514	felt as if I ought to do it, but Plumfield is about as gay as a
514	churchyard, you know, and I'd rather be excused. We had a flurry
514	getting the old lady off, and I had a fright every time she spoke to
514	me, for I was in such a hurry to be through that I was uncommonly
514	helpful and sweet, and feared she'd find it impossible to part from me.
514	I quaked till she was fairly in the carriage, and had a final fright,
514	for as it drove of, she popped out her head, saying, 'Josyphine, won't
514	you--?' I didn't hear any more, for I basely turned and fled.  I did
514	"actually run, and whisked round the corner where I felt safe."""
514	""
514	"""Poor old Jo!  She came in looking as if bears were after her,"" said"
514	Beth, as she cuddled her sister's feet with a motherly air.
514	""
514	"""Aunt March is a regular samphire, is she not?"" observed Amy, tasting"
514	her mixture critically.
514	""
514	"""She means vampire, not seaweed, but it doesn't matter.  It's too warm"
514	"to be particular about one's parts of speech,"" murmured Jo."
514	""
514	"""What shall you do all your vacation?"" asked Amy, changing the subject"
514	with tact.
514	""
514	"""I shall lie abed late, and do nothing,"" replied Meg, from the depths"
514	"of the rocking chair.  ""I've been routed up early all winter and had to"
514	spend my days working for other people, so now I'm going to rest and
514	"revel to my heart's content."""
514	""
514	"""No,"" said Jo, ""that dozy way wouldn't suit me.  I've laid in a heap of"
514	books, and I'm going to improve my shining hours reading on my perch in
514	"the old apple tree, when I'm not having l----"""
514	""
514	"""Don't say 'larks!'"" implored Amy, as a return snub for the 'samphire'"
514	correction.
514	""
514	"""I'll say 'nightingales' then, with Laurie.  That's proper and"
514	"appropriate, since he's a warbler."""
514	""
514	"""Don't let us do any lessons, Beth, for a while, but play all the time"
514	"and rest, as the girls mean to,"" proposed Amy."
514	""
514	"""Well, I will, if Mother doesn't mind.  I want to learn some new songs,"
514	and my children need fitting up for the summer.  They are dreadfully
514	"out of order and really suffering for clothes."""
514	""
514	"""May we, Mother?"" asked Meg, turning to Mrs. March, who sat sewing in"
514	what they called 'Marmee's corner'.
514	""
514	"""You may try your experiment for a week and see how you like it.  I"
514	think by Saturday night you will find that all play and no work is as
514	"bad as all work and no play."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear, no!  It will be delicious, I'm sure,"" said Meg complacently."
514	""
514	"""I now propose a toast, as my 'friend and pardner, Sairy Gamp', says."
514	"Fun forever, and no grubbing!"" cried Jo, rising, glass in hand, as the"
514	lemonade went round.
514	""
514	They all drank it merrily, and began the experiment by lounging for the
514	rest of the day.  Next morning, Meg did not appear till ten o'clock.
514	Her solitary breakfast did not taste good, and the room seemed lonely
514	and untidy, for Jo had not filled the vases, Beth had not dusted, and
514	Amy's books lay scattered about.  Nothing was neat and pleasant but
514	'Marmee's corner', which looked as usual.  And there Meg sat, to 'rest
514	and read', which meant to yawn and imagine what pretty summer dresses
514	she would get with her salary.  Jo spent the morning on the river with
514	Laurie and the afternoon reading and crying over _The Wide, Wide
514	World_, up in the apple tree.  Beth began by rummaging everything out
514	of the big closet where her family resided, but getting tired before
514	half done, she left her establishment topsy-turvy and went to her
514	music, rejoicing that she had no dishes to wash. Amy arranged her
514	bower, put on her best white frock, smoothed her curls, and sat down to
514	draw under the honeysuckle, hoping someone would see and inquire who
514	the young artist was.  As no one appeared but an inquisitive
514	daddy-longlegs, who examined her work with interest, she went to walk,
514	got caught in a shower, and came home dripping.
514	""
514	At teatime they compared notes, and all agreed that it had been a
514	delightful, though unusually long day.  Meg, who went shopping in the
514	afternoon and got a 'sweet blue muslin', had discovered, after she had
514	cut the breadths off, that it wouldn't wash, which mishap made her
514	slightly cross.  Jo had burned the skin off her nose boating, and got a
514	raging headache by reading too long.  Beth was worried by the confusion
514	of her closet and the difficulty of learning three or four songs at
514	once, and Amy deeply regretted the damage done her frock, for Katy
514	Brown's party was to be the next day and now like Flora McFlimsey, she
514	had 'nothing to wear'.  But these were mere trifles, and they assured
514	their mother that the experiment was working finely.  She smiled, said
514	nothing, and with Hannah's help did their neglected work, keeping home
514	pleasant and the domestic machinery running smoothly.  It was
514	astonishing what a peculiar and uncomfortable state of things was
514	produced by the 'resting and reveling' process.  The days kept getting
514	longer and longer, the weather was unusually variable and so were
514	tempers; an unsettled feeling possessed everyone, and Satan found
514	plenty of mischief for the idle hands to do.  As the height of luxury,
514	Meg put out some of her sewing, and then found time hang so heavily,
514	that she fell to snipping and spoiling her clothes in her attempts to
514	furbish them up a la Moffat.  Jo read till her eyes gave out and she
514	was sick of books, got so fidgety that even good-natured Laurie had a
514	quarrel with her, and so reduced in spirits that she desperately wished
514	she had gone with Aunt March.  Beth got on pretty well, for she was
514	constantly forgetting that it was to be all play and no work, and fell
514	back into her old ways now and then.  But something in the air affected
514	her, and more than once her tranquility was much disturbed, so much so
514	that on one occasion she actually shook poor dear Joanna and told her
514	she was 'a fright'.  Amy fared worst of all, for her resources were
514	small, and when her sisters left her to amuse herself, she soon found
514	that accomplished and important little self a great burden.  She didn't
514	like dolls, fairy tales were childish, and one couldn't draw all the
514	time.  Tea parties didn't amount to much, neither did picnics, unless
514	"very well conducted.  ""If one could have a fine house, full of nice"
514	girls, or go traveling, the summer would be delightful, but to stay at
514	home with three selfish sisters and a grown-up boy was enough to try
514	"the patience of a Boaz,"" complained Miss Malaprop, after several days"
514	devoted to pleasure, fretting, and ennui.
514	""
514	No one would own that they were tired of the experiment, but by Friday
514	night each acknowledged to herself that she was glad the week was
514	nearly done.  Hoping to impress the lesson more deeply, Mrs. March, who
514	had a good deal of humor, resolved to finish off the trial in an
514	appropriate manner, so she gave Hannah a holiday and let the girls
514	enjoy the full effect of the play system.
514	""
514	When they got up on Saturday morning, there was no fire in the kitchen,
514	no breakfast in the dining room, and no mother anywhere to be seen.
514	""
514	"""Mercy on us!  What has happened?"" cried Jo, staring about her in"
514	dismay.
514	""
514	Meg ran upstairs and soon came back again, looking relieved but rather
514	bewildered, and a little ashamed.
514	""
514	"""Mother isn't sick, only very tired, and she says she is going to stay"
514	quietly in her room all day and let us do the best we can.  It's a very
514	queer thing for her to do, she doesn't act a bit like herself.  But she
514	says it has been a hard week for her, so we mustn't grumble but take
514	"care of ourselves."""
514	""
514	"""That's easy enough, and I like the idea, I'm aching for something to"
514	"do, that is, some new amusement, you know,"" added Jo quickly."
514	""
514	In fact it was an immense relief to them all to have a little work, and
514	they took hold with a will, but soon realized the truth of Hannah's
514	"saying, ""Housekeeping ain't no joke.""  There was plenty of food in the"
514	larder, and while Beth and Amy set the table, Meg and Jo got breakfast,
514	wondering as they did why servants ever talked about hard work.
514	""
514	"""I shall take some up to Mother, though she said we were not to think"
514	"of her, for she'd take care of herself,"" said Meg, who presided and"
514	felt quite matronly behind the teapot.
514	""
514	So a tray was fitted out before anyone began, and taken up with the
514	cook's compliments.  The boiled tea was very bitter, the omelet
514	scorched, and the biscuits speckled with saleratus, but Mrs. March
514	received her repast with thanks and laughed heartily over it after Jo
514	was gone.
514	""
514	"""Poor little souls, they will have a hard time, I'm afraid, but they"
514	"won't suffer, and it will do them good,"" she said, producing the more"
514	palatable viands with which she had provided herself, and disposing of
514	the bad breakfast, so that their feelings might not be hurt, a motherly
514	little deception for which they were grateful.
514	""
514	Many were the complaints below, and great the chagrin of the head cook
514	"at her failures.  ""Never mind, I'll get the dinner and be servant, you"
514	"be mistress, keep your hands nice, see company, and give orders,"" said"
514	Jo, who knew still less than Meg about culinary affairs.
514	""
514	This obliging offer was gladly accepted, and Margaret retired to the
514	parlor, which she hastily put in order by whisking the litter under the
514	sofa and shutting the blinds to save the trouble of dusting.  Jo, with
514	perfect faith in her own powers and a friendly desire to make up the
514	quarrel, immediately put a note in the office, inviting Laurie to
514	dinner.
514	""
514	"""You'd better see what you have got before you think of having"
514	"company,"" said Meg, when informed of the hospitable but rash act."
514	""
514	"""Oh, there's corned beef and plenty of potatoes, and I shall get some"
514	asparagus and a lobster, 'for a relish', as Hannah says. We'll have
514	lettuce and make a salad.  I don't know how, but the book tells.  I'll
514	have blanc mange and strawberries for dessert, and coffee too, if you
514	"want to be elegant."""
514	""
514	"""Don't try too many messes, Jo, for you can't make anything but"
514	gingerbread and molasses candy fit to eat.  I wash my hands of the
514	dinner party, and since you have asked Laurie on your own
514	"responsibility, you may just take care of him."""
514	""
514	"""I don't want you to do anything but be civil to him and help to the"
514	"pudding.  You'll give me your advice if I get in a muddle, won't you?"""
514	asked Jo, rather hurt.
514	""
514	"""Yes, but I don't know much, except about bread and a few trifles.  You"
514	"had better ask Mother's leave before you order anything,"" returned Meg"
514	prudently.
514	""
514	"""Of course I shall.  I'm not a fool.""  And Jo went off in a huff at the"
514	doubts expressed of her powers.
514	""
514	"""Get what you like, and don't disturb me.  I'm going out to dinner and"
514	"can't worry about things at home,"" said Mrs. March, when Jo spoke to"
514	"her.  ""I never enjoyed housekeeping, and I'm going to take a vacation"
514	"today, and read, write, go visiting, and amuse myself."""
514	""
514	The unusual spectacle of her busy mother rocking comfortably and
514	reading early in the morning made Jo feel as if some unnatural
514	phenomenon had occurred, for an eclipse, an earthquake, or a volcanic
514	eruption would hardly have seemed stranger.
514	""
514	"""Everything is out of sorts, somehow,"" she said to herself, going"
514	"downstairs.  ""There's Beth crying, that's a sure sign that something is"
514	"wrong in this family.  If Amy is bothering, I'll shake her."""
514	""
514	Feeling very much out of sorts herself, Jo hurried into the parlor to
514	find Beth sobbing over Pip, the canary, who lay dead in the cage with
514	his little claws pathetically extended, as if imploring the food for
514	want of which he had died.
514	""
514	"""It's all my fault, I forgot him, there isn't a seed or a drop left."
514	"Oh, Pip!  Oh, Pip!  How could I be so cruel to you?"" cried Beth, taking"
514	the poor thing in her hands and trying to restore him.
514	""
514	Jo peeped into his half-open eye, felt his little heart, and finding
514	him stiff and cold, shook her head, and offered her domino box for a
514	coffin.
514	""
514	"""Put him in the oven, and maybe he will get warm and revive,"" said Amy"
514	hopefully.
514	""
514	"""He's been starved, and he shan't be baked now he's dead.  I'll make"
514	him a shroud, and he shall be buried in the garden, and I'll never have
514	"another bird, never, my Pip! for I am too bad to own one,"" murmured"
514	Beth, sitting on the floor with her pet folded in her hands.
514	""
514	"""The funeral shall be this afternoon, and we will all go.  Now, don't"
514	cry, Bethy.  It's a pity, but nothing goes right this week, and Pip has
514	had the worst of the experiment.  Make the shroud, and lay him in my
514	"box, and after the dinner party, we'll have a nice little funeral,"""
514	said Jo, beginning to feel as if she had undertaken a good deal.
514	""
514	Leaving the others to console Beth, she departed to the kitchen, which
514	was in a most discouraging state of confusion.  Putting on a big apron,
514	she fell to work and got the dishes piled up ready for washing, when
514	she discovered that the fire was out.
514	""
514	"""Here's a sweet prospect!"" muttered Jo, slamming the stove door open,"
514	and poking vigorously among the cinders.
514	""
514	Having rekindled the fire, she thought she would go to market while the
514	water heated.  The walk revived her spirits, and flattering herself
514	that she had made good bargains, she trudged home again, after buying a
514	very young lobster, some very old asparagus, and two boxes of acid
514	strawberries.  By the time she got cleared up, the dinner arrived and
514	the stove was red-hot.  Hannah had left a pan of bread to rise, Meg had
514	worked it up early, set it on the hearth for a second rising, and
514	forgotten it.  Meg was entertaining Sallie Gardiner in the parlor, when
514	the door flew open and a floury, crocky, flushed, and disheveled figure
514	appeared, demanding tartly...
514	""
514	"""I say, isn't bread 'riz' enough when it runs over the pans?"""
514	""
514	Sallie began to laugh, but Meg nodded and lifted her eyebrows as high
514	as they would go, which caused the apparition to vanish and put the
514	sour bread into the oven without further delay.  Mrs. March went out,
514	after peeping here and there to see how matters went, also saying a
514	word of comfort to Beth, who sat making a winding sheet, while the dear
514	departed lay in state in the domino box.  A strange sense of
514	helplessness fell upon the girls as the gray bonnet vanished round the
514	corner, and despair seized them when a few minutes later Miss Crocker
514	appeared, and said she'd come to dinner.  Now this lady was a thin,
514	yellow spinster, with a sharp nose and inquisitive eyes, who saw
514	everything and gossiped about all she saw. They disliked her, but had
514	been taught to be kind to her, simply because she was old and poor and
514	had few friends.  So Meg gave her the easy chair and tried to entertain
514	her, while she asked questions, criticized everything, and told stories
514	of the people whom she knew.
514	""
514	Language cannot describe the anxieties, experiences, and exertions
514	which Jo underwent that morning, and the dinner she served up became a
514	standing joke.  Fearing to ask any more advice, she did her best alone,
514	and discovered that something more than energy and good will is
514	necessary to make a cook.  She boiled the asparagus for an hour and was
514	grieved to find the heads cooked off and the stalks harder than ever.
514	The bread burned black; for the salad dressing so aggravated her that
514	she could not make it fit to eat.  The lobster was a scarlet mystery to
514	her, but she hammered and poked till it was unshelled and its meager
514	proportions concealed in a grove of lettuce leaves.  The potatoes had
514	to be hurried, not to keep the asparagus waiting, and were not done at
514	the last.  The blanc mange was lumpy, and the strawberries not as ripe
514	as they looked, having been skilfully 'deaconed'.
514	""
514	"""Well, they can eat beef and bread and butter, if they are hungry, only"
514	"it's mortifying to have to spend your whole morning for nothing,"""
514	thought Jo, as she rang the bell half an hour later than usual, and
514	stood, hot, tired, and dispirited, surveying the feast spread before
514	Laurie, accustomed to all sorts of elegance, and Miss Crocker, whose
514	tattling tongue would report them far and wide.
514	""
514	Poor Jo would gladly have gone under the table, as one thing after
514	another was tasted and left, while Amy giggled, Meg looked distressed,
514	Miss Crocker pursed her lips, and Laurie talked and laughed with all
514	his might to give a cheerful tone to the festive scene.  Jo's one
514	strong point was the fruit, for she had sugared it well, and had a
514	pitcher of rich cream to eat with it.  Her hot cheeks cooled a trifle,
514	and she drew a long breath as the pretty glass plates went round, and
514	everyone looked graciously at the little rosy islands floating in a sea
514	of cream.  Miss Crocker tasted first, made a wry face, and drank some
514	water hastily.  Jo, who refused, thinking there might not be enough,
514	for they dwindled sadly after the picking over, glanced at Laurie, but
514	he was eating away manfully, though there was a slight pucker about his
514	mouth and he kept his eye fixed on his plate.  Amy, who was fond of
514	delicate fare, took a heaping spoonful, choked, hid her face in her
514	napkin, and left the table precipitately.
514	""
514	"""Oh, what is it?"" exclaimed Jo, trembling."
514	""
514	"""Salt instead of sugar, and the cream is sour,"" replied Meg with a"
514	tragic gesture.
514	""
514	Jo uttered a groan and fell back in her chair, remembering that she had
514	given a last hasty powdering to the berries out of one of the two boxes
514	on the kitchen table, and had neglected to put the milk in the
514	refrigerator.  She turned scarlet and was on the verge of crying, when
514	she met Laurie's eyes, which would look merry in spite of his heroic
514	efforts.  The comical side of the affair suddenly struck her, and she
514	laughed till the tears ran down her cheeks.  So did everyone else, even
514	'Croaker' as the girls called the old lady, and the unfortunate dinner
514	ended gaily, with bread and butter, olives and fun.
514	""
514	"""I haven't strength of mind enough to clear up now, so we will sober"
514	"ourselves with a funeral,"" said Jo, as they rose, and Miss Crocker made"
514	ready to go, being eager to tell the new story at another friend's
514	dinner table.
514	""
514	They did sober themselves for Beth's sake.  Laurie dug a grave under
514	the ferns in the grove, little Pip was laid in, with many tears by his
514	tender-hearted mistress, and covered with moss, while a wreath of
514	violets and chickweed was hung on the stone which bore his epitaph,
514	composed by Jo while she struggled with the dinner.
514	""
514	    Here lies Pip March,
514	    Who died the 7th of June;
514	    Loved and lamented sore,
514	    And not forgotten soon.
514	""
514	At the conclusion of the ceremonies, Beth retired to her room, overcome
514	with emotion and lobster, but there was no place of repose, for the
514	beds were not made, and she found her grief much assuaged by beating up
514	the pillows and putting things in order.  Meg helped Jo clear away the
514	remains of the feast, which took half the afternoon and left them so
514	tired that they agreed to be contented with tea and toast for supper.
514	""
514	Laurie took Amy to drive, which was a deed of charity, for the sour
514	cream seemed to have had a bad effect upon her temper.  Mrs. March came
514	home to find the three older girls hard at work in the middle of the
514	afternoon, and a glance at the closet gave her an idea of the success
514	of one part of the experiment.
514	""
514	Before the housewives could rest, several people called, and there was
514	a scramble to get ready to see them.  Then tea must be got, errands
514	done, and one or two necessary bits of sewing neglected until the last
514	minute.  As twilight fell, dewy and still, one by one they gathered on
514	the porch where the June roses were budding beautifully, and each
514	groaned or sighed as she sat down, as if tired or troubled.
514	""
514	"""What a dreadful day this has been!"" began Jo, usually the first to"
514	speak.
514	""
514	"""It has seemed shorter than usual, but so uncomfortable,"" said Meg."
514	""
514	"""Not a bit like home,"" added Amy."
514	""
514	"""It can't seem so without Marmee and little Pip,"" sighed Beth, glancing"
514	with full eyes at the empty cage above her head.
514	""
514	"""Here's Mother, dear, and you shall have another bird tomorrow, if you"
514	"want it."""
514	""
514	As she spoke, Mrs. March came and took her place among them, looking as
514	if her holiday had not been much pleasanter than theirs.
514	""
514	"""Are you satisfied with your experiment, girls, or do you want another"
514	"week of it?"" she asked, as Beth nestled up to her and the rest turned"
514	toward her with brightening faces, as flowers turn toward the sun.
514	""
514	"""I don't!"" cried Jo decidedly."
514	""
514	"""Nor I,"" echoed the others."
514	""
514	"""You think then, that it is better to have a few duties and live a"
514	"little for others, do you?"""
514	""
514	"""Lounging and larking doesn't pay,"" observed Jo, shaking her head. ""I'm"
514	"tired of it and mean to go to work at something right off."""
514	""
514	"""Suppose you learn plain cooking.  That's a useful accomplishment,"
514	"which no woman should be without,"" said Mrs. March, laughing inaudibly"
514	at the recollection of Jo's dinner party, for she had met Miss Crocker
514	and heard her account of it.
514	""
514	"""Mother, did you go away and let everything be, just to see how we'd"
514	"get on?"" cried Meg, who had had suspicions all day."
514	""
514	"""Yes, I wanted you to see how the comfort of all depends on each doing"
514	her share faithfully.  While Hannah and I did your work, you got on
514	pretty well, though I don't think you were very happy or amiable.  So I
514	thought, as a little lesson, I would show you what happens when
514	everyone thinks only of herself.  Don't you feel that it is pleasanter
514	to help one another, to have daily duties which make leisure sweet when
514	it comes, and to bear and forbear, that home may be comfortable and
514	"lovely to us all?"""
514	""
514	"""We do, Mother, we do!"" cried the girls."
514	""
514	"""Then let me advise you to take up your little burdens again, for"
514	though they seem heavy sometimes, they are good for us, and lighten as
514	we learn to carry them.  Work is wholesome, and there is plenty for
514	everyone.  It keeps us from ennui and mischief, is good for health and
514	spirits, and gives us a sense of power and independence better than
514	"money or fashion."""
514	""
514	"""We'll work like bees, and love it too, see if we don't,"" said Jo."
514	"""I'll learn plain cooking for my holiday task, and the next dinner"
514	"party I have shall be a success."""
514	""
514	"""I'll make the set of shirts for father, instead of letting you do it,"
514	Marmee.  I can and I will, though I'm not fond of sewing. That will be
514	better than fussing over my own things, which are plenty nice enough as
514	"they are."" said Meg."
514	""
514	"""I'll do my lessons every day, and not spend so much time with my music"
514	and dolls.  I am a stupid thing, and ought to be studying, not
514	"playing,"" was Beth's resolution, while Amy followed their example by"
514	"heroically declaring, ""I shall learn to make buttonholes, and attend to"
514	"my parts of speech."""
514	""
514	"""Very good!  Then I am quite satisfied with the experiment, and fancy"
514	that we shall not have to repeat it, only don't go to the other extreme
514	and delve like slaves.  Have regular hours for work and play, make each
514	day both useful and pleasant, and prove that you understand the worth
514	of time by employing it well.  Then youth will be delightful, old age
514	will bring few regrets, and life become a beautiful success, in spite
514	"of poverty."""
514	""
514	"""We'll remember, Mother!"" and they did."
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWELVE
514	""
514	CAMP LAURENCE
514	""
514	Beth was postmistress, for, being most at home, she could attend to it
514	regularly, and dearly liked the daily task of unlocking the little door
514	and distributing the mail.  One July day she came in with her hands
514	full, and went about the house leaving letters and parcels like the
514	penny post.
514	""
514	"""Here's your posy, Mother!  Laurie never forgets that,"" she said,"
514	putting the fresh nosegay in the vase that stood in 'Marmee's corner',
514	and was kept supplied by the affectionate boy.
514	""
514	"""Miss Meg March, one letter and a glove,"" continued Beth, delivering"
514	the articles to her sister, who sat near her mother, stitching
514	wristbands.
514	""
514	"""Why, I left a pair over there, and here is only one,"" said Meg,"
514	"looking at the gray cotton glove.  ""Didn't you drop the other in the"
514	"garden?"""
514	""
514	"""No, I'm sure I didn't, for there was only one in the office."""
514	""
514	"""I hate to have odd gloves!  Never mind, the other may be found.  My"
514	letter is only a translation of the German song I wanted.  I think Mr.
514	"Brooke did it, for this isn't Laurie's writing."""
514	""
514	Mrs. March glanced at Meg, who was looking very pretty in her gingham
514	morning gown, with the little curls blowing about her forehead, and
514	very womanly, as she sat sewing at her little worktable, full of tidy
514	white rolls, so unconscious of the thought in her mother's mind as she
514	sewed and sang, while her fingers flew and her thoughts were busied
514	with girlish fancies as innocent and fresh as the pansies in her belt,
514	that Mrs. March smiled and was satisfied.
514	""
514	"""Two letters for Doctor Jo, a book, and a funny old hat, which covered"
514	"the whole post office and stuck outside,"" said Beth, laughing as she"
514	went into the study where Jo sat writing.
514	""
514	"""What a sly fellow Laurie is!  I said I wished bigger hats were the"
514	fashion, because I burn my face every hot day.  He said, 'Why mind the
514	fashion?  Wear a big hat, and be comfortable!' I said I would if I had
514	one, and he has sent me this, to try me.  I'll wear it for fun, and
514	"show him I don't care for the fashion.""  And hanging the antique"
514	broad-brim on a bust of Plato, Jo read her letters.
514	""
514	One from her mother made her cheeks glow and her eyes fill, for it said
514	to her...
514	""
514	""
514	My Dear:
514	""
514	I write a little word to tell you with how much satisfaction I watch
514	your efforts to control your temper.  You say nothing about your
514	trials, failures, or successes, and think, perhaps, that no one sees
514	them but the Friend whose help you daily ask, if I may trust the
514	well-worn cover of your guidebook.  I, too, have seen them all, and
514	heartily believe in the sincerity of your resolution, since it begins
514	to bear fruit.  Go on, dear, patiently and bravely, and always believe
514	that no one sympathizes more tenderly with you than your loving...
514	""
514	Mother
514	""
514	""
514	"""That does me good!  That's worth millions of money and pecks of"
514	praise.  Oh, Marmee, I do try!  I will keep on trying, and not get
514	"tired, since I have you to help me."""
514	""
514	Laying her head on her arms, Jo wet her little romance with a few happy
514	tears, for she had thought that no one saw and appreciated her efforts
514	to be good, and this assurance was doubly precious, doubly encouraging,
514	because unexpected and from the person whose commendation she most
514	valued.  Feeling stronger than ever to meet and subdue her Apollyon,
514	she pinned the note inside her frock, as a shield and a reminder, lest
514	she be taken unaware, and proceeded to open her other letter, quite
514	ready for either good or bad news.  In a big, dashing hand, Laurie
514	wrote...
514	""
514	Dear Jo, What ho!
514	""
514	Some English girls and boys are coming to see me tomorrow and I want to
514	have a jolly time.  If it's fine, I'm going to pitch my tent in
514	Longmeadow, and row up the whole crew to lunch and croquet--have a
514	fire, make messes, gypsy fashion, and all sorts of larks.  They are
514	nice people, and like such things.  Brooke will go to keep us boys
514	steady, and Kate Vaughn will play propriety for the girls.  I want you
514	all to come, can't let Beth off at any price, and nobody shall worry
514	her.  Don't bother about rations, I'll see to that and everything else,
514	only do come, there's a good fellow!
514	""
514	In a tearing hurry, Yours ever, Laurie.
514	""
514	"""Here's richness!"" cried Jo, flying in to tell the news to Meg."
514	""
514	"""Of course we can go, Mother?  It will be such a help to Laurie, for I"
514	can row, and Meg see to the lunch, and the children be useful in some
514	"way."""
514	""
514	"""I hope the Vaughns are not fine grown-up people.  Do you know anything"
514	"about them, Jo?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""Only that there are four of them.  Kate is older than you, Fred and"
514	Frank (twins) about my age, and a little girl (Grace), who is nine or
514	ten.  Laurie knew them abroad, and liked the boys.  I fancied, from the
514	way he primmed up his mouth in speaking of her, that he didn't admire
514	"Kate much."""
514	""
514	"""I'm so glad my French print is clean, it's just the thing and so"
514	"becoming!"" observed Meg complacently.  ""Have you anything decent, Jo?"""
514	""
514	"""Scarlet and gray boating suit, good enough for me.  I shall row and"
514	tramp about, so I don't want any starch to think of.  You'll come,
514	"Betty?"""
514	""
514	"""If you won't let any boys talk to me."""
514	""
514	"""Not a boy!"""
514	""
514	"""I like to please Laurie, and I'm not afraid of Mr. Brooke, he is so"
514	kind.  But I don't want to play, or sing, or say anything. I'll work
514	hard and not trouble anyone, and you'll take care of me, Jo, so I'll
514	"go."""
514	""
514	"""That's my good girl.  You do try to fight off your shyness, and I love"
514	you for it.  Fighting faults isn't easy, as I know, and a cheery word
514	"kind of gives a lift.  Thank you, Mother,"" And Jo gave the thin cheek a"
514	grateful kiss, more precious to Mrs. March than if it had given back
514	the rosy roundness of her youth.
514	""
514	"""I had a box of chocolate drops, and the picture I wanted to copy,"""
514	said Amy, showing her mail.
514	""
514	"""And I got a note from Mr. Laurence, asking me to come over and play to"
514	"him tonight, before the lamps are lighted, and I shall go,"" added Beth,"
514	whose friendship with the old gentleman prospered finely.
514	""
514	"""Now let's fly round, and do double duty today, so that we can play"
514	"tomorrow with free minds,"" said Jo, preparing to replace her pen with a"
514	broom.
514	""
514	When the sun peeped into the girls' room early next morning to promise
514	them a fine day, he saw a comical sight.  Each had made such
514	preparation for the fete as seemed necessary and proper. Meg had an
514	extra row of little curlpapers across her forehead, Jo had copiously
514	anointed her afflicted face with cold cream, Beth had taken Joanna to
514	bed with her to atone for the approaching separation, and Amy had
514	capped the climax by putting a clothespin on her nose to uplift the
514	offending feature.  It was one of the kind artists use to hold the
514	paper on their drawing boards, therefore quite appropriate and
514	effective for the purpose it was now being put.  This funny spectacle
514	appeared to amuse the sun, for he burst out with such radiance that Jo
514	woke up and roused her sisters by a hearty laugh at Amy's ornament.
514	""
514	Sunshine and laughter were good omens for a pleasure party, and soon a
514	lively bustle began in both houses.  Beth, who was ready first, kept
514	reporting what went on next door, and enlivened her sisters' toilets by
514	frequent telegrams from the window.
514	""
514	"""There goes the man with the tent!  I see Mrs. Barker doing up the"
514	lunch in a hamper and a great basket.  Now Mr. Laurence is looking up
514	at the sky and the weathercock.  I wish he would go too.  There's
514	Laurie, looking like a sailor, nice boy!  Oh, mercy me!  Here's a
514	carriage full of people, a tall lady, a little girl, and two dreadful
514	boys.  One is lame, poor thing, he's got a crutch. Laurie didn't tell
514	us that.  Be quick, girls!  It's getting late. Why, there is Ned
514	Moffat, I do declare.  Meg, isn't that the man who bowed to you one day
514	"when we were shopping?"""
514	""
514	"""So it is.  How queer that he should come.  I thought he was at the"
514	mountains.  There is Sallie.  I'm glad she got back in time. Am I all
514	"right, Jo?"" cried Meg in a flutter."
514	""
514	"""A regular daisy.  Hold up your dress and put your hat on straight, it"
514	looks sentimental tipped that way and will fly off at the first puff.
514	"Now then, come on!"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Jo, you are not going to wear that awful hat?  It's too absurd!"
514	"You shall not make a guy of yourself,"" remonstrated Meg, as Jo tied"
514	down with a red ribbon the broad-brimmed, old-fashioned leghorn Laurie
514	had sent for a joke.
514	""
514	"""I just will, though, for it's capital, so shady, light, and big. It"
514	"will make fun, and I don't mind being a guy if I'm comfortable."" With"
514	that Jo marched straight away and the rest followed, a bright little
514	band of sisters, all looking their best in summer suits, with happy
514	faces under the jaunty hatbrims.
514	""
514	Laurie ran to meet and present them to his friends in the most cordial
514	manner.  The lawn was the reception room, and for several minutes a
514	lively scene was enacted there.  Meg was grateful to see that Miss
514	Kate, though twenty, was dressed with a simplicity which American girls
514	would do well to imitate, and who was much flattered by Mr. Ned's
514	assurances that he came especially to see her.  Jo understood why
514	Laurie 'primmed up his mouth' when speaking of Kate, for that young
514	lady had a standoff-don't-touch-me air, which contrasted strongly with
514	the free and easy demeanor of the other girls.  Beth took an
514	observation of the new boys and decided that the lame one was not
514	'dreadful', but gentle and feeble, and she would be kind to him on that
514	account.  Amy found Grace a well-mannered, merry, little person, and
514	after staring dumbly at one another for a few minutes, they suddenly
514	became very good friends.
514	""
514	Tents, lunch, and croquet utensils having been sent on beforehand, the
514	party was soon embarked, and the two boats pushed off together, leaving
514	Mr. Laurence waving his hat on the shore.  Laurie and Jo rowed one
514	boat, Mr. Brooke and Ned the other, while Fred Vaughn, the riotous
514	twin, did his best to upset both by paddling about in a wherry like a
514	disturbed water bug.  Jo's funny hat deserved a vote of thanks, for it
514	was of general utility.  It broke the ice in the beginning by producing
514	a laugh, it created quite a refreshing breeze, flapping to and fro as
514	she rowed, and would make an excellent umbrella for the whole party, if
514	a shower came up, she said.  Miss Kate decided that she was 'odd', but
514	rather clever, and smiled upon her from afar.
514	""
514	Meg, in the other boat, was delightfully situated, face to face with
514	the rowers, who both admired the prospect and feathered their oars with
514	uncommon 'skill and dexterity'.  Mr. Brooke was a grave, silent young
514	man, with handsome brown eyes and a pleasant voice.  Meg liked his
514	quiet manners and considered him a walking encyclopedia of useful
514	knowledge.  He never talked to her much, but he looked at her a good
514	deal, and she felt sure that he did not regard her with aversion.  Ned,
514	being in college, of course put on all the airs which freshmen think it
514	their bounden duty to assume.  He was not very wise, but very
514	good-natured, and altogether an excellent person to carry on a picnic.
514	Sallie Gardiner was absorbed in keeping her white pique dress clean and
514	chattering with the ubiquitous Fred, who kept Beth in constant terror
514	by his pranks.
514	""
514	It was not far to Longmeadow, but the tent was pitched and the wickets
514	down by the time they arrived.  A pleasant green field, with three
514	wide-spreading oaks in the middle and a smooth strip of turf for
514	croquet.
514	""
514	"""Welcome to Camp Laurence!"" said the young host, as they landed with"
514	exclamations of delight.
514	""
514	"""Brooke is commander in chief, I am commissary general, the other"
514	fellows are staff officers, and you, ladies, are company. The tent is
514	for your especial benefit and that oak is your drawing room, this is
514	the messroom and the third is the camp kitchen.  Now, let's have a game
514	"before it gets hot, and then we'll see about dinner."""
514	""
514	Frank, Beth, Amy, and Grace sat down to watch the game played by the
514	other eight.  Mr. Brooke chose Meg, Kate, and Fred. Laurie took Sallie,
514	Jo, and Ned.  The English played well, but the Americans played better,
514	and contested every inch of the ground as strongly as if the spirit of
514	'76 inspired them.  Jo and Fred had several skirmishes and once
514	narrowly escaped high words. Jo was through the last wicket and had
514	missed the stroke, which failure ruffled her a good deal.  Fred was
514	close behind her and his turn came before hers.  He gave a stroke, his
514	ball hit the wicket, and stopped an inch on the wrong side.  No one was
514	very near, and running up to examine, he gave it a sly nudge with his
514	toe, which put it just an inch on the right side.
514	""
514	"""I'm through!  Now, Miss Jo, I'll settle you, and get in first,"" cried"
514	the young gentleman, swinging his mallet for another blow.
514	""
514	"""You pushed it.  I saw you.  It's my turn now,"" said Jo sharply."
514	""
514	"""Upon my word, I didn't move it.  It rolled a bit, perhaps, but that is"
514	"allowed.  So, stand off please, and let me have a go at the stake."""
514	""
514	"""We don't cheat in America, but you can, if you choose,"" said Jo"
514	angrily.
514	""
514	"""Yankees are a deal the most tricky, everybody knows.  There you go!"""
514	returned Fred, croqueting her ball far away.
514	""
514	Jo opened her lips to say something rude, but checked herself in time,
514	colored up to her forehead and stood a minute, hammering down a wicket
514	with all her might, while Fred hit the stake and declared himself out
514	with much exultation.  She went off to get her ball, and was a long
514	time finding it among the bushes, but she came back, looking cool and
514	quiet, and waited her turn patiently.  It took several strokes to
514	regain the place she had lost, and when she got there, the other side
514	had nearly won, for Kate's ball was the last but one and lay near the
514	stake.
514	""
514	"""By George, it's all up with us!  Goodbye, Kate.  Miss Jo owes me one,"
514	"so you are finished,"" cried Fred excitedly, as they all drew near to"
514	see the finish.
514	""
514	"""Yankees have a trick of being generous to their enemies,"" said Jo,"
514	"with a look that made the lad redden, ""especially when they beat them,"""
514	she added, as, leaving Kate's ball untouched, she won the game by a
514	clever stroke.
514	""
514	Laurie threw up his hat, then remembered that it wouldn't do to exult
514	over the defeat of his guests, and stopped in the middle of the cheer
514	"to whisper to his friend, ""Good for you, Jo!  He did cheat, I saw him."
514	"We can't tell him so, but he won't do it again, take my word for it."""
514	""
514	Meg drew her aside, under pretense of pinning up a loose braid, and
514	"said approvingly, ""It was dreadfully provoking, but you kept your"
514	"temper, and I'm so glad, Jo."""
514	""
514	"""Don't praise me, Meg, for I could box his ears this minute. I should"
514	certainly have boiled over if I hadn't stayed among the nettles till I
514	got my rage under control enough to hold my tongue. It's simmering now,
514	"so I hope he'll keep out of my way,"" returned Jo, biting her lips as"
514	she glowered at Fred from under her big hat.
514	""
514	"""Time for lunch,"" said Mr. Brooke, looking at his watch. ""Commissary"
514	general, will you make the fire and get water, while Miss March, Miss
514	"Sallie, and I spread the table?  Who can make good coffee?"""
514	""
514	"""Jo can,"" said Meg, glad to recommend her sister.  So Jo, feeling that"
514	her late lessons in cookery were to do her honor, went to preside over
514	the coffeepot, while the children collected dry sticks, and the boys
514	made a fire and got water from a spring near by.  Miss Kate sketched
514	and Frank talked to Beth, who was making little mats of braided rushes
514	to serve as plates.
514	""
514	The commander in chief and his aides soon spread the tablecloth with an
514	inviting array of eatables and drinkables, prettily decorated with
514	green leaves.  Jo announced that the coffee was ready, and everyone
514	settled themselves to a hearty meal, for youth is seldom dyspeptic, and
514	exercise develops wholesome appetites. A very merry lunch it was, for
514	everything seemed fresh and funny, and frequent peals of laughter
514	startled a venerable horse who fed near by.  There was a pleasing
514	inequality in the table, which produced many mishaps to cups and
514	plates, acorns dropped in the milk, little black ants partook of the
514	refreshments without being invited, and fuzzy caterpillars swung down
514	from the tree to see what was going on.  Three white-headed children

514	replied Meg, passing over the first part of his reproach, for it was
514	quite true that she had shunned him, remembering the Moffat party and
514	the talk after it.
514	""
514	Ned was offended and turned to Sallie for consolation, saying to her
514	"rather pettishly, ""There isn't a bit of flirt in that girl, is there?"""
514	""
514	"""Not a particle, but she's a dear,"" returned Sallie, defending her"
514	friend even while confessing her shortcomings.
514	""
514	"""She's not a stricken deer anyway,"" said Ned, trying to be witty, and"
514	succeeding as well as very young gentlemen usually do.
514	""
514	On the lawn where it had gathered, the little party separated with
514	cordial good nights and good-byes, for the Vaughns were going to Canada.
514	As the four sisters went home through the garden, Miss Kate looked
514	"after them, saying, without the patronizing tone in her voice, ""In"
514	spite of their demonstrative manners, American girls are very nice when
514	"one knows them."""
514	""
514	"""I quite agree with you,"" said Mr. Brooke."
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTEEN
514	""
514	CASTLES IN THE AIR
514	""
514	Laurie lay luxuriously swinging to and fro in his hammock one warm
514	September afternoon, wondering what his neighbors were about, but too
514	lazy to go and find out.  He was in one of his moods, for the day had
514	been both unprofitable and unsatisfactory, and he was wishing he could
514	live it over again.  The hot weather made him indolent, and he had
514	shirked his studies, tried Mr. Brooke's patience to the utmost,
514	displeased his grandfather by practicing half the afternoon, frightened
514	the maidservants half out of their wits by mischievously hinting that
514	one of his dogs was going mad, and, after high words with the stableman
514	about some fancied neglect of his horse, he had flung himself into his
514	hammock to fume over the stupidity of the world in general, till the
514	peace of the lovely day quieted him in spite of himself. Staring up
514	into the green gloom of the horse-chestnut trees above him, he dreamed
514	dreams of all sorts, and was just imagining himself tossing on the
514	ocean in a voyage round the world, when the sound of voices brought him
514	ashore in a flash. Peeping through the meshes of the hammock, he saw
514	the Marches coming out, as if bound on some expedition.
514	""
514	"""What in the world are those girls about now?"" thought Laurie, opening"
514	his sleepy eyes to take a good look, for there was something rather
514	peculiar in the appearance of his neighbors.  Each wore a large,
514	flapping hat, a brown linen pouch slung over one shoulder, and carried
514	a long staff.  Meg had a cushion, Jo a book, Beth a basket, and Amy a
514	portfolio.  All walked quietly through the garden, out at the little
514	back gate, and began to climb the hill that lay between the house and
514	river.
514	""
514	"""Well, that's cool,"" said Laurie to himself, ""to have a picnic and"
514	never ask me!  They can't be going in the boat, for they haven't got
514	the key.  Perhaps they forgot it.  I'll take it to them, and see what's
514	"going on."""
514	""
514	Though possessed of half a dozen hats, it took him some time to find
514	one, then there was a hunt for the key, which was at last discovered in
514	his pocket, so that the girls were quite out of sight when he leaped
514	the fence and ran after them.  Taking the shortest way to the
514	boathouse, he waited for them to appear, but no one came, and he went
514	up the hill to take an observation.  A grove of pines covered one part
514	of it, and from the heart of this green spot came a clearer sound than
514	the soft sigh of the pines or the drowsy chirp of the crickets.
514	""
514	"""Here's a landscape!"" thought Laurie, peeping through the bushes, and"
514	looking wide-awake and good-natured already.
514	""
514	It was a rather pretty little picture, for the sisters sat together in
514	the shady nook, with sun and shadow flickering over them, the aromatic
514	wind lifting their hair and cooling their hot cheeks, and all the
514	little wood people going on with their affairs as if these were no
514	strangers but old friends.  Meg sat upon her cushion, sewing daintily
514	with her white hands, and looking as fresh and sweet as a rose in her
514	pink dress among the green.  Beth was sorting the cones that lay thick
514	under the hemlock near by, for she made pretty things with them.  Amy
514	was sketching a group of ferns, and Jo was knitting as she read aloud.
514	A shadow passed over the boy's face as he watched them, feeling that he
514	ought to go away because uninvited; yet lingering because home seemed
514	very lonely and this quiet party in the woods most attractive to his
514	restless spirit.  He stood so still that a squirrel, busy with its
514	harvesting, ran down a pine close beside him, saw him suddenly and
514	skipped back, scolding so shrilly that Beth looked up, espied the
514	wistful face behind the birches, and beckoned with a reassuring smile.
514	""
514	"""May I come in, please?  Or shall I be a bother?"" he asked, advancing"
514	slowly.
514	""
514	Meg lifted her eyebrows, but Jo scowled at her defiantly and said at
514	"once, ""Of course you may.  We should have asked you before, only we"
514	"thought you wouldn't care for such a girl's game as this."""
514	""
514	"""I always like your games, but if Meg doesn't want me, I'll go away."""
514	""
514	"""I've no objection, if you do something.  It's against the rules to be"
514	"idle here,"" replied Meg gravely but graciously."
514	""
514	"""Much obliged.  I'll do anything if you'll let me stop a bit, for it's"
514	as dull as the Desert of Sahara down there.  Shall I sew, read, cone,
514	"draw, or do all at once? Bring on your bears. I'm ready.""  And Laurie"
514	sat down with a submissive expression delightful to behold.
514	""
514	"""Finish this story while I set my heel,"" said Jo, handing him the book."
514	""
514	"""Yes'm."" was the meek answer, as he began, doing his best to prove his"
514	gratitude for the favor of admission into the 'Busy Bee Society'.
514	""
514	The story was not a long one, and when it was finished, he ventured to
514	ask a few questions as a reward of merit.
514	""
514	"""Please, ma'am, could I inquire if this highly instructive and charming"
514	"institution is a new one?"""
514	""
514	"""Would you tell him?"" asked Meg of her sisters."
514	""
514	"""He'll laugh,"" said Amy warningly."
514	""
514	"""Who cares?"" said Jo."
514	""
514	"""I guess he'll like it,"" added Beth."
514	""
514	"""Of course I shall!  I give you my word I won't laugh.  Tell away, Jo,"
514	"and don't be afraid."""
514	""
514	"""The idea of being afraid of you!  Well, you see we used to play"
514	Pilgrim's Progress, and we have been going on with it in earnest, all
514	"winter and summer."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I know,"" said Laurie, nodding wisely."
514	""
514	"""Who told you?"" demanded Jo."
514	""
514	"""Spirits."""
514	""
514	"""No, I did.  I wanted to amuse him one night when you were all away,"
514	"and he was rather dismal.  He did like it, so don't scold, Jo,"" said"
514	Beth meekly.
514	""
514	"""You can't keep a secret.  Never mind, it saves trouble now."""
514	""
514	"""Go on, please,"" said Laurie, as Jo became absorbed in her work,"
514	looking a trifle displeased.
514	""
514	"""Oh, didn't she tell you about this new plan of ours?  Well, we have"
514	tried not to waste our holiday, but each has had a task and worked at
514	it with a will.  The vacation is nearly over, the stints are all done,
514	"and we are ever so glad that we didn't dawdle."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I should think so,"" and Laurie thought regretfully of his own"
514	idle days.
514	""
514	"""Mother likes to have us out-of-doors as much as possible, so we bring"
514	our work here and have nice times.  For the fun of it we bring our
514	things in these bags, wear the old hats, use poles to climb the hill,
514	and play pilgrims, as we used to do years ago.  We call this hill the
514	Delectable Mountain, for we can look far away and see the country where
514	"we hope to live some time."""
514	""
514	Jo pointed, and Laurie sat up to examine, for through an opening in the
514	wood one could look cross the wide, blue river, the meadows on the
514	other side, far over the outskirts of the great city, to the green
514	hills that rose to meet the sky.  The sun was low, and the heavens
514	glowed with the splendor of an autumn sunset.  Gold and purple clouds
514	lay on the hilltops, and rising high into the ruddy light were silvery
514	white peaks that shone like the airy spires of some Celestial City.
514	""
514	"""How beautiful that is!"" said Laurie softly, for he was quick to see"
514	and feel beauty of any kind.
514	""
514	"""It's often so, and we like to watch it, for it is never the same, but"
514	"always splendid,"" replied Amy, wishing she could paint it."
514	""
514	"""Jo talks about the country where we hope to live sometime--the real"
514	country, she means, with pigs and chickens and haymaking. It would be
514	nice, but I wish the beautiful country up there was real, and we could
514	"ever go to it,"" said Beth musingly."
514	""
514	"""There is a lovelier country even than that, where we shall go,"
514	"by-and-by, when we are good enough,"" answered Meg with her sweetest"
514	voice.
514	""
514	"""It seems so long to wait, so hard to do.  I want to fly away at once,"
514	"as those swallows fly, and go in at that splendid gate."""
514	""
514	"""You'll get there, Beth, sooner or later, no fear of that,"" said Jo."
514	"""I'm the one that will have to fight and work, and climb and wait, and"
514	"maybe never get in after all."""
514	""
514	"""You'll have me for company, if that's any comfort.  I shall have to do"
514	a deal of traveling before I come in sight of your Celestial City.  If
514	"I arrive late, you'll say a good word for me, won't you, Beth?"""
514	""
514	Something in the boy's face troubled his little friend, but she said
514	"cheerfully, with her quiet eyes on the changing clouds, ""If people"
514	really want to go, and really try all their lives, I think they will
514	get in, for I don't believe there are any locks on that door or any
514	guards at the gate.  I always imagine it is as it is in the picture,
514	where the shining ones stretch out their hands to welcome poor
514	"Christian as he comes up from the river."""
514	""
514	"""Wouldn't it be fun if all the castles in the air which we make could"
514	"come true, and we could live in them?"" said Jo, after a little pause."
514	""
514	"""I've made such quantities it would be hard to choose which I'd have,"""
514	said Laurie, lying flat and throwing cones at the squirrel who had
514	betrayed him.
514	""
514	"""You'd have to take your favorite one.  What is it?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""If I tell mine, will you tell yours?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, if the girls will too."""
514	""
514	"""We will.  Now, Laurie."""
514	""
514	"""After I'd seen as much of the world as I want to, I'd like to settle"
514	in Germany and have just as much music as I choose.  I'm to be a famous
514	musician myself, and all creation is to rush to hear me.  And I'm never
514	to be bothered about money or business, but just enjoy myself and live
514	"for what I like.  That's my favorite castle. What's yours, Meg?"""
514	""
514	Margaret seemed to find it a little hard to tell hers, and waved a
514	brake before her face, as if to disperse imaginary gnats, while she
514	"said slowly, ""I should like a lovely house, full of all sorts of"
514	luxurious things--nice food, pretty clothes, handsome furniture,
514	pleasant people, and heaps of money.  I am to be mistress of it, and
514	manage it as I like, with plenty of servants, so I never need work a
514	bit.  How I should enjoy it!  For I wouldn't be idle, but do good, and
514	"make everyone love me dearly."""
514	""
514	"""Wouldn't you have a master for your castle in the air?"" asked Laurie"
514	slyly.
514	""
514	"""I said 'pleasant people', you know,"" and Meg carefully tied up her"
514	shoe as she spoke, so that no one saw her face.
514	""
514	"""Why don't you say you'd have a splendid, wise, good husband and some"
514	angelic little children?  You know your castle wouldn't be perfect
514	"without,"" said blunt Jo, who had no tender fancies yet, and rather"
514	scorned romance, except in books.
514	""
514	"""You'd have nothing but horses, inkstands, and novels in yours,"""
514	answered Meg petulantly.
514	""
514	"""Wouldn't I though?  I'd have a stable full of Arabian steeds, rooms"
514	piled high with books, and I'd write out of a magic inkstand, so that
514	my works should be as famous as Laurie's music.  I want to do something
514	splendid before I go into my castle, something heroic or wonderful that
514	won't be forgotten after I'm dead.  I don't know what, but I'm on the
514	watch for it, and mean to astonish you all some day.  I think I shall
514	write books, and get rich and famous, that would suit me, so that is my
514	"favorite dream."""
514	""
514	"""Mine is to stay at home safe with Father and Mother, and help take"
514	"care of the family,"" said Beth contentedly."
514	""
514	"""Don't you wish for anything else?"" asked Laurie."
514	""
514	"""Since I had my little piano, I am perfectly satisfied.  I only wish we"
514	"may all keep well and be together, nothing else."""
514	""
514	"""I have ever so many wishes, but the pet one is to be an artist, and go"
514	to Rome, and do fine pictures, and be the best artist in the whole
514	"world,"" was Amy's modest desire."
514	""
514	"""We're an ambitious set, aren't we?  Every one of us, but Beth, wants"
514	to be rich and famous, and gorgeous in every respect. I do wonder if
514	"any of us will ever get our wishes,"" said Laurie, chewing grass like a"
514	meditative calf.
514	""
514	"""I've got the key to my castle in the air, but whether I can unlock the"
514	"door remains to be seen,"" observed Jo mysteriously."
514	""
514	"""I've got the key to mine, but I'm not allowed to try it. Hang"
514	"college!"" muttered Laurie with an impatient sigh."
514	""
514	"""Here's mine!"" and Amy waved her pencil."
514	""
514	"""I haven't got any,"" said Meg forlornly."
514	""
514	"""Yes, you have,"" said Laurie at once."
514	""
514	"""Where?"""
514	""
514	"""In your face."""
514	""
514	"""Nonsense, that's of no use."""
514	""
514	"""Wait and see if it doesn't bring you something worth having,"" replied"
514	the boy, laughing at the thought of a charming little secret which he
514	fancied he knew.
514	""
514	Meg colored behind the brake, but asked no questions and looked across
514	the river with the same expectant expression which Mr. Brooke had worn
514	when he told the story of the knight.
514	""
514	"""If we are all alive ten years hence, let's meet, and see how many of"
514	"us have got our wishes, or how much nearer we are then than now,"" said"
514	Jo, always ready with a plan.
514	""
514	"""Bless me!  How old I shall be, twenty-seven!"" exclaimed Meg, who felt"
514	grown up already, having just reached seventeen.
514	""
514	"""You and I will be twenty-six, Teddy, Beth twenty-four, and Amy"
514	"twenty-two.  What a venerable party!"" said Jo."
514	""
514	"""I hope I shall have done something to be proud of by that time, but"
514	"I'm such a lazy dog, I'm afraid I shall dawdle, Jo."""
514	""
514	"""You need a motive, Mother says, and when you get it, she is sure"
514	"you'll work splendidly."""
514	""
514	"""Is she?  By Jupiter, I will, if I only get the chance!"" cried Laurie,"
514	"sitting up with sudden energy.  ""I ought to be satisfied to please"
514	Grandfather, and I do try, but it's working against the grain, you see,
514	and comes hard.  He wants me to be an India merchant, as he was, and
514	I'd rather be shot.  I hate tea and silk and spices, and every sort of
514	rubbish his old ships bring, and I don't care how soon they go to the
514	bottom when I own them.  Going to college ought to satisfy him, for if
514	I give him four years he ought to let me off from the business.  But
514	he's set, and I've got to do just as he did, unless I break away and
514	please myself, as my father did.  If there was anyone left to stay with
514	"the old gentleman, I'd do it tomorrow."""
514	""
514	Laurie spoke excitedly, and looked ready to carry his threat into
514	execution on the slightest provocation, for he was growing up very fast
514	and, in spite of his indolent ways, had a young man's hatred of
514	subjection, a young man's restless longing to try the world for himself.
514	""
514	"""I advise you to sail away in one of your ships, and never come home"
514	"again till you have tried your own way,"" said Jo, whose imagination was"
514	fired by the thought of such a daring exploit, and whose sympathy was
514	excited by what she called 'Teddy's Wrongs'.
514	""
514	"""That's not right, Jo.  You mustn't talk in that way, and Laurie"
514	mustn't take your bad advice.  You should do just what your grandfather
514	"wishes, my dear boy,"" said Meg in her most maternal tone. ""Do your best"
514	at college, and when he sees that you try to please him, I'm sure he
514	won't be hard on you or unjust to you.  As you say, there is no one
514	else to stay with and love him, and you'd never forgive yourself if you
514	left him without his permission.  Don't be dismal or fret, but do your
514	duty and you'll get your reward, as good Mr. Brooke has, by being
514	"respected and loved."""
514	""
514	"""What do you know about him?"" asked Laurie, grateful for the good"
514	advice, but objecting to the lecture, and glad to turn the conversation
514	from himself after his unusual outbreak.
514	""
514	"""Only what your grandpa told us about him, how he took good care of his"
514	own mother till she died, and wouldn't go abroad as tutor to some nice
514	person because he wouldn't leave her.  And how he provides now for an
514	old woman who nursed his mother, and never tells anyone, but is just as
514	"generous and patient and good as he can be."""
514	""
514	"""So he is, dear old fellow!"" said Laurie heartily, as Meg paused,"
514	"looking flushed and earnest with her story.  ""It's like Grandpa to find"
514	out all about him without letting him know, and to tell all his
514	goodness to others, so that they might like him. Brooke couldn't
514	understand why your mother was so kind to him, asking him over with me
514	and treating him in her beautiful friendly way.  He thought she was
514	just perfect, and talked about it for days and days, and went on about
514	you all in flaming style.  If ever I do get my wish, you see what I'll
514	"do for Brooke."""
514	""
514	"""Begin to do something now by not plaguing his life out,"" said Meg"
514	sharply.
514	""
514	"""How do you know I do, Miss?"""
514	""
514	"""I can always tell by his face when he goes away.  If you have been"
514	good, he looks satisfied and walks briskly.  If you have plagued him,
514	he's sober and walks slowly, as if he wanted to go back and do his work
514	"better."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I like that?  So you keep an account of my good and bad marks in"
514	Brooke's face, do you?  I see him bow and smile as he passes your
514	"window, but I didn't know you'd got up a telegraph."""
514	""
514	"""We haven't.  Don't be angry, and oh, don't tell him I said anything!"
514	It was only to show that I cared how you get on, and what is said here
514	"is said in confidence, you know,"" cried Meg, much alarmed at the"
514	thought of what might follow from her careless speech.
514	""
514	"""I don't tell tales,"" replied Laurie, with his 'high and mighty' air,"
514	"as Jo called a certain expression which he occasionally wore. ""Only if"
514	Brooke is going to be a thermometer, I must mind and have fair weather
514	"for him to report."""
514	""
514	"""Please don't be offended.  I didn't mean to preach or tell tales or be"
514	silly.  I only thought Jo was encouraging you in a feeling which you'd
514	be sorry for by-and-by.  You are so kind to us, we feel as if you were
514	"our brother and say just what we think. Forgive me, I meant it kindly."""
514	And Meg offered her hand with a gesture both affectionate and timid.
514	""
514	Ashamed of his momentary pique, Laurie squeezed the kind little hand,
514	"and said frankly, ""I'm the one to be forgiven.  I'm cross and have been"
514	out of sorts all day.  I like to have you tell me my faults and be
514	sisterly, so don't mind if I am grumpy sometimes.  I thank you all the
514	"same."""
514	""
514	Bent on showing that he was not offended, he made himself as agreeable
514	as possible, wound cotton for Meg, recited poetry to please Jo, shook
514	down cones for Beth, and helped Amy with her ferns, proving himself a
514	fit person to belong to the 'Busy Bee Society'.  In the midst of an
514	animated discussion on the domestic habits of turtles (one of those
514	amiable creatures having strolled up from the river), the faint sound
514	of a bell warned them that Hannah had put the tea 'to draw', and they
514	would just have time to get home to supper.
514	""
514	"""May I come again?"" asked Laurie."
514	""
514	"""Yes, if you are good, and love your book, as the boys in the primer"
514	"are told to do,"" said Meg, smiling."
514	""
514	"""I'll try."""
514	""
514	"""Then you may come, and I'll teach you to knit as the Scotchmen do."
514	"There's a demand for socks just now,"" added Jo, waving hers like a big"
514	blue worsted banner as they parted at the gate.
514	""
514	That night, when Beth played to Mr. Laurence in the twilight, Laurie,
514	standing in the shadow of the curtain, listened to the little David,
514	whose simple music always quieted his moody spirit, and watched the old
514	man, who sat with his gray head on his hand, thinking tender thoughts
514	of the dead child he had loved so much. Remembering the conversation of
514	the afternoon, the boy said to himself, with the resolve to make the
514	"sacrifice cheerfully, ""I'll let my castle go, and stay with the dear"
514	"old gentleman while he needs me, for I am all he has."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FOURTEEN
514	""
514	SECRETS
514	""
514	Jo was very busy in the garret, for the October days began to grow
514	chilly, and the afternoons were short.  For two or three hours the sun
514	lay warmly in the high window, showing Jo seated on the old sofa,
514	writing busily, with her papers spread out upon a trunk before her,
514	while Scrabble, the pet rat, promenaded the beams overhead, accompanied
514	by his oldest son, a fine young fellow, who was evidently very proud of
514	his whiskers. Quite absorbed in her work, Jo scribbled away till the
514	last page was filled, when she signed her name with a flourish and
514	threw down her pen, exclaiming...
514	""
514	"""There, I've done my best!  If this won't suit I shall have to wait"
514	"till I can do better."""
514	""
514	Lying back on the sofa, she read the manuscript carefully through,
514	making dashes here and there, and putting in many exclamation points,
514	which looked like little balloons.  Then she tied it up with a smart
514	red ribbon, and sat a minute looking at it with a sober, wistful
514	expression, which plainly showed how earnest her work had been.  Jo's
514	desk up here was an old tin kitchen which hung against the wall.  In it
514	she kept her papers, and a few books, safely shut away from Scrabble,
514	who, being likewise of a literary turn, was fond of making a
514	circulating library of such books as were left in his way by eating the
514	leaves.  From this tin receptacle Jo produced another manuscript, and
514	putting both in her pocket, crept quietly downstairs, leaving her
514	friends to nibble on her pens and taste her ink.
514	""
514	She put on her hat and jacket as noiselessly as possible, and going to
514	the back entry window, got out upon the roof of a low porch, swung
514	herself down to the grassy bank, and took a roundabout way to the road.
514	Once there, she composed herself, hailed a passing omnibus, and rolled
514	away to town, looking very merry and mysterious.
514	""
514	If anyone had been watching her, he would have thought her movements
514	decidedly peculiar, for on alighting, she went off at a great pace till
514	she reached a certain number in a certain busy street.  Having found
514	the place with some difficulty, she went into the doorway, looked up
514	the dirty stairs, and after standing stock still a minute, suddenly
514	dived into the street and walked away as rapidly as she came.  This
514	maneuver she repeated several times, to the great amusement of a
514	black-eyed young gentleman lounging in the window of a building
514	opposite.  On returning for the third time, Jo gave herself a shake,
514	pulled her hat over her eyes, and walked up the stairs, looking as if
514	she were going to have all her teeth out.
514	""
514	There was a dentist's sign, among others, which adorned the entrance,
514	and after staring a moment at the pair of artificial jaws which slowly
514	opened and shut to draw attention to a fine set of teeth, the young
514	gentleman put on his coat, took his hat, and went down to post himself
514	"in the opposite doorway, saying with a smile and a shiver, ""It's like"
514	her to come alone, but if she has a bad time she'll need someone to
514	"help her home."""
514	""
514	In ten minutes Jo came running downstairs with a very red face and the
514	general appearance of a person who had just passed through a trying
514	ordeal of some sort.  When she saw the young gentleman she looked
514	anything but pleased, and passed him with a nod.  But he followed,
514	"asking with an air of sympathy, ""Did you have a bad time?"""
514	""
514	"""Not very."""
514	""
514	"""You got through quickly."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, thank goodness!"""
514	""
514	"""Why did you go alone?"""
514	""
514	"""Didn't want anyone to know."""
514	""
514	"""You're the oddest fellow I ever saw.  How many did you have out?"""
514	""
514	Jo looked at her friend as if she did not understand him, then began to
514	laugh as if mightily amused at something.
514	""
514	"""There are two which I want to have come out, but I must wait a week."""
514	""
514	"""What are you laughing at?  You are up to some mischief, Jo,"" said"
514	Laurie, looking mystified.
514	""
514	"""So are you.  What were you doing, sir, up in that billiard saloon?"""
514	""
514	"""Begging your pardon, ma'am, it wasn't a billiard saloon, but a"
514	"gymnasium, and I was taking a lesson in fencing."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of that."""
514	""
514	"""Why?"""
514	""
514	"""You can teach me, and then when we play _Hamlet_, you can be Laertes,"
514	"and we'll make a fine thing of the fencing scene."""
514	""
514	Laurie burst out with a hearty boy's laugh, which made several
514	passers-by smile in spite of themselves.
514	""
514	"""I'll teach you whether we play _Hamlet_ or not.  It's grand fun and"
514	will straighten you up capitally.  But I don't believe that was your
514	"only reason for saying 'I'm glad' in that decided way, was it now?"""
514	""
514	"""No, I was glad that you were not in the saloon, because I hope you"
514	"never go to such places.  Do you?"""
514	""
514	"""Not often."""
514	""
514	"""I wish you wouldn't."""
514	""
514	"""It's no harm, Jo.  I have billiards at home, but it's no fun unless"
514	you have good players, so, as I'm fond of it, I come sometimes and have
514	"a game with Ned Moffat or some of the other fellows."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear, I'm so sorry, for you'll get to liking it better and better,"
514	and will waste time and money, and grow like those dreadful boys.  I
514	"did hope you'd stay respectable and be a satisfaction to your friends,"""
514	said Jo, shaking her head.
514	""
514	"""Can't a fellow take a little innocent amusement now and then without"
514	"losing his respectability?"" asked Laurie, looking nettled."
514	""
514	"""That depends upon how and where he takes it.  I don't like Ned and his"
514	set, and wish you'd keep out of it.  Mother won't let us have him at
514	our house, though he wants to come.  And if you grow like him she won't
514	"be willing to have us frolic together as we do now."""
514	""
514	"""Won't she?"" asked Laurie anxiously."
514	""
514	"""No, she can't bear fashionable young men, and she'd shut us all up in"
514	"bandboxes rather than have us associate with them."""
514	""
514	"""Well, she needn't get out her bandboxes yet.  I'm not a fashionable"
514	party and don't mean to be, but I do like harmless larks now and then,
514	"don't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, nobody minds them, so lark away, but don't get wild, will you?"
514	"Or there will be an end of all our good times."""
514	""
514	"""I'll be a double distilled saint."""
514	""
514	"""I can't bear saints.  Just be a simple, honest, respectable boy, and"
514	we'll never desert you.  I don't know what I should do if you acted
514	like Mr. King's son.  He had plenty of money, but didn't know how to
514	spend it, and got tipsy and gambled, and ran away, and forged his
514	"father's name, I believe, and was altogether horrid."""
514	""
514	"""You think I'm likely to do the same?  Much obliged."""
514	""
514	"""No, I don't--oh, dear, no!--but I hear people talking about money"
514	being such a temptation, and I sometimes wish you were poor. I
514	"shouldn't worry then."""
514	""
