514	"""Do you worry about me, Jo?"""
514	""
514	"""A little, when you look moody and discontented, as you sometimes do,"
514	for you've got such a strong will, if you once get started wrong, I'm
514	"afraid it would be hard to stop you."""
514	""
514	Laurie walked in silence a few minutes, and Jo watched him, wishing she
514	had held her tongue, for his eyes looked angry, though his lips smiled
514	as if at her warnings.
514	""
514	"""Are you going to deliver lectures all the way home?"" he asked"
514	presently.
514	""
514	"""Of course not.  Why?"""
514	""
514	"""Because if you are, I'll take a bus.  If you're not, I'd like to walk"
514	"with you and tell you something very interesting."""
514	""
514	"""I won't preach any more, and I'd like to hear the news immensely."""
514	""
514	"""Very well, then, come on.  It's a secret, and if I tell you, you must"
514	"tell me yours."""
514	""
514	"""I haven't got any,"" began Jo, but stopped suddenly, remembering that"
514	she had.
514	""
514	"""You know you have--you can't hide anything, so up and 'fess, or I"
514	"won't tell,"" cried Laurie."
514	""
514	"""Is your secret a nice one?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, isn't it!  All about people you know, and such fun!  You ought to"
514	hear it, and I've been aching to tell it this long time. Come, you
514	"begin."""
514	""
514	"""You'll not say anything about it at home, will you?"""
514	""
514	"""Not a word."""
514	""
514	"""And you won't tease me in private?"""
514	""
514	"""I never tease."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, you do.  You get everything you want out of people.  I don't know"
514	"how you do it, but you are a born wheedler."""
514	""
514	"""Thank you.  Fire away."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I've left two stories with a newspaperman, and he's to give his"
514	"answer next week,"" whispered Jo, in her confidant's ear."
514	""
514	"""Hurrah for Miss March, the celebrated American authoress!"" cried"
514	Laurie, throwing up his hat and catching it again, to the great delight
514	of two ducks, four cats, five hens, and half a dozen Irish children,
514	for they were out of the city now.
514	""
514	"""Hush!  It won't come to anything, I dare say, but I couldn't rest till"
514	I had tried, and I said nothing about it because I didn't want anyone
514	"else to be disappointed."""
514	""
514	"""It won't fail.  Why, Jo, your stories are works of Shakespeare"
514	compared to half the rubbish that is published every day. Won't it be
514	"fun to see them in print, and shan't we feel proud of our authoress?"""
514	""
514	Jo's eyes sparkled, for it is always pleasant to be believed in, and a
514	friend's praise is always sweeter than a dozen newspaper puffs.
514	""
514	"""Where's your secret?  Play fair, Teddy, or I'll never believe you"
514	"again,"" she said, trying to extinguish the brilliant hopes that blazed"
514	up at a word of encouragement.
514	""
514	"""I may get into a scrape for telling, but I didn't promise not to, so I"
514	will, for I never feel easy in my mind till I've told you any plummy
514	"bit of news I get.  I know where Meg's glove is."""
514	""
514	"""Is that all?"" said Jo, looking disappointed, as Laurie nodded and"
514	twinkled with a face full of mysterious intelligence.
514	""
514	"""It's quite enough for the present, as you'll agree when I tell you"
514	"where it is."""
514	""
514	"""Tell, then."""
514	""
514	Laurie bent, and whispered three words in Jo's ear, which produced a
514	comical change.  She stood and stared at him for a minute, looking both
514	"surprised and displeased, then walked on, saying sharply, ""How do you"
514	"know?"""
514	""
514	"""Saw it."""
514	""
514	"""Where?"""
514	""
514	"""Pocket."""
514	""
514	"""All this time?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, isn't that romantic?"""
514	""
514	"""No, it's horrid."""
514	""
514	"""Don't you like it?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course I don't.  It's ridiculous, it won't be allowed.  My"
514	"patience!  What would Meg say?"""
514	""
514	"""You are not to tell anyone.  Mind that."""
514	""
514	"""I didn't promise."""
514	""
514	"""That was understood, and I trusted you."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I won't for the present, anyway, but I'm disgusted, and wish you"
514	"hadn't told me."""
514	""
514	"""I thought you'd be pleased."""
514	""
514	"""At the idea of anybody coming to take Meg away? No, thank you."""
514	""
514	"""You'll feel better about it when somebody comes to take you away."""
514	""
514	"""I'd like to see anyone try it,"" cried Jo fiercely."
514	""
514	"""So should I!"" and Laurie chuckled at the idea."
514	""
514	"""I don't think secrets agree with me, I feel rumpled up in my mind"
514	"since you told me that,"" said Jo rather ungratefully."
514	""
514	"""Race down this hill with me, and you'll be all right,"" suggested"
514	Laurie.
514	""
514	No one was in sight, the smooth road sloped invitingly before her, and
514	finding the temptation irresistible, Jo darted away, soon leaving hat
514	and comb behind her and scattering hairpins as she ran. Laurie reached
514	the goal first and was quite satisfied with the success of his
514	treatment, for his Atlanta came panting up with flying hair, bright
514	eyes, ruddy cheeks, and no signs of dissatisfaction in her face.
514	""
514	"""I wish I was a horse, then I could run for miles in this splendid air,"
514	and not lose my breath.  It was capital, but see what a guy it's made
514	"me.  Go, pick up my things, like a cherub, as you are,"" said Jo,"
514	dropping down under a maple tree, which was carpeting the bank with
514	crimson leaves.
514	""
514	Laurie leisurely departed to recover the lost property, and Jo bundled
514	up her braids, hoping no one would pass by till she was tidy again.
514	But someone did pass, and who should it be but Meg, looking
514	particularly ladylike in her state and festival suit, for she had been
514	making calls.
514	""
514	"""What in the world are you doing here?"" she asked, regarding her"
514	disheveled sister with well-bred surprise.
514	""
514	"""Getting leaves,"" meekly answered Jo, sorting the rosy handful she had"
514	just swept up.
514	""
514	"""And hairpins,"" added Laurie, throwing half a dozen into Jo's lap."
514	"""They grow on this road, Meg, so do combs and brown straw hats."""
514	""
514	"""You have been running, Jo.  How could you?  When will you stop such"
514	"romping ways?"" said Meg reprovingly, as she settled her cuffs and"
514	smoothed her hair, with which the wind had taken liberties.
514	""
514	"""Never till I'm stiff and old and have to use a crutch.  Don't try to"
514	make me grow up before my time, Meg.  It's hard enough to have you
514	"change all of a sudden.  Let me be a little girl as long as I can."""
514	""
514	As she spoke, Jo bent over the leaves to hide the trembling of her
514	lips, for lately she had felt that Margaret was fast getting to be a
514	woman, and Laurie's secret made her dread the separation which must
514	surely come some time and now seemed very near.  He saw the trouble in
514	"her face and drew Meg's attention from it by asking quickly, ""Where"
514	"have you been calling, all so fine?"""
514	""
514	"""At the Gardiners', and Sallie has been telling me all about Belle"
514	Moffat's wedding.  It was very splendid, and they have gone to spend
514	"the winter in Paris.  Just think how delightful that must be!"""
514	""
514	"""Do you envy her, Meg?"" said Laurie."
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid I do."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of it!"" muttered Jo, tying on her hat with a jerk."
514	""
514	"""Why?"" asked Meg, looking surprised."
514	""
514	"""Because if you care much about riches, you will never go and marry a"
514	"poor man,"" said Jo, frowning at Laurie, who was mutely warning her to"
514	mind what she said.
514	""
514	"""I shall never '_go_ and marry' anyone,"" observed Meg, walking on with"
514	great dignity while the others followed, laughing, whispering, skipping
514	stones, and 'behaving like children', as Meg said to herself, though
514	she might have been tempted to join them if she had not had her best
514	dress on.
514	""
514	For a week or two, Jo behaved so queerly that her sisters were quite
514	bewildered.  She rushed to the door when the postman rang, was rude to
514	Mr. Brooke whenever they met, would sit looking at Meg with a
514	woe-begone face, occasionally jumping up to shake and then kiss her in
514	a very mysterious manner.  Laurie and she were always making signs to
514	one another, and talking about 'Spread Eagles' till the girls declared
514	they had both lost their wits.  On the second Saturday after Jo got out
514	of the window, Meg, as she sat sewing at her window, was scandalized by
514	the sight of Laurie chasing Jo all over the garden and finally
514	capturing her in Amy's bower.  What went on there, Meg could not see,
514	but shrieks of laughter were heard, followed by the murmur of voices
514	and a great flapping of newspapers.
514	""
514	"""What shall we do with that girl?  She never _will_ behave like a young"
514	"lady,"" sighed Meg, as she watched the race with a disapproving face."
514	""
514	"""I hope she won't.  She is so funny and dear as she is,"" said Beth, who"
514	had never betrayed that she was a little hurt at Jo's having secrets
514	with anyone but her.
514	""
514	"""It's very trying, but we never can make her _commy la fo_,"" added Amy,"
514	who sat making some new frills for herself, with her curls tied up in a
514	very becoming way, two agreeable things that made her feel unusually
514	elegant and ladylike.
514	""
514	In a few minutes Jo bounced in, laid herself on the sofa, and affected
514	to read.
514	""
514	"""Have you anything interesting there?"" asked Meg, with condescension."
514	""
514	"""Nothing but a story, won't amount to much, I guess,"" returned Jo,"
514	carefully keeping the name of the paper out of sight.
514	""
514	"""You'd better read it aloud.  That will amuse us and keep you out of"
514	"mischief,"" said Amy in her most grown-up tone."
514	""
514	"""What's the name?"" asked Beth, wondering why Jo kept her face behind"
514	the sheet.
514	""
514	"""The Rival Painters."""
514	""
514	"""That sounds well.  Read it,"" said Meg."
514	""
514	"With a loud ""Hem!"" and a long breath, Jo began to read very fast.  The"
514	girls listened with interest, for the tale was romantic, and somewhat
514	"pathetic, as most of the characters died in the end. ""I like that about"
514	"the splendid picture,"" was Amy's approving remark, as Jo paused."
514	""
514	"""I prefer the lovering part.  Viola and Angelo are two of our favorite"
514	"names, isn't that queer?"" said Meg, wiping her eyes, for the lovering"
514	part was tragical.
514	""
514	"""Who wrote it?"" asked Beth, who had caught a glimpse of Jo's face."
514	""
514	The reader suddenly sat up, cast away the paper, displaying a flushed
514	countenance, and with a funny mixture of solemnity and excitement
514	"replied in a loud voice, ""Your sister."""
514	""
514	"""You?"" cried Meg, dropping her work."
514	""
514	"""It's very good,"" said Amy critically."
514	""
514	"""I knew it!  I knew it! Oh, my Jo, I am so proud!""  and Beth ran to hug"
514	her sister and exult over this splendid success.
514	""
514	Dear me, how delighted they all were, to be sure!  How Meg wouldn't
514	"believe it till she saw the words.  ""Miss Josephine March,"" actually"
514	printed in the paper.  How graciously Amy criticized the artistic parts
514	of the story, and offered hints for a sequel, which unfortunately
514	couldn't be carried out, as the hero and heroine were dead.  How Beth
514	got excited, and skipped and sang with joy.  How Hannah came in to
514	"exclaim, ""Sakes alive, well I never!"" in great astonishment at 'that"
514	Jo's doin's'.  How proud Mrs. March was when she knew it.  How Jo
514	laughed, with tears in her eyes, as she declared she might as well be a
514	peacock and done with it, and how the 'Spread Eagle' might be said to
514	flap his wings triumphantly over the House of March, as the paper
514	passed from hand to hand.
514	""
514	"""Tell us about it.""  ""When did it come?"" ""How much did you get for it?"""
514	"""What will Father say?"" ""Won't Laurie laugh?"" cried the family, all in"
514	one breath as they clustered about Jo, for these foolish, affectionate
514	people made a jubilee of every little household joy.
514	""
514	"""Stop jabbering, girls, and I'll tell you everything,"" said Jo,"
514	wondering if Miss Burney felt any grander over her Evelina than she did
514	over her 'Rival Painters'.  Having told how she disposed of her tales,
514	"Jo added, ""And when I went to get my answer, the man said he liked them"
514	both, but didn't pay beginners, only let them print in his paper, and
514	noticed the stories.  It was good practice, he said, and when the
514	beginners improved, anyone would pay.  So I let him have the two
514	stories, and today this was sent to me, and Laurie caught me with it
514	and insisted on seeing it, so I let him.  And he said it was good, and
514	I shall write more, and he's going to get the next paid for, and I am
514	so happy, for in time I may be able to support myself and help the
514	"girls."""
514	""
514	Jo's breath gave out here, and wrapping her head in the paper, she
514	bedewed her little story with a few natural tears, for to be
514	independent and earn the praise of those she loved were the dearest
514	wishes of her heart, and this seemed to be the first step toward that
514	happy end.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FIFTEEN
514	""
514	A TELEGRAM
514	""
514	"""November is the most disagreeable month in the whole year,"" said"
514	Margaret, standing at the window one dull afternoon, looking out at the
514	frostbitten garden.
514	""
514	"""That's the reason I was born in it,"" observed Jo pensively, quite"
514	unconscious of the blot on her nose.
514	""
514	"""If something very pleasant should happen now, we should think it a"
514	"delightful month,"" said Beth, who took a hopeful view of everything,"
514	even November.
514	""
514	"""I dare say, but nothing pleasant ever does happen in this family,"""
514	"said Meg, who was out of sorts.  ""We go grubbing along day after day,"
514	without a bit of change, and very little fun.  We might as well be in a
514	"treadmill."""
514	""
514	"""My patience, how blue we are!"" cried Jo.  ""I don't much wonder, poor"
514	dear, for you see other girls having splendid times, while you grind,
514	grind, year in and year out.  Oh, don't I wish I could manage things
514	for you as I do for my heroines!  You're pretty enough and good enough
514	already, so I'd have some rich relation leave you a fortune
514	unexpectedly.  Then you'd dash out as an heiress, scorn everyone who
514	has slighted you, go abroad, and come home my Lady Something in a blaze
514	"of splendor and elegance."""
514	""
514	"""People don't have fortunes left them in that style nowadays, men have"
514	"to work and women marry for money.  It's a dreadfully unjust world,"""
514	said Meg bitterly.
514	""
514	"""Jo and I are going to make fortunes for you all.  Just wait ten years,"
514	"and see if we don't,"" said Amy, who sat in a corner making mud pies, as"
514	Hannah called her little clay models of birds, fruit, and faces.
514	""
514	"""Can't wait, and I'm afraid I haven't much faith in ink and dirt,"
514	"though I'm grateful for your good intentions."""
514	""
514	Meg sighed, and turned to the frostbitten garden again.  Jo groaned and
514	leaned both elbows on the table in a despondent attitude, but Amy
514	spatted away energetically, and Beth, who sat at the other window,
514	"said, smiling, ""Two pleasant things are going to happen right away."
514	Marmee is coming down the street, and Laurie is tramping through the
514	"garden as if he had something nice to tell."""
514	""
514	"In they both came, Mrs. March with her usual question, ""Any letter from"
514	"Father, girls?"" and Laurie to say in his persuasive way, ""Won't some of"
514	you come for a drive?  I've been working away at mathematics till my
514	head is in a muddle, and I'm going to freshen my wits by a brisk turn.
514	It's a dull day, but the air isn't bad, and I'm going to take Brooke
514	home, so it will be gay inside, if it isn't out.  Come, Jo, you and
514	"Beth will go, won't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course we will."""
514	""
514	"""Much obliged, but I'm busy.""  And Meg whisked out her workbasket, for"
514	she had agreed with her mother that it was best, for her at least, not
514	to drive too often with the young gentleman.
514	""
514	"""We three will be ready in a minute,"" cried Amy, running away to wash"
514	her hands.
514	""
514	"""Can I do anything for you, Madam Mother?"" asked Laurie, leaning over"
514	Mrs. March's chair with the affectionate look and tone he always gave
514	her.
514	""
514	"""No, thank you, except call at the office, if you'll be so kind, dear."
514	It's our day for a letter, and the postman hasn't been.  Father is as
514	"regular as the sun, but there's some delay on the way, perhaps."""
514	""
514	A sharp ring interrupted her, and a minute after Hannah came in with a
514	letter.
514	""
514	"""It's one of them horrid telegraph things, mum,"" she said, handling it"
514	as if she was afraid it would explode and do some damage.
514	""
514	At the word 'telegraph', Mrs. March snatched it, read the two lines it
514	contained, and dropped back into her chair as white as if the little
514	paper had sent a bullet to her heart.  Laurie dashed downstairs for
514	water, while Meg and Hannah supported her, and Jo read aloud, in a
514	frightened voice...
514	""
514	    Mrs. March:
514	    Your husband is very ill.  Come at once.
514	    S.  HALE
514	    Blank Hospital, Washington.
514	""
514	How still the room was as they listened breathlessly, how strangely the
514	day darkened outside, and how suddenly the whole world seemed to
514	change, as the girls gathered about their mother, feeling as if all the
514	happiness and support of their lives was about to be taken from them.
514	""
514	Mrs. March was herself again directly, read the message over, and
514	stretched out her arms to her daughters, saying, in a tone they never
514	"forgot, ""I shall go at once, but it may be too late.  Oh, children,"
514	"children, help me to bear it!"""
514	""
514	For several minutes there was nothing but the sound of sobbing in the
514	room, mingled with broken words of comfort, tender assurances of help,
514	and hopeful whispers that died away in tears.  Poor Hannah was the
514	first to recover, and with unconscious wisdom she set all the rest a
514	good example, for with her, work was panacea for most afflictions.
514	""
514	"""The Lord keep the dear man!  I won't waste no time a-cryin', but git"
514	"your things ready right away, mum,"" she said heartily, as she wiped her"
514	face on her apron, gave her mistress a warm shake of the hand with her
514	own hard one, and went away to work like three women in one.
514	""
514	"""She's right, there's no time for tears now.  Be calm, girls, and let"
514	"me think."""
514	""
514	They tried to be calm, poor things, as their mother sat up, looking
514	pale but steady, and put away her grief to think and plan for them.
514	""
514	"""Where's Laurie?"" she asked presently, when she had collected her"
514	thoughts and decided on the first duties to be done.
514	""
514	"""Here, ma'am.  Oh, let me do something!"" cried the boy, hurrying from"
514	the next room whither he had withdrawn, feeling that their first sorrow
514	was too sacred for even his friendly eyes to see.
514	""
514	"""Send a telegram saying I will come at once.  The next train goes early"
514	"in the morning.  I'll take that."""
514	""
514	"""What else?  The horses are ready.  I can go anywhere, do anything,"" he"
514	said, looking ready to fly to the ends of the earth.
514	""
514	"""Leave a note at Aunt March's.  Jo, give me that pen and paper."""
514	""
514	Tearing off the blank side of one of her newly copied pages, Jo drew
514	the table before her mother, well knowing that money for the long, sad
514	journey must be borrowed, and feeling as if she could do anything to
514	add a little to the sum for her father.
514	""
514	"""Now go, dear, but don't kill yourself driving at a desperate pace."
514	"There is no need of that."""
514	""
514	Mrs. March's warning was evidently thrown away, for five minutes later
514	Laurie tore by the window on his own fleet horse, riding as if for his
514	life.
514	""
514	"""Jo, run to the rooms, and tell Mrs. King that I can't come. On the way"
514	get these things.  I'll put them down, they'll be needed and I must go
514	prepared for nursing.  Hospital stores are not always good.  Beth, go
514	and ask Mr. Laurence for a couple of bottles of old wine.  I'm not too
514	proud to beg for Father.  He shall have the best of everything.  Amy,
514	tell Hannah to get down the black trunk, and Meg, come and help me find
514	"my things, for I'm half bewildered."""
514	""
514	Writing, thinking, and directing all at once might well bewilder the
514	poor lady, and Meg begged her to sit quietly in her room for a little
514	while, and let them work.  Everyone scattered like leaves before a gust
514	of wind, and the quiet, happy household was broken up as suddenly as if
514	the paper had been an evil spell.
514	""
514	Mr. Laurence came hurrying back with Beth, bringing every comfort the
514	kind old gentleman could think of for the invalid, and friendliest
514	promises of protection for the girls during the mother's absence, which
514	comforted her very much.  There was nothing he didn't offer, from his
514	own dressing gown to himself as escort.  But the last was impossible.
514	Mrs. March would not hear of the old gentleman's undertaking the long
514	journey, yet an expression of relief was visible when he spoke of it,
514	for anxiety ill fits one for traveling. He saw the look, knit his heavy
514	eyebrows, rubbed his hands, and marched abruptly away, saying he'd be
514	back directly.  No one had time to think of him again till, as Meg ran
514	through the entry, with a pair of rubbers in one hand and a cup of tea
514	in the other, she came suddenly upon Mr. Brooke.
514	""
514	"""I'm very sorry to hear of this, Miss March,"" he said, in the kind,"
514	"quiet tone which sounded very pleasantly to her perturbed spirit.  ""I"
514	came to offer myself as escort to your mother.  Mr. Laurence has
514	commissions for me in Washington, and it will give me real satisfaction
514	"to be of service to her there."""
514	""
514	Down dropped the rubbers, and the tea was very near following, as Meg
514	put out her hand, with a face so full of gratitude that Mr. Brooke
514	would have felt repaid for a much greater sacrifice than the trifling
514	one of time and comfort which he was about to take.
514	""
514	"""How kind you all are!  Mother will accept, I'm sure, and it will be"
514	such a relief to know that she has someone to take care of her.  Thank
514	"you very, very much!"""
514	""
514	Meg spoke earnestly, and forgot herself entirely till something in the
514	brown eyes looking down at her made her remember the cooling tea, and
514	lead the way into the parlor, saying she would call her mother.
514	""
514	Everything was arranged by the time Laurie returned with a note from
514	Aunt March, enclosing the desired sum, and a few lines repeating what
514	she had often said before, that she had always told them it was absurd
514	for March to go into the army, always predicted that no good would come
514	of it, and she hoped they would take her advice the next time.  Mrs.
514	March put the note in the fire, the money in her purse, and went on
514	with her preparations, with her lips folded tightly in a way which Jo
514	would have understood if she had been there.
514	""
514	The short afternoon wore away.  All other errands were done, and Meg
514	and her mother busy at some necessary needlework, while Beth and Amy
514	got tea, and Hannah finished her ironing with what she called a 'slap
514	and a bang', but still Jo did not come.  They began to get anxious, and
514	Laurie went off to find her, for no one knew what freak Jo might take
514	into her head.  He missed her, however, and she came walking in with a
514	very queer expression of countenance, for there was a mixture of fun
514	and fear, satisfaction and regret in it, which puzzled the family as
514	much as did the roll of bills she laid before her mother, saying with a
514	"little choke in her voice, ""That's my contribution toward making Father"
514	"comfortable and bringing him home!"""
514	""
514	"""My dear, where did you get it?  Twenty-five dollars!  Jo, I hope you"
514	"haven't done anything rash?"""
514	""
514	"""No, it's mine honestly.  I didn't beg, borrow, or steal it.  I earned"
514	"it, and I don't think you'll blame me, for I only sold what was my own."""
514	""
514	As she spoke, Jo took off her bonnet, and a general outcry arose, for
514	all her abundant hair was cut short.
514	""
514	"""Your hair!  Your beautiful hair!""  ""Oh, Jo, how could you? Your one"
514	"beauty.""  ""My dear girl, there was no need of this.""  ""She doesn't look"
514	"like my Jo any more, but I love her dearly for it!"""
514	""
514	As everyone exclaimed, and Beth hugged the cropped head tenderly, Jo
514	assumed an indifferent air, which did not deceive anyone a particle,
514	and said, rumpling up the brown bush and trying to look as if she liked
514	"it, ""It doesn't affect the fate of the nation, so don't wail, Beth.  It"
514	will be good for my vanity, I was getting too proud of my wig.  It will
514	do my brains good to have that mop taken off.  My head feels
514	deliciously light and cool, and the barber said I could soon have a
514	curly crop, which will be boyish, becoming, and easy to keep in order.
514	"I'm satisfied, so please take the money and let's have supper."""
514	""
514	"""Tell me all about it, Jo.  I am not quite satisfied, but I can't blame"
514	you, for I know how willingly you sacrificed your vanity, as you call
514	it, to your love.  But, my dear, it was not necessary, and I'm afraid
514	"you will regret it one of these days,"" said Mrs. March."
514	""
514	"""No, I won't!"" returned Jo stoutly, feeling much relieved that her"
514	prank was not entirely condemned.
514	""
514	"""What made you do it?"" asked Amy, who would as soon have thought of"
514	cutting off her head as her pretty hair.
514	""
514	"""Well, I was wild to do something for Father,"" replied Jo, as they"
514	gathered about the table, for healthy young people can eat even in the
514	"midst of trouble.  ""I hate to borrow as much as Mother does, and I knew"
514	Aunt March would croak, she always does, if you ask for a ninepence.
514	Meg gave all her quarterly salary toward the rent, and I only got some
514	clothes with mine, so I felt wicked, and was bound to have some money,
514	"if I sold the nose off my face to get it."""
514	""
514	"""You needn't feel wicked, my child! You had no winter things and got"
514	"the simplest with your own hard earnings,"" said Mrs. March with a look"
514	that warmed Jo's heart.
514	""
514	"""I hadn't the least idea of selling my hair at first, but as I went"
514	along I kept thinking what I could do, and feeling as if I'd like to
514	dive into some of the rich stores and help myself.  In a barber's
514	window I saw tails of hair with the prices marked, and one black tail,
514	not so thick as mine, was forty dollars.  It came to me all of a sudden
514	that I had one thing to make money out of, and without stopping to
514	think, I walked in, asked if they bought hair, and what they would give
514	"for mine."""
514	""
514	"""I don't see how you dared to do it,"" said Beth in a tone of awe."
514	""
514	"""Oh, he was a little man who looked as if he merely lived to oil his"
514	hair.  He rather stared at first, as if he wasn't used to having girls
514	bounce into his shop and ask him to buy their hair.  He said he didn't
514	care about mine, it wasn't the fashionable color, and he never paid
514	much for it in the first place.  The work put into it made it dear, and
514	so on.  It was getting late, and I was afraid if it wasn't done right
514	away that I shouldn't have it done at all, and you know when I start to
514	do a thing, I hate to give it up.  So I begged him to take it, and told
514	him why I was in such a hurry.  It was silly, I dare say, but it
514	changed his mind, for I got rather excited, and told the story in my
514	topsy-turvy way, and his wife heard, and said so kindly, 'Take it,
514	Thomas, and oblige the young lady.  I'd do as much for our Jimmy any
514	"day if I had a spire of hair worth selling."""
514	""
514	"""Who was Jimmy?"" asked Amy, who liked to have things explained as they"
514	went along.
514	""
514	"""Her son, she said, who was in the army.  How friendly such things make"
514	strangers feel, don't they?  She talked away all the time the man
514	"clipped, and diverted my mind nicely."""
514	""
514	"""Didn't you feel dreadfully when the first cut came?"" asked Meg, with a"
514	shiver.
514	""
514	"""I took a last look at my hair while the man got his things, and that"
514	was the end of it.  I never snivel over trifles like that. I will
514	confess, though, I felt queer when I saw the dear old hair laid out on
514	the table, and felt only the short rough ends of my head. It almost
514	seemed as if I'd an arm or leg off.  The woman saw me look at it, and
514	picked out a long lock for me to keep.  I'll give it to you, Marmee,
514	just to remember past glories by, for a crop is so comfortable I don't
514	"think I shall ever have a mane again."""
514	""
514	Mrs. March folded the wavy chestnut lock, and laid it away with a short
514	"gray one in her desk.  She only said, ""Thank you, deary,"" but something"
514	in her face made the girls change the subject, and talk as cheerfully
514	as they could about Mr. Brooke's kindness, the prospect of a fine day
514	tomorrow, and the happy times they would have when Father came home to
514	be nursed.
514	""
514	No one wanted to go to bed when at ten o'clock Mrs. March put by the
514	"last finished job, and said, ""Come girls.""  Beth went to the piano and"
514	played the father's favorite hymn.  All began bravely, but broke down
514	one by one till Beth was left alone, singing with all her heart, for to
514	her music was always a sweet consoler.
514	""
514	"""Go to bed and don't talk, for we must be up early and shall need all"
514	"the sleep we can get.  Good night, my darlings,"" said Mrs. March, as"
514	the hymn ended, for no one cared to try another.
514	""
514	They kissed her quietly, and went to bed as silently as if the dear
514	invalid lay in the next room.  Beth and Amy soon fell asleep in spite
514	of the great trouble, but Meg lay awake, thinking the most serious
514	thoughts she had ever known in her short life.  Jo lay motionless, and
514	her sister fancied that she was asleep, till a stifled sob made her
514	exclaim, as she touched a wet cheek...
514	""
514	"""Jo, dear, what is it?  Are you crying about father?"""
514	""
514	"""No, not now."""
514	""
514	"""What then?"""
514	""
514	"""My... My hair!"" burst out poor Jo, trying vainly to smother her"
514	emotion in the pillow.
514	""
514	It did not seem at all comical to Meg, who kissed and caressed the
514	afflicted heroine in the tenderest manner.
514	""
514	"""I'm not sorry,"" protested Jo, with a choke.  ""I'd do it again"
514	tomorrow, if I could.  It's only the vain part of me that goes and
514	cries in this silly way.  Don't tell anyone, it's all over now.  I
514	thought you were asleep, so I just made a little private moan for my
514	"one beauty.  How came you to be awake?"""
514	""
514	"""I can't sleep, I'm so anxious,"" said Meg."
514	""
514	"""Think about something pleasant, and you'll soon drop off."""
514	""
514	"""I tried it, but felt wider awake than ever."""
514	""
514	"""What did you think of?"""
514	""
514	"""Handsome faces--eyes particularly,"" answered Meg, smiling to herself"
514	in the dark.
514	""
514	"""What color do you like best?"""
514	""
514	"""Brown, that is, sometimes.  Blue are lovely."""
514	""
514	Jo laughed, and Meg sharply ordered her not to talk, then amiably
514	promised to make her hair curl, and fell asleep to dream of living in
514	her castle in the air.
514	""
514	The clocks were striking midnight and the rooms were very still as a
514	figure glided quietly from bed to bed, smoothing a coverlet here,
514	settling a pillow there, and pausing to look long and tenderly at each
514	unconscious face, to kiss each with lips that mutely blessed, and to
514	pray the fervent prayers which only mothers utter.  As she lifted the
514	curtain to look out into the dreary night, the moon broke suddenly from
514	behind the clouds and shone upon her like a bright, benignant face,
514	"which seemed to whisper in the silence, ""Be comforted, dear soul!"
514	"There is always light behind the clouds."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER SIXTEEN
514	""
514	LETTERS
514	""
514	In the cold gray dawn the sisters lit their lamp and read their chapter
514	with an earnestness never felt before.  For now the shadow of a real
514	trouble had come, the little books were full of help and comfort, and
514	as they dressed, they agreed to say goodbye cheerfully and hopefully,
514	and send their mother on her anxious journey unsaddened by tears or
514	complaints from them.  Everything seemed very strange when they went
514	down, so dim and still outside, so full of light and bustle within.
514	Breakfast at that early hour seemed odd, and even Hannah's familiar
514	face looked unnatural as she flew about her kitchen with her nightcap
514	on.  The big trunk stood ready in the hall, Mother's cloak and bonnet
514	lay on the sofa, and Mother herself sat trying to eat, but looking so
514	pale and worn with sleeplessness and anxiety that the girls found it
514	very hard to keep their resolution.  Meg's eyes kept filling in spite
514	of herself, Jo was obliged to hide her face in the kitchen roller more
514	than once, and the little girls wore a grave, troubled expression, as
514	if sorrow was a new experience to them.
514	""
514	Nobody talked much, but as the time drew very near and they sat waiting
514	for the carriage, Mrs. March said to the girls, who were all busied
514	about her, one folding her shawl, another smoothing out the strings of
514	her bonnet, a third putting on her overshoes, and a fourth fastening up
514	her travelling bag...
514	""
514	"""Children, I leave you to Hannah's care and Mr. Laurence's protection."
514	Hannah is faithfulness itself, and our good neighbor will guard you as
514	if you were his own.  I have no fears for you, yet I am anxious that
514	you should take this trouble rightly.  Don't grieve and fret when I am
514	gone, or think that you can be idle and comfort yourselves by being
514	idle and trying to forget.  Go on with your work as usual, for work is
514	a blessed solace.  Hope and keep busy, and whatever happens, remember
514	"that you never can be fatherless."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, Mother."""
514	""
514	"""Meg, dear, be prudent, watch over your sisters, consult Hannah, and in"
514	any perplexity, go to Mr. Laurence.  Be patient, Jo, don't get
514	despondent or do rash things, write to me often, and be my brave girl,
514	ready to help and cheer all.  Beth, comfort yourself with your music,
514	and be faithful to the little home duties, and you, Amy, help all you
514	"can, be obedient, and keep happy safe at home."""
514	""
514	"""We will, Mother!  We will!"""
514	""
514	The rattle of an approaching carriage made them all start and listen.
514	That was the hard minute, but the girls stood it well.  No one cried,
514	no one ran away or uttered a lamentation, though their hearts were very
514	heavy as they sent loving messages to Father, remembering, as they
514	spoke that it might be too late to deliver them. They kissed their
514	mother quietly, clung about her tenderly, and tried to wave their hands
514	cheerfully when she drove away.
514	""
514	Laurie and his grandfather came over to see her off, and Mr. Brooke
514	looked so strong and sensible and kind that the girls christened him
514	'Mr. Greatheart' on the spot.
514	""
514	"""Good-by, my darlings!  God bless and keep us all!"" whispered Mrs."
514	March, as she kissed one dear little face after the other, and hurried
514	into the carriage.
514	""
514	As she rolled away, the sun came out, and looking back, she saw it
514	shining on the group at the gate like a good omen.  They saw it also,
514	and smiled and waved their hands, and the last thing she beheld as she
514	turned the corner was the four bright faces, and behind them like a
514	bodyguard, old Mr. Laurence, faithful Hannah, and devoted Laurie.
514	""
514	"""How kind everyone is to us!"" she said, turning to find fresh proof of"
514	it in the respectful sympathy of the young man's face.
514	""
514	"""I don't see how they can help it,"" returned Mr. Brooke, laughing so"
514	infectiously that Mrs. March could not help smiling. And so the journey
514	began with the good omens of sunshine, smiles, and cheerful words.
514	""
514	"""I feel as if there had been an earthquake,"" said Jo, as their"
514	neighbors went home to breakfast, leaving them to rest and refresh
514	themselves.
514	""
514	"""It seems as if half the house was gone,"" added Meg forlornly."
514	""
514	Beth opened her lips to say something, but could only point to the pile
514	of nicely mended hose which lay on Mother's table, showing that even in
514	her last hurried moments she had thought and worked for them.  It was a
514	little thing, but it went straight to their hearts, and in spite of
514	their brave resolutions, they all broke down and cried bitterly.
514	""
514	Hannah wisely allowed them to relieve their feelings, and when the
514	shower showed signs of clearing up, she came to the rescue, armed with
514	a coffeepot.
514	""
514	"""Now, my dear young ladies, remember what your ma said, and don't fret."
514	Come and have a cup of coffee all round, and then let's fall to work
514	"and be a credit to the family."""
514	""
514	Coffee was a treat, and Hannah showed great tact in making it that
514	morning.  No one could resist her persuasive nods, or the fragrant
514	invitation issuing from the nose of the coffee pot.  They drew up to
514	the table, exchanged their handkerchiefs for napkins, and in ten
514	minutes were all right again.
514	""
514	"""'Hope and keep busy', that's the motto for us, so let's see who will"
514	remember it best.  I shall go to Aunt March, as usual. Oh, won't she
514	"lecture though!"" said Jo, as she sipped with returning spirit."
514	""
514	"""I shall go to my Kings, though I'd much rather stay at home and attend"
514	"to things here,"" said Meg, wishing she hadn't made her eyes so red."
514	""
514	"""No need of that.  Beth and I can keep house perfectly well,"" put in"
514	Amy, with an important air.
514	""
514	"""Hannah will tell us what to do, and we'll have everything nice when"
514	"you come home,"" added Beth, getting out her mop and dish tub without"
514	delay.
514	""
514	"""I think anxiety is very interesting,"" observed Amy, eating sugar"
514	pensively.
514	""
514	The girls couldn't help laughing, and felt better for it, though Meg
514	shook her head at the young lady who could find consolation in a sugar
514	bowl.
514	""
514	The sight of the turnovers made Jo sober again; and when the two went
514	out to their daily tasks, they looked sorrowfully back at the window
514	where they were accustomed to see their mother's face.  It was gone,
514	but Beth had remembered the little household ceremony, and there she
514	was, nodding away at them like a rosyfaced mandarin.
514	""
514	"""That's so like my Beth!"" said Jo, waving her hat, with a grateful"
514	"face.  ""Goodbye, Meggy, I hope the Kings won't strain today.  Don't"
514	"fret about Father, dear,"" she added, as they parted."
514	""
514	"""And I hope Aunt March won't croak.  Your hair is becoming, and it"
514	"looks very boyish and nice,"" returned Meg, trying not to smile at the"
514	curly head, which looked comically small on her tall sister's shoulders.
514	""
514	"""That's my only comfort."" And, touching her hat a la Laurie, away went"
514	Jo, feeling like a shorn sheep on a wintry day.
514	""
514	News from their father comforted the girls very much, for though
514	dangerously ill, the presence of the best and tenderest of nurses had
514	already done him good.  Mr. Brooke sent a bulletin every day, and as
514	the head of the family, Meg insisted on reading the dispatches, which
514	grew more cheerful as the week passed.  At first, everyone was eager to
514	write, and plump envelopes were carefully poked into the letter box by
514	one or other of the sisters, who felt rather important with their
514	Washington correspondence.  As one of these packets contained
514	characteristic notes from the party, we will rob an imaginary mail, and
514	read them.
514	""
514	My dearest Mother:
514	""
514	It is impossible to tell you how happy your last letter made us, for
514	the news was so good we couldn't help laughing and crying over it.  How
514	very kind Mr. Brooke is, and how fortunate that Mr. Laurence's business
514	detains him near you so long, since he is so useful to you and Father.
514	The girls are all as good as gold.  Jo helps me with the sewing, and
514	insists on doing all sorts of hard jobs.  I should be afraid she might
514	overdo, if I didn't know her 'moral fit' wouldn't last long.  Beth is
514	as regular about her tasks as a clock, and never forgets what you told
514	her.  She grieves about Father, and looks sober except when she is at
514	her little piano.  Amy minds me nicely, and I take great care of her.
514	She does her own hair, and I am teaching her to make buttonholes and
514	mend her stockings. She tries very hard, and I know you will be pleased
514	with her improvement when you come.  Mr. Laurence watches over us like
514	a motherly old hen, as Jo says, and Laurie is very kind and neighborly.
514	He and Jo keep us merry, for we get pretty blue sometimes, and feel
514	like orphans, with you so far away.  Hannah is a perfect saint.  She
514	does not scold at all, and always calls me Miss Margaret, which is
514	quite proper, you know, and treats me with respect.  We are all well
514	and busy, but we long, day and night, to have you back.  Give my
514	dearest love to Father, and believe me, ever your own...
514	""
514	MEG
514	""
514	This note, prettily written on scented paper, was a great contrast to
514	the next, which was scribbled on a big sheet of thin foreign paper,
514	ornamented with blots and all manner of flourishes and curly-tailed
514	letters.
514	""
514	My precious Marmee:
514	""
514	Three cheers for dear Father!  Brooke was a trump to telegraph right
514	off, and let us know the minute he was better.  I rushed up garret when
514	the letter came, and tried to thank god for being so good to us, but I
514	"could only cry, and say, ""I'm glad!  I'm glad!"" Didn't that do as well"
514	as a regular prayer?  For I felt a great many in my heart.  We have
514	such funny times, and now I can enjoy them, for everyone is so
514	desperately good, it's like living in a nest of turtledoves.  You'd
514	laugh to see Meg head the table and try to be motherish.  She gets
514	prettier every day, and I'm in love with her sometimes.  The children
514	are regular archangels, and I--well, I'm Jo, and never shall be
514	anything else.  Oh, I must tell you that I came near having a quarrel
514	with Laurie.  I freed my mind about a silly little thing, and he was
514	offended.  I was right, but didn't speak as I ought, and he marched
514	home, saying he wouldn't come again till I begged pardon.  I declared I
514	wouldn't and got mad. It lasted all day.  I felt bad and wanted you
514	very much.  Laurie and I are both so proud, it's hard to beg pardon.
514	But I thought he'd come to it, for I was in the right.  He didn't come,
514	and just at night I remembered what you said when Amy fell into the
514	river.  I read my little book, felt better, resolved not to let the sun
514	set on my anger, and ran over to tell Laurie I was sorry.  I met him at
514	the gate, coming for the same thing.  We both laughed, begged each
514	other's pardon, and felt all good and comfortable again.
514	""
514	I made a 'pome' yesterday, when I was helping Hannah wash, and as
514	Father likes my silly little things, I put it in to amuse him.  Give
514	him my lovingest hug that ever was, and kiss yourself a dozen times for
514	your...
514	""
514	TOPSY-TURVY JO
514	""
514	""
514	    A SONG FROM THE SUDS
514	""
514	    Queen of my tub, I merrily sing,
514	    While the white foam rises high,
514	    And sturdily wash and rinse and wring,
514	    And fasten the clothes to dry.
514	    Then out in the free fresh air they swing,
514	    Under the sunny sky.
514	""
514	    I wish we could wash from our hearts and souls
514	    The stains of the week away,
514	    And let water and air by their magic make
514	    Ourselves as pure as they.
514	    Then on the earth there would be indeed,
514	    A glorious washing day!
514	""
514	    Along the path of a useful life,
514	    Will heart's-ease ever bloom.
514	    The busy mind has no time to think
514	    Of sorrow or care or gloom.
514	    And anxious thoughts may be swept away,
514	    As we bravely wield a broom.
514	""
514	    I am glad a task to me is given,
514	    To labor at day by day,
514	    For it brings me health and strength and hope,
514	    And I cheerfully learn to say,
514	"    ""Head, you may think, Heart, you may feel,"
514	"    But, Hand, you shall work alway!"""
514	""
514	""
514	Dear Mother,
514	""
514	There is only room for me to send my love, and some pressed pansies
514	from the root I have been keeping safe in the house for Father to see.
514	I read every morning, try to be good all day, and sing myself to sleep
514	with Father's tune.  I can't sing 'LAND OF THE LEAL' now, it makes me
514	cry.  Everyone is very kind, and we are as happy as we can be without
514	you.  Amy wants the rest of the page, so I must stop.  I didn't forget
514	to cover the holders, and I wind the clock and air the rooms every day.
514	""
514	Kiss dear Father on the cheek he calls mine.  Oh, do come soon to your
514	loving...
514	""
514	LITTLE BETH
514	""
514	""
514	Ma Chere Mamma,
514	""
514	We are all well I do my lessons always and never corroberate the
514	girls--Meg says I mean contradick so I put in both words and you can
514	take the properest.  Meg is a great comfort to me and lets me have
514	jelly every night at tea its so good for me Jo says because it keeps me
514	sweet tempered.  Laurie is not as respeckful as he ought to be now I am
514	almost in my teens, he calls me Chick and hurts my feelings by talking
514	French to me very fast when I say Merci or Bon jour as Hattie King
514	does.  The sleeves of my blue dress were all worn out, and Meg put in
514	new ones, but the full front came wrong and they are more blue than the
514	dress.  I felt bad but did not fret I bear my troubles well but I do
514	wish Hannah would put more starch in my aprons and have buckwheats
514	every day.  Can't she?  Didn't I make that interrigation point nice?
514	Meg says my punchtuation and spelling are disgraceful and I am
514	mortyfied but dear me I have so many things to do, I can't stop.
514	Adieu, I send heaps of love to Papa.  Your affectionate daughter...
514	""
514	AMY CURTIS MARCH
514	""
514	""
514	Dear Mis March,
514	""
514	I jes drop a line to say we git on fust rate.  The girls is clever and
514	fly round right smart.  Miss Meg is going to make a proper good
514	housekeeper.  She hes the liking for it, and gits the hang of things
514	surprisin quick.  Jo doos beat all for goin ahead, but she don't stop
514	to cal'k'late fust, and you never know where she's like to bring up.
514	She done out a tub of clothes on Monday, but she starched 'em afore
514	they was wrenched, and blued a pink calico dress till I thought I
514	should a died a laughin.  Beth is the best of little creeters, and a
514	sight of help to me, bein so forehanded and dependable.  She tries to
514	learn everything, and really goes to market beyond her years, likewise
514	keeps accounts, with my help, quite wonderful.  We have got on very
514	economical so fur.  I don't let the girls hev coffee only once a week,
514	accordin to your wish, and keep em on plain wholesome vittles.  Amy
514	does well without frettin, wearin her best clothes and eatin sweet
514	stuff. Mr. Laurie is as full of didoes as usual, and turns the house
514	upside down frequent, but he heartens the girls, so I let em hev full
514	swing.  The old gentleman sends heaps of things, and is rather wearin,
514	but means wal, and it aint my place to say nothin.  My bread is riz, so
514	no more at this time.  I send my duty to Mr. March, and hope he's seen
514	the last of his Pewmonia.
514	""
514	Yours respectful,
514	""
514	Hannah Mullet
514	""
514	""
514	Head Nurse of Ward No. 2,
514	""
514	""
514	All serene on the Rappahannock, troops in fine condition, commisary
514	department well conducted, the Home Guard under Colonel Teddy always on
514	duty, Commander in Chief General Laurence reviews the army daily,
514	Quartermaster Mullet keeps order in camp, and Major Lion does picket
514	duty at night.  A salute of twenty-four guns was fired on receipt of
514	good news from Washington, and a dress parade took place at
514	headquarters.  Commander in chief sends best wishes, in which he is
514	heartily joined by...
514	""
514	COLONEL TEDDY
514	""
514	""
514	Dear Madam:
514	""
514	The little girls are all well.  Beth and my boy report daily. Hannah is
514	a model servant, and guards pretty Meg like a dragon. Glad the fine
514	weather holds.  Pray make Brooke useful, and draw on me for funds if
514	expenses exceed your estimate.  Don't let your husband want anything.
514	Thank God he is mending.
514	""
514	Your sincere friend and servant, JAMES LAURENCE
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER SEVENTEEN
514	""
514	LITTLE FAITHFUL
514	""
514	For a week the amount of virtue in the old house would have supplied
514	the neighborhood.  It was really amazing, for everyone seemed in a
514	heavenly frame of mind, and self-denial was all the fashion.  Relieved
514	of their first anxiety about their father, the girls insensibly relaxed
514	their praiseworthy efforts a little, and began to fall back into old
514	ways.  They did not forget their motto, but hoping and keeping busy
514	seemed to grow easier, and after such tremendous exertions, they felt
514	that Endeavor deserved a holiday, and gave it a good many.
514	""
514	Jo caught a bad cold through neglect to cover the shorn head enough,
514	and was ordered to stay at home till she was better, for Aunt March
514	didn't like to hear people read with colds in their heads.  Jo liked
514	this, and after an energetic rummage from garret to cellar, subsided on
514	the sofa to nurse her cold with arsenicum and books.  Amy found that
514	housework and art did not go well together, and returned to her mud
514	pies.  Meg went daily to her pupils, and sewed, or thought she did, at
514	home, but much time was spent in writing long letters to her mother, or
514	reading the Washington dispatches over and over.  Beth kept on, with
514	only slight relapses into idleness or grieving.
514	""
514	All the little duties were faithfully done each day, and many of her
514	sisters' also, for they were forgetful, and the house seemed like a
514	clock whose pendulum was gone a-visiting.  When her heart got heavy
514	with longings for Mother or fears for Father, she went away into a
514	certain closet, hid her face in the folds of a dear old gown, and made
514	her little moan and prayed her little prayer quietly by herself.
514	Nobody knew what cheered her up after a sober fit, but everyone felt
514	how sweet and helpful Beth was, and fell into a way of going to her for
514	comfort or advice in their small affairs.
514	""
514	All were unconscious that this experience was a test of character, and
514	when the first excitement was over, felt that they had done well and
514	deserved praise.  So they did, but their mistake was in ceasing to do
514	well, and they learned this lesson through much anxiety and regret.
514	""
514	"""Meg, I wish you'd go and see the Hummels.  You know Mother told us not"
514	"to forget them."" said Beth, ten days after Mrs. March's departure."
514	""
514	"""I'm too tired to go this afternoon,"" replied Meg, rocking comfortably"
514	as she sewed.
514	""
514	"""Can't you, Jo?"" asked Beth."
514	""
514	"""Too stormy for me with my cold."""
514	""
514	"""I thought it was almost well."""
514	""
514	"""It's well enough for me to go out with Laurie, but not well enough to"
514	"go to the Hummels',"" said Jo, laughing, but looking a little ashamed of"
514	her inconsistency.
514	""
514	"""Why don't you go yourself?"" asked Meg."
514	""
514	"""I have been every day, but the baby is sick, and I don't know what to"
514	do for it.  Mrs. Hummel goes away to work, and Lottchen takes care of
514	it.  But it gets sicker and sicker, and I think you or Hannah ought to
514	"go."""
514	""
514	Beth spoke earnestly, and Meg promised she would go tomorrow.
514	""
514	"""Ask Hannah for some nice little mess, and take it round, Beth, the air"
514	"will do you good,"" said Jo, adding apologetically, ""I'd go but I want"
514	"to finish my writing."""
514	""
514	"""My head aches and I'm tired, so I thought maybe some of you would go,"""
514	said Beth.
514	""
514	"""Amy will be in presently, and she will run down for us,"" suggested Meg."
514	""
514	So Beth lay down on the sofa, the others returned to their work, and
514	the Hummels were forgotten.  An hour passed.  Amy did not come, Meg
514	went to her room to try on a new dress, Jo was absorbed in her story,
514	and Hannah was sound asleep before the kitchen fire, when Beth quietly
514	put on her hood, filled her basket with odds and ends for the poor
514	children, and went out into the chilly air with a heavy head and a
514	grieved look in her patient eyes.  It was late when she came back, and
514	no one saw her creep upstairs and shut herself into her mother's room.
514	Half an hour after, Jo went to 'Mother's closet' for something, and
514	there found little Beth sitting on the medicine chest, looking very
514	grave, with red eyes and a camphor bottle in her hand.
514	""
514	"""Christopher Columbus!  What's the matter?"" cried Jo, as Beth put out"
514	her hand as if to warn her off, and asked quickly. . .
514	""
514	"""You've had the scarlet fever, haven't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Years ago, when Meg did.  Why?"""
514	""
514	"""Then I'll tell you.  Oh, Jo, the baby's dead!"""
514	""
514	"""What baby?"""
514	""
514	"""Mrs. Hummel's.  It died in my lap before she got home,"" cried Beth"
514	with a sob.
514	""
514	"""My poor dear, how dreadful for you!  I ought to have gone,"" said Jo,"
514	taking her sister in her arms as she sat down in her mother's big
514	chair, with a remorseful face.
514	""
514	"""It wasn't dreadful, Jo, only so sad!  I saw in a minute it was sicker,"
514	but Lottchen said her mother had gone for a doctor, so I took Baby and
514	let Lotty rest.  It seemed asleep, but all of a sudden if gave a little
514	cry and trembled, and then lay very still. I tried to warm its feet,
514	and Lotty gave it some milk, but it didn't stir, and I knew it was
514	"dead."""
514	""
514	"""Don't cry, dear!  What did you do?"""
514	""
514	"""I just sat and held it softly till Mrs. Hummel came with the doctor."
514	He said it was dead, and looked at Heinrich and Minna, who have sore
514	throats.  'Scarlet fever, ma'am.  Ought to have called me before,' he
514	said crossly.  Mrs. Hummel told him she was poor, and had tried to cure
514	baby herself, but now it was too late, and she could only ask him to
514	help the others and trust to charity for his pay.  He smiled then, and
514	was kinder, but it was very sad, and I cried with them till he turned
514	round all of a sudden, and told me to go home and take belladonna right
514	"away, or I'd have the fever."""
514	""
514	"""No, you won't!"" cried Jo, hugging her close, with a frightened look."
514	"""Oh, Beth, if you should be sick I never could forgive myself! What"
514	"shall we do?"""
514	""
514	"""Don't be frightened, I guess I shan't have it badly.  I looked in"
514	Mother's book, and saw that it begins with headache, sore throat, and
514	queer feelings like mine, so I did take some belladonna, and I feel
514	"better,"" said Beth, laying her cold hands on her hot forehead and"
514	trying to look well.
514	""
514	"""If Mother was only at home!"" exclaimed Jo, seizing the book, and"
514	feeling that Washington was an immense way off.  She read a page,
514	looked at Beth, felt her head, peeped into her throat, and then said
514	"gravely, ""You've been over the baby every day for more than a week, and"
514	among the others who are going to have it, so I'm afraid you are going
514	"to have it, Beth.  I'll call Hannah, she knows all about sickness."""
514	""
514	"""Don't let Amy come.  She never had it, and I should hate to give it to"
514	"her.  Can't you and Meg have it over again?"" asked Beth, anxiously."
514	""
514	"""I guess not.  Don't care if I do.  Serve me right, selfish pig, to let"
514	"you go, and stay writing rubbish myself!"" muttered Jo, as she went to"
514	consult Hannah.
514	""
514	The good soul was wide awake in a minute, and took the lead at once,
514	assuring that there was no need to worry; every one had scarlet fever,
514	and if rightly treated, nobody died, all of which Jo believed, and felt
514	much relieved as they went up to call Meg.
514	""
514	"""Now I'll tell you what we'll do,"" said Hannah, when she had examined"
514	"and questioned Beth, ""we will have Dr. Bangs, just to take a look at"
514	you, dear, and see that we start right.  Then we'll send Amy off to
514	Aunt March's for a spell, to keep her out of harm's way, and one of you
514	"girls can stay at home and amuse Beth for a day or two."""
514	""
514	"""I shall stay, of course, I'm oldest,"" began Meg, looking anxious and"
514	self-reproachful.
514	""
514	"""I shall, because it's my fault she is sick.  I told Mother I'd do the"
514	"errands, and I haven't,"" said Jo decidedly."
514	""
514	"""Which will you have, Beth?  There ain't no need of but one,"" aid"
514	Hannah.
514	""
514	"""Jo, please."" And Beth leaned her head against her sister with a"
514	contented look, which effectually settled that point.
514	""
514	"""I'll go and tell Amy,"" said Meg, feeling a little hurt, yet rather"
514	relieved on the whole, for she did not like nursing, and Jo did.
514	""
514	Amy rebelled outright, and passionately declared that she had rather
514	have the fever than go to Aunt March.  Meg reasoned, pleaded, and
514	commanded, all in vain.  Amy protested that she would not go, and Meg
514	left her in despair to ask Hannah what should be done.  Before she came
514	back, Laurie walked into the parlor to find Amy sobbing, with her head
514	in the sofa cushions.  She told her story, expecting to be consoled,
514	but Laurie only put his hands in his pockets and walked about the room,
514	whistling softly, as he knit his brows in deep thought.  Presently he
514	"sat down beside her, and said, in his most wheedlesome tone, ""Now be a"
514	sensible little woman, and do as they say. No, don't cry, but hear what
514	a jolly plan I've got.  You go to Aunt March's, and I'll come and take
514	you out every day, driving or walking, and we'll have capital times.
514	"Won't that be better than moping here?"""
514	""
514	"""I don't wish to be sent off as if I was in the way,"" began Amy, in an"
514	injured voice.
514	""
514	"""Bless your heart, child, it's to keep you well.  You don't want to be"
514	"sick, do you?"""
514	""
514	"""No, I'm sure I don't, but I dare say I shall be, for I've been with"
514	"Beth all the time."""
514	""
514	"""That's the very reason you ought to go away at once, so that you may"
514	escape it.  Change of air and care will keep you well, I dare say, or
514	if it does not entirely, you will have the fever more lightly.  I
514	advise you to be off as soon as you can, for scarlet fever is no joke,
514	"miss."""
514	""
514	"""But it's dull at Aunt March's, and she is so cross,"" said Amy, looking"
514	rather frightened.
514	""
514	"""It won't be dull with me popping in every day to tell you how Beth is,"
514	and take you out gallivanting.  The old lady likes me, and I'll be as
514	"sweet as possible to her, so she won't peck at us, whatever we do."""
514	""
514	"""Will you take me out in the trotting wagon with Puck?"""
514	""
514	"""On my honor as a gentleman."""
514	""
514	"""And come every single day?"""
514	""
514	"""See if I don't!"""
514	""
514	"""And bring me back the minute Beth is well?"""
514	""
514	"""The identical minute."""
514	""
514	"""And go to the theater, truly?"""
514	""
514	"""A dozen theaters, if we may."""
514	""
514	"""Well--I guess I will,"" said Amy slowly."
514	""
514	"""Good girl!  Call Meg, and tell her you'll give in,"" said Laurie, with"
514	an approving pat, which annoyed Amy more than the 'giving in'.
514	""
514	Meg and Jo came running down to behold the miracle which had been
514	wrought, and Amy, feeling very precious and self-sacrificing, promised
514	to go, if the doctor said Beth was going to be ill.
514	""
514	"""How is the little dear?"" asked Laurie, for Beth was his especial pet,"
514	and he felt more anxious about her than he liked to show.
514	""
514	"""She is lying down on Mother's bed, and feels better.  The baby's death"
514	troubled her, but I dare say she has only got cold. Hannah says she
514	"thinks so, but she looks worried, and that makes me fidgety,"" answered"
514	Meg.
514	""
514	"""What a trying world it is!"" said Jo, rumpling up her hair in a fretful"
514	"way.  ""No sooner do we get out of one trouble than down comes another."
514	There doesn't seem to be anything to hold on to when Mother's gone, so
514	"I'm all at sea."""
514	""
514	"""Well, don't make a porcupine of yourself, it isn't becoming. Settle"
514	your wig, Jo, and tell me if I shall telegraph to your mother, or do
514	"anything?"" asked Laurie, who never had been reconciled to the loss of"
514	his friend's one beauty.
514	""
514	"""That is what troubles me,"" said Meg.  ""I think we ought to tell her if"
514	Beth is really ill, but Hannah says we mustn't, for Mother can't leave
514	Father, and it will only make them anxious.  Beth won't be sick long,
514	and Hannah knows just what to do, and Mother said we were to mind her,
514	"so I suppose we must, but it doesn't seem quite right to me."""
514	""
514	"""Hum, well, I can't say.  Suppose you ask Grandfather after the doctor"
514	"has been."""
514	""
514	"""We will.  Jo, go and get Dr. Bangs at once,"" commanded Meg. ""We can't"
514	"decide anything till he has been."""
514	""
514	"""Stay where you are, Jo.  I'm errand boy to this establishment,"" said"
514	Laurie, taking up his cap.
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid you are busy,"" began Meg."
514	""
514	"""No, I've done my lessons for the day."""
514	""
514	"""Do you study in vacation time?"" asked Jo."
514	""
514	"""I follow the good example my neighbors set me,"" was Laurie's answer,"
514	as he swung himself out of the room.
514	""
514	"""I have great hopes for my boy,"" observed Jo, watching him fly over the"
514	fence with an approving smile.
514	""
514	"""He does very well, for a boy,"" was Meg's somewhat ungracious answer,"
514	for the subject did not interest her.
514	""
514	Dr. Bangs came, said Beth had symptoms of the fever, but he thought she
514	would have it lightly, though he looked sober over the Hummel story.
514	Amy was ordered off at once, and provided with something to ward off
514	danger, she departed in great state, with Jo and Laurie as escort.
514	""
514	Aunt March received them with her usual hospitality.
514	""
514	"""What do you want now?"" she asked, looking sharply over her spectacles,"
514	while the parrot, sitting on the back of her chair, called out...
514	""
514	"""Go away.  No boys allowed here."""
514	""
514	Laurie retired to the window, and Jo told her story.
514	""
514	"""No more than I expected, if you are allowed to go poking about among"
514	poor folks.  Amy can stay and make herself useful if she isn't sick,
514	which I've no doubt she will be, looks like it now.  Don't cry, child,
514	"it worries me to hear people sniff."""
514	""
514	Amy was on the point of crying, but Laurie slyly pulled the parrot's
514	tail, which caused Polly to utter an astonished croak and call out,
514	"""Bless my boots!"" in such a funny way, that she laughed instead."
514	""
514	"""What do you hear from your mother?"" asked the old lady gruffly."
514	""
514	"""Father is much better,"" replied Jo, trying to keep sober."
514	""
514	"""Oh, is he?  Well, that won't last long, I fancy.  March never had any"
514	"stamina,"" was the cheerful reply."
514	""
514	"""Ha, ha!  Never say die, take a pinch of snuff, goodbye, goodbye!"""
514	squalled Polly, dancing on her perch, and clawing at the old lady's cap
514	as Laurie tweaked him in the rear.
514	""
514	"""Hold your tongue, you disrespectful old bird!  And, Jo, you'd better"
514	go at once.  It isn't proper to be gadding about so late with a
514	"rattlepated boy like..."""
514	""
514	"""Hold your tongue, you disrespectful old bird!"" cried Polly, tumbling"
514	off the chair with a bounce, and running to peck the 'rattlepated' boy,
514	who was shaking with laughter at the last speech.
514	""
514	"""I don't think I can bear it, but I'll try,"" thought Amy, as she was"
514	left alone with Aunt March.
514	""
514	"""Get along, you fright!"" screamed Polly, and at that rude speech Amy"
514	could not restrain a sniff.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER EIGHTEEN
514	""
514	DARK DAYS
514	""
514	Beth did have the fever, and was much sicker than anyone but Hannah and
514	the doctor suspected.  The girls knew nothing about illness, and Mr.
514	Laurence was not allowed to see her, so Hannah had everything her own
514	way, and busy Dr. Bangs did his best, but left a good deal to the
514	excellent nurse.  Meg stayed at home, lest she should infect the Kings,
514	and kept house, feeling very anxious and a little guilty when she wrote
514	letters in which no mention was made of Beth's illness.  She could not
514	think it right to deceive her mother, but she had been bidden to mind
514	Hannah, and Hannah wouldn't hear of 'Mrs. March bein' told, and worried
514	just for sech a trifle.'
514	""
514	Jo devoted herself to Beth day and night, not a hard task, for Beth was
514	very patient, and bore her pain uncomplainingly as long as she could
514	control herself.  But there came a time when during the fever fits she
514	began to talk in a hoarse, broken voice, to play on the coverlet as if
514	on her beloved little piano, and try to sing with a throat so swollen
514	that there was no music left, a time when she did not know the familiar
514	faces around her, but addressed them by wrong names, and called
514	imploringly for her mother.  Then Jo grew frightened, Meg begged to be
514	allowed to write the truth, and even Hannah said she 'would think of
514	it, though there was no danger yet'.  A letter from Washington added to
514	their trouble, for Mr. March had had a relapse, and could not think of
514	coming home for a long while.
514	""
514	How dark the days seemed now, how sad and lonely the house, and how
514	heavy were the hearts of the sisters as they worked and waited, while
514	the shadow of death hovered over the once happy home. Then it was that
514	Margaret, sitting alone with tears dropping often on her work, felt how
514	rich she had been in things more precious than any luxuries money could
514	buy--in love, protection, peace, and health, the real blessings of
514	life.  Then it was that Jo, living in the darkened room, with that
514	suffering little sister always before her eyes and that pathetic voice
514	sounding in her ears, learned to see the beauty and the sweetness of
514	Beth's nature, to feel how deep and tender a place she filled in all
514	hearts, and to acknowledge the worth of Beth's unselfish ambition to
514	live for others, and make home happy by that exercise of those simple
514	virtues which all may possess, and which all should love and value more
514	than talent, wealth, or beauty.  And Amy, in her exile, longed eagerly
514	to be at home, that she might work for Beth, feeling now that no
514	service would be hard or irksome, and remembering, with regretful
514	grief, how many neglected tasks those willing hands had done for her.
514	Laurie haunted the house like a restless ghost, and Mr. Laurence locked
514	the grand piano, because he could not bear to be reminded of the young
514	neighbor who used to make the twilight pleasant for him.  Everyone
514	missed Beth.  The milkman, baker, grocer, and butcher inquired how she
514	did, poor Mrs. Hummel came to beg pardon for her thoughtlessness and to
514	get a shroud for Minna, the neighbors sent all sorts of comforts and
514	good wishes, and even those who knew her best were surprised to find
514	how many friends shy little Beth had made.
514	""
514	Meanwhile she lay on her bed with old Joanna at her side, for even in
514	her wanderings she did not forget her forlorn protege.  She longed for
514	her cats, but would not have them brought, lest they should get sick,
514	and in her quiet hours she was full of anxiety about Jo.  She sent
514	loving messages to Amy, bade them tell her mother that she would write
514	soon, and often begged for pencil and paper to try to say a word, that
514	Father might not think she had neglected him. But soon even these
514	intervals of consciousness ended, and she lay hour after hour, tossing
514	to and fro, with incoherent words on her lips, or sank into a heavy
514	sleep which brought her no refreshment. Dr. Bangs came twice a day,
514	Hannah sat up at night, Meg kept a telegram in her desk all ready to
514	send off at any minute, and Jo never stirred from Beth's side.
514	""
514	The first of December was a wintry day indeed to them, for a bitter
514	wind blew, snow fell fast, and the year seemed getting ready for its
514	death.  When Dr. Bangs came that morning, he looked long at Beth, held
514	the hot hand in both his own for a minute, and laid it gently down,
514	"saying, in a low voice to Hannah, ""If Mrs. March can leave her husband"
514	"she'd better be sent for."""
514	""
514	Hannah nodded without speaking, for her lips twitched nervously, Meg
514	dropped down into a chair as the strength seemed to go out of her limbs
514	at the sound of those words, and Jo, standing with a pale face for a
514	minute, ran to the parlor, snatched up the telegram, and throwing on
514	her things, rushed out into the storm.  She was soon back, and while
514	noiselessly taking off her cloak, Laurie came in with a letter, saying
514	that Mr. March was mending again.  Jo read it thankfully, but the heavy
514	weight did not seem lifted off her heart, and her face was so full of
514	"misery that Laurie asked quickly, ""What is it?  Is Beth worse?"""
514	""
514	"""I've sent for Mother,"" said Jo, tugging at her rubber boots with a"
514	tragic expression.
514	""
514	"""Good for you, Jo!  Did you do it on your own responsibility?"" asked"
514	Laurie, as he seated her in the hall chair and took off the rebellious
514	boots, seeing how her hands shook.
514	""
514	"""No.  The doctor told us to."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Jo, it's not so bad as that?"" cried Laurie, with a startled face."
514	""
514	"""Yes, it is.  She doesn't know us, she doesn't even talk about the"
514	flocks of green doves, as she calls the vine leaves on the wall. She
514	doesn't look like my Beth, and there's nobody to help us bear it.
514	Mother and father both gone, and God seems so far away I can't find
514	"Him."""
514	""
514	As the tears streamed fast down poor Jo's cheeks, she stretched out her
514	hand in a helpless sort of way, as if groping in the dark, and Laurie
514	took it in his, whispering as well as he could with a lump in his
514	"throat, ""I'm here.  Hold on to me, Jo, dear!"""
514	""
514	She could not speak, but she did 'hold on', and the warm grasp of the
514	friendly human hand comforted her sore heart, and seemed to lead her
514	nearer to the Divine arm which alone could uphold her in her trouble.
514	""
514	Laurie longed to say something tender and comfortable, but no fitting
514	words came to him, so he stood silent, gently stroking her bent head as
514	her mother used to do.  It was the best thing he could have done, far
514	more soothing than the most eloquent words, for Jo felt the unspoken
514	sympathy, and in the silence learned the sweet solace which affection
514	administers to sorrow.  Soon she dried the tears which had relieved
514	her, and looked up with a grateful face.
514	""
514	"""Thank you, Teddy, I'm better now.  I don't feel so forlorn, and will"
514	"try to bear it if it comes."""
514	""
514	"""Keep hoping for the best, that will help you, Jo.  Soon your mother"
514	"will be here, and then everything will be all right."""
514	""
514	"""I'm so glad Father is better.  Now she won't feel so bad about leaving"
514	him.  Oh, me!  It does seem as if all the troubles came in a heap, and
514	"I got the heaviest part on my shoulders,"" sighed Jo, spreading her wet"
514	handkerchief over her knees to dry.
514	""
514	"""Doesn't Meg pull fair?"" asked Laurie, looking indignant."
514	""
514	"""Oh, yes, she tries to, but she can't love Bethy as I do, and she won't"
514	miss her as I shall.  Beth is my conscience, and I can't give her up.
514	"I can't!  I can't!"""
514	""
514	Down went Jo's face into the wet handkerchief, and she cried
514	despairingly, for she had kept up bravely till now and never shed a
514	tear.  Laurie drew his hand across his eyes, but could not speak till
514	he had subdued the choky feeling in his throat and steadied his lips.
514	It might be unmanly, but he couldn't help it, and I am glad of it.
514	"Presently, as Jo's sobs quieted, he said hopefully, ""I don't think she"
514	will die.  She's so good, and we all love her so much, I don't believe
514	"God will take her away yet."""
514	""
514	"""The good and dear people always do die,"" groaned Jo, but she stopped"
514	crying, for her friend's words cheered her up in spite of her own
514	doubts and fears.
514	""
514	"""Poor girl, you're worn out.  It isn't like you to be forlorn. Stop a"
514	"bit.  I'll hearten you up in a jiffy."""
514	""
514	Laurie went off two stairs at a time, and Jo laid her wearied head down
514	on Beth's little brown hood, which no one had thought of moving from
514	the table where she left it.  It must have possessed some magic, for
514	the submissive spirit of its gentle owner seemed to enter into Jo, and
514	when Laurie came running down with a glass of wine, she took it with a
514	"smile, and said bravely, ""I drink-- Health to my Beth!  You are a good"
514	"doctor, Teddy, and such a comfortable friend.  How can I ever pay you?"""
514	she added, as the wine refreshed her body, as the kind words had done
514	her troubled mind.
514	""
514	"""I'll send my bill, by-and-by, and tonight I'll give you something that"
514	"will warm the cockles of your heart better than quarts of wine,"" said"
514	Laurie, beaming at her with a face of suppressed satisfaction at
514	something.
514	""
514	"""What is it?"" cried Jo, forgetting her woes for a minute in her wonder."
514	""
514	"""I telegraphed to your mother yesterday, and Brooke answered she'd come"
514	at once, and she'll be here tonight, and everything will be all right.
514	"Aren't you glad I did it?"""
514	""
514	Laurie spoke very fast, and turned red and excited all in a minute, for
514	he had kept his plot a secret, for fear of disappointing the girls or
514	harming Beth.  Jo grew quite white, flew out of her chair, and the
514	moment he stopped speaking she electrified him by throwing her arms
514	"round his neck, and crying out, with a joyful cry, ""Oh, Laurie!  Oh,"
514	"Mother!  I am so glad!""  She did not weep again, but laughed"
514	hysterically, and trembled and clung to her friend as if she was a
514	little bewildered by the sudden news.
514	""
514	Laurie, though decidedly amazed, behaved with great presence of mind.
514	He patted her back soothingly, and finding that she was recovering,
514	followed it up by a bashful kiss or two, which brought Jo round at
514	once.  Holding on to the banisters, she put him gently away, saying
514	"breathlessly, ""Oh, don't!  I didn't mean to, it was dreadful of me, but"
514	you were such a dear to go and do it in spite of Hannah that I couldn't
514	help flying at you.  Tell me all about it, and don't give me wine
514	"again, it makes me act so."""
514	""
514	"""I don't mind,"" laughed Laurie, as he settled his tie.  ""Why, you see I"
514	got fidgety, and so did Grandpa.  We thought Hannah was overdoing the
514	authority business, and your mother ought to know. She'd never forgive
514	us if Beth...  Well, if anything happened, you know.  So I got grandpa
514	to say it was high time we did something, and off I pelted to the
514	office yesterday, for the doctor looked sober, and Hannah most took my
514	head off when I proposed a telegram.  I never can bear to be 'lorded
514	over', so that settled my mind, and I did it. Your mother will come, I
514	know, and the late train is in at two A.M. I shall go for her, and
514	you've only got to bottle up your rapture, and keep Beth quiet till
514	"that blessed lady gets here."""
514	""
514	"""Laurie, you're an angel!  How shall I ever thank you?"""
514	""
514	"""Fly at me again.  I rather liked it,"" said Laurie, looking"
514	mischievous, a thing he had not done for a fortnight.
514	""
514	"""No, thank you.  I'll do it by proxy, when your grandpa comes. Don't"
514	tease, but go home and rest, for you'll be up half the night. Bless
514	"you, Teddy, bless you!"""
514	""
514	Jo had backed into a corner, and as she finished her speech, she
514	vanished precipitately into the kitchen, where she sat down upon a
514	"dresser and told the assembled cats that she was ""happy, oh, so happy!"""
514	while Laurie departed, feeling that he had made a rather neat thing of
514	it.
514	""
514	"""That's the interferingest chap I ever see, but I forgive him and do"
514	"hope Mrs. March is coming right away,"" said Hannah, with an air of"
514	relief, when Jo told the good news.
514	""
514	Meg had a quiet rapture, and then brooded over the letter, while Jo set
514	"the sickroom in order, and Hannah ""knocked up a couple of pies in case"
514	"of company unexpected"".  A breath of fresh air seemed to blow through"
514	the house, and something better than sunshine brightened the quiet
514	rooms.  Everything appeared to feel the hopeful change.  Beth's bird
514	began to chirp again, and a half-blown rose was discovered on Amy's
514	bush in the window. The fires seemed to burn with unusual cheeriness,
514	and every time the girls met, their pale faces broke into smiles as
514	"they hugged one another, whispering encouragingly, ""Mother's coming,"
514	"dear! Mother's coming!""  Every one rejoiced but Beth.  She lay in that"
514	heavy stupor, alike unconscious of hope and joy, doubt and danger. It
514	was a piteous sight, the once rosy face so changed and vacant, the once
514	busy hands so weak and wasted, the once smiling lips quite dumb, and
514	the once pretty, well-kept hair scattered rough and tangled on the
