514	pillow.  All day she lay so, only rousing now and then to mutter,
514	"""Water!"" with lips so parched they could hardly shape the word.  All"
514	day Jo and Meg hovered over her, watching, waiting, hoping, and
514	trusting in God and Mother, and all day the snow fell, the bitter wind
514	raged, and the hours dragged slowly by.  But night came at last, and
514	every time the clock struck, the sisters, still sitting on either side
514	of the bed, looked at each other with brightening eyes, for each hour
514	brought help nearer.  The doctor had been in to say that some change,
514	for better or worse, would probably take place about midnight, at which
514	time he would return.
514	""
514	Hannah, quite worn out, lay down on the sofa at the bed's foot and fell
514	fast asleep, Mr. Laurence marched to and fro in the parlor, feeling
514	that he would rather face a rebel battery than Mrs. March's countenance
514	as she entered.  Laurie lay on the rug, pretending to rest, but staring
514	into the fire with the thoughtful look which made his black eyes
514	beautifully soft and clear.
514	""
514	The girls never forgot that night, for no sleep came to them as they
514	kept their watch, with that dreadful sense of powerlessness which comes
514	to us in hours like those.
514	""
514	"""If God spares Beth, I never will complain again,"" whispered Meg"
514	earnestly.
514	""
514	"""If god spares Beth, I'll try to love and serve Him all my life,"""
514	answered Jo, with equal fervor.
514	""
514	"""I wish I had no heart, it aches so,"" sighed Meg, after a pause."
514	""
514	"""If life is often as hard as this, I don't see how we ever shall get"
514	"through it,"" added her sister despondently."
514	""
514	Here the clock struck twelve, and both forgot themselves in watching
514	Beth, for they fancied a change passed over her wan face. The house was
514	still as death, and nothing but the wailing of the wind broke the deep
514	hush.  Weary Hannah slept on, and no one but the sisters saw the pale
514	shadow which seemed to fall upon the little bed.  An hour went by, and
514	nothing happened except Laurie's quiet departure for the station.
514	Another hour, still no one came, and anxious fears of delay in the
514	storm, or accidents by the way, or, worst of all, a great grief at
514	Washington, haunted the girls.
514	""
514	It was past two, when Jo, who stood at the window thinking how dreary
514	the world looked in its winding sheet of snow, heard a movement by the
514	bed, and turning quickly, saw Meg kneeling before their mother's easy
514	chair with her face hidden.  A dreadful fear passed coldly over Jo, as
514	"she thought, ""Beth is dead, and Meg is afraid to tell me."""
514	""
514	She was back at her post in an instant, and to her excited eyes a great
514	change seemed to have taken place.  The fever flush and the look of
514	pain were gone, and the beloved little face looked so pale and peaceful
514	in its utter repose that Jo felt no desire to weep or to lament.
514	Leaning low over this dearest of her sisters, she kissed the damp
514	"forehead with her heart on her lips, and softly whispered, ""Good-by, my"
514	"Beth.  Good-by!"""
514	""
514	As if awaked by the stir, Hannah started out of her sleep, hurried to
514	the bed, looked at Beth, felt her hands, listened at her lips, and
514	then, throwing her apron over her head, sat down to rock to and fro,
514	"exclaiming, under her breath, ""The fever's turned, she's sleepin'"
514	nat'ral, her skin's damp, and she breathes easy.  Praise be given!  Oh,
514	"my goodness me!"""
514	""
514	Before the girls could believe the happy truth, the doctor came to
514	confirm it.  He was a homely man, but they thought his face quite
514	"heavenly when he smiled and said, with a fatherly look at them, ""Yes,"
514	my dears, I think the little girl will pull through this time.  Keep
514	"the house quiet, let her sleep, and when she wakes, give her..."""
514	""
514	What they were to give, neither heard, for both crept into the dark
514	hall, and, sitting on the stairs, held each other close, rejoicing with
514	hearts too full for words.  When they went back to be kissed and
514	cuddled by faithful Hannah, they found Beth lying, as she used to do,
514	with her cheek pillowed on her hand, the dreadful pallor gone, and
514	breathing quietly, as if just fallen asleep.
514	""
514	"""If Mother would only come now!"" said Jo, as the winter night began to"
514	wane.
514	""
514	"""See,"" said Meg, coming up with a white, half-opened rose, ""I thought"
514	this would hardly be ready to lay in Beth's hand tomorrow if she--went
514	away from us.  But it has blossomed in the night, and now I mean to put
514	it in my vase here, so that when the darling wakes, the first thing she
514	"sees will be the little rose, and Mother's face."""
514	""
514	Never had the sun risen so beautifully, and never had the world seemed
514	so lovely as it did to the heavy eyes of Meg and Jo, as they looked out
514	in the early morning, when their long, sad vigil was done.
514	""
514	"""It looks like a fairy world,"" said Meg, smiling to herself, as she"
514	stood behind the curtain, watching the dazzling sight.
514	""
514	"""Hark!"" cried Jo, starting to her feet."
514	""
514	Yes, there was a sound of bells at the door below, a cry from Hannah,
514	"and then Laurie's voice saying in a joyful whisper, ""Girls, she's come!"
514	"She's come!"""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER NINETEEN
514	""
514	AMY'S WILL
514	""
514	While these things were happening at home, Amy was having hard times at
514	Aunt March's.  She felt her exile deeply, and for the first time in her
514	life, realized how much she was beloved and petted at home.  Aunt March
514	never petted any one; she did not approve of it, but she meant to be
514	kind, for the well-behaved little girl pleased her very much, and Aunt
514	March had a soft place in her old heart for her nephew's children,
514	though she didn't think it proper to confess it.  She really did her
514	best to make Amy happy, but, dear me, what mistakes she made. Some old
514	people keep young at heart in spite of wrinkles and gray hairs, can
514	sympathize with children's little cares and joys, make them feel at
514	home, and can hide wise lessons under pleasant plays, giving and
514	receiving friendship in the sweetest way.  But Aunt March had not this
514	gift, and she worried Amy very much with her rules and orders, her prim
514	ways, and long, prosy talks.  Finding the child more docile and amiable
514	than her sister, the old lady felt it her duty to try and counteract,
514	as far as possible, the bad effects of home freedom and indulgence.  So
514	she took Amy by the hand, and taught her as she herself had been taught
514	sixty years ago, a process which carried dismay to Amy's soul, and made
514	her feel like a fly in the web of a very strict spider.
514	""
514	She had to wash the cups every morning, and polish up the old-fashioned
514	spoons, the fat silver teapot, and the glasses till they shone.  Then
514	she must dust the room, and what a trying job that was.  Not a speck
514	escaped Aunt March's eye, and all the furniture had claw legs and much
514	carving, which was never dusted to suit.  Then Polly had to be fed, the
514	lap dog combed, and a dozen trips upstairs and down to get things or
514	deliver orders, for the old lady was very lame and seldom left her big
514	chair.  After these tiresome labors, she must do her lessons, which was
514	a daily trial of every virtue she possessed.  Then she was allowed one
514	hour for exercise or play, and didn't she enjoy it?
514	""
514	Laurie came every day, and wheedled Aunt March till Amy was allowed to
514	go out with him, when they walked and rode and had capital times.
514	After dinner, she had to read aloud, and sit still while the old lady
514	slept, which she usually did for an hour, as she dropped off over the
514	first page.  Then patchwork or towels appeared, and Amy sewed with
514	outward meekness and inward rebellion till dusk, when she was allowed
514	to amuse herself as she liked till teatime.  The evenings were the
514	worst of all, for Aunt March fell to telling long stories about her
514	youth, which were so unutterably dull that Amy was always ready to go
514	to bed, intending to cry over her hard fate, but usually going to sleep
514	before she had squeezed out more than a tear or two.
514	""
514	If it had not been for Laurie, and old Esther, the maid, she felt that
514	she never could have got through that dreadful time.  The parrot alone
514	was enough to drive her distracted, for he soon felt that she did not
514	admire him, and revenged himself by being as mischievous as possible.
514	He pulled her hair whenever she came near him, upset his bread and milk
514	to plague her when she had newly cleaned his cage, made Mop bark by
514	pecking at him while Madam dozed, called her names before company, and
514	behaved in all respects like an reprehensible old bird.  Then she could
514	not endure the dog, a fat, cross beast who snarled and yelped at her
514	when she made his toilet, and who lay on his back with all his legs in
514	the air and a most idiotic expression of countenance when he wanted
514	something to eat, which was about a dozen times a day.  The cook was
514	bad-tempered, the old coachman was deaf, and Esther the only one who
514	ever took any notice of the young lady.
514	""
514	Esther was a Frenchwoman, who had lived with 'Madame', as she called her
514	mistress, for many years, and who rather tyrannized over the old lady,
514	who could not get along without her. Her real name was Estelle, but
514	Aunt March ordered her to change it, and she obeyed, on condition that
514	she was never asked to change her religion.  She took a fancy to
514	Mademoiselle, and amused her very much with odd stories of her life in
514	France, when Amy sat with her while she got up Madame's laces.  She
514	also allowed her to roam about the great house, and examine the curious
514	and pretty things stored away in the big wardrobes and the ancient
514	chests, for Aunt March hoarded like a magpie.  Amy's chief delight was
514	an Indian cabinet, full of queer drawers, little pigeonholes, and
514	secret places, in which were kept all sorts of ornaments, some
514	precious, some merely curious, all more or less antique. To examine and
514	arrange these things gave Amy great satisfaction, especially the jewel
514	cases, in which on velvet cushions reposed the ornaments which had
514	adorned a belle forty years ago.  There was the garnet set which Aunt
514	March wore when she came out, the pearls her father gave her on her
514	wedding day, her lover's diamonds, the jet mourning rings and pins, the
514	queer lockets, with portraits of dead friends and weeping willows made
514	of hair inside, the baby bracelets her one little daughter had worn,
514	Uncle March's big watch, with the red seal so many childish hands had
514	played with, and in a box all by itself lay Aunt March's wedding ring,
514	too small now for her fat finger, but put carefully away like the most
514	precious jewel of them all.
514	""
514	"""Which would Mademoiselle choose if she had her will?"" asked Esther,"
514	who always sat near to watch over and lock up the valuables.
514	""
514	"""I like the diamonds best, but there is no necklace among them, and I'm"
514	fond of necklaces, they are so becoming.  I should choose this if I
514	"might,"" replied Amy, looking with great admiration at a string of gold"
514	and ebony beads from which hung a heavy cross of the same.
514	""
514	"""I, too, covet that, but not as a necklace.  Ah, no!  To me it is a"
514	"rosary, and as such I should use it like a good catholic,"" said Esther,"
514	eyeing the handsome thing wistfully.
514	""
514	"""Is it meant to use as you use the string of good-smelling wooden beads"
514	"hanging over your glass?"" asked Amy."
514	""
514	"""Truly, yes, to pray with.  It would be pleasing to the saints if one"
514	"used so fine a rosary as this, instead of wearing it as a vain bijou."""
514	""
514	"""You seem to take a great deal of comfort in your prayers, Esther, and"
514	"always come down looking quiet and satisfied.  I wish I could."""
514	""
514	"""If Mademoiselle was a Catholic, she would find true comfort, but as"
514	that is not to be, it would be well if you went apart each day to
514	meditate and pray, as did the good mistress whom I served before
514	Madame.  She had a little chapel, and in it found solacement for much
514	"trouble."""
514	""
514	"""Would it be right for me to do so too?"" asked Amy, who in her"
514	loneliness felt the need of help of some sort, and found that she was
514	apt to forget her little book, now that Beth was not there to remind
514	her of it.
514	""
514	"""It would be excellent and charming, and I shall gladly arrange the"
514	little dressing room for you if you like it.  Say nothing to Madame,
514	but when she sleeps go you and sit alone a while to think good
514	"thoughts, and pray the dear God preserve your sister."""
514	""
514	Esther was truly pious, and quite sincere in her advice, for she had an
514	affectionate heart, and felt much for the sisters in their anxiety.
514	Amy liked the idea, and gave her leave to arrange the light closet next
514	her room, hoping it would do her good.
514	""
514	"""I wish I knew where all these pretty things would go when Aunt March"
514	"dies,"" she said, as she slowly replaced the shining rosary and shut the"
514	jewel cases one by one.
514	""
514	"""To you and your sisters.  I know it, Madame confides in me. I"
514	"witnessed her will, and it is to be so,"" whispered Esther smiling."
514	""
514	""
514	"""How nice!  But I wish she'd let us have them now. Procrastination is"
514	"not agreeable,"" observed Amy, taking a last look at the diamonds."
514	""
514	"""It is too soon yet for the young ladies to wear these things. The"
514	first one who is affianced will have the pearls, Madame has said it,
514	and I have a fancy that the little turquoise ring will be given to you
514	when you go, for Madame approves your good behavior and charming
514	"manners."""
514	""
514	"""Do you think so?  Oh, I'll be a lamb, if I can only have that lovely"
514	ring!  It's ever so much prettier than Kitty Bryant's.  I do like Aunt
514	"March after all."" And Amy tried on the blue ring with a delighted face"
514	and a firm resolve to earn it.
514	""
514	From that day she was a model of obedience, and the old lady
514	complacently admired the success of her training.  Esther fitted up the
514	closet with a little table, placed a footstool before it, and over it a
514	picture taken from one of the shut-up rooms.  She thought it was of no
514	great value, but, being appropriate, she borrowed it, well knowing that
514	Madame would never know it, nor care if she did.  It was, however, a
514	very valuable copy of one of the famous pictures of the world, and
514	Amy's beauty-loving eyes were never tired of looking up at the sweet
514	face of the Divine Mother, while her tender thoughts of her own were
514	busy at her heart.  On the table she laid her little testament and
514	hymnbook, kept a vase always full of the best flowers Laurie brought
514	her, and came every day to 'sit alone' thinking good thoughts, and
514	praying the dear God to preserve her sister.  Esther had given her a
514	rosary of black beads with a silver cross, but Amy hung it up and did
514	not use it, feeling doubtful as to its fitness for Protestant prayers.
514	""
514	The little girl was very sincere in all this, for being left alone
514	outside the safe home nest, she felt the need of some kind hand to hold
514	by so sorely that she instinctively turned to the strong and tender
514	Friend, whose fatherly love most closely surrounds His little children.
514	She missed her mother's help to understand and rule herself, but having
514	been taught where to look, she did her best to find the way and walk in
514	it confidingly.  But, Amy was a young pilgrim, and just now her burden
514	seemed very heavy. She tried to forget herself, to keep cheerful, and
514	be satisfied with doing right, though no one saw or praised her for it.
514	In her first effort at being very, very good, she decided to make her
514	will, as Aunt March had done, so that if she did fall ill and die, her
514	possessions might be justly and generously divided.  It cost her a pang
514	even to think of giving up the little treasures which in her eyes were
514	as precious as the old lady's jewels.
514	""
514	During one of her play hours she wrote out the important document as
514	well as she could, with some help from Esther as to certain legal
514	terms, and when the good-natured Frenchwoman had signed her name, Amy
514	felt relieved and laid it by to show Laurie, whom she wanted as a
514	second witness.  As it was a rainy day, she went upstairs to amuse
514	herself in one of the large chambers, and took Polly with her for
514	company.  In this room there was a wardrobe full of old-fashioned
514	costumes with which Esther allowed her to play, and it was her favorite
514	amusement to array herself in the faded brocades, and parade up and
514	down before the long mirror, making stately curtsies, and sweeping her
514	train about with a rustle which delighted her ears.  So busy was she on
514	this day that she did not hear Laurie's ring nor see his face peeping
514	in at her as she gravely promenaded to and fro, flirting her fan and
514	tossing her head, on which she wore a great pink turban, contrasting
514	oddly with her blue brocade dress and yellow quilted petticoat.  She
514	was obliged to walk carefully, for she had on high-heeled shoes, and, as
514	Laurie told Jo afterward, it was a comical sight to see her mince along
514	in her gay suit, with Polly sidling and bridling just behind her,
514	imitating her as well as he could, and occasionally stopping to laugh
514	"or exclaim, ""Ain't we fine? Get along, you fright!  Hold your tongue!"
514	"Kiss me, dear!  Ha! Ha!"""
514	""
514	Having with difficulty restrained an explosion of merriment, lest it
514	should offend her majesty, Laurie tapped and was graciously received.
514	""
514	"""Sit down and rest while I put these things away, then I want to"
514	"consult you about a very serious matter,"" said Amy, when she had shown"
514	"her splendor and driven Polly into a corner.  ""That bird is the trial"
514	"of my life,"" she continued, removing the pink mountain from her head,"
514	while Laurie seated himself astride a chair.
514	""
514	"""Yesterday, when Aunt was asleep and I was trying to be as still as a"
514	mouse, Polly began to squall and flap about in his cage, so I went to
514	let him out, and found a big spider there.  I poked it out, and it ran
514	under the bookcase.  Polly marched straight after it, stooped down and
514	peeped under the bookcase, saying, in his funny way, with a cock of his
514	eye, 'Come out and take a walk, my dear.' I couldn't help laughing,
514	"which made Poll swear, and Aunt woke up and scolded us both."""
514	""
514	"""Did the spider accept the old fellow's invitation?"" asked Laurie,"
514	yawning.
514	""
514	"""Yes, out it came, and away ran Polly, frightened to death, and"
514	scrambled up on Aunt's chair, calling out, 'Catch her! Catch her! Catch
514	"her!' as I chased the spider."""
514	""
514	"""That's a lie!  Oh, lor!"" cried the parrot, pecking at Laurie's toes."
514	""
514	"""I'd wring your neck if you were mine, you old torment,"" cried Laurie,"
514	shaking his fist at the bird, who put his head on one side and gravely
514	"croaked, ""Allyluyer! bless your buttons, dear!"""
514	""
514	"""Now I'm ready,"" said Amy, shutting the wardrobe and taking a piece of"
514	"paper out of her pocket.  ""I want you to read that, please, and tell me"
514	if it is legal and right.  I felt I ought to do it, for life is
514	"uncertain and I don't want any ill feeling over my tomb."""
514	""
514	Laurie bit his lips, and turning a little from the pensive speaker,
514	read the following document, with praiseworthy gravity, considering the
514	spelling:
514	""
514	MY LAST WILL AND TESTIMENT
514	""
514	I, Amy Curtis March, being in my sane mind, go give and bequeethe all
514	my earthly property--viz. to wit:--namely
514	""
514	To my father, my best pictures, sketches, maps, and works of art,
514	including frames.  Also my $100, to do what he likes with.
514	""
514	To my mother, all my clothes, except the blue apron with pockets--also
514	my likeness, and my medal, with much love.
514	""
514	To my dear sister Margaret, I give my turkquoise ring (if I get it),
514	also my green box with the doves on it, also my piece of real lace for
514	her neck, and my sketch of her as a memorial of her 'little girl'.
514	""
514	To Jo I leave my breastpin, the one mended with sealing wax, also my
514	bronze inkstand--she lost the cover--and my most precious plaster
514	rabbit, because I am sorry I burned up her story.
514	""
514	To Beth (if she lives after me) I give my dolls and the little bureau,
514	my fan, my linen collars and my new slippers if she can wear them being
514	thin when she gets well.  And I herewith also leave her my regret that
514	I ever made fun of old Joanna.
514	""
514	To my friend and neighbor Theodore Laurence I bequeethe my paper mashay
514	portfolio, my clay model of a horse though he did say it hadn't any
514	neck.  Also in return for his great kindness in the hour of affliction
514	any one of my artistic works he likes, Noter Dame is the best.
514	""
514	To our venerable benefactor Mr. Laurence I leave my purple box with a
514	looking glass in the cover which will be nice for his pens and remind
514	him of the departed girl who thanks him for his favors to her family,
514	especially Beth.
514	""
514	I wish my favorite playmate Kitty Bryant to have the blue silk apron
514	and my gold-bead ring with a kiss.
514	""
514	To Hannah I give the bandbox she wanted and all the patchwork I leave
514	hoping she 'will remember me, when it you see'.
514	""
514	And now having disposed of my most valuable property I hope all will be
514	satisfied and not blame the dead.  I forgive everyone, and trust we may
514	all meet when the trump shall sound.  Amen.
514	""
514	To this will and testiment I set my hand and seal on this 20th day of
514	Nov.  Anni Domino 1861.
514	""
514	Amy Curtis March
514	""
514	Witnesses:
514	""
514	Estelle Valnor, Theodore Laurence.
514	""
514	""
514	The last name was written in pencil, and Amy explained that he was to
514	rewrite it in ink and seal it up for her properly.
514	""
514	"""What put it into your head?  Did anyone tell you about Beth's giving"
514	"away her things?"" asked Laurie soberly, as Amy laid a bit of red tape,"
514	with sealing wax, a taper, and a standish before him.
514	""
514	"She explained and then asked anxiously, ""What about Beth?"""
514	""
514	"""I'm sorry I spoke, but as I did, I'll tell you.  She felt so ill one"
514	day that she told Jo she wanted to give her piano to Meg, her cats to
514	you, and the poor old doll to Jo, who would love it for her sake.  She
514	was sorry she had so little to give, and left locks of hair to the rest
514	"of us, and her best love to Grandpa.  She never thought of a will."""
514	""
514	Laurie was signing and sealing as he spoke, and did not look up till a
514	great tear dropped on the paper.  Amy's face was full of trouble, but
514	"she only said, ""Don't people put sort of postscripts to their wills,"
514	"sometimes?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, 'codicils', they call them."""
514	""
514	"""Put one in mine then, that I wish all my curls cut off, and given"
514	round to my friends.  I forgot it, but I want it done though it will
514	"spoil my looks."""
514	""
514	Laurie added it, smiling at Amy's last and greatest sacrifice. Then he
514	amused her for an hour, and was much interested in all her trials.  But
514	when he came to go, Amy held him back to whisper with trembling lips,
514	"""Is there really any danger about Beth?"""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid there is, but we must hope for the best, so don't cry,"
514	"dear.""  And Laurie put his arm about her with a brotherly gesture which"
514	was very comforting.
514	""
514	When he had gone, she went to her little chapel, and sitting in the
514	twilight, prayed for Beth, with streaming tears and an aching heart,
514	feeling that a million turquoise rings would not console her for the
514	loss of her gentle little sister.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY
514	""
514	CONFIDENTIAL
514	""
514	I don't think I have any words in which to tell the meeting of the
514	mother and daughters.  Such hours are beautiful to live, but very hard
514	to describe, so I will leave it to the imagination of my readers,
514	merely saying that the house was full of genuine happiness, and that
514	Meg's tender hope was realized, for when Beth woke from that long,
514	healing sleep, the first objects on which her eyes fell were the little
514	rose and Mother's face.  Too weak to wonder at anything, she only
514	smiled and nestled close in the loving arms about her, feeling that the
514	hungry longing was satisfied at last.  Then she slept again, and the
514	girls waited upon their mother, for she would not unclasp the thin hand
514	which clung to hers even in sleep.
514	""
514	Hannah had 'dished up' an astonishing breakfast for the traveler,
514	finding it impossible to vent her excitement in any other way, and Meg
514	and Jo fed their mother like dutiful young storks, while they listened
514	to her whispered account of Father's state, Mr. Brooke's promise to
514	stay and nurse him, the delays which the storm occasioned on the
514	homeward journey, and the unspeakable comfort Laurie's hopeful face had
514	given her when she arrived, worn out with fatigue, anxiety, and cold.
514	""
514	What a strange yet pleasant day that was.  So brilliant and gay
514	without, for all the world seemed abroad to welcome the first snow.  So
514	quiet and reposeful within, for everyone slept, spent with watching,
514	and a Sabbath stillness reigned through the house, while nodding Hannah
514	mounted guard at the door.  With a blissful sense of burdens lifted
514	off, Meg and Jo closed their weary eyes, and lay at rest, like
514	storm-beaten boats safe at anchor in a quiet harbor.  Mrs. March would
514	not leave Beth's side, but rested in the big chair, waking often to
514	look at, touch, and brood over her child, like a miser over some
514	recovered treasure.
514	""
514	Laurie meanwhile posted off to comfort Amy, and told his story so well
514	"that Aunt March actually 'sniffed' herself, and never once said ""I told"
514	"you so"".  Amy came out so strong on this occasion that I think the good"
514	thoughts in the little chapel really began to bear fruit.  She dried
514	her tears quickly, restrained her impatience to see her mother, and
514	never even thought of the turquoise ring, when the old lady heartily
514	agreed in Laurie's opinion, that she behaved 'like a capital little
514	woman'.  Even Polly seemed impressed, for he called her a good girl,
514	"blessed her buttons, and begged her to ""come and take a walk, dear"", in"
514	his most affable tone.  She would very gladly have gone out to enjoy
514	the bright wintry weather, but discovering that Laurie was dropping
514	with sleep in spite of manful efforts to conceal the fact, she
514	persuaded him to rest on the sofa, while she wrote a note to her
514	mother.  She was a long time about it, and when she returned, he was
514	stretched out with both arms under his head, sound asleep, while Aunt
514	March had pulled down the curtains and sat doing nothing in an unusual
514	fit of benignity.
514	""
514	After a while, they began to think he was not going to wake up till
514	night, and I'm not sure that he would, had he not been effectually
514	roused by Amy's cry of joy at sight of her mother. There probably were
514	a good many happy little girls in and about the city that day, but it
514	is my private opinion that Amy was the happiest of all, when she sat in
514	her mother's lap and told her trials, receiving consolation and
514	compensation in the shape of approving smiles and fond caresses.  They
514	were alone together in the chapel, to which her mother did not object
514	when its purpose was explained to her.
514	""
514	"""On the contrary, I like it very much, dear,"" looking from the dusty"
514	rosary to the well-worn little book, and the lovely picture with its
514	"garland of evergreen.  ""It is an excellent plan to have some place"
514	where we can go to be quiet, when things vex or grieve us.  There are a
514	good many hard times in this life of ours, but we can always bear them
514	if we ask help in the right way.  I think my little girl is learning
514	"this."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, Mother, and when I go home I mean to have a corner in the big"
514	closet to put my books and the copy of that picture which I've tried to
514	make.  The woman's face is not good, it's too beautiful for me to draw,
514	but the baby is done better, and I love it very much.  I like to think
514	He was a little child once, for then I don't seem so far away, and that
514	"helps me."""
514	""
514	As Amy pointed to the smiling Christ child on his Mother's knee, Mrs.
514	March saw something on the lifted hand that made her smile.  She said
514	nothing, but Amy understood the look, and after a minute's pause, she
514	"added gravely, ""I wanted to speak to you about this, but I forgot it."
514	Aunt gave me the ring today.  She called me to her and kissed me, and
514	put it on my finger, and said I was a credit to her, and she'd like to
514	keep me always. She gave that funny guard to keep the turquoise on, as
514	"it's too big.  I'd like to wear them Mother, can I?"""
514	""
514	"""They are very pretty, but I think you're rather too young for such"
514	"ornaments, Amy,"" said Mrs. March, looking at the plump little hand,"
514	with the band of sky-blue stones on the forefinger, and the quaint
514	guard formed of two tiny golden hands clasped together.
514	""
514	"""I'll try not to be vain,"" said Amy.  ""I don't think I like it only"
514	because it's so pretty, but I want to wear it as the girl in the story
514	"wore her bracelet, to remind me of something."""
514	""
514	"""Do you mean Aunt March?"" asked her mother, laughing."
514	""
514	"""No, to remind me not to be selfish.""  Amy looked so earnest and"
514	sincere about it that her mother stopped laughing, and listened
514	respectfully to the little plan.
514	""
514	"""I've thought a great deal lately about my 'bundle of naughties', and"
514	being selfish is the largest one in it, so I'm going to try hard to
514	cure it, if I can.  Beth isn't selfish, and that's the reason everyone
514	loves her and feels so bad at the thoughts of losing her.  People
514	wouldn't feel so bad about me if I was sick, and I don't deserve to
514	have them, but I'd like to be loved and missed by a great many friends,
514	so I'm going to try and be like Beth all I can.  I'm apt to forget my
514	resolutions, but if I had something always about me to remind me, I
514	"guess I should do better.  May we try this way?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, but I have more faith in the corner of the big closet. Wear your"
514	ring, dear, and do your best.  I think you will prosper, for the
514	sincere wish to be good is half the battle.  Now I must go back to
514	Beth.  Keep up your heart, little daughter, and we will soon have you
514	"home again."""
514	""
514	That evening while Meg was writing to her father to report the
514	traveler's safe arrival, Jo slipped upstairs into Beth's room, and
514	finding her mother in her usual place, stood a minute twisting her
514	fingers in her hair, with a worried gesture and an undecided look.
514	""
514	"""What is it, deary?"" asked Mrs. March, holding out her hand, with a"
514	face which invited confidence.
514	""
514	"""I want to tell you something, Mother."""
514	""
514	"""About Meg?"""
514	""
514	"""How quickly you guessed!  Yes, it's about her, and though it's a"
514	"little thing, it fidgets me."""
514	""
514	"""Beth is asleep.  Speak low, and tell me all about it.  That Moffat"
514	"hasn't been here, I hope?"" asked Mrs. March rather sharply."
514	""
514	"""No.  I should have shut the door in his face if he had,"" said Jo,"
514	"settling herself on the floor at her mother's feet.  ""Last summer Meg"
514	left a pair of gloves over at the Laurences' and only one was returned.
514	We forgot about it, till Teddy told me that Mr. Brooke owned that he
514	liked Meg but didn't dare say so, she was so young and he so poor.
514	"Now, isn't it a dreadful state of things?"""
514	""
514	"""Do you think Meg cares for him?"" asked Mrs. March, with an anxious"
514	look.
514	""
514	"""Mercy me!  I don't know anything about love and such nonsense!"" cried"
514	"Jo, with a funny mixture of interest and contempt. ""In novels, the"
514	girls show it by starting and blushing, fainting away, growing thin,
514	and acting like fools.  Now Meg does not do anything of the sort.  She
514	eats and drinks and sleeps like a sensible creature, she looks straight
514	in my face when I talk about that man, and only blushes a little bit
514	when Teddy jokes about lovers.  I forbid him to do it, but he doesn't
514	"mind me as he ought."""
514	""
514	"""Then you fancy that Meg is not interested in John?"""
514	""
514	"""Who?"" cried Jo, staring."
514	""
514	"""Mr. Brooke.  I call him 'John' now.  We fell into the way of doing so"
514	"at the hospital, and he likes it."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear!  I know you'll take his part.  He's been good to Father, and"
514	you won't send him away, but let Meg marry him, if she wants to.  Mean
514	thing!  To go petting Papa and helping you, just to wheedle you into
514	"liking him."" And Jo pulled her hair again with a wrathful tweak."
514	""
514	"""My dear, don't get angry about it, and I will tell you how it"
514	happened.  John went with me at Mr. Laurence's request, and was so
514	devoted to poor Father that we couldn't help getting fond of him.  He
514	was perfectly open and honorable about Meg, for he told us he loved
514	her, but would earn a comfortable home before he asked her to marry
514	him.  He only wanted our leave to love her and work for her, and the
514	right to make her love him if he could. He is a truly excellent young
514	man, and we could not refuse to listen to him, but I will not consent
514	"to Meg's engaging herself so young."""
514	""
514	"""Of course not.  It would be idiotic!  I knew there was mischief"
514	brewing.  I felt it, and now it's worse than I imagined. I just wish I
514	"could marry Meg myself, and keep her safe in the family."""
514	""
514	"This odd arrangement made Mrs. March smile, but she said gravely, ""Jo,"
514	I confide in you and don't wish you to say anything to Meg yet.  When
514	John comes back, and I see them together, I can judge better of her
514	"feelings toward him."""
514	""
514	"""She'll see those handsome eyes that she talks about, and then it will"
514	be all up with her.  She's got such a soft heart, it will melt like
514	butter in the sun if anyone looks sentimentlly at her.  She read the
514	short reports he sent more than she did your letters, and pinched me
514	when I spoke of it, and likes brown eyes, and doesn't think John an
514	ugly name, and she'll go and fall in love, and there's an end of peace
514	and fun, and cozy times together. I see it all!  They'll go lovering
514	around the house, and we shall have to dodge.  Meg will be absorbed and
514	no good to me any more. Brooke will scratch up a fortune somehow, carry
514	her off, and make a hole in the family, and I shall break my heart, and
514	everything will be abominably uncomfortable.  Oh, dear me!  Why weren't
514	"we all boys, then there wouldn't be any bother."""
514	""
514	Jo leaned her chin on her knees in a disconsolate attitude and shook
514	her fist at the reprehensible John.  Mrs. March sighed, and Jo looked
514	up with an air of relief.
514	""
514	"""You don't like it, Mother?  I'm glad of it.  Let's send him about his"
514	business, and not tell Meg a word of it, but all be happy together as
514	"we always have been."""
514	""
514	"""I did wrong to sigh, Jo.  It is natural and right you should all go to"
514	homes of your own in time, but I do want to keep my girls as long as I
514	can, and I am sorry that this happened so soon, for Meg is only
514	seventeen and it will be some years before John can make a home for
514	her.  Your father and I have agreed that she shall not bind herself in
514	any way, nor be married, before twenty.  If she and John love one
514	another, they can wait, and test the love by doing so.  She is
514	conscientious, and I have no fear of her treating him unkindly.  My
514	"pretty, tender hearted girl!  I hope things will go happily with her."""
514	""
514	"""Hadn't you rather have her marry a rich man?"" asked Jo, as her"
514	mother's voice faltered a little over the last words.
514	""
514	"""Money is a good and useful thing, Jo, and I hope my girls will never"
514	feel the need of it too bitterly, nor be tempted by too much.  I should
514	like to know that John was firmly established in some good business,
514	which gave him an income large enough to keep free from debt and make
514	Meg comfortable.  I'm not ambitious for a splendid fortune, a
514	fashionable position, or a great name for my girls.  If rank and money
514	come with love and virtue, also, I should accept them gratefully, and
514	enjoy your good fortune, but I know, by experience, how much genuine
514	happiness can be had in a plain little house, where the daily bread is
514	earned, and some privations give sweetness to the few pleasures.  I am
514	content to see Meg begin humbly, for if I am not mistaken, she will be
514	rich in the possession of a good man's heart, and that is better than a
514	"fortune."""
514	""
514	"""I understand, Mother, and quite agree, but I'm disappointed about Meg,"
514	for I'd planned to have her marry Teddy by-and-by and sit in the lap of
514	"luxury all her days.  Wouldn't it be nice?"" asked Jo, looking up with a"
514	brighter face.
514	""
514	"""He is younger than she, you know,"" began Mrs. March, but Jo broke in..."
514	""
514	"""Only a little, he's old for his age, and tall, and can be quite"
514	grown-up in his manners if he likes.  Then he's rich and generous and
514	"good, and loves us all, and I say it's a pity my plan is spoiled."""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid Laurie is hardly grown-up enough for Meg, and altogether"
514	too much of a weathercock just now for anyone to depend on.  Don't make
514	plans, Jo, but let time and their own hearts mate your friends.  We
514	can't meddle safely in such matters, and had better not get 'romantic
514	"rubbish' as you call it, into our heads, lest it spoil our friendship."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I won't, but I hate to see things going all crisscross and"
514	getting snarled up, when a pull here and a snip there would straighten
514	it out.  I wish wearing flatirons on our heads would keep us from
514	"growing up.  But buds will be roses, and kittens cats, more's the pity!"""
514	""
514	"""What's that about flatirons and cats?"" asked Meg, as she crept into"
514	the room with the finished letter in her hand.
514	""
514	"""Only one of my stupid speeches.  I'm going to bed.  Come, Peggy,"" said"
514	Jo, unfolding herself like an animated puzzle.
514	""
514	"""Quite right, and beautifully written.  Please add that I send my love"
514	"to John,"" said Mrs. March, as she glanced over the letter and gave it"
514	back.
514	""
514	"""Do you call him 'John'?"" asked Meg, smiling, with her innocent eyes"
514	looking down into her mother's.
514	""
514	"""Yes, he has been like a son to us, and we are very fond of him,"""
514	replied Mrs. March, returning the look with a keen one.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of that, he is so lonely.  Good night, Mother, dear.  It is"
514	"so inexpressibly comfortable to have you here,"" was Meg's answer."
514	""
514	The kiss her mother gave her was a very tender one, and as she went
514	"away, Mrs. March said, with a mixture of satisfaction and regret, ""She"
514	"does not love John yet, but will soon learn to."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE
514	""
514	LAURIE MAKES MISCHIEF, AND JO MAKES PEACE
514	""
514	Jo's face was a study next day, for the secret rather weighed upon her,
514	and she found it hard not to look mysterious and important.  Meg
514	observed it, but did not trouble herself to make inquiries, for she had
514	learned that the best way to manage Jo was by the law of contraries, so
514	she felt sure of being told everything if she did not ask.  She was
514	rather surprised, therefore, when the silence remained unbroken, and Jo
514	assumed a patronizing air, which decidedly aggravated Meg, who in turn
514	assumed an air of dignified reserve and devoted herself to her mother.
514	This left Jo to her own devices, for Mrs. March had taken her place as
514	nurse, and bade her rest, exercise, and amuse herself after her long
514	confinement.  Amy being gone, Laurie was her only refuge, and much as
514	she enjoyed his society, she rather dreaded him just then, for he was
514	an incorrigible tease, and she feared he would coax the secret from her.
514	""
514	She was quite right, for the mischief-loving lad no sooner suspected a
514	mystery than he set himself to find it out, and led Jo a trying life of
514	it.  He wheedled, bribed, ridiculed, threatened, and scolded; affected
514	indifference, that he might surprise the truth from her; declared he
514	knew, then that he didn't care; and at last, by dint of perseverance,
514	he satisfied himself that it concerned Meg and Mr. Brooke.  Feeling
514	indignant that he was not taken into his tutor's confidence, he set his
514	wits to work to devise some proper retaliation for the slight.
514	""
514	Meg meanwhile had apparently forgotten the matter and was absorbed in
514	preparations for her father's return, but all of a sudden a change
514	seemed to come over her, and, for a day or two, she was quite unlike
514	herself.  She started when spoken to, blushed when looked at, was very
514	quiet, and sat over her sewing, with a timid, troubled look on her
514	face.  To her mother's inquiries she answered that she was quite well,
514	and Jo's she silenced by begging to be let alone.
514	""
514	"""She feels it in the air--love, I mean--and she's going very fast."
514	She's got most of the symptoms--is twittery and cross, doesn't eat,
514	lies awake, and mopes in corners.  I caught her singing that song he
514	gave her, and once she said 'John', as you do, and then turned as red
514	"as a poppy.  Whatever shall we do?"" said Jo, looking ready for any"
514	measures, however violent.
514	""
514	"""Nothing but wait.  Let her alone, be kind and patient, and Father's"
514	"coming will settle everything,"" replied her mother."
514	""
514	"""Here's a note to you, Meg, all sealed up.  How odd! Teddy never seals"
514	"mine,"" said Jo next day, as she distributed the contents of the little"
514	post office.
514	""
514	Mrs. March and Jo were deep in their own affairs, when a sound from Meg
514	made them look up to see her staring at her note with a frightened face.
514	""
514	"""My child, what is it?"" cried her mother, running to her, while Jo"
514	tried to take the paper which had done the mischief.
514	""
514	"""It's all a mistake, he didn't send it.  Oh, Jo, how could you do it?"""
514	and Meg hid her face in her hands, crying as if her heart were quite
514	broken.
514	""
514	"""Me!  I've done nothing!  What's she talking about?"" cried Jo,"
514	bewildered.
514	""
514	Meg's mild eyes kindled with anger as she pulled a crumpled note from
514	"her pocket and threw it at Jo, saying reproachfully, ""You wrote it, and"
514	that bad boy helped you.  How could you be so rude, so mean, and cruel
514	"to us both?"""
514	""
514	Jo hardly heard her, for she and her mother were reading the note,
514	which was written in a peculiar hand.
514	""
514	""
514	"""My Dearest Margaret,"
514	""
514	"""I can no longer restrain my passion, and must know my fate before I"
514	return.  I dare not tell your parents yet, but I think they would
514	consent if they knew that we adored one another.  Mr. Laurence will
514	help me to some good place, and then, my sweet girl, you will make me
514	happy.  I implore you to say nothing to your family yet, but to send
514	one word of hope through Laurie to,
514	""
514	"""Your devoted John."""
514	""
514	""
514	"""Oh, the little villain!  That's the way he meant to pay me for keeping"
514	my word to Mother.  I'll give him a hearty scolding and bring him over
514	"to beg pardon,"" cried Jo, burning to execute immediate justice.  But"
514	her mother held her back, saying, with a look she seldom wore...
514	""
514	"""Stop, Jo, you must clear yourself first.  You have played so many"
514	"pranks that I am afraid you have had a hand in this."""
514	""
514	"""On my word, Mother, I haven't!  I never saw that note before, and"
514	"don't know anything about it, as true as I live!"" said Jo, so earnestly"
514	"that they believed her.  ""If I had taken part in it I'd have done it"
514	better than this, and have written a sensible note.  I should think
514	"you'd have known Mr. Brooke wouldn't write such stuff as that,"" she"
514	added, scornfully tossing down the paper.
514	""
514	"""It's like his writing,"" faltered Meg, comparing it with the note in"
514	her hand.
514	""
514	"""Oh, Meg, you didn't answer it?"" cried Mrs. March quickly."
514	""
514	"""Yes, I did!"" and Meg hid her face again, overcome with shame."
514	""
514	"""Here's a scrape!  Do let me bring that wicked boy over to explain and"
514	"be lectured.  I can't rest till I get hold of him."" And Jo made for the"
514	door again.
514	""
514	"""Hush!  Let me handle this, for it is worse than I thought. Margaret,"
514	"tell me the whole story,"" commanded Mrs. March, sitting down by Meg,"
514	yet keeping hold of Jo, lest she should fly off.
514	""
514	"""I received the first letter from Laurie, who didn't look as if he knew"
514	"anything about it,"" began Meg, without looking up. ""I was worried at"
514	first and meant to tell you, then I remembered how you liked Mr.
514	Brooke, so I thought you wouldn't mind if I kept my little secret for a
514	few days.  I'm so silly that I liked to think no one knew, and while I
514	was deciding what to say, I felt like the girls in books, who have such
514	things to do.  Forgive me, Mother, I'm paid for my silliness now.  I
514	"never can look him in the face again."""
514	""
514	"""What did you say to him?"" asked Mrs. March."
514	""
514	"""I only said I was too young to do anything about it yet, that I didn't"
514	wish to have secrets from you, and he must speak to father.  I was very
514	grateful for his kindness, and would be his friend, but nothing more,
514	"for a long while."""
514	""
514	Mrs. March smiled, as if well pleased, and Jo clapped her hands,
514	"exclaiming, with a laugh, ""You are almost equal to Caroline Percy, who"
514	"was a pattern of prudence!  Tell on, Meg. What did he say to that?"""
514	""
514	"""He writes in a different way entirely, telling me that he never sent"
514	any love letter at all, and is very sorry that my roguish sister, Jo,
514	should take liberties with our names.  It's very kind and respectful,
514	"but think how dreadful for me!"""
514	""
514	Meg leaned against her mother, looking the image of despair, and Jo
514	tramped about the room, calling Laurie names.  All of a sudden she
514	stopped, caught up the two notes, and after looking at them closely,
514	"said decidedly, ""I don't believe Brooke ever saw either of these"
514	letters.  Teddy wrote both, and keeps yours to crow over me with
514	"because I wouldn't tell him my secret."""
514	""
514	"""Don't have any secrets, Jo.  Tell it to Mother and keep out of"
514	"trouble, as I should have done,"" said Meg warningly."
514	""
514	"""Bless you, child!  Mother told me."""
514	""
514	"""That will do, Jo.  I'll comfort Meg while you go and get Laurie.  I"
514	shall sift the matter to the bottom, and put a stop to such pranks at
514	"once."""
514	""
514	Away ran Jo, and Mrs. March gently told Meg Mr. Brooke's real feelings.
514	"""Now, dear, what are your own?  Do you love him enough to wait till he"
514	can make a home for you, or will you keep yourself quite free for the
514	"present?"""
514	""
514	"""I've been so scared and worried, I don't want to have anything to do"
514	"with lovers for a long while, perhaps never,"" answered Meg petulantly."
514	"""If John doesn't know anything about this nonsense, don't tell him, and"
514	make Jo and Laurie hold their tongues.  I won't be deceived and plagued
514	"and made a fool of. It's a shame!"""
514	""
514	Seeing Meg's usually gentle temper was roused and her pride hurt by
514	this mischievous joke, Mrs. March soothed her by promises of entire
514	silence and great discretion for the future.  The instant Laurie's step
514	was heard in the hall, Meg fled into the study, and Mrs. March received
514	the culprit alone. Jo had not told him why he was wanted, fearing he
514	wouldn't come, but he knew the minute he saw Mrs. March's face, and
514	stood twirling his hat with a guilty air which convicted him at once.
514	Jo was dismissed, but chose to march up and down the hall like a
514	sentinel, having some fear that the prisoner might bolt.  The sound of
514	voices in the parlor rose and fell for half an hour, but what happened
514	during that interview the girls never knew.
514	""
514	When they were called in, Laurie was standing by their mother with such
514	a penitent face that Jo forgave him on the spot, but did not think it
514	wise to betray the fact.  Meg received his humble apology, and was much
514	comforted by the assurance that Brooke knew nothing of the joke.
514	""
514	"""I'll never tell him to my dying day, wild horses shan't drag it out of"
514	me, so you'll forgive me, Meg, and I'll do anything to show how
514	"out-and-out sorry I am,"" he added, looking very much ashamed of himself."
514	""
514	"""I'll try, but it was a very ungentlemanly thing to do, I didn't think"
514	"you could be so sly and malicious, Laurie,"" replied Meg, trying to hide"
514	her maidenly confusion under a gravely reproachful air.
514	""
514	"""It was altogether abominable, and I don't deserve to be spoken to for"
514	"a month, but you will, though, won't you?"" And Laurie folded his hands"
514	together with such and imploring gesture, as he spoke in his
514	irresistibly persuasive tone, that it was impossible to frown upon him
514	in spite of his scandalous behavior.
514	""
514	Meg pardoned him, and Mrs. March's grave face relaxed, in spite of her
514	efforts to keep sober, when she heard him declare that he would atone
514	for his sins by all sorts of penances, and abase himself like a worm
514	before the injured damsel.
514	""
514	Jo stood aloof, meanwhile, trying to harden her heart against him, and
514	succeeding only in primming up her face into an expression of entire
514	disapprobation.  Laurie looked at her once or twice, but as she showed
514	no sign of relenting, he felt injured, and turned his back on her till
514	the others were done with him, when he made her a low bow and walked
514	off without a word.
514	""
514	As soon as he had gone, she wished she had been more forgiving, and
514	when Meg and her mother went upstairs, she felt lonely and longed for
514	Teddy.  After resisting for some time, she yielded to the impulse, and
514	armed with a book to return, went over to the big house.
514	""
514	"""Is Mr. Laurence in?"" asked Jo, of a housemaid, who was coming"
514	downstairs.
514	""
514	"""Yes, Miss, but I don't believe he's seeable just yet."""
514	""
514	"""Why not?  Is he ill?"""
514	""
514	"""La, no Miss, but he's had a scene with Mr. Laurie, who is in one of"
514	his tantrums about something, which vexes the old gentleman, so I
514	"dursn't go nigh him."""
514	""
514	"""Where is Laurie?"""
514	""
514	"""Shut up in his room, and he won't answer, though I've been a-tapping."
514	I don't know what's to become of the dinner, for it's ready, and
514	"there's no one to eat it."""
514	""
514	"""I'll go and see what the matter is.  I'm not afraid of either of them."""
514	""
514	Up went Jo, and knocked smartly on the door of Laurie's little study.
514	""
514	"""Stop that, or I'll open the door and make you!"" called out the young"
514	gentleman in a threatening tone.
514	""
514	Jo immediately knocked again.  The door flew open, and in she bounced
514	before Laurie could recover from his surprise.  Seeing that he really
514	was out of temper, Jo, who knew how to manage him, assumed a contrite
514	expression, and going artistically down upon her knees, said meekly,
514	"""Please forgive me for being so cross.  I came to make it up, and can't"
514	"go away till I have."""
514	""
514	"""It's all right.  Get up, and don't be a goose, Jo,"" was the cavalier"
514	reply to her petition.
514	""
514	"""Thank you, I will.  Could I ask what's the matter?  You don't look"
514	"exactly easy in your mind."""
514	""
514	"""I've been shaken, and I won't bear it!"" growled Laurie indignantly."
514	""
514	"""Who did it?"" demanded Jo."
514	""
514	"""Grandfather.  If it had been anyone else I'd have..."" And the injured"
514	youth finished his sentence by an energetic gesture of the right arm.
514	""
514	"""That's nothing.  I often shake you, and you don't mind,"" said Jo"
514	soothingly.
514	""
514	"""Pooh!  You're a girl, and it's fun, but I'll allow no man to shake me!"""
514	""
514	"""I don't think anyone would care to try it, if you looked as much like"
514	"a thundercloud as you do now.  Why were you treated so?"""
514	""
514	"""Just because I wouldn't say what your mother wanted me for. I'd"
514	"promised not to tell, and of course I wasn't going to break my word."""
514	""
514	"""Couldn't you satisfy your grandpa in any other way?"""
514	""
514	"""No, he would have the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the"
514	truth.  I'd have told my part of the scrape, if I could without
514	bringing Meg in.  As I couldn't, I held my tongue, and bore the
514	scolding till the old gentleman collared me.  Then I bolted, for fear I
514	"should forget myself."""
514	""
514	"""It wasn't nice, but he's sorry, I know, so go down and make up.  I'll"
514	"help you."""
514	""
514	"""Hanged if I do!  I'm not going to be lectured and pummelled by"
514	everyone, just for a bit of a frolic.  I was sorry about Meg, and
514	begged pardon like a man, but I won't do it again, when I wasn't in the
514	"wrong."""
514	""
514	"""He didn't know that."""
514	""
514	"""He ought to trust me, and not act as if I was a baby.  It's no use,"
514	Jo, he's got to learn that I'm able to take care of myself, and don't
514	"need anyone's apron string to hold on by."""
514	""
514	"""What pepper pots you are!"" sighed Jo.  ""How do you mean to settle this"
514	"affair?"""
514	""
514	"""Well, he ought to beg pardon, and believe me when I say I can't tell"
514	"him what the fuss's about."""
514	""
514	"""Bless you!  He won't do that."""
514	""
514	"""I won't go down till he does."""
514	""
514	"""Now, Teddy, be sensible.  Let it pass, and I'll explain what I can."
514	"You can't stay here, so what's the use of being melodramatic?"""
514	""
514	"""I don't intend to stay here long, anyway.  I'll slip off and take a"
514	journey somewhere, and when Grandpa misses me he'll come round fast
514	"enough."""
514	""
514	"""I dare say, but you ought not to go and worry him."""
514	""
514	"""Don't preach.  I'll go to Washington and see Brooke.  It's gay there,"
514	"and I'll enjoy myself after the troubles."""
514	""
514	"""What fun you'd have!  I wish I could run off too,"" said Jo, forgetting"
514	her part of mentor in lively visions of martial life at the capital.
514	""
514	"""Come on, then!  Why not?  You go and surprise your father, and I'll"
514	stir up old Brooke.  It would be a glorious joke.  Let's do it, Jo.
514	We'll leave a letter saying we are all right, and trot off at once.
514	I've got money enough.  It will do you good, and no harm, as you go to
514	"your father."""
514	""
514	For a moment Jo looked as if she would agree, for wild as the plan was,
514	it just suited her.  She was tired of care and confinement, longed for
514	change, and thoughts of her father blended temptingly with the novel
514	charms of camps and hospitals, liberty and fun.  Her eyes kindled as
514	they turned wistfully toward the window, but they fell on the old house
514	opposite, and she shook her head with sorrowful decision.
514	""
514	"""If I was a boy, we'd run away together, and have a capital time, but"
514	as I'm a miserable girl, I must be proper and stop at home. Don't tempt
514	"me, Teddy, it's a crazy plan."""
514	""
514	"""That's the fun of it,"" began Laurie, who had got a willful fit on him"
514	and was possessed to break out of bounds in some way.
514	""
514	"""Hold your tongue!"" cried Jo, covering her ears.  ""'Prunes and prisms'"
514	are my doom, and I may as well make up my mind to it.  I came here to
514	"moralize, not to hear things that make me skip to think of."""
514	""
514	"""I know Meg would wet-blanket such a proposal, but I thought you had"
514	"more spirit,"" began Laurie insinuatingly."
514	""
514	"""Bad boy, be quiet!  Sit down and think of your own sins, don't go"
514	making me add to mine.  If I get your grandpa to apologize for the
514	"shaking, will you give up running away?"" asked Jo seriously."
514	""
514	"""Yes, but you won't do it,"" answered Laurie, who wished to make up, but"
514	felt that his outraged dignity must be appeased first.
514	""
514	"""If I can manage the young one, I can the old one,"" muttered Jo, as she"
514	walked away, leaving Laurie bent over a railroad map with his head
514	propped up on both hands.
514	""
514	"""Come in!"" and Mr. Laurence's gruff voice sounded gruffer than ever, as"
514	Jo tapped at his door.
514	""
514	"""It's only me, Sir, come to return a book,"" she said blandly, as she"
514	entered.
514	""
514	"""Want any more?"" asked the old gentleman, looking grim and vexed, but"
514	trying not to show it.
514	""
514	"""Yes, please.  I like old Sam so well, I think I'll try the second"
514	"volume,"" returned Jo, hoping to propitiate him by accepting a second"
514	dose of Boswell's Johnson, as he had recommended that lively work.
514	""
514	The shaggy eyebrows unbent a little as he rolled the steps toward the
514	shelf where the Johnsonian literature was placed.  Jo skipped up, and
514	sitting on the top step, affected to be searching for her book, but was
514	really wondering how best to introduce the dangerous object of her
514	visit.  Mr. Laurence seemed to suspect that something was brewing in
514	her mind, for after taking several brisk turns about the room, he faced
514	round on her, speaking so abruptly that Rasselas tumbled face downward
514	on the floor.
514	""
514	"""What has that boy been about?  Don't try to shield him.  I know he has"
514	been in mischief by the way he acted when he came home.  I can't get a
514	word from him, and when I threatened to shake the truth out of him he
514	"bolted upstairs and locked himself into his room."""
514	""
514	"""He did wrong, but we forgave him, and all promised not to say a word"
514	"to anyone,"" began Jo reluctantly."
514	""
514	"""That won't do.  He shall not shelter himself behind a promise from you"
514	softhearted girls.  If he's done anything amiss, he shall confess, beg
514	"pardon, and be punished.  Out with it, Jo. I won't be kept in the dark."""
514	""
514	Mr. Laurence looked so alarming and spoke so sharply that Jo would have
514	gladly run away, if she could, but she was perched aloft on the steps,
514	and he stood at the foot, a lion in the path, so she had to stay and
514	brave it out.
514	""
514	"""Indeed, Sir, I cannot tell.  Mother forbade it.  Laurie has confessed,"
514	asked pardon, and been punished quite enough.  We don't keep silence to
514	shield him, but someone else, and it will make more trouble if you
514	interfere.  Please don't.  It was partly my fault, but it's all right
514	now.  So let's forget it, and talk about the _Rambler_ or something
514	"pleasant."""
514	""
514	"""Hang the _Rambler!_  Come down and give me your word that this"
514	harum-scarum boy of mine hasn't done anything ungrateful or
514	impertinent.  If he has, after all your kindness to him, I'll thrash
514	"him with my own hands."""
514	""
514	The threat sounded awful, but did not alarm Jo, for she knew the
514	irascible old gentleman would never lift a finger against his grandson,
514	whatever he might say to the contrary.  She obediently descended, and
514	made as light of the prank as she could without betraying Meg or
514	forgetting the truth.
514	""
514	"""Hum... ha... well, if the boy held his tongue because he promised, and"
514	not from obstinacy, I'll forgive him. He's a stubborn fellow and hard
514	"to manage,"" said Mr. Laurence, rubbing up his hair till it looked as if"
514	he had been out in a gale, and smoothing the frown from his brow with
514	an air of relief.
514	""
514	"""So am I, but a kind word will govern me when all the king's horses and"
514	"all the king's men couldn't,"" said Jo, trying to say a kind word for"
514	her friend, who seemed to get out of one scrape only to fall into
514	another.
514	""
514	"""You think I'm not kind to him, hey?"" was the sharp answer."
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear no, Sir.  You are rather too kind sometimes, and then just a"
514	"trifle hasty when he tries your patience.  Don't you think you are?"""
514	""
514	Jo was determined to have it out now, and tried to look quite placid,
514	though she quaked a little after her bold speech. To her great relief
514	and surprise, the old gentleman only threw his spectacles onto the
514	"table with a rattle and exclaimed frankly, ""You're right, girl, I am!"
514	I love the boy, but he tries my patience past bearing, and I know how
514	"it will end, if we go on so."""
514	""
514	"""I'll tell you, he'll run away."" Jo was sorry for that speech the"
514	minute it was made.  She meant to warn him that Laurie would not bear
514	much restraint, and hoped he would be more forebearing with the lad.
514	""
514	Mr. Laurence's ruddy face changed suddenly, and he sat down, with a
514	troubled glance at the picture of a handsome man, which hung over his
514	table.  It was Laurie's father, who had run away in his youth, and
514	married against the imperious old man's will. Jo fancied he remembered
514	and regretted the past, and she wished she had held her tongue.
514	""
514	"""He won't do it unless he is very much worried, and only threatens it"
514	sometimes, when he gets tired of studying.  I often think I should like
514	to, especially since my hair was cut, so if you ever miss us, you may
514	"advertise for two boys and look among the ships bound for India."""
514	""
514	She laughed as she spoke, and Mr. Laurence looked relieved, evidently
514	taking the whole as a joke.
514	""
514	"""You hussy, how dare you talk in that way?  Where's your respect for"
514	me, and your proper bringing up?  Bless the boys and girls!  What
514	"torments they are, yet we can't do without them,"" he said, pinching her"
514	"cheeks good-humoredly.  ""Go and bring that boy down to his dinner, tell"
514	him it's all right, and advise him not to put on tragedy airs with his
514	"grandfather.  I won't bear it."""
514	""
514	"""He won't come, Sir.  He feels badly because you didn't believe him"
514	when he said he couldn't tell.  I think the shaking hurt his feelings
514	"very much."""
514	""
514	Jo tried to look pathetic but must have failed, for Mr. Laurence began
514	to laugh, and she knew the day was won.
514	""
514	"""I'm sorry for that, and ought to thank him for not shaking me, I"
514	"suppose.  What the dickens does the fellow expect?"" and the old"
514	gentleman looked a trifle ashamed of his own testiness.
514	""
514	"""If I were you, I'd write him an apology, Sir.  He says he won't come"
514	down till he has one, and talks about Washington, and goes on in an
514	absurd way.  A formal apology will make him see how foolish he is, and
514	bring him down quite amiable.  Try it.  He likes fun, and this way is
514	"better than talking.  I'll carry it up, and teach him his duty."""
514	""
514	Mr. Laurence gave her a sharp look, and put on his spectacles, saying
514	"slowly, ""You're a sly puss, but I don't mind being managed by you and"
514	Beth.  Here, give me a bit of paper, and let us have done with this
514	"nonsense."""
514	""
514	The note was written in the terms which one gentleman would use to
514	another after offering some deep insult.  Jo dropped a kiss on the top
514	of Mr. Laurence's bald head, and ran up to slip the apology under
514	Laurie's door, advising him through the keyhole to be submissive,
514	decorous, and a few other agreeable impossibilities. Finding the door
514	locked again, she left the note to do its work, and was going quietly
514	away, when the young gentleman slid down the banisters, and waited for
514	her at the bottom, saying, with his most virtuous expression of
514	"countenance, ""What a good fellow you are, Jo! Did you get blown up?"" he"
514	added, laughing.
514	""
514	"""No, he was pretty mild, on the whole."""
514	""
514	"""Ah!  I got it all round.  Even you cast me off over there, and I felt"
514	"just ready to go to the deuce,"" he began apologetically."
514	""
514	"""Don't talk that way, turn over a new leaf and begin again, Teddy, my"
514	"son."""
514	""
514	"""I keep turning over new leaves, and spoiling them, as I used to spoil"
514	my copybooks, and I make so many beginnings there never will be an
514	"end,"" he said dolefully."
514	""
514	"""Go and eat your dinner, you'll feel better after it.  Men always croak"
514	"when they are hungry,"" and Jo whisked out at the front door after that."
514	""
514	"""That's a 'label' on my 'sect',"" answered Laurie, quoting Amy, as he"
514	went to partake of humble pie dutifully with his grandfather, who was
514	quite saintly in temper and overwhelmingly respectful in manner all the
514	rest of the day.
514	""
514	Everyone thought the matter ended and the little cloud blown over, but
514	the mischief was done, for though others forgot it, Meg remembered.
514	She never alluded to a certain person, but she thought of him a good
514	deal, dreamed dreams more than ever, and once Jo, rummaging her
514	sister's desk for stamps, found a bit of paper scribbled over with the
514	words, 'Mrs. John Brooke', whereat she groaned tragically and cast it
514	into the fire, feeling that Laurie's prank had hastened the evil day
514	for her.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO
514	""
514	PLEASANT MEADOWS
514	""
514	Like sunshine after a storm were the peaceful weeks which followed.
514	The invalids improved rapidly, and Mr. March began to talk of returning
514	early in the new year.  Beth was soon able to lie on the study sofa all
514	day, amusing herself with the well-beloved cats at first, and in time
514	with doll's sewing, which had fallen sadly behind-hand.  Her once
514	active limbs were so stiff and feeble that Jo took her for a daily
514	airing about the house in her strong arms.  Meg cheerfully blackened
514	and burned her white hands cooking delicate messes for 'the dear',
514	while Amy, a loyal slave of the ring, celebrated her return by giving
514	away as many of her treasures as she could prevail on her sisters to
514	accept.
514	""
514	As Christmas approached, the usual mysteries began to haunt the house,
514	and Jo frequently convulsed the family by proposing utterly impossible
514	or magnificently absurd ceremonies, in honor of this unusually merry
514	Christmas.  Laurie was equally impracticable, and would have had
514	bonfires, skyrockets, and triumphal arches, if he had had his own way.
514	After many skirmishes and snubbings, the ambitious pair were considered
514	effectually quenched and went about with forlorn faces, which were
514	rather belied by explosions of laughter when the two got together.
514	""
514	Several days of unusually mild weather fitly ushered in a splendid
514	Christmas Day.  Hannah 'felt in her bones' that it was going to be an
514	unusually fine day, and she proved herself a true prophetess, for
514	everybody and everything seemed bound to produce a grand success.  To
514	begin with, Mr. March wrote that he should soon be with them, then Beth
514	felt uncommonly well that morning, and, being dressed in her mother's
514	gift, a soft crimson merino wrapper, was borne in high triumph to the
514	window to behold the offering of Jo and Laurie.  The Unquenchables had
514	done their best to be worthy of the name, for like elves they had
514	worked by night and conjured up a comical surprise.  Out in the garden
514	stood a stately snow maiden, crowned with holly, bearing a basket of
514	fruit and flowers in one hand, a great roll of music in the other, a
514	perfect rainbow of an Afghan round her chilly shoulders, and a
514	Christmas carol issuing from her lips on a pink paper streamer.
514	""
514	    THE JUNGFRAU TO BETH
514	""
514	    God bless you, dear Queen Bess!
514	    May nothing you dismay,
514	    But health and peace and happiness
514	    Be yours, this Christmas day.
514	""
514	    Here's fruit to feed our busy bee,
514	    And flowers for her nose.
514	    Here's music for her pianee,
514	    An afghan for her toes,
514	""
514	    A portrait of Joanna, see,
514	    By Raphael No. 2,
514	    Who laboured with great industry
514	    To make it fair and true.
514	""
514	    Accept a ribbon red, I beg,
514	    For Madam Purrer's tail,
514	    And ice cream made by lovely Peg,
514	    A Mont Blanc in a pail.
514	""
514	    Their dearest love my makers laid
514	    Within my breast of snow.
514	    Accept it, and the Alpine maid,
514	    From Laurie and from Jo.
514	""
514	How Beth laughed when she saw it, how Laurie ran up and down to bring
514	in the gifts, and what ridiculous speeches Jo made as she presented
514	them.
514	""
514	"""I'm so full of happiness, that if Father was only here, I couldn't"
514	"hold one drop more,"" said Beth, quite sighing with contentment as Jo"
514	carried her off to the study to rest after the excitement, and to
514	refresh herself with some of the delicious grapes the 'Jungfrau' had
514	sent her.
514	""
514	"""So am I,"" added Jo, slapping the pocket wherein reposed the"
514	long-desired _Undine and Sintram_.
514	""
514	"""I'm sure I am,"" echoed Amy, poring over the engraved copy of the"
514	Madonna and Child, which her mother had given her in a pretty frame.
514	""
514	"""Of course I am!"" cried Meg, smoothing the silvery folds of her first"
514	"silk dress, for Mr. Laurence had insisted on giving it. ""How can I be"
514	"otherwise?"" said Mrs. March gratefully, as her eyes went from her"
514	husband's letter to Beth's smiling face, and her hand caressed the
514	brooch made of gray and golden, chestnut and dark brown hair, which the
514	girls had just fastened on her breast.
514	""
514	Now and then, in this workaday world, things do happen in the
514	delightful storybook fashion, and what a comfort it is.  Half an hour
514	after everyone had said they were so happy they could only hold one
514	drop more, the drop came.  Laurie opened the parlor door and popped his
514	head in very quietly.  He might just as well have turned a somersault
514	and uttered an Indian war whoop, for his face was so full of suppressed
514	excitement and his voice so treacherously joyful that everyone jumped
514	"up, though he only said, in a queer, breathless voice, ""Here's another"
514	"Christmas present for the March family."""
514	""
514	Before the words were well out of his mouth, he was whisked away
514	somehow, and in his place appeared a tall man, muffled up to the eyes,
514	leaning on the arm of another tall man, who tried to say something and
514	couldn't.  Of course there was a general stampede, and for several
514	minutes everybody seemed to lose their wits, for the strangest things
514	were done, and no one said a word.
514	""
514	Mr. March became invisible in the embrace of four pairs of loving arms.
514	Jo disgraced herself by nearly fainting away, and had to be doctored by
514	Laurie in the china closet.  Mr. Brooke kissed Meg entirely by mistake,
514	as he somewhat incoherently explained.  And Amy, the dignified, tumbled
514	over a stool, and never stopping to get up, hugged and cried over her
514	father's boots in the most touching manner.  Mrs. March was the first
514	"to recover herself, and held up her hand with a warning, ""Hush!"
514	"Remember Beth."""
514	""
514	But it was too late.  The study door flew open, the little red wrapper
514	appeared on the threshold, joy put strength into the feeble limbs, and
514	Beth ran straight into her father's arms.  Never mind what happened
514	just after that, for the full hearts overflowed, washing away the
514	bitterness of the past and leaving only the sweetness of the present.
514	""
514	It was not at all romantic, but a hearty laugh set everybody straight
514	again, for Hannah was discovered behind the door, sobbing over the fat
514	turkey, which she had forgotten to put down when she rushed up from the
514	kitchen.  As the laugh subsided, Mrs. March began to thank Mr. Brooke
514	for his faithful care of her husband, at which Mr. Brooke suddenly
514	remembered that Mr. March needed rest, and seizing Laurie, he
514	precipitately retired.  Then the two invalids were ordered to repose,
514	which they did, by both sitting in one big chair and talking hard.
514	""
514	Mr. March told how he had longed to surprise them, and how, when the
514	fine weather came, he had been allowed by his doctor to take advantage
514	of it, how devoted Brooke had been, and how he was altogether a most
514	estimable and upright young man.  Why Mr. March paused a minute just
514	there, and after a glance at Meg, who was violently poking the fire,
514	looked at his wife with an inquiring lift of the eyebrows, I leave you
514	to imagine.  Also why Mrs. March gently nodded her head and asked,
514	rather abruptly, if he wouldn't like to have something to eat.  Jo saw
514	and understood the look, and she stalked grimly away to get wine and
514	"beef tea, muttering to herself as she slammed the door, ""I hate"
514	"estimable young men with brown eyes!"""
514	""
514	There never was such a Christmas dinner as they had that day. The fat
514	turkey was a sight to behold, when Hannah sent him up, stuffed,
514	browned, and decorated.  So was the plum pudding, which melted in one's
514	mouth, likewise the jellies, in which Amy reveled like a fly in a
514	honeypot.  Everything turned out well, which was a mercy, Hannah said,
514	"""For my mind was that flustered, Mum, that it's a merrycle I didn't"
514	roast the pudding, and stuff the turkey with raisins, let alone bilin'
514	"of it in a cloth."""
514	""
514	Mr. Laurence and his grandson dined with them, also Mr. Brooke, at whom
514	Jo glowered darkly, to Laurie's infinite amusement. Two easy chairs
514	stood side by side at the head of the table, in which sat Beth and her
514	father, feasting modestly on chicken and a little fruit.  They drank
514	healths, told stories, sang songs, 'reminisced', as the old folks say,
514	and had a thoroughly good time. A sleigh ride had been planned, but the
514	girls would not leave their father, so the guests departed early, and
514	as twilight gathered, the happy family sat together round the fire.
514	""
514	"""Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected"
514	"to have.  Do you remember?"" asked Jo, breaking a short pause which had"
514	followed a long conversation about many things.
514	""
514	"""Rather a pleasant year on the whole!"" said Meg, smiling at the fire,"
514	and congratulating herself on having treated Mr. Brooke with dignity.
514	""
514	"""I think it's been a pretty hard one,"" observed Amy, watching the light"
514	shine on her ring with thoughtful eyes.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad it's over, because we've got you back,"" whispered Beth, who"
514	sat on her father's knee.
514	""
514	"""Rather a rough road for you to travel, my little pilgrims, especially"
514	the latter part of it.  But you have got on bravely, and I think the
514	"burdens are in a fair way to tumble off very soon,"" said Mr. March,"
514	looking with fatherly satisfaction at the four young faces gathered
514	round him.
514	""
514	"""How do you know?  Did Mother tell you?"" asked Jo."
514	""
514	"""Not much.  Straws show which way the wind blows, and I've made several"
514	"discoveries today."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, tell us what they are!"" cried Meg, who sat beside him."
514	""
514	"""Here is one."" And taking up the hand which lay on the arm of his"
514	chair, he pointed to the roughened forefinger, a burn on the back, and
514	"two or three little hard spots on the palm.  ""I remember a time when"
514	this hand was white and smooth, and your first care was to keep it so.
514	It was very pretty then, but to me it is much prettier now, for in this
514	seeming blemishes I read a little history.  A burnt offering has been
514	made to vanity, this hardened palm has earned something better than
514	blisters, and I'm sure the sewing done by these pricked fingers will
514	last a long time, so much good will went into the stitches.  Meg, my
514	dear, I value the womanly skill which keeps home happy more than white
514	hands or fashionable accomplishments.  I'm proud to shake this good,
514	industrious little hand, and hope I shall not soon be asked to give it
514	"away."""
514	""
514	If Meg had wanted a reward for hours of patient labor, she received it
514	in the hearty pressure of her father's hand and the approving smile he
514	gave her.
514	""
514	"""What about Jo?  Please say something nice, for she has tried so hard"
514	"and been so very, very good to me,"" said Beth in her father's ear."
514	""
514	He laughed and looked across at the tall girl who sat opposite, with an
514	unusually mild expression in her face.
514	""
514	"""In spite of the curly crop, I don't see the 'son Jo' whom I left a"
514	"year ago,"" said Mr. March.  ""I see a young lady who pins her collar"
514	straight, laces her boots neatly, and neither whistles, talks slang,
514	nor lies on the rug as she used to do.  Her face is rather thin and
514	pale just now, with watching and anxiety, but I like to look at it, for
514	it has grown gentler, and her voice is lower.  She doesn't bounce, but
514	moves quietly, and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly
514	way which delights me.  I rather miss my wild girl, but if I get a
514	strong, helpful, tenderhearted woman in her place, I shall feel quite
514	satisfied. I don't know whether the shearing sobered our black sheep,
514	but I do know that in all Washington I couldn't find anything beautiful
514	enough to be bought with the five-and-twenty dollars my good girl sent
514	"me."""
514	""
514	Jo's keen eyes were rather dim for a minute, and her thin face grew
514	rosy in the firelight as she received her father's praise, feeling that
514	she did deserve a portion of it.
514	""
514	"""Now, Beth,"" said Amy, longing for her turn, but ready to wait."
514	""
514	"""There's so little of her, I'm afraid to say much, for fear she will"
514	"slip away altogether, though she is not so shy as she used to be,"""
