514	began their father cheerfully.  But recollecting how nearly he had lost
514	her, he held her close, saying tenderly, with her cheek against his
514	"own, ""I've got you safe, my Beth, and I'll keep you so, please God."""
514	""
514	After a minute's silence, he looked down at Amy, who sat on the cricket
514	at his feet, and said, with a caress of the shining hair...
514	""
514	"""I observed that Amy took drumsticks at dinner, ran errands for her"
514	mother all the afternoon, gave Meg her place tonight, and has waited on
514	every one with patience and good humor.  I also observe that she does
514	not fret much nor look in the glass, and has not even mentioned a very
514	pretty ring which she wears, so I conclude that she has learned to
514	think of other people more and of herself less, and has decided to try
514	and mold her character as carefully as she molds her little clay
514	figures.  I am glad of this, for though I should be very proud of a
514	graceful statue made by her, I shall be infinitely prouder of a lovable
514	"daughter with a talent for making life beautiful to herself and others."""
514	""
514	"""What are you thinking of, Beth?"" asked Jo, when Amy had thanked her"
514	father and told about her ring.
514	""
514	"""I read in _Pilgrim's Progress_ today how, after many troubles,"
514	Christian and Hopeful came to a pleasant green meadow where lilies
514	bloomed all year round, and there they rested happily, as we do now,
514	"before they went on to their journey's end,"" answered Beth, adding, as"
514	"she slipped out of her father's arms and went to the instrument, ""It's"
514	singing time now, and I want to be in my old place.  I'll try to sing
514	the song of the shepherd boy which the Pilgrims heard.  I made the
514	"music for Father, because he likes the verses."""
514	""
514	So, sitting at the dear little piano, Beth softly touched the keys, and
514	in the sweet voice they had never thought to hear again, sang to her
514	own accompaniment the quaint hymn, which was a singularly fitting song
514	for her.
514	""
514	""
514	    He that is down need fear no fall,
514	    He that is low no pride.
514	    He that is humble ever shall
514	    Have God to be his guide.
514	""
514	    I am content with what I have,
514	    Little be it, or much.
514	    And, Lord!  Contentment still I crave,
514	    Because Thou savest such.
514	""
514	    Fulness to them a burden is,
514	    That go on pilgrimage.
514	    Here little, and hereafter bliss,
514	    Is best from age to age!
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE
514	""
514	AUNT MARCH SETTLES THE QUESTION
514	""
514	Like bees swarming after their queen, mother and daughters hovered
514	about Mr. March the next day, neglecting everything to look at, wait
514	upon, and listen to the new invalid, who was in a fair way to be killed
514	by kindness.  As he sat propped up in a big chair by Beth's sofa, with
514	the other three close by, and Hannah popping in her head now and then
514	'to peek at the dear man', nothing seemed needed to complete their
514	happiness.  But something was needed, and the elder ones felt it,
514	though none confessed the fact.  Mr. and Mrs. March looked at one
514	another with an anxious expression, as their eyes followed Meg.  Jo had
514	sudden fits of sobriety, and was seen to shake her fist at Mr. Brooke's
514	umbrella, which had been left in the hall.  Meg was absent-minded, shy,
514	and silent, started when the bell rang, and colored when John's name
514	"was mentioned.  Amy said, ""Everyone seemed waiting for something, and"
514	"couldn't settle down, which was queer, since Father was safe at home,"""
514	and Beth innocently wondered why their neighbors didn't run over as
514	usual.
514	""
514	Laurie went by in the afternoon, and seeing Meg at the window, seemed
514	suddenly possessed with a melodramatic fit, for he fell down on one
514	knee in the snow, beat his breast, tore his hair, and clasped his hands
514	imploringly, as if begging some boon. And when Meg told him to behave
514	himself and go away, he wrung imaginary tears out of his handkerchief,
514	and staggered round the corner as if in utter despair.
514	""
514	"""What does the goose mean?"" said Meg, laughing and trying to look"
514	unconscious.
514	""
514	"""He's showing you how your John will go on by-and-by. Touching, isn't"
514	"it?"" answered Jo scornfully."
514	""
514	"""Don't say my John, it isn't proper or true,"" but Meg's voice lingered"
514	"over the words as if they sounded pleasant to her.  ""Please don't"
514	plague me, Jo, I've told you I don't care much about him, and there
514	isn't to be anything said, but we are all to be friendly, and go on as
514	"before."""
514	""
514	"""We can't, for something has been said, and Laurie's mischief has"
514	spoiled you for me.  I see it, and so does Mother.  You are not like
514	your old self a bit, and seem ever so far away from me.  I don't mean
514	to plague you and will bear it like a man, but I do wish it was all
514	settled.  I hate to wait, so if you mean ever to do it, make haste and
514	"have it over quickly,"" said Jo pettishly."
514	""
514	"""I can't say anything till he speaks, and he won't, because Father said"
514	"I was too young,"" began Meg, bending over her work with a queer little"
514	smile, which suggested that she did not quite agree with her father on
514	that point.
514	""
514	"""If he did speak, you wouldn't know what to say, but would cry or"
514	blush, or let him have his own way, instead of giving a good, decided
514	"no."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not so silly and weak as you think.  I know just what I should"
514	say, for I've planned it all, so I needn't be taken unawares.  There's
514	"no knowing what may happen, and I wished to be prepared."""
514	""
514	Jo couldn't help smiling at the important air which Meg had
514	unconsciously assumed and which was as becoming as the pretty color
514	varying in her cheeks.
514	""
514	"""Would you mind telling me what you'd say?"" asked Jo more respectfully."
514	""
514	"""Not at all.  You are sixteen now, quite old enough to be my confidant,"
514	and my experience will be useful to you by-and-by, perhaps, in your own
514	"affairs of this sort."""
514	""
514	"""Don't mean to have any.  It's fun to watch other people philander, but"
514	"I should feel like a fool doing it myself,"" said Jo, looking alarmed at"
514	the thought.
514	""
514	"""I think not, if you liked anyone very much, and he liked you.""  Meg"
514	spoke as if to herself, and glanced out at the lane where she had often
514	seen lovers walking together in the summer twilight.
514	""
514	"""I thought you were going to tell your speech to that man,"" said Jo,"
514	rudely shortening her sister's little reverie.
514	""
514	"""Oh, I should merely say, quite calmly and decidedly, 'Thank you, Mr."
514	Brooke, you are very kind, but I agree with Father that I am too young
514	to enter into any engagement at present, so please say no more, but let
514	"us be friends as we were.'"""
514	""
514	"""Hum, that's stiff and cool enough!  I don't believe you'll ever say"
514	it, and I know he won't be satisfied if you do.  If he goes on like the
514	rejected lovers in books, you'll give in, rather than hurt his
514	"feelings."""
514	""
514	"""No, I won't.  I shall tell him I've made up my mind, and shall walk"
514	"out of the room with dignity."""
514	""
514	Meg rose as she spoke, and was just going to rehearse the dignified
514	exit, when a step in the hall made her fly into her seat and begin to
514	sew as fast as if her life depended on finishing that particular seam
514	in a given time.  Jo smothered a laugh at the sudden change, and when
514	someone gave a modest tap, opened the door with a grim aspect which was
514	anything but hospitable.
514	""
514	"""Good afternoon.  I came to get my umbrella, that is, to see how your"
514	"father finds himself today,"" said Mr. Brooke, getting a trifle confused"
514	as his eyes went from one telltale face to the other.
514	""
514	"""It's very well, he's in the rack.  I'll get him, and tell it you are"
514	"here.""  And having jumbled her father and the umbrella well together in"
514	her reply, Jo slipped out of the room to give Meg a chance to make her
514	speech and air her dignity.  But the instant she vanished, Meg began to
514	sidle toward the door, murmuring...
514	""
514	"""Mother will like to see you.  Pray sit down, I'll call her."""
514	""
514	"""Don't go.  Are you afraid of me, Margaret?"" and Mr. Brooke looked so"
514	hurt that Meg thought she must have done something very rude.  She
514	blushed up to the little curls on her forehead, for he had never called
514	her Margaret before, and she was surprised to find how natural and
514	sweet it seemed to hear him say it.  Anxious to appear friendly and at
514	her ease, she put out her hand with a confiding gesture, and said
514	gratefully...
514	""
514	"""How can I be afraid when you have been so kind to Father? I only wish"
514	"I could thank you for it."""
514	""
514	"""Shall I tell you how?"" asked Mr. Brooke, holding the small hand fast"
514	in both his own, and looking down at Meg with so much love in the brown
514	eyes that her heart began to flutter, and she both longed to run away
514	and to stop and listen.
514	""
514	"""Oh no, please don't, I'd rather not,"" she said, trying to withdraw her"
514	hand, and looking frightened in spite of her denial.
514	""
514	"""I won't trouble you.  I only want to know if you care for me a little,"
514	"Meg.  I love you so much, dear,"" added Mr. Brooke tenderly."
514	""
514	This was the moment for the calm, proper speech, but Meg didn't make
514	"it.  She forgot every word of it, hung her head, and answered, ""I don't"
514	"know,"" so softly that John had to stoop down to catch the foolish"
514	little reply.
514	""
514	He seemed to think it was worth the trouble, for he smiled to himself
514	as if quite satisfied, pressed the plump hand gratefully, and said in
514	"his most persuasive tone, ""Will you try and find out?  I want to know"
514	so much, for I can't go to work with any heart until I learn whether I
514	"am to have my reward in the end or not."""
514	""
514	"""I'm too young,"" faltered Meg, wondering why she was so fluttered, yet"
514	rather enjoying it.
514	""
514	"""I'll wait, and in the meantime, you could be learning to like me."
514	"Would it be a very hard lesson, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""Not if I chose to learn it, but. . ."""
514	""
514	"""Please choose to learn, Meg.  I love to teach, and this is easier than"
514	"German,"" broke in John, getting possession of the other hand, so that"
514	she had no way of hiding her face as he bent to look into it.
514	""
514	His tone was properly beseeching, but stealing a shy look at him, Meg
514	saw that his eyes were merry as well as tender, and that he wore the
514	satisfied smile of one who had no doubt of his success.  This nettled
514	her.  Annie Moffat's foolish lessons in coquetry came into her mind,
514	and the love of power, which sleeps in the bosoms of the best of little
514	women, woke up all of a sudden and took possession of her.  She felt
514	excited and strange, and not knowing what else to do, followed a
514	"capricious impulse, and, withdrawing her hands, said petulantly, ""I"
514	"don't choose.  Please go away and let me be!"""
514	""
514	Poor Mr. Brooke looked as if his lovely castle in the air was tumbling
514	about his ears, for he had never seen Meg in such a mood before, and it
514	rather bewildered him.
514	""
514	"""Do you really mean that?"" he asked anxiously, following her as she"
514	walked away.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I do.  I don't want to be worried about such things. Father says"
514	"I needn't, it's too soon and I'd rather not."""
514	""
514	"""Mayn't I hope you'll change your mind by-and-by?  I'll wait and say"
514	nothing till you have had more time.  Don't play with me, Meg.  I
514	"didn't think that of you."""
514	""
514	"""Don't think of me at all.  I'd rather you wouldn't,"" said Meg, taking"
514	a naughty satisfaction in trying her lover's patience and her own power.
514	""
514	He was grave and pale now, and looked decidedly more like the novel
514	heroes whom she admired, but he neither slapped his forehead nor
514	tramped about the room as they did.  He just stood looking at her so
514	wistfully, so tenderly, that she found her heart relenting in spite of
514	herself.  What would have happened next I cannot say, if Aunt March had
514	not come hobbling in at this interesting minute.
514	""
514	The old lady couldn't resist her longing to see her nephew, for she had
514	met Laurie as she took her airing, and hearing of Mr. March's arrival,
514	drove straight out to see him.  The family were all busy in the back
514	part of the house, and she had made her way quietly in, hoping to
514	surprise them.  She did surprise two of them so much that Meg started
514	as if she had seen a ghost, and Mr. Brooke vanished into the study.
514	""
514	"""Bless me, what's all this?"" cried the old lady with a rap of her cane"
514	as she glanced from the pale young gentleman to the scarlet young lady.
514	""
514	"""It's Father's friend.  I'm so surprised to see you!"" stammered Meg,"
514	feeling that she was in for a lecture now.
514	""
514	"""That's evident,"" returned Aunt March, sitting down.  ""But what is"
514	Father's friend saying to make you look like a peony? There's mischief
514	"going on, and I insist upon knowing what it is,"" with another rap."
514	""
514	"""We were only talking.  Mr. Brooke came for his umbrella,"" began Meg,"
514	wishing that Mr. Brooke and the umbrella were safely out of the house.
514	""
514	"""Brooke?  That boy's tutor?  Ah! I understand now.  I know all about"
514	it.  Jo blundered into a wrong message in one of your Father's letters,
514	"and I made her tell me.  You haven't gone and accepted him, child?"""
514	cried Aunt March, looking scandalized.
514	""
514	"""Hush! He'll hear.  Shan't I call Mother?"" said Meg, much troubled."
514	""
514	"""Not yet.  I've something to say to you, and I must free my mind at"
514	once.  Tell me, do you mean to marry this Cook?  If you do, not one
514	penny of my money ever goes to you.  Remember that, and be a sensible
514	"girl,"" said the old lady impressively."
514	""
514	Now Aunt March possessed in perfection the art of rousing the spirit of
514	opposition in the gentlest people, and enjoyed doing it.  The best of
514	us have a spice of perversity in us, especially when we are young and
514	in love.  If Aunt March had begged Meg to accept John Brooke, she would
514	probably have declared she couldn't think of it, but as she was
514	preemptorily ordered not to like him, she immediately made up her mind
514	that she would.  Inclination as well as perversity made the decision
514	easy, and being already much excited, Meg opposed the old lady with
514	unusual spirit.
514	""
514	"""I shall marry whom I please, Aunt March, and you can leave your money"
514	"to anyone you like,"" she said, nodding her head with a resolute air."
514	""
514	"""Highty-tighty!  Is that the way you take my advice, Miss? You'll be"
514	sorry for it by-and-by, when you've tried love in a cottage and found
514	"it a failure."""
514	""
514	"""It can't be a worse one than some people find in big houses,"" retorted"
514	Meg.
514	""
514	Aunt March put on her glasses and took a look at the girl, for she did
514	not know her in this new mood.  Meg hardly knew herself, she felt so
514	brave and independent, so glad to defend John and assert her right to
514	love him, if she liked.  Aunt March saw that she had begun wrong, and
514	after a little pause, made a fresh start, saying as mildly as she
514	"could, ""Now, Meg, my dear, be reasonable and take my advice.  I mean it"
514	kindly, and don't want you to spoil your whole life by making a mistake
514	at the beginning.  You ought to marry well and help your family.  It's
514	"your duty to make a rich match and it ought to be impressed upon you."""
514	""
514	"""Father and Mother don't think so.  They like John though he is poor."""
514	""
514	"""Your parents, my dear, have no more worldly wisdom than a pair of"
514	"babies."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of it,"" cried Meg stoutly."
514	""
514	"Aunt March took no notice, but went on with her lecture. ""This Rook is"
514	"poor and hasn't got any rich relations, has he?"""
514	""
514	"""No, but he has many warm friends."""
514	""
514	"""You can't live on friends, try it and see how cool they'll grow.  He"
514	"hasn't any business, has he?"""
514	""
514	"""Not yet.  Mr. Laurence is going to help him."""
514	""
514	"""That won't last long.  James Laurence is a crotchety old fellow and"
514	not to be depended on.  So you intend to marry a man without money,
514	position, or business, and go on working harder than you do now, when
514	you might be comfortable all your days by minding me and doing better?
514	"I thought you had more sense, Meg."""
514	""
514	"""I couldn't do better if I waited half my life!  John is good and wise,"
514	he's got heaps of talent, he's willing to work and sure to get on, he's
514	so energetic and brave.  Everyone likes and respects him, and I'm proud
514	"to think he cares for me, though I'm so poor and young and silly,"" said"
514	Meg, looking prettier than ever in her earnestness.
514	""
514	"""He knows you have got rich relations, child.  That's the secret of his"
514	"liking, I suspect."""
514	""
514	"""Aunt March, how dare you say such a thing?  John is above such"
514	"meanness, and I won't listen to you a minute if you talk so,"" cried Meg"
514	indignantly, forgetting everything but the injustice of the old lady's
514	"suspicions.  ""My John wouldn't marry for money, any more than I would."
514	We are willing to work and we mean to wait.  I'm not afraid of being
514	poor, for I've been happy so far, and I know I shall be with him
514	"because he loves me, and I..."""
514	""
514	Meg stopped there, remembering all of a sudden that she hadn't made up
514	her mind, that she had told 'her John' to go away, and that he might be
514	overhearing her inconsistent remarks.
514	""
514	Aunt March was very angry, for she had set her heart on having her
514	pretty niece make a fine match, and something in the girl's happy young
514	face made the lonely old woman feel both sad and sour.
514	""
514	"""Well, I wash my hands of the whole affair!  You are a willful child,"
514	and you've lost more than you know by this piece of folly. No, I won't
514	stop.  I'm disappointed in you, and haven't spirits to see your father
514	now.  Don't expect anything from me when you are married.  Your Mr.
514	"Brooke's friends must take care of you.  I'm done with you forever."""
514	""
514	And slamming the door in Meg's face, Aunt March drove off in high
514	dudgeon.  She seemed to take all the girl's courage with her, for when
514	left alone, Meg stood for a moment, undecided whether to laugh or cry.
514	Before she could make up her mind, she was taken possession of by Mr.
514	"Brooke, who said all in one breath, ""I couldn't help hearing, Meg."
514	Thank you for defending me, and Aunt March for proving that you do care
514	"for me a little bit."""
514	""
514	"""I didn't know how much till she abused you,"" began Meg."
514	""
514	"""And I needn't go away, but may stay and be happy, may I, dear?"""
514	""
514	Here was another fine chance to make the crushing speech and the
514	stately exit, but Meg never thought of doing either, and disgraced
514	"herself forever in Jo's eyes by meekly whispering, ""Yes,  John,"" and"
514	hiding her face on Mr. Brooke's waistcoat.
514	""
514	Fifteen minutes after Aunt March's departure, Jo came softly
514	downstairs, paused an instant at the parlor door, and hearing no sound
514	within, nodded and smiled with a satisfied expression, saying to
514	"herself, ""She has seen him away as we planned, and that affair is"
514	"settled.  I'll go and hear the fun, and have a good laugh over it."""
514	""
514	But poor Jo never got her laugh, for she was transfixed upon the
514	threshold by a spectacle which held her there, staring with her mouth
514	nearly as wide open as her eyes.  Going in to exult over a fallen enemy
514	and to praise a strong-minded sister for the banishment of an
514	objectionable lover, it certainly was a shock to behold the aforesaid
514	enemy serenely sitting on the sofa, with the strongminded sister
514	enthroned upon his knee and wearing an expression of the most abject
514	submission.  Jo gave a sort of gasp, as if a cold shower bath had
514	suddenly fallen upon her, for such an unexpected turning of the tables
514	actually took her breath away.  At the odd sound the lovers turned and
514	saw her.  Meg jumped up, looking both proud and shy, but 'that man', as
514	Jo called him, actually laughed and said coolly, as he kissed the
514	"astonished newcomer, ""Sister Jo, congratulate us!"""
514	""
514	That was adding insult to injury, it was altogether too much, and
514	making some wild demonstration with her hands, Jo vanished without a
514	word.  Rushing upstairs, she startled the invalids by exclaiming
514	"tragically as she burst into the room, ""Oh, do somebody go down quick!"
514	"John Brooke is acting dreadfully, and Meg likes it!"""
514	""
514	Mr. and Mrs. March left the room with speed, and casting herself upon
514	the bed, Jo cried and scolded tempestuously as she told the awful news
514	to Beth and Amy.  The little girls, however, considered it a most
514	agreeable and interesting event, and Jo got little comfort from them,
514	so she went up to her refuge in the garret, and confided her troubles
514	to the rats.
514	""
514	Nobody ever knew what went on in the parlor that afternoon, but a great
514	deal of talking was done, and quiet Mr. Brooke astonished his friends
514	by the eloquence and spirit with which he pleaded his suit, told his
514	plans, and persuaded them to arrange everything just as he wanted it.
514	""
514	The tea bell rang before he had finished describing the paradise which
514	he meant to earn for Meg, and he proudly took her in to supper, both
514	looking so happy that Jo hadn't the heart to be jealous or dismal. Amy
514	was very much impressed by John's devotion and Meg's dignity, Beth
514	beamed at them from a distance, while Mr. and Mrs. March surveyed the
514	young couple with such tender satisfaction that it was perfectly
514	evident Aunt March was right in calling them as 'unworldly as a pair of
514	babies'.  No one ate much, but everyone looked very happy, and the old
514	room seemed to brighten up amazingly when the first romance of the
514	family began there.
514	""
514	"""You can't say nothing pleasant ever happens now, can you, Meg?"" said"
514	Amy, trying to decide how she would group the lovers in a sketch she
514	was planning to make.
514	""
514	"""No, I'm sure I can't.  How much has happened since I said that! It"
514	"seems a year ago,"" answered Meg, who was in a blissful dream lifted far"
514	above such common things as bread and butter.
514	""
514	"""The joys come close upon the sorrows this time, and I rather think the"
514	"changes have begun,"" said Mrs. March.  ""In most families there comes,"
514	now and then, a year full of events.  This has been such a one, but it
514	"ends well, after all."""
514	""
514	"""Hope the next will end better,"" muttered Jo, who found it very hard to"
514	see Meg absorbed in a stranger before her face, for Jo loved a few
514	persons very dearly and dreaded to have their affection lost or
514	lessened in any way.
514	""
514	"""I hope the third year from this will end better.  I mean it shall, if"
514	"I live to work out my plans,"" said Mr. Brooke, smiling at Meg, as if"
514	everything had become possible to him now.
514	""
514	"""Doesn't it seem very long to wait?"" asked Amy, who was in a hurry for"
514	the wedding.
514	""
514	"""I've got so much to learn before I shall be ready, it seems a short"
514	"time to me,"" answered Meg, with a sweet gravity in her face never seen"
514	there before.
514	""
514	"""You have only to wait, I am to do the work,"" said John beginning his"
514	labors by picking up Meg's napkin, with an expression which caused Jo
514	to shake her head, and then say to herself with an air of relief as the
514	"front door banged, ""Here comes Laurie.  Now we shall have some sensible"
514	"conversation."""
514	""
514	But Jo was mistaken, for Laurie came prancing in, overflowing with good
514	spirits, bearing a great bridal-looking bouquet for 'Mrs. John Brooke',
514	and evidently laboring under the delusion that the whole affair had
514	been brought about by his excellent management.
514	""
514	"""I knew Brooke would have it all his own way, he always does, for when"
514	he makes up his mind to accomplish anything, it's done though the sky
514	"falls,"" said Laurie, when he had presented his offering and his"
514	congratulations.
514	""
514	"""Much obliged for that recommendation.  I take it as a good omen for"
514	"the future and invite you to my wedding on the spot,"" answered Mr."
514	Brooke, who felt at peace with all mankind, even his mischievous pupil.
514	""
514	"""I'll come if I'm at the ends of the earth, for the sight of Jo's face"
514	alone on that occasion would be worth a long journey. You don't look
514	"festive, ma'am, what's the matter?"" asked Laurie, following her into a"
514	corner of the parlor, whither all had adjourned to greet Mr. Laurence.
514	""
514	"""I don't approve of the match, but I've made up my mind to bear it, and"
514	"shall not say a word against it,"" said Jo solemnly.  ""You can't know"
514	"how hard it is for me to give up Meg,"" she continued with a little"
514	quiver in her voice.
514	""
514	"""You don't give her up.  You only go halves,"" said Laurie consolingly."
514	""
514	"""It can never be the same again.  I've lost my dearest friend,"" sighed"
514	Jo.
514	""
514	"""You've got me, anyhow.  I'm not good for much, I know, but I'll stand"
514	"by you, Jo, all the days of my life.  Upon my word I will!"" and Laurie"
514	meant what he said.
514	""
514	"""I know you will, and I'm ever so much obliged.  You are always a great"
514	"comfort to me, Teddy,"" returned Jo, gratefully shaking hands."
514	""
514	"""Well, now, don't be dismal, there's a good fellow.  It's all right you"
514	see.  Meg is happy, Brooke will fly round and get settled immediately,
514	Grandpa will attend to him, and it will be very jolly to see Meg in her
514	own little house.  We'll have capital times after she is gone, for I
514	shall be through college before long, and then we'll go abroad on some
514	"nice trip or other.  Wouldn't that console you?"""
514	""
514	"""I rather think it would, but there's no knowing what may happen in"
514	"three years,"" said Jo thoughtfully."
514	""
514	"""That's true.  Don't you wish you could take a look forward and see"
514	"where we shall all be then?  I do,"" returned Laurie."
514	""
514	"""I think not, for I might see something sad, and everyone looks so"
514	"happy now, I don't believe they could be much improved."" And Jo's eyes"
514	went slowly round the room, brightening as they looked, for the
514	prospect was a pleasant one.
514	""
514	Father and Mother sat together, quietly reliving the first chapter of
514	the romance which for them began some twenty years ago. Amy was drawing
514	the lovers, who sat apart in a beautiful world of their own, the light
514	of which touched their faces with a grace the little artist could not
514	copy.  Beth lay on her sofa, talking cheerily with her old friend, who
514	held her little hand as if he felt that it possessed the power to lead
514	him along the peaceful way she walked. Jo lounged in her favorite low
514	seat, with the grave quiet look which best became her, and Laurie,
514	leaning on the back of her chair, his chin on a level with her curly
514	head, smiled with his friendliest aspect, and nodded at her in the long
514	glass which reflected them both.
514	""
514	""
514	So the curtain falls upon Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy.  Whether it ever
514	rises again, depends upon the reception given the first act of the
514	domestic drama called _Little Women_.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	LITTLE WOMEN PART 2
514	""
514	In order that we may start afresh and go to Meg's wedding...
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR
514	""
514	GOSSIP
514	""
514	In order that we may start afresh and go to Meg's wedding with free
514	minds, it will be well to begin with a little gossip about the Marches.
514	And here let me premise that if any of the elders think there is too
514	much 'lovering' in the story, as I fear they may (I'm not afraid the
514	young folks will make that objection), I can only say with Mrs. March,
514	"""What can you expect when I have four gay girls in the house, and a"
514	"dashing young neighbor over the way?"""
514	""
514	The three years that have passed have brought but few changes to the
514	quiet family.  The war is over, and Mr. March safely at home, busy with
514	his books and the small parish which found in him a minister by nature
514	as by grace, a quiet, studious man, rich in the wisdom that is better
514	than learning, the charity which calls all mankind 'brother', the piety
514	that blossoms into character, making it august and lovely.
514	""
514	These attributes, in spite of poverty and the strict integrity which
514	shut him out from the more worldly successes, attracted to him many
514	admirable persons, as naturally as sweet herbs draw bees, and as
514	naturally he gave them the honey into which fifty years of hard
514	experience had distilled no bitter drop.  Earnest young men found the
514	gray-headed scholar as young at heart as they; thoughtful or troubled
514	women instinctively brought their doubts to him, sure of finding the
514	gentlest sympathy, the wisest counsel.  Sinners told their sins to the
514	pure-hearted old man and were both rebuked and saved.  Gifted men found
514	a companion in him.  Ambitious men caught glimpses of nobler ambitions
514	than their own, and even worldlings confessed that his beliefs were
514	beautiful and true, although 'they wouldn't pay'.
514	""
514	To outsiders the five energetic women seemed to rule the house, and so
514	they did in many things, but the quiet scholar, sitting among his
514	books, was still the head of the family, the household conscience,
514	anchor, and comforter, for to him the busy, anxious women always turned
514	in troublous times, finding him, in the truest sense of those sacred
514	words, husband and father.
514	""
514	The girls gave their hearts into their mother's keeping, their souls
514	into their father's, and to both parents, who lived and labored so
514	faithfully for them, they gave a love that grew with their growth and
514	bound them tenderly together by the sweetest tie which blesses life and
514	outlives death.
514	""
514	Mrs. March is as brisk and cheery, though rather grayer, than when we
514	saw her last, and just now so absorbed in Meg's affairs that the
514	hospitals and homes still full of wounded 'boys' and soldiers' widows,
514	decidedly miss the motherly missionary's visits.
514	""
514	John Brooke did his duty manfully for a year, got wounded, was sent
514	home, and not allowed to return.  He received no stars or bars, but he
514	deserved them, for he cheerfully risked all he had, and life and love
514	are very precious when both are in full bloom.  Perfectly resigned to
514	his discharge, he devoted himself to getting well, preparing for
514	business, and earning a home for Meg.  With the good sense and sturdy
514	independence that characterized him, he refused Mr. Laurence's more
514	generous offers, and accepted the place of bookkeeper, feeling better
514	satisfied to begin with an honestly earned salary than by running any
514	risks with borrowed money.
514	""
514	Meg had spent the time in working as well as waiting, growing womanly
514	in character, wise in housewifely arts, and prettier than ever, for
514	love is a great beautifier.  She had her girlish ambitions and hopes,
514	and felt some disappointment at the humble way in which the new life
514	must begin.  Ned Moffat had just married Sallie Gardiner, and Meg
514	couldn't help contrasting their fine house and carriage, many gifts,
514	and splendid outfit with her own, and secretly wishing she could have
514	the same.  But somehow envy and discontent soon vanished when she
514	thought of all the patient love and labor John had put into the little
514	home awaiting her, and when they sat together in the twilight, talking
514	over their small plans, the future always grew so beautiful and bright
514	that she forgot Sallie's splendor and felt herself the richest,
514	happiest girl in Christendom.
514	""
514	Jo never went back to Aunt March, for the old lady took such a fancy to
514	Amy that she bribed her with the offer of drawing lessons from one of
514	the best teachers going, and for the sake of this advantage, Amy would
514	have served a far harder mistress.  So she gave her mornings to duty,
514	her afternoons to pleasure, and prospered finely. Jo meantime devoted
514	herself to literature and Beth, who remained delicate long after the
514	fever was a thing of the past.  Not an invalid exactly, but never again
514	the rosy, healthy creature she had been, yet always hopeful, happy, and
514	serene, and busy with the quiet duties she loved, everyone's friend,
514	and an angel in the house, long before those who loved her most had
514	learned to know it.
514	""
514	As long as _The Spread Eagle_ paid her a dollar a column for her
514	'rubbish', as she called it, Jo felt herself a woman of means, and spun
514	her little romances diligently.  But great plans fermented in her busy
514	brain and ambitious mind, and the old tin kitchen in the garret held a
514	slowly increasing pile of blotted manuscript, which was one day to
514	place the name of March upon the roll of fame.
514	""
514	Laurie, having dutifully gone to college to please his grandfather, was
514	now getting through it in the easiest possible manner to please
514	himself.  A universal favorite, thanks to money, manners, much talent,
514	and the kindest heart that ever got its owner into scrapes by trying to
514	get other people out of them, he stood in great danger of being
514	spoiled, and probably would have been, like many another promising boy,
514	if he had not possessed a talisman against evil in the memory of the
514	kind old man who was bound up in his success, the motherly friend who
514	watched over him as if he were her son, and last, but not least by any
514	means, the knowledge that four innocent girls loved, admired, and
514	believed in him with all their hearts.
514	""
514	Being only 'a glorious human boy', of course he frolicked and flirted,
514	grew dandified, aquatic, sentimental, or gymnastic, as college fashions
514	ordained, hazed and was hazed, talked slang, and more than once came
514	perilously near suspension and expulsion.  But as high spirits and the
514	love of fun were the causes of these pranks, he always managed to save
514	himself by frank confession, honorable atonement, or the irresistible
514	power of persuasion which he possessed in perfection.  In fact, he
514	rather prided himself on his narrow escapes, and liked to thrill the
514	girls with graphic accounts of his triumphs over wrathful tutors,
514	dignified professors, and vanquished enemies.  The 'men of my class',
514	were heroes in the eyes of the girls, who never wearied of the exploits
514	of 'our fellows', and were frequently allowed to bask in the smiles of
514	these great creatures, when Laurie brought them home with him.
514	""
514	Amy especially enjoyed this high honor, and became quite a belle among
514	them, for her ladyship early felt and learned to use the gift of
514	fascination with which she was endowed.  Meg was too much absorbed in
514	her private and particular John to care for any other lords of
514	creation, and Beth too shy to do more than peep at them and wonder how
514	Amy dared to order them about so, but Jo felt quite in her own element,
514	and found it very difficult to refrain from imitating the gentlemanly
514	attitudes, phrases, and feats, which seemed more natural to her than
514	the decorums prescribed for young ladies.  They all liked Jo immensely,
514	but never fell in love with her, though very few escaped without paying
514	the tribute of a sentimental sigh or two at Amy's shrine.  And speaking
514	of sentiment brings us very naturally to the 'Dovecote'.
514	""
514	That was the name of the little brown house Mr. Brooke had prepared for
514	Meg's first home.  Laurie had christened it, saying it was highly
514	appropriate to the gentle lovers who 'went on together like a pair of
514	turtledoves, with first a bill and then a coo'.  It was a tiny house,
514	with a little garden behind and a lawn about as big as a pocket
514	handkerchief in the front.  Here Meg meant to have a fountain,
514	shrubbery, and a profusion of lovely flowers, though just at present
514	the fountain was represented by a weather-beaten urn, very like a
514	dilapidated slopbowl, the shrubbery consisted of several young larches,
514	undecided whether to live or die, and the profusion of flowers was
514	merely hinted by regiments of sticks to show where seeds were planted.
514	But inside, it was altogether charming, and the happy bride saw no
514	fault from garret to cellar.  To be sure, the hall was so narrow it was
514	fortunate that they had no piano, for one never could have been got in
514	whole, the dining room was so small that six people were a tight fit,
514	and the kitchen stairs seemed built for the express purpose of
514	precipitating both servants and china pell-mell into the coalbin.  But
514	once get used to these slight blemishes and nothing could be more
514	complete, for good sense and good taste had presided over the
514	furnishing, and the result was highly satisfactory.  There were no
514	marble-topped tables, long mirrors, or lace curtains in the little
514	parlor, but simple furniture, plenty of books, a fine picture or two, a
514	stand of flowers in the bay window, and, scattered all about, the
514	pretty gifts which came from friendly hands and were the fairer for the
514	loving messages they brought.
514	""
514	I don't think the Parian Psyche Laurie gave lost any of its beauty
514	because John put up the bracket it stood upon, that any upholsterer
514	could have draped the plain muslin curtains more gracefully than Amy's
514	artistic hand, or that any store-room was ever better provided with
514	good wishes, merry words, and happy hopes than that in which Jo and her
514	mother put away Meg's few boxes, barrels, and bundles, and I am morally
514	certain that the spandy new kitchen never could have looked so cozy and
514	neat if Hannah had not arranged every pot and pan a dozen times over,
514	and laid the fire all ready for lighting the minute 'Mis.  Brooke came
514	home'.  I also doubt if any young matron ever began life with so rich a
514	supply of dusters, holders, and piece bags, for Beth made enough to
514	last till the silver wedding came round, and invented three different
514	kinds of dishcloths for the express service of the bridal china.
514	""
514	People who hire all these things done for them never know what they
514	lose, for the homeliest tasks get beautified if loving hands do them,
514	and Meg found so many proofs of this that everything in her small nest,
514	from the kitchen roller to the silver vase on her parlor table, was
514	eloquent of home love and tender forethought.
514	""
514	What happy times they had planning together, what solemn shopping
514	excursions, what funny mistakes they made, and what shouts of laughter
514	arose over Laurie's ridiculous bargains.  In his love of jokes, this
514	young gentleman, though nearly through college, was a much of a boy as
514	ever.  His last whim had been to bring with him on his weekly visits
514	some new, useful, and ingenious article for the young housekeeper.  Now
514	a bag of remarkable clothespins, next, a wonderful nutmeg grater which
514	fell to pieces at the first trial, a knife cleaner that spoiled all the
514	knives, or a sweeper that picked the nap neatly off the carpet and left
514	the dirt, labor-saving soap that took the skin off one's hands,
514	infallible cements which stuck firmly to nothing but the fingers of the
514	deluded buyer, and every kind of tinware, from a toy savings bank for
514	odd pennies, to a wonderful boiler which would wash articles in its own
514	steam with every prospect of exploding in the process.
514	""
514	In vain Meg begged him to stop.  John laughed at him, and Jo called him
514	'Mr. Toodles'.  He was possessed with a mania for patronizing Yankee
514	ingenuity, and seeing his friends fitly furnished forth. So each week
514	beheld some fresh absurdity.
514	""
514	Everything was done at last, even to Amy's arranging different colored
514	soaps to match the different colored rooms, and Beth's setting the
514	table for the first meal.
514	""
514	"""Are you satisfied?  Does it seem like home, and do you feel as if you"
514	"should be happy here?"" asked Mrs. March, as she and her daughter went"
514	through the new kingdom arm in arm, for just then they seemed to cling
514	together more tenderly than ever.
514	""
514	"""Yes, Mother, perfectly satisfied, thanks to you all, and so happy that"
514	"I can't talk about it,"" with a look that was far better than words."
514	""
514	"""If she only had a servant or two it would be all right,"" said Amy,"
514	coming out of the parlor, where she had been trying to decide whether
514	the bronze Mercury looked best on the whatnot or the mantlepiece.
514	""
514	"""Mother and I have talked that over, and I have made up my mind to try"
514	her way first.  There will be so little to do that with Lotty to run my
514	errands and help me here and there, I shall only have enough work to
514	"keep me from getting lazy or homesick,"" answered Meg tranquilly."
514	""
514	"""Sallie Moffat has four,"" began Amy."
514	""
514	"""If Meg had four, the house wouldn't hold them, and master and missis"
514	"would have to camp in the garden,"" broke in Jo, who, enveloped in a big"
514	blue pinafore, was giving the last polish to the door handles.
514	""
514	"""Sallie isn't a poor man's wife, and many maids are in keeping with her"
514	fine establishment.  Meg and John begin humbly, but I have a feeling
514	that there will be quite as much happiness in the little house as in
514	the big one.  It's a great mistake for young girls like Meg to leave
514	themselves nothing to do but dress, give orders, and gossip.  When I
514	was first married, I used to long for my new clothes to wear out or get
514	torn, so that I might have the pleasure of mending them, for I got
514	"heartily sick of doing fancywork and tending my pocket handkerchief."""
514	""
514	"""Why didn't you go into the kitchen and make messes, as Sallie says she"
514	does to amuse herself, though they never turn out well and the servants
514	"laugh at her,"" said Meg."
514	""
514	"""I did after a while, not to 'mess' but to learn of Hannah how things"
514	should be done, that my servants need not laugh at me.  It was play
514	then, but there came a time when I was truly grateful that I not only
514	possessed the will but the power to cook wholesome food for my little
514	girls, and help myself when I could no longer afford to hire help.  You
514	begin at the other end, Meg, dear, but the lessons you learn now will
514	be of use to you by-and-by when John is a richer man, for the mistress
514	of a house, however splendid, should know how work ought to be done, if
514	"she wishes to be well and honestly served."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, Mother, I'm sure of that,"" said Meg, listening respectfully to"
514	the little lecture, for the best of women will hold forth upon the all
514	"absorbing subject of house keeping.  ""Do you know I like this room most"
514	"of all in my baby house,"" added Meg, a minute after, as they went"
514	upstairs and she looked into her well-stored linen closet.
514	""
514	Beth was there, laying the snowy piles smoothly on the shelves and
514	exulting over the goodly array.  All three laughed as Meg spoke, for
514	that linen closet was a joke.  You see, having said that if Meg married
514	'that Brooke' she shouldn't have a cent of her money, Aunt March was
514	rather in a quandary when time had appeased her wrath and made her
514	repent her vow.  She never broke her word, and was much exercised in
514	her mind how to get round it, and at last devised a plan whereby she
514	could satisfy herself.  Mrs. Carrol, Florence's mamma, was ordered to
514	buy, have made, and marked a generous supply of house and table linen,
514	and send it as her present, all of which was faithfully done, but the
514	secret leaked out, and was greatly enjoyed by the family, for Aunt
514	March tried to look utterly unconscious, and insisted that she could
514	give nothing but the old-fashioned pearls long promised to the first
514	bride.
514	""
514	"""That's a housewifely taste which I am glad to see.  I had a young"
514	friend who set up housekeeping with six sheets, but she had finger
514	"bowls for company and that satisfied her,"" said Mrs. March, patting the"
514	damask tablecloths, with a truly feminine appreciation of their
514	fineness.
514	""
514	"""I haven't a single finger bowl, but this is a setout that will last me"
514	"all my days, Hannah says.""  And Meg looked quite contented, as well she"
514	might.
514	""
514	A tall, broad-shouldered young fellow, with a cropped head, a felt
514	basin of a hat, and a flyaway coat, came tramping down the road at a
514	great pace, walked over the low fence without stopping to open the
514	gate, straight up to Mrs. March, with both hands out and a hearty...
514	""
514	"""Here I am, Mother!  Yes, it's all right."""
514	""
514	The last words were in answer to the look the elder lady gave him, a
514	kindly questioning look which the handsome eyes met so frankly that the
514	little ceremony closed, as usual, with a motherly kiss.
514	""
514	"""For Mrs. John Brooke, with the maker's congratulations and"
514	compliments.  Bless you, Beth!  What a refreshing spectacle you are,
514	"Jo.  Amy, you are getting altogether too handsome for a single lady."""
514	""
514	As Laurie spoke, he delivered a brown paper parcel to Meg, pulled
514	Beth's hair ribbon, stared at Jo's big pinafore, and fell into an
514	attitude of mock rapture before Amy, then shook hands all round, and
514	everyone began to talk.
514	""
514	"""Where is John?"" asked Meg anxiously."
514	""
514	"""Stopped to get the license for tomorrow, ma'am."""
514	""
514	"""Which side won the last match, Teddy?"" inquired Jo, who persisted in"
514	feeling an interest in manly sports despite her nineteen years.
514	""
514	"""Ours, of course.  Wish you'd been there to see."""
514	""
514	"""How is the lovely Miss Randal?"" asked Amy with a significant smile."
514	""
514	"""More cruel than ever.  Don't you see how I'm pining away?"" and Laurie"
514	gave his broad chest a sounding slap and heaved a melodramatic sigh.
514	""
514	"""What's the last joke?  Undo the bundle and see, Meg,"" said Beth, eying"
514	the knobby parcel with curiosity.
514	""
514	"""It's a useful thing to have in the house in case of fire or thieves,"""
514	observed Laurie, as a watchman's rattle appeared, amid the laughter of
514	the girls.
514	""
514	"""Any time when John is away and you get frightened, Mrs. Meg, just"
514	swing that out of the front window, and it will rouse the neighborhood
514	"in a jiffy.  Nice thing, isn't it?"" and Laurie gave them a sample of"
514	its powers that made them cover up their ears.
514	""
514	"""There's gratitude for you!  And speaking of gratitude reminds me to"
514	mention that you may thank Hannah for saving your wedding cake from
514	destruction.  I saw it going into your house as I came by, and if she
514	hadn't defended it manfully I'd have had a pick at it, for it looked
514	"like a remarkably plummy one."""
514	""
514	"""I wonder if you will ever grow up, Laurie,"" said Meg in a matronly"
514	tone.
514	""
514	"""I'm doing my best, ma'am, but can't get much higher, I'm afraid, as"
514	"six feet is about all men can do in these degenerate days,"" responded"
514	the young gentleman, whose head was about level with the little
514	chandelier.
514	""
514	"""I suppose it would be profanation to eat anything in this"
514	spick-and-span bower, so as I'm tremendously hungry, I propose an
514	"adjournment,"" he added presently."
514	""
514	"""Mother and I are going to wait for John.  There are some last things"
514	"to settle,"" said Meg, bustling away."
514	""
514	"""Beth and I are going over to Kitty Bryant's to get more flowers for"
514	"tomorrow,"" added Amy, tying a picturesque hat over her picturesque"
514	curls, and enjoying the effect as much as anybody.
514	""
514	"""Come, Jo, don't desert a fellow.  I'm in such a state of exhaustion I"
514	can't get home without help.  Don't take off your apron, whatever you
514	"do, it's peculiarly becoming,"" said Laurie, as Jo bestowed his especial"
514	aversion in her capacious pocket and offered her arm to support his
514	feeble steps.
514	""
514	"""Now, Teddy, I want to talk seriously to you about tomorrow,"" began Jo,"
514	"as they strolled away together.  ""You must promise to behave well, and"
514	"not cut up any pranks, and spoil our plans."""
514	""
514	"""Not a prank."""
514	""
514	"""And don't say funny things when we ought to be sober."""
514	""
514	"""I never do.  You are the one for that."""
514	""
514	"""And I implore you not to look at me during the ceremony.  I shall"
514	"certainly laugh if you do."""
514	""
514	"""You won't see me, you'll be crying so hard that the thick fog round"
514	"you will obscure the prospect."""
514	""
514	"""I never cry unless for some great affliction."""
514	""
514	"""Such as fellows going to college, hey?"" cut in Laurie, with suggestive"
514	laugh.
514	""
514	"""Don't be a peacock.  I only moaned a trifle to keep the girls company."""
514	""
514	"""Exactly.  I say, Jo, how is Grandpa this week?  Pretty amiable?"""
514	""
514	"""Very.  Why, have you got into a scrape and want to know how he'll take"
514	"it?"" asked Jo rather sharply."
514	""
514	"""Now, Jo, do you think I'd look your mother in the face and say 'All"
514	"right', if it wasn't?"" and Laurie stopped short, with an injured air."
514	""
514	"""No, I don't."""
514	""
514	"""Then don't go and be suspicious.  I only want some money,"" said"
514	Laurie, walking on again, appeased by her hearty tone.
514	""
514	"""You spend a great deal, Teddy."""
514	""
514	"""Bless you, I don't spend it, it spends itself somehow, and is gone"
514	"before I know it."""
514	""
514	"""You are so generous and kind-hearted that you let people borrow, and"
514	can't say 'No' to anyone.  We heard about Henshaw and all you did for
514	"him.  If you always spent money in that way, no one would blame you,"""
514	said Jo warmly.
514	""
514	"""Oh, he made a mountain out of a molehill.  You wouldn't have me let"
514	that fine fellow work himself to death just for want of a little help,
514	"when he is worth a dozen of us lazy chaps, would you?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course not, but I don't see the use of your having seventeen"
514	waistcoats, endless neckties, and a new hat every time you come home. I
514	thought you'd got over the dandy period, but every now and then it
514	breaks out in a new spot.  Just now it's the fashion to be hideous, to
514	make your head look like a scrubbing brush, wear a strait jacket,
514	orange gloves, and clumping square-toed boots.  If it was cheap
514	ugliness, I'd say nothing, but it costs as much as the other, and I
514	"don't get any satisfaction out of it."""
514	""
514	Laurie threw back his head, and laughed so heartily at this attack,
514	that the felt hat fell off, and Jo walked on it, which insult only
514	afforded him an opportunity for expatiating on the advantages of a
514	rough-and-ready costume, as he folded up the maltreated hat, and
514	stuffed it into his pocket.
514	""
514	"""Don't lecture any more, there's a good soul!  I have enough all"
514	through the week, and like to enjoy myself when I come home. I'll get
514	myself up regardless of expense tomorrow and be a satisfaction to my
514	"friends."""
514	""
514	"""I'll leave you in peace if you'll only let your hair grow. I'm not"
514	aristocratic, but I do object to being seen with a person who looks
514	"like a young prize fighter,"" observed Jo severely."
514	""
514	"""This unassuming style promotes study, that's why we adopt it,"""
514	returned Laurie, who certainly could not be accused of vanity, having
514	voluntarily sacrificed a handsome curly crop to the demand for
514	quarter-inch-long stubble.
514	""
514	"""By the way, Jo, I think that little Parker is really getting desperate"
514	about Amy.  He talks of her constantly, writes poetry, and moons about
514	in a most suspicious manner.  He'd better nip his little passion in the
514	"bud, hadn't he?"" added Laurie, in a confidential, elder brotherly tone,"
514	after a minute's silence.
514	""
514	"""Of course he had.  We don't want any more marrying in this family for"
514	"years to come.  Mercy on us, what are the children thinking of?"" and Jo"
514	looked as much scandalized as if Amy and little Parker were not yet in
514	their teens.
514	""
514	"""It's a fast age, and I don't know what we are coming to, ma'am. You"
514	are a mere infant, but you'll go next, Jo, and we'll be left
514	"lamenting,"" said Laurie, shaking his head over the degeneracy of the"
514	times.
514	""
514	"""Don't be alarmed.  I'm not one of the agreeable sort.  Nobody will"
514	want me, and it's a mercy, for there should always be one old maid in a
514	"family."""
514	""
514	"""You won't give anyone a chance,"" said Laurie, with a sidelong glance"
514	"and a little more color than before in his sunburned face. ""You won't"
514	show the soft side of your character, and if a fellow gets a peep at it
514	by accident and can't help showing that he likes it, you treat him as
514	Mrs. Gummidge did her sweetheart, throw cold water over him, and get so
514	"thorny no one dares touch or look at you."""
514	""
514	"""I don't like that sort of thing.  I'm too busy to be worried with"
514	nonsense, and I think it's dreadful to break up families so. Now don't
514	say any more about it.  Meg's wedding has turned all our heads, and we
514	talk of nothing but lovers and such absurdities.  I don't wish to get
514	"cross, so let's change the subject;""  and Jo looked quite ready to"
514	fling cold water on the slightest provocation.
514	""
514	Whatever his feelings might have been, Laurie found a vent for them in
514	a long low whistle and the fearful prediction as they parted at the
514	"gate, ""Mark my words, Jo, you'll go next."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE
514	""
514	THE FIRST WEDDING
514	""
514	The June roses over the porch were awake bright and early on that
514	morning, rejoicing with all their hearts in the cloudless sunshine,
514	like friendly little neighbors, as they were.  Quite flushed with
514	excitement were their ruddy faces, as they swung in the wind,
514	whispering to one another what they had seen, for some peeped in at the
514	dining room windows where the feast was spread, some climbed up to nod
514	and smile at the sisters as they dressed the bride, others waved a
514	welcome to those who came and went on various errands in garden, porch,
514	and hall, and all, from the rosiest full-blown flower to the palest
514	baby bud, offered their tribute of beauty and fragrance to the gentle
514	mistress who had loved and tended them so long.
514	""
514	Meg looked very like a rose herself, for all that was best and sweetest
514	in heart and soul seemed to bloom into her face that day, making it
514	fair and tender, with a charm more beautiful than beauty. Neither silk,
514	"lace, nor orange flowers would she have.  ""I don't want a fashionable"
514	wedding, but only those about me whom I love, and to them I wish to
514	"look and be my familiar self."""
514	""
514	So she made her wedding gown herself, sewing into it the tender hopes
514	and innocent romances of a girlish heart.  Her sisters braided up her
514	pretty hair, and the only ornaments she wore were the lilies of the
514	valley, which 'her John' liked best of all the flowers that grew.
514	""
514	"""You do look just like our own dear Meg, only so very sweet and lovely"
514	"that I should hug you if it wouldn't crumple your dress,"" cried Amy,"
514	surveying her with delight when all was done.
514	""
514	"""Then I am satisfied.  But please hug and kiss me, everyone, and don't"
514	mind my dress.  I want a great many crumples of this sort put into it
514	"today,""  and Meg opened her arms to her sisters, who clung about her"
514	with April faces for a minute, feeling that the new love had not
514	changed the old.
514	""
514	"""Now I'm going to tie John's cravat for him, and then to stay a few"
514	"minutes with Father quietly in the study,""  and Meg ran down to perform"
514	these little ceremonies, and then to follow her mother wherever she
514	went, conscious that in spite of the smiles on the motherly face, there
514	was a secret sorrow hid in the motherly heart at the flight of the
514	first bird from the nest.
514	""
514	As the younger girls stand together, giving the last touches to their
514	simple toilet, it may be a good time to tell of a few changes which
514	three years have wrought in their appearance, for all are looking their
514	best just now.
514	""
514	Jo's angles are much softened, she has learned to carry herself with
514	ease, if not grace.  The curly crop has lengthened into a thick coil,
514	more becoming to the small head atop of the tall figure.  There is a
514	fresh collar in her brown cheeks, a soft shine in her eyes, and only
514	gentle words fall from her sharp tongue today.
514	""
514	Beth has grown slender, pale, and more quiet than ever.  The beautiful,
514	kind eyes are larger, and in them lies an expression that saddens one,
514	although it is not sad itself.  It is the shadow of pain which touches
514	the young face with such pathetic patience, but Beth seldom complains
514	and always speaks hopefully of 'being better soon'.
514	""
514	Amy is with truth considered 'the flower of the family', for at sixteen
514	she has the air and bearing of a full-grown woman, not beautiful, but
514	possessed of that indescribable charm called grace. One saw it in the
514	lines of her figure, the make and motion of her hands, the flow of her
514	dress, the droop of her hair, unconscious yet harmonious, and as
514	attractive to many as beauty itself.  Amy's nose still afflicted her,
514	for it never would grow Grecian, so did her mouth, being too wide, and
514	having a decided chin.  These offending features gave character to her
514	whole face, but she never could see it, and consoled herself with her
514	wonderfully fair complexion, keen blue eyes, and curls more golden and
514	abundant than ever.
514	""
514	All three wore suits of thin silver gray (their best gowns for the
514	summer), with blush roses in hair and bosom, and all three looked just
514	what they were, fresh-faced, happy-hearted girls, pausing a moment in
514	their busy lives to read with wistful eyes the sweetest chapter in the
514	romance of womanhood.
514	""
514	There were to be no ceremonious performances, everything was to be as
514	natural and homelike as possible, so when Aunt March arrived, she was
514	scandalized to see the bride come running to welcome and lead her in,
514	to find the bridegroom fastening up a garland that had fallen down, and
514	to catch a glimpse of the paternal minister marching upstairs with a
514	grave countenance and a wine bottle under each arm.
514	""
514	"""Upon my word, here's a state of things!"" cried the old lady, taking"
514	the seat of honor prepared for her, and settling the folds of her
514	"lavender moire with a great rustle.  ""You oughtn't to be seen till the"
514	"last minute, child."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not a show, Aunty, and no one is coming to stare at me, to"
514	criticize my dress, or count the cost of my luncheon.  I'm too happy to
514	care what anyone says or thinks, and I'm going to have my little
514	"wedding just as I like it.  John, dear, here's your hammer.""  And away"
514	went Meg to help 'that man' in his highly improper employment.
514	""
514	"Mr. Brooke didn't even say, ""Thank you,"" but as he stooped for the"
514	unromantic tool, he kissed his little bride behind the folding door,
514	with a look that made Aunt March whisk out her pocket handkerchief with
514	a sudden dew in her sharp old eyes.
514	""
514	A crash, a cry, and a laugh from Laurie, accompanied by the indecorous
514	"exclamation, ""Jupiter Ammon!  Jo's upset the cake again!"" caused a"
514	momentary flurry, which was hardly over when a flock of cousins
514	arrived, and 'the party came in', as Beth used to say when a child.
514	""
514	"""Don't let that young giant come near me, he worries me worse than"
514	"mosquitoes,"" whispered the old lady to Amy, as the rooms filled and"
514	Laurie's black head towered above the rest.
514	""
514	"""He has promised to be very good today, and he can be perfectly elegant"
514	"if he likes,"" returned Amy, and gliding away to warn Hercules to beware"
514	of the dragon, which warning caused him to haunt the old lady with a
514	devotion that nearly distracted her.
514	""
514	There was no bridal procession, but a sudden silence fell upon the room
514	as Mr. March and the young couple took their places under the green
514	arch.  Mother and sisters gathered close, as if loath to give Meg up.
514	The fatherly voice broke more than once, which only seemed to make the
514	service more beautiful and solemn.  The bridegroom's hand trembled
514	visibly, and no one heard his replies.  But Meg looked straight up in
514	"her husband's eyes, and said, ""I will!"" with such tender trust in her"
514	own face and voice that her mother's heart rejoiced and Aunt March
514	sniffed audibly.
514	""
514	Jo did not cry, though she was very near it once, and was only saved
514	from a demonstration by the consciousness that Laurie was staring
514	fixedly at her, with a comical mixture of merriment and emotion in his
514	wicked black eyes.  Beth kept her face hidden on her mother's shoulder,
514	but Amy stood like a graceful statue, with a most becoming ray of
514	sunshine touching her white forehead and the flower in her hair.
514	""
514	It wasn't at all the thing, I'm afraid, but the minute she was fairly
514	"married, Meg cried, ""The first kiss for Marmee!"" and turning, gave it"
514	with her heart on her lips.  During the next fifteen minutes she looked
514	more like a rose than ever, for everyone availed themselves of their
514	privileges to the fullest extent, from Mr. Laurence to old Hannah, who,
514	adorned with a headdress fearfully and wonderfully made, fell upon her
514	"in the hall, crying with a sob and a chuckle, ""Bless you, deary, a"
514	hundred times!  The cake ain't hurt a mite, and everything looks
514	"lovely."""
514	""
514	Everybody cleared up after that, and said something brilliant, or tried
514	to, which did just as well, for laughter is ready when hearts are
514	light.  There was no display of gifts, for they were already in the
514	little house, nor was there an elaborate breakfast, but a plentiful
514	lunch of cake and fruit, dressed with flowers. Mr. Laurence and Aunt
514	March shrugged and smiled at one another when water, lemonade, and
514	coffee were found to be to only sorts of nectar which the three Hebes
514	carried round.  No one said anything, till Laurie, who insisted on
514	serving the bride, appeared before her, with a loaded salver in his
514	hand and a puzzled expression on his face.
514	""
514	"""Has Jo smashed all the bottles by accident?"" he whispered, ""or am I"
514	merely laboring under a delusion that I saw some lying about loose this
514	"morning?"""
514	""
514	"""No, your grandfather kindly offered us his best, and Aunt March"
514	actually sent some, but Father put away a little for Beth, and
514	dispatched the rest to the Soldier's Home.  You know he thinks that
514	wine should be used only in illness, and Mother says that neither she
514	"nor her daughters will ever offer it to any young man under her roof."""
514	""
514	Meg spoke seriously and expected to see Laurie frown or laugh, but he
514	did neither, for after a quick look at her, he said, in his impetuous
514	"way, ""I like that!  For I've seen enough harm done to wish other women"
514	"would think as you do."""
514	""
514	"""You are not made wise by experience, I hope?"" and there was an anxious"
514	accent in Meg's voice.
514	""
514	"""No.  I give you my word for it.  Don't think too well of me, either,"
514	this is not one of my temptations.  Being brought up where wine is as
514	common as water and almost as harmless, I don't care for it, but when a
514	"pretty girl offers it, one doesn't like to refuse, you see."""
514	""
514	"""But you will, for the sake of others, if not for your own. Come,"
514	Laurie, promise, and give me one more reason to call this the happiest
514	"day of my life."""
514	""
514	A demand so sudden and so serious made the young man hesitate a moment,
514	for ridicule is often harder to bear than self-denial. Meg knew that if
514	he gave the promise he would keep it at all costs, and feeling her
514	power, used it as a woman may for her friend's good. She did not speak,
514	but she looked up at him with a face made very eloquent by happiness,
514	"and a smile which said, ""No one can refuse me anything today."""
514	""
514	Laurie certainly could not, and with an answering smile, he gave her
514	"his hand, saying heartily, ""I promise, Mrs. Brooke!"""
514	""
514	"""I thank you, very, very much."""
514	""
514	"""And I drink 'long life to your resolution', Teddy,"" cried Jo,"
514	baptizing him with a splash of lemonade, as she waved her glass and
514	beamed approvingly upon him.
514	""
514	So the toast was drunk, the pledge made and loyally kept in spite of
514	many temptations, for with instinctive wisdom, the girls seized a happy
514	moment to do their friend a service, for which he thanked them all his
514	life.
514	""
514	After lunch, people strolled about, by twos and threes, through the
514	house and garden, enjoying the sunshine without and within.  Meg and
514	John happened to be standing together in the middle of the grass plot,
514	when Laurie was seized with an inspiration which put the finishing
514	touch to this unfashionable wedding.
514	""
514	"""All the married people take hands and dance round the new-made husband"
514	and wife, as the Germans do, while we bachelors and spinsters prance in
514	"couples outside!"" cried Laurie, promenading down the path with Amy,"
514	with such infectious spirit and skill that everyone else followed their
514	example without a murmur.  Mr. and Mrs. March, Aunt and Uncle Carrol
514	began it, others rapidly joined in, even Sallie Moffat, after a
514	moment's hesitation, threw her train over her arm and whisked Ned into
514	the ring.  But the crowning joke was Mr. Laurence and Aunt March, for
514	when the stately old gentleman chasseed solemnly up to the old lady,
514	she just tucked her cane under her arm, and hopped briskly away to join
514	hands with the rest and dance about the bridal pair, while the young
514	folks pervaded the garden like butterflies on a midsummer day.
514	""
514	Want of breath brought the impromptu ball to a close, and then people
514	began to go.
514	""
514	"""I wish you well, my dear, I heartily wish you well, but I think you'll"
514	"be sorry for it,"" said Aunt March to Meg, adding to the bridegroom, as"
514	"he led her to the carriage, ""You've got a treasure, young man, see that"
514	"you deserve it."""
514	""
514	"""That is the prettiest wedding I've been to for an age, Ned, and I"
514	"don't see why, for there wasn't a bit of style about it,"" observed Mrs."
514	Moffat to her husband, as they drove away.
514	""
514	"""Laurie, my lad, if you ever want to indulge in this sort of thing, get"
514	one of those little girls to help you, and I shall be perfectly
514	"satisfied,"" said Mr. Laurence, settling himself in his easy chair to"
514	rest after the excitement of the morning.
514	""
514	"""I'll do my best to gratify you, Sir,"" was Laurie's unusually dutiful"
514	reply, as he carefully unpinned the posy Jo had put in his buttonhole.
514	""
514	The little house was not far away, and the only bridal journey Meg had
514	was the quiet walk with John from the old home to the new. When she
514	came down, looking like a pretty Quakeress in her dove-colored suit and
514	straw bonnet tied with white, they all gathered about her to say
514	'good-by', as tenderly as if she had been going to make the grand tour.
514	""
514	"""Don't feel that I am separated from you, Marmee dear, or that I love"
514	"you any the less for loving John so much,"" she said, clinging to her"
514	"mother, with full eyes for a moment.  ""I shall come every day, Father,"
514	and expect to keep my old place in all your hearts, though I am
514	married.  Beth is going to be with me a great deal, and the other girls
514	will drop in now and then to laugh at my housekeeping struggles. Thank
514	"you all for my happy wedding day.  Good-by, good-by!"""
514	""
514	They stood watching her, with faces full of love and hope and tender
514	pride as she walked away, leaning on her husband's arm, with her hands
514	full of flowers and the June sunshine brightening her happy face--and
514	so Meg's married life began.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-SIX
514	""
514	ARTISTIC ATTEMPTS
514	""
514	It takes people a long time to learn the difference between talent and
514	genius, especially ambitious young men and women.  Amy was learning
514	this distinction through much tribulation, for mistaking enthusiasm for
514	inspiration, she attempted every branch of art with youthful audacity.
514	For a long time there was a lull in the 'mud-pie' business, and she
514	devoted herself to the finest pen-and-ink drawing, in which she showed
514	such taste and skill that her graceful handiwork proved both pleasant
514	and profitable.  But over-strained eyes caused pen and ink to be laid
514	aside for a bold attempt at poker-sketching. While this attack lasted,
514	the family lived in constant fear of a conflagration, for the odor of
514	burning wood pervaded the house at all hours, smoke issued from attic
514	and shed with alarming frequency, red-hot pokers lay about
514	promiscuously, and Hannah never went to bed without a pail of water and
514	the dinner bell at her door in case of fire.  Raphael's face was found
514	boldly executed on the underside of the moulding board, and Bacchus on
514	the head of a beer barrel.  A chanting cherub adorned the cover of the
514	sugar bucket, and attempts to portray Romeo and Juliet supplied
514	kindling for some time.
514	""
514	From fire to oil was a natural transition for burned fingers, and Amy
514	fell to painting with undiminished ardor.  An artist friend fitted her
514	out with his castoff palettes, brushes, and colors, and she daubed
514	away, producing pastoral and marine views such as were never seen on
514	land or sea.  Her monstrosities in the way of cattle would have taken
514	prizes at an agricultural fair, and the perilous pitching of her
514	vessels would have produced seasickness in the most nautical observer,
514	if the utter disregard to all known rules of shipbuilding and rigging
514	had not convulsed him with laughter at the first glance.  Swarthy boys
514	and dark-eyed Madonnas, staring at you from one corner of the studio,
514	suggested Murillo; oily brown shadows of faces with a lurid streak in
514	the wrong place, meant Rembrandt; buxom ladies and dropiscal infants,
514	Rubens; and Turner appeared in tempests of blue thunder, orange
514	lightning, brown rain, and purple clouds, with a tomato-colored splash
514	in the middle, which might be the sun or a bouy, a sailor's shirt or a
514	king's robe, as the spectator pleased.
514	""
514	Charcoal portraits came next, and the entire family hung in a row,
514	looking as wild and crocky as if just evoked from a coalbin. Softened
514	into crayon sketches, they did better, for the likenesses were good,
514	and Amy's hair, Jo's nose, Meg's mouth, and Laurie's eyes were
514	pronounced 'wonderfully fine'.  A return to clay and plaster followed,
514	and ghostly casts of her acquaintances haunted corners of the house, or
514	tumbled off closet shelves onto people's heads.  Children were enticed
514	in as models, till their incoherent accounts of her mysterious doings
514	caused Miss Amy to be regarded in the light of a young ogress.  Her
514	efforts in this line, however, were brought to an abrupt close by an
514	untoward accident, which quenched her ardor.  Other models failing her
514	for a time, she undertook to cast her own pretty foot, and the family
514	were one day alarmed by an unearthly bumping and screaming and running
514	to the rescue, found the young enthusiast hopping wildly about the shed
514	with her foot held fast in a pan full of plaster, which had hardened
514	with unexpected rapidity.  With much difficulty and some danger she was
514	dug out, for Jo was so overcome with laughter while she excavated that
514	her knife went too far, cut the poor foot, and left a lasting memorial
514	of one artistic attempt, at least.
514	""
514	After this Amy subsided, till a mania for sketching from nature set her
514	to haunting river, field, and wood, for picturesque studies, and
514	sighing for ruins to copy.  She caught endless colds sitting on damp
514	grass to book 'a delicious bit', composed of a stone, a stump, one
514	mushroom, and a broken mullein stalk, or 'a heavenly mass of clouds',
514	that looked like a choice display of featherbeds when done. She
514	sacrificed her complexion floating on the river in the midsummer sun to
514	study light and shade, and got a wrinkle over her nose trying after
514	'points of sight', or whatever the squint-and-string performance is
514	called.
514	""
514	If 'genius is eternal patience', as Michelangelo affirms, Amy had some
514	claim to the divine attribute, for she persevered in spite of all
514	obstacles, failures, and discouragements, firmly believing that in time
514	she should do something worthy to be called 'high art'.
514	""
514	She was learning, doing, and enjoying other things, meanwhile, for she
514	had resolved to be an attractive and accomplished woman, even if she
514	never became a great artist.  Here she succeeded better, for she was
514	one of those happily created beings who please without effort, make
514	friends everywhere, and take life so gracefully and easily that less
514	fortunate souls are tempted to believe that such are born under a lucky
514	star.  Everybody liked her, for among her good gifts was tact.  She had
514	an instinctive sense of what was pleasing and proper, always said the
514	right thing to the right person, did just what suited the time and
514	"place, and was so self-possessed that her sisters used to say, ""If Amy"
514	went to court without any rehearsal beforehand, she'd know exactly what
514	"to do."""
514	""
514	One of her weaknesses was a desire to move in 'our best society',
514	without being quite sure what the best really was.  Money, position,
514	fashionable accomplishments, and elegant manners were most desirable
514	things in her eyes, and she liked to associate with those who possessed
514	them, often mistaking the false for the true, and admiring what was not
514	admirable.  Never forgetting that by birth she was a gentlewoman, she
514	cultivated her aristocratic tastes and feelings, so that when the
514	opportunity came she might be ready to take the place from which
514	poverty now excluded her.
514	""
514	"""My lady,"" as her friends called her, sincerely desired to be a genuine"
514	lady, and was so at heart, but had yet to learn that money cannot buy
514	refinement of nature, that rank does not always confer nobility, and
514	that true breeding makes itself felt in spite of external drawbacks.
514	""
514	"""I want to ask a favor of you, Mamma,"" Amy said, coming in with an"
514	important air one day.
514	""
514	"""Well, little girl, what is it?"" replied her mother, in whose eyes the"
514	stately young lady still remained 'the baby'.
514	""
514	"""Our drawing class breaks up next week, and before the girls separate"
514	for the summer, I want to ask them out here for a day.  They are wild
514	to see the river, sketch the broken bridge, and copy some of the things
514	they admire in my book.  They have been very kind to me in many ways,
514	and I am grateful, for they are all rich and I know I am poor, yet they
514	"never made any difference."""
514	""
514	"""Why should they?"" and Mrs. March put the question with what the girls"
514	called her 'Maria Theresa air'.
514	""
514	"""You know as well as I that it does make a difference with nearly"
514	everyone, so don't ruffle up like a dear, motherly hen, when your
514	chickens get pecked by smarter birds.  The ugly duckling turned out a
514	"swan, you know.""  and Amy smiled without bitterness, for she possessed"
514	a happy temper and hopeful spirit.
514	""
514	Mrs. March laughed, and smoothed down her maternal pride as she asked,
514	"""Well, my swan, what is your plan?"""
514	""
514	"""I should like to ask the girls out to lunch next week, to take them"
514	for a drive to the places they want to see, a row on the river,
514	"perhaps, and make a little artistic fete for them."""
514	""
514	"""That looks feasible.  What do you want for lunch?  Cake, sandwiches,"
514	"fruit, and coffee will be all that is necessary, I suppose?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear, no!  We must have cold tongue and chicken, French chocolate"
514	and ice cream, besides.  The girls are used to such things, and I want
514	"my lunch to be proper and elegant, though I do work for my living."""
514	""
514	"""How many young ladies are there?"" asked her mother, beginning to look"
514	sober.
514	""
514	"""Twelve or fourteen in the class, but I dare say they won't all come."""
514	""
514	"""Bless me, child, you will have to charter an omnibus to carry them"
514	"about."""
514	""
514	"""Why, Mother, how can you think of such a thing?  Not more than six or"
514	eight will probably come, so I shall hire a beach wagon and borrow Mr.
514	"Laurence's cherry-bounce."" (Hannah's pronunciation of char-a-banc.)"
514	""
514	"""All of this will be expensive, Amy."""
514	""
514	"""Not very.  I've calculated the cost, and I'll pay for it myself."""
514	""
514	"""Don't you think, dear, that as these girls are used to such things,"
514	and the best we can do will be nothing new, that some simpler plan
514	would be pleasanter to them, as a change if nothing more, and much
514	better for us than buying or borrowing what we don't need, and
514	"attempting a style not in keeping with our circumstances?"""
514	""
514	"""If I can't have it as I like, I don't care to have it at all. I know"
514	that I can carry it out perfectly well, if you and the girls will help
514	"a little, and I don't see why I can't if I'm willing to pay for it,"""
514	said Amy, with the decision which opposition was apt to change into
514	obstinacy.
514	""
