514	Mrs. March knew that experience was an excellent teacher, and when it
514	was possible she left her children to learn alone the lessons which she
514	would gladly have made easier, if they had not objected to taking
514	advice as much as they did salts and senna.
514	""
514	"""Very well, Amy, if your heart is set upon it, and you see your way"
514	through without too great an outlay of money, time, and temper, I'll
514	say no more.  Talk it over with the girls, and whichever way you
514	"decide, I'll do my best to help you."""
514	""
514	"""Thanks, Mother, you are always so kind."" and away went Amy to lay her"
514	plan before her sisters.
514	""
514	Meg agreed at once, and promised her aid, gladly offering anything she
514	possessed, from her little house itself to her very best saltspoons.
514	But Jo frowned upon the whole project and would have nothing to do with
514	it at first.
514	""
514	"""Why in the world should you spend your money, worry your family, and"
514	turn the house upside down for a parcel of girls who don't care a
514	sixpence for you?  I thought you had too much pride and sense to
514	truckle to any mortal woman just because she wears French boots and
514	"rides in a coupe,"" said Jo, who, being called from the tragic climax of"
514	her novel, was not in the best mood for social enterprises.
514	""
514	"""I don't truckle, and I hate being patronized as much as you do!"""
514	returned Amy indignantly, for the two still jangled when such questions
514	"arose. ""The girls do care for me, and I for them, and there's a great"
514	deal of kindness and sense and talent among them, in spite of what you
514	call fashionable nonsense.  You don't care to make people like you, to
514	go into good society, and cultivate your manners and tastes.  I do, and
514	I mean to make the most of every chance that comes.  You can go through
514	the world with your elbows out and your nose in the air, and call it
514	"independence, if you like.  That's not my way."""
514	""
514	When Amy had whetted her tongue and freed her mind she usually got the
514	best of it, for she seldom failed to have common sense on her side,
514	while Jo carried her love of liberty and hate of conventionalities to
514	such an unlimited extent that she naturally found herself worsted in an
514	argument.  Amy's definition of Jo's idea of independence was such a
514	good hit that both burst out laughing, and the discussion took a more
514	amiable turn.  Much against her will, Jo at length consented to
514	sacrifice a day to Mrs. Grundy, and help her sister through what she
514	regarded as 'a nonsensical business'.
514	""
514	The invitations were sent, nearly all accepted, and the following
514	Monday was set apart for the grand event.  Hannah was out of humor
514	"because her week's work was deranged, and prophesied that ""ef the"
514	washin' and ironin' warn't done reg'lar, nothin' would go well
514	"anywheres"".  This hitch in the mainspring of the domestic machinery had"
514	a bad effect upon the whole concern, but Amy's motto was 'Nil
514	desperandum', and having made up her mind what to do, she proceeded to
514	do it in spite of all obstacles.  To begin with, Hannah's cooking
514	didn't turn out well.  The chicken was tough, the tongue too salty, and
514	the chocolate wouldn't froth properly.  Then the cake and ice cost more
514	than Amy expected, so did the wagon, and various other expenses, which
514	seemed trifling at the outset, counted up rather alarmingly afterward.
514	Beth got a cold and took to her bed.  Meg had an unusual number of
514	callers to keep her at home, and Jo was in such a divided state of mind
514	that her breakages, accidents, and mistakes were uncommonly numerous,
514	serious, and trying.
514	""
514	If it was not fair on Monday, the young ladies were to come on Tuesday,
514	an arrangement which aggravated Jo and Hannah to the last degree.  On
514	Monday morning the weather was in that undecided state which is more
514	exasperating than a steady pour.  It drizzled a little, shone a little,
514	blew a little, and didn't make up its mind till it was too late for
514	anyone else to make up theirs.  Amy was up at dawn, hustling people out
514	of their beds and through their breakfasts, that the house might be got
514	in order.  The parlor struck her as looking uncommonly shabby, but
514	without stopping to sigh for what she had not, she skillfully made the
514	best of what she had, arranging chairs over the worn places in the
514	carpet, covering stains on the walls with homemade statuary, which gave
514	an artistic air to the room, as did the lovely vases of flowers Jo
514	scattered about.
514	""
514	The lunch looked charming, and as she surveyed it, she sincerely hoped
514	it would taste well, and that the borrowed glass, china, and silver
514	would get safely home again.  The carriages were promised, Meg and
514	Mother were all ready to do the honors, Beth was able to help Hannah
514	behind the scenes, Jo had engaged to be as lively and amiable as an
514	absent mind, and aching head, and a very decided disapproval of
514	everybody and everything would allow, and as she wearily dressed, Amy
514	cheered herself with anticipations of the happy moment when, lunch
514	safely over, she should drive away with her friends for an afternoon of
514	artistic delights, for the 'cherry bounce' and the broken bridge were
514	her strong points.
514	""
514	Then came the hours of suspense, during which she vibrated from parlor
514	to porch, while public opinion varied like the weathercock.  A smart
514	shower at eleven had evidently quenched the enthusiasm of the young
514	ladies who were to arrive at twelve, for nobody came, and at two the
514	exhausted family sat down in a blaze of sunshine to consume the
514	perishable portions of the feast, that nothing might be lost.
514	""
514	"""No doubt about the weather today, they will certainly come, so we must"
514	"fly round and be ready for them,"" said Amy, as the sun woke her next"
514	morning.  She spoke briskly, but in her secret soul she wished she had
514	said nothing about Tuesday, for her interest like her cake was getting
514	a little stale.
514	""
514	"""I can't get any lobsters, so you will have to do without salad today,"""
514	said Mr. March, coming in half an hour later, with an expression of
514	placid despair.
514	""
514	"""Use the chicken then, the toughness won't matter in a salad,"" advised"
514	his wife.
514	""
514	"""Hannah left it on the kitchen table a minute, and the kittens got at"
514	"it.  I'm very sorry, Amy,"" added Beth, who was still a patroness of"
514	cats.
514	""
514	"""Then I must have a lobster, for tongue alone won't do,"" said Amy"
514	decidedly.
514	""
514	"""Shall I rush into town and demand one?"" asked Jo, with the magnanimity"
514	of a martyr.
514	""
514	"""You'd come bringing it home under your arm without any paper, just to"
514	"try me.  I'll go myself,"" answered Amy, whose temper was beginning to"
514	fail.
514	""
514	Shrouded in a thick veil and armed with a genteel traveling basket, she
514	departed, feeling that a cool drive would soothe her ruffled spirit and
514	fit her for the labors of the day.  After some delay, the object of her
514	desire was procured, likewise a bottle of dressing to prevent further
514	loss of time at home, and off she drove again, well pleased with her
514	own forethought.
514	""
514	As the omnibus contained only one other passenger, a sleepy old lady,
514	Amy pocketed her veil and beguiled the tedium of the way by trying to
514	find out where all her money had gone to.  So busy was she with her
514	card full of refractory figures that she did not observe a newcomer,
514	who entered without stopping the vehicle, till a masculine voice said,
514	"""Good morning, Miss March,"" and, looking up, she beheld one of Laurie's"
514	most elegant college friends.  Fervently hoping that he would get out
514	before she did, Amy utterly ignored the basket at her feet, and
514	congratulating herself that she had on her new traveling dress,
514	returned the young man's greeting with her usual suavity and spirit.
514	""
514	They got on excellently, for Amy's chief care was soon set at rest by
514	learning that the gentleman would leave first, and she was chatting
514	away in a peculiarly lofty strain, when the old lady got out. In
514	stumbling to the door, she upset the basket, and--oh horror!--the
514	lobster, in all its vulgar size and brilliancy, was revealed to the
514	highborn eyes of a Tudor!
514	""
514	"""By Jove, she's forgotten her dinner!"" cried the unconscious youth,"
514	poking the scarlet monster into its place with his cane, and preparing
514	to hand out the basket after the old lady.
514	""
514	"""Please don't--it's--it's mine,"" murmured Amy, with a face nearly as"
514	red as her fish.
514	""
514	"""Oh, really, I beg pardon.  It's an uncommonly fine one, isn't it?"""
514	said Tudor, with great presence of mind, and an air of sober interest
514	that did credit to his breeding.
514	""
514	Amy recovered herself in a breath, set her basket boldly on the seat,
514	"and said, laughing, ""Don't you wish you were to have some of the salad"
514	he's going to make, and to see the charming young ladies who are to eat
514	"it?"""
514	""
514	Now that was tact, for two of the ruling foibles of the masculine mind
514	were touched.  The lobster was instantly surrounded by a halo of
514	pleasing reminiscences, and curiosity about 'the charming young ladies'
514	diverted his mind from the comical mishap.
514	""
514	"""I suppose he'll laugh and joke over it with Laurie, but I shan't see"
514	"them, that's a comfort,"" thought Amy, as Tudor bowed and departed."
514	""
514	She did not mention this meeting at home (though she discovered that,
514	thanks to the upset, her new dress was much damaged by the rivulets of
514	dressing that meandered down the skirt), but went through with the
514	preparations which now seemed more irksome than before, and at twelve
514	o'clock all was ready again.  Feeling that the neighbors were
514	interested in her movements, she wished to efface the memory of
514	yesterday's failure by a grand success today, so she ordered the
514	'cherry bounce', and drove away in state to meet and escort her guests
514	to the banquet.
514	""
514	"""There's the rumble, they're coming!  I'll go onto the porch and meet"
514	them.  It looks hospitable, and I want the poor child to have a good
514	"time after all her trouble,"" said Mrs. March, suiting the action to the"
514	word.  But after one glance, she retired, with an indescribable
514	expression, for looking quite lost in the big carriage, sat Amy and one
514	young lady.
514	""
514	"""Run, Beth, and help Hannah clear half the things off the table. It"
514	"will be too absurd to put a luncheon for twelve before a single girl,"""
514	cried Jo, hurrying away to the lower regions, too excited to stop even
514	for a laugh.
514	""
514	In came Amy, quite calm and delightfully cordial to the one guest who
514	had kept her promise.  The rest of the family, being of a dramatic
514	turn, played their parts equally well, and Miss Eliott found them a
514	most hilarious set, for it was impossible to control entirely the
514	merriment which possessed them.  The remodeled lunch being gaily
514	partaken of, the studio and garden visited, and art discussed with
514	enthusiasm, Amy ordered a buggy (alas for the elegant cherry-bounce),
514	and drove her friend quietly about the neighborhood till sunset, when
514	'the party went out'.
514	""
514	As she came walking in, looking very tired but as composed as ever, she
514	observed that every vestige of the unfortunate fete had disappeared,
514	except a suspicious pucker about the corners of Jo's mouth.
514	""
514	"""You've had a lovely afternoon for your drive, dear,"" said her mother,"
514	as respectfully as if the whole twelve had come.
514	""
514	"""Miss Eliott is a very sweet girl, and seemed to enjoy herself, I"
514	"thought,"" observed Beth, with unusual warmth."
514	""
514	"""Could you spare me some of your cake?  I really need some, I have so"
514	"much company, and I can't make such delicious stuff as yours,"" asked"
514	Meg soberly.
514	""
514	"""Take it all.  I'm the only one here who likes sweet things, and it"
514	"will mold before I can dispose of it,"" answered Amy, thinking with a"
514	sigh of the generous store she had laid in for such an end as this.
514	""
514	"""It's a pity Laurie isn't here to help us,"" began Jo, as they sat down"
514	to ice cream and salad for the second time in two days.
514	""
514	A warning look from her mother checked any further remarks, and the
514	whole family ate in heroic silence, till Mr. March mildly observed,
514	"""salad was one of the favorite dishes of the ancients, and Evelyn..."""
514	Here a general explosion of laughter cut short the 'history of salads',
514	to the great surprise of the learned gentleman.
514	""
514	"""Bundle everything into a basket and send it to the Hummels.  Germans"
514	like messes.  I'm sick of the sight of this, and there's no reason you
514	"should all die of a surfeit because I've been a fool,"" cried Amy,"
514	wiping her eyes.
514	""
514	"""I thought I should have died when I saw you two girls rattling about"
514	in the what-you-call-it, like two little kernels in a very big
514	"nutshell, and Mother waiting in state to receive the throng,"" sighed"
514	Jo, quite spent with laughter.
514	""
514	"""I'm very sorry you were disappointed, dear, but we all did our best to"
514	"satisfy you,"" said Mrs. March, in a tone full of motherly regret."
514	""
514	"""I am satisfied.  I've done what I undertook, and it's not my fault"
514	"that it failed.  I comfort myself with that,"" said Amy with a little"
514	"quiver in her voice.  ""I thank you all very much for helping me, and"
514	I'll thank you still more if you won't allude to it for a month, at
514	"least."""
514	""
514	No one did for several months, but the word 'fete' always produced a
514	general smile, and Laurie's birthday gift to Amy was a tiny coral
514	lobster in the shape of a charm for her watch guard.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-SEVEN
514	""
514	LITERARY LESSONS
514	""
514	Fortune suddenly smiled upon Jo, and dropped a good luck penny in her
514	path.  Not a golden penny, exactly, but I doubt if half a million would
514	have given more real happiness then did the little sum that came to her
514	in this wise.
514	""
514	Every few weeks she would shut herself up in her room, put on her
514	scribbling suit, and 'fall into a vortex', as she expressed it, writing
514	away at her novel with all her heart and soul, for till that was
514	finished she could find no peace.  Her 'scribbling suit' consisted of a
514	black woolen pinafore on which she could wipe her pen at will, and a
514	cap of the same material, adorned with a cheerful red bow, into which
514	she bundled her hair when the decks were cleared for action.  This cap
514	was a beacon to the inquiring eyes of her family, who during these
514	periods kept their distance, merely popping in their heads
514	"semi-occasionally to ask, with interest, ""Does genius burn, Jo?"" They"
514	did not always venture even to ask this question, but took an
514	observation of the cap, and judged accordingly.  If this expressive
514	article of dress was drawn low upon the forehead, it was a sign that
514	hard work was going on, in exciting moments it was pushed rakishly
514	askew, and when despair seized the author it was plucked wholly off,
514	and cast upon the floor.  At such times the intruder silently withdrew,
514	and not until the red bow was seen gaily erect upon the gifted brow,
514	did anyone dare address Jo.
514	""
514	She did not think herself a genius by any means, but when the writing
514	fit came on, she gave herself up to it with entire abandon, and led a
514	blissful life, unconscious of want, care, or bad weather, while she sat
514	safe and happy in an imaginary world, full of friends almost as real
514	and dear to her as any in the flesh.  Sleep forsook her eyes, meals
514	stood untasted, day and night were all too short to enjoy the happiness
514	which blessed her only at such times, and made these hours worth
514	living, even if they bore no other fruit.  The divine afflatus usually
514	lasted a week or two, and then she emerged from her 'vortex', hungry,
514	sleepy, cross, or despondent.
514	""
514	She was just recovering from one of these attacks when she was
514	prevailed upon to escort Miss Crocker to a lecture, and in return for
514	her virtue was rewarded with a new idea.  It was a People's Course, the
514	lecture on the Pyramids, and Jo rather wondered at the choice of such a
514	subject for such an audience, but took it for granted that some great
514	social evil would be remedied or some great want supplied by unfolding
514	the glories of the Pharaohs to an audience whose thoughts were busy
514	with the price of coal and flour, and whose lives were spent in trying
514	to solve harder riddles than that of the Sphinx.
514	""
514	They were early, and while Miss Crocker set the heel of her stocking,
514	Jo amused herself by examining the faces of the people who occupied the
514	seat with them.  On her left were two matrons, with massive foreheads
514	and bonnets to match, discussing Women's Rights and making tatting.
514	Beyond sat a pair of humble lovers, artlessly holding each other by the
514	hand, a somber spinster eating peppermints out of a paper bag, and an
514	old gentleman taking his preparatory nap behind a yellow bandanna.  On
514	her right, her only neighbor was a studious looking lad absorbed in a
514	newspaper.
514	""
514	It was a pictorial sheet, and Jo examined the work of art nearest her,
514	idly wondering what fortuitous concatenation of circumstances needed
514	the melodramatic illustration of an Indian in full war costume,
514	tumbling over a precipice with a wolf at his throat, while two
514	infuriated young gentlemen, with unnaturally small feet and big eyes,
514	were stabbing each other close by, and a disheveled female was flying
514	away in the background with her mouth wide open.  Pausing to turn a
514	page, the lad saw her looking and, with boyish good nature offered half
514	"his paper, saying bluntly, ""want to read it? That's a first-rate story."""
514	""
514	Jo accepted it with a smile, for she had never outgrown her liking for
514	lads, and soon found herself involved in the usual labyrinth of love,
514	mystery, and murder, for the story belonged to that class of light
514	literature in which the passions have a holiday, and when the author's
514	invention fails, a grand catastrophe clears the stage of one half the
514	dramatis personae, leaving the other half to exult over their downfall.
514	""
514	"""Prime, isn't it?"" asked the boy, as her eye went down the last"
514	paragraph of her portion.
514	""
514	"""I think you and I could do as well as that if we tried,"" returned Jo,"
514	amused at his admiration of the trash.
514	""
514	"""I should think I was a pretty lucky chap if I could.  She makes a good"
514	"living out of such stories, they say."" and he pointed to the name of"
514	Mrs. S.L.A.N.G.  Northbury, under the title of the tale.
514	""
514	"""Do you know her?"" asked Jo, with sudden interest."
514	""
514	"""No, but I read all her pieces, and I know a fellow who works in the"
514	"office where this paper is printed."""
514	""
514	"""Do you say she makes a good living out of stories like this?"" and Jo"
514	looked more respectfully at the agitated group and thickly sprinkled
514	exclamation points that adorned the page.
514	""
514	"""Guess she does!  She knows just what folks like, and gets paid well"
514	"for writing it."""
514	""
514	Here the lecture began, but Jo heard very little of it, for while
514	Professor Sands was prosing away about Belzoni, Cheops, scarabei, and
514	hieroglyphics, she was covertly taking down the address of the paper,
514	and boldly resolving to try for the hundred-dollar prize offered in its
514	columns for a sensational story.  By the time the lecture ended and the
514	audience awoke, she had built up a splendid fortune for herself (not
514	the first founded on paper), and was already deep in the concoction of
514	her story, being unable to decide whether the duel should come before
514	the elopement or after the murder.
514	""
514	She said nothing of her plan at home, but fell to work next day, much
514	to the disquiet of her mother, who always looked a little anxious when
514	'genius took to burning'.  Jo had never tried this style before,
514	contenting herself with very mild romances for _The Spread Eagle_.  Her
514	experience and miscellaneous reading were of service now, for they gave
514	her some idea of dramatic effect, and supplied plot, language, and
514	costumes.  Her story was as full of desperation and despair as her
514	limited acquaintance with those uncomfortable emotions enabled her to
514	make it, and having located it in Lisbon, she wound up with an
514	earthquake, as a striking and appropriate denouement.  The manuscript
514	was privately dispatched, accompanied by a note, modestly saying that
514	if the tale didn't get the prize, which the writer hardly dared expect,
514	she would be very glad to receive any sum it might be considered worth.
514	""
514	Six weeks is a long time to wait, and a still longer time for a girl to
514	keep a secret, but Jo did both, and was just beginning to give up all
514	hope of ever seeing her manuscript again, when a letter arrived which
514	almost took her breath away, for on opening it, a check for a hundred
514	dollars fell into her lap.  For a minute she stared at it as if it had
514	been a snake, then she read her letter and began to cry.  If the
514	amiable gentleman who wrote that kindly note could have known what
514	intense happiness he was giving a fellow creature, I think he would
514	devote his leisure hours, if he has any, to that amusement, for Jo
514	valued the letter more than the money, because it was encouraging, and
514	after years of effort it was so pleasant to find that she had learned
514	to do something, though it was only to write a sensation story.
514	""
514	A prouder young woman was seldom seen than she, when, having composed
514	herself, she electrified the family by appearing before them with the
514	letter in one hand, the check in the other, announcing that she had won
514	the prize.  Of course there was a great jubilee, and when the story
514	came everyone read and praised it, though after her father had told her
514	that the language was good, the romance fresh and hearty, and the
514	tragedy quite thrilling, he shook his head, and said in his unworldly
514	way...
514	""
514	"""You can do better than this, Jo.  Aim at the highest, and never mind"
514	"the money."""
514	""
514	"""I think the money is the best part of it.  What will you do with such"
514	"a fortune?"" asked Amy, regarding the magic slip of paper with a"
514	reverential eye.
514	""
514	"""Send Beth and Mother to the seaside for a month or two,"" answered Jo"
514	promptly.
514	""
514	To the seaside they went, after much discussion, and though Beth didn't
514	come home as plump and rosy as could be desired, she was much better,
514	while Mrs. March declared she felt ten years younger.  So Jo was
514	satisfied with the investment of her prize money, and fell to work with
514	a cheery spirit, bent on earning more of those delightful checks. She
514	did earn several that year, and began to feel herself a power in the
514	house, for by the magic of a pen, her 'rubbish' turned into comforts
514	for them all.  The Duke's Daughter paid the butcher's bill, A Phantom
514	Hand put down a new carpet, and the Curse of the Coventrys proved the
514	blessing of the Marches in the way of groceries and gowns.
514	""
514	Wealth is certainly a most desirable thing, but poverty has its sunny
514	side, and one of the sweet uses of adversity is the genuine
514	satisfaction which comes from hearty work of head or hand, and to the
514	inspiration of necessity, we owe half the wise, beautiful, and useful
514	blessings of the world.  Jo enjoyed a taste of this satisfaction, and
514	ceased to envy richer girls, taking great comfort in the knowledge that
514	she could supply her own wants, and need ask no one for a penny.
514	""
514	Little notice was taken of her stories, but they found a market, and
514	encouraged by this fact, she resolved to make a bold stroke for fame
514	and fortune.  Having copied her novel for the fourth time, read it to
514	all her confidential friends, and submitted it with fear and trembling
514	to three publishers, she at last disposed of it, on condition that she
514	would cut it down one third, and omit all the parts which she
514	particularly admired.
514	""
514	"""Now I must either bundle it back in to my tin kitchen to mold, pay for"
514	printing it myself, or chop it up to suit purchasers and get what I can
514	for it.  Fame is a very good thing to have in the house, but cash is
514	more convenient, so I wish to take the sense of the meeting on this
514	"important subject,"" said Jo, calling a family council."
514	""
514	"""Don't spoil your book, my girl, for there is more in it than you know,"
514	"and the idea is well worked out.  Let it wait and ripen,"" was her"
514	father's advice, and he practiced what he preached, having waited
514	patiently thirty years for fruit of his own to ripen, and being in no
514	haste to gather it even now when it was sweet and mellow.
514	""
514	"""It seems to me that Jo will profit more by taking the trial than by"
514	"waiting,"" said Mrs. March.  ""Criticism is the best test of such work,"
514	for it will show her both unsuspected merits and faults, and help her
514	to do better next time.  We are too partial, but the praise and blame
514	"of outsiders will prove useful, even if she gets but little money."""
514	""
514	"""Yes,"" said Jo, knitting her brows, ""that's just it.  I've been fussing"
514	over the thing so long, I really don't know whether it's good, bad, or
514	indifferent.  It will be a great help to have cool, impartial persons
514	"take a look at it, and tell me what they think of it."""
514	""
514	"""I wouldn't leave a word out of it.  You'll spoil it if you do, for the"
514	interest of the story is more in the minds than in the actions of the
514	"people, and it will be all a muddle if you don't explain as you go on,"""
514	said Meg, who firmly believed that this book was the most remarkable
514	novel ever written.
514	""
514	"""But Mr. Allen says, 'Leave out the explanations, make it brief and"
514	"dramatic, and let the characters tell the story',"" interrupted Jo,"
514	turning to the publisher's note.
514	""
514	"""Do as he tells you.  He knows what will sell, and we don't. Make a"
514	good, popular book, and get as much money as you can. By-and-by, when
514	you've got a name, you can afford to digress, and have philosophical
514	"and metaphysical people in your novels,"" said Amy, who took a strictly"
514	practical view of the subject.
514	""
514	"""Well,"" said Jo, laughing, ""if my people are 'philosophical and"
514	metaphysical', it isn't my fault, for I know nothing about such things,
514	except what I hear father say, sometimes.  If I've got some of his wise
514	ideas jumbled up with my romance, so much the better for me.  Now,
514	"Beth, what do you say?"""
514	""
514	"""I should so like to see it printed soon,"" was all Beth said, and"
514	smiled in saying it.  But there was an unconscious emphasis on the last
514	word, and a wistful look in the eyes that never lost their childlike
514	candor, which chilled Jo's heart for a minute with a forboding fear,
514	and decided her to make her little venture 'soon'.
514	""
514	So, with Spartan firmness, the young authoress laid her first-born on
514	her table, and chopped it up as ruthlessly as any ogre.  In the hope of
514	pleasing everyone, she took everyone's advice, and like the old man and
514	his donkey in the fable suited nobody.
514	""
514	Her father liked the metaphysical streak which had unconsciously got
514	into it, so that was allowed to remain though she had her doubts about
514	it.  Her mother thought that there was a trifle too much description.
514	Out, therefore it came, and with it many necessary links in the story.
514	Meg admired the tragedy, so Jo piled up the agony to suit her, while
514	Amy objected to the fun, and, with the best intentions in life, Jo
514	quenched the spritly scenes which relieved the somber character of the
514	story.  Then, to complicate the ruin, she cut it down one third, and
514	confidingly sent the poor little romance, like a picked robin, out into
514	the big, busy world to try its fate.
514	""
514	Well, it was printed, and she got three hundred dollars for it,
514	likewise plenty of praise and blame, both so much greater than she
514	expected that she was thrown into a state of bewilderment from which it
514	took her some time to recover.
514	""
514	"""You said, Mother, that criticism would help me.  But how can it, when"
514	it's so contradictory that I don't know whether I've written a
514	"promising book or broken all the ten commandments?"" cried poor Jo,"
514	turning over a heap of notices, the perusal of which filled her with
514	"pride and joy one minute, wrath and dismay the next.  ""This man says,"
514	'An exquisite book, full of truth, beauty, and earnestness.' 'All is
514	"sweet, pure, and healthy.'"" continued the perplexed authoress.  ""The"
514	next, 'The theory of the book is bad, full of morbid fancies,
514	spiritualistic ideas, and unnatural characters.' Now, as I had no
514	theory of any kind, don't believe in Spiritualism, and copied my
514	characters from life, I don't see how this critic can be right.
514	Another says, 'It's one of the best American novels which has appeared
514	for years.' (I know better than that), and the next asserts that
514	'Though it is original, and written with great force and feeling, it is
514	a dangerous book.' 'Tisn't!  Some make fun of it, some overpraise, and
514	nearly all insist that I had a deep theory to expound, when I only
514	wrote it for the pleasure and the money.  I wish I'd printed the whole
514	"or not at all, for I do hate to be so misjudged."""
514	""
514	Her family and friends administered comfort and commendation liberally.
514	Yet it was a hard time for sensitive, high-spirited Jo, who meant so
514	well and had apparently done so ill.  But it did her good, for those
514	whose opinion had real value gave her the criticism which is an
514	author's best education, and when the first soreness was over, she
514	could laugh at her poor little book, yet believe in it still, and feel
514	herself the wiser and stronger for the buffeting she had received.
514	""
514	"""Not being a genius, like Keats, it won't kill me,"" she said stoutly,"
514	"""and I've got the joke on my side, after all, for the parts that were"
514	taken straight out of real life are denounced as impossible and absurd,
514	and the scenes that I made up out of my own silly head are pronounced
514	'charmingly natural, tender, and true'.  So I'll comfort myself with
514	"that, and when I'm ready, I'll up again and take another."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-EIGHT
514	""
514	DOMESTIC EXPERIENCES
514	""
514	Like most other young matrons, Meg began her married life with the
514	determination to be a model housekeeper.  John should find home a
514	paradise, he should always see a smiling face, should fare sumptuously
514	every day, and never know the loss of a button.  She brought so much
514	love, energy, and cheerfulness to the work that she could not but
514	succeed, in spite of some obstacles.  Her paradise was not a tranquil
514	one, for the little woman fussed, was over-anxious to please, and
514	bustled about like a true Martha, cumbered with many cares.  She was
514	too tired, sometimes, even to smile, John grew dyspeptic after a course
514	of dainty dishes and ungratefully demanded plain fare.  As for buttons,
514	she soon learned to wonder where they went, to shake her head over the
514	carelessness of men, and to threaten to make him sew them on himself,
514	and see if his work would stand impatient and clumsy fingers any better
514	than hers.
514	""
514	They were very happy, even after they discovered that they couldn't
514	live on love alone.  John did not find Meg's beauty diminished, though
514	she beamed at him from behind the familiar coffee pot.  Nor did Meg
514	miss any of the romance from the daily parting, when her husband
514	"followed up his kiss with the tender inquiry, ""Shall I send some veal"
514	"or mutton for dinner, darling?"" The little house ceased to be a"
514	glorified bower, but it became a home, and the young couple soon felt
514	that it was a change for the better.  At first they played keep-house,
514	and frolicked over it like children.  Then John took steadily to
514	business, feeling the cares of the head of a family upon his shoulders,
514	and Meg laid by her cambric wrappers, put on a big apron, and fell to
514	work, as before said, with more energy than discretion.
514	""
514	While the cooking mania lasted she went through Mrs. Cornelius's
514	Receipt Book as if it were a mathematical exercise, working out the
514	problems with patience and care.  Sometimes her family were invited in
514	to help eat up a too bounteous feast of successes, or Lotty would be
514	privately dispatched with a batch of failures, which were to be
514	concealed from all eyes in the convenient stomachs of the little
514	Hummels.  An evening with John over the account books usually produced
514	a temporary lull in the culinary enthusiasm, and a frugal fit would
514	ensue, during which the poor man was put through a course of bread
514	pudding, hash, and warmed-over coffee, which tried his soul, although
514	he bore it with praiseworthy fortitude.  Before the golden mean was
514	found, however, Meg added to her domestic possessions what young
514	couples seldom get on long without, a family jar.
514	""
514	Fired with a housewifely wish to see her storeroom stocked with
514	homemade preserves, she undertook to put up her own currant jelly. John
514	was requested to order home a dozen or so of little pots and an extra
514	quantity of sugar, for their own currants were ripe and were to be
514	attended to at once.  As John firmly believed that 'my wife' was equal
514	to anything, and took a natural pride in her skill, he resolved that
514	she should be gratified, and their only crop of fruit laid by in a most
514	pleasing form for winter use.  Home came four dozen delightful little
514	pots, half a barrel of sugar, and a small boy to pick the currants for
514	her.  With her pretty hair tucked into a little cap, arms bared to the
514	elbow, and a checked apron which had a coquettish look in spite of the
514	bib, the young housewife fell to work, feeling no doubts about her
514	success, for hadn't she seen Hannah do it hundreds of times?  The array
514	of pots rather amazed her at first, but John was so fond of jelly, and
514	the nice little jars would look so well on the top shelf, that Meg
514	resolved to fill them all, and spent a long day picking, boiling,
514	straining, and fussing over her jelly.  She did her best, she asked
514	advice of Mrs. Cornelius, she racked her brain to remember what Hannah
514	did that she left undone, she reboiled, resugared, and restrained, but
514	that dreadful stuff wouldn't 'jell'.
514	""
514	She longed to run home, bib and all, and ask Mother to lend her a hand,
514	but John and she had agreed that they would never annoy anyone with
514	their private worries, experiments, or quarrels.  They had laughed over
514	that last word as if the idea it suggested was a most preposterous one,
514	but they had held to their resolve, and whenever they could get on
514	without help they did so, and no one interfered, for Mrs. March had
514	advised the plan.  So Meg wrestled alone with the refractory sweetmeats
514	all that hot summer day, and at five o'clock sat down in her
514	topsy-turvey kitchen, wrung her bedaubed hands, lifted up her voice and
514	wept.
514	""
514	"Now, in the first flush of the new life, she had often said, ""My"
514	husband shall always feel free to bring a friend home whenever he
514	likes.  I shall always be prepared.  There shall be no flurry, no
514	scolding, no discomfort, but a neat house, a cheerful wife, and a good
514	dinner.  John, dear, never stop to ask my leave, invite whom you
514	"please, and be sure of a welcome from me."""
514	""
514	How charming that was, to be sure!  John quite glowed with pride to
514	hear her say it, and felt what a blessed thing it was to have a
514	superior wife.  But, although they had had company from time to time,
514	it never happened to be unexpected, and Meg had never had an
514	opportunity to distinguish herself till now.  It always happens so in
514	this vale of tears, there is an inevitability about such things which
514	we can only wonder at, deplore, and bear as we best can.
514	""
514	If John had not forgotten all about the jelly, it really would have
514	been unpardonable in him to choose that day, of all the days in the
514	year, to bring a friend home to dinner unexpectedly.  Congratulating
514	himself that a handsome repast had been ordered that morning, feeling
514	sure that it would be ready to the minute, and indulging in pleasant
514	anticipations of the charming effect it would produce, when his pretty
514	wife came running out to meet him, he escorted his friend to his
514	mansion, with the irrepressible satisfaction of a young host and
514	husband.
514	""
514	It is a world of disappointments, as John discovered when he reached
514	the Dovecote.  The front door usually stood hospitably open. Now it was
514	not only shut, but locked, and yesterday's mud still adorned the steps.
514	The parlor windows were closed and curtained, no picture of the pretty
514	wife sewing on the piazza, in white, with a distracting little bow in
514	her hair, or a bright-eyed hostess, smiling a shy welcome as she
514	greeted her guest.  Nothing of the sort, for not a soul appeared but a
514	sanginary-looking boy asleep under the current bushes.
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid something has happened.  Step into the garden, Scott, while"
514	"I look up Mrs. Brooke,"" said John, alarmed at the silence and solitude."
514	""
514	Round the house he hurried, led by a pungent smell of burned sugar, and
514	Mr. Scott strolled after him, with a queer look on his face.  He paused
514	discreetly at a distance when Brooke disappeared, but he could both see
514	and hear, and being a bachelor, enjoyed the prospect mightily.
514	""
514	In the kitchen reigned confusion and despair.  One edition of jelly was
514	trickled from pot to pot, another lay upon the floor, and a third was
514	burning gaily on the stove.  Lotty, with Teutonic phlegm, was calmly
514	eating bread and currant wine, for the jelly was still in a hopelessly
514	liquid state, while Mrs. Brooke, with her apron over her head, sat
514	sobbing dismally.
514	""
514	"""My dearest girl, what is the matter?"" cried John, rushing in, with"
514	awful visions of scalded hands, sudden news of affliction, and secret
514	consternation at the thought of the guest in the garden.
514	""
514	"""Oh, John, I am so tired and hot and cross and worried!  I've been at"
514	"it till I'm all worn out.  Do come and help me or I shall die!"" and the"
514	exhausted housewife cast herself upon his breast, giving him a sweet
514	welcome in every sense of the word, for her pinafore had been baptized
514	at the same time as the floor.
514	""
514	"""What worries you dear?  Has anything dreadful happened?"" asked the"
514	anxious John, tenderly kissing the crown of the little cap, which was
514	all askew.
514	""
514	"""Yes,"" sobbed Meg despairingly."
514	""
514	"""Tell me quick, then.  Don't cry.  I can bear anything better than"
514	"that.  Out with it, love."""
514	""
514	"""The... The jelly won't jell and I don't know what to do!"""
514	""
514	John Brooke laughed then as he never dared to laugh afterward, and the
514	derisive Scott smiled involuntarily as he heard the hearty peal, which
514	put the finishing stroke to poor Meg's woe.
514	""
514	"""Is that all?  Fling it out of the window, and don't bother any more"
514	about it.  I'll buy you quarts if you want it, but for heaven's sake
514	don't have hysterics, for I've brought Jack Scott home to dinner,
514	"and..."""
514	""
514	John got no further, for Meg cast him off, and clasped her hands with a
514	tragic gesture as she fell into a chair, exclaiming in a tone of
514	mingled indignation, reproach, and dismay...
514	""
514	"""A man to dinner, and everything in a mess!  John Brooke, how could you"
514	"do such a thing?"""
514	""
514	"""Hush, he's in the garden!  I forgot the confounded jelly, but it can't"
514	"be helped now,"" said John, surveying the prospect with an anxious eye."
514	""
514	"""You ought to have sent word, or told me this morning, and you ought to"
514	"have remembered how busy I was,"" continued Meg petulantly, for even"
514	turtledoves will peck when ruffled.
514	""
514	"""I didn't know it this morning, and there was no time to send word, for"
514	I met him on the way out.  I never thought of asking leave, when you
514	have always told me to do as I liked.  I never tried it before, and
514	"hang me if I ever do again!"" added John, with an aggrieved air."
514	""
514	"""I should hope not!  Take him away at once.  I can't see him, and there"
514	"isn't any dinner."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I like that!  Where's the beef and vegetables I sent home, and"
514	"the pudding you promised?"" cried John, rushing to the larder."
514	""
514	"""I hadn't time to cook anything.  I meant to dine at Mother's. I'm"
514	"sorry, but I was so busy,"" and Meg's tears began again."
514	""
514	John was a mild man, but he was human, and after a long day's work to
514	come home tired, hungry, and hopeful, to find a chaotic house, an empty
514	table, and a cross wife was not exactly conducive to repose of mind or
514	manner.  He restrained himself however, and the little squall would
514	have blown over, but for one unlucky word.
514	""
514	"""It's a scrape, I acknowledge, but if you will lend a hand, we'll pull"
514	through and have a good time yet.  Don't cry, dear, but just exert
514	yourself a bit, and fix us up something to eat.  We're both as hungry
514	as hunters, so we shan't mind what it is.  Give us the cold meat, and
514	"bread and cheese.  We won't ask for jelly."""
514	""
514	He meant it to be a good-natured joke, but that one word sealed his
514	fate.  Meg thought it was too cruel to hint about her sad failure, and
514	the last atom of patience vanished as he spoke.
514	""
514	"""You must get yourself out of the scrape as you can.  I'm too used up"
514	to 'exert' myself for anyone.  It's like a man to propose a bone and
514	vulgar bread and cheese for company.  I won't have anything of the sort
514	in my house.  Take that Scott up to Mother's, and tell him I'm away,
514	sick, dead, anything.  I won't see him, and you two can laugh at me and
514	"my jelly as much as you like.  You won't have anything else here.""  and"
514	having delivered her defiance all on one breath, Meg cast away her
514	pinafore and precipitately left the field to bemoan herself in her own
514	room.
514	""
514	What those two creatures did in her absence, she never knew, but Mr.
514	Scott was not taken 'up to Mother's', and when Meg descended, after
514	they had strolled away together, she found traces of a promiscuous
514	lunch which filled her with horror.  Lotty reported that they had eaten
514	"""a much, and greatly laughed, and the master bid her throw away all the"
514	"sweet stuff, and hide the pots."""
514	""
514	Meg longed to go and tell Mother, but a sense of shame at her own
514	"short-comings, of loyalty to John, ""who might be cruel, but nobody"
514	"should know it,"" restrained her, and after a summary cleaning up, she"
514	dressed herself prettily, and sat down to wait for John to come and be
514	forgiven.
514	""
514	Unfortunately, John didn't come, not seeing the matter in that light.
514	He had carried it off as a good joke with Scott, excused his little
514	wife as well as he could, and played the host so hospitably that his
514	friend enjoyed the impromptu dinner, and promised to come again, but
514	John was angry, though he did not show it, he felt that Meg had
514	"deserted him in his hour of need.  ""It wasn't fair to tell a man to"
514	bring folks home any time, with perfect freedom, and when he took you
514	at your word, to flame up and blame him, and leave him in the lurch, to
514	be laughed at or pitied.  No, by George, it wasn't! And Meg must know
514	"it."""
514	""
514	He had fumed inwardly during the feast, but when the flurry was over
514	and he strolled home after seeing Scott off, a milder mood came over
514	"him.  ""Poor little thing!  It was hard upon her when she tried so"
514	heartily to please me.  She was wrong, of course, but then she was
514	"young.  I must be patient and teach her.""  He hoped she had not gone"
514	home--he hated gossip and interference.  For a minute he was ruffled
514	again at the mere thought of it, and then the fear that Meg would cry
514	herself sick softened his heart, and sent him on at a quicker pace,
514	resolving to be calm and kind, but firm, quite firm, and show her where
514	she had failed in her duty to her spouse.
514	""
514	Meg likewise resolved to be 'calm and kind, but firm', and show him his
514	duty.  She longed to run to meet him, and beg pardon, and be kissed and
514	comforted, as she was sure of being, but, of course, she did nothing of
514	the sort, and when she saw John coming, began to hum quite naturally,
514	as she rocked and sewed, like a lady of leisure in her best parlor.
514	""
514	John was a little disappointed not to find a tender Niobe, but feeling
514	that his dignity demanded the first apology, he made none, only came
514	leisurely in and laid himself upon the sofa with the singularly
514	"relevant remark, ""We are going to have a new moon, my dear."""
514	""
514	"""I've no objection,"" was Meg's equally soothing remark.  A few other"
514	topics of general interest were introduced by Mr. Brooke and
514	wet-blanketed by Mrs. Brooke, and conversation languished.  John went
514	to one window, unfolded his paper, and wrapped himself in it,
514	figuratively speaking.  Meg went to the other window, and sewed as if
514	new rosettes for slippers were among the necessaries of life. Neither
514	spoke.  Both looked quite 'calm and firm', and both felt desperately
514	uncomfortable.
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear,"" thought Meg, ""married life is very trying, and does need"
514	"infinite patience as well as love, as Mother says.""  The word 'Mother'"
514	suggested other maternal counsels given long ago, and received with
514	unbelieving protests.
514	""
514	"""John is a good man, but he has his faults, and you must learn to see"
514	and bear with them, remembering your own.  He is very decided, but
514	never will be obstinate, if you reason kindly, not oppose impatiently.
514	He is very accurate, and particular about the truth--a good trait,
514	though you call him 'fussy'. Never deceive him by look or word, Meg,
514	and he will give you the confidence you deserve, the support you need.
514	He has a temper, not like ours--one flash and then all over--but the
514	white, still anger that is seldom stirred, but once kindled is hard to
514	quench.  Be careful, be very careful, not to wake his anger against
514	yourself, for peace and happiness depend on keeping his respect.  Watch
514	yourself, be the first to ask pardon if you both err, and guard against
514	the little piques, misunderstandings, and hasty words that often pave
514	"the way for bitter sorrow and regret."""
514	""
514	These words came back to Meg, as she sat sewing in the sunset,
514	especially the last.  This was the first serious disagreement, her own
514	hasty speeches sounded both silly and unkind, as she recalled them, her
514	own anger looked childish now, and thoughts of poor John coming home to
514	such a scene quite melted her heart.  She glanced at him with tears in
514	her eyes, but he did not see them.  She put down her work and got up,
514	"thinking, ""I will be the first to say, 'Forgive me'"", but he did not"
514	seem to hear her.  She went very slowly across the room, for pride was
514	hard to swallow, and stood by him, but he did not turn his head.  For a
514	minute she felt as if she really couldn't do it, then came the thought,
514	"""This is the beginning. I'll do my part, and have nothing to reproach"
514	"myself with,"" and stooping down, she softly kissed her husband on the"
514	forehead. Of course that settled it.  The penitent kiss was better than
514	a world of words, and John had her on his knee in a minute, saying
514	tenderly...
514	""
514	"""It was too bad to laugh at the poor little jelly pots. Forgive me,"
514	"dear.  I never will again!"""
514	""
514	But he did, oh bless you, yes, hundreds of times, and so did Meg, both
514	declaring that it was the sweetest jelly they ever made, for family
514	peace was preserved in that little family jar.
514	""
514	After this, Meg had Mr. Scott to dinner by special invitation, and
514	served him up a pleasant feast without a cooked wife for the first
514	course, on which occasion she was so gay and gracious, and made
514	everything go off so charmingly, that Mr. Scott told John he was a
514	lucky fellow, and shook his head over the hardships of bachelorhood all
514	the way home.
514	""
514	In the autumn, new trials and experiences came to Meg.  Sallie Moffat
514	renewed her friendship, was always running out for a dish of gossip at
514	the little house, or inviting 'that poor dear' to come in and spend the
514	day at the big house.  It was pleasant, for in dull weather Meg often
514	felt lonely.  All were busy at home, John absent till night, and
514	nothing to do but sew, or read, or potter about.  So it naturally fell
514	out that Meg got into the way of gadding and gossiping with her friend.
514	Seeing Sallie's pretty things made her long for such, and pity herself
514	because she had not got them.  Sallie was very kind, and often offered
514	her the coveted trifles, but Meg declined them, knowing that John
514	wouldn't like it, and then this foolish little woman went and did what
514	John disliked even worse.
514	""
514	She knew her husband's income, and she loved to feel that he trusted
514	her, not only with his happiness, but what some men seem to value
514	more--his money.  She knew where it was, was free to take what she
514	liked, and all he asked was that she should keep account of every
514	penny, pay bills once a month, and remember that she was a poor man's
514	wife.  Till now she had done well, been prudent and exact, kept her
514	little account books neatly, and showed them to him monthly without
514	fear.  But that autumn the serpent got into Meg's paradise, and tempted
514	her like many a modern Eve, not with apples, but with dress.  Meg
514	didn't like to be pitied and made to feel poor.  It irritated her, but
514	she was ashamed to confess it, and now and then she tried to console
514	herself by buying something pretty, so that Sallie needn't think she
514	had to economize.  She always felt wicked after it, for the pretty
514	things were seldom necessaries, but then they cost so little, it wasn't
514	worth worrying about, so the trifles increased unconsciously, and in
514	the shopping excursions she was no longer a passive looker-on.
514	""
514	But the trifles cost more than one would imagine, and when she cast up
514	her accounts at the end of the month the sum total rather scared her.
514	John was busy that month and left the bills to her, the next month he
514	was absent, but the third he had a grand quarterly settling up, and Meg
514	never forgot it.  A few days before she had done a dreadful thing, and
514	it weighed upon her conscience.  Sallie had been buying silks, and Meg
514	longed for a new one, just a handsome light one for parties, her black
514	silk was so common, and thin things for evening wear were only proper
514	for girls.  Aunt March usually gave the sisters a present of
514	twenty-five dollars apiece at New Year's.  That was only a month to
514	wait, and here was a lovely violet silk going at a bargain, and she had
514	the money, if she only dared to take it.  John always said what was his
514	was hers, but would he think it right to spend not only the prospective
514	five-and-twenty, but another five-and-twenty out of the household fund?
514	That was the question. Sallie had urged her to do it, had offered to
514	lend the money, and with the best intentions in life had tempted Meg
514	beyond her strength. In an evil moment the shopman held up the lovely,
514	"shimmering folds, and said, ""A bargain, I assure, you, ma'am."" She"
514	"answered, ""I'll take it,"" and it was cut off and paid for, and Sallie"
514	had exulted, and she had laughed as if it were a thing of no
514	consequence, and driven away, feeling as if she had stolen something,
514	and the police were after her.
514	""
514	When she got home, she tried to assuage the pangs of remorse by
514	spreading forth the lovely silk, but it looked less silvery now, didn't
514	become her, after all, and the words 'fifty dollars' seemed stamped
514	like a pattern down each breadth.  She put it away, but it haunted her,
514	not delightfully as a new dress should, but dreadfully like the ghost
514	of a folly that was not easily laid.  When John got out his books that
514	night, Meg's heart sank, and for the first time in her married life,
514	she was afraid of her husband.  The kind, brown eyes looked as if they
514	could be stern, and though he was unusually merry, she fancied he had
514	found her out, but didn't mean to let her know it.  The house bills
514	were all paid, the books all in order. John had praised her, and was
514	undoing the old pocketbook which they called the 'bank', when Meg,
514	knowing that it was quite empty, stopped his hand, saying nervously...
514	""
514	"""You haven't seen my private expense book yet."""
514	""
514	John never asked to see it, but she always insisted on his doing so,
514	and used to enjoy his masculine amazement at the queer things women
514	wanted, and made him guess what piping was, demand fiercely the meaning
514	of a hug-me-tight, or wonder how a little thing composed of three
514	rosebuds, a bit of velvet, and a pair of strings, could possibly be a
514	bonnet, and cost six dollars.  That night he looked as if he would like
514	the fun of quizzing her figures and pretending to be horrified at her
514	extravagance, as he often did, being particularly proud of his prudent
514	wife.
514	""
514	The little book was brought slowly out and laid down before him. Meg
514	got behind his chair under pretense of smoothing the wrinkles out of
514	his tired forehead, and standing there, she said, with her panic
514	increasing with every word...
514	""
514	"""John, dear, I'm ashamed to show you my book, for I've really been"
514	dreadfully extravagant lately.  I go about so much I must have things,
514	you know, and Sallie advised my getting it, so I did, and my New Year's
514	money will partly pay for it, but I was sorry after I had done it, for
514	"I knew you'd think it wrong in me."""
514	""
514	John laughed, and drew her round beside him, saying goodhumoredly,
514	"""Don't go and hide.  I won't beat you if you have got a pair of killing"
514	boots.  I'm rather proud of my wife's feet, and don't mind if she does
514	"pay eight or nine dollars for her boots, if they are good ones."""
514	""
514	That had been one of her last 'trifles', and John's eye had fallen on
514	"it as he spoke.  ""Oh, what will he say when he comes to that awful"
514	"fifty dollars!"" thought Meg, with a shiver."
514	""
514	"""It's worse than boots, it's a silk dress,"" she said, with the calmness"
514	of desperation, for she wanted the worst over.
514	""
514	"""Well, dear, what is the 'dem'd total', as Mr. Mantalini says?"""
514	""
514	That didn't sound like John, and she knew he was looking up at her with
514	the straightforward look that she had always been ready to meet and
514	answer with one as frank till now.  She turned the page and her head at
514	the same time, pointing to the sum which would have been bad enough
514	without the fifty, but which was appalling to her with that added.  For
514	a minute the room was very still, then John said slowly--but she could
514	feel it cost him an effort to express no displeasure--. . .
514	""
514	"""Well, I don't know that fifty is much for a dress, with all the"
514	"furbelows and notions you have to have to finish it off these days."""
514	""
514	"""It isn't made or trimmed,"" sighed Meg, faintly, for a sudden"
514	recollection of the cost still to be incurred quite overwhelmed her.
514	""
514	"""Twenty-five yards of silk seems a good deal to cover one small woman,"
514	but I've no doubt my wife will look as fine as Ned Moffat's when she
514	"gets it on,"" said John dryly."
514	""
514	"""I know you are angry, John, but I can't help it.  I don't mean to"
514	waste your money, and I didn't think those little things would count up
514	so.  I can't resist them when I see Sallie buying all she wants, and
514	pitying me because I don't.  I try to be contented, but it is hard, and
514	"I'm tired of being poor."""
514	""
514	The last words were spoken so low she thought he did not hear them, but
514	he did, and they wounded him deeply, for he had denied himself many
514	pleasures for Meg's sake.  She could have bitten her tongue out the
514	minute she had said it, for John pushed the books away and got up,
514	"saying with a little quiver in his voice, ""I was afraid of this.  I do"
514	"my best, Meg.""  If he had scolded her, or even shaken her, it would not"
514	have broken her heart like those few words.  She ran to him and held
514	"him close, crying, with repentant tears, ""Oh, John, my dear, kind,"
514	hard-working boy.  I didn't mean it!  It was so wicked, so untrue and
514	"ungrateful, how could I say it! Oh, how could I say it!"""
514	""
514	He was very kind, forgave her readily, and did not utter one reproach,
514	but Meg knew that she had done and said a thing which would not be
514	forgotten soon, although he might never allude to it again.  She had
514	promised to love him for better or worse, and then she, his wife, had
514	reproached him with his poverty, after spending his earnings
514	recklessly.  It was dreadful, and the worst of it was John went on so
514	quietly afterward, just as if nothing had happened, except that he
514	stayed in town later, and worked at night when she had gone to cry
514	herself to sleep.  A week of remorse nearly made Meg sick, and the
514	discovery that John had countermanded the order for his new greatcoat
514	reduced her to a state of despair which was pathetic to behold.  He had
514	"simply said, in answer to her surprised inquiries as to the change, ""I"
514	"can't afford it, my dear."""
514	""
514	Meg said no more, but a few minutes after he found her in the hall with
514	her face buried in the old greatcoat, crying as if her heart would
514	break.
514	""
514	They had a long talk that night, and Meg learned to love her husband
514	better for his poverty, because it seemed to have made a man of him,
514	given him the strength and courage to fight his own way, and taught him
514	a tender patience with which to bear and comfort the natural longings
514	and failures of those he loved.
514	""
514	Next day she put her pride in her pocket, went to Sallie, told the
514	truth, and asked her to buy the silk as a favor.  The good-natured Mrs.
514	Moffat willingly did so, and had the delicacy not to make her a present
514	of it immediately afterward.  Then Meg ordered home the greatcoat, and
514	when John arrived, she put it on, and asked him how he liked her new
514	silk gown.  One can imagine what answer he made, how he received his
514	present, and what a blissful state of things ensued.  John came home
514	early, Meg gadded no more, and that greatcoat was put on in the morning
514	by a very happy husband, and taken off at night by a most devoted
514	little wife.  So the year rolled round, and at midsummer there came to
514	Meg a new experience, the deepest and tenderest of a woman's life.
514	""
514	Laurie came sneaking into the kitchen of the Dovecote one Saturday,
514	with an excited face, and was received with the clash of cymbals, for
514	Hannah clapped her hands with a saucepan in one and the cover in the
514	other.
514	""
514	"""How's the little mamma?  Where is everybody?  Why didn't you tell me"
514	"before I came home?"" began Laurie in a loud whisper."
514	""
514	"""Happy as a queen, the dear!  Every soul of 'em is upstairs a"
514	worshipin'.  We didn't want no hurrycanes round.  Now you go into the
514	"parlor, and I'll send 'em down to you,"" with which somewhat involved"
514	reply Hannah vanished, chuckling ecstatically.
514	""
514	Presently Jo appeared, proudly bearing a flannel bundle laid forth upon
514	a large pillow.  Jo's face was very sober, but her eyes twinkled, and
514	there was an odd sound in her voice of repressed emotion of some sort.
514	""
514	"""Shut your eyes and hold out your arms,"" she said invitingly."
514	""
514	Laurie backed precipitately into a corner, and put his hands behind him
514	"with an imploring gesture.  ""No, thank you.  I'd rather not.  I shall"
514	"drop it or smash it, as sure as fate."""
514	""
514	"""Then you shan't see your nevvy,"" said Jo decidedly, turning as if to"
514	go.
514	""
514	"""I will, I will!  Only you must be responsible for damages."" and"
514	obeying orders, Laurie heroically shut his eyes while something was put
514	into his arms.  A peal of laughter from Jo, Amy, Mrs. March, Hannah,
514	and John caused him to open them the next minute, to find himself
514	invested with two babies instead of one.
514	""
514	No wonder they laughed, for the expression of his face was droll enough
514	to convulse a Quaker, as he stood and stared wildly from the
514	unconscious innocents to the hilarious spectators with such dismay that
514	Jo sat down on the floor and screamed.
514	""
514	"""Twins, by Jupiter!"" was all he said for a minute, then turning to the"
514	women with an appealing look that was comically piteous, he added,
514	"""Take 'em quick, somebody!  I'm going to laugh, and I shall drop 'em."""
514	""
514	Jo rescued his babies, and marched up and down, with one on each arm,
514	as if already initiated into the mysteries of babytending, while Laurie
514	laughed till the tears ran down his cheeks.
514	""
514	"""It's the best joke of the season, isn't it?  I wouldn't have told you,"
514	for I set my heart on surprising you, and I flatter myself I've done
514	"it,"" said Jo, when she got her breath."
514	""
514	"""I never was more staggered in my life.  Isn't it fun?  Are they boys?"
514	What are you going to name them? Let's have another look.  Hold me up,
514	"Jo, for upon my life it's one too many for me,"" returned Laurie,"
514	regarding the infants with the air of a big, benevolent Newfoundland
514	looking at a pair of infantile kittens.
514	""
514	"""Boy and girl.  Aren't they beauties?"" said the proud papa, beaming"
514	upon the little red squirmers as if they were unfledged angels.
514	""
514	"""Most remarkable children I ever saw.  Which is which?"" and Laurie bent"
514	like a well-sweep to examine the prodigies.
514	""
514	"""Amy put a blue ribbon on the boy and a pink on the girl, French"
514	fashion, so you can always tell.  Besides, one has blue eyes and one
514	"brown.  Kiss them, Uncle Teddy,"" said wicked Jo."
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid they mightn't like it,"" began Laurie, with unusual timidity"
514	in such matters.
514	""
514	"""Of course they will, they are used to it now.  Do it this minute,"
514	"sir!"" commanded Jo, fearing he might propose a proxy."
514	""
514	Laurie screwed up his face and obeyed with a gingerly peck at each
514	little cheek that produced another laugh, and made the babies squeal.
514	""
514	"""There, I knew they didn't like it!  That's the boy, see him kick, he"
514	hits out with his fists like a good one.  Now then, young Brooke, pitch
514	"into a man of your own size, will you?"" cried Laurie, delighted with a"
514	poke in the face from a tiny fist, flapping aimlessly about.
514	""
514	"""He's to be named John Laurence, and the girl Margaret, after mother"
514	and grandmother.  We shall call her Daisey, so as not to have two Megs,
514	"and I suppose the mannie will be Jack, unless we find a better name,"""
514	said Amy, with aunt-like interest.
514	""
514	"""Name him Demijohn, and call him Demi for short,"" said Laurie."
514	""
514	"""Daisy and Demi, just the thing!  I knew Teddy would do it,"" cried Jo"
514	clapping her hands.
514	""
514	Teddy certainly had done it that time, for the babies were 'Daisy' and
514	'Demi' to the end of the chapter.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER TWENTY-NINE
514	""
514	CALLS
514	""
514	"""Come, Jo, it's time."""
514	""
514	"""For what?"""
514	""
514	"""You don't mean to say you have forgotten that you promised to make"
514	"half a dozen calls with me today?"""
514	""
514	"""I've done a good many rash and foolish things in my life, but I don't"
514	think I ever was mad enough to say I'd make six calls in one day, when
514	"a single one upsets me for a week."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, you did, it was a bargain between us.  I was to finish the crayon"
514	of Beth for you, and you were to go properly with me, and return our
514	"neighbors' visits."""
514	""
514	"""If it was fair, that was in the bond, and I stand to the letter of my"
514	bond, Shylock.  There is a pile of clouds in the east, it's not fair,
514	"and I don't go."""
514	""
514	"""Now, that's shirking.  It's a lovely day, no prospect of rain, and you"
514	pride yourself on keeping promises, so be honorable, come and do your
514	"duty, and then be at peace for another six months."""
514	""
514	At that minute Jo was particularly absorbed in dressmaking, for she was
514	mantua-maker general to the family, and took especial credit to herself
514	because she could use a needle as well as a pen. It was very provoking
514	to be arrested in the act of a first trying-on, and ordered out to make
514	calls in her best array on a warm July day. She hated calls of the
514	formal sort, and never made any till Amy compelled her with a bargain,
514	bribe, or promise.  In the present instance there was no escape, and
514	having clashed her scissors rebelliously, while protesting that she
514	smelled thunder, she gave in, put away her work, and taking up her hat
514	and gloves with an air of resignation, told Amy the victim was ready.
514	""
514	"""Jo March, you are perverse enough to provoke a saint!  You don't"
514	"intend to make calls in that state, I hope,"" cried Amy, surveying her"
514	with amazement.
514	""
514	"""Why not?  I'm neat and cool and comfortable, quite proper for a dusty"
514	walk on a warm day.  If people care more for my clothes than they do
514	for me, I don't wish to see them.  You can dress for both, and be as
514	elegant as you please.  It pays for you to be fine.  It doesn't for me,
514	"and furbelows only worry me."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, dear!"" sighed Amy, ""now she's in a contrary fit, and will drive me"
514	distracted before I can get her properly ready. I'm sure it's no
514	pleasure to me to go today, but it's a debt we owe society, and there's
514	no one to pay it but you and me.  I'll do anything for you, Jo, if
514	you'll only dress yourself nicely, and come and help me do the civil.
514	You can talk so well, look so aristocratic in your best things, and
514	behave so beautifully, if you try, that I'm proud of you.  I'm afraid
514	"to go alone, do come and take care of me."""
514	""
514	"""You're an artful little puss to flatter and wheedle your cross old"
514	sister in that way.  The idea of my being aristocratic and well-bred,
514	and your being afraid to go anywhere alone!  I don't know which is the
514	most absurd.  Well, I'll go if I must, and do my best.  You shall be
514	commander of the expedition, and I'll obey blindly, will that satisfy
514	"you?"" said Jo, with a sudden change from perversity to lamblike"
514	submission.
514	""
514	"""You're a perfect cherub!  Now put on all your best things, and I'll"
514	tell you how to behave at each place, so that you will make a good
514	impression.  I want people to like you, and they would if you'd only
514	try to be a little more agreeable.  Do your hair the pretty way, and
514	put the pink rose in your bonnet.  It's becoming, and you look too
514	sober in your plain suit.  Take your light gloves and the embroidered
514	handkerchief.  We'll stop at Meg's, and borrow her white sunshade, and
514	"then you can have my dove-colored one."""
514	""
514	While Amy dressed, she issued her orders, and Jo obeyed them, not
514	without entering her protest, however, for she sighed as she rustled
514	into her new organdie, frowned darkly at herself as she tied her bonnet
514	strings in an irreproachable bow, wrestled viciously with pins as she
514	put on her collar, wrinkled up her features generally as she shook out
514	the handkerchief, whose embroidery was as irritating to her nose as the
514	present mission was to her feelings, and when she had squeezed her
514	hands into tight gloves with three buttons and a tassel, as the last
514	touch of elegance, she turned to Amy with an imbecile expression of
514	countenance, saying meekly...
514	""
514	"""I'm perfectly miserable, but if you consider me presentable, I die"
514	"happy."""
514	""
514	"""You're highly satisfactory.  Turn slowly round, and let me get a"
514	"careful view."" Jo revolved, and Amy gave a touch here and there, then"
514	"fell back, with her head on one side, observing graciously, ""Yes,"
514	you'll do.  Your head is all I could ask, for that white bonnet with
514	the rose is quite ravishing.  Hold back your shoulders, and carry your
514	hands easily, no matter if your gloves do pinch.  There's one thing you
514	can do well, Jo, that is, wear a shawl.  I can't, but it's very nice to
514	see you, and I'm so glad Aunt March gave you that lovely one.  It's
514	simple, but handsome, and those folds over the arm are really artistic.
514	Is the point of my mantle in the middle, and have I looped my dress
514	evenly? I like to show my boots, for my feet are pretty, though my nose
514	"isn't."""
514	""
514	"""You are a thing of beauty and a joy forever,"" said Jo, looking through"
514	her hand with the air of a connoisseur at the blue feather against the
514	"golden hair.  ""Am I to drag my best dress through the dust, or loop it"
514	"up, please, ma'am?"""
514	""
514	"""Hold it up when you walk, but drop it in the house.  The sweeping"
514	style suits you best, and you must learn to trail your skirts
514	gracefully.  You haven't half buttoned one cuff, do it at once.  You'll
514	never look finished if you are not careful about the little details,
514	"for they make up the pleasing whole."""
514	""
514	Jo sighed, and proceeded to burst the buttons off her glove, in doing
514	up her cuff, but at last both were ready, and sailed away, looking as
514	'pretty as picters', Hannah said, as she hung out of the upper window
514	to watch them.
514	""
514	"""Now, Jo dear, the Chesters consider themselves very elegant people, so"
514	I want you to put on your best deportment.  Don't make any of your
514	abrupt remarks, or do anything odd, will you?  Just be calm, cool, and
514	quiet, that's safe and ladylike, and you can easily do it for fifteen
514	"minutes,"" said Amy, as they approached the first place, having borrowed"
514	the white parasol and been inspected by Meg, with a baby on each arm.
514	""
514	"""Let me see.  'Calm, cool, and quiet', yes, I think I can promise that."
514	I've played the part of a prim young lady on the stage, and I'll try it
514	off.  My powers are great, as you shall see, so be easy in your mind,
514	"my child."""
514	""
514	Amy looked relieved, but naughty Jo took her at her word, for during
514	the first call she sat with every limb gracefully composed, every fold
514	correctly draped, calm as a summer sea, cool as a snowbank, and as
514	silent as the sphinx.  In vain Mrs. Chester alluded to her 'charming
514	novel', and the Misses Chester introduced parties, picnics, the opera,
514	and the fashions.  Each and all were answered by a smile, a bow, and a
514	"demure ""Yes"" or ""No"" with the chill on.  In vain Amy telegraphed the"
514	word 'talk', tried to draw her out, and administered covert pokes with
514	her foot.  Jo sat as if blandly unconscious of it all, with deportment
514	like Maud's face, 'icily regular, splendidly null'.
514	""
514	"""What a haughty, uninteresting creature that oldest Miss March is!"" was"
514	the unfortunately audible remark of one of the ladies, as the door
514	closed upon their guests.  Jo laughed noiselessly all through the hall,
514	but Amy looked disgusted at the failure of her instructions, and very
514	naturally laid the blame upon Jo.
514	""
514	"""How could you mistake me so?  I merely meant you to be properly"
514	dignified and composed, and you made yourself a perfect stock and
514	stone.  Try to be sociable at the Lambs'.  Gossip as other girls do,
514	and be interested in dress and flirtations and whatever nonsense comes
514	up.  They move in the best society, are valuable persons for us to
514	"know, and I wouldn't fail to make a good impression there for anything."""
514	""
514	"""I'll be agreeable.  I'll gossip and giggle, and have horrors and"
514	raptures over any trifle you like.  I rather enjoy this, and now I'll
514	imitate what is called 'a charming girl'.  I can do it, for I have May
514	Chester as a model, and I'll improve upon her.  See if the Lambs don't
514	"say, 'What a lively, nice creature that Jo March is!"""
514	""
514	Amy felt anxious, as well she might, for when Jo turned freakish there
514	was no knowing where she would stop.  Amy's face was a study when she
514	saw her sister skim into the next drawing room, kiss all the young
514	ladies with effusion, beam graciously upon the young gentlemen, and
514	join in the chat with a spirit which amazed the beholder. Amy was taken
514	possession of by Mrs. Lamb, with whom she was a favorite, and forced to
514	hear a long account of Lucretia's last attack, while three delightful
514	young gentlemen hovered near, waiting for a pause when they might rush
514	in and rescue her.  So situated, she was powerless to check Jo, who
514	seemed possessed by a spirit of mischief, and talked away as volubly as
514	the lady.  A knot of heads gathered about her, and Amy strained her
514	ears to hear what was going on, for broken sentences filled her with
514	curiosity, and frequent peals of laughter made her wild to share the
514	fun.  One may imagine her suffering on overhearing fragments of this
514	sort of conversation.
514	""
514	"""She rides splendidly.  Who taught her?"""
514	""
514	"""No one.  She used to practice mounting, holding the reins, and sitting"
514	straight on an old saddle in a tree.  Now she rides anything, for she
514	doesn't know what fear is, and the stableman lets her have horses cheap
514	because she trains them to carry ladies so well.  She has such a
514	passion for it, I often tell her if everything else fails, she can be a
514	"horsebreaker, and get her living so."""
514	""
514	At this awful speech Amy contained herself with difficulty, for the
514	impression was being given that she was rather a fast young lady, which
514	was her especial aversion.  But what could she do?  For the old lady
514	was in the middle of her story, and long before it was done, Jo was off
514	again, making more droll revelations and committing still more fearful
514	blunders.
514	""
514	"""Yes, Amy was in despair that day, for all the good beasts were gone,"
514	and of three left, one was lame, one blind, and the other so balky that
514	you had to put dirt in his mouth before he would start. Nice animal for
514	"a pleasure party, wasn't it?"""
514	""
514	"""Which did she choose?"" asked one of the laughing gentlemen, who"
514	enjoyed the subject.
514	""
514	"""None of them.  She heard of a young horse at the farm house over the"
514	river, and though a lady had never ridden him, she resolved to try,
514	because he was handsome and spirited.  Her struggles were really
514	pathetic.  There was no one to bring the horse to the saddle, so she
514	took the saddle to the horse.  My dear creature, she actually rowed it
514	over the river, put it on her head, and marched up to the barn to the
514	"utter amazement of the old man!"""
514	""
514	"""Did she ride the horse?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course she did, and had a capital time.  I expected to see her"
514	brought home in fragments, but she managed him perfectly, and was the
514	"life of the party."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I call that plucky!"" and young Mr. Lamb turned an approving"
514	glance upon Amy, wondering what his mother could be saying to make the
514	girl look so red and uncomfortable.
514	""
514	She was still redder and more uncomfortable a moment after, when a
514	sudden turn in the conversation introduced the subject of dress.  One
514	of the young ladies asked Jo where she got the pretty drab hat she wore
514	to the picnic and stupid Jo, instead of mentioning the place where it
514	was bought two years ago, must needs answer with unnecessary frankness,
514	"""Oh, Amy painted it.  You can't buy those soft shades, so we paint ours"
514	"any color we like.  It's a great comfort to have an artistic sister."""
514	""
514	"""Isn't that an original idea?"" cried Miss Lamb, who found Jo great fun."
514	""
514	"""That's nothing compared to some of her brilliant performances. There's"
514	nothing the child can't do.  Why, she wanted a pair of blue boots for
514	Sallie's party, so she just painted her soiled white ones the loveliest
514	"shade of sky blue you ever saw, and they looked exactly like satin,"""
514	added Jo, with an air of pride in her sister's accomplishments that
514	exasperated Amy till she felt that it would be a relief to throw her
514	cardcase at her.
514	""
514	"""We read a story of yours the other day, and enjoyed it very much,"""
514	observed the elder Miss Lamb, wishing to compliment the literary lady,
514	who did not look the character just then, it must be confessed.
514	""
514	Any mention of her 'works' always had a bad effect upon Jo, who either
514	grew rigid and looked offended, or changed the subject with a brusque
514	"remark, as now.  ""Sorry you could find nothing better to read.  I write"
514	that rubbish because it sells, and ordinary people like it.  Are you
514	"going to New York this winter?"""
514	""
514	As Miss Lamb had 'enjoyed' the story, this speech was not exactly
514	grateful or complimentary.  The minute it was made Jo saw her mistake,
514	but fearing to make the matter worse, suddenly remembered that it was
514	for her to make the first move toward departure, and did so with an
514	abruptness that left three people with half-finished sentences in their
514	mouths.
514	""
514	"""Amy, we must go.  Good-by, dear, do come and see us.  We are pining"
