514	for a visit.  I don't dare to ask you, Mr. Lamb, but if you should
514	"come, I don't think I shall have the heart to send you away."""
514	""
514	Jo said this with such a droll imitation of May Chester's gushing style
514	that Amy got out of the room as rapidly as possible, feeling a strong
514	desire to laugh and cry at the same time.
514	""
514	"""Didn't I do well?"" asked Jo, with a satisfied air as they walked away."
514	""
514	"""Nothing could have been worse,"" was Amy's crushing reply. ""What"
514	possessed you to tell those stories about my saddle, and the hats and
514	"boots, and all the rest of it?"""
514	""
514	"""Why, it's funny, and amuses people.  They know we are poor, so it's no"
514	use pretending that we have grooms, buy three or four hats a season,
514	"and have things as easy and fine as they do."""
514	""
514	"""You needn't go and tell them all our little shifts, and expose our"
514	poverty in that perfectly unnecessary way.  You haven't a bit of proper
514	pride, and never will learn when to hold your tongue and when to
514	"speak,"" said Amy despairingly."
514	""
514	Poor Jo looked abashed, and silently chafed the end of her nose with
514	the stiff handkerchief, as if performing a penance for her misdemeanors.
514	""
514	"""How shall I behave here?"" she asked, as they approached the third"
514	mansion.
514	""
514	"""Just as you please.  I wash my hands of you,"" was Amy's short answer."
514	""
514	"""Then I'll enjoy myself.  The boys are at home, and we'll have a"
514	comfortable time.  Goodness knows I need a little change, for elegance
514	"has a bad effect upon my constitution,"" returned Jo gruffly, being"
514	disturbed by her failure to suit.
514	""
514	An enthusiastic welcome from three big boys and several pretty children
514	speedily soothed her ruffled feelings, and leaving Amy to entertain the
514	hostess and Mr. Tudor, who happened to be calling likewise, Jo devoted
514	herself to the young folks and found the change refreshing.  She
514	listened to college stories with deep interest, caressed pointers and
514	"poodles without a murmur, agreed heartily that ""Tom Brown was a brick,"""
514	regardless of the improper form of praise, and when one lad proposed a
514	visit to his turtle tank, she went with an alacrity which caused Mamma
514	to smile upon her, as that motherly lady settled the cap which was left
514	in a ruinous condition by filial hugs, bearlike but affectionate, and
514	dearer to her than the most faultless coiffure from the hands of an
514	inspired Frenchwoman.
514	""
514	Leaving her sister to her own devices, Amy proceeded to enjoy herself
514	to her heart's content.  Mr. Tudor's uncle had married an English lady
514	who was third cousin to a living lord, and Amy regarded the whole
514	family with great respect, for in spite of her American birth and
514	breeding, she possessed that reverence for titles which haunts the best
514	of us--that unacknowledged loyalty to the early faith in kings which
514	set the most democratic nation under the sun in ferment at the coming
514	of a royal yellow-haired laddie, some years ago, and which still has
514	something to do with the love the young country bears the old, like
514	that of a big son for an imperious little mother, who held him while
514	she could, and let him go with a farewell scolding when he rebelled.
514	But even the satisfaction of talking with a distant connection of the
514	British nobility did not render Amy forgetful of time, and when the
514	proper number of minutes had passed, she reluctantly tore herself from
514	this aristocratic society, and looked about for Jo, fervently hoping
514	that her incorrigible sister would not be found in any position which
514	should bring disgrace upon the name of March.
514	""
514	It might have been worse, but Amy considered it bad.  For Jo sat on the
514	grass, with an encampment of boys about her, and a dirty-footed dog
514	reposing on the skirt of her state and festival dress, as she related
514	one of Laurie's pranks to her admiring audience.  One small child was
514	poking turtles with Amy's cherished parasol, a second was eating
514	gingerbread over Jo's best bonnet, and a third playing ball with her
514	gloves, but all were enjoying themselves, and when Jo collected her
514	damaged property to go, her escort accompanied her, begging her to come
514	"again, ""It was such fun to hear about Laurie's larks."""
514	""
514	"""Capital boys, aren't they?  I feel quite young and brisk again after"
514	"that."" said Jo, strolling along with her hands behind her, partly from"
514	habit, partly to conceal the bespattered parasol.
514	""
514	"""Why do you always avoid Mr. Tudor?"" asked Amy, wisely refraining from"
514	any comment upon Jo's dilapidated appearance.
514	""
514	"""Don't like him, he puts on airs, snubs his sisters, worries his"
514	father, and doesn't speak respectfully of his mother.  Laurie says he
514	is fast, and I don't consider him a desirable acquaintance, so I let
514	"him alone."""
514	""
514	"""You might treat him civilly, at least.  You gave him a cool nod, and"
514	just now you bowed and smiled in the politest way to Tommy Chamberlain,
514	whose father keeps a grocery store.  If you had just reversed the nod
514	"and the bow, it would have been right,"" said Amy reprovingly."
514	""
514	"""No, it wouldn't,"" returned Jo, ""I neither like, respect, nor admire"
514	Tudor, though his grandfather's uncle's nephew's niece was a third
514	cousin to a lord.  Tommy is poor and bashful and good and very clever.
514	I think well of him, and like to show that I do, for he is a gentleman
514	"in spite of the brown paper parcels."""
514	""
514	"""It's no use trying to argue with you,"" began Amy."
514	""
514	"""Not the least, my dear,"" interrupted Jo, ""so let us look amiable, and"
514	drop a card here, as the Kings are evidently out, for which I'm deeply
514	"grateful."""
514	""
514	The family cardcase having done its duty the girls walked on, and Jo
514	uttered another thanksgiving on reaching the fifth house, and being
514	told that the young ladies were engaged.
514	""
514	"""Now let us go home, and never mind Aunt March today.  We can run down"
514	there any time, and it's really a pity to trail through the dust in our
514	"best bibs and tuckers, when we are tired and cross."""
514	""
514	"""Speak for yourself, if you please.  Aunt March likes to have us pay"
514	her the compliment of coming in style, and making a formal call. It's a
514	little thing to do, but it gives her pleasure, and I don't believe it
514	will hurt your things half so much as letting dirty dogs and clumping
514	boys spoil them.  Stoop down, and let me take the crumbs off of your
514	"bonnet."""
514	""
514	"""What a good girl you are, Amy!"" said Jo, with a repentant glance from"
514	her own damaged costume to that of her sister, which was fresh and
514	"spotless still.  ""I wish it was as easy for me to do little things to"
514	please people as it is for you.  I think of them, but it takes too much
514	time to do them, so I wait for a chance to confer a great favor, and
514	"let the small ones slip, but they tell best in the end, I fancy."""
514	""
514	Amy smiled and was mollified at once, saying with a maternal air,
514	"""Women should learn to be agreeable, particularly poor ones, for they"
514	have no other way of repaying the kindnesses they receive. If you'd
514	remember that, and practice it, you'd be better liked than I am,
514	"because there is more of you."""
514	""
514	"""I'm a crotchety old thing, and always shall be, but I'm willing to own"
514	that you are right, only it's easier for me to risk my life for a
514	person than to be pleasant to him when I don't feel like it.  It's a
514	"great misfortune to have such strong likes and dislikes, isn't it?"""
514	""
514	"""It's a greater not to be able to hide them.  I don't mind saying that"
514	I don't approve of Tudor any more than you do, but I'm not called upon
514	to tell him so.  Neither are you, and there is no use in making
514	"yourself disagreeable because he is."""
514	""
514	"""But I think girls ought to show when they disapprove of young men, and"
514	how can they do it except by their manners? Preaching does not do any
514	good, as I know to my sorrow, since I've had Teddie to manage.  But
514	there are many little ways in which I can influence him without a word,
514	"and I say we ought to do it to others if we can."""
514	""
514	"""Teddy is a remarkable boy, and can't be taken as a sample of other"
514	"boys,"" said Amy, in a tone of solemn conviction, which would have"
514	"convulsed the 'remarkable boy' if he had heard it.  ""If we were belles,"
514	or women of wealth and position, we might do something, perhaps, but
514	for us to frown at one set of young gentlemen because we don't approve
514	of them, and smile upon another set because we do, wouldn't have a
514	particle of effect, and we should only be considered odd and
514	"puritanical."""
514	""
514	"""So we are to countenance things and people which we detest, merely"
514	because we are not belles and millionaires, are we? That's a nice sort
514	"of morality."""
514	""
514	"""I can't argue about it, I only know that it's the way of the world,"
514	and people who set themselves against it only get laughed at for their
514	"pains.  I don't like reformers, and I hope you never try to be one."""
514	""
514	"""I do like them, and I shall be one if I can, for in spite of the"
514	laughing the world would never get on without them.  We can't agree
514	about that, for you belong to the old set, and I to the new. You will
514	get on the best, but I shall have the liveliest time of it. I should
514	"rather enjoy the brickbats and hooting, I think."""
514	""
514	"""Well, compose yourself now, and don't worry Aunt with your new ideas."""
514	""
514	"""I'll try not to, but I'm always possessed to burst out with some"
514	particularly blunt speech or revolutionary sentiment before her.  It's
514	"my doom, and I can't help it."""
514	""
514	They found Aunt Carrol with the old lady, both absorbed in some very
514	interesting subject, but they dropped it as the girls came in, with a
514	conscious look which betrayed that they had been talking about their
514	nieces.  Jo was not in a good humor, and the perverse fit returned, but
514	Amy, who had virtuously done her duty, kept her temper and pleased
514	everybody, was in a most angelic frame of mind.  This amiable spirit
514	was felt at once, and both aunts 'my deared' her affectionately,
514	"looking what they afterward said emphatically, ""That child improves"
514	"every day."""
514	""
514	"""Are you going to help about the fair, dear?"" asked Mrs. Carrol, as Amy"
514	sat down beside her with the confiding air elderly people like so well
514	in the young.
514	""
514	"""Yes, Aunt.  Mrs. Chester asked me if I would, and I offered to tend a"
514	"table, as I have nothing but my time to give."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not,"" put in Jo decidedly.  ""I hate to be patronized, and the"
514	Chesters think it's a great favor to allow us to help with their highly
514	connected fair.  I wonder you consented, Amy, they only want you to
514	"work."""
514	""
514	"""I am willing to work.  It's for the freedmen as well as the Chesters,"
514	and I think it very kind of them to let me share the labor and the fun.
514	"Patronage does not trouble me when it is well meant."""
514	""
514	"""Quite right and proper.  I like your grateful spirit, my dear. It's a"
514	pleasure to help people who appreciate our efforts.  Some do not, and
514	"that is trying,"" observed Aunt March, looking over her spectacles at"
514	Jo, who sat apart, rocking herself, with a somewhat morose expression.
514	""
514	If Jo had only known what a great happiness was wavering in the balance
514	for one of them, she would have turned dove-like in a minute, but
514	unfortunately, we don't have windows in our breasts, and cannot see
514	what goes on in the minds of our friends.  Better for us that we cannot
514	as a general thing, but now and then it would be such a comfort, such a
514	saving of time and temper.  By her next speech, Jo deprived herself of
514	several years of pleasure, and received a timely lesson in the art of
514	holding her tongue.
514	""
514	"""I don't like favors, they oppress and make me feel like a slave.  I'd"
514	"rather do everything for myself, and be perfectly independent."""
514	""
514	"""Ahem!"" coughed Aunt Carrol softly, with a look at Aunt March."
514	""
514	"""I told you so,"" said Aunt March, with a decided nod to Aunt Carrol."
514	""
514	Mercifully unconscious of what she had done, Jo sat with her nose in
514	the air, and a revolutionary aspect which was anything but inviting.
514	""
514	"""Do you speak French, dear?"" asked Mrs. Carrol, laying a hand on Amy's."
514	""
514	"""Pretty well, thanks to Aunt March, who lets Esther talk to me as often"
514	"as I like,"" replied Amy, with a grateful look, which caused the old"
514	lady to smile affably.
514	""
514	"""How are you about languages?"" asked Mrs. Carrol of Jo."
514	""
514	"""Don't know a word.  I'm very stupid about studying anything, can't"
514	"bear French, it's such a slippery, silly sort of language,"" was the"
514	brusque reply.
514	""
514	Another look passed between the ladies, and Aunt March said to Amy,
514	"""You are quite strong and well now, dear, I believe?  Eyes don't"
514	"trouble you any more, do they?"""
514	""
514	"""Not at all, thank you, ma'am.  I'm very well, and mean to do great"
514	things next winter, so that I may be ready for Rome, whenever that
514	"joyful time arrives."""
514	""
514	"""Good girl!  You deserve to go, and I'm sure you will some day,"" said"
514	Aunt March, with an approving pat on the head, as Amy picked up her
514	ball for her.
514	""
514	    Crosspatch, draw the latch,
514	    Sit by the fire and spin,
514	""
514	squalled Polly, bending down from his perch on the back of her chair to
514	peep into Jo's face, with such a comical air of impertinent inquiry
514	that it was impossible to help laughing.
514	""
514	"""Most observing bird,"" said the old lady."
514	""
514	"""Come and take a walk, my dear?"" cried Polly, hopping toward the china"
514	closet, with a look suggestive of a lump of sugar.
514	""
514	"""Thank you, I will.  Come Amy."" and Jo brought the visit to an end,"
514	feeling more strongly than ever that calls did have a bad effect upon
514	her constitution.  She shook hands in a gentlemanly manner, but Amy
514	kissed both the aunts, and the girls departed, leaving behind them the
514	impression of shadow and sunshine, which impression caused Aunt March
514	to say, as they vanished...
514	""
514	"""You'd better do it, Mary.  I'll supply the money."" and Aunt Carrol to"
514	"reply decidedly, ""I certainly will, if her father and mother consent."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY
514	""
514	CONSEQUENCES
514	""
514	Mrs. Chester's fair was so very elegant and select that it was
514	considered a great honor by the young ladies of the neighborhood to be
514	invited to take a table, and everyone was much interested in the
514	matter.  Amy was asked, but Jo was not, which was fortunate for all
514	parties, as her elbows were decidedly akimbo at this period of her
514	life, and it took a good many hard knocks to teach her how to get on
514	easily.  The 'haughty, uninteresting creature' was let severely alone,
514	but Amy's talent and taste were duly complimented by the offer of the
514	art table, and she exerted herself to prepare and secure appropriate
514	and valuable contributions to it.
514	""
514	Everything went on smoothly till the day before the fair opened, then
514	there occurred one of the little skirmishes which it is almost
514	impossible to avoid, when some five-and-twenty women, old and young,
514	with all their private piques and prejudices, try to work together.
514	""
514	May Chester was rather jealous of Amy because the latter was a greater
514	favorite than herself, and just at this time several trifling
514	circumstances occurred to increase the feeling.  Amy's dainty
514	pen-and-ink work entirely eclipsed May's painted vases--that was one
514	thorn.  Then the all conquering Tudor had danced four times with Amy at
514	a late party and only once with May--that was thorn number two.  But
514	the chief grievance that rankled in her soul, and gave an excuse for
514	her unfriendly conduct, was a rumor which some obliging gossip had
514	whispered to her, that the March girls had made fun of her at the
514	Lambs'. All the blame of this should have fallen upon Jo, for her
514	naughty imitation had been too lifelike to escape detection, and the
514	frolicsome Lambs had permitted the joke to escape.  No hint of this had
514	reached the culprits, however, and Amy's dismay can be imagined, when,
514	the very evening before the fair, as she was putting the last touches
514	to her pretty table, Mrs. Chester, who, of course, resented the
514	supposed ridicule of her daughter, said, in a bland tone, but with a
514	cold look...
514	""
514	"""I find, dear, that there is some feeling among the young ladies about"
514	my giving this table to anyone but my girls.  As this is the most
514	prominent, and some say the most attractive table of all, and they are
514	the chief getters-up of the fair, it is thought best for them to take
514	this place.  I'm sorry, but I know you are too sincerely interested in
514	the cause to mind a little personal disappointment, and you shall have
514	"another table if you like."""
514	""
514	Mrs. Chester fancied beforehand that it would be easy to deliver this
514	little speech, but when the time came, she found it rather difficult to
514	utter it naturally, with Amy's unsuspicious eyes looking straight at
514	her full of surprise and trouble.
514	""
514	Amy felt that there was something behind this, but could not guess
514	what, and said quietly, feeling hurt, and showing that she did,
514	"""Perhaps you had rather I took no table at all?"""
514	""
514	"""Now, my dear, don't have any ill feeling, I beg.  It's merely a matter"
514	of expediency, you see, my girls will naturally take the lead, and this
514	table is considered their proper place.  I think it very appropriate to
514	you, and feel very grateful for your efforts to make it so pretty, but
514	we must give up our private wishes, of course, and I will see that you
514	have a good place elsewhere. Wouldn't you like the flower table? The
514	little girls undertook it, but they are discouraged.  You could make a
514	charming thing of it, and the flower table is always attractive you
514	"know."""
514	""
514	"""Especially to gentlemen,"" added May, with a look which enlightened Amy"
514	as to one cause of her sudden fall from favor.  She colored angrily,
514	but took no other notice of that girlish sarcasm, and answered with
514	unexpected amiability...
514	""
514	"""It shall be as you please, Mrs. Chester.  I'll give up my place here"
514	"at once, and attend to the flowers, if you like."""
514	""
514	"""You can put your own things on your own table, if you prefer,"" began"
514	May, feeling a little conscience-stricken, as she looked at the pretty
514	racks, the painted shells, and quaint illuminations Amy had so
514	carefully made and so gracefully arranged.  She meant it kindly, but
514	Amy mistook her meaning, and said quickly...
514	""
514	"""Oh, certainly, if they are in your way,"" and sweeping her"
514	contributions into her apron, pell-mell, she walked off, feeling that
514	herself and her works of art had been insulted past forgiveness.
514	""
514	"""Now she's mad.  Oh, dear, I wish I hadn't asked you to speak,  Mama,"""
514	said May, looking disconsolately at the empty spaces on her table.
514	""
514	"""Girls' quarrels are soon over,"" returned her mother, feeling a trifle"
514	ashamed of her own part in this one, as well she might.
514	""
514	The little girls hailed Amy and her treasures with delight, which
514	cordial reception somewhat soothed her perturbed spirit, and she fell
514	to work, determined to succeed florally, if she could not artistically.
514	But everything seemed against her.  It was late, and she was tired.
514	Everyone was too busy with their own affairs to help her, and the
514	little girls were only hindrances, for the dears fussed and chattered
514	like so many magpies, making a great deal of confusion in their artless
514	efforts to preserve the most perfect order.  The evergreen arch
514	wouldn't stay firm after she got it up, but wiggled and threatened to
514	tumble down on her head when the hanging baskets were filled.  Her best
514	tile got a splash of water, which left a sepia tear on the Cupid's
514	cheek.  She bruised her hands with hammering, and got cold working in a
514	draft, which last affliction filled her with apprehensions for the
514	morrow.  Any girl reader who has suffered like afflictions will
514	sympathize with poor Amy and wish her well through her task.
514	""
514	There was great indignation at home when she told her story that
514	evening.  Her mother said it was a shame, but told her she had done
514	right.  Beth declared she wouldn't go to the fair at all, and Jo
514	demanded why she didn't take all her pretty things and leave those mean
514	people to get on without her.
514	""
514	"""Because they are mean is no reason why I should be.  I hate such"
514	things, and though I think I've a right to be hurt, I don't intend to
514	show it.  They will feel that more than angry speeches or huffy
514	"actions, won't they, Marmee?"""
514	""
514	"""That's the right spirit, my dear.  A kiss for a blow is always best,"
514	"though it's not very easy to give it sometimes,"" said her mother, with"
514	the air of one who had learned the difference between preaching and
514	practicing.
514	""
514	In spite of various very natural temptations to resent and retaliate,
514	Amy adhered to her resolution all the next day, bent on conquering her
514	enemy by kindness.  She began well, thanks to a silent reminder that
514	came to her unexpectedly, but most opportunely. As she arranged her
514	table that morning, while the little girls were in the anteroom filling
514	the baskets, she took up her pet production, a little book, the antique
514	cover of which her father had found among his treasures, and in which
514	on leaves of vellum she had beautifully illuminated different texts.
514	As she turned the pages rich in dainty devices with very pardonable
514	pride, her eye fell upon one verse that made her stop and think.
514	Framed in a brilliant scrollwork of scarlet, blue and gold, with little
514	spirits of good will helping one another up and down among the thorns
514	"and flowers, were the words, ""Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself."""
514	""
514	"""I ought, but I don't,"" thought Amy, as her eye went from the bright"
514	page to May's discontented face behind the big vases, that could not
514	hide the vacancies her pretty work had once filled.  Amy stood a
514	minute, turning the leaves in her hand, reading on each some sweet
514	rebuke for all heartburnings and uncharitableness of spirit. Many wise
514	and true sermons are preached us every day by unconscious ministers in
514	street, school, office, or home.  Even a fair table may become a
514	pulpit, if it can offer the good and helpful words which are never out
514	of season.  Amy's conscience preached her a little sermon from that
514	text, then and there, and she did what many of us do not always do,
514	took the sermon to heart, and straightway put it in practice.
514	""
514	A group of girls were standing about May's table, admiring the pretty
514	things, and talking over the change of saleswomen.  They dropped their
514	voices, but Amy knew they were speaking of her, hearing one side of the
514	story and judging accordingly.  It was not pleasant, but a better
514	spirit had come over her, and presently a chance offered for proving
514	it.  She heard May say sorrowfully...
514	""
514	"""It's too bad, for there is no time to make other things, and I don't"
514	want to fill up with odds and ends.  The table was just complete then.
514	"Now it's spoiled."""
514	""
514	"""I dare say she'd put them back if you asked her,"" suggested someone."
514	""
514	"""How could I after all the fuss?"" began May, but she did not finish,"
514	for Amy's voice came across the hall, saying pleasantly...
514	""
514	"""You may have them, and welcome, without asking, if you want them.  I"
514	was just thinking I'd offer to put them back, for they belong to your
514	table rather than mine.  Here they are, please take them, and forgive
514	"me if I was hasty in carrying them away last night."""
514	""
514	As she spoke, Amy returned her contribution, with a nod and a smile,
514	and hurried away again, feeling that it was easier to do a friendly
514	thing than it was to stay and be thanked for it.
514	""
514	"""Now, I call that lovely of her, don't you?"" cried one girl."
514	""
514	May's answer was inaudible, but another young lady, whose temper was
514	evidently a little soured by making lemonade, added, with a
514	"disagreeable laugh, ""Very lovely, for she knew she wouldn't sell them"
514	"at her own table."""
514	""
514	Now, that was hard.  When we make little sacrifices we like to have
514	them appreciated, at least, and for a minute Amy was sorry she had done
514	it, feeling that virtue was not always its own reward. But it is, as
514	she presently discovered, for her spirits began to rise, and her table
514	to blossom under her skillful hands, the girls were very kind, and that
514	one little act seemed to have cleared the atmosphere amazingly.
514	""
514	It was a very long day and a hard one for Amy, as she sat behind her
514	table, often quite alone, for the little girls deserted very soon.  Few
514	cared to buy flowers in summer, and her bouquets began to droop long
514	before night.
514	""
514	The art table was the most attractive in the room.  There was a crowd
514	about it all day long, and the tenders were constantly flying to and
514	fro with important faces and rattling money boxes.  Amy often looked
514	wistfully across, longing to be there, where she felt at home and
514	happy, instead of in a corner with nothing to do.  It might seem no
514	hardship to some of us, but to a pretty, blithe young girl, it was not
514	only tedious, but very trying, and the thought of Laurie and his
514	friends made it a real martyrdom.
514	""
514	She did not go home till night, and then she looked so pale and quiet
514	that they knew the day had been a hard one, though she made no
514	complaint, and did not even tell what she had done.  Her mother gave
514	her an extra cordial cup of tea.  Beth helped her dress, and made a
514	charming little wreath for her hair, while Jo astonished her family by
514	getting herself up with unusual care, and hinting darkly that the
514	tables were about to be turned.
514	""
514	"""Don't do anything rude, pray Jo; I won't have any fuss made, so let it"
514	"all pass and behave yourself,"" begged Amy, as she departed early,"
514	hoping to find a reinforcement of flowers to refresh her poor little
514	table.
514	""
514	"""I merely intend to make myself entrancingly agreeable to every one I"
514	know, and to keep them in your corner as long as possible. Teddy and
514	"his boys will lend a hand, and we'll have a good time yet."" returned"
514	Jo, leaning over the gate to watch for Laurie.  Presently the familiar
514	tramp was heard in the dusk, and she ran out to meet him.
514	""
514	"""Is that my boy?"""
514	""
514	"""As sure as this is my girl!"" and Laurie tucked her hand under his arm"
514	with the air of a man whose every wish was gratified.
514	""
514	"""Oh, Teddy, such doings!"" and Jo told Amy's wrongs with sisterly zeal."
514	""
514	"""A flock of our fellows are going to drive over by-and-by, and I'll be"
514	hanged if I don't make them buy every flower she's got, and camp down
514	"before her table afterward,"" said Laurie, espousing her cause with"
514	warmth.
514	""
514	"""The flowers are not at all nice, Amy says, and the fresh ones may not"
514	arrive in time.  I don't wish to be unjust or suspicious, but I
514	shouldn't wonder if they never came at all.  When people do one mean
514	"thing they are very likely to do another,"" observed Jo in a disgusted"
514	tone.
514	""
514	"""Didn't Hayes give you the best out of our gardens? I told him to."""
514	""
514	"""I didn't know that, he forgot, I suppose, and, as your grandpa was"
514	"poorly, I didn't like to worry him by asking, though I did want some."""
514	""
514	"""Now, Jo, how could you think there was any need of asking? They are"
514	"just as much yours as mine.  Don't we always go halves in everything?"""
514	began Laurie, in the tone that always made Jo turn thorny.
514	""
514	"""Gracious, I hope not!  Half of some of your things wouldn't suit me at"
514	all.  But we mustn't stand philandering here.  I've got to help Amy, so
514	you go and make yourself splendid, and if you'll be so very kind as to
514	let Hayes take a few nice flowers up to the Hall, I'll bless you
514	"forever."""
514	""
514	"""Couldn't you do it now?"" asked Laurie, so suggestively that Jo shut"
514	the gate in his face with inhospitable haste, and called through the
514	"bars, ""Go away, Teddy, I'm busy."""
514	""
514	Thanks to the conspirators, the tables were turned that night, for
514	Hayes sent up a wilderness of flowers, with a lovely basket arranged
514	in his best manner for a centerpiece.  Then the March family turned out
514	en masse, and Jo exerted herself to some purpose, for people not only
514	came, but stayed, laughing at her nonsense, admiring Amy's taste, and
514	apparently enjoying themselves very much.  Laurie and his friends
514	gallantly threw themselves into the breach, bought up the bouquets,
514	encamped before the table, and made that corner the liveliest spot in
514	the room.  Amy was in her element now, and out of gratitude, if nothing
514	more, was as spritely and gracious as possible, coming to the
514	conclusion, about that time, that virtue was its own reward, after all.
514	""
514	Jo behaved herself with exemplary propriety, and when Amy was happily
514	surrounded by her guard of honor, Jo circulated about the Hall, picking
514	up various bits of gossip, which enlightened her upon the subject of
514	the Chester change of base.  She reproached herself for her share of
514	the ill feeling and resolved to exonerate Amy as soon as possible.  She
514	also discovered what Amy had done about the things in the morning, and
514	considered her a model of magnanimity.  As she passed the art table,
514	she glanced over it for her sister's things, but saw no sign of them.
514	"""Tucked away out of sight, I dare say,"" thought Jo, who could forgive"
514	her own wrongs, but hotly resented any insult offered her family.
514	""
514	"""Good evening, Miss Jo.  How does Amy get on?"" asked May with a"
514	conciliatory air, for she wanted to show that she also could be
514	generous.
514	""
514	"""She has sold everything she had that was worth selling, and now she is"
514	enjoying herself.  The flower table is always attractive, you know,
514	"'especially to gentlemen'."" Jo couldn't resist giving that little slap,"
514	but May took it so meekly she regretted it a minute after, and fell to
514	praising the great vases, which still remained unsold.
514	""
514	"""Is Amy's illumination anywhere about?  I took a fancy to buy that for"
514	"Father,"" said Jo, very anxious to learn the fate of her sister's work."
514	""
514	"""Everything of Amy's sold long ago.  I took care that the right people"
514	"saw them, and they made a nice little sum of money for us,"" returned"
514	May, who had overcome sundry small temptations, as well as Amy had,
514	that day.
514	""
514	Much gratified, Jo rushed back to tell the good news, and Amy looked
514	both touched and surprised by the report of May's word and manner.
514	""
514	"""Now, gentlemen, I want you to go and do your duty by the other tables"
514	"as generously as you have by mine, especially the art table,"" she said,"
514	ordering out 'Teddy's own', as the girls called the college friends.
514	""
514	"""'Charge, Chester, charge!' is the motto for that table, but do your"
514	duty like men, and you'll get your money's worth of art in every sense
514	"of the word,"" said the irrepressible Jo, as the devoted phalanx"
514	prepared to take the field.
514	""
514	"""To hear is to obey, but March is fairer far than May,"" said little"
514	Parker, making a frantic effort to be both witty and tender, and
514	getting promptly quenched by Laurie, who said...
514	""
514	"""Very well, my son, for a small boy!"" and walked him off, with a"
514	paternal pat on the head.
514	""
514	"""Buy the vases,"" whispered Amy to Laurie, as a final heaping of coals"
514	of fire on her enemy's head.
514	""
514	To May's great delight, Mr. Laurence not only bought the vases, but
514	pervaded the hall with one under each arm.  The other gentlemen
514	speculated with equal rashness in all sorts of frail trifles, and
514	wandered helplessly about afterward, burdened with wax flowers, painted
514	fans, filigree portfolios, and other useful and appropriate purchases.
514	""
514	Aunt Carrol was there, heard the story, looked pleased, and said
514	something to Mrs. March in a corner, which made the latter lady beam
514	with satisfaction, and watch Amy with a face full of mingled pride and
514	anxiety, though she did not betray the cause of her pleasure till
514	several days later.
514	""
514	The fair was pronounced a success, and when May bade Amy goodnight, she
514	did not gush as usual, but gave her an affectionate kiss, and a look
514	which said 'forgive and forget'.  That satisfied Amy, and when she got
514	home she found the vases paraded on the parlor chimney piece with a
514	"great bouquet in each.  ""The reward of merit for a magnanimous March,"""
514	as Laurie announced with a flourish.
514	""
514	"""You've a deal more principle and generosity and nobleness of character"
514	than I ever gave you credit for, Amy.  You've behaved sweetly, and I
514	"respect you with all my heart,"" said Jo warmly, as they brushed their"
514	hair together late that night.
514	""
514	"""Yes, we all do, and love her for being so ready to forgive.  It must"
514	have been dreadfully hard, after working so long and setting your heart
514	on selling your own pretty things.  I don't believe I could have done
514	"it as kindly as you did,"" added Beth from her pillow."
514	""
514	"""Why, girls, you needn't praise me so.  I only did as I'd be done by."
514	You laugh at me when I say I want to be a lady, but I mean a true
514	gentlewoman in mind and manners, and I try to do it as far as I know
514	how.  I can't explain exactly, but I want to be above the little
514	meannesses and follies and faults that spoil so many women.  I'm far
514	"from it now, but I do my best, and hope in time to be what Mother is."""
514	""
514	"Amy spoke earnestly, and Jo said, with a cordial hug, ""I understand now"
514	what you mean, and I'll never laugh at you again. You are getting on
514	faster than you think, and I'll take lessons of you in true politeness,
514	for you've learned the secret, I believe. Try away, deary, you'll get
514	"your reward some day, and no one will be more delighted than I shall."""
514	""
514	A week later Amy did get her reward, and poor Jo found it hard to be
514	delighted.  A letter came from Aunt Carrol, and Mrs. March's face was
514	illuminated to such a degree when she read it that Jo and Beth, who
514	were with her, demanded what the glad tidings were.
514	""
514	"""Aunt Carrol is going abroad next month, and wants..."""
514	""
514	"""Me to go with her!"" burst in Jo, flying out of her chair in an"
514	uncontrollable rapture.
514	""
514	"""No, dear, not you.  It's Amy."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Mother!  She's too young, it's my turn first.  I've wanted it so"
514	long.  It would do me so much good, and be so altogether splendid.  I
514	"must go!"""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid it's impossible, Jo.  Aunt says Amy, decidedly, and it is"
514	"not for us to dictate when she offers such a favor."""
514	""
514	"""It's always so.  Amy has all the fun and I have all the work. It isn't"
514	"fair, oh, it isn't fair!"" cried Jo passionately."
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid it's partly your own fault, dear.  When Aunt spoke to me"
514	the other day, she regretted your blunt manners and too independent
514	spirit, and here she writes, as if quoting something you had said--'I
514	planned at first to ask Jo, but as 'favors burden her', and she 'hates
514	French', I think I won't venture to invite her.  Amy is more docile,
514	will make a good companion for Flo, and receive gratefully any help the
514	"trip may give her."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, my tongue, my abominable tongue!  Why can't I learn to keep it"
514	"quiet?"" groaned Jo, remembering words which had been her undoing.  When"
514	she had heard the explanation of the quoted phrases, Mrs. March said
514	sorrowfully...
514	""
514	"""I wish you could have gone, but there is no hope of it this time, so"
514	try to bear it cheerfully, and don't sadden Amy's pleasure by
514	"reproaches or regrets."""
514	""
514	"""I'll try,"" said Jo, winking hard as she knelt down to pick up the"
514	"basket she had joyfully upset.  ""I'll take a leaf out of her book, and"
514	try not only to seem glad, but to be so, and not grudge her one minute
514	of happiness.  But it won't be easy, for it is a dreadful
514	"disappointment,"" and poor Jo bedewed the little fat pincushion she held"
514	with several very bitter tears.
514	""
514	"""Jo, dear, I'm very selfish, but I couldn't spare you, and I'm glad you"
514	"are not going quite yet,"" whispered Beth, embracing her, basket and"
514	all, with such a clinging touch and loving face that Jo felt comforted
514	in spite of the sharp regret that made her want to box her own ears,
514	and humbly beg Aunt Carrol to burden her with this favor, and see how
514	gratefully she would bear it.
514	""
514	By the time Amy came in, Jo was able to take her part in the family
514	jubilation, not quite as heartily as usual, perhaps, but without
514	repinings at Amy's good fortune.  The young lady herself received the
514	news as tidings of great joy, went about in a solemn sort of rapture,
514	and began to sort her colors and pack her pencils that evening, leaving
514	such trifles as clothes, money, and passports to those less absorbed in
514	visions of art than herself.
514	""
514	"""It isn't a mere pleasure trip to me, girls,"" she said impressively, as"
514	"she scraped her best palette.  ""It will decide my career, for if I have"
514	any genius, I shall find it out in Rome, and will do something to prove
514	"it."""
514	""
514	"""Suppose you haven't?"" said Jo, sewing away, with red eyes, at the new"
514	collars which were to be handed over to Amy.
514	""
514	"""Then I shall come home and teach drawing for my living,"" replied the"
514	aspirant for fame, with philosophic composure. But she made a wry face
514	at the prospect, and scratched away at her palette as if bent on
514	vigorous measures before she gave up her hopes.
514	""
514	"""No, you won't.  You hate hard work, and you'll marry some rich man,"
514	"and come home to sit in the lap of luxury all your days,"" said Jo."
514	""
514	"""Your predictions sometimes come to pass, but I don't believe that one"
514	will.  I'm sure I wish it would, for if I can't be an artist myself, I
514	"should like to be able to help those who are,"" said Amy, smiling, as if"
514	the part of Lady Bountiful would suit her better than that of a poor
514	drawing teacher.
514	""
514	"""Hum!"" said Jo, with a sigh.  ""If you wish it you'll have it, for your"
514	"wishes are always granted--mine never."""
514	""
514	"""Would you like to go?"" asked Amy, thoughtfully patting her nose with"
514	her knife.
514	""
514	"""Rather!"""
514	""
514	"""Well, in a year or two I'll send for you, and we'll dig in the Forum"
514	"for relics, and carry out all the plans we've made so many times."""
514	""
514	"""Thank you.  I'll remind you of your promise when that joyful day"
514	"comes, if it ever does,"" returned Jo, accepting the vague but"
514	magnificent offer as gratefully as she could.
514	""
514	There was not much time for preparation, and the house was in a ferment
514	till Amy was off.  Jo bore up very well till the last flutter of blue
514	ribbon vanished, when she retired to her refuge, the garret, and cried
514	till she couldn't cry any more. Amy likewise bore up stoutly till the
514	steamer sailed.  Then just as the gangway was about to be withdrawn, it
514	suddenly came over her that a whole ocean was soon to roll between her
514	and those who loved her best, and she clung to Laurie, the last
514	lingerer, saying with a sob...
514	""
514	"""Oh, take care of them for me, and if anything should happen..."""
514	""
514	"""I will, dear, I will, and if anything happens, I'll come and comfort"
514	"you,"" whispered Laurie, little dreaming that he would be called upon to"
514	keep his word.
514	""
514	So Amy sailed away to find the Old World, which is always new and
514	beautiful to young eyes, while her father and friend watched her from
514	the shore, fervently hoping that none but gentle fortunes would befall
514	the happy-hearted girl, who waved her hand to them till they could see
514	nothing but the summer sunshine dazzling on the sea.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-ONE
514	""
514	OUR FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT
514	""
514	London
514	""
514	Dearest People, Here I really sit at a front window of the Bath Hotel,
514	Piccadilly.  It's not a fashionable place, but Uncle stopped here years
514	ago, and won't go anywhere else.  However, we don't mean to stay long,
514	so it's no great matter.  Oh, I can't begin to tell you how I enjoy it
514	all!  I never can, so I'll only give you bits out of my notebook, for
514	I've done nothing but sketch and scribble since I started.
514	""
514	I sent a line from Halifax, when I felt pretty miserable, but after
514	that I got on delightfully, seldom ill, on deck all day, with plenty of
514	pleasant people to amuse me.  Everyone was very kind to me, especially
514	the officers.  Don't laugh, Jo, gentlemen really are very necessary
514	aboard ship, to hold on to, or to wait upon one, and as they have
514	nothing to do, it's a mercy to make them useful, otherwise they would
514	smoke themselves to death, I'm afraid.
514	""
514	Aunt and Flo were poorly all the way, and liked to be let alone, so
514	when I had done what I could for them, I went and enjoyed myself.  Such
514	walks on deck, such sunsets, such splendid air and waves!  It was
514	almost as exciting as riding a fast horse, when we went rushing on so
514	grandly.  I wish Beth could have come, it would have done her so much
514	good.  As for Jo, she would have gone up and sat on the maintop jib, or
514	whatever the high thing is called, made friends with the engineers, and
514	tooted on the captain's speaking trumpet, she'd have been in such a
514	state of rapture.
514	""
514	It was all heavenly, but I was glad to see the Irish coast, and found
514	it very lovely, so green and sunny, with brown cabins here and there,
514	ruins on some of the hills, and gentlemen's countryseats in the
514	valleys, with deer feeding in the parks. It was early in the morning,
514	but I didn't regret getting up to see it, for the bay was full of
514	little boats, the shore so picturesque, and a rosy sky overhead.  I
514	never shall forget it.
514	""
514	At Queenstown one of my new acquaintances left us, Mr. Lennox, and when
514	I said something about the Lakes of Killarney, he sighed, and sung,
514	with a look at me...
514	""
514	"    ""Oh, have you e'er heard of Kate Kearney?"
514	    She lives on the banks of Killarney;
514	    From the glance of her eye,
514	    Shun danger and fly,
514	"    For fatal's the glance of Kate Kearney."""
514	""
514	Wasn't that nonsensical?
514	""
514	We only stopped at Liverpool a few hours.  It's a dirty, noisy place,
514	and I was glad to leave it.  Uncle rushed out and bought a pair of
514	dogskin gloves, some ugly, thick shoes, and an umbrella, and got shaved
514	_a la_ mutton chop, the first thing. Then he flattered himself that he
514	looked like a true Briton, but the first time he had the mud cleaned
514	off his shoes, the little bootblack knew that an American stood in
514	"them, and said, with a grin, ""There yer har, sir.  I've given 'em the"
514	"latest Yankee shine.""  It amused Uncle immensely.  Oh, I must tell you"
514	what that absurd Lennox did!  He got his friend Ward, who came on with
514	us, to order a bouquet for me, and the first thing I saw in my room was
514	"a lovely one, with ""Robert Lennox's compliments,"" on the card.  Wasn't"
514	that fun, girls? I like traveling.
514	""
514	I never shall get to London if I don't hurry.  The trip was like riding
514	through a long picture gallery, full of lovely landscapes. The
514	farmhouses were my delight, with thatched roofs, ivy up to the eaves,
514	latticed windows, and stout women with rosy children at the doors.  The
514	very cattle looked more tranquil than ours, as they stood knee-deep in
514	clover, and the hens had a contented cluck, as if they never got
514	nervous like Yankee biddies.  Such perfect color I never saw, the grass
514	so green, sky so blue, grain so yellow, woods so dark, I was in a
514	rapture all the way.  So was Flo, and we kept bouncing from one side to
514	the other, trying to see everything while we were whisking along at the
514	rate of sixty miles an hour.  Aunt was tired and went to sleep, but
514	Uncle read his guidebook, and wouldn't be astonished at anything. This
514	"is the way we went on.  Amy, flying up--""Oh, that must be Kenilworth,"
514	"that gray place among the trees!""  Flo, darting to my window--""How"
514	"sweet!  We must go there sometime, won't we Papa?"" Uncle, calmly"
514	"admiring his boots--""No, my dear, not unless you want beer, that's a"
514	"brewery."""
514	""
514	"A pause--then Flo cried out, ""Bless me, there's a gallows and a man"
514	"going up.""  ""Where, where?"" shrieks Amy, staring out at two tall posts"
514	"with a crossbeam and some dangling chains.  ""A colliery,"" remarks"
514	"Uncle, with a twinkle of the eye.  ""Here's a lovely flock of lambs all"
514	"lying down,"" says Amy.  ""See, Papa, aren't they pretty?"" added Flo"
514	"sentimentally.  ""Geese, young ladies,"" returns Uncle, in a tone that"
514	keeps us quiet till Flo settles down to enjoy the _Flirtations of
514	Captain Cavendish_, and I have the scenery all to myself.
514	""
514	Of course it rained when we got to London, and there was nothing to be
514	seen but fog and umbrellas.  We rested, unpacked, and shopped a little
514	between the showers.  Aunt Mary got me some new things, for I came off
514	in such a hurry I wasn't half ready. A white hat and blue feather, a
514	muslin dress to match, and the loveliest mantle you ever saw.  Shopping
514	in Regent Street is perfectly splendid.  Things seem so cheap, nice
514	ribbons only sixpence a yard.  I laid in a stock, but shall get my
514	gloves in Paris.  Doesn't that sound sort of elegant and rich?
514	""
514	Flo and I, for the fun of it, ordered a hansom cab, while Aunt and
514	Uncle were out, and went for a drive, though we learned afterward that
514	it wasn't the thing for young ladies to ride in them alone.  It was so
514	droll!  For when we were shut in by the wooden apron, the man drove so
514	fast that Flo was frightened, and told me to stop him, but he was up
514	outside behind somewhere, and I couldn't get at him.  He didn't hear me
514	call, nor see me flap my parasol in front, and there we were, quite
514	helpless, rattling away, and whirling around corners at a breakneck
514	pace. At last, in my despair, I saw a little door in the roof, and on
514	poking it open, a red eye appeared, and a beery voice said...
514	""
514	"""Now, then, mum?"""
514	""
514	I gave my order as soberly as I could, and slamming down the door, with
514	"an ""Aye, aye, mum,"" the man made his horse walk, as if going to a"
514	"funeral.  I poked again and said, ""A little faster,"" then off he went,"
514	helter-skelter as before, and we resigned ourselves to our fate.
514	""
514	Today was fair, and we went to Hyde Park, close by, for we are more
514	aristocratic than we look.  The Duke of Devonshire lives near.  I often
514	see his footmen lounging at the back gate, and the Duke of Wellington's
514	house is not far off.  Such sights as I saw, my dear!  It was as good
514	as Punch, for there were fat dowagers rolling about in their red and
514	yellow coaches, with gorgeous Jeameses in silk stockings and velvet
514	coats, up behind, and powdered coachmen in front.  Smart maids, with
514	the rosiest children I ever saw, handsome girls, looking half asleep,
514	dandies in queer English hats and lavender kids lounging about, and
514	tall soldiers, in short red jackets and muffin caps stuck on one side,
514	looking so funny I longed to sketch them.
514	""
514	Rotten Row means 'Route de Roi', or the king's way, but now it's more
514	like a riding school than anything else.  The horses are splendid, and
514	the men, especially the grooms, ride well, but the women are stiff, and
514	bounce, which isn't according to our rules.  I longed to show them a
514	tearing American gallop, for they trotted solemnly up and down, in
514	their scant habits and high hats, looking like the women in a toy
514	Noah's Ark.  Everyone rides--old men, stout ladies, little
514	children--and the young folks do a deal of flirting here, I saw a pair
514	exchange rose buds, for it's the thing to wear one in the button-hole,
514	and I thought it rather a nice little idea.
514	""
514	In the P.M.  to Westminster Abbey, but don't expect me to describe it,
514	that's impossible, so I'll only say it was sublime! This evening we are
514	going to see Fechter, which will be an appropriate end to the happiest
514	day of my life.
514	""
514	It's very late, but I can't let my letter go in the morning without
514	telling you what happened last evening.  Who do you think came in, as
514	we were at tea?  Laurie's English friends, Fred and Frank Vaughn!  I
514	was so surprised, for I shouldn't have known them but for the cards.
514	Both are tall fellows with whiskers, Fred handsome in the English
514	style, and Frank much better, for he only limps slightly, and uses no
514	crutches.  They had heard from Laurie where we were to be, and came to
514	ask us to their house, but Uncle won't go, so we shall return the call,
514	and see them as we can.  They went to the theater with us, and we did
514	have such a good time, for Frank devoted himself to Flo, and Fred and I
514	talked over past, present, and future fun as if we had known each other
514	all our days.  Tell Beth Frank asked for her, and was sorry to hear of
514	her ill health.  Fred laughed when I spoke of Jo, and sent his
514	'respectful compliments to the big hat'. Neither of them had forgotten
514	Camp Laurence, or the fun we had there.  What ages ago it seems,
514	doesn't it?
514	""
514	Aunt is tapping on the wall for the third time, so I must stop.  I
514	really feel like a dissipated London fine lady, writing here so late,
514	with my room full of pretty things, and my head a jumble of parks,
514	"theaters, new gowns, and gallant creatures who say ""Ah!"" and twirl"
514	their blond mustaches with the true English lordliness.  I long to see
514	you all, and in spite of my nonsense am, as ever, your loving...
514	""
514	AMY
514	""
514	""
514	PARIS
514	""
514	Dear girls,
514	""
514	In my last I told you about our London visit, how kind the Vaughns
514	were, and what pleasant parties they made for us.  I enjoyed the trips
514	to Hampton Court and the Kensington Museum more than anything else, for
514	at Hampton I saw Raphael's cartoons, and at the Museum, rooms full of
514	pictures by Turner, Lawrence, Reynolds, Hogarth, and the other great
514	creatures.  The day in Richmond Park was charming, for we had a regular
514	English picnic, and I had more splendid oaks and groups of deer than I
514	could copy, also heard a nightingale, and saw larks go up.  We 'did'
514	London to our heart's content, thanks to Fred and Frank, and were sorry
514	to go away, for though English people are slow to take you in, when
514	they once make up their minds to do it they cannot be outdone in
514	hospitality, I think.  The Vaughns hope to meet us in Rome next winter,
514	and I shall be dreadfully disappointed if they don't, for Grace and I
514	are great friends, and the boys very nice fellows, especially Fred.
514	""
514	Well, we were hardly settled here, when he turned up again, saying he
514	had come for a holiday, and was going to Switzerland. Aunt looked sober
514	at first, but he was so cool about it she couldn't say a word.  And now
514	we get on nicely, and are very glad he came, for he speaks French like
514	a native, and I don't know what we should do without him.  Uncle
514	doesn't know ten words, and insists on talking English very loud, as if
514	it would make people understand him.  Aunt's pronunciation is
514	old-fashioned, and Flo and I, though we flattered ourselves that we
514	knew a good deal, find we don't, and are very grateful to have Fred do
514	the '_parley vooing_', as Uncle calls it.
514	""
514	Such delightful times as we are having!  Sight-seeing from morning till
514	night, stopping for nice lunches in the gay _cafes_, and meeting with
514	all sorts of droll adventures.  Rainy days I spend in the Louvre,
514	revelling in pictures.  Jo would turn up her naughty nose at some of
514	the finest, because she has no soul for art, but I have, and I'm
514	cultivating eye and taste as fast as I can.  She would like the relics
514	of great people better, for I've seen her Napoleon's cocked hat and
514	gray coat, his baby's cradle and his old toothbrush, also Marie
514	Antoinette's little shoe, the ring of Saint Denis, Charlemagne's sword,
514	and many other interesting things.  I'll talk for hours about them when
514	I come, but haven't time to write.
514	""
514	The Palais Royale is a heavenly place, so full of _bijouterie_ and
514	lovely things that I'm nearly distracted because I can't buy them.
514	Fred wanted to get me some, but of course I didn't allow it.  Then the
514	Bois and Champs Elysees are _tres magnifique_. I've seen the imperial
514	family several times, the emperor an ugly, hard-looking man, the
514	empress pale and pretty, but dressed in bad taste, I thought--purple
514	dress, green hat, and yellow gloves. Little Nap is a handsome boy, who
514	sits chatting to his tutor, and kisses his hand to the people as he
514	passes in his four-horse barouche, with postilions in red satin jackets
514	and a mounted guard before and behind.
514	""
514	We often walk in the Tuileries Gardens, for they are lovely, though the
514	antique Luxembourg Gardens suit me better. Pere la Chaise is very
514	curious, for many of the tombs are like small rooms, and looking in,
514	one sees a table, with images or pictures of the dead, and chairs for
514	the mourners to sit in when they come to lament.  That is so Frenchy.
514	""
514	Our rooms are on the Rue de Rivoli, and sitting on the balcony, we look
514	up and down the long, brilliant street.  It is so pleasant that we
514	spend our evenings talking there when too tired with our day's work to
514	go out.  Fred is very entertaining, and is altogether the most
514	agreeable young man I ever knew--except Laurie, whose manners are more
514	charming.  I wish Fred was dark, for I don't fancy light men, however,
514	the Vaughns are very rich and come of an excellent family, so I won't
514	find fault with their yellow hair, as my own is yellower.
514	""
514	Next week we are off to Germany and Switzerland, and as we shall travel
514	fast, I shall only be able to give you hasty letters.  I keep my diary,
514	and try to 'remember correctly and describe clearly all that I see and
514	admire', as Father advised. It is good practice for me, and with my
514	sketchbook will give you a better idea of my tour than these scribbles.
514	""
514	"Adieu, I embrace you tenderly. _""Votre Amie.""_"
514	""
514	""
514	HEIDELBERG
514	""
514	My dear Mamma,
514	""
514	Having a quiet hour before we leave for Berne, I'll try to tell you
514	what has happened, for some of it is very important, as you will see.
514	""
514	The sail up the Rhine was perfect, and I just sat and enjoyed it with
514	all my might.  Get Father's old guidebooks and read about it.  I
514	haven't words beautiful enough to describe it. At Coblentz we had a
514	lovely time, for some students from Bonn, with whom Fred got acquainted
514	on the boat, gave us a serenade. It was a moonlight night, and about
514	one o'clock Flo and I were waked by the most delicious music under our
514	windows.  We flew up, and hid behind the curtains, but sly peeps showed
514	us Fred and the students singing away down below.  It was the most
514	romantic thing I ever saw--the river, the bridge of boats, the great
514	fortress opposite, moonlight everywhere, and music fit to melt a heart
514	of stone.
514	""
514	When they were done we threw down some flowers, and saw them scramble
514	for them, kiss their hands to the invisible ladies, and go laughing
514	away, to smoke and drink beer, I suppose.  Next morning Fred showed me
514	one of the crumpled flowers in his vest pocket, and looked very
514	sentimental.  I laughed at him, and said I didn't throw it, but Flo,
514	which seemed to disgust him, for he tossed it out of the window, and
514	turned sensible again.  I'm afraid I'm going to have trouble with that
514	boy, it begins to look like it.
514	""
514	The baths at Nassau were very gay, so was Baden-Baden, where Fred lost
514	some money, and I scolded him.  He needs someone to look after him when
514	Frank is not with him.  Kate said once she hoped he'd marry soon, and I
514	quite agree with her that it would be well for him.  Frankfurt was
514	delightful.  I saw Goethe's house, Schiller's statue, and Dannecker's
514	famous 'Ariadne.'  It was very lovely, but I should have enjoyed it
514	more if I had known the story better.  I didn't like to ask, as
514	everyone knew it or pretended they did.  I wish Jo would tell me all
514	about it.  I ought to have read more, for I find I don't know anything,
514	and it mortifies me.
514	""
514	Now comes the serious part, for it happened here, and Fred has just
514	gone.  He has been so kind and jolly that we all got quite fond of him.
514	I never thought of anything but a traveling friendship till the
514	serenade night.  Since then I've begun to feel that the moonlight
514	walks, balcony talks, and daily adventures were something more to him
514	than fun.  I haven't flirted, Mother, truly, but remembered what you
514	said to me, and have done my very best.  I can't help it if people like
514	me.  I don't try to make them, and it worries me if I don't care for
514	them, though Jo says I haven't got any heart.  Now I know Mother will
514	"shake her head, and the girls say, ""Oh, the mercenary little wretch!"","
514	but I've made up my mind, and if Fred asks me, I shall accept him,
514	though I'm not madly in love.  I like him, and we get on comfortably
514	together.  He is handsome, young, clever enough, and very rich--ever so
514	much richer than the Laurences.  I don't think his family would object,
514	and I should be very happy, for they are all kind, well-bred, generous
514	people, and they like me.  Fred, as the eldest twin, will have the
514	estate, I suppose, and such a splendid one it is!  A city house in a
514	fashionable street, not so showy as our big houses, but twice as
514	comfortable and full of solid luxury, such as English people believe
514	in.  I like it, for it's genuine.  I've seen the plate, the family
514	jewels, the old servants, and pictures of the country place, with its
514	park, great house, lovely grounds, and fine horses.  Oh, it would be
514	all I should ask!  And I'd rather have it than any title such as girls
514	snap up so readily, and find nothing behind.  I may be mercenary, but I
514	hate poverty, and don't mean to bear it a minute longer than I can
514	help.  One of us _must_ marry well.  Meg didn't, Jo won't, Beth can't
514	yet, so I shall, and make everything okay all round.  I wouldn't marry
514	a man I hated or despised.  You may be sure of that, and though Fred is
514	not my model hero, he does very well, and in time I should get fond
514	enough of him if he was very fond of me, and let me do just as I liked.
514	So I've been turning the matter over in my mind the last week, for it
514	was impossible to help seeing that Fred liked me.  He said nothing, but
514	little things showed it.  He never goes with Flo, always gets on my
514	side of the carriage, table, or promenade, looks sentimental when we
514	are alone, and frowns at anyone else who ventures to speak to me.
514	Yesterday at dinner, when an Austrian officer stared at us and then
514	said something to his friend, a rakish-looking baron, about '_ein
514	wonderschones Blondchen'_, Fred looked as fierce as a lion, and cut his
514	meat so savagely it nearly flew off his plate.  He isn't one of the
514	cool, stiff Englishmen, but is rather peppery, for he has Scotch blood
514	in him, as one might guess from his bonnie blue eyes.
514	""
514	Well, last evening we went up to the castle about sunset, at least all
514	of us but Fred, who was to meet us there after going to the Post
514	Restante for letters.  We had a charming time poking about the ruins,
514	the vaults where the monster tun is, and the beautiful gardens made by
514	the elector long ago for his English wife.  I liked the great terrace
514	best, for the view was divine, so while the rest went to see the rooms
514	inside, I sat there trying to sketch the gray stone lion's head on the
514	wall, with scarlet woodbine sprays hanging round it.  I felt as if I'd
514	got into a romance, sitting there, watching the Neckar rolling through
514	the valley, listening to the music of the Austrian band below, and
514	waiting for my lover, like a real storybook girl.  I had a feeling that
514	something was going to happen and I was ready for it.  I didn't feel
514	blushy or quakey, but quite cool and only a little excited.
514	""
514	By-and-by I heard Fred's voice, and then he came hurrying through the
514	great arch to find me.  He looked so troubled that I forgot all about
514	myself, and asked what the matter was.  He said he'd just got a letter
514	begging him to come home, for Frank was very ill.  So he was going at
514	once on the night train and only had time to say good-by.  I was very
514	sorry for him, and disappointed for myself, but only for a minute
514	because he said, as he shook hands, and said it in a way that I could
514	"not mistake,  ""I shall soon come back, you won't forget me, Amy?"""
514	""
514	I didn't promise, but I looked at him, and he seemed satisfied, and
514	there was no time for anything but messages and good-byes, for he was
514	off in an hour, and we all miss him very much. I know he wanted to
514	speak, but I think, from something he once hinted, that he had promised
514	his father not to do anything of the sort yet a while, for he is a rash
514	boy, and the old gentleman dreads a foreign daughter-in-law.  We shall
514	"soon meet in Rome, and then, if I don't change my mind, I'll say ""Yes,"
514	"thank you,"" when he says ""Will you, please?"""
514	""
514	Of course this is all _very private_, but I wished you to know what was
514	going on.  Don't be anxious about me, remember I am your 'prudent Amy',
514	and be sure I will do nothing rashly. Send me as much advice as you
514	like.  I'll use it if I can.  I wish I could see you for a good talk,
514	Marmee.  Love and trust me.
514	""
514	Ever your AMY
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-TWO
514	""
514	TENDER TROUBLES
514	""
514	"""Jo, I'm anxious about Beth."""
514	""
514	"""Why, Mother, she has seemed unusually well since the babies came."""
514	""
514	"""It's not her health that troubles me now, it's her spirits. I'm sure"
514	"there is something on her mind, and I want you to discover what it is."""
514	""
514	"""What makes you think so, Mother?"""
514	""
514	"""She sits alone a good deal, and doesn't talk to her father as much as"
514	she used.  I found her crying over the babies the other day.  When she
514	sings, the songs are always sad ones, and now and then I see a look in
514	her face that I don't understand. This isn't like Beth, and it worries
514	"me."""
514	""
514	"""Have you asked her about it?"""
514	""
514	"""I have tried once or twice, but she either evaded my questions or"
514	looked so distressed that I stopped.  I never force my children's
514	"confidence, and I seldom have to wait for long."""
514	""
514	Mrs. March glanced at Jo as she spoke, but the face opposite seemed
514	quite unconscious of any secret disquietude but Beth's, and after
514	"sewing thoughtfully for a minute, Jo said, ""I think she is growing up,"
514	and so begins to dream dreams, and have hopes and fears and fidgets,
514	without knowing why or being able to explain them.  Why, Mother, Beth's
514	eighteen, but we don't realize it, and treat her like a child,
514	"forgetting she's a woman."""
514	""
514	"""So she is.  Dear heart, how fast you do grow up,"" returned her mother"
514	with a sigh and a smile.
514	""
514	"""Can't be helped, Marmee, so you must resign yourself to all sorts of"
514	worries, and let your birds hop out of the nest, one by one.  I promise
514	"never to hop very far, if that is any comfort to you."""
514	""
514	"""It's a great comfort, Jo.  I always feel strong when you are at home,"
514	now Meg is gone.  Beth is too feeble and Amy too young to depend upon,
514	"but when the tug comes, you are always ready."""
514	""
514	"""Why, you know I don't mind hard jobs much, and there must always be"
514	one scrub in a family.  Amy is splendid in fine works and I'm not, but
514	I feel in my element when all the carpets are to be taken up, or half
514	the family fall sick at once. Amy is distinguishing herself abroad, but
514	"if anything is amiss at home, I'm your man."""
514	""
514	"""I leave Beth to your hands, then, for she will open her tender little"
514	heart to her Jo sooner than to anyone else.  Be very kind, and don't
514	let her think anyone watches or talks about her.  If she only would get
514	"quite strong and cheerful again, I shouldn't have a wish in the world."""
514	""
514	"""Happy woman!  I've got heaps."""
514	""
514	"""My dear, what are they?"""
514	""
514	"""I'll settle Bethy's troubles, and then I'll tell you mine. They are"
514	"not very wearing, so they'll keep."" and Jo stitched away, with a wise"
514	nod which set her mother's heart at rest about her for the present at
514	least.
514	""
514	While apparently absorbed in her own affairs, Jo watched Beth, and
514	after many conflicting conjectures, finally settled upon one which
514	seemed to explain the change in her.  A slight incident gave Jo the
514	clue to the mystery, she thought, and lively fancy, loving heart did
514	the rest.  She was affecting to write busily one Saturday afternoon,
514	when she and Beth were alone together.  Yet as she scribbled, she kept
514	her eye on her sister, who seemed unusually quiet.  Sitting at the
514	window, Beth's work often dropped into her lap, and she leaned her head
514	upon her hand, in a dejected attitude, while her eyes rested on the
514	dull, autumnal landscape.  Suddenly some one passed below, whistling
514	"like an operatic blackbird, and a voice called out, ""All serene! Coming"
514	"in tonight."""
514	""
514	Beth started, leaned forward, smiled and nodded, watched the passer-by
514	"till his quick tramp died away, then said softly as if to herself, ""How"
514	"strong and well and happy that dear boy looks."""
514	""
514	"""Hum!"" said Jo, still intent upon her sister's face, for the bright"
514	color faded as quickly as it came, the smile vanished, and presently a
514	tear lay shining on the window ledge.  Beth whisked it off, and in her
514	half-averted face read a tender sorrow that made her own eyes fill.
514	Fearing to betray herself, she slipped away, murmuring something about
514	needing more paper.
514	""
514	"""Mercy on me, Beth loves Laurie!"" she said, sitting down in her own"
514	room, pale with the shock of the discovery which she believed she had
514	"just made.  ""I never dreamed of such a thing. What will Mother say?  I"
514	"wonder if her...""  there Jo stopped and turned scarlet with a sudden"
514	"thought.  ""If he shouldn't love back again, how dreadful it would be."
514	"He must.  I'll make him!"" and she shook her head threateningly at the"
514	picture of the mischievous-looking boy laughing at her from the wall.
514	"""Oh dear, we are growing up with a vengeance.  Here's Meg married and a"
514	mamma, Amy flourishing away at Paris, and Beth in love.  I'm the only
514	"one that has sense enough to keep out of mischief."" Jo thought intently"
514	for a minute with her eyes fixed on the picture, then she smoothed out
514	her wrinkled forehead and said, with a decided nod at the face
514	"opposite, ""No thank you, sir, you're very charming, but you've no more"
514	stability than a weathercock.  So you needn't write touching notes and
514	smile in that insinuating way, for it won't do a bit of good, and I
514	"won't have it."""
514	""
514	Then she sighed, and fell into a reverie from which she did not wake
514	till the early twilight sent her down to take new observations, which
514	only confirmed her suspicion.  Though Laurie flirted with Amy and joked
514	with Jo, his manner to Beth had always been peculiarly kind and gentle,
514	but so was everybody's. Therefore, no one thought of imagining that he
514	cared more for her than for the others.  Indeed, a general impression
514	had prevailed in the family of late that 'our boy' was getting fonder
514	than ever of Jo, who, however, wouldn't hear a word upon the subject
514	and scolded violently if anyone dared to suggest it. If they had known
514	the various tender passages which had been nipped in the bud, they
514	"would have had the immense satisfaction of saying, ""I told you so."""
514	But Jo hated 'philandering', and wouldn't allow it, always having a
514	joke or a smile ready at the least sign of impending danger.
514	""
514	When Laurie first went to college, he fell in love about once a month,
514	but these small flames were as brief as ardent, did no damage, and much
514	amused Jo, who took great interest in the alternations of hope,
514	despair, and resignation, which were confided to her in their weekly
514	conferences.  But there came a time when Laurie ceased to worship at
514	many shrines, hinted darkly at one all-absorbing passion, and indulged
514	occasionally in Byronic fits of gloom.  Then he avoided the tender
514	subject altogether, wrote philosophical notes to Jo, turned studious,
514	and gave out that he was going to 'dig', intending to graduate in a
514	blaze of glory.  This suited the young lady better than twilight
514	confidences, tender pressures of the hand, and eloquent glances of the
514	eye, for with Jo, brain developed earlier than heart, and she preferred
514	imaginary heroes to real ones, because when tired of them, the former
514	could be shut up in the tin kitchen till called for, and the latter
514	were less manageable.
514	""
514	Things were in this state when the grand discovery was made, and Jo
514	watched Laurie that night as she had never done before.  If she had not
514	got the new idea into her head, she would have seen nothing unusual in
514	the fact that Beth was very quiet, and Laurie very kind to her.  But
514	having given the rein to her lively fancy, it galloped away with her at
514	a great pace, and common sense, being rather weakened by a long course
514	of romance writing, did not come to the rescue.  As usual Beth lay on
514	the sofa and Laurie sat in a low chair close by, amusing her with all
514	sorts of gossip, for she depended on her weekly 'spin', and he never
514	disappointed her.  But that evening Jo fancied that Beth's eyes rested
514	on the lively, dark face beside her with peculiar pleasure, and that
514	she listened with intense interest to an account of some exciting
514	cricket match, though the phrases, 'caught off a tice', 'stumped off
514	his ground', and 'the leg hit for three', were as intelligible to her
514	as Sanskrit.  She also fancied, having set her heart upon seeing it,
514	that she saw a certain increase of gentleness in Laurie's manner, that
514	he dropped his voice now and then, laughed less than usual, was a
514	little absent-minded, and settled the afghan over Beth's feet with an
514	assiduity that was really almost tender.
514	""
514	"""Who knows?  Stranger things have happened,"" thought Jo, as she fussed"
514	"about the room.  ""She will make quite an angel of him, and he will make"
514	life delightfully easy and pleasant for the dear, if they only love
514	each other.  I don't see how he can help it, and I do believe he would
514	"if the rest of us were out of the way."""
514	""
514	As everyone was out of the way but herself, Jo began to feel that she
514	ought to dispose of herself with all speed.  But where should she go?
514	And burning to lay herself upon the shrine of sisterly devotion, she
514	sat down to settle that point.
514	""
514	Now, the old sofa was a regular patriarch of a sofa--long, broad,
514	well-cushioned, and low, a trifle shabby, as well it might be, for the
514	girls had slept and sprawled on it as babies, fished over the back,
514	rode on the arms, and had menageries under it as children, and rested
514	tired heads, dreamed dreams, and listened to tender talk on it as young
514	women.  They all loved it, for it was a family refuge, and one corner
514	had always been Jo's favorite lounging place.  Among the many pillows
514	that adorned the venerable couch was one, hard, round, covered with
514	prickly horsehair, and furnished with a knobby button at each end.
514	This repulsive pillow was her especial property, being used as a weapon
514	of defense, a barricade, or a stern preventive of too much slumber.
514	""
514	Laurie knew this pillow well, and had cause to regard it with deep
514	aversion, having been unmercifully pummeled with it in former days when
514	romping was allowed, and now frequently debarred by it from the seat he
514	most coveted next to Jo in the sofa corner.  If 'the sausage' as they
514	called it, stood on end, it was a sign that he might approach and
514	repose, but if it lay flat across the sofa, woe to man, woman, or child
514	who dared disturb it!  That evening Jo forgot to barricade her corner,
514	and had not been in her seat five minutes, before a massive form
514	appeared beside her, and with both arms spread over the sofa back, both
514	long legs stretched out before him, Laurie exclaimed, with a sigh of
514	satisfaction...
514	""
514	"""Now, this is filling at the price."""
514	""
514	"""No slang,"" snapped Jo, slamming down the pillow.  But it was too late,"
514	there was no room for it, and coasting onto the floor, it disappeared
514	in a most mysterious manner.
514	""
514	"""Come, Jo, don't be thorny.  After studying himself to a skeleton all"
514	"the week, a fellow deserves petting and ought to get it."""
514	""
514	"""Beth will pet you.  I'm busy."""
514	""
514	"""No, she's not to be bothered with me, but you like that sort of thing,"
514	unless you've suddenly lost your taste for it.  Have you? Do you hate
514	"your boy, and want to fire pillows at him?"""
514	""
514	Anything more wheedlesome than that touching appeal was seldom heard,
514	"but Jo quenched 'her boy' by turning on him with a stern query, ""How"
514	"many bouquets have you sent Miss Randal this week?"""
514	""
514	"""Not one, upon my word.  She's engaged.  Now then."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of it, that's one of your foolish extravagances, sending"
514	"flowers and things to girls for whom you don't care two pins,"""
514	continued Jo reprovingly.
514	""
514	"""Sensible girls for whom I do care whole papers of pins won't let me"
514	send them 'flowers and things', so what can I do? My feelings need a
514	"'vent'."""
514	""
514	"""Mother doesn't approve of flirting even in fun, and you do flirt"
514	"desperately, Teddy."""
514	""
514	"""I'd give anything if I could answer, 'So do you'.  As I can't, I'll"
514	merely say that I don't see any harm in that pleasant little game, if
514	"all parties understand that it's only play."""
514	""
514	"""Well, it does look pleasant, but I can't learn how it's done. I've"
514	tried, because one feels awkward in company not to do as everybody else
514	"is doing, but I don't seem to get on"", said Jo, forgetting to play"
514	mentor.
514	""
514	"""Take lessons of Amy, she has a regular talent for it."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, she does it very prettily, and never seems to go too far.  I"
514	suppose it's natural to some people to please without trying, and
514	"others to always say and do the wrong thing in the wrong place."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad you can't flirt.  It's really refreshing to see a sensible,"
514	straightforward girl, who can be jolly and kind without making a fool
514	of herself.  Between ourselves, Jo, some of the girls I know really do
514	go on at such a rate I'm ashamed of them. They don't mean any harm, I'm
514	sure, but if they knew how we fellows talked about them afterward,
514	"they'd mend their ways, I fancy."""
514	""
514	"""They do the same, and as their tongues are the sharpest, you fellows"
514	get the worst of it, for you are as silly as they, every bit.  If you
514	behaved properly, they would, but knowing you like their nonsense, they
514	"keep it up, and then you blame them."""
514	""
514	"""Much you know about it, ma'am,"" said Laurie in a superior tone. ""We"
514	don't like romps and flirts, though we may act as if we did sometimes.
514	The pretty, modest girls are never talked about, except respectfully,
514	among gentleman. Bless your innocent soul!  If you could be in my place
514	for a month you'd see things that would astonish you a trifle. Upon my
514	word, when I see one of those harum-scarum girls, I always want to say
514	with our friend Cock Robin...
514	""
514	"    ""Out upon you, fie upon you,"
514	"     Bold-faced jig!"""
514	""
514	It was impossible to help laughing at the funny conflict between
514	Laurie's chivalrous reluctance to speak ill of womankind, and his very
514	natural dislike of the unfeminine folly of which fashionable society
514	showed him many samples.  Jo knew that 'young Laurence' was regarded as
514	a most eligible parti by worldly mamas, was much smiled upon by their
514	daughters, and flattered enough by ladies of all ages to make a coxcomb
514	of him, so she watched him rather jealously, fearing he would be
514	spoiled, and rejoiced more than she confessed to find that he still
514	believed in modest girls.  Returning suddenly to her admonitory tone,
514	"she said, dropping her voice, ""If you must have a 'vent', Teddy, go and"
514	devote yourself to one of the 'pretty, modest girls' whom you do
514	"respect, and not waste your time with the silly ones."""
514	""
514	"""You really advise it?"" and Laurie looked at her with an odd mixture of"
514	anxiety and merriment in his face.
514	""
