514	"""Yes, I do, but you'd better wait till you are through college, on the"
514	whole, and be fitting yourself for the place meantime.  You're not half
514	"good enough for--well, whoever the modest girl may be."" and Jo looked a"
514	little queer likewise, for a name had almost escaped her.
514	""
514	"""That I'm not!"" acquiesced Laurie, with an expression of humility quite"
514	new to him, as he dropped his eyes and absently wound Jo's apron tassel
514	round his finger.
514	""
514	"""Mercy on us, this will never do,"" thought Jo, adding aloud, ""Go and"
514	"sing to me.  I'm dying for some music, and always like yours."""
514	""
514	"""I'd rather stay here, thank you."""
514	""
514	"""Well, you can't, there isn't room.  Go and make yourself useful, since"
514	you are too big to be ornamental.  I thought you hated to be tied to a
514	"woman's apron string?"" retorted Jo, quoting certain rebellious words of"
514	his own.
514	""
514	"""Ah, that depends on who wears the apron!"" and Laurie gave an audacious"
514	tweak at the tassel.
514	""
514	"""Are you going?"" demanded Jo, diving for the pillow."
514	""
514	"He fled at once, and the minute it was well, ""Up with the bonnets of"
514	"bonnie Dundee,"" she slipped away to return no more till the young"
514	gentleman departed in high dudgeon.
514	""
514	Jo lay long awake that night, and was just dropping off when the sound
514	of a stifled sob made her fly to Beth's bedside, with the anxious
514	"inquiry, ""What is it, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""I thought you were asleep,"" sobbed Beth."
514	""
514	"""Is it the old pain, my precious?"""
514	""
514	"""No, it's a new one, but I can bear it,"" and Beth tried to check her"
514	tears.
514	""
514	"""Tell me all about it, and let me cure it as I often did the other."""
514	""
514	"""You can't, there is no cure.""  There Beth's voice gave way, and"
514	clinging to her sister, she cried so despairingly that Jo was
514	frightened.
514	""
514	"""Where is it?  Shall I call Mother?"""
514	""
514	"""No, no, don't call her, don't tell her.  I shall be better soon.  Lie"
514	down here and 'poor' my head.  I'll be quiet and go to sleep, indeed I
514	"will."""
514	""
514	Jo obeyed, but as her hand went softly to and fro across Beth's hot
514	forehead and wet eyelids, her heart was very full and she longed to
514	speak.  But young as she was, Jo had learned that hearts, like flowers,
514	cannot be rudely handled, but must open naturally, so though she
514	believed she knew the cause of Beth's new pain, she only said, in her
514	"tenderest tone, ""Does anything trouble you, deary?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, Jo,"" after a long pause."
514	""
514	"""Wouldn't it comfort you to tell me what it is?"""
514	""
514	"""Not now, not yet."""
514	""
514	"""Then I won't ask, but remember, Bethy, that Mother and Jo are always"
514	"glad to hear and help you, if they can."""
514	""
514	"""I know it.  I'll tell you by-and-by."""
514	""
514	"""Is the pain better now?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, yes, much better, you are so comfortable, Jo."""
514	""
514	"""Go to sleep, dear.  I'll stay with you."""
514	""
514	So cheek to cheek they fell asleep, and on the morrow Beth seemed quite
514	herself again, for at eighteen neither heads nor hearts ache long, and
514	a loving word can medicine most ills.
514	""
514	But Jo had made up her mind, and after pondering over a project for
514	some days, she confided it to her mother.
514	""
514	"""You asked me the other day what my wishes were.  I'll tell you one of"
514	"them, Marmee,"" she began, as they sat along together.  ""I want to go"
514	"away somewhere this winter for a change."""
514	""
514	"""Why, Jo?"" and her mother looked up quickly, as if the words suggested"
514	a double meaning.
514	""
514	"With her eyes on her work Jo answered soberly, ""I want something new."
514	I feel restless and anxious to be seeing, doing, and learning more than
514	I am.  I brood too much over my own small affairs, and need stirring
514	up, so as I can be spared this winter, I'd like to hop a little way and
514	"try my wings."""
514	""
514	"""Where will you hop?"""
514	""
514	"""To New York.  I had a bright idea yesterday, and this is it.  You know"
514	Mrs. Kirke wrote to you for some respectable young person to teach her
514	children and sew.  It's rather hard to find just the thing, but I think
514	"I should suit if I tried."""
514	""
514	"""My dear, go out to service in that great boarding house!"" and Mrs."
514	March looked surprised, but not displeased.
514	""
514	"""It's not exactly going out to service, for Mrs. Kirke is your"
514	friend--the kindest soul that ever lived--and would make things
514	pleasant for me, I know.  Her family is separate from the rest, and no
514	one knows me there.  Don't care if they do. It's honest work, and I'm
514	"not ashamed of it."""
514	""
514	"""Nor I.  But your writing?"""
514	""
514	"""All the better for the change.  I shall see and hear new things, get"
514	new ideas, and even if I haven't much time there, I shall bring home
514	"quantities of material for my rubbish."""
514	""
514	"""I have no doubt of it, but are these your only reasons for this sudden"
514	"fancy?"""
514	""
514	"""No, Mother."""
514	""
514	"""May I know the others?"""
514	""
514	Jo looked up and Jo looked down, then said slowly, with sudden color in
514	"her cheeks.  ""It may be vain and wrong to say it, but--I'm"
514	"afraid--Laurie is getting too fond of me."""
514	""
514	"""Then you don't care for him in the way it is evident he begins to care"
514	"for you?"" and Mrs. March looked anxious as she put the question."
514	""
514	"""Mercy, no!  I love the dear boy, as I always have, and am immensely"
514	"proud of him, but as for anything more, it's out of the question."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of that, Jo."""
514	""
514	"""Why, please?"""
514	""
514	"""Because, dear, I don't think you suited to one another.  As friends"
514	you are very happy, and your frequent quarrels soon blow over, but I
514	fear you would both rebel if you were mated for life. You are too much
514	alike and too fond of freedom, not to mention hot tempers and strong
514	wills, to get on happily together, in a relation which needs infinite
514	"patience and forbearance, as well as love."""
514	""
514	"""That's just the feeling I had, though I couldn't express it. I'm glad"
514	you think he is only beginning to care for me.  It would trouble me
514	sadly to make him unhappy, for I couldn't fall in love with the dear
514	"old fellow merely out of gratitude, could I?"""
514	""
514	"""You are sure of his feeling for you?"""
514	""
514	The color deepened in Jo's cheeks as she answered, with the look of
514	mingled pleasure, pride, and pain which young girls wear when speaking
514	"of first lovers, ""I'm afraid it is so, Mother.  He hasn't said"
514	anything, but he looks a great deal. I think I had better go away
514	"before it comes to anything."""
514	""
514	"""I agree with you, and if it can be managed you shall go."""
514	""
514	"Jo looked relieved, and after a pause, said, smiling, ""How Mrs. Moffat"
514	would wonder at your want of management, if she knew, and how she will
514	"rejoice that Annie may still hope."""
514	""
514	"""Ah, Jo, mothers may differ in their management, but the hope is the"
514	same in all--the desire to see their children happy. Meg is so, and I
514	am content with her success.  You I leave to enjoy your liberty till
514	you tire of it, for only then will you find that there is something
514	sweeter.  Amy is my chief care now, but her good sense will help her.
514	For Beth, I indulge no hopes except that she may be well.  By the way,
514	she seems brighter this last day or two.  Have you spoken to her?'
514	""
514	"""Yes, she owned she had a trouble, and promised to tell me by-and-by."
514	"I said no more, for I think I know it,"" and Jo told her little story."
514	""
514	Mrs. March shook her head, and did not take so romantic a view of the
514	case, but looked grave, and repeated her opinion that for Laurie's sake
514	Jo should go away for a time.
514	""
514	"""Let us say nothing about it to him till the plan is settled, then I'll"
514	run away before he can collect his wits and be tragic. Beth must think
514	I'm going to please myself, as I am, for I can't talk about Laurie to
514	her.  But she can pet and comfort him after I'm gone, and so cure him
514	of this romantic notion.  He's been through so many little trials of
514	"the sort, he's used to it, and will soon get over his lovelornity."""
514	""
514	Jo spoke hopefully, but could not rid herself of the foreboding fear
514	that this 'little trial' would be harder than the others, and that
514	Laurie would not get over his 'lovelornity' as easily as heretofore.
514	""
514	The plan was talked over in a family council and agreed upon, for Mrs.
514	Kirke gladly accepted Jo, and promised to make a pleasant home for her.
514	The teaching would render her independent, and such leisure as she got
514	might be made profitable by writing, while the new scenes and society
514	would be both useful and agreeable.  Jo liked the prospect and was
514	eager to be gone, for the home nest was growing too narrow for her
514	restless nature and adventurous spirit.  When all was settled, with
514	fear and trembling she told Laurie, but to her surprise he took it very
514	quietly.  He had been graver than usual of late, but very pleasant, and
514	when jokingly accused of turning over a new leaf, he answered soberly,
514	"""So I am, and I mean this one shall stay turned."""
514	""
514	Jo was very much relieved that one of his virtuous fits should come on
514	just then, and made her preparations with a lightened heart, for Beth
514	seemed more cheerful, and hoped she was doing the best for all.
514	""
514	"""One thing I leave in your especial care,"" she said, the night before"
514	she left.
514	""
514	"""You mean your papers?"" asked Beth."
514	""
514	"""No, my boy.  Be very good to him, won't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course I will, but I can't fill your place, and he'll miss you"
514	"sadly."""
514	""
514	"""It won't hurt him, so remember, I leave him in your charge, to plague,"
514	"pet, and keep in order."""
514	""
514	"""I'll do my best, for your sake,"" promised Beth, wondering why Jo"
514	looked at her so queerly.
514	""
514	"When Laurie said good-by, he whispered significantly, ""It won't do a"
514	bit of good, Jo.  My eye is on you, so mind what you do, or I'll come
514	"and bring you home."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE
514	""
514	JO'S JOURNAL
514	""
514	New York, November
514	""
514	Dear Marmee and Beth,
514	""
514	I'm going to write you a regular volume, for I've got heaps to tell,
514	though I'm not a fine young lady traveling on the continent. When I
514	lost sight of Father's dear old face, I felt a trifle blue, and might
514	have shed a briny drop or two, if an Irish lady with four small
514	children, all crying more or less, hadn't diverted my mind, for I
514	amused myself by dropping gingerbread nuts over the seat every time
514	they opened their mouths to roar.
514	""
514	Soon the sun came out, and taking it as a good omen, I cleared up
514	likewise and enjoyed my journey with all my heart.
514	""
514	Mrs. Kirke welcomed me so kindly I felt at home at once, even in that
514	big house full of strangers.  She gave me a funny little sky
514	parlor--all she had, but there is a stove in it, and a nice table in a
514	sunny window, so I can sit here and write whenever I like.  A fine view
514	and a church tower opposite atone for the many stairs, and I took a
514	fancy to my den on the spot. The nursery, where I am to teach and sew,
514	is a pleasant room next Mrs. Kirke's private parlor, and the two little
514	girls are pretty children, rather spoiled, I fancy, but they took to me
514	after telling them The Seven Bad Pigs, and I've no doubt I shall make a
514	model governess.
514	""
514	I am to have my meals with the children, if I prefer it to the great
514	table, and for the present I do, for I am bashful, though no one will
514	believe it.
514	""
514	"""Now, my dear, make yourself at home,"" said Mrs. K.  in her motherly"
514	"way, ""I'm on the drive from morning to night, as you may suppose with"
514	such a family, but a great anxiety will be off my mind if I know the
514	children are safe with you.  My rooms are always open to you, and your
514	own shall be as comfortable as I can make it.  There are some pleasant
514	people in the house if you feel sociable, and your evenings are always
514	free.  Come to me if anything goes wrong, and be as happy as you can.
514	"There's the tea bell, I must run and change my cap.""  And off she"
514	bustled, leaving me to settle myself in my new nest.
514	""
514	As I went downstairs soon after, I saw something I liked. The flights
514	are very long in this tall house, and as I stood waiting at the head of
514	the third one for a little servant girl to lumber up, I saw a gentleman
514	come along behind her, take the heavy hod of coal out of her hand,
514	carry it all the way up, put it down at a door near by, and walk away,
514	"saying, with a kind nod and a foreign accent, ""It goes better so.  The"
514	"little back is too young to haf such heaviness."""
514	""
514	Wasn't it good of him?  I like such things, for as Father says, trifles
514	show character.  When I mentioned it to Mrs. K., that evening, she
514	"laughed, and said, ""That must have been Professor Bhaer, he's always"
514	"doing things of that sort."""
514	""
514	Mrs. K.  told me he was from Berlin, very learned and good, but poor as
514	a church mouse, and gives lessons to support himself and two little
514	orphan nephews whom he is educating here, according to the wishes of
514	his sister, who married an American.  Not a very romantic story, but it
514	interested me, and I was glad to hear that Mrs. K.  lends him her
514	parlor for some of his scholars. There is a glass door between it and
514	the nursery, and I mean to peep at him, and then I'll tell you how he
514	looks.  He's almost forty, so it's no harm, Marmee.
514	""
514	After tea and a go-to-bed romp with the little girls, I attacked the
514	big workbasket, and had a quiet evening chatting with my new friend.  I
514	shall keep a journal-letter, and send it once a week, so goodnight, and
514	more tomorrow.
514	""
514	Tuesday Eve
514	""
514	Had a lively time in my seminary this morning, for the children acted
514	like Sancho, and at one time I really thought I should shake them all
514	round.  Some good angel inspired me to try gymnastics, and I kept it up
514	till they were glad to sit down and keep still.  After luncheon, the
514	girl took them out for a walk, and I went to my needlework like little
514	Mabel 'with a willing mind'.  I was thanking my stars that I'd learned
514	to make nice buttonholes, when the parlor door opened and shut, and
514	someone began to hum, Kennst Du Das Land, like a big bumblebee. It was
514	dreadfully improper, I know, but I couldn't resist the temptation, and
514	lifting one end of the curtain before the glass door, I peeped in.
514	Professor Bhaer was there, and while he arranged his books, I took a
514	good look at him.  A regular German--rather stout, with brown hair
514	tumbled all over his head, a bushy beard, good nose, the kindest eyes I
514	ever saw, and a splendid big voice that does one's ears good, after our
514	sharp or slipshod American gabble.  His clothes were rusty, his hands
514	were large, and he hadn't a really handsome feature in his face, except
514	his beautiful teeth, yet I liked him, for he had a fine head, his linen
514	was very nice, and he looked like a gentleman, though two buttons were
514	off his coat and there was a patch on one shoe.  He looked sober in
514	spite of his humming, till he went to the window to turn the hyacinth
514	bulbs toward the sun, and stroke the cat, who received him like an old
514	friend.  Then he smiled, and when a tap came at the door, called out in
514	"a loud, brisk tone, ""Herein!"""
514	""
514	I was just going to run, when I caught sight of a morsel of a child
514	carrying a big book, and stopped, to see what was going on.
514	""
514	"""Me wants me Bhaer,"" said the mite, slamming down her book and running"
514	to meet him.
514	""
514	"""Thou shalt haf thy Bhaer.  Come, then, and take a goot hug from him,"
514	"my Tina,"" said the Professor, catching her up with a laugh, and holding"
514	her so high over his head that she had to stoop her little face to kiss
514	him.
514	""
514	"""Now me mus tuddy my lessin,"" went on the funny little thing.  So he"
514	put her up at the table, opened the great dictionary she had brought,
514	and gave her a paper and pencil, and she scribbled away, turning a leaf
514	now and then, and passing her little fat finger down the page, as if
514	finding a word, so soberly that I nearly betrayed myself by a laugh,
514	while Mr. Bhaer stood stroking her pretty hair with a fatherly look
514	that made me think she must be his own, though she looked more French
514	than German.
514	""
514	Another knock and the appearance of two young ladies sent me back to my
514	work, and there I virtuously remained through all the noise and
514	gabbling that went on next door.  One of the girls kept laughing
514	"affectedly, and saying, ""Now Professor,"" in a coquettish tone, and the"
514	other pronounced her German with an accent that must have made it hard
514	for him to keep sober.
514	""
514	Both seemed to try his patience sorely, for more than once I heard him
514	"say emphatically, ""No, no, it is not so, you haf not attend to what I"
514	"say,"" and once there was a loud rap, as if he struck the table with his"
514	"book, followed by the despairing exclamation, ""Prut!  It all goes bad"
514	"this day."""
514	""
514	Poor man, I pitied him, and when the girls were gone, took just one
514	more peep to see if he survived it.  He seemed to have thrown himself
514	back in his chair, tired out, and sat there with his eyes shut till the
514	clock struck two, when he jumped up, put his books in his pocket, as if
514	ready for another lesson, and taking little Tina who had fallen asleep
514	on the sofa in his arms, he carried her quietly away.  I fancy he has a
514	hard life of it.  Mrs. Kirke asked me if I wouldn't go down to the five
514	o'clock dinner, and feeling a little bit homesick, I thought I would,
514	just to see what sort of people are under the same roof with me.  So I
514	made myself respectable and tried to slip in behind Mrs. Kirke, but as
514	she is short and I'm tall, my efforts at concealment were rather a
514	failure.  She gave me a seat by her, and after my face cooled off, I
514	plucked up courage and looked about me.  The long table was full, and
514	every one intent on getting their dinner, the gentlemen especially, who
514	seemed to be eating on time, for they bolted in every sense of the
514	word, vanishing as soon as they were done.  There was the usual
514	assortment of young men absorbed in themselves, young couples absorbed
514	in each other, married ladies in their babies, and old gentlemen in
514	politics.  I don't think I shall care to have much to do with any of
514	them, except one sweetfaced maiden lady, who looks as if she had
514	something in her.
514	""
514	Cast away at the very bottom of the table was the Professor, shouting
514	answers to the questions of a very inquisitive, deaf old gentleman on
514	one side, and talking philosophy with a Frenchman on the other.  If Amy
514	had been here, she'd have turned her back on him forever because, sad
514	to relate, he had a great appetite, and shoveled in his dinner in a
514	manner which would have horrified 'her ladyship'.  I didn't mind, for I
514	like 'to see folks eat with a relish', as Hannah says, and the poor man
514	must have needed a deal of food after teaching idiots all day.
514	""
514	As I went upstairs after dinner, two of the young men were settling
514	their hats before the hall mirror, and I heard one say low to the
514	"other, ""Who's the new party?"""
514	""
514	"""Governess, or something of that sort."""
514	""
514	"""What the deuce is she at our table for?"""
514	""
514	"""Friend of the old lady's."""
514	""
514	"""Handsome head, but no style."""
514	""
514	"""Not a bit of it.  Give us a light and come on."""
514	""
514	I felt angry at first, and then I didn't care, for a governess is as
514	good as a clerk, and I've got sense, if I haven't style, which is more
514	than some people have, judging from the remarks of the elegant beings
514	who clattered away, smoking like bad chimneys.  I hate ordinary people!
514	""
514	""
514	Thursday
514	""
514	Yesterday was a quiet day spent in teaching, sewing, and writing in my
514	little room, which is very cozy, with a light and fire.  I picked up a
514	few bits of news and was introduced to the Professor.  It seems that
514	Tina is the child of the Frenchwoman who does the fine ironing in the
514	laundry here.  The little thing has lost her heart to Mr. Bhaer, and
514	follows him about the house like a dog whenever he is at home, which
514	delights him, as he is very fond of children, though a 'bacheldore'.
514	Kitty and Minnie Kirke likewise regard him with affection, and tell all
514	sorts of stories about the plays he invents, the presents he brings,
514	and the splendid tales he tells.  The younger men quiz him, it seems,
514	call him Old Fritz, Lager Beer, Ursa Major, and make all manner of
514	jokes on his name.  But he enjoys it like a boy, Mrs. Kirke says, and
514	takes it so good-naturedly that they all like him in spite of his
514	foreign ways.
514	""
514	The maiden lady is a Miss Norton, rich, cultivated, and kind.  She
514	spoke to me at dinner today (for I went to table again, it's such fun
514	to watch people), and asked me to come and see her at her room.  She
514	has fine books and pictures, knows interesting persons, and seems
514	friendly, so I shall make myself agreeable, for I do want to get into
514	good society, only it isn't the same sort that Amy likes.
514	""
514	I was in our parlor last evening when Mr. Bhaer came in with some
514	newspapers for Mrs. Kirke.  She wasn't there, but Minnie, who is a
514	"little old woman, introduced me very prettily. ""This is Mamma's friend,"
514	"Miss March."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, and she's jolly and we like her lots,"" added Kitty, who is an"
514	'enfant terrible'.
514	""
514	We both bowed, and then we laughed, for the prim introduction and the
514	blunt addition were rather a comical contrast.
514	""
514	"""Ah, yes, I hear these naughty ones go to vex you, Mees Marsch.  If so"
514	"again, call at me and I come,"" he said, with a threatening frown that"
514	delighted the little wretches.
514	""
514	I promised I would, and he departed, but it seems as if I was doomed to
514	see a good deal of him, for today as I passed his door on my way out,
514	by accident I knocked against it with my umbrella.  It flew open, and
514	there he stood in his dressing gown, with a big blue sock on one hand
514	and a darning needle in the other.  He didn't seem at all ashamed of
514	it, for when I explained and hurried on, he waved his hand, sock and
514	all, saying in his loud, cheerful way...
514	""
514	"""You haf a fine day to make your walk.  Bon voyage, Mademoiselle."""
514	""
514	I laughed all the way downstairs, but it was a little pathetic, also to
514	think of the poor man having to mend his own clothes. The German
514	gentlemen embroider, I know, but darning hose is another thing and not
514	so pretty.
514	""
514	""
514	Saturday
514	""
514	Nothing has happened to write about, except a call on Miss Norton, who
514	has a room full of pretty things, and who was very charming, for she
514	showed me all her treasures, and asked me if I would sometimes go with
514	her to lectures and concerts, as her escort, if I enjoyed them.  She
514	put it as a favor, but I'm sure Mrs. Kirke has told her about us, and
514	she does it out of kindness to me.  I'm as proud as Lucifer, but such
514	favors from such people don't burden me, and I accepted gratefully.
514	""
514	When I got back to the nursery there was such an uproar in the parlor
514	that I looked in, and there was Mr. Bhaer down on his hands and knees,
514	with Tina on his back, Kitty leading him with a jump rope, and Minnie
514	feeding two small boys with seedcakes, as they roared and ramped in
514	cages built of chairs.
514	""
514	"""We are playing nargerie,"" explained Kitty."
514	""
514	"""Dis is mine effalunt!"" added Tina, holding on by the Professor's hair."
514	""
514	"""Mamma always allows us to do what we like Saturday afternoon, when"
514	"Franz and Emil come, doesn't she, Mr. Bhaer?"" said Minnie."
514	""
514	The 'effalunt' sat up, looking as much in earnest as any of them, and
514	"said soberly to me, ""I gif you my wort it is so, if we make too large a"
514	"noise you shall say Hush! to us, and we go more softly."""
514	""
514	I promised to do so, but left the door open and enjoyed the fun as much
514	as they did, for a more glorious frolic I never witnessed.  They played
514	tag and soldiers, danced and sang, and when it began to grow dark they
514	all piled onto the sofa about the Professor, while he told charming
514	fairy stories of the storks on the chimney tops, and the little
514	'koblods', who ride the snowflakes as they fall.  I wish Americans were
514	as simple and natural as Germans, don't you?
514	""
514	I'm so fond of writing, I should go spinning on forever if motives of
514	economy didn't stop me, for though I've used thin paper and written
514	fine, I tremble to think of the stamps this long letter will need.
514	Pray forward Amy's as soon as you can spare them.  My small news will
514	sound very flat after her splendors, but you will like them, I know.
514	Is Teddy studying so hard that he can't find time to write to his
514	friends?  Take good care of him for me, Beth, and tell me all about the
514	babies, and give heaps of love to everyone.  From your faithful Jo.
514	""
514	P.S.  On reading over my letter, it strikes me as rather Bhaery, but I
514	am always interested in odd people, and I really had nothing else to
514	write about.  Bless you!
514	""
514	DECEMBER
514	""
514	My Precious Betsey,
514	""
514	As this is to be a scribble-scrabble letter, I direct it to you, for it
514	may amuse you, and give you some idea of my goings on, for though
514	quiet, they are rather amusing, for which, oh, be joyful!  After what
514	Amy would call Herculaneum efforts, in the way of mental and moral
514	agriculture, my young ideas begin to shoot and my little twigs to bend
514	as I could wish.  They are not so interesting to me as Tina and the
514	boys, but I do my duty by them, and they are fond of me.  Franz and
514	Emil are jolly little lads, quite after my own heart, for the mixture
514	of German and American spirit in them produces a constant state of
514	effervescence.  Saturday afternoons are riotous times, whether spent in
514	the house or out, for on pleasant days they all go to walk, like a
514	seminary, with the Professor and myself to keep order, and then such
514	fun!
514	""
514	We are very good friends now, and I've begun to take lessons.  I really
514	couldn't help it, and it all came about in such a droll way that I must
514	tell you.  To begin at the beginning, Mrs. Kirke called to me one day
514	as I passed Mr. Bhaer's room where she was rummaging.
514	""
514	"""Did you ever see such a den, my dear?  Just come and help me put these"
514	books to rights, for I've turned everything upside down, trying to
514	discover what he has done with the six new handkerchiefs I gave him not
514	"long ago."""
514	""
514	I went in, and while we worked I looked about me, for it was 'a den' to
514	be sure.  Books and papers everywhere, a broken meerschaum, and an old
514	flute over the mantlepiece as if done with, a ragged bird without any
514	tail chirped on one window seat, and a box of white mice adorned the
514	other.  Half-finished boats and bits of string lay among the
514	manuscripts.  Dirty little boots stood drying before the fire, and
514	traces of the dearly beloved boys, for whom he makes a slave of
514	himself, were to be seen all over the room.  After a grand rummage
514	three of the missing articles were found, one over the bird cage, one
514	covered with ink, and a third burned brown, having been used as a
514	holder.
514	""
514	"""Such a man!"" laughed good-natured Mrs. K., as she put the relics in"
514	"the rag bag.  ""I suppose the others are torn up to rig ships, bandage"
514	cut fingers, or make kite tails.  It's dreadful, but I can't scold him.
514	He's so absent-minded and goodnatured, he lets those boys ride over him
514	roughshod.  I agreed to do his washing and mending, but he forgets to
514	give out his things and I forget to look them over, so he comes to a
514	"sad pass sometimes."""
514	""
514	"""Let me mend them,"" said I.  ""I don't mind it, and he needn't know."
514	I'd like to, he's so kind to me about bringing my letters and lending
514	"books."""
514	""
514	So I have got his things in order, and knit heels into two pairs of the
514	socks, for they were boggled out of shape with his queer darns.
514	Nothing was said, and I hoped he wouldn't find it out, but one day last
514	week he caught me at it.  Hearing the lessons he gives to others has
514	interested and amused me so much that I took a fancy to learn, for Tina
514	runs in and out, leaving the door open, and I can hear.  I had been
514	sitting near this door, finishing off the last sock, and trying to
514	understand what he said to a new scholar, who is as stupid as I am.
514	The girl had gone, and I thought he had also, it was so still, and I
514	was busily gabbling over a verb, and rocking to and fro in a most
514	absurd way, when a little crow made me look up, and there was Mr. Bhaer
514	looking and laughing quietly, while he made signs to Tina not to betray
514	him.
514	""
514	"""So!"" he said, as I stopped and stared like a goose, ""you peep at me, I"
514	peep at you, and this is not bad, but see, I am not pleasanting when I
514	"say, haf you a wish for German?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, but you are too busy.  I am too stupid to learn,"" I blundered"
514	out, as red as a peony.
514	""
514	"""Prut!  We will make the time, and we fail not to find the sense.  At"
514	efening I shall gif a little lesson with much gladness, for look you,
514	"Mees Marsch, I haf this debt to pay.""  And he pointed to my work 'Yes,'"
514	they say to one another, these so kind ladies, 'he is a stupid old
514	fellow, he will see not what we do, he will never observe that his sock
514	heels go not in holes any more, he will think his buttons grow out new
514	"when they fall, and believe that strings make theirselves.' ""Ah!  But I"
514	haf an eye, and I see much.  I haf a heart, and I feel thanks for this.
514	Come, a little lesson then and now, or--no more good fairy works for me
514	"and mine."""
514	""
514	Of course I couldn't say anything after that, and as it really is a
514	splendid opportunity, I made the bargain, and we began.  I took four
514	lessons, and then I stuck fast in a grammatical bog.  The Professor was
514	very patient with me, but it must have been torment to him, and now and
514	then he'd look at me with such an expression of mild despair that it
514	was a toss-up with me whether to laugh or cry.  I tried both ways, and
514	when it came to a sniff or utter mortification and woe, he just threw
514	the grammar on to the floor and marched out of the room. I felt myself
514	disgraced and deserted forever, but didn't blame him a particle, and
514	was scrambling my papers together, meaning to rush upstairs and shake
514	myself hard, when in he came, as brisk and beaming as if I'd covered
514	myself in glory.
514	""
514	"""Now we shall try a new way.  You and I will read these pleasant little"
514	_marchen_ together, and dig no more in that dry book, that goes in the
514	"corner for making us trouble."""
514	""
514	He spoke so kindly, and opened Hans Anderson's fairy tales so
514	invitingly before me, that I was more ashamed than ever, and went at my
514	lesson in a neck-or-nothing style that seemed to amuse him immensely.
514	I forgot my bashfulness, and pegged away (no other word will express
514	it) with all my might, tumbling over long words, pronouncing according
514	to inspiration of the minute, and doing my very best.  When I finished
514	reading my first page, and stopped for breath, he clapped his hands and
514	"cried out in his hearty way, ""Das ist gut! Now we go well!  My turn.  I"
514	"do him in German, gif me your ear.""  And away he went, rumbling out the"
514	words with his strong voice and a relish which was good to see as well
514	as hear.  Fortunately the story was _The Constant Tin Soldier_, which
514	is droll, you know, so I could laugh, and I did, though I didn't
514	understand half he read, for I couldn't help it, he was so earnest, I
514	so excited, and the whole thing so comical.
514	""
514	After that we got on better, and now I read my lessons pretty well, for
514	this way of studying suits me, and I can see that the grammar gets
514	tucked into the tales and poetry as one gives pills in jelly.  I like
514	it very much, and he doesn't seem tired of it yet, which is very good
514	of him, isn't it?  I mean to give him something on Christmas, for I
514	dare not offer money. Tell me something nice, Marmee.
514	""
514	I'm glad Laurie seems so happy and busy, that he has given up smoking
514	and lets his hair grow.  You see Beth manages him better than I did.
514	I'm not jealous, dear, do your best, only don't make a saint of him.
514	I'm afraid I couldn't like him without a spice of human naughtiness.
514	Read him bits of my letters.  I haven't time to write much, and that
514	will do just as well.  Thank Heaven Beth continues so comfortable.
514	""
514	JANUARY
514	""
514	A Happy New Year to you all, my dearest family, which of course
514	includes Mr. L.  and a young man by the name of Teddy. I can't tell you
514	how much I enjoyed your Christmas bundle, for I didn't get it till
514	night and had given up hoping.  Your letter came in the morning, but
514	you said nothing about a parcel, meaning it for a surprise, so I was
514	disappointed, for I'd had a 'kind of feeling' that you wouldn't forget
514	me. I felt a little low in my mind as I sat up in my room after tea,
514	and when the big, muddy, battered-looking bundle was brought to me, I
514	just hugged it and pranced.  It was so homey and refreshing that I sat
514	down on the floor and read and looked and ate and laughed and cried, in
514	my usual absurd way.  The things were just what I wanted, and all the
514	better for being made instead of bought.  Beth's new 'ink bib' was
514	capital, and Hannah's box of hard gingerbread will be a treasure.  I'll
514	be sure and wear the nice flannels you sent, Marmee, and read carefully
514	the books Father has marked.  Thank you all, heaps and heaps!
514	""
514	Speaking of books reminds me that I'm getting rich in that line, for on
514	New Year's Day Mr. Bhaer gave me a fine Shakespeare. It is one he
514	values much, and I've often admired it, set up in the place of honor
514	with his German Bible, Plato, Homer, and Milton, so you may imagine how
514	I felt when he brought it down, without its cover, and showed me my own
514	"name in it, ""from my friend Friedrich Bhaer""."
514	""
514	"""You say often you wish a library.  Here I gif you one, for between"
514	these lids (he meant covers) is many books in one.  Read him well, and
514	he will help you much, for the study of character in this book will
514	"help you to read it in the world and paint it with your pen."""
514	""
514	I thanked him as well as I could, and talk now about 'my library', as
514	if I had a hundred books.  I never knew how much there was in
514	Shakespeare before, but then I never had a Bhaer to explain it to me.
514	Now don't laugh at his horrid name.  It isn't pronounced either Bear or
514	Beer, as people will say it, but something between the two, as only
514	Germans can give it. I'm glad you both like what I tell you about him,
514	and hope you will know him some day.  Mother would admire his warm
514	heart, Father his wise head.  I admire both, and feel rich in my new
514	'friend Friedrich Bhaer'.
514	""
514	Not having much money, or knowing what he'd like, I got several little
514	things, and put them about the room, where he would find them
514	unexpectedly.  They were useful, pretty, or funny, a new standish on
514	his table, a little vase for his flower, he always has one, or a bit of
514	green in a glass, to keep him fresh, he says, and a holder for his
514	blower, so that he needn't burn up what Amy calls 'mouchoirs'.  I made
514	it like those Beth invented, a big butterfly with a fat body, and black
514	and yellow wings, worsted feelers, and bead eyes. It took his fancy
514	immensely, and he put it on his mantlepiece as an article of virtue, so
514	it was rather a failure after all. Poor as he is, he didn't forget a
514	servant or a child in the house, and not a soul here, from the French
514	laundrywoman to Miss Norton forgot him.  I was so glad of that.
514	""
514	They got up a masquerade, and had a gay time New Year's Eve.  I didn't
514	mean to go down, having no dress.  But at the last minute, Mrs. Kirke
514	remembered some old brocades, and Miss Norton lent me lace and
514	feathers.  So I dressed up as Mrs. Malaprop, and sailed in with a mask
514	on.  No one knew me, for I disguised my voice, and no one dreamed of
514	the silent, haughty Miss March (for they think I am very stiff and
514	cool, most of them, and so I am to whippersnappers) could dance and
514	dress, and burst out into a 'nice derangement of epitaphs, like an
514	allegory on the banks of the Nile'.  I enjoyed it very much, and when
514	we unmasked it was fun to see them stare at me.  I heard one of the
514	young men tell another that he knew I'd been an actress, in fact, he
514	thought he remembered seeing me at one of the minor theaters.  Meg will
514	relish that joke.  Mr. Bhaer was Nick Bottom, and Tina was Titania, a
514	perfect little fairy in his arms.  To see them dance was 'quite a
514	landscape', to use a Teddyism.
514	""
514	I had a very happy New Year, after all, and when I thought it over in
514	my room, I felt as if I was getting on a little in spite of my many
514	failures, for I'm cheerful all the time now, work with a will, and take
514	more interest in other people than I used to, which is satisfactory.
514	Bless you all!  Ever your loving...  Jo
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-FOUR
514	""
514	FRIEND
514	""
514	Though very happy in the social atmosphere about her, and very busy
514	with the daily work that earned her bread and made it sweeter for the
514	effort, Jo still found time for literary labors.  The purpose which now
514	took possession of her was a natural one to a poor and ambitious girl,
514	but the means she took to gain her end were not the best.  She saw that
514	money conferred power, money and power, therefore, she resolved to
514	have, not to be used for herself alone, but for those whom she loved
514	more than life.  The dream of filling home with comforts, giving Beth
514	everything she wanted, from strawberries in winter to an organ in her
514	bedroom, going abroad herself, and always having more than enough, so
514	that she might indulge in the luxury of charity, had been for years
514	Jo's most cherished castle in the air.
514	""
514	The prize-story experience had seemed to open a way which might, after
514	long traveling and much uphill work, lead to this delightful chateau en
514	Espagne.  But the novel disaster quenched her courage for a time, for
514	public opinion is a giant which has frightened stouter-hearted Jacks on
514	bigger beanstalks than hers. Like that immortal hero, she reposed
514	awhile after the first attempt, which resulted in a tumble and the
514	least lovely of the giant's treasures, if I remember rightly.  But the
514	'up again and take another' spirit was as strong in Jo as in Jack, so
514	she scrambled up on the shady side this time and got more booty, but
514	nearly left behind her what was far more precious than the moneybags.
514	""
514	She took to writing sensation stories, for in those dark ages, even
514	all-perfect America read rubbish.  She told no one, but concocted a
514	'thrilling tale', and boldly carried it herself to Mr. Dashwood, editor
514	of the Weekly Volcano.  She had never read Sartor Resartus, but she had
514	a womanly instinct that clothes possess an influence more powerful over
514	many than the worth of character or the magic of manners.  So she
514	dressed herself in her best, and trying to persuade herself that she
514	was neither excited nor nervous, bravely climbed two pairs of dark and
514	dirty stairs to find herself in a disorderly room, a cloud of cigar
514	smoke, and the presence of three gentlemen, sitting with their heels
514	rather higher than their hats, which articles of dress none of them
514	took the trouble to remove on her appearance.  Somewhat daunted by this
514	reception, Jo hesitated on the threshold, murmuring in much
514	embarrassment...
514	""
514	"""Excuse me, I was looking for the Weekly Volcano office. I wished to"
514	"see Mr. Dashwood."""
514	""
514	Down went the highest pair of heels, up rose the smokiest gentleman,
514	and carefully cherishing his cigar between his fingers, he advanced
514	with a nod and a countenance expressive of nothing but sleep.  Feeling
514	that she must get through the matter somehow, Jo produced her
514	manuscript and, blushing redder and redder with each sentence,
514	blundered out fragments of the little speech carefully prepared for the
514	occasion.
514	""
514	"""A friend of mine desired me to offer--a story--just as an"
514	experiment--would like your opinion--be glad to write more if this
514	"suits."""
514	""
514	While she blushed and blundered, Mr. Dashwood had taken the manuscript,
514	and was turning over the leaves with a pair of rather dirty fingers,
514	and casting critical glances up and down the neat pages.
514	""
514	"""Not a first attempt, I take it?"" observing that the pages were"
514	numbered, covered only on one side, and not tied up with a ribbon--sure
514	sign of a novice.
514	""
514	"""No, sir.  She has had some experience, and got a prize for a tale in"
514	"the _Blarneystone Banner_."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, did she?"" and Mr. Dashwood gave Jo a quick look, which seemed to"
514	take note of everything she had on, from the bow in her bonnet to the
514	"buttons on her boots.  ""Well, you can leave it, if you like.  We've"
514	more of this sort of thing on hand than we know what to do with at
514	"present, but I'll run my eye over it, and give you an answer next week."""
514	""
514	Now, Jo did _not_ like to leave it, for Mr. Dashwood didn't suit her at
514	all, but, under the circumstances, there was nothing for her to do but
514	bow and walk away, looking particularly tall and dignified, as she was
514	apt to do when nettled or abashed. Just then she was both, for it was
514	perfectly evident from the knowing glances exchanged among the
514	gentlemen that her little fiction of 'my friend' was considered a good
514	joke, and a laugh, produced by some inaudible remark of the editor, as
514	he closed the door, completed her discomfiture.  Half resolving never
514	to return, she went home, and worked off her irritation by stitching
514	pinafores vigorously, and in an hour or two was cool enough to laugh
514	over the scene and long for next week.
514	""
514	When she went again, Mr. Dashwood was alone, whereat she rejoiced.  Mr.
514	Dashwood was much wider awake than before, which was agreeable, and Mr.
514	Dashwood was not too deeply absorbed in a cigar to remember his
514	manners, so the second interview was much more comfortable than the
514	first.
514	""
514	"""We'll take this (editors never say I), if you don't object to a few"
514	alterations.  It's too long, but omitting the passages I've marked will
514	"make it just the right length,"" he said, in a businesslike tone."
514	""
514	Jo hardly knew her own MS.  again, so crumpled and underscored were its
514	pages and paragraphs, but feeling as a tender parent might on being
514	asked to cut off her baby's legs in order that it might fit into a new
514	cradle, she looked at the marked passages and was surprised to find
514	that all the moral reflections--which she had carefully put in as
514	ballast for much romance--had been stricken out.
514	""
514	"""But, Sir, I thought every story should have some sort of a moral, so I"
514	"took care to have a few of my sinners repent."""
514	""
514	Mr. Dashwoods's editorial gravity relaxed into a smile, for Jo had
514	forgotten her 'friend', and spoken as only an author could.
514	""
514	"""People want to be amused, not preached at, you know.  Morals don't"
514	"sell nowadays.""  Which was not quite a correct statement, by the way."
514	""
514	"""You think it would do with these alterations, then?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, it's a new plot, and pretty well worked up--language good, and so"
514	"on,"" was Mr. Dashwood's affable reply."
514	""
514	"""What do you--that is, what compensation--"" began Jo, not exactly"
514	knowing how to express herself.
514	""
514	"""Oh, yes, well, we give from twenty-five to thirty for things of this"
514	"sort.  Pay when it comes out,"" returned Mr. Dashwood, as if that point"
514	had escaped him.  Such trifles do escape the editorial mind, it is said.
514	""
514	"""Very well, you can have it,"" said Jo, handing back the story with a"
514	satisfied air, for after the dollar-a-column work, even twenty-five
514	seemed good pay.
514	""
514	"""Shall I tell my friend you will take another if she has one better"
514	"than this?"" asked Jo, unconscious of her little slip of the tongue, and"
514	emboldened by her success.
514	""
514	"""Well, we'll look at it.  Can't promise to take it.  Tell her to make"
514	it short and spicy, and never mind the moral.  What name would your
514	"friend like to put on it?"" in a careless tone."
514	""
514	"""None at all, if you please, she doesn't wish her name to appear and"
514	"has no nom de plume,"" said Jo, blushing in spite of herself."
514	""
514	"""Just as she likes, of course.  The tale will be out next week. Will"
514	"you call for the money, or shall I send it?"" asked Mr. Dashwood, who"
514	felt a natural desire to know who his new contributor might be.
514	""
514	"""I'll call.  Good morning, Sir."""
514	""
514	As she departed, Mr. Dashwood put up his feet, with the graceful
514	"remark, ""Poor and proud, as usual, but she'll do."""
514	""
514	Following Mr. Dashwood's directions, and making Mrs. Northbury her
514	model, Jo rashly took a plunge into the frothy sea of sensational
514	literature, but thanks to the life preserver thrown her by a friend,
514	she came up again not much the worse for her ducking.
514	""
514	Like most young scribblers, she went abroad for her characters and
514	scenery, and banditti, counts, gypsies, nuns, and duchesses appeared
514	upon her stage, and played their parts with as much accuracy and spirit
514	as could be expected.  Her readers were not particular about such
514	trifles as grammar, punctuation, and probability, and Mr. Dashwood
514	graciously permitted her to fill his columns at the lowest prices, not
514	thinking it necessary to tell her that the real cause of his
514	hospitality was the fact that one of his hacks, on being offered higher
514	wages, had basely left him in the lurch.
514	""
514	She soon became interested in her work, for her emaciated purse grew
514	stout, and the little hoard she was making to take Beth to the
514	mountains next summer grew slowly but surely as the weeks passed.  One
514	thing disturbed her satisfaction, and that was that she did not tell
514	them at home.  She had a feeling that Father and Mother would not
514	approve, and preferred to have her own way first, and beg pardon
514	afterward.  It was easy to keep her secret, for no name appeared with
514	her stories.  Mr. Dashwood had of course found it out very soon, but
514	promised to be dumb, and for a wonder kept his word.
514	""
514	She thought it would do her no harm, for she sincerely meant to write
514	nothing of which she would be ashamed, and quieted all pricks of
514	conscience by anticipations of the happy minute when she should show
514	her earnings and laugh over her well-kept secret.
514	""
514	But Mr. Dashwood rejected any but thrilling tales, and as thrills could
514	not be produced except by harrowing up the souls of the readers,
514	history and romance, land and sea, science and art, police records and
514	lunatic asylums, had to be ransacked for the purpose.  Jo soon found
514	that her innocent experience had given her but few glimpses of the
514	tragic world which underlies society, so regarding it in a business
514	light, she set about supplying her deficiencies with characteristic
514	energy. Eager to find material for stories, and bent on making them
514	original in plot, if not masterly in execution, she searched newspapers
514	for accidents, incidents, and crimes.  She excited the suspicions of
514	public librarians by asking for works on poisons.  She studied faces in
514	the street, and characters, good, bad, and indifferent, all about her.
514	She delved in the dust of ancient times for facts or fictions so old
514	that they were as good as new, and introduced herself to folly, sin,
514	and misery, as well as her limited opportunities allowed.  She thought
514	she was prospering finely, but unconsciously she was beginning to
514	desecrate some of the womanliest attributes of a woman's character.
514	She was living in bad society, and imaginary though it was, its
514	influence affected her, for she was feeding heart and fancy on
514	dangerous and unsubstantial food, and was fast brushing the innocent
514	bloom from her nature by a premature acquaintance with the darker side
514	of life, which comes soon enough to all of us.
514	""
514	She was beginning to feel rather than see this, for much describing of
514	other people's passions and feelings set her to studying and
514	speculating about her own, a morbid amusement in which healthy young
514	minds do not voluntarily indulge. Wrongdoing always brings its own
514	punishment, and when Jo most needed hers, she got it.
514	""
514	I don't know whether the study of Shakespeare helped her to read
514	character, or the natural instinct of a woman for what was honest,
514	brave, and strong, but while endowing her imaginary heroes with every
514	perfection under the sun, Jo was discovering a live hero, who
514	interested her in spite of many human imperfections.  Mr. Bhaer, in one
514	of their conversations, had advised her to study simple, true, and
514	lovely characters, wherever she found them, as good training for a
514	writer.  Jo took him at his word, for she coolly turned round and
514	studied him--a proceeding which would have much surprised him, had he
514	known it, for the worthy Professor was very humble in his own conceit.
514	""
514	Why everybody liked him was what puzzled Jo, at first.  He was neither
514	rich nor great, young nor handsome, in no respect what is called
514	fascinating, imposing, or brilliant, and yet he was as attractive as a
514	genial fire, and people seemed to gather about him as naturally as
514	about a warm hearth.  He was poor, yet always appeared to be giving
514	something away; a stranger, yet everyone was his friend; no longer
514	young, but as happy-hearted as a boy; plain and peculiar, yet his face
514	looked beautiful to many, and his oddities were freely forgiven for his
514	sake.  Jo often watched him, trying to discover the charm, and at last
514	decided that it was benevolence which worked the miracle.  If he had
514	any sorrow, 'it sat with its head under its wing', and he turned only
514	his sunny side to the world.  There were lines upon his forehead, but
514	Time seemed to have touched him gently, remembering how kind he was to
514	others.  The pleasant curves about his mouth were the memorials of many
514	friendly words and cheery laughs, his eyes were never cold or hard, and
514	his big hand had a warm, strong grasp that was more expressive than
514	words.
514	""
514	His very clothes seemed to partake of the hospitable nature of the
514	wearer.  They looked as if they were at ease, and liked to make him
514	comfortable.  His capacious waistcoat was suggestive of a large heart
514	underneath.  His rusty coat had a social air, and the baggy pockets
514	plainly proved that little hands often went in empty and came out full.
514	His very boots were benevolent, and his collars never stiff and raspy
514	like other people's.
514	""
514	"""That's it!"" said Jo to herself, when she at length discovered that"
514	genuine good will toward one's fellow men could beautify and dignify
514	even a stout German teacher, who shoveled in his dinner, darned his own
514	socks, and was burdened with the name of Bhaer.
514	""
514	Jo valued goodness highly, but she also possessed a most feminine
514	respect for intellect, and a little discovery which she made about the
514	Professor added much to her regard for him. He never spoke of himself,
514	and no one ever knew that in his native city he had been a man much
514	honored and esteemed for learning and integrity, till a countryman came
514	to see him. He never spoke of himself, and in a conversation with Miss
514	Norton divulged the pleasing fact.  From her Jo learned it, and liked
514	it all the better because Mr. Bhaer had never told it.  She felt proud
514	to know that he was an honored Professor in Berlin, though only a poor
514	language-master in America, and his homely, hard-working life was much
514	beautified by the spice of romance which this discovery gave it.
514	Another and a better gift than intellect was shown her in a most
514	unexpected manner.  Miss Norton had the entree into most society, which
514	Jo would have had no chance of seeing but for her.  The solitary woman
514	felt an interest in the ambitious girl, and kindly conferred many
514	favors of this sort both on Jo and the Professor.  She took them with
514	her one night to a select symposium, held in honor of several
514	celebrities.
514	""
514	Jo went prepared to bow down and adore the mighty ones whom she had
514	worshiped with youthful enthusiasm afar off.  But her reverence for
514	genius received a severe shock that night, and it took her some time to
514	recover from the discovery that the great creatures were only men and
514	women after all.  Imagine her dismay, on stealing a glance of timid
514	admiration at the poet whose lines suggested an ethereal being fed on
514	'spirit, fire, and dew', to behold him devouring his supper with an
514	ardor which flushed his intellectual countenance.  Turning as from a
514	fallen idol, she made other discoveries which rapidly dispelled her
514	romantic illusions.  The great novelist vibrated between two decanters
514	with the regularity of a pendulum; the famous divine flirted openly
514	with one of the Madame de Staels of the age, who looked daggers at
514	another Corinne, who was amiably satirizing her, after outmaneuvering
514	her in efforts to absorb the profound philosopher, who imbibed tea
514	Johnsonianly and appeared to slumber, the loquacity of the lady
514	rendering speech impossible.  The scientific celebrities, forgetting
514	their mollusks and glacial periods, gossiped about art, while devoting
514	themselves to oysters and ices with characteristic energy; the young
514	musician, who was charming the city like a second Orpheus, talked
514	horses; and the specimen of the British nobility present happened to be
514	the most ordinary man of the party.
514	""
514	Before the evening was half over, Jo felt so completely disillusioned,
514	that she sat down in a corner to recover herself. Mr. Bhaer soon joined
514	her, looking rather out of his element, and presently several of the
514	philosophers, each mounted on his hobby, came ambling up to hold an
514	intellectual tournament in the recess.  The conversations were miles
514	beyond Jo's comprehension, but she enjoyed it, though Kant and Hegel
514	were unknown gods, the Subjective and Objective unintelligible terms,
514	and the only thing 'evolved from her inner consciousness' was a bad
514	headache after it was all over.  It dawned upon her gradually that the
514	world was being picked to pieces, and put together on new and,
514	according to the talkers, on infinitely better principles than before,
514	that religion was in a fair way to be reasoned into nothingness, and
514	intellect was to be the only God.  Jo knew nothing about philosophy or
514	metaphysics of any sort, but a curious excitement, half pleasurable,
514	half painful, came over her as she listened with a sense of being
514	turned adrift into time and space, like a young balloon out on a
514	holiday.
514	""
514	She looked round to see how the Professor liked it, and found him
514	looking at her with the grimmest expression she had ever seen him wear.
514	He shook his head and beckoned her to come away, but she was fascinated
514	just then by the freedom of Speculative Philosophy, and kept her seat,
514	trying to find out what the wise gentlemen intended to rely upon after
514	they had annihilated all the old beliefs.
514	""
514	Now, Mr. Bhaer was a diffident man and slow to offer his own opinions,
514	not because they were unsettled, but too sincere and earnest to be
514	lightly spoken.  As he glanced from Jo to several other young people,
514	attracted by the brilliancy of the philosophic pyrotechnics, he knit
514	his brows and longed to speak, fearing that some inflammable young soul
514	would be led astray by the rockets, to find when the display was over
514	that they had only an empty stick or a scorched hand.
514	""
514	He bore it as long as he could, but when he was appealed to for an
514	opinion, he blazed up with honest indignation and defended religion
514	with all the eloquence of truth--an eloquence which made his broken
514	English musical and his plain face beautiful.  He had a hard fight, for
514	the wise men argued well, but he didn't know when he was beaten and
514	stood to his colors like a man.  Somehow, as he talked, the world got
514	right again to Jo.  The old beliefs, that had lasted so long, seemed
514	better than the new.  God was not a blind force, and immortality was
514	not a pretty fable, but a blessed fact.  She felt as if she had solid
514	ground under her feet again, and when Mr. Bhaer paused, outtalked but
514	not one whit convinced, Jo wanted to clap her hands and thank him.
514	""
514	She did neither, but she remembered the scene, and gave the Professor
514	her heartiest respect, for she knew it cost him an effort to speak out
514	then and there, because his conscience would not let him be silent.
514	She began to see that character is a better possession than money,
514	rank, intellect, or beauty, and to feel that if greatness is what a
514	wise man has defined it to be, 'truth, reverence, and good will', then
514	her friend Friedrich Bhaer was not only good, but great.
514	""
514	This belief strengthened daily.  She valued his esteem, she coveted his
514	respect, she wanted to be worthy of his friendship, and just when the
514	wish was sincerest, she came near to losing everything.  It all grew
514	out of a cocked hat, for one evening the Professor came in to give Jo
514	her lesson with a paper soldier cap on his head, which Tina had put
514	there and he had forgotten to take off.
514	""
514	"""It's evident he doesn't look in his glass before coming down,"" thought"
514	"Jo, with a smile, as he said ""Goot efening,"" and sat soberly down,"
514	quite unconscious of the ludicrous contrast between his subject and his
514	headgear, for he was going to read her the Death of Wallenstein.
514	""
514	She said nothing at first, for she liked to hear him laugh out his big,
514	hearty laugh when anything funny happened, so she left him to discover
514	it for himself, and presently forgot all about it, for to hear a German
514	read Schiller is rather an absorbing occupation.  After the reading
514	came the lesson, which was a lively one, for Jo was in a gay mood that
514	night, and the cocked hat kept her eyes dancing with merriment.  The
514	Professor didn't know what to make of her, and stopped at last to ask
514	with an air of mild surprise that was irresistible. . .
514	""
514	"""Mees Marsch, for what do you laugh in your master's face? Haf you no"
514	"respect for me, that you go on so bad?"""
514	""
514	"""How can I be respectful, Sir, when you forget to take your hat off?"""
514	said Jo.
514	""
514	Lifting his hand to his head, the absent-minded Professor gravely felt
514	and removed the little cocked hat, looked at it a minute, and then
514	threw back his head and laughed like a merry bass viol.
514	""
514	"""Ah!  I see him now, it is that imp Tina who makes me a fool with my"
514	cap.  Well, it is nothing, but see you, if this lesson goes not well,
514	"you too shall wear him."""
514	""
514	But the lesson did not go at all for a few minutes because Mr. Bhaer
514	caught sight of a picture on the hat, and unfolding it, said with great
514	"disgust, ""I wish these papers did not come in the house.  They are not"
514	for children to see,  nor young people to read. It is not well, and I
514	"haf no patience with those who make this harm."""
514	""
514	Jo glanced at the sheet and saw a pleasing illustration composed of a
514	lunatic, a corpse, a villain, and a viper.  She did not like it, but
514	the impulse that made her turn it over was not one of displeasure but
514	fear, because for a minute she fancied the paper was the Volcano.  It
514	was not, however, and her panic subsided as she remembered that even if
514	it had been and one of her own tales in it, there would have been no
514	name to betray her.  She had betrayed herself, however, by a look and a
514	blush, for though an absent man, the Professor saw a good deal more
514	than people fancied.  He knew that Jo wrote, and had met her down among
514	the newspaper offices more than once, but as she never spoke of it, he
514	asked no questions in spite of a strong desire to see her work.  Now it
514	occurred to him that she was doing what she was ashamed to own, and it
514	"troubled him.  He did not say to himself, ""It is none of my business."
514	"I've no right to say anything,"" as many people would have done.  He"
514	only remembered that she was young and poor, a girl far away from
514	mother's love and father's care, and he was moved to help her with an
514	impulse as quick and natural as that which would prompt him to put out
514	his hand to save a baby from a puddle.  All this flashed through his
514	mind in a minute, but not a trace of it appeared in his face, and by
514	the time the paper was turned, and Jo's needle threaded, he was ready
514	to say quite naturally, but very gravely...
514	""
514	"""Yes, you are right to put it from you.  I do not think that good young"
514	girls should see such things.  They are made pleasant to some, but I
514	would more rather give my boys gunpowder to play with than this bad
514	"trash."""
514	""
514	"""All may not be bad, only silly, you know, and if there is a demand for"
514	it, I don't see any harm in supplying it. Many very respectable people
514	"make an honest living out of what are called sensation stories,"" said"
514	Jo, scratching gathers so energetically that a row of little slits
514	followed her pin.
514	""
514	"""There is a demand for whisky, but I think you and I do not care to"
514	sell it.  If the respectable people knew what harm they did, they would
514	not feel that the living was honest.  They haf no right to put poison
514	in the sugarplum, and let the small ones eat it.  No, they should think
514	"a little, and sweep mud in the street before they do this thing."""
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer spoke warmly, and walked to the fire, crumpling the paper in
514	his hands.  Jo sat still, looking as if the fire had come to her, for
514	her cheeks burned long after the cocked hat had turned to smoke and
514	gone harmlessly up the chimney.
514	""
514	"""I should like much to send all the rest after him,"" muttered the"
514	Professor, coming back with a relieved air.
514	""
514	Jo thought what a blaze her pile of papers upstairs would make, and her
514	hard-earned money lay rather heavily on her conscience at that minute.
514	"Then she thought consolingly to herself, ""Mine are not like that, they"
514	"are only silly, never bad, so I won't be worried,"" and taking up her"
514	"book, she said, with a studious face, ""Shall we go on, Sir? I'll be"
514	"very good and proper now."""
514	""
514	"""I shall hope so,"" was all he said, but he meant more than she"
514	imagined, and the grave, kind look he gave her made her feel as if the
514	words Weekly Volcano were printed in large type on her forehead.
514	""
514	As soon as she went to her room, she got out her papers, and carefully
514	reread every one of her stories.  Being a little shortsighted, Mr.
514	Bhaer sometimes used eye glasses, and Jo had tried them once, smiling
514	to see how they magnified the fine print of her book.  Now she seemed
514	to have on the Professor's mental or moral spectacles also, for the
514	faults of these poor stories glared at her dreadfully and filled her
514	with dismay.
514	""
514	"""They are trash, and will soon be worse trash if I go on, for each is"
514	more sensational than the last.  I've gone blindly on, hurting myself
514	and other people, for the sake of money.  I know it's so, for I can't
514	read this stuff in sober earnest without being horribly ashamed of it,
514	and what should I do if they were seen at home or Mr. Bhaer got hold of
514	"them?"""
514	""
514	Jo turned hot at the bare idea, and stuffed the whole bundle into her
514	stove, nearly setting the chimney afire with the blaze.
514	""
514	"""Yes, that's the best place for such inflammable nonsense. I'd better"
514	burn the house down, I suppose, than let other people blow themselves
514	"up with my gunpowder,"" she thought as she watched the Demon of the Jura"
514	whisk away, a little black cinder with fiery eyes.
514	""
514	But when nothing remained of all her three month's work except a heap
514	of ashes and the money in her lap, Jo looked sober, as she sat on the
514	floor, wondering what she ought to do about her wages.
514	""
514	"""I think I haven't done much harm yet, and may keep this to pay for my"
514	"time,"" she said, after a long meditation, adding impatiently, ""I almost"
514	wish I hadn't any conscience, it's so inconvenient.  If I didn't care
514	about doing right, and didn't feel uncomfortable when doing wrong, I
514	should get on capitally. I can't help wishing sometimes, that Mother
514	"and Father hadn't been so particular about such things."""
514	""
514	Ah, Jo, instead of wishing that, thank God that 'Father and Mother were
514	particular', and pity from your heart those who have no such guardians
514	to hedge them round with principles which may seem like prison walls to
514	impatient youth, but which will prove sure foundations to build
514	character upon in womanhood.
514	""
514	Jo wrote no more sensational stories, deciding that the money did not
514	pay for her share of the sensation, but going to the other extreme, as
514	is the way with people of her stamp, she took a course of Mrs.
514	Sherwood, Miss Edgeworth, and Hannah More, and then produced a tale
514	which might have been more properly called an essay or a sermon, so
514	intensely moral was it.  She had her doubts about it from the
514	beginning, for her lively fancy and girlish romance felt as ill at ease
514	in the new style as she would have done masquerading in the stiff and
514	cumbrous costume of the last century.  She sent this didactic gem to
514	several markets, but it found no purchaser, and she was inclined to
514	agree with Mr. Dashwood that morals didn't sell.
514	""
514	Then she tried a child's story, which she could easily have disposed of
514	if she had not been mercenary enough to demand filthy lucre for it.
514	The only person who offered enough to make it worth her while to try
514	juvenile literature was a worthy gentleman who felt it his mission to
514	convert all the world to his particular belief.  But much as she liked
514	to write for children, Jo could not consent to depict all her naughty
514	boys as being eaten by bears or tossed by mad bulls because they did
514	not go to a particular Sabbath school, nor all the good infants who did
514	go as rewarded by every kind of bliss, from gilded gingerbread to
514	escorts of angels when they departed this life with psalms or sermons
514	on their lisping tongues.  So nothing came of these trials, and Jo
514	corked up her inkstand, and said in a fit of very wholesome humility...
514	""
514	"""I don't know anything.  I'll wait until I do before I try again, and"
514	meantime, 'sweep mud in the street' if I can't do better, that's
514	"honest, at least.""  Which decision proved that her second tumble down"
514	the beanstalk had done her some good.
514	""
514	While these internal revolutions were going on, her external life had
514	been as busy and uneventful as usual, and if she sometimes looked
514	serious or a little sad no one observed it but Professor Bhaer.  He did
514	it so quietly that Jo never knew he was watching to see if she would
514	accept and profit by his reproof, but she stood the test, and he was
514	satisfied, for though no words passed between them, he knew that she
514	had given up writing.  Not only did he guess it by the fact that the
514	second finger of her right hand was no longer inky, but she spent her
514	evenings downstairs now, was met no more among newspaper offices, and
514	studied with a dogged patience, which assured him that she was bent on
514	occupying her mind with something useful, if not pleasant.
514	""
514	He helped her in many ways, proving himself a true friend, and Jo was
514	happy, for while her pen lay idle, she was learning other lessons
514	besides German, and laying a foundation for the sensation story of her
514	own life.
514	""
514	It was a pleasant winter and a long one, for she did not leave Mrs.
514	Kirke till June.  Everyone seemed sorry when the time came.  The
514	children were inconsolable, and Mr. Bhaer's hair stuck straight up all
514	over his head, for he always rumpled it wildly when disturbed in mind.
514	""
514	"""Going home?  Ah, you are happy that you haf a home to go in,"" he said,"
514	when she told him, and sat silently pulling his beard in the corner,
514	while she held a little levee on that last evening.
514	""
514	She was going early, so she bade them all goodbye overnight, and when
514	"his turn came, she said warmly, ""Now, Sir, you won't forget to come and"
514	see us, if you ever travel our way, will you? I'll never forgive you if
514	"you do, for I want them all to know my friend."""
514	""
514	"""Do you?  Shall I come?"" he asked, looking down at her with an eager"
514	expression which she did not see.
514	""
514	"""Yes, come next month.  Laurie graduates then, and you'd enjoy"
514	"commencement as something new."""
514	""
514	"""That is your best friend, of whom you speak?"" he said in an altered"
514	tone.
514	""
514	"""Yes, my boy Teddy.  I'm very proud of him and should like you to see"
514	"him."""
514	""
514	Jo looked up then, quite unconscious of anything but her own pleasure
514	in the prospect of showing them to one another. Something in Mr.
514	Bhaer's face suddenly recalled the fact that she might find Laurie more
514	than a 'best friend', and simply because she particularly wished not to
514	look as if anything was the matter, she involuntarily began to blush,
514	and the more she tried not to, the redder she grew.  If it had not been
514	for Tina on her knee.  She didn't know what would have become of her.
514	Fortunately the child was moved to hug her, so she managed to hide her
514	face an instant, hoping the Professor did not see it. But he did, and
514	his own changed again from that momentary anxiety to its usual
514	expression, as he said cordially...
514	""
514	"""I fear I shall not make the time for that, but I wish the friend much"
514	"success, and you all happiness.  Gott bless you!""  And with that, he"
514	shook hands warmly, shouldered Tina, and went away.
514	""
514	But after the boys were abed, he sat long before his fire with the
514	tired look on his face and the 'heimweh', or homesickness, lying heavy
514	at his heart.  Once, when he remembered Jo as she sat with the little
514	child in her lap and that new softness in her face, he leaned his head
514	on his hands a minute, and then roamed about the room, as if in search
514	of something that he could not find.
514	""
514	"""It is not for me, I must not hope it now,"" he said to himself, with a"
514	sigh that was almost a groan.  Then, as if reproaching himself for the
514	longing that he could not repress, he went and kissed the two tousled
514	heads upon the pillow, took down his seldom-used meerschaum, and opened
514	his Plato.
514	""
514	He did his best and did it manfully, but I don't think he found that a
514	pair of rampant boys, a pipe, or even the divine Plato, were very
514	satisfactory substitutes for wife and child at home.
514	""
514	Early as it was, he was at the station next morning to see Jo off, and
514	thanks to him, she began her solitary journey with the pleasant memory
514	of a familiar face smiling its farewell, a bunch of violets to keep her
514	"company, and best of all, the happy thought, ""Well, the winter's gone,"
514	and I've written no books, earned no fortune, but I've made a friend
514	"worth having and I'll try to keep him all my life."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-FIVE
514	""
514	HEARTACHE
514	""
514	Whatever his motive might have been, Laurie studied to some purpose
514	that year, for he graduated with honor, and gave the Latin oration with
514	the grace of a Phillips and the eloquence of a Demosthenes, so his
514	friends said.  They were all there, his grandfather--oh, so proud--Mr.
514	and Mrs. March, John and Meg, Jo and Beth, and all exulted over him
514	with the sincere admiration which boys make light of at the time, but
514	fail to win from the world by any after-triumphs.
514	""
514	"""I've got to stay for this confounded supper, but I shall be home early"
514	"tomorrow.  You'll come and meet me as usual, girls?"" Laurie said, as he"
514	put the sisters into the carriage after the joys of the day were over.
514	He said 'girls', but he meant Jo, for she was the only one who kept up
514	the old custom. She had not the heart to refuse her splendid,
514	successful boy anything, and answered warmly...
514	""
514	"""I'll come, Teddy, rain or shine, and march before you, playing 'Hail"
514	"the conquering hero comes' on a jew's-harp."""
514	""
514	Laurie thanked her with a look that made her think in a sudden panic,
514	"""Oh, deary me!  I know he'll say something, and then what shall I do?"""
514	""
514	Evening meditation and morning work somewhat allayed her fears, and
514	having decided that she wouldn't be vain enough to think people were
514	going to propose when she had given them every reason to know what her
514	answer would be, she set forth at the appointed time, hoping Teddy
514	wouldn't do anything to make her hurt his poor feelings.  A call at
514	Meg's, and a refreshing sniff and sip at the Daisy and Demijohn, still
514	further fortified her for the tete-a-tete, but when she saw a stalwart
514	figure looming in the distance, she had a strong desire to turn about
514	and run away.
514	""
514	"""Where's the jew's-harp, Jo?"" cried Laurie, as soon as he was within"
514	speaking distance.
514	""
514	"""I forgot it."" And Jo took heart again, for that salutation could not"
514	be called lover-like.
514	""
514	She always used to take his arm on these occasions, now she did not,
514	and he made no complaint, which was a bad sign, but talked on rapidly
514	about all sorts of faraway subjects, till they turned from the road
514	into the little path that led homeward through the grove.  Then he
514	walked more slowly, suddenly lost his fine flow of language, and now
514	and then a dreadful pause occurred.  To rescue the conversation from
514	one of the wells of silence into which it kept falling, Jo said
514	"hastily, ""Now you must have a good long holiday!"""
514	""
514	"""I intend to."""
514	""
514	Something in his resolute tone made Jo look up quickly to find him
514	looking down at her with an expression that assured her the dreaded
514	"moment had come, and made her put out her hand with an imploring, ""No,"
514	"Teddy.  Please don't!"""
514	""
514	"""I will, and you must hear me.  It's no use, Jo, we've got to have it"
514	"out, and the sooner the better for both of us,"" he answered, getting"
514	flushed and excited all at once.
514	""
514	"""Say what you like then.  I'll listen,"" said Jo, with a desperate sort"
514	of patience.
514	""
514	Laurie was a young lover, but he was in earnest, and meant to 'have it
514	out', if he died in the attempt, so he plunged into the subject with
514	characteristic impetuousity, saying in a voice that would get choky now
514	and then, in spite of manful efforts to keep it steady...
514	""
514	"""I've loved you ever since I've known you, Jo, couldn't help it, you've"
514	been so good to me.  I've tried to show it, but you wouldn't let me.
514	Now I'm going to make you hear, and give me an answer, for I can't go
514	"on so any longer."""
514	""
514	"""I wanted to save you this.  I thought you'd understand..."" began Jo,"
514	finding it a great deal harder than she expected.
514	""
514	"""I know you did, but the girls are so queer you never know what they"
514	mean.  They say no when they mean yes, and drive a man out of his wits
514	"just for the fun of it,"" returned Laurie, entrenching himself behind an"
514	undeniable fact.
514	""
514	"""I don't.  I never wanted to make you care for me so, and I went away"
514	"to keep you from it if I could."""
514	""
514	"""I thought so.  It was like you, but it was no use.  I only loved you"
514	all the more, and I worked hard to please you, and I gave up billiards
514	and everything you didn't like, and waited and never complained, for I
514	"hoped you'd love me, though I'm not half good enough..."" Here there was"
514	a choke that couldn't be controlled, so he decapitated buttercups while
514	he cleared his 'confounded throat'.
514	""
514	"""You, you are, you're a great deal too good for me, and I'm so grateful"
514	to you, and so proud and fond of you, I don't know why I can't love you
514	as you want me to.  I've tried, but I can't change the feeling, and it
514	"would be a lie to say I do when I don't."""
514	""
514	"""Really, truly, Jo?"""
514	""
514	He stopped short, and caught both her hands as he put his question with
514	a look that she did not soon forget.
514	""
514	"""Really, truly, dear."""
514	""
514	They were in the grove now, close by the stile, and when the last words
514	fell reluctantly from Jo's lips, Laurie dropped her hands and turned as
514	if to go on, but for once in his life the fence was too much for him.
514	So he just laid his head down on the mossy post, and stood so still
514	that Jo was frightened.
514	""
