514	"""Oh, Teddy, I'm sorry, so desperately sorry, I could kill myself if it"
514	would do any good!  I wish you wouldn't take it so hard, I can't help
514	it.  You know it's impossible for people to make themselves love other
514	"people if they don't,"" cried Jo inelegantly but remorsefully, as she"
514	softly patted his shoulder, remembering the time when he had comforted
514	her so long ago.
514	""
514	"""They do sometimes,"" said a muffled voice from the post. ""I don't"
514	"believe it's the right sort of love, and I'd rather not try it,"" was"
514	the decided answer.
514	""
514	There was a long pause, while a blackbird sung blithely on the willow
514	by the river, and the tall grass rustled in the wind. Presently Jo said
514	"very soberly, as she sat down on the step of the stile, ""Laurie, I want"
514	"to tell you something."""
514	""
514	He started as if he had been shot, threw up his head, and cried out in
514	"a fierce tone, ""Don't tell me that, Jo, I can't bear it now!"""
514	""
514	"""Tell what?"" she asked, wondering at his violence."
514	""
514	"""That you love that old man."""
514	""
514	"""What old man?"" demanded Jo, thinking he must mean his grandfather."
514	""
514	"""That devilish Professor you were always writing about. If you say you"
514	"love him, I know I shall do something desperate;"" and he looked as if"
514	he would keep his word, as he clenched his hands with a wrathful spark
514	in his eyes.
514	""
514	Jo wanted to laugh, but restrained herself and said warmly, for she
514	"too, was getting excited with all this, ""Don't swear, Teddy!  He isn't"
514	old, nor anything bad, but good and kind, and the best friend I've got,
514	next to you.  Pray, don't fly into a passion.  I want to be kind, but I
514	know I shall get angry if you abuse my Professor.  I haven't the least
514	"idea of loving him or anybody else."""
514	""
514	"""But you will after a while, and then what will become of me?"""
514	""
514	"""You'll love someone else too, like a sensible boy, and forget all this"
514	"trouble."""
514	""
514	"""I can't love anyone else, and I'll never forget you, Jo, Never!"
514	"Never!"" with a stamp to emphasize his passionate words."
514	""
514	"""What shall I do with him?"" sighed Jo, finding that emotions were more"
514	"unmanagable than she expected.  ""You haven't heard what I wanted to"
514	tell you.  Sit down and listen, for indeed I want to do right and make
514	"you happy,"" she said, hoping to soothe him with a little reason, which"
514	proved that she knew nothing about love.
514	""
514	Seeing a ray of hope in that last speech, Laurie threw himself down on
514	the grass at her feet, leaned his arm on the lower step of the stile,
514	and looked up at her with an expectant face. Now that arrangement was
514	not conducive to calm speech or clear thought on Jo's part, for how
514	could she say hard things to her boy while he watched her with eyes
514	full of love and longing, and lashes still wet with the bitter drop or
514	two her hardness of heart had wrung from him?  She gently turned his
514	head away, saying, as she stroked the wavy hair which had been allowed
514	"to grow for her sake--how touching that was, to be sure! ""I agree with"
514	Mother that you and I are not suited to each other, because our quick
514	tempers and strong wills would probably make us very miserable, if we
514	"were so foolish as to..."" Jo paused a little over the last word, but"
514	Laurie uttered it with a rapturous expression.
514	""
514	"""Marry--no we shouldn't!  If you loved me, Jo, I should be a perfect"
514	"saint, for you could make me anything you like."""
514	""
514	"""No, I can't.  I've tried and failed, and I won't risk our happiness by"
514	such a serious experiment.  We don't agree and we never shall, so we'll
514	"be good friends all our lives, but we won't go and do anything rash."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, we will if we get the chance,"" muttered Laurie rebelliously."
514	""
514	"""Now do be reasonable, and take a sensible view of the case,"" implored"
514	Jo, almost at her wit's end.
514	""
514	"""I won't be reasonable.  I don't want to take what you call 'a sensible"
514	view'.  It won't help me, and it only makes it harder.  I don't believe
514	"you've got any heart."""
514	""
514	"""I wish I hadn't."""
514	""
514	There was a little quiver in Jo's voice, and thinking it a good omen,
514	Laurie turned round, bringing all his persuasive powers to bear as he
514	said, in the wheedlesome tone that had never been so dangerously
514	"wheedlesome before, ""Don't disappoint us, dear!  Everyone expects it."
514	Grandpa has set his heart upon it, your people like it, and I can't get
514	"on without you.  Say you will, and let's be happy.  Do, do!"""
514	""
514	Not until months afterward did Jo understand how she had the strength
514	of mind to hold fast to the resolution she had made when she decided
514	that she did not love her boy, and never could.  It was very hard to
514	do, but she did it, knowing that delay was both useless and cruel.
514	""
514	"""I can't say 'yes' truly, so I won't say it at all.  You'll see that"
514	"I'm right, by-and-by, and thank me for it..."" she began solemnly."
514	""
514	"""I'll be hanged if I do!"" and Laurie bounced up off the grass, burning"
514	with indignation at the very idea.
514	""
514	"""Yes, you will!"" persisted Jo.  ""You'll get over this after a while,"
514	and find some lovely accomplished girl, who will adore you, and make a
514	fine mistress for your fine house.  I shouldn't. I'm homely and awkward
514	and odd and old, and you'd be ashamed of me, and we should quarrel--we
514	can't help it even now, you see--and I shouldn't like elegant society
514	and you would, and you'd hate my scribbling, and I couldn't get on
514	without it, and we should be unhappy, and wish we hadn't done it, and
514	"everything would be horrid!"""
514	""
514	"""Anything more?"" asked Laurie, finding it hard to listen patiently to"
514	this prophetic burst.
514	""
514	"""Nothing more, except that I don't believe I shall ever marry.  I'm"
514	happy as I am, and love my liberty too well to be in a hurry to give it
514	"up for any mortal man."""
514	""
514	"""I know better!"" broke in Laurie.  ""You think so now, but there'll come"
514	a time when you will care for somebody, and you'll love him
514	tremendously, and live and die for him.  I know you will, it's your
514	"way, and I shall have to stand by and see it,"" and the despairing lover"
514	cast his hat upon the ground with a gesture that would have seemed
514	comical, if his face had not been so tragic.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I will live and die for him, if he ever comes and makes me love"
514	"him in spite of myself, and you must do the best you can!"" cried Jo,"
514	"losing patience with poor Teddy.  ""I've done my best, but you won't be"
514	reasonable, and it's selfish of you to keep teasing for what I can't
514	give.  I shall always be fond of you, very fond indeed, as a friend,
514	but I'll never marry you, and the sooner you believe it the better for
514	"both of us--so now!"""
514	""
514	That speech was like gunpowder.  Laurie looked at her a minute as if he
514	did not quite know what to do with himself, then turned sharply away,
514	"saying in a desperate sort of tone, ""You'll be sorry some day, Jo."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, where are you going?"" she cried, for his face frightened her."
514	""
514	"""To the devil!"" was the consoling answer."
514	""
514	For a minute Jo's heart stood still, as he swung himself down the bank
514	toward the river, but it takes much folly, sin or misery to send a
514	young man to a violent death, and Laurie was not one of the weak sort
514	who are conquered by a single failure.  He had no thought of a
514	melodramatic plunge, but some blind instinct led him to fling hat and
514	coat into his boat, and row away with all his might, making better time
514	up the river than he had done in any race.  Jo drew a long breath and
514	unclasped her hands as she watched the poor fellow trying to outstrip
514	the trouble which he carried in his heart.
514	""
514	"""That will do him good, and he'll come home in such a tender, penitent"
514	"state of mind, that I shan't dare to see him,"" she said, adding, as she"
514	went slowly home, feeling as if she had murdered some innocent thing,
514	"and buried it under the leaves.  ""Now I must go and prepare Mr."
514	Laurence to be very kind to my poor boy.  I wish he'd love Beth,
514	perhaps he may in time, but I begin to think I was mistaken about her.
514	Oh dear!  How can girls like to have lovers and refuse them?  I think
514	"it's dreadful."""
514	""
514	Being sure that no one could do it so well as herself, she went
514	straight to Mr. Laurence, told the hard story bravely through, and then
514	broke down, crying so dismally over her own insensibility that the kind
514	old gentleman, though sorely disappointed, did not utter a reproach.
514	He found it difficult to understand how any girl could help loving
514	Laurie, and hoped she would change her mind, but he knew even better
514	than Jo that love cannot be forced, so he shook his head sadly and
514	resolved to carry his boy out of harm's way, for Young Impetuosity's
514	parting words to Jo disturbed him more than he would confess.
514	""
514	When Laurie came home, dead tired but quite composed, his grandfather
514	met him as if he knew nothing, and kept up the delusion very
514	successfully for an hour or two.  But when they sat together in the
514	twilight, the time they used to enjoy so much, it was hard work for the
514	old man to ramble on as usual, and harder still for the young one to
514	listen to praises of the last year's success, which to him now seemed
514	like love's labor lost.  He bore it as long as he could, then went to
514	his piano and began to play.  The windows were open, and Jo, walking
514	in the garden with Beth, for once understood music better than her
514	sister, for he played the '_Sonata Pathetique_', and played it as he
514	never did before.
514	""
514	"""That's very fine, I dare say, but it's sad enough to make one cry."
514	"Give us something gayer, lad,"" said Mr. Laurence, whose kind old heart"
514	was full of sympathy, which he longed to show but knew not how.
514	""
514	Laurie dashed into a livelier strain, played stormily for several
514	minutes, and would have got through bravely, if in a momentary lull
514	"Mrs. March's voice had not been heard calling, ""Jo, dear, come in.  I"
514	"want you."""
514	""
514	Just what Laurie longed to say, with a different meaning! As he
514	listened, he lost his place, the music ended with a broken chord, and
514	the musician sat silent in the dark.
514	""
514	"""I can't stand this,"" muttered the old gentleman.  Up he got, groped"
514	his way to the piano, laid a kind hand on either of the broad
514	"shoulders, and said, as gently as a woman, ""I know, my boy, I know."""
514	""
514	"No answer for an instant, then Laurie asked sharply, ""Who told you?"""
514	""
514	"""Jo herself."""
514	""
514	"""Then there's an end of it!""  And he shook off his grandfather's hands"
514	with an impatient motion, for though grateful for the sympathy, his
514	man's pride could not bear a man's pity.
514	""
514	"""Not quite.  I want to say one thing, and then there shall be an end of"
514	"it,"" returned Mr. Laurence with unusual mildness. ""You won't care to"
514	"stay at home now, perhaps?"""
514	""
514	"""I don't intend to run away from a girl.  Jo can't prevent my seeing"
514	"her, and I shall stay and do it as long as I like,"" interrupted Laurie"
514	in a defiant tone.
514	""
514	"""Not if you are the gentleman I think you.  I'm disappointed, but the"
514	girl can't help it, and the only thing left for you to do is to go away
514	"for a time.  Where will you go?"""
514	""
514	"""Anywhere.  I don't care what becomes of me,"" and Laurie got up with a"
514	reckless laugh that grated on his grandfather's ear.
514	""
514	"""Take it like a man, and don't do anything rash, for God's sake.  Why"
514	"not go abroad, as you planned, and forget it?"""
514	""
514	"""I can't."""
514	""
514	"""But you've been wild to go, and I promised you should when you got"
514	"through college."""
514	""
514	"""Ah, but I didn't mean to go alone!"" and Laurie walked fast through the"
514	room with an expression which it was well his grandfather did not see.
514	""
514	"""I don't ask you to go alone.  There's someone ready and glad to go"
514	"with you, anywhere in the world."""
514	""
514	"""Who, Sir?"" stopping to listen."
514	""
514	"""Myself."""
514	""
514	Laurie came back as quickly as he went, and put out his hand, saying
514	"huskily, ""I'm a selfish brute, but--you know--Grandfather--"""
514	""
514	"""Lord help me, yes, I do know, for I've been through it all before,"
514	once in my own young days, and then with your father. Now, my dear boy,
514	just sit quietly down and hear my plan.  It's all settled, and can be
514	"carried out at once,"" said Mr. Laurence, keeping hold of the young man,"
514	as if fearful that he would break away as his father had done before
514	him.
514	""
514	"""Well, sir, what is it?"" and Laurie sat down, without a sign of"
514	interest in face or voice.
514	""
514	"""There is business in London that needs looking after.  I meant you"
514	should attend to it, but I can do it better myself, and things here
514	will get on very well with Brooke to manage them.  My partners do
514	almost everything, I'm merely holding on until you take my place, and
514	"can be off at any time."""
514	""
514	"""But you hate traveling, Sir.  I can't ask it of you at your age,"""
514	began Laurie, who was grateful for the sacrifice, but much preferred to
514	go alone, if he went at all.
514	""
514	The old gentleman knew that perfectly well, and particularly desired to
514	prevent it, for the mood in which he found his grandson assured him
514	that it would not be wise to leave him to his own devices.  So,
514	stifling a natural regret at the thought of the home comforts he would
514	"leave behind him, he said stoutly, ""Bless your soul, I'm not"
514	superannuated yet.  I quite enjoy the idea.  It will do me good, and my
514	old bones won't suffer, for traveling nowadays is almost as easy as
514	"sitting in a chair."""
514	""
514	A restless movement from Laurie suggested that his chair was not easy,
514	"or that he did not like the plan, and made the old man add hastily, ""I"
514	don't mean to be a marplot or a burden. I go because I think you'd feel
514	happier than if I was left behind.  I don't intend to gad about with
514	you, but leave you free to go where you like, while I amuse myself in
514	my own way.  I've friends in London and Paris, and should like to visit
514	them.  Meantime you can go to Italy, Germany, Switzerland, where you
514	will, and enjoy pictures, music, scenery, and adventures to your
514	"heart's content."""
514	""
514	Now, Laurie felt just then that his heart was entirely broken and the
514	world a howling wilderness, but at the sound of certain words which the
514	old gentleman artfully introduced into his closing sentence, the broken
514	heart gave an unexpected leap, and a green oasis or two suddenly
514	appeared in the howling wilderness.  He sighed, and then said, in a
514	"spiritless tone, ""Just as you like, Sir.  It doesn't matter where I go"
514	"or what I do."""
514	""
514	"""It does to me, remember that, my lad.  I give you entire liberty, but"
514	"I trust you to make an honest use of it.  Promise me that, Laurie."""
514	""
514	"""Anything you like, Sir."""
514	""
514	"""Good,"" thought the old gentleman.  ""You don't care now, but there'll"
514	come a time when that promise will keep you out of mischief, or I'm
514	"much mistaken."""
514	""
514	Being an energetic individual, Mr. Laurence struck while the iron was
514	hot, and before the blighted being recovered spirit enough to rebel,
514	they were off.  During the time necessary for preparation, Laurie bore
514	himself as young gentleman usually do in such cases.  He was moody,
514	irritable, and pensive by turns, lost his appetite, neglected his dress
514	and devoted much time to playing tempestuously on his piano, avoided
514	Jo, but consoled himself by staring at her from his window, with a
514	tragic face that haunted her dreams by night and oppressed her with a
514	heavy sense of guilt by day.  Unlike some sufferers, he never spoke of
514	his unrequited passion, and would allow no one, not even Mrs. March, to
514	attempt consolation or offer sympathy.  On some accounts, this was a
514	relief to his friends, but the weeks before his departure were very
514	uncomfortable, and everyone rejoiced that the 'poor, dear fellow was
514	going away to forget his trouble, and come home happy'.  Of course, he
514	smiled darkly at their delusion, but passed it by with the sad
514	superiority of one who knew that his fidelity like his love was
514	unalterable.
514	""
514	When the parting came he affected high spirits, to conceal certain
514	inconvenient emotions which seemed inclined to assert themselves.  This
514	gaiety did not impose upon anybody, but they tried to look as if it did
514	for his sake, and he got on very well till Mrs. March kissed him, with
514	a whisper full of motherly solicitude.  Then feeling that he was going
514	very fast, he hastily embraced them all round, not forgetting the
514	afflicted Hannah, and ran downstairs as if for his life.  Jo followed a
514	minute after to wave her hand to him if he looked round.  He did look
514	round, came back, put his arms about her as she stood on the step above
514	him, and looked up at her with a face that made his short appeal
514	eloquent and pathetic.
514	""
514	"""Oh, Jo, can't you?"""
514	""
514	"""Teddy, dear, I wish I could!"""
514	""
514	That was all, except a little pause.  Then Laurie straightened himself
514	"up, said, ""It's all right, never mind,"" and went away without another"
514	word.  Ah, but it wasn't all right, and Jo did mind, for while the
514	curly head lay on her arm a minute after her hard answer, she felt as
514	if she had stabbed her dearest friend, and when he left her without a
514	look behind him, she knew that the boy Laurie never would come again.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-SIX
514	""
514	BETH'S SECRET
514	""
514	When Jo came home that spring, she had been struck with the change in
514	Beth.  No one spoke of it or seemed aware of it, for it had come too
514	gradually to startle those who saw her daily, but to eyes sharpened by
514	absence, it was very plain and a heavy weight fell on Jo's heart as she
514	saw her sister's face. It was no paler and but littler thinner than in
514	the autumn, yet there was a strange, transparent look about it, as if
514	the mortal was being slowly refined away, and the immortal shining
514	through the frail flesh with an indescribably pathetic beauty.  Jo saw
514	and felt it, but said nothing at the time, and soon the first
514	impression lost much of its power, for Beth seemed happy, no one
514	appeared to doubt that she was better, and presently in other cares Jo
514	for a time forgot her fear.
514	""
514	But when Laurie was gone, and peace prevailed again, the vague anxiety
514	returned and haunted her.  She had confessed her sins and been
514	forgiven, but when she showed her savings and proposed a mountain trip,
514	Beth had thanked her heartily, but begged not to go so far away from
514	home.  Another little visit to the seashore would suit her better, and
514	as Grandma could not be prevailed upon to leave the babies, Jo took
514	Beth down to the quiet place, where she could live much in the open
514	air, and let the fresh sea breezes blow a little color into her pale
514	cheeks.
514	""
514	It was not a fashionable place, but even among the pleasant people
514	there, the girls made few friends, preferring to live for one another.
514	Beth was too shy to enjoy society, and Jo too wrapped up in her to care
514	for anyone else.  So they were all in all to each other, and came and
514	went, quite unconscious of the interest they excited in those about
514	them, who watched with sympathetic eyes the strong sister and the
514	feeble one, always together, as if they felt instinctively that a long
514	separation was not far away.
514	""
514	They did feel it, yet neither spoke of it, for often between ourselves
514	and those nearest and dearest to us there exists a reserve which it is
514	very hard to overcome.  Jo felt as if a veil had fallen between her
514	heart and Beth's, but when she put out her hand to lift it up, there
514	seemed something sacred in the silence, and she waited for Beth to
514	speak.  She wondered, and was thankful also, that her parents did not
514	seem to see what she saw, and during the quiet weeks when the shadows
514	grew so plain to her, she said nothing of it to those at home,
514	believing that it would tell itself when Beth came back no better. She
514	wondered still more if her sister really guessed the hard truth, and
514	what thoughts were passing through her mind during the long hours when
514	she lay on the warm rocks with her head in Jo's lap, while the winds
514	blew healthfully over her and the sea made music at her feet.
514	""
514	One day Beth told her.  Jo thought she was asleep, she lay so still,
514	and putting down her book, sat looking at her with wistful eyes, trying
514	to see signs of hope in the faint color on Beth's cheeks.  But she
514	could not find enough to satisfy her, for the cheeks were very thin,
514	and the hands seemed too feeble to hold even the rosy little shells
514	they had been collecting. It came to her then more bitterly than ever
514	that Beth was slowly drifting away from her, and her arms instinctively
514	tightened their hold upon the dearest treasure she possessed. For a
514	minute her eyes were too dim for seeing, and when they cleared, Beth
514	was looking up at her so tenderly that there was hardly any need for
514	"her to say, ""Jo, dear, I'm glad you know it.  I've tried to tell you,"
514	"but I couldn't."""
514	""
514	There was no answer except her sister's cheek against her own, not even
514	tears, for when most deeply moved, Jo did not cry.  She was the weaker
514	then, and Beth tried to comfort and sustain her, with her arms about
514	her and the soothing words she whispered in her ear.
514	""
514	"""I've known it for a good while, dear, and now I'm used to it, it isn't"
514	hard to think of or to bear.  Try to see it so and don't be troubled
514	"about me, because it's best, indeed it is."""
514	""
514	"""Is this what made you so unhappy in the autumn, Beth? You did not feel"
514	"it then, and keep it to yourself so long, did you?"" asked Jo, refusing"
514	to see or say that it was best, but glad to know that Laurie had no
514	part in Beth's trouble.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I gave up hoping then, but I didn't like to own it. I tried to"
514	think it was a sick fancy, and would not let it trouble anyone.  But
514	when I saw you all so well and strong and full of happy plans, it was
514	hard to feel that I could never be like you, and then I was miserable,
514	"Jo."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, Beth, and you didn't tell me, didn't let me comfort and help you?"
514	"How could you shut me out, bear it all alone?"""
514	""
514	Jo's voice was full of tender reproach, and her heart ached to think of
514	the solitary struggle that must have gone on while Beth learned to say
514	goodbye to health, love, and life, and take up her cross so cheerfully.
514	""
514	"""Perhaps it was wrong, but I tried to do right.  I wasn't sure, no one"
514	said anything, and I hoped I was mistaken.  It would have been selfish
514	to frighten you all when Marmee was so anxious about Meg, and Amy away,
514	"and you so happy with Laurie--at least I thought so then."""
514	""
514	"""And I thought you loved him, Beth, and I went away because I"
514	"couldn't,"" cried Jo, glad to say all the truth."
514	""
514	Beth looked so amazed at the idea that Jo smiled in spite of her pain,
514	"and added softly, ""Then you didn't, dearie? I was afraid it was so, and"
514	"imagined your poor little heart full of lovelornity all that while."""
514	""
514	"""Why, Jo, how could I, when he was so fond of you?"" asked Beth, as"
514	"innocently as a child.  ""I do love him dearly.  He is so good to me,"
514	how can I help It?  But he could never be anything to me but my
514	"brother.  I hope he truly will be, sometime."""
514	""
514	"""Not through me,"" said Jo decidedly.  ""Amy is left for him, and they"
514	would suit excellently, but I have no heart for such things, now.  I
514	"don't care what becomes of anybody but you, Beth. You must get well."""
514	""
514	"""I want to, oh, so much!  I try, but every day I lose a little, and"
514	feel more sure that I shall never gain it back.  It's like the tide,
514	"Jo, when it turns, it goes slowly, but it can't be stopped."""
514	""
514	"""It shall be stopped, your tide must not turn so soon, nineteen is too"
514	young, Beth.  I can't let you go.  I'll work and pray and fight against
514	it.  I'll keep you in spite of everything.  There must be ways, it
514	"can't be too late.  God won't be so cruel as to take you from me,"""
514	cried poor Jo rebelliously, for her spirit was far less piously
514	submissive than Beth's.
514	""
514	Simple, sincere people seldom speak much of their piety.  It shows
514	itself in acts rather than in words, and has more influence than
514	homilies or protestations.  Beth could not reason upon or explain the
514	faith that gave her courage and patience to give up life, and
514	cheerfully wait for death.  Like a confiding child, she asked no
514	questions, but left everything to God and nature, Father and Mother of
514	us all, feeling sure that they, and they only, could teach and
514	strengthen heart and spirit for this life and the life to come.  She
514	did not rebuke Jo with saintly speeches, only loved her better for her
514	passionate affection, and clung more closely to the dear human love,
514	from which our Father never means us to be weaned, but through which He
514	"draws us closer to Himself.  She could not say, ""I'm glad to go,"" for"
514	"life was very sweet for her.  She could only sob out, ""I try to be"
514	"willing,"" while she held fast to Jo, as the first bitter wave of this"
514	great sorrow broke over them together.
514	""
514	"By and by Beth said, with recovered serenity, ""You'll tell them this"
514	"when we go home?"""
514	""
514	"""I think they will see it without words,"" sighed Jo, for now it seemed"
514	to her that Beth changed every day.
514	""
514	"""Perhaps not.  I've heard that the people who love best are often"
514	blindest to such things.  If they don't see it, you will tell them for
514	me.  I don't want any secrets, and it's kinder to prepare them.  Meg
514	has John and the babies to comfort her, but you must stand by Father
514	"and Mother, won't you Jo?"""
514	""
514	"""If I can.  But, Beth, I don't give up yet.  I'm going to believe that"
514	"it is a sick fancy, and not let you think it's true."" said Jo, trying"
514	to speak cheerfully.
514	""
514	"Beth lay a minute thinking, and then said in her quiet way, ""I don't"
514	know how to express myself, and shouldn't try to anyone but you,
514	because I can't speak out except to my Jo.  I only mean to say that I
514	have a feeling that it never was intended I should live long.  I'm not
514	like the rest of you.  I never made any plans about what I'd do when I
514	grew up.  I never thought of being married, as you all did.  I couldn't
514	seem to imagine myself anything but stupid little Beth, trotting about
514	at home, of no use anywhere but there.  I never wanted to go away, and
514	the hard part now is the leaving you all.  I'm not afraid, but it seems
514	"as if I should be homesick for you even in heaven."""
514	""
514	Jo could not speak, and for several minutes there was no sound but the
514	sigh of the wind and the lapping of the tide.  A white-winged gull flew
514	by, with the flash of sunshine on its silvery breast.  Beth watched it
514	till it vanished, and her eyes were full of sadness.  A little
514	gray-coated sand bird came tripping over the beach 'peeping' softly to
514	itself, as if enjoying the sun and sea.  It came quite close to Beth,
514	and looked at her with a friendly eye and sat upon a warm stone,
514	dressing its wet feathers, quite at home.  Beth smiled and felt
514	comforted, for the tiny thing seemed to offer its small friendship and
514	remind her that a pleasant world was still to be enjoyed.
514	""
514	"""Dear little bird!  See, Jo, how tame it is.  I like peeps better than"
514	the gulls.  They are not so wild and handsome, but they seem happy,
514	confiding little things.  I used to call them my birds last summer, and
514	Mother said they reminded her of me--busy, quaker-colored creatures,
514	always near the shore, and always chirping that contented little song
514	of theirs.  You are the gull, Jo, strong and wild, fond of the storm
514	and the wind, flying far out to sea, and happy all alone.  Meg is the
514	turtledove, and Amy is like the lark she writes about, trying to get up
514	among the clouds, but always dropping down into its nest again.  Dear
514	little girl!  She's so ambitious, but her heart is good and tender, and
514	no matter how high she flies, she never will forget home.  I hope I
514	"shall see her again, but she seems so far away."""
514	""
514	"""She is coming in the spring, and I mean that you shall be all ready to"
514	"see and enjoy her.  I'm going to have you well and rosy by that time,"""
514	began Jo, feeling that of all the changes in Beth, the talking change
514	was the greatest, for it seemed to cost no effort now, and she thought
514	aloud in a way quite unlike bashful Beth.
514	""
514	"""Jo, dear, don't hope any more.  It won't do any good.  I'm sure of"
514	that.  We won't be miserable, but enjoy being together while we wait.
514	We'll have happy times, for I don't suffer much, and I think the tide
514	"will go out easily, if you help me."""
514	""
514	Jo leaned down to kiss the tranquil face, and with that silent kiss,
514	she dedicated herself soul and body to Beth.
514	""
514	She was right.  There was no need of any words when they got home, for
514	Father and Mother saw plainly now what they had prayed to be saved from
514	seeing.  Tired with her short journey, Beth went at once to bed, saying
514	how glad she was to be home, and when Jo went down, she found that she
514	would be spared the hard task of telling Beth's secret.  Her father
514	stood leaning his head on the mantelpiece and did not turn as she came
514	in, but her mother stretched out her arms as if for help, and Jo went
514	to comfort her without a word.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-SEVEN
514	""
514	NEW IMPRESSIONS
514	""
514	At three o'clock in the afternoon, all the fashionable world at Nice
514	may be seen on the Promenade des Anglais--a charming place, for the
514	wide walk, bordered with palms, flowers, and tropical shrubs, is
514	bounded on one side by the sea, on the other by the grand drive, lined
514	with hotels and villas, while beyond lie orange orchards and the hills.
514	Many nations are represented, many languages spoken, many costumes
514	worn, and on a sunny day the spectacle is as gay and brilliant as a
514	carnival.  Haughty English, lively French, sober Germans, handsome
514	Spaniards, ugly Russians, meek Jews, free-and-easy Americans, all
514	drive, sit, or saunter here, chatting over the news, and criticizing
514	the latest celebrity who has arrived--Ristori or Dickens, Victor
514	Emmanuel or the Queen of the Sandwich Islands.  The equipages are as
514	varied as the company and attract as much attention, especially the low
514	basket barouches in which ladies drive themselves, with a pair of
514	dashing ponies, gay nets to keep their voluminous flounces from
514	overflowing the diminutive vehicles, and little grooms on the perch
514	behind.
514	""
514	Along this walk, on Christmas Day, a tall young man walked slowly, with
514	his hands behind him, and a somewhat absent expression of countenance.
514	He looked like an Italian, was dressed like an Englishman, and had the
514	independent air of an American--a combination which caused sundry pairs
514	of feminine eyes to look approvingly after him, and sundry dandies in
514	black velvet suits, with rose-colored neckties, buff gloves, and orange
514	flowers in their buttonholes, to shrug their shoulders, and then envy
514	him his inches. There were plenty of pretty faces to admire, but the
514	young man took little notice of them, except to glance now and then at
514	some blonde girl in blue.  Presently he strolled out of the promenade
514	and stood a moment at the crossing, as if undecided whether to go and
514	listen to the band in the Jardin Publique, or to wander along the beach
514	toward Castle Hill.  The quick trot of ponies' feet made him look up,
514	as one of the little carriages, containing a single young lady, came
514	rapidly down the street.  The lady was young, blonde, and dressed in
514	blue.  He stared a minute, then his whole face woke up, and, waving his
514	hat like a boy, he hurried forward to meet her.
514	""
514	"""Oh, Laurie, is it really you?  I thought you'd never come!"" cried Amy,"
514	dropping the reins and holding out both hands, to the great
514	scandalization of a French mamma, who hastened her daughter's steps,
514	lest she should be demoralized by beholding the free manners of these
514	'mad English'.
514	""
514	"""I was detained by the way, but I promised to spend Christmas with you,"
514	"and here I am."""
514	""
514	"""How is your grandfather?  When did you come?  Where are you staying?"""
514	""
514	"""Very well--last night--at the Chauvain.  I called at your hotel, but"
514	"you were out."""
514	""
514	"""I have so much to say, I don't know where to begin!  Get in and we can"
514	talk at our ease.  I was going for a drive and longing for company.
514	"Flo's saving up for tonight."""
514	""
514	"""What happens then, a ball?"""
514	""
514	"""A Christmas party at our hotel.  There are many Americans there, and"
514	they give it in honor of the day.  You'll go with us, of course?  Aunt
514	"will be charmed."""
514	""
514	"""Thank you.  Where now?"" asked Laurie, leaning back and folding his"
514	arms, a proceeding which suited Amy, who preferred to drive, for her
514	parasol whip and blue reins over the white ponies' backs afforded her
514	infinite satisfaction.
514	""
514	"""I'm going to the bankers first for letters, and then to Castle Hill."
514	The view is so lovely, and I like to feed the peacocks. Have you ever
514	"been there?"""
514	""
514	"""Often, years ago, but I don't mind having a look at it."""
514	""
514	"""Now tell me all about yourself.  The last I heard of you, your"
514	"grandfather wrote that he expected you from Berlin."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I spent a month there and then joined him in Paris, where he has"
514	settled for the winter.  He has friends there and finds plenty to amuse
514	"him, so I go and come, and we get on capitally."""
514	""
514	"""That's a sociable arrangement,"" said Amy, missing something in"
514	Laurie's manner, though she couldn't tell what.
514	""
514	"""Why, you see, he hates to travel, and I hate to keep still, so we each"
514	suit ourselves, and there is no trouble.  I am often with him, and he
514	enjoys my adventures, while I like to feel that someone is glad to see
514	"me when I get back from my wanderings.  Dirty old hole, isn't it?"" he"
514	added, with a look of disgust as they drove along the boulevard to the
514	Place Napoleon in the old city.
514	""
514	"""The dirt is picturesque, so I don't mind.  The river and the hills are"
514	delicious, and these glimpses of the narrow cross streets are my
514	delight.  Now we shall have to wait for that procession to pass.  It's
514	"going to the Church of St.  John."""
514	""
514	While Laurie listlessly watched the procession of priests under their
514	canopies, white-veiled nuns bearing lighted tapers, and some
514	brotherhood in blue chanting as they walked, Amy watched him, and felt
514	a new sort of shyness steal over her, for he was changed, and she could
514	not find the merry-faced boy she left in the moody-looking man beside
514	her.  He was handsomer than ever and greatly improved, she thought, but
514	now that the flush of pleasure at meeting her was over, he looked tired
514	and spiritless--not sick, nor exactly unhappy, but older and graver
514	than a year or two of prosperous life should have made him.  She
514	couldn't understand it and did not venture to ask questions, so she
514	shook her head and touched up her ponies, as the procession wound away
514	across the arches of the Paglioni bridge and vanished in the church.
514	""
514	"""Que pensez-vous?"" she said, airing her French, which had improved in"
514	quantity, if not in quality, since she came abroad.
514	""
514	"""That mademoiselle has made good use of her time, and the result is"
514	"charming,"" replied Laurie, bowing with his hand on his heart and an"
514	admiring look.
514	""
514	She blushed with pleasure, but somehow the compliment did not satisfy
514	her like the blunt praises he used to give her at home, when he
514	promenaded round her on festival occasions, and told her she was
514	'altogether jolly', with a hearty smile and an approving pat on the
514	head.  She didn't like the new tone, for though not blase, it sounded
514	indifferent in spite of the look.
514	""
514	"""If that's the way he's going to grow up, I wish he'd stay a boy,"" she"
514	thought, with a curious sense of disappointment and discomfort, trying
514	meantime to seem quite easy and gay.
514	""
514	At Avigdor's she found the precious home letters and, giving the reins
514	to Laurie, read them luxuriously as they wound up the shady road
514	between green hedges, where tea roses bloomed as freshly as in June.
514	""
514	"""Beth is very poorly, Mother says.  I often think I ought to go home,"
514	but they all say 'stay'.  So I do, for I shall never have another
514	"chance like this,"" said Amy, looking sober over one page."
514	""
514	"""I think you are right, there.  You could do nothing at home, and it is"
514	a great comfort to them to know that you are well and happy, and
514	"enjoying so much, my dear."""
514	""
514	He drew a little nearer, and looked more like his old self as he said
514	that, and the fear that sometimes weighed on Amy's heart was lightened,
514	for the look, the act, the brotherly 'my dear', seemed to assure her
514	that if any trouble did come, she would not be alone in a strange land.
514	Presently she laughed and showed him a small sketch of Jo in her
514	scribbling suit, with the bow rampantly erect upon her cap, and issuing
514	from her mouth the words, 'Genius burns!'.
514	""
514	Laurie smiled, took it, put it in his vest pocket 'to keep it from
514	blowing away', and listened with interest to the lively letter Amy read
514	him.
514	""
514	"""This will be a regularly merry Christmas to me, with presents in the"
514	"morning, you and letters in the afternoon, and a party at night,"" said"
514	Amy, as they alighted among the ruins of the old fort, and a flock of
514	splendid peacocks came trooping about them, tamely waiting to be fed.
514	While Amy stood laughing on the bank above him as she scattered crumbs
514	to the brilliant birds, Laurie looked at her as she had looked at him,
514	with a natural curiosity to see what changes time and absence had
514	wrought.  He found nothing to perplex or disappoint, much to admire and
514	approve, for overlooking a few little affectations of speech and
514	manner, she was as sprightly and graceful as ever, with the addition of
514	that indescribable something in dress and bearing which we call
514	elegance.  Always mature for her age, she had gained a certain aplomb
514	in both carriage and conversation, which made her seem more of a woman
514	of the world than she was, but her old petulance now and then showed
514	itself, her strong will still held its own, and her native frankness
514	was unspoiled by foreign polish.
514	""
514	Laurie did not read all this while he watched her feed the peacocks,
514	but he saw enough to satisfy and interest him, and carried away a
514	pretty little picture of a bright-faced girl standing in the sunshine,
514	which brought out the soft hue of her dress, the fresh collar of her
514	cheeks, the golden gloss of her hair, and made her a prominent figure
514	in the pleasant scene.
514	""
514	As they came up onto the stone plateau that crowns the hill, Amy waved
514	her hand as if welcoming him to her favorite haunt, and said, pointing
514	"here and there, ""Do you remember the Cathedral and the Corso, the"
514	fishermen dragging their nets in the bay, and the lovely road to Villa
514	Franca, Schubert's Tower, just below, and best of all, that speck far
514	"out to sea which they say is Corsica?"""
514	""
514	"""I remember.  It's not much changed,"" he answered without enthusiasm."
514	""
514	"""What Jo would give for a sight of that famous speck!"" said Amy,"
514	feeling in good spirits and anxious to see him so also.
514	""
514	"""Yes,"" was all he said, but he turned and strained his eyes to see the"
514	island which a greater usurper than even Napoleon now made interesting
514	in his sight.
514	""
514	"""Take a good look at it for her sake, and then come and tell me what"
514	"you have been doing with yourself all this while,"" said Amy, seating"
514	herself, ready for a good talk.
514	""
514	But she did not get it, for though he joined her and answered all her
514	questions freely, she could only learn that he had roved about the
514	Continent and been to Greece.  So after idling away an hour, they drove
514	home again, and having paid his respects to Mrs. Carrol, Laurie left
514	them, promising to return in the evening.
514	""
514	It must be recorded of Amy that she deliberately prinked that night.
514	Time and absence had done its work on both the young people. She had
514	seen her old friend in a new light, not as 'our boy', but as a handsome
514	and agreeable man, and she was conscious of a very natural desire to
514	find favor in his sight.  Amy knew her good points, and made the most
514	of them with the taste and skill which is a fortune to a poor and
514	pretty woman.
514	""
514	Tarlatan and tulle were cheap at Nice, so she enveloped herself in them
514	on such occasions, and following the sensible English fashion of simple
514	dress for young girls, got up charming little toilettes with fresh
514	flowers, a few trinkets, and all manner of dainty devices, which were
514	both inexpensive and effective.  It must be confessed that the artist
514	sometimes got possession of the woman, and indulged in antique
514	coiffures, statuesque attitudes, and classic draperies. But, dear
514	heart, we all have our little weaknesses, and find it easy to pardon
514	such in the young, who satisfy our eyes with their comeliness, and keep
514	our hearts merry with their artless vanities.
514	""
514	"""I do want him to think I look well, and tell them so at home,"" said"
514	Amy to herself, as she put on Flo's old white silk ball dress, and
514	covered it with a cloud of fresh illusion, out of which her white
514	shoulders and golden head emerged with a most artistic effect. Her hair
514	she had the sense to let alone, after gathering up the thick waves and
514	curls into a Hebe-like knot at the back of her head.
514	""
514	"""It's not the fashion, but it's becoming, and I can't afford to make a"
514	"fright of myself,"" she used to say, when advised to frizzle, puff, or"
514	braid, as the latest style commanded.
514	""
514	Having no ornaments fine enough for this important occasion, Amy looped
514	her fleecy skirts with rosy clusters of azalea, and framed the white
514	shoulders in delicate green vines.  Remembering the painted boots, she
514	surveyed her white satin slippers with girlish satisfaction, and
514	chasseed down the room, admiring her aristocratic feet all by herself.
514	""
514	"""My new fan just matches my flowers, my gloves fit to a charm, and the"
514	real lace on Aunt's mouchoir gives an air to my whole dress. If I only
514	"had a classical nose and mouth I should be perfectly happy,"" she said,"
514	surveying herself with a critical eye and a candle in each hand.
514	""
514	In spite of this affliction, she looked unusually gay and graceful as
514	she glided away.  She seldom ran--it did not suit her style, she
514	thought, for being tall, the stately and Junoesque was more appropriate
514	than the sportive or piquante.  She walked up and down the long saloon
514	while waiting for Laurie, and once arranged herself under the
514	chandelier, which had a good effect upon her hair, then she thought
514	better of it, and went away to the other end of the room, as if ashamed
514	of the girlish desire to have the first view a propitious one.  It so
514	happened that she could not have done a better thing, for Laurie came
514	in so quietly she did not hear him, and as she stood at the distant
514	window, with her head half turned and one hand gathering up her dress,
514	the slender, white figure against the red curtains was as effective as
514	a well-placed statue.
514	""
514	"""Good evening, Diana!"" said Laurie, with the look of satisfaction she"
514	liked to see in his eyes when they rested on her.
514	""
514	"""Good evening, Apollo!"" she answered, smiling back at him, for he too"
514	looked unusually debonair, and the thought of entering the ballroom on
514	the arm of such a personable man caused Amy to pity the four plain
514	Misses Davis from the bottom of her heart.
514	""
514	"""Here are your flowers.  I arranged them myself, remembering that you"
514	"didn't like what Hannah calls a 'sot-bookay',"" said Laurie, handing her"
514	a delicate nosegay, in a holder that she had long coveted as she daily
514	passed it in Cardiglia's window.
514	""
514	"""How kind you are!"" she exclaimed gratefully.  ""If I'd known you were"
514	coming I'd have had something ready for you today, though not as pretty
514	"as this, I'm afraid."""
514	""
514	"""Thank you.  It isn't what it should be, but you have improved it,"" he"
514	added, as she snapped the silver bracelet on her wrist.
514	""
514	"""Please don't."""
514	""
514	"""I thought you liked that sort of thing."""
514	""
514	"""Not from you, it doesn't sound natural, and I like your old bluntness"
514	"better."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of it,"" he answered, with a look of relief, then buttoned her"
514	gloves for her, and asked if his tie was straight, just as he used to
514	do when they went to parties together at home.
514	""
514	The company assembled in the long salle a manger, that evening, was
514	such as one sees nowhere but on the Continent.  The hospitable
514	Americans had invited every acquaintance they had in Nice, and having
514	no prejudice against titles, secured a few to add luster to their
514	Christmas ball.
514	""
514	A Russian prince condescended to sit in a corner for an hour and talk
514	with a massive lady, dressed like Hamlet's mother in black velvet with
514	a pearl bridle under her chin.  A Polish count, aged eighteen, devoted
514	himself to the ladies, who pronounced him, 'a fascinating dear', and a
514	German Serene Something, having come to supper alone, roamed vaguely
514	about, seeking what he might devour.  Baron Rothschild's private
514	secretary, a large-nosed Jew in tight boots, affably beamed upon the
514	world, as if his master's name crowned him with a golden halo.  A stout
514	Frenchman, who knew the Emperor, came to indulge his mania for dancing,
514	and Lady de Jones, a British matron, adorned the scene with her little
514	family of eight.  Of course, there were many light-footed,
514	shrill-voiced American girls, handsome, lifeless-looking English ditto,
514	and a few plain but piquante French demoiselles, likewise the usual set
514	of traveling young gentlemen who disported themselves gaily, while
514	mammas of all nations lined the walls and smiled upon them benignly
514	when they danced with their daughters.
514	""
514	Any young girl can imagine Amy's state of mind when she 'took the
514	stage' that night, leaning on Laurie's arm.  She knew she looked well,
514	she loved to dance, she felt that her foot was on her native heath in a
514	ballroom, and enjoyed the delightful sense of power which comes when
514	young girls first discover the new and lovely kingdom they are born to
514	rule by virtue of beauty, youth, and womanhood.  She did pity the Davis
514	girls, who were awkward, plain, and destitute of escort, except a grim
514	papa and three grimmer maiden aunts, and she bowed to them in her
514	friendliest manner as she passed, which was good of her, as it
514	permitted them to see her dress, and burn with curiosity to know who
514	her distinguished-looking friend might be.  With the first burst of the
514	band, Amy's color rose, her eyes began to sparkle, and her feet to tap
514	the floor impatiently, for she danced well and wanted Laurie to know
514	it.  Therefore the shock she received can better be imagined than
514	"described, when he said in a perfectly tranquil tone, ""Do you care to"
514	"dance?"""
514	""
514	"""One usually does at a ball."""
514	""
514	Her amazed look and quick answer caused Laurie to repair his error as
514	fast as possible.
514	""
514	"""I meant the first dance.  May I have the honor?"""
514	""
514	"""I can give you one if I put off the Count.  He dances divinely, but he"
514	"will excuse me, as you are an old friend,"" said Amy, hoping that the"
514	name would have a good effect, and show Laurie that she was not to be
514	trifled with.
514	""
514	"""Nice little boy, but rather a short Pole to support..."
514	""
514	    A daughter of the gods,
514	"    Divinely tall, and most divinely fair,"""
514	""
514	was all the satisfaction she got, however.
514	""
514	The set in which they found themselves was composed of English, and Amy
514	was compelled to walk decorously through a cotillion, feeling all the
514	while as if she could dance the tarantella with relish.  Laurie
514	resigned her to the 'nice little boy', and went to do his duty to Flo,
514	without securing Amy for the joys to come, which reprehensible want of
514	forethought was properly punished, for she immediately engaged herself
514	till supper, meaning to relent if he then gave any signs penitence. She
514	showed him her ball book with demure satisfaction when he strolled
514	instead of rushed up to claim her for the next, a glorious polka
514	redowa.  But his polite regrets didn't impose upon her, and when she
514	galloped away with the Count, she saw Laurie sit down by her aunt with
514	an actual expression of relief.
514	""
514	That was unpardonable, and Amy took no more notice of him for a long
514	while, except a word now and then when she came to her chaperon between
514	the dances for a necessary pin or a moment's rest.  Her anger had a
514	good effect, however, for she hid it under a smiling face, and seemed
514	unusually blithe and brilliant.  Laurie's eyes followed her with
514	pleasure, for she neither romped nor sauntered, but danced with spirit
514	and grace, making the delightsome pastime what it should be.  He very
514	naturally fell to studying her from this new point of view, and before
514	the evening was half over, had decided that 'little Amy was going to
514	make a very charming woman'.
514	""
514	It was a lively scene, for soon the spirit of the social season took
514	possession of everyone, and Christmas merriment made all faces shine,
514	hearts happy, and heels light.  The musicians fiddled, tooted, and
514	banged as if they enjoyed it, everybody danced who could, and those who
514	couldn't admired their neighbors with uncommon warmth.  The air was
514	dark with Davises, and many Joneses gamboled like a flock of young
514	giraffes.  The golden secretary darted through the room like a meteor
514	with a dashing French-woman who carpeted the floor with her pink satin
514	train.  The serene Teuton found the supper-table and was happy, eating
514	steadily through the bill of fare, and dismayed the garcons by the
514	ravages he committed.  But the Emperor's friend covered himself with
514	glory, for he danced everything, whether he knew it or not, and
514	introduced impromptu pirouettes when the figures bewildered him.  The
514	boyish abandon of that stout man was charming to behold, for though he
514	'carried weight', he danced like an India-rubber ball.  He ran, he
514	flew, he pranced, his face glowed, his bald head shown, his coattails
514	waved wildly, his pumps actually twinkled in the air, and when the
514	music stopped, he wiped the drops from his brow, and beamed upon his
514	fellow men like a French Pickwick without glasses.
514	""
514	Amy and her Pole distinguished themselves by equal enthusiasm but more
514	graceful agility, and Laurie found himself involuntarily keeping time
514	to the rhythmic rise and fall of the white slippers as they flew by as
514	indefatigably as if winged. When little Vladimir finally relinquished
514	her, with assurances that he was 'desolated to leave so early', she was
514	ready to rest, and see how her recreant knight had borne his punishment.
514	""
514	It had been successful, for at three-and-twenty, blighted affections
514	find a balm in friendly society, and young nerves will thrill, young
514	blood dance, and healthy young spirits rise, when subjected to the
514	enchantment of beauty, light, music, and motion.  Laurie had a waked-up
514	look as he rose to give her his seat, and when he hurried away to bring
514	"her some supper, she said to herself, with a satisfied smile, ""Ah, I"
514	"thought that would do him good!"""
514	""
514	"""You look like Balzac's '_Femme Peinte Par Elle-Meme_',"" he said, as he"
514	fanned her with one hand and held her coffee cup in the other.
514	""
514	"""My rouge won't come off."" and Amy rubbed her brilliant cheek, and"
514	showed him her white glove with a sober simplicity that made him laugh
514	outright.
514	""
514	"""What do you call this stuff?"" he asked, touching a fold of her dress"
514	that had blown over his knee.
514	""
514	"""Illusion."""
514	""
514	"""Good name for it.  It's very pretty--new thing, isn't it?"""
514	""
514	"""It's as old as the hills.  You have seen it on dozens of girls, and"
514	"you never found out that it was pretty till now--stupide!"""
514	""
514	"""I never saw it on you before, which accounts for the mistake, you see."""
514	""
514	"""None of that, it is forbidden.  I'd rather take coffee than"
514	"compliments just now.  No, don't lounge, it makes me nervous."""
514	""
514	Laurie sat bold upright, and meekly took her empty plate feeling an odd
514	sort of pleasure in having 'little Amy' order him about, for she had
514	lost her shyness now, and felt an irrestible desire to trample on him,
514	as girls have a delightful way of doing when lords of creation show any
514	signs of subjection.
514	""
514	"""Where did you learn all this sort of thing?"" he asked with a quizzical"
514	look.
514	""
514	"""As 'this sort of thing' is rather a vague expression, would you kindly"
514	"explain?"" returned Amy, knowing perfectly well what he meant, but"
514	wickedly leaving him to describe what is indescribable.
514	""
514	"""Well--the general air, the style, the self-possession,"
514	"the--the--illusion--you know"", laughed Laurie, breaking down and"
514	helping himself out of his quandary with the new word.
514	""
514	Amy was gratified, but of course didn't show it, and demurely answered,
514	"""Foreign life polishes one in spite of one's self.  I study as well as"
514	"play, and as for this""--with a little gesture toward her dress--""why,"
514	tulle is cheap, posies to be had for nothing, and I am used to making
514	"the most of my poor little things."""
514	""
514	Amy rather regretted that last sentence, fearing it wasn't in good
514	taste, but Laurie liked her better for it, and found himself both
514	admiring and respecting the brave patience that made the most of
514	opportunity, and the cheerful spirit that covered poverty with flowers.
514	Amy did not know why he looked at her so kindly, nor why he filled up
514	her book with his own name, and devoted himself to her for the rest of
514	the evening in the most delightful manner; but the impulse that wrought
514	this agreeable change was the result of one of the new impressions
514	which both of them were unconsciously giving and receiving.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-EIGHT
514	""
514	ON THE SHELF
514	""
514	In France the young girls have a dull time of it till they are married,
514	when 'Vive la liberte!' becomes their motto.  In America, as everyone
514	knows, girls early sign the declaration of independence, and enjoy
514	their freedom with republican zest, but the young matrons usually
514	abdicate with the first heir to the throne and go into a seclusion
514	almost as close as a French nunnery, though by no means as quiet.
514	Whether they like it or not, they are virtually put upon the shelf as
514	soon as the wedding excitement is over, and most of them might exclaim,
514	"as did a very pretty woman the other day, ""I'm as handsome as ever, but"
514	"no one takes any notice of me because I'm married."""
514	""
514	Not being a belle or even a fashionable lady, Meg did not experience
514	this affliction till her babies were a year old, for in her little
514	world primitive customs prevailed, and she found herself more admired
514	and beloved than ever.
514	""
514	As she was a womanly little woman, the maternal instinct was very
514	strong, and she was entirely absorbed in her children, to the utter
514	exclusion of everything and everybody else.  Day and night she brooded
514	over them with tireless devotion and anxiety, leaving John to the
514	tender mercies of the help, for an Irish lady now presided over the
514	kitchen department.  Being a domestic man, John decidedly missed the
514	wifely attentions he had been accustomed to receive, but as he adored
514	his babies, he cheerfully relinquished his comfort for a time,
514	supposing with masculine ignorance that peace would soon be restored.
514	But three months passed, and there was no return of repose.  Meg looked
514	worn and nervous, the babies absorbed every minute of her time, the
514	house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took life 'aisy', kept
514	him on short commons.  When he went out in the morning he was
514	bewildered by small commissions for the captive mamma, if he came gaily
514	"in at night, eager to embrace his family, he was quenched by a ""Hush!"
514	"They are just asleep after worrying all day.""  If he proposed a little"
514	"amusement at home, ""No, it would disturb the babies.""  If he hinted at"
514	a lecture or a concert, he was answered with a reproachful look, and a
514	"decided--""Leave my children for pleasure, never!""  His sleep was broken"
514	by infant wails and visions of a phantom figure pacing noiselessly to
514	and fro in the watches of the night.  His meals were interrupted by the
514	frequent flight of the presiding genius, who deserted him, half-helped,
514	if a muffled chirp sounded from the nest above.  And when he read his
514	paper of an evening, Demi's colic got into the shipping list and
514	Daisy's fall affected the price of stocks, for Mrs. Brooke was only
514	interested in domestic news.
514	""
514	The poor man was very uncomfortable, for the children had bereft him of
514	his wife, home was merely a nursery and the perpetual 'hushing' made
514	him feel like a brutal intruder whenever he entered the sacred
514	precincts of Babyland.  He bore it very patiently for six months, and
514	when no signs of amendment appeared, he did what other paternal exiles
514	do--tried to get a little comfort elsewhere.  Scott had married and
514	gone to housekeeping not far off, and John fell into the way of running
514	over for an hour or two of an evening, when his own parlor was empty,
514	and his own wife singing lullabies that seemed to have no end.  Mrs.
514	Scott was a lively, pretty girl, with nothing to do but be agreeable,
514	and she performed her mission most successfully.  The parlor was always
514	bright and attractive, the chessboard ready, the piano in tune, plenty
514	of gay gossip, and a nice little supper set forth in tempting style.
514	""
514	John would have preferred his own fireside if it had not been so
514	lonely, but as it was he gratefully took the next best thing and
514	enjoyed his neighbor's society.
514	""
514	Meg rather approved of the new arrangement at first, and found it a
514	relief to know that John was having a good time instead of dozing in
514	the parlor, or tramping about the house and waking the children.  But
514	by-and-by, when the teething worry was over and the idols went to sleep
514	at proper hours, leaving Mamma time to rest, she began to miss John,
514	and find her workbasket dull company, when he was not sitting opposite
514	in his old dressing gown, comfortably scorching his slippers on the
514	fender.  She would not ask him to stay at home, but felt injured
514	because he did not know that she wanted him without being told,
514	entirely forgetting the many evenings he had waited for her in vain.
514	She was nervous and worn out with watching and worry, and in that
514	unreasonable frame of mind which the best of mothers occasionally
514	experience when domestic cares oppress them.  Want of exercise robs
514	them of cheerfulness, and too much devotion to that idol of American
514	women, the teapot, makes them feel as if they were all nerve and no
514	muscle.
514	""
514	"""Yes,"" she would say, looking in the glass, ""I'm getting old and ugly."
514	John doesn't find me interesting any longer, so he leaves his faded
514	wife and goes to see his pretty neighbor, who has no incumbrances.
514	Well, the babies love me, they don't care if I am thin and pale and
514	haven't time to crimp my hair, they are my comfort, and some day John
514	"will see what I've gladly sacrificed for them, won't he, my precious?"""
514	""
514	To which pathetic appeal Daisy would answer with a coo, or Demi with a
514	crow, and Meg would put by her lamentations for a maternal revel, which
514	soothed her solitude for the time being. But the pain increased as
514	politics absorbed John, who was always running over to discuss
514	interesting points with Scott, quite unconscious that Meg missed him.
514	Not a word did she say, however, till her mother found her in tears one
514	day, and insisted on knowing what the matter was, for Meg's drooping
514	spirits had not escaped her observation.
514	""
514	"""I wouldn't tell anyone except you, Mother, but I really do need"
514	"advice, for if John goes on much longer I might as well be widowed,"""
514	replied Mrs. Brooke, drying her tears on Daisy's bib with an injured
514	air.
514	""
514	"""Goes on how, my dear?"" asked her mother anxiously."
514	""
514	"""He's away all day, and at night when I want to see him, he is"
514	continually going over to the Scotts'.  It isn't fair that I should
514	have the hardest work, and never any amusement. Men are very selfish,
514	"even the best of them."""
514	""
514	"""So are women.  Don't blame John till you see where you are wrong"
514	"yourself."""
514	""
514	"""But it can't be right for him to neglect me."""
514	""
514	"""Don't you neglect him?"""
514	""
514	"""Why, Mother, I thought you'd take my part!"""
514	""
514	"""So I do, as far as sympathizing goes, but I think the fault is yours,"
514	"Meg."""
514	""
514	"""I don't see how."""
514	""
514	"""Let me show you.  Did John ever neglect you, as you call it, while you"
514	made it a point to give him your society of an evening, his only
514	"leisure time?"""
514	""
514	"""No, but I can't do it now, with two babies to tend."""
514	""
514	"""I think you could, dear, and I think you ought.  May I speak quite"
514	freely, and will you remember that it's Mother who blames as well as
514	"Mother who sympathizes?"""
514	""
514	"""Indeed I will!  Speak to me as if I were little Meg again. I often"
514	feel as if I needed teaching more than ever since these babies look to
514	"me for everything."""
514	""
514	Meg drew her low chair beside her mother's, and with a little
514	interruption in either lap, the two women rocked and talked lovingly
514	together, feeling that the tie of motherhood made them more one than
514	ever.
514	""
514	"""You have only made the mistake that most young wives make--forgotten"
514	your duty to your husband in your love for your children. A very
514	natural and forgivable mistake, Meg, but one that had better be
514	remedied before you take to different ways, for children should draw
514	you nearer than ever, not separate you, as if they were all yours, and
514	John had nothing to do but support them.  I've seen it for some weeks,
514	"but have not spoken, feeling sure it would come right in time."""
514	""
514	"""I'm afraid it won't.  If I ask him to stay, he'll think I'm jealous,"
514	and I wouldn't insult him by such an idea.  He doesn't see that I want
514	"him, and I don't know how to tell him without words."""
514	""
514	"""Make it so pleasant he won't want to go away.  My dear, he's longing"
514	for his little home, but it isn't home without you, and you are always
514	"in the nursery."""
514	""
514	"""Oughtn't I to be there?"""
514	""
514	"""Not all the time, too much confinement makes you nervous, and then you"
514	are unfitted for everything.  Besides, you owe something to John as
514	well as to the babies.  Don't neglect husband for children, don't shut
514	him out of the nursery, but teach him how to help in it.  His place is
514	there as well as yours, and the children need him.  Let him feel that
514	he has a part to do, and he will do it gladly and faithfully, and it
514	"will be better for you all."""
514	""
514	"""You really think so, Mother?"""
514	""
514	"""I know it, Meg, for I've tried it, and I seldom give advice unless"
514	I've proved its practicability.  When you and Jo were little, I went on
514	just as you are, feeling as if I didn't do my duty unless I devoted
514	myself wholly to you.  Poor Father took to his books, after I had
514	refused all offers of help, and left me to try my experiment alone.  I
514	struggled along as well as I could, but Jo was too much for me.  I
514	nearly spoiled her by indulgence.  You were poorly, and I worried about
514	you till I fell sick myself.  Then Father came to the rescue, quietly
514	managed everything, and made himself so helpful that I saw my mistake,
514	and never have been able to get on without him since.  That is the
514	secret of our home happiness.  He does not let business wean him from
514	the little cares and duties that affect us all, and I try not to let
514	domestic worries destroy my interest in his pursuits.  Each do our part
514	"alone in many things, but at home we work together, always."""
514	""
514	"""It is so, Mother, and my great wish is to be to my husband and"
514	children what you have been to yours.  Show me how, I'll do anything
514	"you say."""
514	""
514	"""You always were my docile daughter.  Well, dear, if I were you, I'd"
514	let John have more to do with the management of Demi, for the boy needs
514	training, and it's none too soon to begin. Then I'd do what I have
514	often proposed, let Hannah come and help you.  She is a capital nurse,
514	and you may trust the precious babies to her while you do more
514	housework.  You need the exercise, Hannah would enjoy the rest, and
514	John would find his wife again. Go out more, keep cheerful as well as
514	busy, for you are the sunshine-maker of the family, and if you get
514	dismal there is no fair weather.  Then I'd try to take an interest in
514	whatever John likes--talk with him, let him read to you, exchange
514	ideas, and help each other in that way.  Don't shut yourself up in a
514	bandbox because you are a woman, but understand what is going on, and
514	educate yourself to take your part in the world's work, for it all
514	"affects you and yours."""
514	""
514	"""John is so sensible, I'm afraid he will think I'm stupid if I ask"
514	"questions about politics and things."""
514	""
514	"""I don't believe he would.  Love covers a multitude of sins, and of"
514	whom could you ask more freely than of him?  Try it, and see if he
514	"doesn't find your society far more agreeable than Mrs. Scott's suppers."""
514	""
514	"""I will.  Poor John!  I'm afraid I have neglected him sadly, but I"
514	"thought I was right, and he never said anything."""
514	""
514	"""He tried not to be selfish, but he has felt rather forlorn, I fancy."
514	This is just the time, Meg, when young married people are apt to grow
514	apart, and the very time when they ought to be most together, for the
514	first tenderness soon wears off, unless care is taken to preserve it.
514	And no time is so beautiful and precious to parents as the first years
514	of the little lives given to them to train.  Don't let John be a
514	stranger to the babies, for they will do more to keep him safe and
514	happy in this world of trial and temptation than anything else, and
514	through them you will learn to know and love one another as you should.
514	Now, dear, good-by.  Think over Mother's preachment, act upon it if it
514	"seems good, and God bless you all."""
514	""
514	Meg did think it over, found it good, and acted upon it, though the
514	first attempt was not made exactly as she planned to have it.  Of
514	course the children tyrannized over her, and ruled the house as soon as
514	they found out that kicking and squalling brought them whatever they
514	wanted.  Mamma was an abject slave to their caprices, but Papa was not
514	so easily subjugated, and occasionally afflicted his tender spouse by
514	an attempt at paternal discipline with his obstreperous son. For Demi
514	inherited a trifle of his sire's firmness of character, we won't call
514	it obstinacy, and when he made up his little mind to have or to do
514	anything, all the king's horses and all the king's men could not change
514	that pertinacious little mind.  Mamma thought the dear too young to be
514	taught to conquer his prejudices, but Papa believed that it never was
514	too soon to learn obedience.  So Master Demi early discovered that when
514	he undertook to 'wrastle' with 'Parpar', he always got the worst of it,
514	yet like the Englishman, baby respected the man who conquered him, and
514	"loved the father whose grave ""No, no,"" was more impressive than all"
514	Mamma's love pats.
514	""
514	A few days after the talk with her mother, Meg resolved to try a social
514	evening with John, so she ordered a nice supper, set the parlor in
514	order, dressed herself prettily, and put the children to bed early,
514	that nothing should interfere with her experiment.  But unfortunately
514	Demi's most unconquerable prejudice was against going to bed, and that
514	night he decided to go on a rampage.  So poor Meg sang and rocked, told
514	stories and tried every sleep-prevoking wile she could devise, but all
514	in vain, the big eyes wouldn't shut, and long after Daisy had gone to
514	byelow, like the chubby little bunch of good nature she was, naughty
514	Demi lay staring at the light, with the most discouragingly wide-awake
514	expression of countenance.
514	""
514	"""Will Demi lie still like a good boy, while Mamma runs down and gives"
514	"poor Papa his tea?"" asked Meg, as the hall door softly closed, and the"
514	well-known step went tip-toeing into the dining room.
514	""
514	"""Me has tea!"" said Demi, preparing to join in the revel."
514	""
514	"""No, but I'll save you some little cakies for breakfast, if you'll go"
514	"bye-bye like Daisy.  Will you, lovey?"""
514	""
514	"""Iss!"" and Demi shut his eyes tight, as if to catch sleep and hurry the"
514	desired day.
514	""
514	Taking advantage of the propitious moment, Meg slipped away and ran
514	down to greet her husband with a smiling face and the little blue bow
514	in her hair which was his especial admiration.  He saw it at once and
514	"said with pleased surprise, ""Why, little mother, how gay we are"
514	"tonight.  Do you expect company?"""
514	""
514	"""Only you, dear."""
514	""
514	"""Is it a birthday, anniversary, or anything?"""
514	""
514	"""No, I'm tired of being dowdy, so I dressed up as a change.  You always"
514	make yourself nice for table, no matter how tired you are, so why
514	"shouldn't I when I have the time?"""
514	""
514	"""I do it out of respect for you, my dear,"" said old-fashioned John."
514	""
514	"""Ditto, ditto, Mr. Brooke,"" laughed Meg, looking young and pretty"
514	again, as she nodded to him over the teapot.
514	""
514	"""Well, it's altogether delightful, and like old times.  This tastes"
514	"right.  I drink your health, dear."" and John sipped his tea with an air"
514	of reposeful rapture, which was of very short duration however, for as
514	he put down his cup, the door handle rattled mysteriously, and a little
514	voice was heard, saying impatiently...
514	""
514	"""Opy doy.  Me's tummin!"""
514	""
514	"""It's that naughty boy.  I told him to go to sleep alone, and here he"
514	"is, downstairs, getting his death a-cold pattering over that canvas,"""
514	said Meg, answering the call.
514	""
514	"""Mornin' now,"" announced Demi in joyful tone as he entered, with his"
514	long nightgown gracefully festooned over his arm and every curl bobbing
514	gayly as he pranced about the table, eyeing the 'cakies' with loving
514	glances.
514	""
514	"""No, it isn't morning yet.  You must go to bed, and not trouble poor"
514	"Mamma.  Then you can have the little cake with sugar on it."""
514	""
514	"""Me loves Parpar,"" said the artful one, preparing to climb the paternal"
514	knee and revel in forbidden joys.  But John shook his head, and said to
514	Meg...
514	""
514	"""If you told him to stay up there, and go to sleep alone, make him do"
514	"it, or he will never learn to mind you."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, of course.  Come, Demi,""  and Meg led her son away, feeling a"
514	strong desire to spank the little marplot who hopped beside her,
514	laboring under the delusion that the bribe was to be administered as
514	soon as they reached the nursery.
514	""
514	Nor was he disappointed, for that shortsighted woman actually gave him
514	a lump of sugar, tucked him into his bed, and forbade any more
514	promenades till morning.
514	""
514	"""Iss!"" said Demi the perjured, blissfully sucking his sugar, and"
514	regarding his first attempt as eminently successful.
514	""
514	Meg returned to her place, and supper was progressing pleasantly, when
514	the little ghost walked again, and exposed the maternal delinquencies
514	"by boldly demanding, ""More sudar, Marmar."""
514	""
514	"""Now this won't do,"" said John, hardening his heart against the"
514	"engaging little sinner.  ""We shall never know any peace till that child"
514	learns to go to bed properly.  You have made a slave of yourself long
514	enough.  Give him one lesson, and then there will be an end of it.  Put
514	"him in his bed and leave him, Meg."""
514	""
514	"""He won't stay there, he never does unless I sit by him."""
514	""
514	"""I'll manage him.  Demi, go upstairs, and get into your bed, as Mamma"
514	"bids you."""
514	""
514	"""S'ant!"" replied the young rebel, helping himself to the coveted"
514	'cakie', and beginning to eat the same with calm audacity.
514	""
514	"""You must never say that to Papa.  I shall carry you if you don't go"
514	"yourself."""
514	""
514	"""Go 'way, me don't love Parpar."" and Demi retired to his mother's"
514	skirts for protection.
514	""
514	But even that refuge proved unavailing, for he was delivered over to
514	"the enemy, with a ""Be gentle with him, John,"" which struck the culprit"
514	with dismay, for when Mamma deserted him, then the judgment day was at
514	hand.  Bereft of his cake, defrauded of his frolic, and borne away by a
514	strong hand to that detested bed, poor Demi could not restrain his
514	wrath, but openly defied Papa, and kicked and screamed lustily all the
514	way upstairs.  The minute he was put into bed on one side, he rolled
514	out on the other, and made for the door, only to be ignominiously
514	caught up by the tail of his little toga and put back again, which
514	lively performance was kept up till the young man's strength gave out,
514	when he devoted himself to roaring at the top of his voice.  This vocal
514	exercise usually conquered Meg, but John sat as unmoved as the post
514	which is popularly believed to be deaf.  No coaxing, no sugar, no
514	lullaby, no story, even the light was put out and only the red glow of
514	the fire enlivened the 'big dark' which Demi regarded with curiosity
514	rather than fear.  This new order of things disgusted him, and he
514	howled dismally for 'Marmar', as his angry passions subsided, and
514	recollections of his tender bondwoman returned to the captive autocrat.
514	The plaintive wail which succeeded the passionate roar went to Meg's
514	heart, and she ran up to say beseechingly...
514	""
514	"""Let me stay with him, he'll be good now, John."""
514	""
514	"""No, my dear.  I've told him he must go to sleep, as you bid him, and"
514	"he must, if I stay here all night."""
514	""
514	"""But he'll cry himself sick,"" pleaded Meg, reproaching herself for"
514	deserting her boy.
514	""
514	"""No, he won't, he's so tired he will soon drop off and then the matter"
514	is settled, for he will understand that he has got to mind.  Don't
514	"interfere, I'll manage him."""
514	""
514	"""He's my child, and I can't have his spirit broken by harshness."""
514	""
514	"""He's my child, and I won't have his temper spoiled by indulgence.  Go"
514	"down, my dear, and leave the boy to me."""
514	""
514	When John spoke in that masterful tone, Meg always obeyed, and never
514	regretted her docility.
514	""
514	"""Please let me kiss him once, John?"""
514	""
514	"""Certainly.  Demi, say good night to Mamma, and let her go and rest,"
514	"for she is very tired with taking care of you all day."""
514	""
514	Meg always insisted upon it that the kiss won the victory, for after it
514	was given, Demi sobbed more quietly, and lay quite still at the bottom
514	of the bed, whither he had wriggled in his anguish of mind.
514	""
514	"""Poor little man, he's worn out with sleep and crying.  I'll cover him"
514	"up, and then go and set Meg's heart at rest,"" thought John, creeping to"
514	the bedside, hoping to find his rebellious heir asleep.
514	""
514	But he wasn't, for the moment his father peeped at him, Demi's eyes
514	opened, his little chin began to quiver, and he put up his arms, saying
514	"with a penitent hiccough, ""Me's dood, now."""
514	""
514	Sitting on the stairs outside Meg wondered at the long silence which
514	followed the uproar, and after imagining all sorts of impossible
514	accidents, she slipped into the room to set her fears at rest.  Demi
514	lay fast asleep, not in his usual spreadeagle attitude, but in a
514	subdued bunch, cuddled close in the circle of his father's arm and
514	holding his father's finger, as if he felt that justice was tempered
514	with mercy, and had gone to sleep a sadder and wiser baby.  So held,
514	John had waited with a womanly patience till the little hand relaxed
514	its hold, and while waiting had fallen asleep, more tired by that
