514	tussle with his son than with his whole day's work.
514	""
514	As Meg stood watching the two faces on the pillow, she smiled to
514	"herself, and then slipped away again, saying in a satisfied tone, ""I"
514	never need fear that John will be too harsh with my babies.  He does
514	know how to manage them, and will be a great help, for Demi is getting
514	"too much for me."""
514	""
514	When John came down at last, expecting to find a pensive or reproachful
514	wife, he was agreeably surprised to find Meg placidly trimming a
514	bonnet, and to be greeted with the request to read something about the
514	election, if he was not too tired.  John saw in a minute that a
514	revolution of some kind was going on, but wisely asked no questions,
514	knowing that Meg was such a transparent little person, she couldn't
514	keep a secret to save her life, and therefore the clue would soon
514	appear.  He read a long debate with the most amiable readiness and then
514	explained it in his most lucid manner, while Meg tried to look deeply
514	interested, to ask intelligent questions, and keep her thoughts from
514	wandering from the state of the nation to the state of her bonnet.  In
514	her secret soul, however, she decided that politics were as bad as
514	mathematics, and that the mission of politicians seemed to be calling
514	each other names, but she kept these feminine ideas to herself, and
514	when John paused, shook her head and said with what she thought
514	"diplomatic ambiguity, ""Well, I really don't see what we are coming to."""
514	""
514	John laughed, and watched her for a minute, as she poised a pretty
514	little preparation of lace and flowers on her hand, and regarded it
514	with the genuine interest which his harangue had failed to waken.
514	""
514	"""She is trying to like politics for my sake, so I'll try and like"
514	"millinery for hers, that's only fair,"" thought John the Just, adding"
514	"aloud, ""That's very pretty.  Is it what you call a breakfast cap?"""
514	""
514	"""My dear man, it's a bonnet!   My very best go-to-concert-and-theater"
514	"bonnet."""
514	""
514	"""I beg your pardon, it was so small, I naturally mistook it for one of"
514	"the flyaway things you sometimes wear. How do you keep it on?"""
514	""
514	"""These bits of lace are fastened under the chin with a rosebud, so,"""
514	and Meg illustrated by putting on the bonnet and regarding him with an
514	air of calm satisfaction that was irresistible.
514	""
514	"""It's a love of a bonnet, but I prefer the face inside, for it looks"
514	"young and happy again,"" and John kissed the smiling face, to the great"
514	detriment of the rosebud under the chin.
514	""
514	"""I'm glad you like it, for I want you to take me to one of the new"
514	concerts some night.  I really need some music to put me in tune.  Will
514	"you, please?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course I will, with all my heart, or anywhere else you like.  You"
514	have been shut up so long, it will do you no end of good, and I shall
514	"enjoy it, of all things.  What put it into your head, little mother?"""
514	""
514	"""Well, I had a talk with Marmee the other day, and told her how nervous"
514	and cross and out of sorts I felt, and she said I needed change and
514	less care, so Hannah is to help me with the children, and I'm to see to
514	things about the house more, and now and then have a little fun, just
514	to keep me from getting to be a fidgety, broken-down old woman before
514	my time.  It's only an experiment, John, and I want to try it for your
514	sake as much as for mine, because I've neglected you shamefully lately,
514	and I'm going to make home what it used to be, if I can.  You don't
514	"object, I hope?"""
514	""
514	Never mind what John said, or what a very narrow escape the little
514	bonnet had from utter ruin.  All that we have any business to know is
514	that John did not appear to object, judging from the changes which
514	gradually took place in the house and its inmates.  It was not all
514	Paradise by any means, but everyone was better for the division of
514	labor system.  The children throve under the paternal rule, for
514	accurate, steadfast John brought order and obedience into Babydom, while
514	Meg recovered her spirits and composed her nerves by plenty of
514	wholesome exercise, a little pleasure, and much confidential
514	conversation with her sensible husband.  Home grew homelike again, and
514	John had no wish to leave it, unless he took Meg with him.  The Scotts
514	came to the Brookes' now, and everyone found the little house a
514	cheerful place, full of happiness, content, and family love.  Even
514	"Sallie Moffatt liked to go there.  ""It is always so quiet and pleasant"
514	"here, it does me good, Meg,"" she used to say, looking about her with"
514	wistful eyes, as if trying to discover the charm, that she might use it
514	in her great house, full of splendid loneliness, for there were no
514	riotous, sunny-faced babies there, and Ned lived in a world of his own,
514	where there was no place for her.
514	""
514	This household happiness did not come all at once, but John and Meg had
514	found the key to it, and each year of married life taught them how to
514	use it, unlocking the treasuries of real home love and mutual
514	helpfulness, which the poorest may possess, and the richest cannot buy.
514	This is the sort of shelf on which young wives and mothers may consent
514	to be laid, safe from the restless fret and fever of the world, finding
514	loyal lovers in the little sons and daughters who cling to them,
514	undaunted by sorrow, poverty, or age, walking side by side, through
514	fair and stormy weather, with a faithful friend, who is, in the true
514	sense of the good old Saxon word, the 'house-band', and learning, as
514	Meg learned, that a woman's happiest kingdom is home, her highest honor
514	the art of ruling it not as a queen, but as a wise wife and mother.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER THIRTY-NINE
514	""
514	LAZY LAURENCE
514	""
514	Laurie went to Nice intending to stay a week, and remained a month.  He
514	was tired of wandering about alone, and Amy's familiar presence seemed
514	to give a homelike charm to the foreign scenes in which she bore a
514	part.  He rather missed the 'petting' he used to receive, and enjoyed a
514	taste of it again, for no attentions, however flattering, from
514	strangers, were half so pleasant as the sisterly adoration of the girls
514	at home.  Amy never would pet him like the others, but she was very
514	glad to see him now, and quite clung to him, feeling that he was the
514	representative of the dear family for whom she longed more than she
514	would confess.  They naturally took comfort in each other's society and
514	were much together, riding, walking, dancing, or dawdling, for at Nice
514	no one can be very industrious during the gay season.  But, while
514	apparently amusing themselves in the most careless fashion, they were
514	half-consciously making discoveries and forming opinions about each
514	other.  Amy rose daily in the estimation of her friend, but he sank in
514	hers, and each felt the truth before a word was spoken.  Amy tried to
514	please, and succeeded, for she was grateful for the many pleasures he
514	gave her, and repaid him with the little services to which womanly
514	women know how to lend an indescribable charm.  Laurie made no effort
514	of any kind, but just let himself drift along as comfortably as
514	possible, trying to forget, and feeling that all women owed him a kind
514	word because one had been cold to him.  It cost him no effort to be
514	generous, and he would have given Amy all the trinkets in Nice if she
514	would have taken them, but at the same time he felt that he could not
514	change the opinion she was forming of him, and he rather dreaded the
514	keen blue eyes that seemed to watch him with such half-sorrowful,
514	half-scornful surprise.
514	""
514	"""All the rest have gone to Monaco for the day.  I preferred to stay at"
514	home and write letters.  They are done now, and I am going to Valrosa
514	"to sketch, will you come?"" said Amy, as she joined Laurie one lovely"
514	day when he lounged in as usual, about noon.
514	""
514	"""Well, yes, but isn't it rather warm for such a long walk?"" he answered"
514	slowly, for the shaded salon looked inviting after the glare without.
514	""
514	"""I'm going to have the little carriage, and Baptiste can drive, so"
514	you'll have nothing to do but hold your umbrella, and keep your gloves
514	"nice,"" returned Amy, with a sarcastic glance at the immaculate kids,"
514	which were a weak point with Laurie.
514	""
514	"""Then I'll go with pleasure."" and he put out his hand for her"
514	sketchbook.  But she tucked it under her arm with a sharp...
514	""
514	"""Don't trouble yourself.  It's no exertion to me, but you don't look"
514	"equal to it."""
514	""
514	Laurie lifted his eyebrows and followed at a leisurely pace as she ran
514	downstairs, but when they got into the carriage he took the reins
514	himself, and left little Baptiste nothing to do but fold his arms and
514	fall asleep on his perch.
514	""
514	The two never quarreled.  Amy was too well-bred, and just now Laurie
514	was too lazy, so in a minute he peeped under her hatbrim with an
514	inquiring air.  She answered him with a smile, and they went on
514	together in the most amicable manner.
514	""
514	It was a lovely drive, along winding roads rich in the picturesque
514	scenes that delight beauty-loving eyes.  Here an ancient monastery,
514	whence the solemn chanting of the monks came down to them.  There a
514	bare-legged shepherd, in wooden shoes, pointed hat, and rough jacket
514	over one shoulder, sat piping on a stone while his goats skipped among
514	the rocks or lay at his feet.  Meek, mouse-colored donkeys, laden with
514	panniers of freshly cut grass passed by, with a pretty girl in a
514	capaline sitting between the green piles, or an old woman spinning with
514	a distaff as she went. Brown, soft-eyed children ran out from the
514	quaint stone hovels to offer nosegays, or bunches of oranges still on
514	the bough. Gnarled olive trees covered the hills with their dusky
514	foliage, fruit hung golden in the orchard, and great scarlet anemones
514	fringed the roadside, while beyond green slopes and craggy heights, the
514	Maritime Alps rose sharp and white against the blue Italian sky.
514	""
514	Valrosa well deserved its name, for in that climate of perpetual summer
514	roses blossomed everywhere.  They overhung the archway, thrust
514	themselves between the bars of the great gate with a sweet welcome to
514	passers-by, and lined the avenue, winding through lemon trees and
514	feathery palms up to the villa on the hill. Every shadowy nook, where
514	seats invited one to stop and rest, was a mass of bloom, every cool
514	grotto had its marble nymph smiling from a veil of flowers and every
514	fountain reflected crimson, white, or pale pink roses, leaning down to
514	smile at their own beauty. Roses covered the walls of the house, draped
514	the cornices, climbed the pillars, and ran riot over the balustrade of
514	the wide terrace, whence one looked down on the sunny Mediterranean,
514	and the white-walled city on its shore.
514	""
514	"""This is a regular honeymoon paradise, isn't it?  Did you ever see such"
514	"roses?"" asked Amy, pausing on the terrace to enjoy the view, and a"
514	luxurious whiff of perfume that came wandering by.
514	""
514	"""No, nor felt such thorns,"" returned Laurie, with his thumb in his"
514	mouth, after a vain attempt to capture a solitary scarlet flower that
514	grew just beyond his reach.
514	""
514	"""Try lower down, and pick those that have no thorns,"" said Amy,"
514	gathering three of the tiny cream-colored ones that starred the wall
514	behind her.  She put them in his buttonhole as a peace offering, and he
514	stood a minute looking down at them with a curious expression, for in
514	the Italian part of his nature there was a touch of superstition, and
514	he was just then in that state of half-sweet, half-bitter melancholy,
514	when imaginative young men find significance in trifles and food for
514	romance everywhere. He had thought of Jo in reaching after the thorny
514	red rose, for vivid flowers became her, and she had often worn ones
514	like that from the greenhouse at home.  The pale roses Amy gave him
514	were the sort that the Italians lay in dead hands, never in bridal
514	wreaths, and for a moment he wondered if the omen was for Jo or for
514	himself, but the next instant his American common sense got the better
514	of sentimentality, and he laughed a heartier laugh than Amy had heard
514	since he came.
514	""
514	"""It's good advice, you'd better take it and save your fingers,"" she"
514	said, thinking her speech amused him.
514	""
514	"""Thank you, I will,"" he answered in jest, and a few months later he did"
514	it in earnest.
514	""
514	"""Laurie, when are you going to your grandfather?"" she asked presently,"
514	as she settled herself on a rustic seat.
514	""
514	"""Very soon."""
514	""
514	"""You have said that a dozen times within the last three weeks."""
514	""
514	"""I dare say, short answers save trouble."""
514	""
514	"""He expects you, and you really ought to go."""
514	""
514	"""Hospitable creature!  I know it."""
514	""
514	"""Then why don't you do it?"""
514	""
514	"""Natural depravity, I suppose."""
514	""
514	"""Natural indolence, you mean.  It's really dreadful!"" and Amy looked"
514	severe.
514	""
514	"""Not so bad as it seems, for I should only plague him if I went, so I"

514	""
514	Amy shook her head and opened her sketchbook with an air of
514	resignation, but she had made up her mind to lecture 'that boy' and in
514	a minute she began again.
514	""
514	"""What are you doing just now?"""
514	""
514	"""Watching lizards."""
514	""
514	"""No, no.  I mean what do you intend and wish to do?"""
514	""
514	"""Smoke a cigarette, if you'll allow me."""
514	""
514	"""How provoking you are!  I don't approve of cigars and I will only"
514	allow it on condition that you let me put you into my sketch.  I need a
514	"figure."""
514	""
514	"""With all the pleasure in life.  How will you have me, full length or"
514	three-quarters, on my head or my heels?  I should respectfully suggest
514	a recumbent posture, then put yourself in also and call it 'Dolce far

514	""
514	"""Stay as you are, and go to sleep if you like.  I intend to work hard,"""

514	""
514	"""What delightful enthusiasm!"" and he leaned against a tall urn with an"

514	""
514	"""What would Jo say if she saw you now?"" asked Amy impatiently, hoping"

514	""
514	"""As usual, 'Go away, Teddy.  I'm busy!'"" He laughed as he spoke, but"
514	the laugh was not natural, and a shade passed over his face, for the
514	utterance of the familiar name touched the wound that was not healed

514	regret.  It was gone before she could study it and the listless
514	expression back again. She watched him for a moment with artistic
514	pleasure, thinking how like an Italian he looked, as he lay basking in
514	the sun with uncovered head and eyes full of southern dreaminess, for
514	he seemed to have forgotten her and fallen into a reverie.
514	""
514	"""You look like the effigy of a young knight asleep on his tomb,"" she"
514	said, carefully tracing the well-cut profile defined against the dark

514	""
514	"""Wish I was!"""
514	""
514	"""That's a foolish wish, unless you have spoiled your life. You are so"
514	"changed, I sometimes think--"" there Amy stopped, with a half-timid,"
514	half-wistful look, more significant than her unfinished speech.
514	""
514	Laurie saw and understood the affectionate anxiety which she hesitated

514	""

514	""
514	"""I'm glad of that!  I didn't think you'd been a very bad boy, but I"

514	""

514	""
514	"""I'm all ready for the secrets."" and he glanced up with a decided"

514	""
514	"""I've none to tell.  You may begin."""
514	""

514	"news from home.."""
514	""

514	"fancied Jo would send you volumes."""
514	""

514	""
514	"""Never,"" she answered, with a despondent but decided air. ""Rome took"
514	all the vanity out of me, for after seeing the wonders there, I felt
514	"too insignificant to live and gave up all my foolish hopes in despair."""
514	""
514	"""Why should you, with so much energy and talent?"""
514	""
514	"""That's just why, because talent isn't genius, and no amount of energy"

514	"common-place dauber, so I don't intend to try any more."""
514	""
514	"""And what are you going to do with yourself now, if I may ask?"""
514	""
514	"""Polish up my other talents, and be an ornament to society, if I get"
514	"the chance."""
514	""
514	It was a characteristic speech, and sounded daring, but audacity
514	becomes young people, and Amy's ambition had a good foundation.  Laurie
514	smiled, but he liked the spirit with which she took up a new purpose
514	when a long-cherished one died, and spent no time lamenting.
514	""
514	"""Good!  And here is where Fred Vaughn comes in, I fancy."""
514	""
514	Amy preserved a discreet silence, but there was a conscious look in her

514	""
514	"""I don't promise to answer."""
514	""

514	""
514	"""That's not for me to say,"" was Amy's grim reply, but her lips would"

514	""
514	"""You are not engaged, I hope?"" and Laurie looked very elder-brotherly"

514	""
514	"""No."""
514	""
514	"""But you will be, if he comes back and goes properly down on his knees,"

514	""
514	"""Very likely."""
514	""
514	"""Then you are fond of old Fred?"""
514	""
514	"""I could be, if I tried."""
514	""
514	"""But you don't intend to try till the proper moment? Bless my soul,"

514	""
514	"""He is rich, a gentleman, and has delightful manners,"" began Amy,"

514	""
514	"""I understand.  Queens of society can't get on without money, so you"

514	""
514	"""True, nevertheless."""
514	""
514	A short speech, but the quiet decision with which it was uttered

514	""
514	"""I wish you'd do me the favor to rouse yourself a little,"" she said"

514	""
514	"""Do it for me, there's a dear girl."""
514	""
514	"""I could, if I tried."" and she looked as if she would like doing it in"

514	""

514	"""You'd be angry in five minutes."""
514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""Pining to be told."""

514	""

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""Strong language, mademoiselle."""
514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""I thought you'd find it so.  Selfish people always like to talk about"

514	""

514	""

514	""
514	"""I supposed you'd take it so.  You men tell us we are angels, and say"

514	""
514	In a minute a hand came down over the page, so that she could not draw,

514	""
514	But Amy did not laugh, for she was in earnest, and tapping on the
514	"outspread hand with her pencil, said soberly, ""Aren't you ashamed of a"
514	hand like that?  It's as soft and white as a woman's, and looks as if
514	it never did anything but wear Jouvin's best gloves and pick flowers
514	for ladies.  You are not a dandy, thank Heaven, so I'm glad to see
514	there are no diamonds or big seal rings on it, only the little old one
514	"Jo gave you so long ago.  Dear soul, I wish she was here to help me!"""
514	""
514	"""So do I!"""
514	""
514	The hand vanished as suddenly as it came, and there was energy enough
514	in the echo of her wish to suit even Amy.  She glanced down at him with
514	a new thought in her mind, but he was lying with his hat half over his
514	face, as if for shade, and his mustache hid his mouth.  She only saw
514	his chest rise and fall, with a long breath that might have been a
514	sigh, and the hand that wore the ring nestled down into the grass, as
514	if to hide something too precious or too tender to be spoken of. All in
514	a minute various hints and trifles assumed shape and significance in
514	Amy's mind, and told her what her sister never had confided to her.
514	She remembered that Laurie never spoke voluntarily of Jo, she recalled
514	the shadow on his face just now, the change in his character, and the
514	wearing of the little old ring which was no ornament to a handsome
514	hand.  Girls are quick to read such signs and feel their eloquence.
514	Amy had fancied that perhaps a love trouble was at the bottom of the
514	alteration, and now she was sure of it.  Her keen eyes filled, and when
514	she spoke again, it was in a voice that could be beautifully soft and
514	kind when she chose to make it so.
514	""
514	"""I know I have no right to talk so to you, Laurie, and if you weren't"
514	the sweetest-tempered fellow in the world, you'd be very angry with me.
514	But we are all so fond and proud of you, I couldn't bear to think they
514	should be disappointed in you at home as I have been, though, perhaps
514	"they would understand the change better than I do."""
514	""
514	"""I think they would,"" came from under the hat, in a grim tone, quite as"
514	touching as a broken one.
514	""
514	"""They ought to have told me, and not let me go blundering and scolding,"
514	when I should have been more kind and patient than ever.  I never did
514	"like that Miss Randal and now I hate her!"" said artful Amy, wishing to"
514	be sure of her facts this time.
514	""
514	"""Hang Miss Randal!"" and Laurie knocked the hat off his face with a look"
514	that left no doubt of his sentiments toward that young lady.
514	""
514	"""I beg pardon, I thought..."" and there she paused diplomatically."
514	""
514	"""No, you didn't, you knew perfectly well I never cared for anyone but"
514	"Jo,"" Laurie said that in his old, impetuous tone, and turned his face"
514	away as he spoke.
514	""
514	"""I did think so, but as they never said anything about it, and you came"
514	away, I supposed I was mistaken.  And Jo wouldn't be kind to you?  Why,
514	"I was sure she loved you dearly."""
514	""
514	"""She was kind, but not in the right way, and it's lucky for her she"
514	didn't love me, if I'm the good-for-nothing fellow you think me.  It's
514	"her fault though, and you may tell her so."""
514	""
514	The hard, bitter look came back again as he said that, and it troubled
514	Amy, for she did not know what balm to apply.
514	""
514	"""I was wrong, I didn't know.  I'm very sorry I was so cross, but I"
514	"can't help wishing you'd bear it better, Teddy, dear."""
514	""
514	"""Don't, that's her name for me!"" and Laurie put up his hand with a"
514	quick gesture to stop the words spoken in Jo's half-kind,
514	"half-reproachful tone.  ""Wait till you've tried it yourself,"" he added"
514	in a low voice, as he pulled up the grass by the handful.
514	""
514	"""I'd take it manfully, and be respected if I couldn't be loved,"" said"
514	Amy, with the decision of one who knew nothing about it.
514	""
514	Now, Laurie flattered himself that he had borne it remarkably well,
514	making no moan, asking no sympathy, and taking his trouble away to live
514	it down alone.  Amy's lecture put the matter in a new light, and for
514	the first time it did look weak and selfish to lose heart at the first
514	failure, and shut himself up in moody indifference.  He felt as if
514	suddenly shaken out of a pensive dream and found it impossible to go to
514	"sleep again.  Presently he sat up and asked slowly, ""Do you think Jo"
514	"would despise me as you do?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, if she saw you now.  She hates lazy people.  Why don't you do"
514	"something splendid, and make her love you?"""
514	""
514	"""I did my best, but it was no use."""
514	""
514	"""Graduating well, you mean?  That was no more than you ought to have"
514	done, for your grandfather's sake.  It would have been shameful to fail
514	after spending so much time and money, when everyone knew that you
514	"could do well."""
514	""
514	"""I did fail, say what you will, for Jo wouldn't love me,"" began Laurie,"
514	leaning his head on his hand in a despondent attitude.
514	""
514	"""No, you didn't, and you'll say so in the end, for it did you good, and"
514	proved that you could do something if you tried. If you'd only set
514	about another task of some sort, you'd soon be your hearty, happy self
514	"again, and forget your trouble."""
514	""
514	"""That's impossible."""
514	""
514	"""Try it and see.  You needn't shrug your shoulders, and think, 'Much"
514	she knows about such things'.  I don't pretend to be wise, but I am
514	observing, and I see a great deal more than you'd imagine.  I'm
514	interested in other people's experiences and inconsistencies, and
514	though I can't explain, I remember and use them for my own benefit.
514	Love Jo all your days, if you choose, but don't let it spoil you, for
514	it's wicked to throw away so many good gifts because you can't have the
514	one you want.  There, I won't lecture any more, for I know you'll wake
514	"up and be a man in spite of that hardhearted girl."""
514	""
514	Neither spoke for several minutes.  Laurie sat turning the little ring
514	on his finger, and Amy put the last touches to the hasty sketch she had
514	been working at while she talked. Presently she put it on his knee,
514	"merely saying, ""How do you like that?"""
514	""
514	He looked and then he smiled, as he could not well help doing, for it
514	was capitally done, the long, lazy figure on the grass, with listless
514	face, half-shut eyes, and one hand holding a cigar, from which came the
514	little wreath of smoke that encircled the dreamer's head.
514	""
514	"""How well you draw!"" he said, with a genuine surprise and pleasure at"
514	"her skill, adding, with a half-laugh, ""Yes, that's me."""
514	""
514	"""As you are.  This is as you were."" and Amy laid another sketch beside"
514	the one he held.
514	""
514	It was not nearly so well done, but there was a life and spirit in it
514	which atoned for many faults, and it recalled the past so vividly that
514	a sudden change swept over the young man's face as he looked.  Only a
514	rough sketch of Laurie taming a horse.  Hat and coat were off, and
514	every line of the active figure, resolute face, and commanding attitude
514	was full of energy and meaning.  The handsome brute, just subdued,
514	stood arching his neck under the tightly drawn rein, with one foot
514	impatiently pawing the ground, and ears pricked up as if listening for
514	the voice that had mastered him.  In the ruffled mane, the rider's
514	breezy hair and erect attitude, there was a suggestion of suddenly
514	arrested motion, of strength, courage, and youthful buoyancy that
514	contrasted sharply with the supine grace of the '_Dolce far Niente_'
514	sketch.  Laurie said nothing but as his eye went from one to the other,
514	Amy saw him flush up and fold his lips together as if he read and
514	accepted the little lesson she had given him.  That satisfied her, and
514	without waiting for him to speak, she said, in her sprightly way...
514	""
514	"""Don't you remember the day you played Rarey with Puck, and we all"
514	looked on?  Meg and Beth were frightened, but Jo clapped and pranced,
514	and I sat on the fence and drew you.  I found that sketch in my
514	"portfolio the other day, touched it up, and kept it to show you."""
514	""
514	"""Much obliged.  You've improved immensely since then, and I"
514	congratulate you.  May I venture to suggest in 'a honeymoon paradise'
514	"that five o'clock is the dinner hour at your hotel?"""
514	""
514	Laurie rose as he spoke, returned the pictures with a smile and a bow
514	and looked at his watch, as if to remind her that even moral lectures
514	should have an end.  He tried to resume his former easy, indifferent
514	air, but it was an affectation now, for the rousing had been more
514	effacious than he would confess.  Amy felt the shade of coldness in his
514	manner, and said to herself...
514	""
514	"""Now, I've offended him.  Well, if it does him good, I'm glad, if it"
514	makes him hate me, I'm sorry, but it's true, and I can't take back a
514	"word of it."""
514	""
514	They laughed and chatted all the way home, and little Baptiste, up
514	behind, thought that monsieur and madamoiselle were in charming
514	spirits.  But both felt ill at ease.  The friendly frankness was
514	disturbed, the sunshine had a shadow over it, and despite their
514	apparent gaiety, there was a secret discontent in the heart of each.
514	""
514	"""Shall we see you this evening, mon frere?"" asked Amy, as they parted"
514	at her aunt's door.
514	""
514	"""Unfortunately I have an engagement.  Au revoir, madamoiselle,"" and"
514	Laurie bent as if to kiss her hand, in the foreign fashion, which
514	became him better than many men.  Something in his face made Amy say
514	quickly and warmly...
514	""
514	"""No, be yourself with me, Laurie, and part in the good old way. I'd"
514	rather have a hearty English handshake than all the sentimental
514	"salutations in France."""
514	""
514	"""Goodbye, dear,"" and with these words, uttered in the tone she liked,"
514	Laurie left her, after a handshake almost painful in its heartiness.
514	""
514	Next morning, instead of the usual call, Amy received a note which made
514	her smile at the beginning and sigh at the end.
514	""
514	My Dear Mentor, Please make my adieux to your aunt, and exult within
514	yourself, for 'Lazy Laurence' has gone to his grandpa, like the best of
514	boys.  A pleasant winter to you, and may the gods grant you a blissful
514	honeymoon at Valrosa!  I think Fred would be benefited by a rouser.
514	Tell him so, with my congratulations.
514	""
514	Yours gratefully, Telemachus
514	""
514	""
514	"""Good boy!  I'm glad he's gone,"" said Amy, with an approving smile. The"
514	next minute her face fell as she glanced about the empty room, adding,
514	"with an involuntary sigh, ""Yes, I am glad, but how I shall miss him."""
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY
514	""
514	THE VALLEY OF THE SHADOW
514	""
514	When the first bitterness was over, the family accepted the inevitable,
514	and tried to bear it cheerfully, helping one another by the increased
514	affection which comes to bind households tenderly together in times of
514	trouble.  They put away their grief, and each did his or her part
514	toward making that last year a happy one.
514	""
514	The pleasantest room in the house was set apart for Beth, and in it was
514	gathered everything that she most loved, flowers, pictures, her piano,
514	the little worktable, and the beloved pussies.  Father's best books
514	found their way there, Mother's easy chair, Jo's desk, Amy's finest
514	sketches, and every day Meg brought her babies on a loving pilgrimage,
514	to make sunshine for Aunty Beth.  John quietly set apart a little sum,
514	that he might enjoy the pleasure of keeping the invalid supplied with
514	the fruit she loved and longed for.  Old Hannah never wearied of
514	concocting dainty dishes to tempt a capricious appetite, dropping tears
514	as she worked, and from across the sea came little gifts and cheerful
514	letters, seeming to bring breaths of warmth and fragrance from lands
514	that know no winter.
514	""
514	Here, cherished like a household saint in its shrine, sat Beth,
514	tranquil and busy as ever, for nothing could change the sweet,
514	unselfish nature, and even while preparing to leave life, she tried to
514	make it happier for those who should remain behind.  The feeble fingers
514	were never idle, and one of her pleasures was to make little things for
514	the school children daily passing to and fro, to drop a pair of mittens
514	from her window for a pair of purple hands, a needlebook for some small
514	mother of many dolls, penwipers for young penmen toiling through
514	forests of pothooks, scrapbooks for picture-loving eyes, and all manner
514	of pleasant devices, till the reluctant climbers of the ladder of
514	learning found their way strewn with flowers, as it were, and came to
514	regard the gentle giver as a sort of fairy godmother, who sat above
514	there, and showered down gifts miraculously suited to their tastes and
514	needs.  If Beth had wanted any reward, she found it in the bright
514	little faces always turned up to her window, with nods and smiles, and
514	the droll little letters which came to her, full of blots and gratitude.
514	""
514	The first few months were very happy ones, and Beth often used to look
514	"round, and say ""How beautiful this is!"" as they all sat together in her"
514	sunny room, the babies kicking and crowing on the floor, mother and
514	sisters working near, and father reading, in his pleasant voice, from
514	the wise old books which seemed rich in good and comfortable words, as
514	applicable now as when written centuries ago, a little chapel, where a
514	paternal priest taught his flock the hard lessons all must learn,
514	trying to show them that hope can comfort love, and faith make
514	resignation possible.  Simple sermons, that went straight to the souls
514	of those who listened, for the father's heart was in the minister's
514	religion, and the frequent falter in the voice gave a double eloquence
514	to the words he spoke or read.
514	""
514	It was well for all that this peaceful time was given them as
514	preparation for the sad hours to come, for by-and-by, Beth said the
514	needle was 'so heavy', and put it down forever.  Talking wearied her,
514	faces troubled her, pain claimed her for its own, and her tranquil
514	spirit was sorrowfully perturbed by the ills that vexed her feeble
514	flesh.  Ah me! Such heavy days, such long, long nights, such aching
514	hearts and imploring prayers, when those who loved her best were forced
514	to see the thin hands stretched out to them beseechingly, to hear the
514	"bitter cry, ""Help me, help me!"" and to feel that there was no help.  A"
514	sad eclipse of the serene soul, a sharp struggle of the young life with
514	death, but both were mercifully brief, and then the natural rebellion
514	over, the old peace returned more beautiful than ever.  With the wreck
514	of her frail body, Beth's soul grew strong, and though she said little,
514	those about her felt that she was ready, saw that the first pilgrim
514	called was likewise the fittest, and waited with her on the shore,
514	trying to see the Shining Ones coming to receive her when she crossed
514	the river.
514	""
514	"Jo never left her for an hour since Beth had said ""I feel stronger when"
514	"you are here.""  She slept on a couch in the room, waking often to renew"
514	the fire, to feed, lift, or wait upon the patient creature who seldom
514	asked for anything, and 'tried not to be a trouble'.  All day she
514	haunted the room, jealous of any other nurse, and prouder of being
514	chosen then than of any honor her life ever brought her.  Precious and
514	helpful hours to Jo, for now her heart received the teaching that it
514	needed.  Lessons in patience were so sweetly taught her that she could
514	not fail to learn them, charity for all, the lovely spirit that can
514	forgive and truly forget unkindness, the loyalty to duty that makes the
514	hardest easy, and the sincere faith that fears nothing, but trusts
514	undoubtingly.
514	""
514	Often when she woke Jo found Beth reading in her well-worn little book,
514	heard her singing softly, to beguile the sleepless night, or saw her
514	lean her face upon her hands, while slow tears dropped through the
514	transparent fingers, and Jo would lie watching her with thoughts too
514	deep for tears, feeling that Beth, in her simple, unselfish way, was
514	trying to wean herself from the dear old life, and fit herself for the
514	life to come, by sacred words of comfort, quiet prayers, and the music
514	she loved so well.
514	""
514	Seeing this did more for Jo than the wisest sermons, the saintliest
514	hymns, the most fervent prayers that any voice could utter.  For with
514	eyes made clear by many tears, and a heart softened by the tenderest
514	sorrow, she recognized the beauty of her sister's life--uneventful,
514	unambitious, yet full of the genuine virtues which 'smell sweet, and
514	blossom in the dust', the self-forgetfulness that makes the humblest on
514	earth remembered soonest in heaven, the true success which is possible
514	to all.
514	""
514	One night when Beth looked among the books upon her table, to find
514	something to make her forget the mortal weariness that was almost as
514	hard to bear as pain, as she turned the leaves of her old favorite,
514	Pilgrims's Progress, she found a little paper, scribbled over in Jo's
514	hand.  The name caught her eye and the blurred look of the lines made
514	her sure that tears had fallen on it.
514	""
514	"""Poor Jo!  She's fast asleep, so I won't wake her to ask leave.  She"
514	shows me all her things, and I don't think she'll mind if I look at
514	"this"", thought Beth, with a glance at her sister, who lay on the rug,"
514	with the tongs beside her, ready to wake up the minute the log fell
514	apart.
514	""
514	    MY BETH
514	""
514	    Sitting patient in the shadow
514	    Till the blessed light shall come,
514	    A serene and saintly presence
514	    Sanctifies our troubled home.
514	    Earthly joys and hopes and sorrows
514	    Break like ripples on the strand
514	    Of the deep and solemn river
514	    Where her willing feet now stand.
514	""
514	    O my sister, passing from me,
514	    Out of human care and strife,
514	    Leave me, as a gift, those virtues
514	    Which have beautified your life.
514	    Dear, bequeath me that great patience
514	    Which has power to sustain
514	    A cheerful, uncomplaining spirit
514	    In its prison-house of pain.
514	""
514	    Give me, for I need it sorely,
514	    Of that courage, wise and sweet,
514	    Which has made the path of duty
514	    Green beneath your willing feet.
514	    Give me that unselfish nature,
514	    That with charity divine
514	    Can pardon wrong for love's dear sake--
514	    Meek heart, forgive me mine!
514	""
514	    Thus our parting daily loseth
514	    Something of its bitter pain,
514	    And while learning this hard lesson,
514	    My great loss becomes my gain.
514	    For the touch of grief will render
514	    My wild nature more serene,
514	    Give to life new aspirations,
514	    A new trust in the unseen.
514	""
514	    Henceforth, safe across the river,
514	    I shall see forever more
514	    A beloved, household spirit
514	    Waiting for me on the shore.
514	    Hope and faith, born of my sorrow,
514	    Guardian angels shall become,
514	    And the sister gone before me
514	    By their hands shall lead me home.
514	""
514	Blurred and blotted, faulty and feeble as the lines were, they brought
514	a look of inexpressible comfort to Beth's face, for her one regret had
514	been that she had done so little, and this seemed to assure her that
514	her life had not been useless, that her death would not bring the
514	despair she feared.  As she sat with the paper folded between her
514	hands, the charred log fell asunder.  Jo started up, revived the blaze,
514	and crept to the bedside, hoping Beth slept.
514	""
514	"""Not asleep, but so happy, dear.  See, I found this and read it. I knew"
514	"you wouldn't care.  Have I been all that to you, Jo?"" she asked, with"
514	wistful, humble earnestness.
514	""
514	"""_Oh_, Beth, so much, so much!"" and Jo's head went down upon the pillow"
514	beside her sister's.
514	""
514	"""Then I don't feel as if I'd wasted my life.  I'm not so good as you"
514	make me, but I have tried to do right.  And now, when it's too late to
514	begin even to do better, it's such a comfort to know that someone loves
514	"me so much, and feels as if I'd helped them."""
514	""
514	"""More than any one in the world, Beth.  I used to think I couldn't let"
514	you go, but I'm learning to feel that I don't lose you, that you'll be
514	"more to me than ever, and death can't part us, though it seems to."""
514	""
514	"""I know it cannot, and I don't fear it any longer, for I'm sure I shall"
514	be your Beth still, to love and help you more than ever.  You must take
514	my place, Jo, and be everything to Father and Mother when I'm gone.
514	They will turn to you, don't fail them, and if it's hard to work alone,
514	remember that I don't forget you, and that you'll be happier in doing
514	that than writing splendid books or seeing all the world, for love is
514	the only thing that we can carry with us when we go, and it makes the
514	"end so easy."""
514	""
514	"""I'll try, Beth."" and then and there Jo renounced her old ambition,"
514	pledged herself to a new and better one, acknowledging the poverty of
514	other desires, and feeling the blessed solace of a belief in the
514	immortality of love.
514	""
514	So the spring days came and went, the sky grew clearer, the earth
514	greener, the flowers were up fairly early, and the birds came back in
514	time to say goodbye to Beth, who, like a tired but trustful child,
514	clung to the hands that had led her all her life, as Father and Mother
514	guided her tenderly through the Valley of the Shadow, and gave her up
514	to God.
514	""
514	Seldom except in books do the dying utter memorable words, see visions,
514	or depart with beatified countenances, and those who have sped many
514	parting souls know that to most the end comes as naturally and simply
514	as sleep.  As Beth had hoped, the 'tide went out easily', and in the
514	dark hour before dawn, on the bosom where she had drawn her first
514	breath, she quietly drew her last, with no farewell but one loving
514	look, one little sigh.
514	""
514	With tears and prayers and tender hands, Mother and sisters made her
514	ready for the long sleep that pain would never mar again, seeing with
514	grateful eyes the beautiful serenity that soon replaced the pathetic
514	patience that had wrung their hearts so long, and feeling with reverent
514	joy that to their darling death was a benignant angel, not a phantom
514	full of dread.
514	""
514	When morning came, for the first time in many months the fire was out,
514	Jo's place was empty, and the room was very still.  But a bird sang
514	blithely on a budding bough, close by, the snowdrops blossomed freshly
514	at the window, and the spring sunshine streamed in like a benediction
514	over the placid face upon the pillow, a face so full of painless peace
514	that those who loved it best smiled through their tears, and thanked
514	God that Beth was well at last.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-ONE
514	""
514	LEARNING TO FORGET
514	""
514	Amy's lecture did Laurie good, though, of course, he did not own it
514	till long afterward.  Men seldom do, for when women are the advisers,
514	the lords of creation don't take the advice till they have persuaded
514	themselves that it is just what they intended to do.  Then they act
514	upon it, and, if it succeeds, they give the weaker vessel half the
514	credit of it.  If it fails, they generously give her the whole.  Laurie
514	went back to his grandfather, and was so dutifully devoted for several
514	weeks that the old gentleman declared the climate of Nice had improved
514	him wonderfully, and he had better try it again. There was nothing the
514	young gentleman would have liked better, but elephants could not have
514	dragged him back after the scolding he had received.  Pride forbid, and
514	whenever the longing grew very strong, he fortified his resolution by
514	"repeating the words that had made the deepest impression--""I despise"
514	"you."" ""Go and do something splendid that will make her love you."""
514	""
514	Laurie turned the matter over in his mind so often that he soon brought
514	himself to confess that he had been selfish and lazy, but then when a
514	man has a great sorrow, he should be indulged in all sorts of vagaries
514	till he has lived it down.  He felt that his blighted affections were
514	quite dead now, and though he should never cease to be a faithful
514	mourner, there was no occasion to wear his weeds ostentatiously.  Jo
514	wouldn't love him, but he might make her respect and admire him by
514	doing something which should prove that a girl's 'No' had not spoiled
514	his life.  He had always meant to do something, and Amy's advice was
514	quite unnecessary.  He had only been waiting till the aforesaid
514	blighted affections were decently interred. That being done, he felt
514	that he was ready to 'hide his stricken heart, and still toil on'.
514	""
514	As Goethe, when he had a joy or a grief, put it into a song, so Laurie
514	resolved to embalm his love sorrow in music, and to compose a Requiem
514	which should harrow up Jo's soul and melt the heart of every hearer.
514	Therefore the next time the old gentleman found him getting restless
514	and moody and ordered him off, he went to Vienna, where he had musical
514	friends, and fell to work with the firm determination to distinguish
514	himself.  But whether the sorrow was too vast to be embodied in music,
514	or music too ethereal to uplift a mortal woe, he soon discovered that
514	the Requiem was beyond him just at present.  It was evident that his
514	mind was not in working order yet, and his ideas needed clarifying, for
514	often in the middle of a plaintive strain, he would find himself
514	humming a dancing tune that vividly recalled the Christmas ball at
514	Nice, especially the stout Frenchman, and put an effectual stop to
514	tragic composition for the time being.
514	""
514	Then he tried an opera, for nothing seemed impossible in the beginning,
514	but here again unforeseen difficulties beset him.  He wanted Jo for his
514	heroine, and called upon his memory to supply him with tender
514	recollections and romantic visions of his love.  But memory turned
514	traitor, and as if possessed by the perverse spirit of the girl, would
514	only recall Jo's oddities, faults, and freaks, would only show her in
514	the most unsentimental aspects--beating mats with her head tied up in a
514	bandanna, barricading herself with the sofa pillow, or throwing cold
514	water over his passion a la Gummidge--and an irresistable laugh spoiled
514	the pensive picture he was endeavoring to paint.  Jo wouldn't be put
514	"into the opera at any price, and he had to give her up with a ""Bless"
514	"that girl, what a torment she is!"" and a clutch at his hair, as became"
514	a distracted composer.
514	""
514	When he looked about him for another and a less intractable damsel to
514	immortalize in melody, memory produced one with the most obliging
514	readiness.  This phantom wore many faces, but it always had golden
514	hair, was enveloped in a diaphanous cloud, and floated airily before
514	his mind's eye in a pleasing chaos of roses, peacocks, white ponies,
514	and blue ribbons.  He did not give the complacent wraith any name, but
514	he took her for his heroine and grew quite fond of her, as well he
514	might, for he gifted her with every gift and grace under the sun, and
514	escorted her, unscathed, through trials which would have annihilated
514	any mortal woman.
514	""
514	Thanks to this inspiration, he got on swimmingly for a time, but
514	gradually the work lost its charm, and he forgot to compose, while he
514	sat musing, pen in hand, or roamed about the gay city to get some new
514	ideas and refresh his mind, which seemed to be in a somewhat unsettled
514	state that winter.  He did not do much, but he thought a great deal and
514	was conscious of a change of some sort going on in spite of himself.
514	"""It's genius simmering, perhaps.  I'll let it simmer, and see what"
514	"comes of it,"" he said, with a secret suspicion all the while that it"
514	wasn't genius, but something far more common.  Whatever it was, it
514	simmered to some purpose, for he grew more and more discontented with
514	his desultory life, began to long for some real and earnest work to go
514	at, soul and body, and finally came to the wise conclusion that
514	everyone who loved music was not a composer.  Returning from one of
514	Mozart's grand operas, splendidly performed at the Royal Theatre, he
514	looked over his own, played a few of the best parts, sat staring at the
514	busts of Mendelssohn, Beethoven, and Bach, who stared benignly back
514	again.  Then suddenly he tore up his music sheets, one by one, and as
514	the last fluttered out of his hand, he said soberly to himself...
514	""
514	"""She is right!  Talent isn't genius, and you can't make it so.  That"
514	music has taken the vanity out of me as Rome took it out of her, and I
514	"won't be a humbug any longer.  Now what shall I do?"""
514	""
514	That seemed a hard question to answer, and Laurie began to wish he had
514	to work for his daily bread.  Now if ever, occurred an eligible
514	opportunity for 'going to the devil', as he once forcibly expressed it,
514	for he had plenty of money and nothing to do, and Satan is proverbially
514	fond of providing employment for full and idle hands.  The poor fellow
514	had temptations enough from without and from within, but he withstood
514	them pretty well, for much as he valued liberty, he valued good faith
514	and confidence more, so his promise to his grandfather, and his desire
514	to be able to look honestly into the eyes of the women who loved him,
514	"and say ""All's well,"" kept him safe and steady."
514	""
514	"Very likely some Mrs. Grundy will observe, ""I don't believe it, boys"
514	will be boys, young men must sow their wild oats, and women must not
514	"expect miracles.""  I dare say you don't, Mrs. Grundy, but it's true"
514	nevertheless.  Women work a good many miracles, and I have a persuasion
514	that they may perform even that of raising the standard of manhood by
514	refusing to echo such sayings.  Let the boys be boys, the longer the
514	better, and let the young men sow their wild oats if they must.  But
514	mothers, sisters, and friends may help to make the crop a small one,
514	and keep many tares from spoiling the harvest, by believing, and
514	showing that they believe, in the possibility of loyalty to the virtues
514	which make men manliest in good women's eyes.  If it is a feminine
514	delusion, leave us to enjoy it while we may, for without it half the
514	beauty and the romance of life is lost, and sorrowful forebodings would
514	embitter all our hopes of the brave, tenderhearted little lads, who
514	still love their mothers better than themselves and are not ashamed to
514	own it.
514	""
514	Laurie thought that the task of forgetting his love for Jo would absorb
514	all his powers for years, but to his great surprise he discovered it
514	grew easier every day.  He refused to believe it at first, got angry
514	with himself, and couldn't understand it, but these hearts of ours are
514	curious and contrary things, and time and nature work their will in
514	spite of us.  Laurie's heart wouldn't ache.  The wound persisted in
514	healing with a rapidity that astonished him, and instead of trying to
514	forget, he found himself trying to remember.  He had not foreseen this
514	turn of affairs, and was not prepared for it.  He was disgusted with
514	himself, surprised at his own fickleness, and full of a queer mixture
514	of disappointment and relief that he could recover from such a
514	tremendous blow so soon.  He carefully stirred up the embers of his
514	lost love, but they refused to burst into a blaze.  There was only a
514	comfortable glow that warmed and did him good without putting him into
514	a fever, and he was reluctantly obliged to confess that the boyish
514	passion was slowly subsiding into a more tranquil sentiment, very
514	tender, a little sad and resentful still, but that was sure to pass
514	away in time, leaving a brotherly affection which would last unbroken
514	to the end.
514	""
514	As the word 'brotherly' passed through his mind in one of his reveries,
514	he smiled, and glanced up at the picture of Mozart that was before
514	him...
514	""
514	"""Well, he was a great man, and when he couldn't have one sister he took"
514	"the other, and was happy."""
514	""
514	Laurie did not utter the words, but he thought them, and the next
514	"instant kissed the little old ring, saying to himself, ""No, I won't!  I"
514	haven't forgotten, I never can.  I'll try again, and if that fails, why
514	"then..."""
514	""
514	Leaving his sentence unfinished, he seized pen and paper and wrote to
514	Jo, telling her that he could not settle to anything while there was
514	the least hope of her changing her mind. Couldn't she, wouldn't
514	she--and let him come home and be happy? While waiting for an answer he
514	did nothing, but he did it energetically, for he was in a fever of
514	impatience.  It came at last, and settled his mind effectually on one
514	point, for Jo decidedly couldn't and wouldn't.  She was wrapped up in
514	Beth, and never wished to hear the word love again.  Then she begged
514	him to be happy with somebody else, but always keep a little corner of
514	his heart for his loving sister Jo.  In a postscript she desired him
514	not to tell Amy that Beth was worse, she was coming home in the spring
514	and there was no need of saddening the remainder of her stay.  That
514	would be time enough, please God, but Laurie must write to her often,
514	and not let her feel lonely, homesick or anxious.
514	""
514	"""So I will, at once.  Poor little girl, it will be a sad going home for"
514	"her, I'm afraid,"" and Laurie opened his desk, as if writing to Amy had"
514	been the proper conclusion of the sentence left unfinished some weeks
514	before.
514	""
514	But he did not write the letter that day, for as he rummaged out his
514	best paper, he came across something which changed his purpose.
514	Tumbling about in one part of the desk among bills, passports, and
514	business documents of various kinds were several of Jo's letters, and
514	in another compartment were three notes from Amy, carefully tied up
514	with one of her blue ribbons and sweetly suggestive of the little dead
514	roses put away inside.  With a half-repentant, half-amused expression,
514	Laurie gathered up all Jo's letters, smoothed, folded, and put them
514	neatly into a small drawer of the desk, stood a minute turning the ring
514	thoughtfully on his finger, then slowly drew it off, laid it with the
514	letters, locked the drawer, and went out to hear High Mass at Saint
514	Stefan's, feeling as if there had been a funeral, and though not
514	overwhelmed with affliction, this seemed a more proper way to spend the
514	rest of the day than in writing letters to charming young ladies.
514	""
514	The letter went very soon, however, and was promptly answered, for Amy
514	was homesick, and confessed it in the most delightfully confiding
514	manner.  The correspondence flourished famously, and letters flew to
514	and fro with unfailing regularity all through the early spring.  Laurie
514	sold his busts, made allumettes of his opera, and went back to Paris,
514	hoping somebody would arrive before long.  He wanted desperately to go
514	to Nice, but would not till he was asked, and Amy would not ask him,
514	for just then she was having little experiences of her own, which made
514	her rather wish to avoid the quizzical eyes of 'our boy'.
514	""
514	Fred Vaughn had returned, and put the question to which she had once
514	"decided to answer, ""Yes, thank you,"" but now she said, ""No, thank you,"""
514	kindly but steadily, for when the time came, her courage failed her,
514	and she found that something more than money and position was needed to
514	satisfy the new longing that filled her heart so full of tender hopes
514	"and fears.  The words, ""Fred is a good fellow, but not at all the man I"
514	"fancied you would ever like,"" and Laurie's face when he uttered them,"
514	kept returning to her as pertinaciously as her own did when she said in
514	"look, if not in words, ""I shall marry for money.""  It troubled her to"
514	remember that now, she wished she could take it back, it sounded so
514	unwomanly. She didn't want Laurie to think her a heartless,  worldly
514	creature.  She didn't care to be a queen of society now half so much as
514	she did to be a lovable woman.  She was so glad he didn't hate her for
514	the dreadful things she said, but took them so beautifully and was
514	kinder than ever.  His letters were such a comfort, for the home
514	letters were very irregular and not half so satisfactory as his when
514	they did come.  It was not only a pleasure, but a duty to answer them,
514	for the poor fellow was forlorn, and needed petting, since Jo persisted
514	in being stonyhearted.  She ought to have made an effort and tried to
514	love him.  It couldn't be very hard, many people would be proud and
514	glad to have such a dear boy care for them.  But Jo never would act
514	like other girls, so there was nothing to do but be very kind and treat
514	him like a brother.
514	""
514	If all brothers were treated as well as Laurie was at this period, they
514	would be a much happier race of beings than they are.  Amy never
514	lectured now.  She asked his opinion on all subjects, she was
514	interested in everything he did, made charming little presents for him,
514	and sent him two letters a week, full of lively gossip, sisterly
514	confidences, and captivating sketches of the lovely scenes about her.
514	As few brothers are complimented by having their letters carried about
514	in their sister's pockets, read and reread diligently, cried over when
514	short, kissed when long, and treasured carefully, we will not hint that
514	Amy did any of these fond and foolish things.  But she certainly did
514	grow a little pale and pensive that spring, lost much of her relish for
514	society, and went out sketching alone a good deal.  She never had much
514	to show when she came home, but was studying nature, I dare say, while
514	she sat for hours, with her hands folded, on the terrace at Valrosa, or
514	absently sketched any fancy that occurred to her, a stalwart knight
514	carved on a tomb, a young man asleep in the grass, with his hat over
514	his eyes, or a curly haired girl in gorgeous array, promenading down a
514	ballroom on the arm of a tall gentleman, both faces being left a blur
514	according to the last fashion in art, which was safe but not altogether
514	satisfactory.
514	""
514	Her aunt thought that she regretted her answer to Fred, and finding
514	denials useless and explanations impossible, Amy left her to think what
514	she liked, taking care that Laurie should know that Fred had gone to
514	Egypt.  That was all, but he understood it, and looked relieved, as he
514	said to himself, with a venerable air...
514	""
514	"""I was sure she would think better of it.  Poor old fellow! I've been"
514	"through it all, and I can sympathize."""
514	""
514	With that he heaved a great sigh, and then, as if he had discharged his
514	duty to the past, put his feet up on the sofa and enjoyed Amy's letter
514	luxuriously.
514	""
514	While these changes were going on abroad, trouble had come at home.
514	But the letter telling that Beth was failing never reached Amy, and
514	when they next found her the grass was green above her sister. The sad
514	news met her at at Vevay, for the heat had driven them from Nice in
514	May, and they had travelled slowly to Switzerland, by way of Genoa and
514	the Italian lakes.  She bore it very well, and quietly submitted to
514	the family decree that she should not shorten her visit, for since it
514	was too late to say goodbye to Beth, she had better stay, and let
514	absence soften her sorrow.  But her heart was very heavy, she longed
514	to be at home, and every day looked wistfully across the lake, waiting
514	for Laurie to come and comfort her.
514	""
514	He did come very soon, for the same mail brought letters to them both,
514	but he was in Germany, and it took some days to reach him.  The moment
514	he read it, he packed his knapsack, bade adieu to his fellow
514	pedestrians, and was off to keep his promise, with a heart full of joy
514	and sorrow, hope and suspense.
514	""
514	He knew Vevay well, and as soon as the boat touched the little quay, he
514	hurried along the shore to La Tour, where the Carrols were living en
514	pension.  The garcon was in despair that the whole family had gone to
514	take a promenade on the lake, but no, the blonde mademoiselle might be
514	in the chateau garden.  If monsieur would give himself the pain of
514	sitting down, a flash of time should present her.  But monsieur could
514	not wait even a 'flash of time', and in the middle of the speech
514	departed to find mademoiselle himself.
514	""
514	A pleasant old garden on the borders of the lovely lake, with chestnuts
514	rustling overhead, ivy climbing everywhere, and the black shadow of the
514	tower falling far across the sunny water.  At one corner of the wide,
514	low wall was a seat, and here Amy often came to read or work, or
514	console herself with the beauty all about her.  She was sitting here
514	that day, leaning her head on her hand, with a homesick heart and heavy
514	eyes, thinking of Beth and wondering why Laurie did not come.  She did
514	not hear him cross the courtyard beyond, nor see him pause in the
514	archway that led from the subterranean path into the garden.  He stood
514	a minute looking at her with new eyes, seeing what no one had ever seen
514	before, the tender side of Amy's character. Everything about her mutely
514	suggested love and sorrow, the blotted letters in her lap, the black
514	ribbon that tied up her hair, the womanly pain and patience in her
514	face, even the little ebony cross at her throat seemed pathetic to
514	Laurie, for he had given it to her, and she wore it as her only
514	ornament. If he had any doubts about the reception she would give him,
514	they were set at rest the minute she looked up and saw him, for
514	dropping everything, she ran to him, exclaiming in a tone of
514	unmistakable love and longing...
514	""
514	"""Oh, Laurie, Laurie, I knew you'd come to me!"""
514	""
514	I think everything was said and settled then, for as they stood
514	together quite silent for a moment, with the dark head bent down
514	protectingly over the light one, Amy felt that no one could comfort and
514	sustain her so well as Laurie, and Laurie decided that Amy was the only
514	woman in the world who could fill Jo's place and make him happy.  He
514	did not tell her so, but she was not disappointed, for both felt the
514	truth, were satisfied, and gladly left the rest to silence.
514	""
514	In a minute Amy went back to her place, and while she dried her tears,
514	Laurie gathered up the scattered papers, finding in the sight of sundry
514	well-worn letters and suggestive sketches good omens for the future.
514	As he sat down beside her, Amy felt shy again, and turned rosy red at
514	the recollection of her impulsive greeting.
514	""
514	"""I couldn't help it, I felt so lonely and sad, and was so very glad to"
514	see you.  It was such a surprise to look up and find you, just as I was
514	"beginning to fear you wouldn't come,"" she said, trying in vain to speak"
514	quite naturally.
514	""
514	"""I came the minute I heard.  I wish I could say something to comfort"
514	"you for the loss of dear little Beth, but I can only feel, and...""  He"
514	could not get any further, for he too turned bashful all of a sudden,
514	and did not quite know what to say.  He longed to lay Amy's head down
514	on his shoulder, and tell her to have a good cry, but he did not dare,
514	so took her hand instead, and gave it a sympathetic squeeze that was
514	better than words.
514	""
514	"""You needn't say anything, this comforts me,"" she said softly.  ""Beth"
514	is well and happy, and I mustn't wish her back, but I dread the going
514	home, much as I long to see them all. We won't talk about it now, for
514	it makes me cry, and I want to enjoy you while you stay.  You needn't
514	"go right back, need you?"""
514	""
514	"""Not if you want me, dear."""
514	""
514	"""I do, so much.  Aunt and Flo are very kind, but you seem like one of"
514	the family, and it would be so comfortable to have you for a little
514	"while."""
514	""
514	Amy spoke and looked so like a homesick child whose heart was full that
514	Laurie forgot his bashfulness all at once, and gave her just what she
514	wanted--the petting she was used to and the cheerful conversation she
514	needed.
514	""
514	"""Poor little soul, you look as if you'd grieved yourself half sick!"
514	I'm going to take care of you, so don't cry any more, but come and walk
514	"about with me, the wind is too chilly for you to sit still,"" he said,"
514	in the half-caressing, half-commanding way that Amy liked, as he tied
514	on her hat, drew her arm through his, and began to pace up and down the
514	sunny walk under the new-leaved chestnuts.  He felt more at ease upon
514	his legs, and Amy found it pleasant to have a strong arm to lean upon,
514	a familiar face to smile at her, and a kind voice to talk delightfully
514	for her alone.
514	""
514	The quaint old garden had sheltered many pairs of lovers, and seemed
514	expressly made for them, so sunny and secluded was it, with nothing but
514	the tower to overlook them, and the wide lake to carry away the echo of
514	their words, as it rippled by below.  For an hour this new pair walked
514	and talked, or rested on the wall, enjoying the sweet influences which
514	gave such a charm to time and place, and when an unromantic dinner bell
514	warned them away, Amy felt as if she left her burden of loneliness and
514	sorrow behind her in the chateau garden.
514	""
514	The moment Mrs. Carrol saw the girl's altered face, she was illuminated
514	"with a new idea, and exclaimed to herself, ""Now I understand it"
514	all--the child has been pining for young Laurence.  Bless my heart, I
514	"never thought of such a thing!"""
514	""
514	With praiseworthy discretion, the good lady said nothing, and betrayed
514	no sign of enlightenment, but cordially urged Laurie to stay and begged
514	Amy to enjoy his society, for it would do her more good than so much
514	solitude.  Amy was a model of docility, and as her aunt was a good deal
514	occupied with Flo, she was left to entertain her friend, and did it
514	with more than her usual success.
514	""
514	At Nice, Laurie had lounged and Amy had scolded.  At Vevay, Laurie was
514	never idle, but always walking, riding, boating, or studying in the
514	most energetic manner, while Amy admired everything he did and followed
514	his example as far and as fast as she could.  He said the change was
514	owing to the climate, and she did not contradict him, being glad of a
514	like excuse for her own recovered health and spirits.
514	""
514	The invigorating air did them both good, and much exercise worked
514	wholesome changes in minds as well as bodies. They seemed to get
514	clearer views of life and duty up there among the everlasting hills.
514	The fresh winds blew away desponding doubts, delusive fancies, and
514	moody mists.  The warm spring sunshine brought out all sorts of
514	aspiring ideas, tender hopes, and happy thoughts.  The lake seemed to
514	wash away the troubles of the past, and the grand old mountains to look
514	"benignly down upon them saying, ""Little children, love one another."""
514	""
514	In spite of the new sorrow, it was a very happy time, so happy that
514	Laurie could not bear to disturb it by a word.  It took him a little
514	while to recover from his surprise at the cure of his first, and as he
514	had firmly believed, his last and only love.  He consoled himself for
514	the seeming disloyalty by the thought that Jo's sister was almost the
514	same as Jo's self, and the conviction that it would have been
514	impossible to love any other woman but Amy so soon and so well.  His
514	first wooing had been of the tempestuous order, and he looked back upon
514	it as if through a long vista of years with a feeling of compassion
514	blended with regret.  He was not ashamed of it, but put it away as one
514	of the bitter-sweet experiences of his life, for which he could be
514	grateful when the pain was over. His second wooing, he resolved, should
514	be as calm and simple as possible.  There was no need of having a
514	scene, hardly any need of telling Amy that he loved her, she knew it
514	without words and had given him his answer long ago.  It all came about
514	so naturally that no one could complain, and he knew that everybody
514	would be pleased, even Jo.  But when our first little passion has been
514	crushed, we are apt to be wary and slow in making a second trial, so
514	Laurie let the days pass, enjoying every hour, and leaving to chance
514	the utterance of the word that would put an end to the first and
514	sweetest part of his new romance.
514	""
514	He had rather imagined that the denoument would take place in the
514	chateau garden by moonlight, and in the most graceful and decorous
514	manner, but it turned out exactly the reverse, for the matter was
514	settled on the lake at noonday in a few blunt words. They had been
514	floating about all the morning, from gloomy St.  Gingolf to sunny
514	Montreux, with the Alps of Savoy on one side, Mont St.  Bernard and the
514	Dent du Midi on the other, pretty Vevay in the valley, and Lausanne
514	upon the hill beyond, a cloudless blue sky overhead, and the bluer lake
514	below, dotted with the picturesque boats that look like white-winged
514	gulls.
514	""
514	They had been talking of Bonnivard, as they glided past Chillon, and of
514	Rousseau, as they looked up at Clarens, where he wrote his Heloise.
514	Neither had read it, but they knew it was a love story, and each
514	privately wondered if it was half as interesting as their own.  Amy had
514	been dabbling her hand in the water during the little pause that fell
514	between them, and when she looked up, Laurie was leaning on his oars
514	with an expression in his eyes that made her say hastily, merely for
514	the sake of saying something...
514	""
514	"""You must be tired.  Rest a little, and let me row.  It will do me"
514	"good, for since you came I have been altogether lazy and luxurious."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not tired, but you may take an oar, if you like.  There's room"
514	enough, though I have to sit nearly in the middle, else the boat won't
514	"trim,"" returned Laurie, as if he rather liked the arrangement."
514	""
514	Feeling that she had not mended matters much, Amy took the offered
514	third of a seat, shook her hair over her face, and accepted an oar.
514	She rowed as well as she did many other things, and though she used
514	both hands, and Laurie but one, the oars kept time, and the boat went
514	smoothly through the water.
514	""
514	"""How well we pull together, don't we?"" said Amy, who objected to"
514	silence just then.
514	""
514	"""So well that I wish we might always pull in the same boat. Will you,"
514	"Amy?"" very tenderly."
514	""
514	"""Yes, Laurie,"" very low."
514	""
514	Then they both stopped rowing, and unconsciously added a pretty little
514	tableau of human love and happiness to the dissolving views reflected
514	in the lake.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-TWO
514	""
514	ALL ALONE
514	""
514	It was easy to promise self-abnegation when self was wrapped up in
514	another, and heart and soul were purified by a sweet example.  But when
514	the helpful voice was silent, the daily lesson over, the beloved
514	presence gone, and nothing remained but loneliness and grief, then Jo
514	found her promise very hard to keep.  How could she 'comfort Father and
514	Mother' when her own heart ached with a ceaseless longing for her
514	sister, how could she 'make the house cheerful' when all its light and
514	warmth and beauty seemed to have deserted it when Beth left the old
514	home for the new, and where in all the world could she 'find some
514	useful, happy work to do', that would take the place of the loving
514	service which had been its own reward?  She tried in a blind, hopeless
514	way to do her duty, secretly rebelling against it all the while, for it
514	seemed unjust that her few joys should be lessened, her burdens made
514	heavier, and life get harder and harder as she toiled along.  Some
514	people seemed to get all sunshine, and some all shadow.  It was not
514	fair, for she tried more than Amy to be good, but never got any reward,
514	only disappointment, trouble and hard work.
514	""
514	Poor Jo, these were dark days to her, for something like despair came
514	over her when she thought of spending all her life in that quiet house,
514	devoted to humdrum cares, a few small pleasures, and the duty that
514	"never seemed to grow any easier.  ""I can't do it. I wasn't meant for a"
514	life like this, and I know I shall break away and do something
514	"desperate if somebody doesn't come and help me,"" she said to herself,"
514	when her first efforts failed and she fell into the moody, miserable
514	state of mind which often comes when strong wills have to yield to the
514	inevitable.
514	""
514	But someone did come and help her, though Jo did not recognize her good
514	angels at once because they wore familiar shapes and used the simple
514	spells best fitted to poor humanity.  Often she started up at night,
514	thinking Beth called her, and when the sight of the little empty bed
514	"made her cry with the bitter cry of unsubmissive sorrow, ""Oh, Beth,"
514	"come back!  Come back!"" she did not stretch out her yearning arms in"
514	vain.  For, as quick to hear her sobbing as she had been to hear her
514	sister's faintest whisper, her mother came to comfort her, not with
514	words only, but the patient tenderness that soothes by a touch, tears
514	that were mute reminders of a greater grief than Jo's, and broken
514	whispers, more eloquent than prayers, because hopeful resignation went
514	hand-in-hand with natural sorrow. Sacred moments, when heart talked to
514	heart in the silence of the night, turning affliction to a blessing,
514	which chastened grief and strengthened love.  Feeling this, Jo's burden
514	seemed easier to bear, duty grew sweeter, and life looked more
514	endurable, seen from the safe shelter of her mother's arms.
514	""
514	When aching heart was a little comforted, troubled mind likewise found
514	help, for one day she went to the study, and leaning over the good gray
514	head lifted to welcome her with a tranquil smile, she said very humbly,
514	"""Father, talk to me as you did to Beth.  I need it more than she did,"
514	"for I'm all wrong."""
514	""
514	"""My dear, nothing can comfort me like this,"" he answered, with a falter"
514	in his voice, and both arms round her, as if he too, needed help, and
514	did not fear to ask for it.
514	""
514	Then, sitting in Beth's little chair close beside him, Jo told her
514	troubles, the resentful sorrow for her loss, the fruitless efforts that
514	discouraged her, the want of faith that made life look so dark, and all
514	the sad bewilderment which we call despair.  She gave him entire
514	confidence, he gave her the help she needed, and both found consolation
514	in the act.  For the time had come when they could talk together not
514	only as father and daughter, but as man and woman, able and glad to
514	serve each other with mutual sympathy as well as mutual love.  Happy,
514	thoughtful times there in the old study which Jo called 'the church of
514	one member', and from which she came with fresh courage, recovered
514	cheerfulness, and a more submissive spirit. For the parents who had
514	taught one child to meet death without fear, were trying now to teach
514	another to accept life without despondency or distrust, and to use its
514	beautiful opportunities with gratitude and power.
514	""
514	Other helps had Jo--humble, wholesome duties and delights that would
514	not be denied their part in serving her, and which she slowly learned
514	to see and value.  Brooms and dishcloths never could be as distasteful
514	as they once had been, for Beth had presided over both, and something
514	of her housewifely spirit seemed to linger around the little mop and
514	the old brush, never thrown away.  As she used them, Jo found herself
514	humming the songs Beth used to hum, imitating Beth's orderly ways, and
514	giving the little touches here and there that kept everything fresh and
514	cozy, which was the first step toward making home happy, though she
514	didn't know it till Hannah said with an approving squeeze of the hand...
514	""
514	"""You thoughtful creeter, you're determined we shan't miss that dear"
514	lamb ef you can help it.  We don't say much, but we see it, and the
514	"Lord will bless you for't, see ef He don't."""
514	""
514	As they sat sewing together, Jo discovered how much improved her sister
514	Meg was, how well she could talk, how much she knew about good, womanly
514	impulses, thoughts, and feelings, how happy she was in husband and
514	children, and how much they were all doing for each other.
514	""
514	"""Marriage is an excellent thing, after all.  I wonder if I should"
514	blossom out half as well as you have, if I tried it?, always
514	"_'perwisin'_ I could,"" said Jo, as she constructed a kite for Demi in"
514	the topsy-turvy nursery.
514	""
514	"""It's just what you need to bring out the tender womanly half of your"
514	nature, Jo.  You are like a chestnut burr, prickly outside, but
514	silky-soft within, and a sweet kernal, if one can only get at it.  Love
514	will make you show your heart one day, and then the rough burr will
514	"fall off."""
514	""
514	"""Frost opens chestnut burrs, ma'am, and it takes a good shake to bring"
514	"them down.  Boys go nutting, and I don't care to be bagged by them,"""
514	returned Jo, pasting away at the kite which no wind that blows would
514	ever carry up, for Daisy had tied herself on as a bob.
514	""
514	Meg laughed, for she was glad to see a glimmer of Jo's old spirit, but
514	she felt it her duty to enforce her opinion by every argument in her
514	power, and the sisterly chats were not wasted, especially as two of
514	Meg's most effective arguments were the babies, whom Jo loved tenderly.
514	Grief is the best opener of some hearts, and Jo's was nearly ready for
514	the bag.  A little more sunshine to ripen the nut, then, not a boy's
514	impatient shake, but a man's hand reached up to pick it gently from the
514	burr, and find the kernal sound and sweet. If she suspected this, she
514	would have shut up tight, and been more prickly than ever, fortunately
514	she wasn't thinking about herself, so when the time came, down she
514	dropped.
514	""
514	Now, if she had been the heroine of a moral storybook, she ought at
514	this period of her life to have become quite saintly, renounced the
514	world, and gone about doing good in a mortified bonnet, with tracts in
514	her pocket.  But, you see, Jo wasn't a heroine, she was only a
514	struggling human girl like hundreds of others, and she just acted out
514	her nature, being sad, cross, listless, or energetic, as the mood
514	suggested.  It's highly virtuous to say we'll be good, but we can't do
514	it all at once, and it takes a long pull, a strong pull, and a pull all
514	together before some of us even get our feet set in the right way.  Jo
514	had got so far, she was learning to do her duty, and to feel unhappy if
514	she did not, but to do it cheerfully, ah, that was another thing!  She
514	had often said she wanted to do something splendid, no matter how hard,
514	and now she had her wish, for what could be more beautiful than to
514	devote her life to Father and Mother, trying to make home as happy to
514	them as they had to her?  And if difficulties were necessary to
514	increase the splendor of the effort, what could be harder for a
514	restless, ambitious girl than to give up her own hopes, plans, and
