514	desires, and cheerfully live for others?
514	""
514	Providence had taken her at her word.  Here was the task, not what she
514	had expected, but better because self had no part in it. Now, could she
514	do it?  She decided that she would try, and in her first attempt she
514	found the helps I have suggested.  Still another was given her, and she
514	took it, not as a reward, but as a comfort, as Christian took the
514	refreshment afforded by the little arbor where he rested, as he climbed
514	the hill called Difficulty.
514	""
514	"""Why don't you write?  That always used to make you happy,"" said her"
514	mother once, when the desponding fit over-shadowed Jo.
514	""
514	"""I've no heart to write, and if I had, nobody cares for my things."""
514	""
514	"""We do.  Write something for us, and never mind the rest of the world."
514	"Try it, dear.  I'm sure it would do you good, and please us very much."""
514	""
514	"""Don't believe I can.""  But Jo got out her desk and began to overhaul"
514	her half-finished manuscripts.
514	""
514	An hour afterward her mother peeped in and there she was, scratching
514	away, with her black pinafore on, and an absorbed expression, which
514	caused Mrs. March to smile and slip away, well pleased with the success
514	of her suggestion.  Jo never knew how it happened, but something got
514	into that story that went straight to the hearts of those who read it,
514	for when her family had laughed and cried over it, her father sent it,
514	much against her will, to one of the popular magazines, and to her
514	utter surprise, it was not only paid for, but others requested.
514	Letters from several persons, whose praise was honor, followed the
514	appearance of the little story, newspapers copied it, and strangers as
514	well as friends admired it.  For a small thing it was a great success,
514	and Jo was more astonished than when her novel was commended and
514	condemned all at once.
514	""
514	"""I don't understand it.  What can there be in a simple little story"
514	"like that to make people praise it so?"" she said, quite bewildered."
514	""
514	"""There is truth in it, Jo, that's the secret.  Humor and pathos make it"
514	alive, and you have found your style at last.  You wrote with no
514	thoughts of fame and money, and put your heart into it, my daughter.
514	You have had the bitter, now comes the sweet.  Do your best, and grow
514	"as happy as we are in your success."""
514	""
514	"""If there is anything good or true in what I write, it isn't mine.  I"
514	"owe it all to you and Mother and Beth,"" said Jo, more touched by her"
514	father's words than by any amount of praise from the world.
514	""
514	So taught by love and sorrow, Jo wrote her little stories, and sent
514	them away to make friends for themselves and her, finding it a very
514	charitable world to such humble wanderers, for they were kindly
514	welcomed, and sent home comfortable tokens to their mother, like
514	dutiful children whom good fortune overtakes.
514	""
514	When Amy and Laurie wrote of their engagement, Mrs. March feared that
514	Jo would find it difficult to rejoice over it, but her fears were soon
514	set at rest, for though Jo looked grave at first, she took it very
514	quietly, and was full of hopes and plans for 'the children' before she
514	read the letter twice.  It was a sort of written duet, wherein each
514	glorified the other in loverlike fashion, very pleasant to read and
514	satisfactory to think of, for no one had any objection to make.
514	""
514	"""You like it, Mother?"" said Jo, as they laid down the closely written"
514	sheets and looked at one another.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I hoped it would be so, ever since Amy wrote that she had refused"
514	Fred.  I felt sure then that something better than what you call the
514	'mercenary spirit' had come over her, and a hint here and there in her
514	"letters made me suspect that love and Laurie would win the day."""
514	""
514	"""How sharp you are, Marmee, and how silent!  You never said a word to"
514	"me."""
514	""
514	"""Mothers have need of sharp eyes and discreet tongues when they have"
514	girls to manage.  I was half afraid to put the idea into your head,
514	lest you should write and congratulate them before the thing was
514	"settled."""
514	""
514	"""I'm not the scatterbrain I was.  You may trust me.  I'm sober and"
514	"sensible enough for anyone's confidante now."""
514	""
514	"""So you are, my dear, and I should have made you mine, only I fancied"
514	"it might pain you to learn that your Teddy loved someone else."""
514	""
514	"""Now, Mother, did you really think I could be so silly and selfish,"
514	"after I'd refused his love, when it was freshest, if not best?"""
514	""
514	"""I knew you were sincere then, Jo, but lately I have thought that if he"
514	came back, and asked again, you might perhaps, feel like giving another
514	answer.  Forgive me, dear, I can't help seeing that you are very
514	lonely, and sometimes there is a hungry look in your eyes that goes to
514	my heart.  So I fancied that your boy might fill the empty place if he
514	"tried now."""
514	""
514	"""No, Mother, it is better as it is, and I'm glad Amy has learned to"
514	love him.  But you are right in one thing.  I am lonely, and perhaps if
514	Teddy had tried again, I might have said 'Yes', not because I love him
514	"any more, but because I care more to be loved than when he went away."""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad of that, Jo, for it shows that you are getting on. There are"
514	plenty to love you, so try to be satisfied with Father and Mother,
514	sisters and brothers, friends and babies, till the best lover of all
514	"comes to give you your reward."""
514	""
514	"""Mothers are the best lovers in the world, but I don't mind whispering"
514	to Marmee that I'd like to try all kinds.  It's very curious, but the
514	more I try to satisfy myself with all sorts of natural affections, the
514	more I seem to want.  I'd no idea hearts could take in so many.  Mine
514	is so elastic, it never seems full now, and I used to be quite
514	"contented with my family.  I don't understand it."""
514	""
514	"""I do,"" and Mrs. March smiled her wise smile, as Jo turned back the"
514	leaves to read what Amy said of Laurie.
514	""
514	"""It is so beautiful to be loved as Laurie loves me.  He isn't"
514	sentimental, doesn't say much about it, but I see and feel it in all he
514	says and does, and it makes me so happy and so humble that I don't seem
514	to be the same girl I was.  I never knew how good and generous and
514	tender he was till now, for he lets me read his heart, and I find it
514	full of noble impulses and hopes and purposes, and am so proud to know
514	it's mine.  He says he feels as if he 'could make a prosperous voyage
514	now with me aboard as mate, and lots of love for ballast'.  I pray he
514	may, and try to be all he believes me, for I love my gallant captain
514	with all my heart and soul and might, and never will desert him, while
514	God lets us be together. Oh, Mother, I never knew how much like heaven
514	"this world could be, when two people love and live for one another!"""
514	""
514	"""And that's our cool, reserved, and worldly Amy!  Truly, love does work"
514	"miracles.  How very, very happy they must be!"" and Jo laid the rustling"
514	sheets together with a careful hand, as one might shut the covers of a
514	lovely romance, which holds the reader fast till the end comes, and he
514	finds himself alone in the workaday world again.
514	""
514	By-and-by Jo roamed away upstairs, for it was rainy, and she could not
514	walk.  A restless spirit possessed her, and the old feeling came again,
514	not bitter as it once was, but a sorrowfully patient wonder why one
514	sister should have all she asked, the other nothing.  It was not true,
514	she knew that and tried to put it away, but the natural craving for
514	affection was strong, and Amy's happiness woke the hungry longing for
514	someone to 'love with heart and soul, and cling to while God let them
514	be together'. Up in the garret, where Jo's unquiet wanderings ended
514	stood four little wooden chests in a row, each marked with its owners
514	name, and each filled with relics of the childhood and girlhood ended
514	now for all.  Jo glanced into them, and when she came to her own,
514	leaned her chin on the edge, and stared absently at the chaotic
514	collection, till a bundle of old exercise books caught her eye.  She
514	drew them out, turned them over, and relived that pleasant winter at
514	kind Mrs. Kirke's.  She had smiled at first, then she looked
514	thoughtful, next sad, and when she came to a little message written in
514	the Professor's hand, her lips began to tremble, the books slid out of
514	her lap, and she sat looking at the friendly words, as they took a new
514	meaning, and touched a tender spot in her heart.
514	""
514	"""Wait for me, my friend.  I may be a little late, but I shall surely"
514	"come."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, if he only would!  So kind, so good, so patient with me always, my"
514	dear old Fritz.  I didn't value him half enough when I had him, but now
514	how I should love to see him, for everyone seems going away from me,
514	"and I'm all alone."""
514	""
514	And holding the little paper fast, as if it were a promise yet to be
514	fulfilled, Jo laid her head down on a comfortable rag bag, and cried,
514	as if in opposition to the rain pattering on the roof.
514	""
514	Was it all self-pity, loneliness, or low spirits?  Or was it the waking
514	up of a sentiment which had bided its time as patiently as its
514	inspirer?  Who shall say?
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-THREE
514	""
514	SURPRISES
514	""
514	Jo was alone in the twilight, lying on the old sofa, looking at the
514	fire, and thinking.  It was her favorite way of spending the hour of
514	dusk.  No one disturbed her, and she used to lie there on Beth's little
514	red pillow, planning stories, dreaming dreams, or thinking tender
514	thoughts of the sister who never seemed far away.  Her face looked
514	tired, grave, and rather sad, for tomorrow was her birthday, and she
514	was thinking how fast the years went by, how old she was getting, and
514	how little she seemed to have accomplished.  Almost twenty-five, and
514	nothing to show for it.  Jo was mistaken in that.  There was a good
514	deal to show, and by-and-by she saw, and was grateful for it.
514	""
514	"""An old maid, that's what I'm to be.  A literary spinster, with a pen"
514	for a spouse, a family of stories for children, and twenty years hence
514	a morsel of fame, perhaps, when, like poor Johnson, I'm old and can't
514	enjoy it, solitary, and can't share it, independent, and don't need it.
514	Well, I needn't be a sour saint nor a selfish sinner, and, I dare say,
514	"old maids are very comfortable when they get used to it, but..."" and"
514	there Jo sighed, as if the prospect was not inviting.
514	""
514	It seldom is, at first, and thirty seems the end of all things to
514	five-and-twenty.  But it's not as bad as it looks, and one can get on
514	quite happily if one has something in one's self to fall back upon.  At
514	twenty-five, girls begin to talk about being old maids, but secretly
514	resolve that they never will be.  At thirty they say nothing about it,
514	but quietly accept the fact, and if sensible, console themselves by
514	remembering that they have twenty more useful, happy years, in which
514	they may be learning to grow old gracefully.  Don't laugh at the
514	spinsters, dear girls, for often very tender, tragic romances are
514	hidden away in the hearts that beat so quietly under the sober gowns,
514	and many silent sacrifices of youth, health, ambition, love itself,
514	make the faded faces beautiful in God's sight.  Even the sad, sour
514	sisters should be kindly dealt with, because they have missed the
514	sweetest part of life, if for no other reason.  And looking at them
514	with compassion, not contempt, girls in their bloom should remember
514	that they too may miss the blossom time.  That rosy cheeks don't last
514	forever, that silver threads will come in the bonnie brown hair, and
514	that, by-and-by, kindness and respect will be as sweet as love and
514	admiration now.
514	""
514	Gentlemen, which means boys, be courteous to the old maids, no matter
514	how poor and plain and prim, for the only chivalry worth having is that
514	which is the readiest to pay deference to the old, protect the feeble,
514	and serve womankind, regardless of rank, age, or color.  Just recollect
514	the good aunts who have not only lectured and fussed, but nursed and
514	petted, too often without thanks, the scrapes they have helped you out
514	of, the tips they have given you from their small store, the stitches
514	the patient old fingers have set for you, the steps the willing old
514	feet have taken, and gratefully pay the dear old ladies the little
514	attentions that women love to receive as long as they live.  The
514	bright-eyed girls are quick to see such traits, and will like you all
514	the better for them, and if death, almost the only power that can part
514	mother and son, should rob you of yours, you will be sure to find a
514	tender welcome and maternal cherishing from some Aunt Priscilla, who
514	has kept the warmest corner of her lonely old heart for 'the best nevvy
514	in the world'.
514	""
514	Jo must have fallen asleep (as I dare say my reader has during this
514	little homily), for suddenly Laurie's ghost seemed to stand before her,
514	a substantial, lifelike ghost, leaning over her with the very look he
514	used to wear when he felt a good deal and didn't like to show it.  But,
514	like Jenny in the ballad...
514	""
514	"  ""She could not think it he,"""
514	""
514	and lay staring up at him in startled silence, till he stooped and
514	kissed her.  Then she knew him, and flew up, crying joyfully...
514	""
514	"""Oh my Teddy!  Oh my Teddy!"""
514	""
514	"""Dear Jo, you are glad to see me, then?"""
514	""
514	"""Glad!  My blessed boy, words can't express my gladness. Where's Amy?"""
514	""
514	"""Your mother has got her down at Meg's.  We stopped there by the way,"
514	"and there was no getting my wife out of their clutches."""
514	""
514	"""Your what?"" cried Jo, for Laurie uttered those two words with an"
514	unconscious pride and satisfaction which betrayed him.
514	""
514	"""Oh, the dickens!  Now I've done it,"" and he looked so guilty that Jo"
514	was down on him like a flash.
514	""
514	"""You've gone and got married!"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, please, but I never will again,"" and he went down upon his knees,"
514	with a penitent clasping of hands, and a face full of mischief, mirth,
514	and triumph.
514	""
514	"""Actually married?"""
514	""
514	"""Very much so, thank you."""
514	""
514	"""Mercy on us.  What dreadful thing will you do next?"" and Jo fell into"
514	her seat with a gasp.
514	""
514	"""A characteristic, but not exactly complimentary, congratulation,"""
514	returned Laurie, still in an abject attitude, but beaming with
514	satisfaction.
514	""
514	"""What can you expect, when you take one's breath away, creeping in like"
514	a burglar, and letting cats out of bags like that? Get up, you
514	"ridiculous boy, and tell me all about it."""
514	""
514	"""Not a word, unless you let me come in my old place, and promise not to"
514	"barricade."""
514	""
514	Jo laughed at that as she had not done for many a long day, and patted
514	"the sofa invitingly, as she said in a cordial tone, ""The old pillow is"
514	"up garret, and we don't need it now.  So, come and 'fess, Teddy."""
514	""
514	"""How good it sounds to hear you say 'Teddy'! No one ever calls me that"
514	"but you,"" and Laurie sat down with an air of great content."
514	""
514	"""What does Amy call you?"""
514	""
514	"""My lord."""
514	""
514	"""That's like her.  Well, you look it,"" and Jo's eye plainly betrayed"
514	that she found her boy comelier than ever.
514	""
514	The pillow was gone, but there was a barricade, nevertheless, a natural
514	one, raised by time, absence, and change of heart.  Both felt it, and
514	for a minute looked at one another as if that invisible barrier cast a
514	little shadow over them.  It was gone directly however, for Laurie
514	said, with a vain attempt at dignity...
514	""
514	"""Don't I look like a married man and the head of a family?"""
514	""
514	"""Not a bit, and you never will.  You've grown bigger and bonnier, but"
514	"you are the same scapegrace as ever."""
514	""
514	"""Now really, Jo, you ought to treat me with more respect,"" began"
514	Laurie, who enjoyed it all immensely.
514	""
514	"""How can I, when the mere idea of you, married and settled, is so"
514	"irresistibly funny that I can't keep sober!"" answered Jo, smiling all"
514	over her face, so infectiously that they had another laugh, and then
514	settled down for a good talk, quite in the pleasant old fashion.
514	""
514	"""It's no use your going out in the cold to get Amy, for they are all"
514	coming up presently.  I couldn't wait.  I wanted to be the one to tell
514	you the grand surprise, and have 'first skim' as we used to say when we
514	"squabbled about the cream."""
514	""
514	"""Of course you did, and spoiled your story by beginning at the wrong"
514	end.  Now, start right, and tell me how it all happened. I'm pining to
514	"know."""
514	""
514	"""Well, I did it to please Amy,"" began Laurie, with a twinkle that made"
514	Jo exclaim...
514	""
514	"""Fib number one.  Amy did it to please you.  Go on, and tell the truth,"
514	"if you can, sir."""
514	""
514	"""Now she's beginning to marm it.  Isn't it jolly to hear her?"" said"
514	Laurie to the fire, and the fire glowed and sparkled as if it quite
514	"agreed.  ""It's all the same, you know, she and I being one. We planned"
514	to come home with the Carrols, a month or more ago, but they suddenly
514	changed their minds, and decided to pass another winter in Paris.  But
514	Grandpa wanted to come home.  He went to please me, and I couldn't let
514	him go alone, neither could I leave Amy, and Mrs. Carrol had got
514	English notions about chaperons and such nonsense, and wouldn't let Amy
514	come with us.  So I just settled the difficulty by saying, 'Let's be
514	"married, and then we can do as we like'."""
514	""
514	"""Of course you did.  You always have things to suit you."""
514	""
514	"""Not always,"" and something in Laurie's voice made Jo say hastily..."
514	""
514	"""How did you ever get Aunt to agree?"""
514	""
514	"""It was hard work, but between us, we talked her over, for we had heaps"
514	of good reasons on our side.  There wasn't time to write and ask leave,
514	but you all liked it, had consented to it by-and-by, and it was only
514	"'taking time by the fetlock', as my wife says."""
514	""
514	"""Aren't we proud of those two words, and don't we like to say them?"""
514	interrupted Jo, addressing the fire in her turn, and watching with
514	delight the happy light it seemed to kindle in the eyes that had been
514	so tragically gloomy when she saw them last.
514	""
514	"""A trifle, perhaps, she's such a captivating little woman I can't help"
514	being proud of her.  Well, then Uncle and Aunt were there to play
514	propriety.  We were so absorbed in one another we were of no mortal use
514	apart, and that charming arrangement would make everything easy all
514	"round, so we did it."""
514	""
514	"""When, where, how?"" asked Jo, in a fever of feminine interest and"
514	curiosity, for she could not realize it a particle.
514	""
514	"""Six weeks ago, at the American consul's, in Paris, a very quiet"
514	wedding of course, for even in our happiness we didn't forget dear
514	"little Beth."""
514	""
514	Jo put her hand in his as he said that, and Laurie gently smoothed the
514	little red pillow, which he remembered well.
514	""
514	"""Why didn't you let us know afterward?"" asked Jo, in a quieter tone,"
514	when they had sat quite still a minute.
514	""
514	"""We wanted to surprise you.  We thought we were coming directly home,"
514	at first, but the dear old gentleman, as soon as we were married, found
514	he couldn't be ready under a month, at least, and sent us off to spend
514	our honeymoon wherever we liked. Amy had once called Valrosa a regular
514	honeymoon home, so we went there, and were as happy as people are but
514	"once in their lives. My faith!  Wasn't it love among the roses!"""
514	""
514	Laurie seemed to forget Jo for a minute, and Jo was glad of it, for the
514	fact that he told her these things so freely and so naturally assured
514	her that he had quite forgiven and forgotten. She tried to draw away
514	her hand, but as if he guessed the thought that prompted the
514	half-involuntary impulse, Laurie held it fast, and said, with a manly
514	gravity she had never seen in him before...
514	""
514	"""Jo, dear, I want to say one thing, and then we'll put it by forever."
514	As I told you in my letter when I wrote that Amy had been so kind to
514	me, I never shall stop loving you, but the love is altered, and I have
514	learned to see that it is better as it is. Amy and you changed places
514	in my heart, that's all.  I think it was meant to be so, and would have
514	come about naturally, if I had waited, as you tried to make me, but I
514	never could be patient, and so I got a heartache.  I was a boy then,
514	headstrong and violent, and it took a hard lesson to show me my
514	mistake.  For it was one, Jo, as you said, and I found it out, after
514	making a fool of myself. Upon my word, I was so tumbled up in my mind,
514	at one time, that I didn't know which I loved best, you or Amy, and
514	tried to love you both alike.  But I couldn't, and when I saw her in
514	Switzerland, everything seemed to clear up all at once.  You both got
514	into your right places, and I felt sure that it was well off with the
514	old love before it was on with the new, that I could honestly share my
514	heart between sister Jo and wife Amy, and love them dearly. Will you
514	believe it, and go back to the happy old times when we first knew one
514	"another?"""
514	""
514	"""I'll believe it, with all my heart, but, Teddy, we never can be boy"
514	and girl again.  The happy old times can't come back, and we mustn't
514	expect it.  We are man and woman now, with sober work to do, for
514	playtime is over, and we must give up frolicking.  I'm sure you feel
514	this.  I see the change in you, and you'll find it in me.  I shall miss
514	my boy, but I shall love the man as much, and admire him more, because
514	he means to be what I hoped he would.  We can't be little playmates any
514	longer, but we will be brother and sister, to love and help one another
514	"all our lives, won't we, Laurie?"""
514	""
514	He did not say a word, but took the hand she offered him, and laid his
514	face down on it for a minute, feeling that out of the grave of a boyish
514	passion, there had risen a beautiful, strong friendship to bless them
514	both.  Presently Jo said cheerfully, for she didn't want the coming
514	"home to be a sad one, ""I can't make it true that you children are"
514	really married and going to set up housekeeping. Why, it seems only
514	yesterday that I was buttoning Amy's pinafore, and pulling your hair
514	"when you teased.  Mercy me, how time does fly!"""
514	""
514	"""As one of the children is older than yourself, you needn't talk so"
514	like a grandma.  I flatter myself I'm a 'gentleman growed' as Peggotty
514	said of David, and when you see Amy, you'll find her rather a
514	"precocious infant,"" said Laurie, looking amused at her maternal air."
514	""
514	"""You may be a little older in years, but I'm ever so much older in"
514	feeling, Teddy.  Women always are, and this last year has been such a
514	"hard one that I feel forty."""
514	""
514	"""Poor Jo!  We left you to bear it alone, while we went pleasuring. You"
514	are older.  Here's a line, and there's another.  Unless you smile, your
514	eyes look sad, and when I touched the cushion, just now, I found a tear
514	on it.  You've had a great deal to bear, and had to bear it all alone.
514	"What a selfish beast I've been!"" and Laurie pulled his own hair, with a"
514	remorseful look.
514	""
514	But Jo only turned over the traitorous pillow, and answered, in a tone
514	"which she tried to make more cheerful, ""No, I had Father and Mother to"
514	help me, and the dear babies to comfort me, and the thought that you
514	and Amy were safe and happy, to make the troubles here easier to bear.
514	"I am lonely, sometimes, but I dare say it's good for me, and..."""
514	""
514	"""You never shall be again,"" broke in Laurie, putting his arm about her,"
514	"as if to fence out every human ill.  ""Amy and I can't get on without"
514	you, so you must come and teach 'the children' to keep house, and go
514	halves in everything, just as we used to do, and let us pet you, and
514	"all be blissfully happy and friendly together."""
514	""
514	"""If I shouldn't be in the way, it would be very pleasant.  I begin to"
514	feel quite young already, for somehow all my troubles seemed to fly
514	"away when you came.  You always were a comfort, Teddy,"" and Jo leaned"
514	her head on his shoulder, just as she did years ago, when Beth lay ill
514	and Laurie told her to hold on to him.
514	""
514	He looked down at her, wondering if she remembered the time, but Jo was
514	smiling to herself, as if in truth her troubles had all vanished at his
514	coming.
514	""
514	"""You are the same Jo still, dropping tears about one minute, and"
514	"laughing the next.  You look a little wicked now.  What is it, Grandma?"""
514	""
514	"""I was wondering how you and Amy get on together."""
514	""
514	"""Like angels!"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, of course, but which rules?"""
514	""
514	"""I don't mind telling you that she does now, at least I let her think"
514	so, it pleases her, you know.  By-and-by we shall take turns, for
514	"marriage, they say, halves one's rights and doubles one's duties."""
514	""
514	"""You'll go on as you begin, and Amy will rule you all the days of your"
514	"life."""
514	""
514	"""Well, she does it so imperceptibly that I don't think I shall mind"
514	much.  She is the sort of woman who knows how to rule well.  In fact, I
514	rather like it, for she winds one round her finger as softly and
514	prettily as a skein of silk, and makes you feel as if she was doing you
514	"a favor all the while."""
514	""
514	"""That ever I should live to see you a henpecked husband and enjoying"
514	"it!"" cried Jo, with uplifted hands."
514	""
514	It was good to see Laurie square his shoulders, and smile with
514	"masculine scorn at that insinuation, as he replied, with his ""high and"
514	"mighty"" air, ""Amy is too well-bred for that, and I am not the sort of"
514	man to submit to it.  My wife and I respect ourselves and one another
514	"too much ever to tyrannize or quarrel."""
514	""
514	Jo liked that, and thought the new dignity very becoming, but the boy
514	seemed changing very fast into the man, and regret mingled with her
514	pleasure.
514	""
514	"""I am sure of that.  Amy and you never did quarrel as we used to. She"
514	is the sun and I the wind, in the fable, and the sun managed the man
514	"best, you remember."""
514	""
514	"""She can blow him up as well as shine on him,"" laughed Laurie. ""Such a"
514	lecture as I got at Nice!  I give you my word it was a deal worse than
514	any of your scoldings, a regular rouser.  I'll tell you all about it
514	sometime, she never will, because after telling me that she despised
514	and was ashamed of me, she lost her heart to the despicable party and
514	"married the good-for-nothing."""
514	""
514	"""What baseness!  Well, if she abuses you, come to me, and I'll defend"
514	"you."""
514	""
514	"""I look as if I needed it, don't I?"" said Laurie, getting up and"
514	striking an attitude which suddenly changed from the imposing to the
514	"rapturous, as Amy's voice was heard calling, ""Where is she? Where's my"
514	"dear old Jo?"""
514	""
514	In trooped the whole family, and everyone was hugged and kissed all
514	over again, and after several vain attempts, the three wanderers were
514	set down to be looked at and exulted over.  Mr. Laurence, hale and
514	hearty as ever, was quite as much improved as the others by his foreign
514	tour, for the crustiness seemed to be nearly gone, and the
514	old-fashioned courtliness had received a polish which made it kindlier
514	than ever.  It was good to see him beam at 'my children', as he called
514	the young pair.  It was better still to see Amy pay him the daughterly
514	duty and affection which completely won his old heart, and best of all,
514	to watch Laurie revolve about the two, as if never tired of enjoying
514	the pretty picture they made.
514	""
514	The minute she put her eyes upon Amy, Meg became conscious that her own
514	dress hadn't a Parisian air, that young Mrs. Moffat would be entirely
514	eclipsed by young Mrs. Laurence, and that 'her ladyship' was altogether
514	a most elegant and graceful woman.  Jo thought, as she watched the
514	"pair, ""How well they look together!  I was right, and Laurie has found"
514	the beautiful, accomplished girl who will become his home better than
514	"clumsy old Jo, and be a pride, not a torment to him.""  Mrs. March and"
514	her husband smiled and nodded at each other with happy faces, for they
514	saw that their youngest had done well, not only in worldly things, but
514	the better wealth of love, confidence, and happiness.
514	""
514	For Amy's face was full of the soft brightness which betokens a
514	peaceful heart, her voice had a new tenderness in it, and the cool,
514	prim carriage was changed to a gentle dignity, both womanly and
514	winning. No little affectations marred it, and the cordial sweetness of
514	her manner was more charming than the new beauty or the old grace, for
514	it stamped her at once with the unmistakable sign of the true
514	gentlewoman she had hoped to become.
514	""
514	"""Love has done much for our little girl,"" said her mother softly."
514	""
514	"""She has had a good example before her all her life, my dear,"" Mr."
514	March whispered back, with a loving look at the worn face and gray head
514	beside him.
514	""
514	Daisy found it impossible to keep her eyes off her 'pitty aunty', but
514	attached herself like a lap dog to the wonderful chatelaine full of
514	delightful charms.  Demi paused to consider the new relationship before
514	he compromised himself by the rash acceptance of a bribe, which took
514	the tempting form of a family of wooden bears from Berne. A flank
514	movement produced an unconditional surrender, however, for Laurie knew
514	where to have him.
514	""
514	"""Young man, when I first had the honor of making your acquaintance you"
514	"hit me in the face.  Now I demand the satisfaction of a gentleman,"" and"
514	with that the tall uncle proceeded to toss and tousle the small nephew
514	in a way that damaged his philosophical dignity as much as it delighted
514	his boyish soul.
514	""
514	"""Blest if she ain't in silk from head to foot; ain't it a relishin'"
514	sight to see her settin' there as fine as a fiddle, and hear folks
514	"calling little Amy 'Mis.  Laurence!'"" muttered old Hannah, who could"
514	"not resist frequent ""peeks"" through the slide as she set the table in a"
514	most decidedly promiscuous manner.
514	""
514	Mercy on us, how they did talk! first one, then the other, then all
514	burst out together--trying to tell the history of three years in half
514	an hour.  It was fortunate that tea was at hand, to produce a lull and
514	provide refreshment--for they would have been hoarse and faint if they
514	had gone on much longer.  Such a happy procession as filed away into
514	the little dining room! Mr. March proudly escorted Mrs. Laurence.  Mrs.
514	March as proudly leaned on the arm of 'my son'. The old gentleman took
514	"Jo, with a whispered, ""You must be my girl now,"" and a glance at the"
514	"empty corner by the fire, that made Jo whisper back, ""I'll try to fill"
514	"her place, sir."""
514	""
514	The twins pranced behind, feeling that the millennium was at hand, for
514	everyone was so busy with the newcomers that they were left to revel at
514	their own sweet will, and you may be sure they made the most of the
514	opportunity.  Didn't they steal sips of tea, stuff gingerbread ad
514	libitum, get a hot biscuit apiece, and as a crowning trespass, didn't
514	they each whisk a captivating little tart into their tiny pockets,
514	there to stick and crumble treacherously, teaching them that both human
514	nature and a pastry are frail? Burdened with the guilty consciousness
514	of the sequestered tarts, and fearing that Dodo's sharp eyes would
514	pierce the thin disguise of cambric and merino which hid their booty,
514	the little sinners attached themselves to 'Dranpa', who hadn't his
514	spectacles on.  Amy, who was handed about like refreshments, returned
514	to the parlor on Father Laurence's arm.  The others paired off as
514	before, and this arrangement left Jo companionless.  She did not mind
514	it at the minute, for she lingered to answer Hannah's eager inquiry.
514	""
514	"""Will Miss Amy ride in her coop (coupe), and use all them lovely silver"
514	"dishes that's stored away over yander?"""
514	""
514	"""Shouldn't wonder if she drove six white horses, ate off gold plate,"
514	and wore diamonds and point lace every day.  Teddy thinks nothing too
514	"good for her,"" returned Jo with infinite satisfaction."
514	""
514	"""No more there is!  Will you have hash or fishballs for breakfast?"""
514	asked Hannah, who wisely mingled poetry and prose.
514	""
514	"""I don't care,"" and Jo shut the door, feeling that food was an"
514	uncongenial topic just then.  She stood a minute looking at the party
514	vanishing above, and as Demi's short plaid legs toiled up the last
514	stair, a sudden sense of loneliness came over her so strongly that she
514	looked about her with dim eyes, as if to find something to lean upon,
514	for even Teddy had deserted her.  If she had known what birthday gift
514	was coming every minute nearer and nearer, she would not have said to
514	"herself, ""I'll weep a little weep when I go to bed. It won't do to be"
514	"dismal now.""  Then she drew her hand over her eyes, for one of her"
514	boyish habits was never to know where her handkerchief was, and had
514	just managed to call up a smile when there came a knock at the porch
514	door.
514	""
514	She opened with hospitable haste, and started as if another ghost had
514	come to surprise her, for there stood a tall bearded gentleman, beaming
514	on her from the darkness like a midnight sun.
514	""
514	"""Oh, Mr. Bhaer, I am so glad to see you!"" cried Jo, with a clutch, as"
514	if she feared the night would swallow him up before she could get him
514	in.
514	""
514	"""And I to see Miss Marsch, but no, you haf a party,"" and the Professor"
514	paused as the sound of voices and the tap of dancing feet came down to
514	them.
514	""
514	"""No, we haven't, only the family.  My sister and friends have just come"
514	"home, and we are all very happy.  Come in, and make one of us."""
514	""
514	Though a very social man, I think Mr. Bhaer would have gone decorously
514	away, and come again another day, but how could he, when Jo shut the
514	door behind him, and bereft him of his hat? Perhaps her face had
514	something to do with it, for she forgot to hide her joy at seeing him,
514	and showed it with a frankness that proved irresistible to the solitary
514	man, whose welcome far exceeded his boldest hopes.
514	""
514	"""If I shall not be Monsieur de Trop, I will so gladly see them all."
514	"You haf been ill, my friend?"""
514	""
514	He put the question abruptly, for, as Jo hung up his coat, the light
514	fell on her face, and he saw a change in it.
514	""
514	"""Not ill, but tired and sorrowful.  We have had trouble since I saw you"
514	"last."""
514	""
514	"""Ah, yes, I know.  My heart was sore for you when I heard that,"" and he"
514	shook hands again, with such a sympathetic face that Jo felt as if no
514	comfort could equal the look of the kind eyes, the grasp of the big,
514	warm hand.
514	""
514	"""Father, Mother, this is my friend, Professor Bhaer,"" she said, with a"
514	face and tone of such irrepressible pride and pleasure that she might
514	as well have blown a trumpet and opened the door with a flourish.
514	""
514	If the stranger had any doubts about his reception, they were set at
514	rest in a minute by the cordial welcome he received. Everyone greeted
514	him kindly, for Jo's sake at first, but very soon they liked him for
514	his own.  They could not help it, for he carried the talisman that
514	opens all hearts, and these simple people warmed to him at once,
514	feeling even the more friendly because he was poor.  For poverty
514	enriches those who live above it, and is a sure passport to truly
514	hospitable spirits.  Mr. Bhaer sat looking about him with the air of a
514	traveler who knocks at a strange door, and when it opens, finds himself
514	at home.  The children went to him like bees to a honeypot, and
514	establishing themselves on each knee, proceeded to captivate him by
514	rifling his pockets, pulling his beard, and investigating his watch,
514	with juvenile audacity.  The women telegraphed their approval to one
514	another, and Mr. March, feeling that he had got a kindred spirit,
514	opened his choicest stores for his guest's benefit, while silent John
514	listened and enjoyed the talk, but said not a word, and Mr. Laurence
514	found it impossible to go to sleep.
514	""
514	If Jo had not been otherwise engaged, Laurie's behavior would have
514	amused her, for a faint twinge, not of jealousy, but something like
514	suspicion, caused that gentleman to stand aloof at first, and observe
514	the newcomer with brotherly circumspection. But it did not last long.
514	He got interested in spite of himself, and before he knew it, was drawn
514	into the circle.  For Mr. Bhaer talked well in this genial atmosphere,
514	and did himself justice. He seldom spoke to Laurie, but he looked at
514	him often, and a shadow would pass across his face, as if regretting
514	his own lost youth, as he watched the young man in his prime.  Then his
514	eyes would turn to Jo so wistfully that she would have surely answered
514	the mute inquiry if she had seen it.  But Jo had her own eyes to take
514	care of, and feeling that they could not be trusted, she prudently kept
514	them on the little sock she was knitting, like a model maiden aunt.
514	""
514	A stealthy glance now and then refreshed her like sips of fresh water
514	after a dusty walk, for the sidelong peeps showed her several
514	propitious omens.  Mr. Bhaer's face had lost the absent-minded
514	expression, and looked all alive with interest in the present moment,
514	actually young and handsome, she thought, forgetting to compare him
514	with Laurie, as she usually did strange men, to their great detriment.
514	Then he seemed quite inspired, though the burial customs of the
514	ancients, to which the conversation had strayed, might not be
514	considered an exhilarating topic. Jo quite glowed with triumph when
514	Teddy got quenched in an argument, and thought to herself, as she
514	"watched her father's absorbed face, ""How he would enjoy having such a"
514	"man as my Professor to talk with every day!""  Lastly, Mr. Bhaer was"
514	dressed in a new suit of black, which made him look more like a
514	gentleman than ever.  His bushy hair had been cut and smoothly brushed,
514	but didn't stay in order long, for in exciting moments, he rumpled it
514	up in the droll way he used to do, and Jo liked it rampantly erect
514	better than flat, because she thought it gave his fine forehead a
514	Jove-like aspect.  Poor Jo, how she did glorify that plain man, as she
514	sat knitting away so quietly, yet letting nothing escape her, not even
514	the fact that Mr. Bhaer actually had gold sleeve-buttons in his
514	immaculate wristbands.
514	""
514	"""Dear old fellow!  He couldn't have got himself up with more care if"
514	"he'd been going a-wooing,"" said Jo to herself, and then a sudden"
514	thought born of the words made her blush so dreadfully that she had to
514	drop her ball, and go down after it to hide her face.
514	""
514	The maneuver did not succeed as well as she expected, however, for
514	though just in the act of setting fire to a funeral pyre, the Professor
514	dropped his torch, metaphorically speaking, and made a dive after the
514	little blue ball.  Of course they bumped their heads smartly together,
514	saw stars, and both came up flushed and laughing, without the ball, to
514	resume their seats, wishing they had not left them.
514	""
514	Nobody knew where the evening went to, for Hannah skillfully abstracted
514	the babies at an early hour, nodding like two rosy poppies, and Mr.
514	Laurence went home to rest.  The others sat round the fire, talking
514	away, utterly regardless of the lapse of time, till Meg, whose maternal
514	mind was impressed with a firm conviction that Daisy had tumbled out of
514	bed, and Demi set his nightgown afire studying the structure of
514	matches, made a move to go.
514	""
514	"""We must have our sing, in the good old way, for we are all together"
514	"again once more,"" said Jo, feeling that a good shout would be a safe"
514	and pleasant vent for the jubilant emotions of her soul.
514	""
514	They were not all there.  But no one found the words thoughtless or
514	untrue, for Beth still seemed among them, a peaceful presence,
514	invisible, but dearer than ever, since death could not break the
514	household league that love made dissoluble.  The little chair stood in
514	its old place.  The tidy basket, with the bit of work she left
514	unfinished when the needle grew 'so heavy', was still on its accustomed
514	shelf.  The beloved instrument, seldom touched now had not been moved,
514	and above it Beth's face, serene and smiling, as in the early days,
514	"looked down upon them, seeming to say, ""Be happy.  I am here."""
514	""
514	"""Play something, Amy.  Let them hear how much you have improved,"" said"
514	Laurie, with pardonable pride in his promising pupil.
514	""
514	"But Amy whispered, with full eyes, as she twirled the faded stool, ""Not"
514	"tonight, dear.  I can't show off tonight."""
514	""
514	But she did show something better than brilliancy or skill, for she
514	sang Beth's songs with a tender music in her voice which the best
514	master could not have taught, and touched the listener's hearts with a
514	sweeter power than any other inspiration could have given her.  The
514	room was very still, when the clear voice failed suddenly at the last
514	line of Beth's favorite hymn.  It was hard to say...
514	""
514	    Earth hath no sorrow that heaven cannot heal;
514	""
514	and Amy leaned against her husband, who stood behind her, feeling that
514	her welcome home was not quite perfect without Beth's kiss.
514	""
514	"""Now, we must finish with Mignon's song, for Mr. Bhaer sings that,"""
514	said Jo, before the pause grew painful.  And Mr. Bhaer cleared his
514	"throat with a gratified ""Hem!"" as he stepped into the corner where Jo"
514	stood, saying...
514	""
514	"""You will sing with me?  We go excellently well together."""
514	""
514	A pleasing fiction, by the way, for Jo had no more idea of music than a
514	grasshopper.  But she would have consented if he had proposed to sing a
514	whole opera, and warbled away, blissfully regardless of time and tune.
514	It didn't much matter, for Mr. Bhaer sang like a true German, heartily
514	and well, and Jo soon subsided into a subdued hum, that she might
514	listen to the mellow voice that seemed to sing for her alone.
514	""
514	    Know'st thou the land where the citron blooms,
514	""
514	used to be the Professor's favorite line, for 'das land' meant Germany
514	to him, but now he seemed to dwell, with peculiar warmth and melody,
514	upon the words...
514	""
514	    There, oh there, might I with thee,
514	    O, my beloved, go
514	""
514	and one listener was so thrilled by the tender invitation that she
514	longed to say she did know the land, and would joyfully depart thither
514	whenever he liked.
514	""
514	The song was considered a great success, and the singer retired covered
514	with laurels.  But a few minutes afterward, he forgot his manners
514	entirely, and stared at Amy putting on her bonnet, for she had been
514	introduced simply as 'my sister', and no one had called her by her new
514	name since he came.  He forgot himself still further when Laurie said,
514	in his most gracious manner, at parting...
514	""
514	"""My wife and I are very glad to meet you, sir.  Please remember that"
514	"there is always a welcome waiting for you over the way."""
514	""
514	Then the Professor thanked him so heartily, and looked so suddenly
514	illuminated with satisfaction, that Laurie thought him the most
514	delightfully demonstrative old fellow he ever met.
514	""
514	"""I too shall go, but I shall gladly come again, if you will gif me"
514	leave, dear madame, for a little business in the city will keep me here
514	"some days."""
514	""
514	He spoke to Mrs. March, but he looked at Jo, and the mother's voice
514	gave as cordial an assent as did the daughter's eyes, for Mrs. March
514	was not so blind to her children's interest as Mrs. Moffat supposed.
514	""
514	"""I suspect that is a wise man,"" remarked Mr. March, with placid"
514	satisfaction, from the hearthrug, after the last guest had gone.
514	""
514	"""I know he is a good one,"" added Mrs. March, with decided approval, as"
514	she wound up the clock.
514	""
514	"""I thought you'd like him,"" was all Jo said, as she slipped away to her"
514	bed.
514	""
514	She wondered what the business was that brought Mr. Bhaer to the city,
514	and finally decided that he had been appointed to some great honor,
514	somewhere, but had been too modest to mention the fact.  If she had
514	seen his face when, safe in his own room, he looked at the picture of a
514	severe and rigid young lady, with a good deal of hair, who appeared to
514	be gazing darkly into futurity, it might have thrown some light upon
514	the subject, especially when he turned off the gas, and kissed the
514	picture in the dark.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-FOUR
514	""
514	MY LORD AND LADY
514	""
514	"""Please, Madam Mother, could you lend me my wife for half an hour?  The"
514	luggage has come, and I've been making hay of Amy's Paris finery,
514	"trying to find some things I want,"" said Laurie, coming in the next day"
514	to find Mrs. Laurence sitting in her mother's lap, as if being made
514	'the baby' again.
514	""
514	"""Certainly.  Go, dear, I forgot that you have any home but this,"" and"
514	Mrs. March pressed the white hand that wore the wedding ring, as if
514	asking pardon for her maternal covetousness.
514	""
514	"""I shouldn't have come over if I could have helped it, but I can't get"
514	"on without my little woman any more than a..."""
514	""
514	"""Weathercock can without the wind,"" suggested Jo, as he paused for a"
514	simile.  Jo had grown quite her own saucy self again since Teddy came
514	home.
514	""
514	"""Exactly, for Amy keeps me pointing due west most of the time, with"
514	only an occasional whiffle round to the south, and I haven't had an
514	easterly spell since I was married.  Don't know anything about the
514	"north, but am altogether salubrious and balmy, hey, my lady?"""
514	""
514	"""Lovely weather so far.  I don't know how long it will last, but I'm"
514	not afraid of storms, for I'm learning how to sail my ship.  Come home,
514	dear, and I'll find your bootjack.  I suppose that's what you are
514	"rummaging after among my things.  Men are so helpless, Mother,"" said"
514	Amy, with a matronly air, which delighted her husband.
514	""
514	"""What are you going to do with yourselves after you get settled?"" asked"
514	Jo, buttoning Amy's cloak as she used to button her pinafores.
514	""
514	"""We have our plans.  We don't mean to say much about them yet, because"
514	we are such very new brooms, but we don't intend to be idle.  I'm going
514	into business with a devotion that shall delight Grandfather, and prove
514	to him that I'm not spoiled.  I need something of the sort to keep me
514	"steady.  I'm tired of dawdling, and mean to work like a man."""
514	""
514	"""And Amy, what is she going to do?"" asked Mrs. March, well pleased at"
514	Laurie's decision and the energy with which he spoke.
514	""
514	"""After doing the civil all round, and airing our best bonnet, we shall"
514	astonish you by the elegant hospitalities of our mansion, the brilliant
514	society we shall draw about us, and the beneficial influence we shall
514	exert over the world at large.  That's about it, isn't it, Madame
514	"Recamier?"" asked Laurie with a quizzical look at Amy."
514	""
514	"""Time will show.  Come away, Impertinence, and don't shock my family by"
514	"calling me names before their faces,"" answered Amy, resolving that"
514	there should be a home with a good wife in it before she set up a salon
514	as a queen of society.
514	""
514	"""How happy those children seem together!"" observed Mr. March, finding"
514	it difficult to become absorbed in his Aristotle after the young couple
514	had gone.
514	""
514	"""Yes, and I think it will last,"" added Mrs. March, with the restful"
514	expression of a pilot who has brought a ship safely into port.
514	""
514	"""I know it will.  Happy Amy!"" and Jo sighed, then smiled brightly as"
514	Professor Bhaer opened the gate with an impatient push.
514	""
514	Later in the evening, when his mind had been set at rest about the
514	"bootjack, Laurie said suddenly to his wife, ""Mrs. Laurence."""
514	""
514	"""My Lord!"""
514	""
514	"""That man intends to marry our Jo!"""
514	""
514	"""I hope so, don't you, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""Well, my love, I consider him a trump, in the fullest sense of that"
514	expressive word, but I do wish he was a little younger and a good deal
514	"richer."""
514	""
514	"""Now, Laurie, don't be too fastidious and worldly-minded. If they love"
514	one another it doesn't matter a particle how old they are nor how poor.
514	"Women never should marry for money..."" Amy caught herself up short as"
514	the words escaped her, and looked at her husband, who replied, with
514	malicious gravity...
514	""
514	"""Certainly not, though you do hear charming girls say that they intend"
514	to do it sometimes.  If my memory serves me, you once thought it your
514	duty to make a rich match.  That accounts, perhaps, for your marrying a
514	"good-for-nothing like me."""
514	""
514	"""Oh, my dearest boy, don't, don't say that!  I forgot you were rich"
514	when I said 'Yes'.  I'd have married you if you hadn't a penny, and I
514	"sometimes wish you were poor that I might show how much I love you."""
514	And Amy, who was very dignified in public and very fond in private,
514	gave convincing proofs of the truth of her words.
514	""
514	"""You don't really think I am such a mercenary creature as I tried to be"
514	once, do you?  It would break my heart if you didn't believe that I'd
514	gladly pull in the same boat with you, even if you had to get your
514	"living by rowing on the lake."""
514	""
514	"""Am I an idiot and a brute?  How could I think so, when you refused a"
514	richer man for me, and won't let me give you half I want to now, when I
514	have the right?  Girls do it every day, poor things, and are taught to
514	think it is their only salvation, but you had better lessons, and
514	though I trembled for you at one time, I was not disappointed, for the
514	daughter was true to the mother's teaching.  I told Mamma so yesterday,
514	and she looked as glad and grateful as if I'd given her a check for a
514	million, to be spent in charity.  You are not listening to my moral
514	"remarks, Mrs. Laurence,"" and Laurie paused, for Amy's eyes had an"
514	absent look, though fixed upon his face.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I am, and admiring the mole in your chin at the same time.  I"
514	don't wish to make you vain, but I must confess that I'm prouder of my
514	handsome husband than of all his money. Don't laugh, but your nose is
514	"such a comfort to me,"" and Amy softly caressed the well-cut feature"
514	with artistic satisfaction.
514	""
514	Laurie had received many compliments in his life, but never one that
514	suited him better, as he plainly showed though he did laugh at his
514	"wife's peculiar taste, while she said slowly, ""May I ask you a"
514	"question, dear?"""
514	""
514	"""Of course, you may."""
514	""
514	"""Shall you care if Jo does marry Mr. Bhaer?"""
514	""
514	"""Oh, that's the trouble is it?  I thought there was something in the"
514	dimple that didn't quite suit you.  Not being a dog in the manger, but
514	the happiest fellow alive, I assure you I can dance at Jo's wedding
514	"with a heart as light as my heels.  Do you doubt it, my darling?"""
514	""
514	Amy looked up at him, and was satisfied.  Her little jealous fear
514	vanished forever, and she thanked him, with a face full of love and
514	confidence.
514	""
514	"""I wish we could do something for that capital old Professor. Couldn't"
514	we invent a rich relation, who shall obligingly die out there in
514	"Germany, and leave him a tidy little fortune?"" said Laurie, when they"
514	began to pace up and down the long drawing room, arm in arm, as they
514	were fond of doing, in memory of the chateau garden.
514	""
514	"""Jo would find us out, and spoil it all.  She is very proud of him,"
514	just as he is, and said yesterday that she thought poverty was a
514	"beautiful thing."""
514	""
514	"""Bless her dear heart!  She won't think so when she has a literary"
514	husband, and a dozen little professors and professorins to support.  We
514	won't interfere now, but watch our chance, and do them a good turn in
514	spite of themselves.  I owe Jo for a part of my education, and she
514	believes in people's paying their honest debts, so I'll get round her
514	"in that way."""
514	""
514	"""How delightful it is to be able to help others, isn't it? That was"
514	always one of my dreams, to have the power of giving freely, and thanks
514	"to you, the dream has come true."""
514	""
514	"""Ah, we'll do quantities of good, won't we?  There's one sort of"
514	poverty that I particularly like to help.  Out-and-out beggars get
514	taken care of, but poor gentle folks fare badly, because they won't
514	ask, and people don't dare to offer charity. Yet there are a thousand
514	ways of helping them, if one only knows how to do it so delicately that
514	it does not offend.  I must say, I like to serve a decayed gentleman
514	better than a blarnerying beggar.  I suppose it's wrong, but I do,
514	"though it is harder."""
514	""
514	"""Because it takes a gentleman to do it,"" added the other member of the"
514	domestic admiration society.
514	""
514	"""Thank you, I'm afraid I don't deserve that pretty compliment. But I"
514	was going to say that while I was dawdling about abroad, I saw a good
514	many talented young fellows making all sorts of sacrifices, and
514	enduring real hardships, that they might realize their dreams. Splendid
514	fellows, some of them, working like heros,  poor and friendless, but so
514	full of courage, patience, and ambition that I was ashamed of myself,
514	and longed to give them a right good lift.  Those are people whom it's
514	a satisfaction to help, for if they've got genius, it's an honor to be
514	allowed to serve them, and not let it be lost or delayed for want of
514	fuel to keep the pot boiling.  If they haven't, it's a pleasure to
514	comfort the poor souls, and keep them from despair when they find it
514	"out."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, indeed, and there's another class who can't ask, and who suffer"
514	in silence.  I know something of it, for I belonged to it before you
514	made a princess of me, as the king does the beggarmaid in the old
514	story.  Ambitious girls have a hard time, Laurie, and often have to see
514	youth, health, and precious opportunities go by, just for want of a
514	little help at the right minute.  People have been very kind to me, and
514	whenever I see girls struggling along, as we used to do, I want to put
514	"out my hand and help them, as I was helped."""
514	""
514	"""And so you shall, like an angel as you are!"" cried Laurie, resolving,"
514	with a glow of philanthropic zeal, to found and endow an institution
514	"for the express benefit of young women with artistic tendencies.  ""Rich"
514	people have no right to sit down and enjoy themselves, or let their
514	money accumulate for others to waste.  It's not half so sensible to
514	leave legacies when one dies as it is to use the money wisely while
514	alive, and enjoy making one's fellow creatures happy with it.  We'll
514	have a good time ourselves, and add an extra relish to our own pleasure
514	by giving other people a generous taste.  Will you be a little Dorcas,
514	going about emptying a big basket of comforts, and filling it up with
514	"good deeds?"""
514	""
514	"""With all my heart, if you will be a brave St.  Martin, stopping as you"
514	"ride gallantly through the world to share your cloak with the beggar."""
514	""
514	"""It's a bargain, and we shall get the best of it!"""
514	""
514	So the young pair shook hands upon it, and then paced happily on again,
514	feeling that their pleasant home was more homelike because they hoped
514	to brighten other homes, believing that their own feet would walk more
514	uprightly along the flowery path before them, if they smoothed rough
514	ways for other feet, and feeling that their hearts were more closely
514	knit together by a love which could tenderly remember those less blest
514	than they.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-FIVE
514	""
514	DAISY AND DEMI
514	""
514	I cannot feel that I have done my duty as humble historian of the March
514	family, without devoting at least one chapter to the two most precious
514	and important members of it.  Daisy and Demi had now arrived at years
514	of discretion, for in this fast age babies of three or four assert
514	their rights, and get them, too, which is more than many of their
514	elders do.  If there ever were a pair of twins in danger of being
514	utterly spoiled by adoration, it was these prattling Brookes.  Of
514	course they were the most remarkable children ever born, as will be
514	shown when I mention that they walked at eight months, talked fluently
514	at twelve months, and at two years they took their places at table, and
514	behaved with a propriety which charmed all beholders. At three, Daisy
514	demanded a 'needler', and actually made a bag with four stitches in it.
514	She likewise set up housekeeping in the sideboard, and managed a
514	microscopic cooking stove with a skill that brought tears of pride to
514	Hannah's eyes, while Demi learned his letters with his grandfather, who
514	invented a new mode of teaching the alphabet by forming letters with
514	his arms and legs, thus uniting gymnastics for head and heels.  The boy
514	early developed a mechanical genius which delighted his father and
514	distracted his mother, for he tried to imitate every machine he saw,
514	and kept the nursery in a chaotic condition, with his 'sewinsheen', a
514	mysterious structure of string, chairs, clothespins, and spools, for
514	wheels to go 'wound and wound'.  Also a basket hung over the back of a
514	chair, in which he vainly tried to hoist his too confiding sister, who,
514	with feminine devotion, allowed her little head to be bumped till
514	"rescued, when the young inventor indignantly remarked, ""Why, Marmar,"
514	"dat's my lellywaiter, and me's trying to pull her up."""
514	""
514	Though utterly unlike in character, the twins got on remarkably well
514	together, and seldom quarreled more than thrice a day.  Of course, Demi
514	tyrannized over Daisy, and gallantly defended her from every other
514	aggressor, while Daisy made a galley slave of herself, and adored her
514	brother as the one perfect being in the world.  A rosy, chubby,
514	sunshiny little soul was Daisy, who found her way to everybody's heart,
514	and nestled there.  One of the captivating children, who seem made to
514	be kissed and cuddled, adorned and adored like little goddesses, and
514	produced for general approval on all festive occasions. Her small
514	virtues were so sweet that she would have been quite angelic if a few
514	small naughtinesses had not kept her delightfully human.  It was all
514	fair weather in her world, and every morning she scrambled up to the
514	window in her little nightgown to look out, and say, no matter whether
514	"it rained or shone, ""Oh, pitty day, oh, pitty day!"" Everyone was a"
514	friend, and she offered kisses to a stranger so confidingly that the
514	most inveterate bachelor relented, and baby-lovers became faithful
514	worshipers.
514	""
514	"""Me loves evvybody,"" she once said, opening her arms, with her spoon in"
514	one hand, and her mug in the other, as if eager to embrace and nourish
514	the whole world.
514	""
514	As she grew, her mother began to feel that the Dovecote would be
514	blessed by the presence of an inmate as serene and loving as that which
514	had helped to make the old house home, and to pray that she might be
514	spared a loss like that which had lately taught them how long they had
514	entertained an angel unawares.  Her grandfather often called her
514	'Beth', and her grandmother watched over her with untiring devotion, as
514	if trying to atone for some past mistake, which no eye but her own
514	could see.
514	""
514	Demi, like a true Yankee, was of an inquiring turn, wanting to know
514	everything, and often getting much disturbed because he could not get
514	"satisfactory answers to his perpetual ""What for?"""
514	""
514	He also possessed a philosophic bent, to the great delight of his
514	grandfather, who used to hold Socratic conversations with him, in which
514	the precocious pupil occasionally posed his teacher, to the undisguised
514	satisfaction of the womenfolk.
514	""
514	"""What makes my legs go, Dranpa?"" asked the young philosopher, surveying"
514	those active portions of his frame with a meditative air, while resting
514	after a go-to-bed frolic one night.
514	""
514	"""It's your little mind, Demi,"" replied the sage, stroking the yellow"
514	head respectfully.
514	""
514	"""What is a little mine?"""
514	""
514	"""It is something which makes your body move, as the spring made the"
514	"wheels go in my watch when I showed it to you."""
514	""
514	"""Open me.  I want to see it go wound."""
514	""
514	"""I can't do that any more than you could open the watch.  God winds you"
514	"up, and you go till He stops you."""
514	""
514	"""Does I?"" and Demi's brown eyes grew big and bright as he took in the"
514	"new thought.  ""Is I wounded up like the watch?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, but I can't show you how, for it is done when we don't see."""
514	""
514	Demi felt his back, as if expecting to find it like that of the watch,
514	"and then gravely remarked, ""I dess Dod does it when I's asleep."""
514	""
514	A careful explanation followed, to which he listened so attentively
514	"that his anxious grandmother said, ""My dear, do you think it wise to"
514	talk about such things to that baby?  He's getting great bumps over his
514	"eyes, and learning to ask the most unanswerable questions."""
514	""
514	"""If he is old enough to ask the question he is old enough to receive"
514	true answers.  I am not putting the thoughts into his head, but helping
514	him unfold those already there.  These children are wiser than we are,
514	and I have no doubt the boy understands every word I have said to him.
514	"Now, Demi, tell me where you keep your mind."""
514	""
514	"If the boy had replied like Alcibiades, ""By the gods, Socrates, I"
514	"cannot tell,"" his grandfather would not have been surprised, but when,"
514	after standing a moment on one leg, like a meditative young stork, he
514	"answered, in a tone of calm conviction, ""In my little belly,"" the old"
514	gentleman could only join in Grandma's laugh, and dismiss the class in
514	metaphysics.
514	""
514	There might have been cause for maternal anxiety, if Demi had not given
514	convincing proofs that he was a true boy, as well as a budding
514	philosopher, for often, after a discussion which caused Hannah to
514	"prophesy, with ominous nods, ""That child ain't long for this world,"" he"
514	would turn about and set her fears at rest by some of the pranks with
514	which dear, dirty, naughty little rascals distract and delight their
514	parent's souls.
514	""
514	Meg made many moral rules, and tried to keep them, but what mother was
514	ever proof against the winning wiles, the ingenious evasions, or the
514	tranquil audacity of the miniature men and women who so early show
514	themselves accomplished Artful Dodgers?
514	""
514	"""No more raisins, Demi.  They'll make you sick,"" says Mamma to the"
514	young person who offers his services in the kitchen with unfailing
514	regularity on plum-pudding day.
514	""
514	"""Me likes to be sick."""
514	""
514	"""I don't want to have you, so run away and help Daisy make patty cakes."""
514	""
514	He reluctantly departs, but his wrongs weigh upon his spirit, and
514	by-and-by when an opportunity comes to redress them, he outwits Mamma
514	by a shrewd bargain.
514	""
514	"""Now you have been good children, and I'll play anything you like,"""
514	says Meg, as she leads her assistant cooks upstairs, when the pudding
514	is safely bouncing in the pot.
514	""
514	"""Truly, Marmar?"" asks Demi, with a brilliant idea in his well-powdered"
514	head.
514	""
514	"""Yes, truly.  Anything you say,"" replies the shortsighted parent,"
514	"preparing herself to sing, ""The Three Little Kittens"" half a dozen"
514	"times over, or to take her family to ""Buy a penny bun,"" regardless of"
514	wind or limb.  But Demi corners her by the cool reply...
514	""
514	"""Then we'll go and eat up all the raisins."""
514	""
514	Aunt Dodo was chief playmate and confidante of both children, and the
514	trio turned the little house topsy-turvy.  Aunt Amy was as yet only a
514	name to them, Aunt Beth soon faded into a pleasantly vague memory, but
514	Aunt Dodo was a living reality, and they made the most of her, for
514	which compliment she was deeply grateful.  But when Mr. Bhaer came, Jo
514	neglected her playfellows, and dismay and desolation fell upon their
514	little souls.  Daisy, who was fond of going about peddling kisses, lost
514	her best customer and became bankrupt.  Demi, with infantile
514	penetration, soon discovered that Dodo like to play with 'the bear-man'
514	better than she did him, but though hurt, he concealed his anguish, for
514	he hadn't the heart to insult a rival who kept a mine of chocolate
514	drops in his waistcoat pocket, and a watch that could be taken out of
514	its case and freely shaken by ardent admirers.
514	""
514	Some persons might have considered these pleasing liberties as bribes,
514	but Demi didn't see it in that light, and continued to patronize the
514	'the bear-man' with pensive affability, while Daisy bestowed her small
514	affections upon him at the third call, and considered his shoulder her
514	throne, his arm her refuge, his gifts treasures surpassing worth.
514	""
514	Gentlemen are sometimes seized with sudden fits of admiration for the
514	young relatives of ladies whom they honor with their regard, but this
514	counterfeit philoprogenitiveness sits uneasily upon them, and does not
514	deceive anybody a particle.  Mr. Bhaer's devotion was sincere, however
514	likewise effective--for honesty is the best policy in love as in law.
514	He was one of the men who are at home with children, and looked
514	particularly well when little faces made a pleasant contrast with his
514	manly one.  His business, whatever it was, detained him from day to
514	day, but evening seldom failed to bring him out to see--well, he always
514	asked for Mr. March, so I suppose he was the attraction.  The excellent
514	papa labored under the delusion that he was, and reveled in long
514	discussions with the kindred spirit, till a chance remark of his more
514	observing grandson suddenly enlightened him.
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer came in one evening to pause on the threshold of the study,
514	astonished by the spectacle that met his eye.  Prone upon the floor lay
514	Mr. March, with his respectable legs in the air, and beside him,
514	likewise prone, was Demi, trying to imitate the attitude with his own
514	short, scarlet-stockinged legs, both grovelers so seriously absorbed
514	that they were unconscious of spectators, till Mr. Bhaer laughed his
514	sonorous laugh, and Jo cried out, with a scandalized face...
514	""
514	"""Father, Father, here's the Professor!"""
514	""
514	Down went the black legs and up came the gray head, as the preceptor
514	"said, with undisturbed dignity, ""Good evening, Mr. Bhaer. Excuse me for"
514	a moment.  We are just finishing our lesson.  Now, Demi, make the
514	"letter and tell its name."""
514	""
514	"""I knows him!"" and, after a few convulsive efforts, the red legs took"
514	the shape of a pair of compasses, and the intelligent pupil
514	"triumphantly shouted, ""It's a We, Dranpa, it's a We!"""
514	""
514	"""He's a born Weller,"" laughed Jo, as her parent gathered himself up,"
514	and her nephew tried to stand on his head, as the only mode of
514	expressing his satisfaction that school was over.
514	""
514	"""What have you been at today, bubchen?"" asked Mr. Bhaer, picking up the"
514	gymnast.
514	""
514	"""Me went to see little Mary."""
514	""
514	"""And what did you there?"""
514	""
514	"""I kissed her,"" began Demi, with artless frankness."
514	""
514	"""Prut!  Thou beginnest early.  What did the little Mary say to that?"""
514	asked Mr. Bhaer, continuing to confess the young sinner, who stood upon
514	the knee, exploring the waistcoat pocket.
514	""
514	"""Oh, she liked it, and she kissed me, and I liked it.  Don't little"
514	"boys like little girls?"" asked Demi, with his mouth full, and an air of"
514	bland satisfaction.
514	""
514	"""You precocious chick!  Who put that into your head?"" said Jo, enjoying"
514	the innocent revelation as much as the Professor.
514	""
514	"""'Tisn't in mine head, it's in mine mouf,"" answered literal Demi,"
514	putting out his tongue, with a chocolate drop on it, thinking she
514	alluded to confectionery, not ideas.
514	""
514	"""Thou shouldst save some for the little friend.  Sweets to the sweet,"
514	"mannling,"" and Mr. Bhaer offered Jo some, with a look that made her"
514	wonder if chocolate was not the nectar drunk by the gods.  Demi also
514	saw the smile, was impressed by it, and artlessy inquired.  ..
514	""
514	"""Do great boys like great girls, to, 'Fessor?"""
514	""
514	Like young Washington, Mr. Bhaer 'couldn't tell a lie', so he gave the
514	somewhat vague reply that he believed they did sometimes, in a tone
514	that made Mr. March put down his clothesbrush, glance at Jo's retiring
514	face, and then sink into his chair, looking as if the 'precocious
514	chick' had put an idea into his head that was both sweet and sour.
514	""
514	Why Dodo, when she caught him in the china closet half an hour
514	afterward, nearly squeezed the breath out of his little body with a
514	tender embrace, instead of shaking him for being there, and why she
514	followed up this novel performance by the unexpected gift of a big
514	slice of bread and jelly, remained one of the problems over which Demi
514	puzzled his small wits, and was forced to leave unsolved forever.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-SIX
514	""
514	UNDER THE UMBRELLA
514	""
514	While Laurie and Amy were taking conjugal strolls over velvet carpets,
514	as they set their house in order, and planned a blissful future, Mr.
514	Bhaer and Jo were enjoying promenades of a different sort, along muddy
514	roads and sodden fields.
514	""
514	"""I always do take a walk toward evening, and I don't know why I should"
514	give it up, just because I happen to meet the Professor on his way
514	"out,"" said Jo to herself, after two or three encounters, for though"
514	there were two paths to Meg's whichever one she took she was sure to
514	meet him, either going or returning. He was always walking rapidly, and
514	never seemed to see her until quite close, when he would look as if his
514	short-sighted eyes had failed to recognize the approaching lady till
514	that moment.  Then, if she was going to Meg's he always had something
514	for the babies.  If her face was turned homeward, he had merely
514	strolled down to see the river, and was just returning, unless they
514	were tired of his frequent calls.
514	""
514	Under the circumstances, what could Jo do but greet him civilly, and
514	invite him in?  If she was tired of his visits, she concealed her
514	weariness with perfect skill, and took care that there should be coffee
514	"for supper, ""as Friedrich--I mean Mr. Bhaer--doesn't like tea."""
514	""
514	By the second week, everyone knew perfectly well what was going on, yet
514	everyone tried to look as if they were stone-blind to the changes in
514	Jo's face.  They never asked why she sang about her work, did up her
514	hair three times a day, and got so blooming with her evening exercise.
514	And no one seemed to have the slightest suspicion that Professor Bhaer,
514	while talking philosophy with the father, was giving the daughter
514	lessons in love.
514	""
514	Jo couldn't even lose her heart in a decorous manner, but sternly tried
514	to quench her feelings, and failing to do so, led a somewhat agitated
514	life.  She was mortally afraid of being laughed at for surrendering,
514	after her many and vehement declarations of independence.  Laurie was
514	her especial dread, but thanks to the new manager, he behaved with
514	praiseworthy propriety, never called Mr. Bhaer 'a capital old fellow'
514	in public, never alluded, in the remotest manner, to Jo's improved
514	appearance, or expressed the least surprise at seeing the Professor's
514	hat on the Marches' table nearly every evening.  But he exulted in
514	private and longed for the time to come when he could give Jo a piece
514	of plate, with a bear and a ragged staff on it as an appropriate coat
514	of arms.
514	""
514	For a fortnight, the Professor came and went with lover-like
514	regularity.  Then he stayed away for three whole days, and made no
514	sign, a proceeding which caused everybody to look sober, and Jo to
514	become pensive, at first, and then--alas for romance--very cross.
514	""
514	"""Disgusted, I dare say, and gone home as suddenly as he came. It's"
514	nothing to me, of course, but I should think he would have come and bid
514	"us goodbye like a gentleman,"" she said to herself, with a despairing"
514	look at the gate, as she put on her things for the customary walk one
514	dull afternoon.
514	""
514	"""You'd better take the little umbrella, dear.  It looks like rain,"""
514	said her mother, observing that she had on her new bonnet, but not
514	alluding to the fact.
514	""
514	"""Yes, Marmee, do you want anything in town?  I've got to run in and get"
514	"some paper,"" returned Jo, pulling out the bow under her chin before the"
514	glass as an excuse for not looking at her mother.
514	""
514	"""Yes, I want some twilled silesia, a paper of number nine needles, and"
514	two yards of narrow lavender ribbon.  Have you got your thick boots on,
514	"and something warm under your cloak?"""
514	""
514	"""I believe so,"" answered Jo absently."
514	""
514	"""If you happen to meet Mr. Bhaer, bring him home to tea. I quite long"
514	"to see the dear man,"" added Mrs. March."
514	""
514	Jo heard that, but made no answer, except to kiss her mother, and walk
514	rapidly away, thinking with a glow of gratitude, in spite of her
514	"heartache, ""How good she is to me! What do girls do who haven't any"
514	"mothers to help them through their troubles?"""
514	""
514	The dry-goods stores were not down among the counting-houses, banks,
514	and wholesale warerooms, where gentlemen most do congregate, but Jo
514	found herself in that part of the city before she did a single errand,
514	loitering along as if waiting for someone, examining engineering
514	instruments in one window and samples of wool in another, with most
514	unfeminine interest, tumbling over barrels, being half-smothered by
514	descending bales, and hustled unceremoniously by busy men who looked as
514	if they wondered 'how the deuce she got there'.  A drop of rain on her
514	cheek recalled her thoughts from baffled hopes to ruined ribbons.  For
514	the drops continued to fall, and being a woman as well as a lover, she
514	felt that, though it was too late to save her heart, she might her
514	bonnet.  Now she remembered the little umbrella, which she had
514	forgotten to take in her hurry to be off, but regret was unavailing,
514	and nothing could be done but borrow one or submit to a drenching.  She
514	looked up at the lowering sky, down at the crimson bow already flecked
514	with black, forward along the muddy street, then one long, lingering
514	look behind, at a certain grimy warehouse, with 'Hoffmann, Swartz, &
514	Co.' over the door, and said to herself, with a sternly reproachful
514	air...
514	""
514	"""It serves me right! what business had I to put on all my best things"
514	and come philandering down here, hoping to see the Professor?  Jo, I'm
514	ashamed of you!  No, you shall not go there to borrow an umbrella, or
514	find out where he is, from his friends. You shall trudge away, and do
514	your errands in the rain, and if you catch your death and ruin your
514	"bonnet, it's no more than you deserve.  Now then!"""
514	""
514	With that she rushed across the street so impetuously that she narrowly
514	escaped annihilation from a passing truck, and precipitated herself
514	"into the arms of a stately old gentleman, who said, ""I beg pardon,"
514	"ma'am,"" and looked mortally offended.  Somewhat daunted, Jo righted"
514	herself, spread her handkerchief over the devoted ribbons, and putting
514	temptation behind her, hurried on, with increasing dampness about the
514	ankles, and much clashing of umbrellas overhead.  The fact that a
514	somewhat dilapidated blue one remained stationary above the unprotected
514	bonnet attracted her attention, and looking up, she saw Mr. Bhaer
514	looking down.
514	""
514	"""I feel to know the strong-minded lady who goes so bravely under many"
514	horse noses, and so fast through much mud.  What do you down here, my
514	"friend?"""
514	""
514	"""I'm shopping."""
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer smiled, as he glanced from the pickle factory on one side to
514	the wholesale hide and leather concern on the other, but he only said
514	"politely, ""You haf no umbrella.  May I go also, and take for you the"
514	"bundles?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, thank you."""
514	""
514	Jo's cheeks were as red as her ribbon, and she wondered what he thought
514	of her, but she didn't care, for in a minute she found herself walking
514	away arm in arm with her Professor, feeling as if the sun had suddenly
514	burst out with uncommon brilliancy, that the world was all right again,
514	and that one thoroughly happy woman was paddling through the wet that
514	day.
514	""
514	"""We thought you had gone,"" said Jo hastily, for she knew he was looking"
