514	at her.  Her bonnet wasn't big enough to hide her face, and she feared
514	he might think the joy it betrayed unmaidenly.
514	""
514	"""Did you believe that I should go with no farewell to those who haf"
514	"been so heavenly kind to me?"" he asked so reproachfully that she felt"
514	as if she had insulted him by the suggestion, and answered heartily...
514	""
514	"""No, I didn't.  I knew you were busy about your own affairs, but we"
514	"rather missed you, Father and Mother especially."""
514	""
514	"""And you?"""
514	""
514	"""I'm always glad to see you, sir."""
514	""
514	In her anxiety to keep her voice quite calm, Jo made it rather cool,
514	and the frosty little monosyllable at the end seemed to chill the
514	Professor, for his smile vanished, as he said gravely...
514	""
514	"""I thank you, and come one more time before I go."""
514	""
514	"""You are going, then?"""
514	""
514	"""I haf no longer any business here, it is done."""
514	""
514	"""Successfully, I hope?"" said Jo, for the bitterness of disappointment"
514	was in that short reply of his.
514	""
514	"""I ought to think so, for I haf a way opened to me by which I can make"
514	"my bread and gif my Junglings much help."""
514	""
514	"""Tell me, please!  I like to know all about the--the boys,"" said Jo"
514	eagerly.
514	""
514	"""That is so kind, I gladly tell you.  My friends find for me a place in"
514	a college, where I teach as at home, and earn enough to make the way
514	smooth for Franz and Emil.  For this I should be grateful, should I
514	"not?"""
514	""
514	"""Indeed you should.  How splendid it will be to have you doing what you"
514	"like, and be able to see you often, and the boys!"" cried Jo, clinging"
514	to the lads as an excuse for the satisfaction she could not help
514	betraying.
514	""
514	"""Ah!  But we shall not meet often, I fear, this place is at the West."""
514	""
514	"""So far away!"" and Jo left her skirts to their fate, as if it didn't"
514	matter now what became of her clothes or herself.
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer could read several languages, but he had not learned to read
514	women yet.  He flattered himself that he knew Jo pretty well, and was,
514	therefore, much amazed by the contradictions of voice, face, and
514	manner, which she showed him in rapid succession that day, for she was
514	in half a dozen different moods in the course of half an hour.  When
514	she met him she looked surprised, though it was impossible to help
514	suspecting that she had come for that express purpose.  When he offered
514	her his arm, she took it with a look that filled him with delight, but
514	when he asked if she missed him, she gave such a chilly, formal reply
514	that despair fell upon him.  On learning his good fortune she almost
514	clapped her hands.  Was the joy all for the boys? Then on hearing his
514	"destination, she said, ""So far away!"" in a tone of despair that lifted"
514	him on to a pinnacle of hope, but the next minute she tumbled him down
514	again by observing, like one entirely absorbed in the matter...
514	""
514	"""Here's the place for my errands.  Will you come in? It won't take"
514	"long."""
514	""
514	Jo rather prided herself upon her shopping capabilities, and
514	particularly wished to impress her escort with the neatness and
514	dispatch with which she would accomplish the business. But owing to the
514	flutter she was in, everything went amiss. She upset the tray of
514	needles, forgot the silesia was to be 'twilled' till it was cut off,
514	gave the wrong change, and covered herself with confusion by asking for
514	lavender ribbon at the calico counter.  Mr. Bhaer stood by, watching
514	her blush and blunder, and as he watched, his own bewilderment seemed
514	to subside, for he was beginning to see that on some occasions, women,
514	like dreams, go by contraries.
514	""
514	When they came out, he put the parcel under his arm with a more
514	cheerful aspect, and splashed through the puddles as if he rather
514	enjoyed it on the whole.
514	""
514	"""Should we no do a little what you call shopping for the babies, and"
514	haf a farewell feast tonight if I go for my last call at your so
514	"pleasant home?"" he asked, stopping before a window full of fruit and"
514	flowers.
514	""
514	"""What will we buy?"" asked Jo, ignoring the latter part of his speech,"
514	and sniffing the mingled odors with an affectation of delight as they
514	went in.
514	""
514	"""May they haf oranges and figs?"" asked Mr. Bhaer, with a paternal air."
514	""
514	"""They eat them when they can get them."""
514	""
514	"""Do you care for nuts?"""
514	""
514	"""Like a squirrel."""
514	""
514	"""Hamburg grapes.  Yes, we shall drink to the Fatherland in those?"""
514	""
514	Jo frowned upon that piece of extravagance, and asked why he didn't buy
514	a frail of dates, a cask of raisins, and a bag of almonds, and be done
514	with it?  Whereat Mr. Bhaer confiscated her purse, produced his own,
514	and finished the marketing by buying several pounds of grapes, a pot of
514	rosy daisies, and a pretty jar of honey, to be regarded in the light of
514	a demijohn.  Then distorting his pockets with knobby bundles, and
514	giving her the flowers to hold, he put up the old umbrella, and they
514	traveled on again.
514	""
514	"""Miss Marsch, I haf a great favor to ask of you,"" began the Professor,"
514	after a moist promenade of half a block.
514	""
514	"""Yes, sir?"" and Jo's heart began to beat so hard she was afraid he"
514	would hear it.
514	""
514	"""I am bold to say it in spite of the rain, because so short a time"
514	"remains to me."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, sir,"" and Jo nearly crushed the small flowerpot with the sudden"
514	squeeze she gave it.
514	""
514	"""I wish to get a little dress for my Tina, and I am too stupid to go"
514	"alone.  Will you kindly gif me a word of taste and help?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, sir,"" and Jo felt as calm and cool all of a sudden as if she had"
514	stepped into a refrigerator.
514	""
514	"""Perhaps also a shawl for Tina's mother, she is so poor and sick, and"
514	the husband is such a care.  Yes, yes, a thick, warm shawl would be a
514	"friendly thing to take the little mother."""
514	""
514	"""I'll do it with pleasure, Mr. Bhaer.""  ""I'm going very fast, and he's"
514	"getting dearer every minute,"" added Jo to herself, then with a mental"
514	shake she entered into the business with an energy that was pleasant to
514	behold.
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer left it all to her, so she chose a pretty gown for Tina, and
514	then ordered out the shawls.  The clerk, being a married man,
514	condescended to take an interest in the couple, who appeared to be
514	shopping for their family.
514	""
514	"""Your lady may prefer this.  It's a superior article, a most desirable"
514	"color, quite chaste and genteel,"" he said, shaking out a comfortable"
514	gray shawl, and throwing it over Jo's shoulders.
514	""
514	"""Does this suit you, Mr. Bhaer?"" she asked, turning her back to him,"
514	and feeling deeply grateful for the chance of hiding her face.
514	""
514	"""Excellently well, we will haf it,"" answered the Professor, smiling to"
514	himself as he paid for it, while Jo continued to rummage the counters
514	like a confirmed bargain-hunter.
514	""
514	"""Now shall we go home?"" he asked, as if the words were very pleasant to"
514	him.
514	""
514	"""Yes, it's late, and I'm _so_ tired."" Jo's voice was more pathetic than"
514	she knew.  For now the sun seemed to have gone in as suddenly as it
514	came out, and the world grew muddy and miserable again, and for the
514	first time she discovered that her feet were cold, her head ached, and
514	that her heart was colder than the former, fuller of pain than the
514	latter.  Mr. Bhaer was going away, he only cared for her as a friend,
514	it was all a mistake, and the sooner it was over the better.  With this
514	idea in her head, she hailed an approaching omnibus with such a hasty
514	gesture that the daisies flew out of the pot and were badly damaged.
514	""
514	"""This is not our omniboos,"" said the Professor, waving the loaded"
514	vehicle away, and stopping to pick up the poor little flowers.
514	""
514	"""I beg your pardon.  I didn't see the name distinctly.  Never mind, I"
514	"can walk.  I'm used to plodding in the mud,"" returned Jo, winking hard,"
514	because she would have died rather than openly wipe her eyes.
514	""
514	Mr. Bhaer saw the drops on her cheeks, though she turned her head away.
514	The sight seemed to touch him very much, for suddenly stooping down, he
514	"asked in a tone that meant a great deal, ""Heart's dearest, why do you"
514	"cry?"""
514	""
514	Now, if Jo had not been new to this sort of thing she would have said
514	she wasn't crying, had a cold in her head, or told any other feminine
514	fib proper to the occasion.  Instead of which, that undignified
514	"creature answered, with an irrepressible sob, ""Because you are going"
514	"away."""
514	""
514	"""Ach, mein Gott, that is so good!"" cried Mr. Bhaer, managing to clasp"
514	"his hands in spite of the umbrella and the bundles, ""Jo, I haf nothing"
514	but much love to gif you.  I came to see if you could care for it, and
514	I waited to be sure that I was something more than a friend.  Am I?
514	"Can you make a little place in your heart for old Fritz?"" he added, all"
514	in one breath.
514	""
514	"""Oh, yes!"" said Jo, and he was quite satisfied, for she folded both"
514	hands over his arm, and looked up at him with an expression that
514	plainly showed how happy she would be to walk through life beside him,
514	even though she had no better shelter than the old umbrella, if he
514	carried it.
514	""
514	It was certainly proposing under difficulties, for even if he had
514	desired to do so, Mr. Bhaer could not go down upon his knees, on
514	account of the mud.  Neither could he offer Jo his hand, except
514	figuratively, for both were full.  Much less could he indulge in tender
514	remonstrations in the open street, though he was near it.  So the only
514	way in which he could express his rapture was to look at her, with an
514	expression which glorified his face to such a degree that there
514	actually seemed to be little rainbows in the drops that sparkled on his
514	beard.  If he had not loved Jo very much, I don't think he could have
514	done it then, for she looked far from lovely, with her skirts in a
514	deplorable state, her rubber boots splashed to the ankle, and her
514	bonnet a ruin.  Fortunately, Mr. Bhaer considered her the most
514	"beautiful woman living, and she found him more ""Jove-like"" than ever,"
514	though his hatbrim was quite limp with the little rills trickling
514	thence upon his shoulders (for he held the umbrella all over Jo), and
514	every finger of his gloves needed mending.
514	""
514	Passers-by probably thought them a pair of harmless lunatics, for they
514	entirely forgot to hail a bus, and strolled leisurely along, oblivious
514	of deepening dusk and fog.  Little they cared what anybody thought, for
514	they were enjoying the happy hour that seldom comes but once in any
514	life, the magical moment which bestows youth on the old, beauty on the
514	plain, wealth on the poor, and gives human hearts a foretaste of
514	heaven. The Professor looked as if he had conquered a kingdom, and the
514	world had nothing more to offer him in the way of bliss.  While Jo
514	trudged beside him, feeling as if her place had always been there, and
514	wondering how she ever could have chosen any other lot.  Of course, she
514	was the first to speak--intelligibly, I mean, for the emotional remarks
514	"which followed her impetuous ""Oh, yes!"" were not of a coherent or"
514	reportable character.
514	""
514	"""Friedrich, why didn't you..."""
514	""
514	"""Ah, heaven, she gifs me the name that no one speaks since Minna died!"""
514	cried the Professor, pausing in a puddle to regard her with grateful
514	delight.
514	""
514	"""I always call you so to myself--I forgot, but I won't unless you like"
514	"it."""
514	""
514	"""Like it?  It is more sweet to me than I can tell.  Say 'thou', also,"
514	"and I shall say your language is almost as beautiful as mine."""
514	""
514	"""Isn't 'thou' a little sentimental?"" asked Jo, privately thinking it a"
514	lovely monosyllable.
514	""
514	"""Sentimental? Yes.  Thank Gott, we Germans believe in sentiment, and"
514	keep ourselves young mit it.  Your English 'you' is so cold, say
514	"'thou', heart's dearest, it means so much to me,"" pleaded Mr. Bhaer,"
514	more like a romantic student than a grave professor.
514	""
514	"""Well, then, why didn't thou tell me all this sooner?"" asked Jo"
514	bashfully.
514	""
514	"""Now I shall haf to show thee all my heart, and I so gladly will,"
514	because thou must take care of it hereafter.  See, then, my Jo--ah, the
514	dear, funny little name--I had a wish to tell something the day I said
514	goodbye in New York, but I thought the handsome friend was betrothed to
514	thee, and so I spoke not.  Wouldst thou have said 'Yes', then, if I had
514	"spoken?"""
514	""
514	"""I don't know.  I'm afraid not, for I didn't have any heart just then."""
514	""
514	"""Prut!  That I do not believe.  It was asleep till the fairy prince"
514	came through the wood, and waked it up.  Ah, well, 'Die erste Liebe ist
514	"die beste', but that I should not expect."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, the first love is the best, but be so contented, for I never had"
514	"another.  Teddy was only a boy, and soon got over his little fancy,"""
514	said Jo, anxious to correct the Professor's mistake.
514	""
514	"""Good!  Then I shall rest happy, and be sure that thou givest me all."
514	I haf waited so long, I am grown selfish, as thou wilt find,
514	"Professorin."""
514	""
514	"""I like that,"" cried Jo, delighted with her new name.  ""Now tell me"
514	"what brought you, at last, just when I wanted you?"""
514	""
514	"""This,"" and Mr. Bhaer took a little worn paper out of his waistcoat"
514	pocket.
514	""
514	Jo unfolded it, and looked much abashed, for it was one of her own
514	contributions to a paper that paid for poetry, which accounted for her
514	sending it an occasional attempt.
514	""
514	"""How could that bring you?"" she asked, wondering what he meant."
514	""
514	"""I found it by chance.  I knew it by the names and the initials, and in"
514	it there was one little verse that seemed to call me.  Read and find
514	"him.  I will see that you go not in the wet."""
514	""
514	""
514	    IN THE GARRET
514	""
514	    Four little chests all in a row,
514	    Dim with dust, and worn by time,
514	    All fashioned and filled, long ago,
514	    By children now in their prime.
514	    Four little keys hung side by side,
514	    With faded ribbons, brave and gay
514	    When fastened there, with childish pride,
514	    Long ago, on a rainy day.
514	    Four little names, one on each lid,
514	    Carved out by a boyish hand,
514	    And underneath there lieth hid
514	    Histories of the happy band
514	    Once playing here, and pausing oft
514	    To hear the sweet refrain,
514	    That came and went on the roof aloft,
514	    In the falling summer rain.
514	""
514	"    ""Meg"" on the first lid, smooth and fair."
514	    I look in with loving eyes,
514	    For folded here, with well-known care,
514	    A goodly gathering lies,
514	    The record of a peaceful life--
514	    Gifts to gentle child and girl,
514	    A bridal gown, lines to a wife,
514	    A tiny shoe, a baby curl.
514	    No toys in this first chest remain,
514	    For all are carried away,
514	    In their old age, to join again
514	    In another small Meg's play.
514	    Ah, happy mother!  Well I know
514	    You hear, like a sweet refrain,
514	    Lullabies ever soft and low
514	    In the falling summer rain.
514	""
514	"    ""Jo"" on the next lid, scratched and worn,"
514	    And within a motley store
514	    Of headless dolls, of schoolbooks torn,
514	    Birds and beasts that speak no more,
514	    Spoils brought home from the fairy ground
514	    Only trod by youthful feet,
514	    Dreams of a future never found,
514	    Memories of a past still sweet,
514	    Half-writ poems, stories wild,
514	    April letters, warm and cold,
514	    Diaries of a wilful child,
514	    Hints of a woman early old,
514	    A woman in a lonely home,
514	    Hearing, like a sad refrain--
514	"    ""Be worthy, love, and love will come,"""
514	    In the falling summer rain.
514	""
514	    My Beth!  the dust is always swept
514	    From the lid that bears your name,
514	    As if by loving eyes that wept,
514	    By careful hands that often came.
514	    Death canonized for us one saint,
514	    Ever less human than divine,
514	    And still we lay, with tender plaint,
514	    Relics in this household shrine--
514	    The silver bell, so seldom rung,
514	    The little cap which last she wore,
514	    The fair, dead Catherine that hung
514	    By angels borne above her door.
514	    The songs she sang, without lament,
514	    In her prison-house of pain,
514	    Forever are they sweetly blent
514	    With the falling summer rain.
514	""
514	    Upon the last lid's polished field--
514	    Legend now both fair and true
514	    A gallant knight bears on his shield,
514	"    ""Amy"" in letters gold and blue."
514	    Within lie snoods that bound her hair,
514	    Slippers that have danced their last,
514	    Faded flowers laid by with care,
514	    Fans whose airy toils are past,
514	    Gay valentines, all ardent flames,
514	    Trifles that have borne their part
514	    In girlish hopes and fears and shames,
514	    The record of a maiden heart
514	    Now learning fairer, truer spells,
514	    Hearing, like a blithe refrain,
514	    The silver sound of bridal bells
514	    In the falling summer rain.
514	""
514	    Four little chests all in a row,
514	    Dim with dust, and worn by time,
514	    Four women, taught by weal and woe
514	    To love and labor in their prime.
514	    Four sisters, parted for an hour,
514	    None lost, one only gone before,
514	    Made by love's immortal power,
514	    Nearest and dearest evermore.
514	    Oh, when these hidden stores of ours
514	    Lie open to the Father's sight,
514	    May they be rich in golden hours,
514	    Deeds that show fairer for the light,
514	    Lives whose brave music long shall ring,
514	    Like a spirit-stirring strain,
514	    Souls that shall gladly soar and sing
514	    In the long sunshine after rain.
514	""
514	"""It's very bad poetry, but I felt it when I wrote it, one day when I"
514	was very lonely, and had a good cry on a rag bag.  I never thought it
514	"would go where it could tell tales,"" said Jo, tearing up the verses the"
514	Professor had treasured so long.
514	""
514	"""Let it go, it has done its duty, and I will haf a fresh one when I"
514	"read all the brown book in which she keeps her little secrets,"" said"
514	Mr. Bhaer with a smile as he watched the fragments fly away on the
514	"wind.  ""Yes,"" he added earnestly, ""I read that, and I think to myself,"
514	She has a sorrow, she is lonely, she would find comfort in true love.
514	I haf a heart full, full for her.  Shall I not go and say, 'If this is
514	not too poor a thing to gif for what I shall hope to receive, take it
514	"in Gott's name?'"""
514	""
514	"""And so you came to find that it was not too poor, but the one precious"
514	"thing I needed,"" whispered Jo."
514	""
514	"""I had no courage to think that at first, heavenly kind as was your"
514	welcome to me.  But soon I began to hope, and then I said, 'I will haf
514	"her if I die for it,' and so I will!"" cried Mr. Bhaer, with a defiant"
514	nod, as if the walls of mist closing round them were barriers which he
514	was to surmount or valiantly knock down.
514	""
514	Jo thought that was splendid, and resolved to be worthy of her knight,
514	though he did not come prancing on a charger in gorgeous array.
514	""
514	"""What made you stay away so long?"" she asked presently, finding it so"
514	pleasant to ask confidential questions and get delightful answers that
514	she could not keep silent.
514	""
514	"""It was not easy, but I could not find the heart to take you from that"
514	so happy home until I could haf a prospect of one to gif you, after
514	much time, perhaps, and hard work.  How could I ask you to gif up so
514	"much for a poor old fellow, who has no fortune but a little learning?"""
514	""
514	"""I'm glad you are poor.  I couldn't bear a rich husband,"" said Jo"
514	"decidedly, adding in a softer tone, ""Don't fear poverty. I've known it"
514	long enough to lose my dread and be happy working for those I love, and
514	don't call yourself old--forty is the prime of life.  I couldn't help
514	"loving you if you were seventy!"""
514	""
514	The Professor found that so touching that he would have been glad of
514	his handkerchief, if he could have got at it.  As he couldn't, Jo wiped
514	his eyes for him, and said, laughing, as she took away a bundle or
514	two...
514	""
514	"""I may be strong-minded, but no one can say I'm out of my sphere now,"
514	for woman's special mission is supposed to be drying tears and bearing
514	burdens.  I'm to carry my share, Friedrich, and help to earn the home.
514	"Make up your mind to that, or I'll never go,"" she added resolutely, as"
514	he tried to reclaim his load.
514	""
514	"""We shall see.  Haf you patience to wait a long time, Jo? I must go"
514	away and do my work alone.  I must help my boys first, because, even
514	for you, I may not break my word to Minna.  Can you forgif that, and be
514	"happy while we hope and wait?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I know I can, for we love one another, and that makes all the"
514	rest easy to bear.  I have my duty, also, and my work. I couldn't enjoy
514	myself if I neglected them even for you, so there's no need of hurry or
514	impatience.  You can do your part out West, I can do mine here, and
514	both be happy hoping for the best, and leaving the future to be as God
514	"wills."""
514	""
514	"""Ah! Thou gifest me such hope and courage, and I haf nothing to gif"
514	"back but a full heart and these empty hands,"" cried the Professor,"
514	quite overcome.
514	""
514	Jo never, never would learn to be proper, for when he said that as they
514	stood upon the steps, she just put both hands into his, whispering
514	"tenderly, ""Not empty now,"" and stooping down, kissed her Friedrich"
514	under the umbrella.  It was dreadful, but she would have done it if the
514	flock of draggle-tailed sparrows on the hedge had been human beings,
514	for she was very far gone indeed, and quite regardless of everything
514	but her own happiness. Though it came in such a very simple guise, that
514	was the crowning moment of both their lives, when, turning from the
514	night and storm and loneliness to the household light and warmth and
514	"peace waiting to receive them, with a glad ""Welcome home!""  Jo led her"
514	lover in, and shut the door.
514	""
514	""
514	""
514	CHAPTER FORTY-SEVEN
514	""
514	HARVEST TIME
514	""
514	For a year Jo and her Professor worked and waited, hoped and loved, met
514	occasionally, and wrote such voluminous letters that the rise in the
514	price of paper was accounted for, Laurie said.  The second year began
514	rather soberly, for their prospects did not brighten, and Aunt March
514	died suddenly.  But when their first sorrow was over--for they loved
514	the old lady in spite of her sharp tongue--they found they had cause
514	for rejoicing, for she had left Plumfield to Jo, which made all sorts
514	of joyful things possible.
514	""
514	"""It's a fine old place, and will bring a handsome sum, for of course"
514	"you intend to sell it,"" said Laurie, as they were all talking the"
514	matter over some weeks later.
514	""
514	"""No, I don't,"" was Jo's decided answer, as she petted the fat poodle,"
514	whom she had adopted, out of respect to his former mistress.
514	""
514	"""You don't mean to live there?"""
514	""
514	"""Yes, I do."""
514	""
514	"""But, my dear girl, it's an immense house, and will take a power of"
514	money to keep it in order.  The garden and orchard alone need two or
514	"three men, and farming isn't in Bhaer's line, I take it."""
514	""
514	"""He'll try his hand at it there, if I propose it."""
514	""
514	"""And you expect to live on the produce of the place?  Well, that sounds"
514	"paradisiacal, but you'll find it desperate hard work."""
514	""
514	"""The crop we are going to raise is a profitable one,"" and Jo laughed."
514	""
514	"""Of what is this fine crop to consist, ma'am?"""
514	""
514	"""Boys.  I want to open a school for little lads--a good, happy,"
514	"homelike school, with me to take care of them and Fritz to teach them."""
514	""
514	"""That's a truly Joian plan for you!  Isn't that just like her?"" cried"
514	Laurie, appealing to the family, who looked as much surprised as he.
514	""
514	"""I like it,"" said Mrs. March decidedly."
514	""
514	"""So do I,"" added her husband, who welcomed the thought of a chance for"
514	trying the Socratic method of education on modern youth.
514	""
514	"""It will be an immense care for Jo,"" said Meg, stroking the head of her"
514	one all-absorbing son.
514	""
514	"""Jo can do it, and be happy in it.  It's a splendid idea. Tell us all"
514	"about it,"" cried Mr. Laurence, who had been longing to lend the lovers"
514	a hand, but knew that they would refuse his help.
514	""
514	"""I knew you'd stand by me, sir.  Amy does too--I see it in her eyes,"
514	though she prudently waits to turn it over in her mind before she
514	"speaks.  Now, my dear people,"" continued Jo earnestly, ""just understand"
514	that this isn't a new idea of mine, but a long cherished plan.  Before
514	my Fritz came, I used to think how, when I'd made my fortune, and no
514	one needed me at home, I'd hire a big house, and pick up some poor,
514	forlorn little lads who hadn't any mothers, and take care of them, and
514	make life jolly for them before it was too late.  I see so many going
514	to ruin for want of help at the right minute, I love so to do anything
514	for them, I seem to feel their wants, and sympathize with their
514	"troubles, and oh, I should so like to be a mother to them!"""
514	""
514	Mrs. March held out her hand to Jo, who took it, smiling, with tears in
514	her eyes, and went on in the old enthusiastic way, which they had not
514	seen for a long while.
514	""
514	"""I told my plan to Fritz once, and he said it was just what he would"
514	like, and agreed to try it when we got rich.  Bless his dear heart,
514	he's been doing it all his life--helping poor boys, I mean, not getting
514	rich, that he'll never be.  Money doesn't stay in his pocket long
514	enough to lay up any.  But now, thanks to my good old aunt, who loved
514	me better than I ever deserved, I'm rich, at least I feel so, and we
514	can live at Plumfield perfectly well, if we have a flourishing school.
514	It's just the place for boys, the house is big, and the furniture
514	strong and plain.  There's plenty of room for dozens inside, and
514	splendid grounds outside. They could help in the garden and orchard.
514	Such work is healthy, isn't it, sir?  Then Fritz could train and teach
514	in his own way, and Father will help him.  I can feed and nurse and pet
514	and scold them, and Mother will be my stand-by.  I've always longed for
514	lots of boys, and never had enough, now I can fill the house full and
514	revel in the little dears to my heart's content.  Think what luxury--
514	"Plumfield my own, and a wilderness of boys to enjoy it with me."""
514	""
514	As Jo waved her hands and gave a sigh of rapture, the family went off
514	into a gale of merriment, and Mr. Laurence laughed till they thought
514	he'd have an apoplectic fit.
514	""
514	"""I don't see anything funny,"" she said gravely, when she could be"
514	"heard.  ""Nothing could be more natural and proper than for my Professor"
514	"to open a school, and for me to prefer to reside in my own estate."""
514	""
514	"""She is putting on airs already,"" said Laurie, who regarded the idea in"
514	"the light of a capital joke.  ""But may I inquire how you intend to"
514	support the establishment? If all the pupils are little ragamuffins,
514	I'm afraid your crop won't be profitable in a worldly sense, Mrs.
514	"Bhaer."""
514	""
514	"""Now don't be a wet-blanket, Teddy.  Of course I shall have rich"
514	pupils, also--perhaps begin with such altogether.  Then, when I've got
514	a start, I can take in a ragamuffin or two, just for a relish. Rich
514	people's children often need care and comfort, as well as poor. I've
514	seen unfortunate little creatures left to servants, or backward ones
514	pushed forward, when it's real cruelty.  Some are naughty through
514	mismanagment or neglect, and some lose their mothers. Besides, the best
514	have to get through the hobbledehoy age, and that's the very time they
514	need most patience and kindness.  People laugh at them, and hustle them
514	about, try to keep them out of sight, and expect them to turn all at
514	once from pretty children into fine young men.  They don't complain
514	much--plucky little souls--but they feel it.  I've been through
514	something of it, and I know all about it. I've a special interest in
514	such young bears, and like to show them that I see the warm, honest,
514	well-meaning boys' hearts, in spite of the clumsy arms and legs and the
514	topsy-turvy heads.  I've had experience, too, for haven't I brought up
514	"one boy to be a pride and honor to his family?"""
514	""
514	"""I'll testify that you tried to do it,"" said Laurie with a grateful"
514	look.
514	""
514	"""And I've succeeded beyond my hopes, for here you are, a steady,"
514	sensible businessman, doing heaps of good with your money, and laying
514	up the blessings of the poor, instead of dollars. But you are not
514	merely a businessman, you love good and beautiful things, enjoy them
514	yourself, and let others go halves, as you always did in the old times.
514	I am proud of you, Teddy, for you get better every year, and everyone
514	feels it, though you won't let them say so.  Yes, and when I have my
514	"flock, I'll just point to you, and say 'There's your model, my lads'."""
514	""
514	Poor Laurie didn't know where to look, for, man though he was,
514	something of the old bashfulness came over him as this burst of praise
514	made all faces turn approvingly upon him.
514	""
514	"""I say, Jo, that's rather too much,"" he began, just in his old boyish"
514	"way.  ""You have all done more for me than I can ever thank you for,"
514	except by doing my best not to disappoint you.  You have rather cast me
514	off lately, Jo, but I've had the best of help, nevertheless.  So, if
514	"I've got on at all, you may thank these two for it,"" and he laid one"
514	hand gently on his grandfather's head, and the other on Amy's golden
514	one, for the three were never far apart.
514	""
514	"""I do think that families are the most beautiful things in all the"
514	"world!"" burst out Jo, who was in an unusually up-lifted frame of mind"
514	"just then.  ""When I have one of my own, I hope it will be as happy as"
514	the three I know and love the best.  If John and my Fritz were only
514	"here, it would be quite a little heaven on earth,"" she added more"
514	quietly.  And that night when she went to her room after a blissful
514	evening of family counsels, hopes, and plans, her heart was so full of
514	happiness that she could only calm it by kneeling beside the empty bed
514	always near her own, and thinking tender thoughts of Beth.
514	""
514	It was a very astonishing year altogether, for things seemed to happen
514	in an unusually rapid and delightful manner.  Almost before she knew
514	where she was, Jo found herself married and settled at Plumfield.  Then
514	a family of six or seven boys sprung up like mushrooms, and flourished
514	surprisingly, poor boys as well as rich, for Mr. Laurence was
514	continually finding some touching case of destitution, and begging the
514	Bhaers to take pity on the child, and he would gladly pay a trifle for
514	its support.  In this way, the sly old gentleman got round proud Jo,
514	and furnished her with the style of boy in which she most delighted.
514	""
514	Of course it was uphill work at first, and Jo made queer mistakes, but
514	the wise Professor steered her safely into calmer waters, and the most
514	rampant ragamuffin was conquered in the end. How Jo did enjoy her
514	'wilderness of boys', and how poor, dear Aunt March would have lamented
514	had she been there to see the sacred precincts of prim, well-ordered
514	Plumfield overrun with Toms, Dicks, and Harrys!  There was a sort of
514	poetic justice about it, after all, for the old lady had been the
514	terror of the boys for miles around, and now the exiles feasted freely
514	on forbidden plums, kicked up the gravel with profane boots unreproved,
514	and played cricket in the big field where the irritable 'cow with a
514	crumpled horn' used to invite rash youths to come and be tossed.  It
514	became a sort of boys' paradise, and Laurie suggested that it should be
514	called the 'Bhaer-garten', as a compliment to its master and
514	appropriate to its inhabitants.
514	""
514	It never was a fashionable school, and the Professor did not lay up a
514	fortune, but it was just what Jo intended it to be--'a happy, homelike
514	place for boys, who needed teaching, care, and kindness'.  Every room
514	in the big house was soon full.  Every little plot in the garden soon
514	had its owner.  A regular menagerie appeared in barn and shed, for pet
514	animals were allowed. And three times a day, Jo smiled at her Fritz
514	from the head of a long table lined on either side with rows of happy
514	young faces, which all turned to her with affectionate eyes, confiding
514	words, and grateful hearts, full of love for 'Mother Bhaer'.  She had
514	boys enough now, and did not tire of them, though they were not angels,
514	by any means, and some of them caused both Professor and Professorin
514	much trouble and anxiety.  But her faith in the good spot which exists
514	in the heart of the naughtiest, sauciest, most tantalizing little
514	ragamuffin gave her patience, skill, and in time success, for no mortal
514	boy could hold out long with Father Bhaer shining on him as
514	benevolently as the sun, and Mother Bhaer forgiving him seventy times
514	seven.  Very precious to Jo was the friendship of the lads, their
514	penitent sniffs and whispers after wrongdoing, their droll or touching
514	little confidences, their pleasant enthusiasms, hopes, and plans, even
514	their misfortunes, for they only endeared them to her all the more.
514	There were slow boys and bashful boys, feeble boys and riotous boys,
514	boys that lisped and boys that stuttered, one or two lame ones, and a
514	merry little quadroon, who could not be taken in elsewhere, but who was
514	welcome to the 'Bhaer-garten', though some people predicted that his
514	admission would ruin the school.
514	""
514	Yes, Jo was a very happy woman there, in spite of hard work, much
514	anxiety, and a perpetual racket.  She enjoyed it heartily and found the
514	applause of her boys more satisfying than any praise of the world, for
514	now she told no stories except to her flock of enthusiastic believers
514	and admirers.  As the years went on, two little lads of her own came to
514	increase her happiness--Rob, named for Grandpa, and Teddy, a
514	happy-go-lucky baby, who seemed to have inherited his papa's sunshiny
514	temper as well as his mother's lively spirit.  How they ever grew up
514	alive in that whirlpool of boys was a mystery to their grandma and
514	aunts, but they flourished like dandelions in spring, and their rough
514	nurses loved and served them well.
514	""
514	There were a great many holidays at Plumfield, and one of the most
514	delightful was the yearly apple-picking.  For then the Marches,
514	Laurences, Brookes and Bhaers turned out in full force and made a day
514	of it.  Five years after Jo's wedding, one of these fruitful festivals
514	occurred, a mellow October day, when the air was full of an
514	exhilarating freshness which made the spirits rise and the blood dance
514	healthily in the veins.  The old orchard wore its holiday attire.
514	Goldenrod and asters fringed the mossy walls. Grasshoppers skipped
514	briskly in the sere grass, and crickets chirped like fairy pipers at a
514	feast.  Squirrels were busy with their small harvesting.  Birds
514	twittered their adieux from the alders in the lane, and every tree
514	stood ready to send down its shower of red or yellow apples at the
514	first shake.  Everybody was there. Everybody laughed and sang, climbed
514	up and tumbled down.  Everybody declared that there never had been such
514	a perfect day or such a jolly set to enjoy it, and everyone gave
514	themselves up to the simple pleasures of the hour as freely as if there
514	were no such things as care or sorrow in the world.
514	""
514	Mr. March strolled placidly about, quoting Tusser, Cowley, and
514	Columella to Mr. Laurence, while enjoying...
514	""
514	The gentle apple's winey juice.
514	""
514	The Professor charged up and down the green aisles like a stout
514	Teutonic knight, with a pole for a lance, leading on the boys, who made
514	a hook and ladder company of themselves, and performed wonders in the
514	way of ground and lofty tumbling.  Laurie devoted himself to the little
514	ones, rode his small daughter in a bushel-basket, took Daisy up among
514	the bird's nests, and kept adventurous Rob from breaking his neck.
514	Mrs. March and Meg sat among the apple piles like a pair of Pomonas,
514	sorting the contributions that kept pouring in, while Amy with a
514	beautiful motherly expression in her face sketched the various groups,
514	and watched over one pale lad, who sat adoring her with his little
514	crutch beside him.
514	""
514	Jo was in her element that day, and rushed about, with her gown pinned
514	up, and her hat anywhere but on her head, and her baby tucked under her
514	arm, ready for any lively adventure which might turn up.  Little Teddy
514	bore a charmed life, for nothing ever happened to him, and Jo never
514	felt any anxiety when he was whisked up into a tree by one lad,
514	galloped off on the back of another, or supplied with sour russets by
514	his indulgent papa, who labored under the Germanic delusion that babies
514	could digest anything, from pickled cabbage to buttons, nails, and
514	their own small shoes.  She knew that little Ted would turn up again in
514	time, safe and rosy, dirty and serene, and she always received him back
514	with a hearty welcome, for Jo loved her babies tenderly.
514	""
514	At four o'clock a lull took place, and baskets remained empty, while
514	the apple pickers rested and compared rents and bruises.  Then Jo and
514	Meg, with a detachment of the bigger boys, set forth the supper on the
514	grass, for an out-of-door tea was always the crowning joy of the day.
514	The land literally flowed with milk and honey on such occasions, for
514	the lads were not required to sit at table, but allowed to partake of
514	refreshment as they liked--freedom being the sauce best beloved by the
514	boyish soul.  They availed themselves of the rare privilege to the
514	fullest extent, for some tried the pleasing experiment of drinking milk
514	while standing on their heads, others lent a charm to leapfrog by
514	eating pie in the pauses of the game, cookies were sown broadcast over
514	the field, and apple turnovers roosted in the trees like a new style of
514	bird.  The little girls had a private tea party, and Ted roved among
514	the edibles at his own sweet will.
514	""
514	When no one could eat any more, the Professor proposed the first
514	"regular toast, which was always drunk at such times--""Aunt March, God"
514	"bless her!""  A toast heartily given by the good man, who never forgot"
514	how much he owed her, and quietly drunk by the boys, who had been
514	taught to keep her memory green.
514	""
514	"""Now, Grandma's sixtieth birthday!  Long life to her, with three times"
514	"three!"""
514	""
514	That was given with a will, as you may well believe, and the cheering
514	once begun, it was hard to stop it.  Everybody's health was proposed,
514	from Mr. Laurence, who was considered their special patron, to the
514	astonished guinea pig, who had strayed from its proper sphere in search
514	of its young master.  Demi, as the oldest grandchild, then presented
514	the queen of the day with various gifts, so numerous that they were
514	transported to the festive scene in a wheelbarrow.  Funny presents,
514	some of them, but what would have been defects to other eyes were
514	ornaments to Grandma's--for the children's gifts were all their own.
514	Every stitch Daisy's patient little fingers had put into the
514	handkerchiefs she hemmed was better than embroidery to Mrs. March.
514	Demi's miracle of mechanical skill, though the cover wouldn't shut,
514	Rob's footstool had a wiggle in its uneven legs that she declared was
514	soothing, and no page of the costly book Amy's child gave her was so
514	"fair as that on which appeared in tipsy capitals, the words--""To dear"
514	"Grandma, from her little Beth."""
514	""
514	During the ceremony the boys had mysteriously disappeared, and when
514	Mrs. March had tried to thank her children, and broken down, while
514	Teddy wiped her eyes on his pinafore, the Professor suddenly began to
514	sing.  Then, from above him, voice after voice took up the words, and
514	from tree to tree echoed the music of the unseen choir, as the boys
514	sang with all their hearts the little song that Jo had written, Laurie
514	set to music, and the Professor trained his lads to give with the best
514	effect.  This was something altogether new, and it proved a grand
514	success, for Mrs. March couldn't get over her surprise, and insisted on
514	shaking hands with every one of the featherless birds, from tall Franz
514	and Emil to the little quadroon, who had the sweetest voice of all.
514	""
514	After this, the boys dispersed for a final lark, leaving Mrs. March and
514	her daughters under the festival tree.
514	""
514	"""I don't think I ever ought to call myself 'unlucky Jo' again, when my"
514	"greatest wish has been so beautifully gratified,"" said Mrs. Bhaer,"
514	taking Teddy's little fist out of the milk pitcher, in which he was
514	rapturously churning.
514	""
514	"""And yet your life is very different from the one you pictured so long"
514	"ago.  Do you remember our castles in the air?"" asked Amy, smiling as"
514	she watched Laurie and John playing cricket with the boys.
514	""
514	"""Dear fellows!  It does my heart good to see them forget business and"
514	"frolic for a day,"" answered Jo, who now spoke in a maternal way of all"
514	"mankind.  ""Yes, I remember, but the life I wanted then seems selfish,"
514	lonely, and cold to me now.  I haven't given up the hope that I may
514	write a good book yet, but I can wait, and I'm sure it will be all the
514	"better for such experiences and illustrations as these,"" and Jo pointed"
514	from the lively lads in the distance to her father, leaning on the
514	Professor's arm, as they walked to and fro in the sunshine, deep in one
514	of the conversations which both enjoyed so much, and then to her
514	mother, sitting enthroned among her daughters, with their children in
514	her lap and at her feet, as if all found help and happiness in the face
514	which never could grow old to them.
514	""
514	"""My castle was the most nearly realized of all.  I asked for splendid"
514	things, to be sure, but in my heart I knew I should be satisfied, if I
514	had a little home, and John, and some dear children like these.  I've
514	"got them all, thank God, and am the happiest woman in the world,"" and"
514	Meg laid her hand on her tall boy's head, with a face full of tender
514	and devout content.
514	""
514	"""My castle is very different from what I planned, but I would not alter"
514	it, though, like Jo, I don't relinquish all my artistic hopes, or
514	confine myself to helping others fulfill their dreams of beauty.  I've
514	begun to model a figure of baby, and Laurie says it is the best thing
514	I've ever done.  I think so, myself, and mean to do it in marble, so
514	that, whatever happens, I may at least keep the image of my little
514	"angel."""
514	""
514	As Amy spoke, a great tear dropped on the golden hair of the sleeping
514	child in her arms, for her one well-beloved daughter was a frail little
514	creature and the dread of losing her was the shadow over Amy's
514	sunshine.  This cross was doing much for both father and mother, for
514	one love and sorrow bound them closely together. Amy's nature was
514	growing sweeter, deeper, and more tender.  Laurie was growing more
514	serious, strong, and firm, and both were learning that beauty, youth,
514	good fortune, even love itself, cannot keep care and pain, loss and
514	sorrow, from the most blessed for ...
514	""
514	""
514	    Into each life some rain must fall,
514	    Some days must be dark and sad and dreary.
514	""
514	""
514	"""She is growing better, I am sure of it, my dear.  Don't despond, but"
514	"hope and keep happy,"" said Mrs. March, as tenderhearted Daisy stooped"
514	from her knee to lay her rosy cheek against her little cousin's pale
514	one.
514	""
514	"""I never ought to, while I have you to cheer me up, Marmee, and Laurie"
514	"to take more than half of every burden,"" replied Amy warmly.  ""He never"
514	lets me see his anxiety, but is so sweet and patient with me, so
514	devoted to Beth, and such a stay and comfort to me always that I can't
514	love him enough.  So, in spite of my one cross, I can say with Meg,
514	"'Thank God, I'm a happy woman.'"""
514	""
514	"""There's no need for me to say it, for everyone can see that I'm far"
514	"happier than I deserve,"" added Jo, glancing from her good husband to"
514	"her chubby children, tumbling on the grass beside her.  ""Fritz is"
514	getting gray and stout.  I'm growing as thin as a shadow, and am
514	thirty.  We never shall be rich, and Plumfield may burn up any night,
514	for that incorrigible Tommy Bangs will smoke sweet-fern cigars under
514	the bed-clothes, though he's set himself afire three times already.
514	But in spite of these unromantic facts, I have nothing to complain of,
514	and never was so jolly in my life.  Excuse the remark, but living among
514	"boys, I can't help using their expressions now and then."""
514	""
514	"""Yes, Jo, I think your harvest will be a good one,"" began Mrs. March,"
514	frightening away a big black cricket that was staring Teddy out of
514	countenance.
514	""
514	"""Not half so good as yours, Mother.  Here it is, and we never can thank"
514	"you enough for the patient sowing and reaping you have done,"" cried Jo,"
514	with the loving impetuosity which she never would outgrow.
514	""
514	"""I hope there will be more wheat and fewer tares every year,"" said Amy"
514	softly.
514	""
514	"""A large sheaf, but I know there's room in your heart for it, Marmee"
514	"dear,"" added Meg's tender voice."
514	""
514	Touched to the heart, Mrs. March could only stretch out her arms, as if
514	to gather children and grandchildren to herself, and say, with face and
514	voice full of motherly love, gratitude, and humility...
514	""
514	"""Oh, my girls, however long you may live, I never can wish you a"
514	"greater happiness than this!"""
